text: “The Struggle for Mastery in the Fertile Crescent” by Fouad Ajami (July 2014).  This is touted as a 68-page-long “paperback”.  Well, that’s stretching things a bit; calling this a “paperback” is being overly charitable.  There are only 51 pages of text, and given the size of this “paperback” (3.5” x 6”), I’d list it as more of a monograph (and really, $8.95 for this?).The author provides a very brief review of the Sunni-Shia battle throughout the Middle East.  But it’s just too brief.  He will mention the significance of some religious war-lord in Syria or Lebanon, but doesn’t provide any details about the number of soldiers in that war-lord’s army.  Nor does he provide any data regarding the financial strength of any war-lord.  So there is no way how one can measure the real strength of any of the characters listed by the author; few war-lords are actually named.The author noted that Iran (Shia) and Saudi Arabia (Sunni) are “in it for the long haul” in trying to influence the political powers in the Middle East, but doesn’t provide any data pertaining to finances or foot soldiers involved in the raging conflicts.There is no explanation as to why these two Islamic sects can’t reconcile.Despite any data regarding the various competing forces, the author’s review of the M.E. conflicts provides more insight about the competing actors than the usual prattle printed in most news-journal editorials.This booklet ignores detailing the political divisions of the 1980s Lebanese civil war, concentrating instead more on the 2010-2013 conflicts within Syria; but even there few names are detailed.The author doesn’t get much into the “whys” as to why some sub-conflict is happening, but his “generality” comments seem beneficial.  Doesn’t explain “why” Turkey or Iran so involved with Middle East issues.Despite its lack of depth in analyzing much of anything, this tract is definitely worth reading for its Arab author’s perspectives.

[Brief comments from a brief review by William Philpott in the 12-13 July 2014 “Wall Street J”, p.C10.)  “A Fatalist at War” (1927)  by Rudolf Binding.]  “A reserve cavalry officer, Binding fought largely on the Western Front, and he bears witness to its horrors… Binding comes across as both a Hun and a humanitarian.  He was not squeamish about executing Belgian civilians in 1914, while wringing his hands at the suffering of his own soldiers in the trenches…. His real-time experiences take the reader into the middle of that ‘stupid senseless brawl…’”

“Business Adventures” by John Brooks (orig hardback in 1969, Kindle e-book since 8 July 2014, and also in paperback), 360-400 pgs.Mr. Bill Gates ( a co-founder of Microsoft), opined that this “remains the best business book I’ve ever read” in the July 12-13, 2014 “Wall Street J.” (p. C3).It contains 12 chapters regarding various businesses (Xerox, Edsel/Ford, General Electric, Piggly Wiggly, Texas Gulf Sulphur, the 1962 Stock Market crash, Mr. David E. Lilienthal, the British Sterling Pound currency, and more) as they succeeded or failed to expand on some budding side-line in their company.As Mr. Gates commented: “Brooks’s work is a great reminder that the rules for running a strong business and creating value haven’t changed….. It doesn’t matter if you have a perfect product, production plan and marketing pitch; you’ll still need the right people to lead and implement those plans.”  In conclusion, Mr. Gates wrote:  “’Business Adventures’ is as much about the strengths and weaknesses of leaders in challenging circumstances as it is about the particulars of one business or another.  In that sense, it is still relevant not despite its age but because of it.  John Brooks’ work is really about human nature, which is why it has stood the test of time.”This book was recommended to Mr. Gates by his fellow card-playing aficionado: Mr. Warren Buffett [who also recommends “The Intelligent Investor” (1949) by Benjamin Graham]. [Disclaimer: I used to be a shuttle driver at Microsoft.]

“Living Hell: The Dark Side of the Civil War” by Michael Adams (May 2014).  I’ve read many books about the U.S. Civil war, almost all of which detailed how some Union or Rebel general maneuvered his units around some battlefield – including the fine relics by Bruce Catton. “Living Hell” is just about the first one I’ve read that really details what it was like to participate in a battle; from the time being fitted with a uniform, learning during basic training, then marching and fighting in a battle: of the shock in witnessing a buddy’s head being shot away by a cannon ball and watching the arterial blood shoot up into the air for a couple of feet, or watching someone receive a bullet through the head which forced blood to pop out his eye-balls and then squirt out in two steams through the empty sockets – before finally collapsing.And the stories of young soldiers who quickly tired of the thrill of war, to be replaced by the thrill of terror of not wanting to die any longer at such of a young  age for their country.  Then there are the burial details:  the gravediggers using long hooks to pull at smelly, rotting corpses into shallow trenches with a little dirt thrown atop – but washing away during a light rain, and then the farmer’s pigs and dogs eating exuberantly at the exposed remains.How generals on both side of the conflict had to deal with soldiers who fell away during marches to the next battlefield, how those stragglers who were deemed to be cowards were either hung or shot by their commanders -- even after listening to their pitiful pleas for mercy.And the author provided stories about how the wounded were treated after a battle, moved inside jostling horse-drawn field ambulance-wagons to aid stations were their fate usually met a quick but gristly amputation – maybe succored with some opium (which was scarce in the South).  Or so badly wounded they could not move, but could merely holler for help for several days in tall weeds before being found and given food and water – if feral pigs didn’t find them first and gnaw upon them.How to treat those who had both hands shot away, maybe they could be fitted with a bad prosthesis.  But how do you repair a damaged mind, either wounded by bullet or shell shocked by battle – how PTSD existed even then but wasn’t recognized -- except by being labeled instead as a slacker or coward?  Thousands upon tens of thousands of damaged bodies and scared minds.And stories of the young, harried female nurses who comforted the slowly but surely dying.  What of the justice that officers could resign their commissions and escape the next battle, but the drafted enlisted had to continue their mach to the next meat-grinding battle?  Anti-draft riots formed, but the war nonetheless continued.  And so much more!“Living Hell” is a highly recommended read, along with “The Aftermath of Battle" by Meg Thompson.

“Give Me A Fast Ship” by Tim McGrath (July 2014). [Partial comments from a review by Jonathan Jordan in the July 5-6  “Wall Street  J.”):  This book “sails smoothly in 13 roughly chronological chapters over the turbulent waters of 1775 to 1783”  …. Mr. McGrath’s prose betrays him as an avid fan of sailing adventure novels.  Readers will find his dry wit and eye for maritime life reminiscent of the late Patrick O’Brian’s .…  In the crew’s living quarters below decks, we learn, “bilge water, livestock, unwashed bodies, smoke and tar created an odor that defied description.”  …  It is rare for a one-volume work to fill the sails of personalities and battles separated from the modern reader by nearly two centuries, but “Give Me A Fast Ship” pulls it off beautifully.”[The author details the naval exploits of American ship commanders:  John Paul Jones, John Barry, Nicholas Biddle, Richard Dale, Alexander Murray & Edward Preble, amongst lesser-known buccaneers.  The author discusses the British attacks upon the colonial Atlantic seaports, reviews American vs. British naval engagements on the high seas, and notes how the naval war was finally taken to the British shore itself.]

“Judaism and Islam” by Stephan Hunt (Nov. 2010) in the series: "The Library of Essays on Sexuality and Religion”.Info from publisher:Contents: Introduction;Judaism: Part I Judaism and Sexuality: Exploring Historical Viewpoints: Are there any Jews in 'the history of sexuality'?, Daniel Boyarin; The Song of Songs and the Garden of Eden, Francis Landy; The One: God's unity and genderless divinity in Judaism, Hagar Lahav; Gender and sexuality in the Garden of Eden, Jerome Gellman; The hole in the sheet and other myths about sexuality and Judaism, David S. Ribner and Peggy J. Kleinplatz.Part II Judaism and Sexuality: the Traditional-Modernist Divide: Lived regulations, systemic attributions: menstrual separation and ritual immersion in the experience of Orthodox Jewish women, Tova Hartman and Naomi Marmon; Observance of the laws of family purity in modern-orthodox Judaism, Mark A. Guterman; Jewish women and sexuality, Judi Keshet-Orr; Of pearls and fish: an analysis of Jewish legal texts on sexuality and their significance for contemporary American Jewish movements, Rachel Sara Rosenthal; Homosexuality and the Orthodox Jewish community, Marc Angel, Hillel Goldberg and Pinchas Stolper.Islam: Part III Islam and Sexuality in Historical Context: She's upright: sexuality and obscenity in Islam, A.E. Souaiaia; Gender boundaries and sexual categories in the Arab world, As'ad AbuKhalil; The Sharia, Islamic family laws and international human rights law: examining the theory and practice of polygamy and talaq, Javaid Rehman; Islamic female sexuality and gender in modern feminist interpretation, Elizabeth Shlala Leo; Migration challenges views on sexuality, Nader Ahmadi.Part IV Islam and Sexuality in Global Perspective: 'He is your garment and you are his …': religious precepts, interpretations, and power relations in marital sexuality among Javanese Muslim women, Lily Zakiyah Munir; Sexuality in contemporary Arab society, Abdessamad Dialmy; Zina and the moral regulation of Pakistani women, Shahnaz Khan; Sexuality and the moral 'construction' of women in an Islamic society, Janet L. Bauer; Negotiating space with family and kin in identity construction: the narratives of British non-heterosexual Muslims, Andrew K.T. Yip; .... Name index.About the Editor: Stephen Hunt is Reader in Sociology at the University of the West of England, UK

"The Map Thief” by Michael Blanding (2014).  The earlier reviews have pretty well covered the plot of this book: a seller of old maps, who has fallen heavily into debt to pay for his lavish lifestyle, stole old maps from old books in old universities for re-sale to those who collect very, very expensive historical maps.Besides discussing how the thief was caught, the author adds much to this book by detailing some of the political shenanigans of early 16th Century cartographers:  drawing fictitious boundaries on New World maps to support their nation’s political goals of claiming larger swaths of land than what their explorers had actually discovered.Besides detailing the swashbuckling, good-time party-man, back-slapping personality of the map thief, this book could almost stand alone as a book discussing the historical development of maps regarding the New World.This isn’t a book about how to lay out strands of chain-links in how to map as a budding  land surveyor, but it is an informative look at the development of cartography of New World maps. Why, two books for the price of one!  An insight to the lack of security at many big-name libraries.The author was able to arrange only one meeting with the thief, before he clamed up for good  -- the author speculates that perhaps the thief didn't want to become liable for more prison time if he were to reveal that perhaps he hadn't been fully forthcoming in his admissions as to what more he might have purloined.  Although the thief admitted to stealing some 110+ maps, several librarians thought that he might have stolen more -- as many other maps disappeared from their libraries shortly after the thief had visited them.  A good enjoyable, interesting and informative read by a determined author who doggedly wrote a fine book.

Hmm, the ad stated that you can soak someone up to 38 feet away .... about the best I did was 15 even on the "single spray" selection.  When you switch it to the tri-spray mode, it takes a couple of pumping actions to get the water into the "wings" of the crossbow -- and they don't shoot as far.  It claims that it can hold 40 oz. of water, which seems to empty all too soon in the heat of soaking someone.  (Certainly hold more than the old handgun model I had 60 years ago!)  I would have liked a larger water-holding tank:  maybe something of a machine-gun drum on a crossbow -- although that would mess with historical accuracy. I don't think that the triple-squirting really adds that much.  The single spray seems to be enough to catch their attention.  I liked the handling of this soaker, and it is well built.  DO FOLLOW THE INITIAL SET-UP instructions!

“The Lion’s Gate” by Steven Pressfield (2014).  This book presents snippets of the personal combat stories of  100?, 125? (I can’t count them all), Israeli military personnel who served during the 5-10 June 1967 “Six Day War”.  These stories cover the various battlefronts: Gaza Strip, Sinai (Egypt), West Bank (Transjordan) & the Golan Heights (Syria).These stories include the exploits of infantrymen, tankers, sailors, helicopter & aircraft pilots – of all ranks. Some of the accounts are short, only a paragraph or two in length, with longer articles by those explaining some of the “big picture” insights of some campaign.Being in junior high school at in May 1967 in Oregon, I remember reading the newspapers and hearing on the media that Egypt’s Pres. Nasser had closed the sea-lane to southern Israel), how Israelis in Tel Aviv where digging protective ditches, and how it seemed that tiny Israel would soon be overwhelmed by menacing Arab armies.Once the “fog of war” had cleared on June 11, it was amazing to learn of Israel’s amazing war victory.  This book provides the intimate stories of Israeli military personnel who in lightly armoured vehicles attacked Egyptian units in the Sinai; engaged in hand-to-hand fighting while clearing enemy soldiers from houses in Arab-occupied Jerusalem; or flew planes hugging the ground to avoid Arab radar to make surprising raids on Egyptian airfields.There were a couple of short accounts as to how the Israeli upper commanders plotted their battle strategy – these were new accounts to me in learning how the commanders quickly reacted to new military threats as Jordan, then Syria, were hoodwinked by Nasser to join his failing battle strategy.One critic thought that there were too many “hurrah” hero stories here;  but that’s the way this war was fought: the Israelis were fighting for the life-or-death of their country; it required many acts of heroism of getting “up close” in order to engage well-entrenched Arab soldiers.  There are many accounts of high Israeli battlefield casualties, too.Perhaps someday some Arab historian can write a similar book from the Arab perspective (I’m not aware of anything currently available; if something like it exists -- hopefully they can be noted here in "comments").  Most of the brave Arab soldiers who would have a perceptive tale to tell died at their posts.Another worthy  similar, companion book is "The Battle for Jerusalem" by A. Rabinovich.

These are my favorite $10-$15 range of headphones, and I have gone through over 7 or 8 in this price range.They fit in my ears well, and provide good protection against ambient sound for this price range. The best part is they sound great for this range of headphones. The bass is good, but not overpowering, as well as the mids and highs.Overall if you need a cheap pair off in ear headphones that don't sound bad, this it your best bet. Received the item at a discounted price for my honest review.

These are comfortable, have good sound quality and base, and you can't beat the price! I even gave them to my friend to test and he gave it a thumbs up. I love these new earbuds and they have the new slit form ear pieces. They stay in place. The sound is good to very good.The earbuds look very durable. I wear them most of the time, and they are holding up great. Received the item at a discounted price for my honest review.

This facial cleanser is great, because it is organic, alcohol free, and free of parabens and sulfate. It's also cruelty free which is very important to me. It has a nice mild scent. This cleanser left my skin feeling refreshed and clean. It didn't dry my skin out like some cleansers to. I have very sensitive skin, and this cleanser didn't cause any reaction or redness. This products it stuffed full of great natural ingredients like rose hip oil which works to hydrate your skin, and of course vitamin E which has so many healing properties for your skin. I really liked this cleanser.I received this product for free for my honest unbiased review.

Overall, I like these earrings and they're worth the price (around 20$ when I bought them). I like the pear shape because it kind of sinks into your earlobe instead of a tall setting. The size is good--not too big, not to small. I also like the pear set because it's a little different than regular round.The only thing I'm a little disappointed with is that they don't sparkle as much as I thought they would from the pictures and other reviews. They sparkle when you hold them directly up to a light or look closely, but standing about 3 feet from the mirror in a well-lighted room, they look more glassy than sparkly. Of course I don't expect $20 cubic zirconia earrings to be as good as actual diamonds or Swarovski crystals, but I have other higher quality CZ jewelry that can sparkle from halfway across a room.All in all, though, these are very cute everyday wear earrings and I like them. Definitely having a good use....

I would highly recommend this to anyone and everyone.  I like to wear them for party wear, so no need for diamonds, just some amazing sparkle!Received at  a discounted price for my honest review.

I'm a loose leaf tea junkie and have all sorts of tea brewing and drinking paraphernalia, from mesh tea balls and disposable DIY tea bags/filters, to tea presses, one-cup tea baskets and pots with built in strainers. This is by far my favorite item for the following reasons:- Easy to clean- Easy to pack- Fits into my car's and outdoor folding chair's cup holder- Looks attractive (especially with the whole star anise pod floating in my favorite tea blend)- Keeps my tea warm- Big enough for a whole morning's worth of tea at my desk- Comfortable to hold temperature-wise even when the contents are piping hot- Love the glass interior--no metallic taste transfer, no reactive or toxic plastics-Remove the strainer at the bottom and perfect as a glass water bottleCons:- Not sure how it will hold when dropped, am scared that I will drop this one day and will break into piecesReceived the item at a discounted price for my honest review

I have dry skin and a lot of bb creams or foundations normally stick to those spots or dry my face out but this one does not! It has a slight sunscreeny smell but it isn't strong.Pros: Full coverage with natural look, buildable, light. Matches my tones.Cons: Needs a pump for dispensing. Needs darker tones.

I received this at no cost for my honest review. Here are my comments.1. I use this at the airport to keep track of my passports and iPhone 6. This looks nice and is very roomy. It measures 7.5 x 0.1 x 5.7 inches and has three compartments. In one I can easily fit two passports and in the other my iPhone 6. There is still plenty of room for a couple of pens for the family to fill out immigration forms.2. The strap is adjustable, but is still somewhat long even at its shortest length, though it's perfectly useable. No problem walking around the airport with this.3. Value for money, you would get similar models for around 25$, so this one works just as well.4. In comparison to Belt model I prefer the neck one as it is more easy just like my purse, but my man prefers the belt model. So it is basically personal preference.

I got this package and the instructions were pretty clear. As stated in the videos on the product website, it is better to install in the evening and leave it overnight to dry.I installed initially and the protector kept moving over the screen, even after waiting for 15 minutes. I ended up waiting for 45 minutes and then pressing the edges of the screen over the watch. One edge of the screen did not stick properly and I have to regularly press over it. I left the watch to dry overnight with the screen protector and except for the one edge, rest was fine.I would recommend this over any case as it is barely noticeable and does a good job protecting the watch screen. About two days after installing I was walking at work and the screen scraped a pillar. There were minor scratches on the protector and I am so glad to have it on the watch.

Bought this jacket for my toddler and it was a little big.But I loved the way it looks! Looks just like the picture.  I can't tell how warm it will keep you in the cooler months because I ordered in the summer time.

This is a well made waist trimmer. It is lightweight and comfortable to wear. It does not interfere with your normal movements.The wrap has some built in support for the back, however, the amount of stretch is minimal so there is less compression than if there was more elasticity. This is not a criticism, but it is something to take into a consideration depending on what you hope to accomplish by wearing it. The belt is held closed by Velcro, which seems to be of good quality.Sample provided for review.

Excellent product. I especially like the way it folds for carrying. You get two of these which is great!This float allows the water to surround you and let's you sunbathe without getting too hot. You can deflate the pillow and fold it to take it with you. It's very lightweight, but pretty durable. Received the item at a discounted price for my honest review.
They're accu-wedges all right... and they're cheap.  If you are buying them chances are you already have one and know what they do... these work fine.

This lock is better made than your typical TSA luggage locks, which often seem to be little more than junk.  I bought it in the hopes that the cable loop is longer than your typical cabled luggage lock and I wasn't disappointed.  I have the Master luggage/TSA lock and its not long enough to do the job I want... but this one has enough cable and more.Many cable style locks have a simple unlocking mechanism - dial the combo and press inwards on the cable at its base.  Cable slips free from latching to the outer edge of the lock housing.  Simple -- and cheap to manufacture.  Except its easy to operate holding it in your hand... but wrapped tightly and upside down on your luggage?  Not so much.  This lock has a push button to release the cable.  To me that one feature is worth the higher price of this lock.  The added cable length is a bonus.

If you remember the Kobalt Double Drive that hit the airwaves in advance of Christmas at Lowe's, this is the same as that ORIGINAL all-metal version that was later sold under the Master Mechanic brand name at True Value hardware stores.  The original Kobalt product that got all the media attention was replaced with an all-plastic revision that was much weaker.  Original metal versions sell now at online auctions for ridiculous prices.  Just buy this one and you are golden for a much lower cost.

My ARMS #22 mk1 QD scope rings fit loosely.  Actually they *looked* tight but I could tell by the tension on the lock lever they were loose.  A tug on the scope and sure enough they moved.  Would not withstand 223 recoil without losing zero.  Those ARMS rings are to say the least professional grade products, and that specific rig will work on numerous other rifles just fine and fit quite tightly... it ain't the rings' fault.If on the other hand you have rings or a mount where you can vary the attachment clamping force (ARMS Mk 2 rings, or just about any screw-down picatinny mount) then likely you can overcome the rail sizing issue with a few extra turns of the screw.  But if you have a QD product that depends on an in-spec rail then you'd better look elsewhere.On the plus side, it fits fine on my 1990's Colt A2 receiver, and I have no issues using the iron sights.  Fit is snug and I'm sure a little locktite will keep the thing snug.  I have other rings I can use with this so I'll keep it.

Amazon tells me I bought the last one of these I own (I have two) in April of 2011.  Thats over 4 1/2 years ago.  I have a very nice electric rice cooker ... that is buried in a cupboard.  I only use this microwave cooker.  Its perfect... once you know how to set it up and run it, so to speak.Worth noting up front:  There is no need to get your hand near anything that vents steam.  You can touch this cooker straight out of the microwave by using your bare fingertips on the two handles.  Look closely at vent placement on some other cookers.  Not all of them are so generous.  After removing the cooker from the microwave, you can flip up the two lid latches straightaway and quickly lift off the lid (there will be quite a steam cloud if you do this fresh out of the microwave, so exercise proper care and attention if you choose to open it up quickly).A key feature on the cooker is the vent at top.  I cook 1 cup of rice and 1 1/3 cups of water on high in an 1100 watt microwave in two steps.  The first is 5 minutes with the vent only very slightly open (one dot on each side of the vent open to the black underneath).  After 5 minutes, close the vent and nuke it for another 5 minutes.  By varying the venting you marshal the heat that is inside the cooker while ensuring it doesn't boil over and further all of your the water will not boil away.You can use the cooker as a storage container by simply putting the lid back on and tossing it into the fridge.Its easy to clean.  Don't be afraid to pry off the inner lid... I guess its a heat shield, underneath it is some black plastic widget and all three just need a quick wash and reassemble easily.There are no chemical smells associated with this cooker, although if you let the water boil away that could change.  It has no evil chemicals (BPA etc.) in its construction.If there's a starchy smell its because you didn't rinse the rice first and that has nothing to do with the cooker.

Bought one for a small project, and came back right after opening the box to order their 3-pack.  I'll put one in the trunk of each car to keep misc items from floating around.My project:  I needed to build a cheapie range cart for CMP/NRA high power club matches.  Bungee this crate to the base of a light folding hand truck and stack your goodies inside. On the line, use the crate as a rifle rest in the offhand phase.  Depending on your ejection arc it can also be a brass catcher during seated and prone.Regardless of the application, one of these crates attached to a light duty hand truck turns it into a heavy hauler.UPDATE (May 6 2015):  Its been a few months and I've had plenty of experience with these.  I am docking them two stars, to three from five.  The plastic on these is sturdy but its nothing like a real milk crate.  As a result I have seen the tops bend under what I would consider to be not-excessive load.  Stuff a few pounds of gear in one in a trunk and the thing bows outward over time.  That range cart I described?  I Midway heavy  duty shooting mat - only weighs a couple pounds - rolled up and sitting atop the forward edge causes it to bow outward.  And sitting or standing on it?  Don't do that like you would with a real milk crate.  They are worth the money but they are not as strong as real milk crates.

These sights are good for tinkering around, but after you are done playing around in the end (tinkering is fun and not a bad thing) you're very likely to be better off using a truly square-profile sight.These sights are a good learning tool to let you see what works and doesn't in terms of width.  My eyes told me very quickly that the 0.034 sizes were so small that my older eyes couldn't use them.  The 0.072 sights - both the ball and the square post - were the same width as stock so not much to be gained there unless I wanted to keep the 0.072 size and move to the ball.  I didn't.  There's a reason the military doesn't use that type of sight themselves and instead sticks to the square edges.  The 0.052 widths match up pretty well with the outer edges of match targets at high power events.  You learn real fast that there is an advantage in having a sight that appears to be just as wide as the black of the target - its real easy to see if you are centered, or not.But the 0.052 square post is not truly a square.  Its a little box on top of a bigger post.  That contributes - on my eyes at least - to a little bit more ghosting around the edges than I would get with a traditional post that is 0.052" wide top to bottom.So for matches, after experimenting with these I wound up going to a 0.062" match sight that ran me about $11 plus shipping.  I don't regret buying these.... they taught me some things about sights and sight picture in a match environment.  They were worth the money to me for that.  But they weren't suited to stay on the rifle.Lastly - note that these sights are quite a bit taller than stock versions.  This might be no big deal or a very bad thing for your style of shooting.  You won't know until you find you need to adjust the sight and it bottoms out well before you get to where you need to be zeroed into.  0.032 tall (according to another reviewer) is quite high.  If you are using an Improved Battlesight Zero or a Revised Improved Battlesight Zero (google it) these sights' increased height may actually help rather than hurt.

Short version:  This is a good product if you look at it as part of your backup strategy in an overall low light setup that includes optics.  But if you just want the best overall sight post there are other, better options.There are two ways to look at this sight with respect to rating its performance.  The first is as a generic black rifle sight post.  The second is to consider it as a tool dedicated to low light performance.  Unfortunately, unless you only need to patrol a cave or are invading one of the Earth's two poles you will have daylight to contend with, so you have to consider this sight against its less exotic counterparts.As an all around AR front sight post:  The Meprolight front sight post is effectively an M16A1 profile.  It has the round, tapering shape found on that Version 1.0 model.  Unfortunately the A2 replaced the A1 for a reason:  Sone of its improvements were to the sights and included a square front sight post with sharp edges for a clearer sight picture.  Its easy to see why Meprolight went to the earlier, less-effective design since the round sight allows them to rotate the outer shell to account for site adjustments.  However they COULD have had a rounded inner core with a square shell and given the consumer a better sight.This statement in the product description is, unfortunately, egregiously false:"This sight has a round front post, which is much narrower than the square post currently coming on the AR rifles. This thinner post gives more accuracy since it does not cover as great an area of the target at distances."This is a flat out misrepresentation.  The very widest of AR15/M16 sights are about 0.070" in width.  Usually 0.072".  This sight, if anything, is WIDER that the standard-issue sight.  Target or "national match" sights are typically 0.052" in width, and you can find intermediate sights in 0.062" at specialty match rifle outfitters, and 0.032" sights right here on Amazon.  Claiming that the Meprolight sight is narrower - and giving it the benefits of a match sight - is a patently false claim that deserves to be called out.Now, onto its use as a night sight:Its as good as they get.  Low light 'iron' sights are sub-optimal compared to a variety of options out there, not the least of which is co-witnessing thru a red dot where you can dial up or down brightness at will.  A decent, basic red dot can be had for about the price of this sight post, too.  However if your job is mission-critical then you've got an optic and you will also want your irons to be fully functional, and thats where this sight post's size comes into its own.  It may be fatter than a standard sight... but that is a *good* thing in low light conditions, where its unlikely you will be doing any long range target or bench shooting.Does it glow?  Yes.  Does it glow like a red dot sight?  Not even close.  These sights have been available for many years, and while they once were state of the art, that is no longer the case.  They remain the smallest, lightest and most fail-safe option, but they are far from the best performers and are barely holding onto the label of 'cheapest'.Worth mentioning:  The A1 profile is faithful right down to the need to use the 5-prong A1 sight adjustment tool (which most people don't have and many won't even know exists).  However an A1 tool will not work given the 2-piece nature of the sight.  Its no problem dealing with this.  I used a dental pick to depress the detent and then the sight spins around just fine with a standard A1 tool.  When its time to turn the glowing bit so it faces you a standard A1 tool works just fine for this.

Very warm.  Easily covers your ears completely.  Stays put the way you fold it.  Never has a mind of its own and flops over your eyes or similar.  Best of all its super soft and never scratchy no matter what.  I've got plenty of wool beanies with and without visors - including some fancy fine-weave Italian army surplus - that are great in theory but its only a matter of time before they get itchy.  The fancy stuff just takes longer to start bugging you.This beanie is the first I have ever worn that I forget I have on for an entire day.  I bought two more soon after the first.
An essential add-on.  Very well made.  Seals tight.  The thumb hole makes for a solid handle.  Usable with and without the straw attached.  Get this and you never have to actually open the jug.

This is, I believe, the lightest mildot scope on the market.  I also have the illuminated reticle version (I never use that feature) and my experience with that scope caused me to buy this one for a second rifle - a 10/22 Takedown.  Scope has clear glass and is easy to adjust.  The adjustable objective alters parallax right down to about 10 feet (seriously).  Great for general plinking and worked a treat for me at two 25-meter Appleseeds.  I've used it out to 200 yards, which is about as far as I can reliably lob a 22LR up a hillside and have it still register on the bottom mildot.

Its a simple product, well made that does its intended job.  What makes it noteworthy of a review are the little whatsits on the female plugs that easily allow you to lever off an attached plug.  Amazing that no one has thought of this before.  A nice, unobtrusive improvement to an otherwise established, longstanding plug design.

Extremely handy.  I travel frequently for long distances and this has 1) gotten the inverter off of its permanent place on my passenger seat and 2) eliminated my need to use a 2nd power outlet.  My shaver, ipod and phone can all be charged by this single device.  I also like the fact that, even though it sits in an enclosed space, it doesn't fire up an internal fan that whizzes annoyingly at me for hours on end.EDIT:  I found that the USB ports on this unit are unusually fast.  They charge at about double the speed of my other chargers on my Note 3.  Thats a nice spiff worth mentioning.
Used per Sadlak's recommendation to provide absolute solidity to their front picatinny sling rail on a walnut National Match stock and it worked an absolute treat.

Its a flat pouch... not much you can screw up there.  Its also made sturdily with heavy cloth.  The velcro backing is generous and effective.  So much for the good news.The molle webbing on the back is spaced *all* wrong.  Its impossible to interweave the straps to the pack, which is the point of molle attachment.  There are two horizontal straps on the back if this piece, and the first is directly at the very top... thus making them impossible to use.  The second set of horizontal strips are too far down.  What you wind up doing is looping under two sets of molle straps on your pack, then you can move underneath the last strap on this pouch.  But oh by the way that second horizontal strap is only secured at each end and the middle.  So the manufacturer found a way to make them nearly worthless as well.  Did I mention the vertical straps aren't spaced out quite right either, in terms of width apart?This is ok for morale patches on your kid's tactical school backpack, but its not suited to any serious application.

Its small.  Its sturdy.  Its cheap.  It can use a cheap AA battery (rechargeable or not) and using a AA for the power source its plenty bright.I bought three of these.  All were of comparable quality with no defects.  I tested two by loading each with Maha/Powerex 2700 mah batteries, standing them on their bottoms facing up and letting them provide light for the room until the batteries wore out.  The power lasted for two solid hours before it visibly began to fall off (fairly quickly).  During that time a touch test showed that there was no issue whatsoever with heat even directly touching the lens.The crenelated bezel is an affectation.  You won't be doing any hard work with it, but it does serve as a protector for the dome-shaped lens.  HOWEVER the crenelations are ALMOST as long as the height of the lens.  If you try to stand the light on its face (you can do that) the bulb center touches whatever surface you are standing the light on.  So while you can do it you are contacting the lens and over time that is bound to scratch it up.  All they have to do is make those little tabs a bit longer and the lens will be much better protected.The focus mechanism is simplistic - a simple slider moves the outer casing in and out which alters the lens focus to a pinpoint square (thats the shape of the LED itself) or a sharply defined, enlarging circle.  A scew-in/out mechanism would be nicer but of course this is a bargain-basement price so its hard to complain too loudly.  The mechanism has a nice detent and stays put so long as you don't bump it, but if you do it will change whatever the focus level is that you have chosen.The screw-on rear cap has an o-ring but I don't think I would want to drop this light in the water on purpose. Other reviewers have stated these lights aren't waterproof.Its a nice bright light that doesn't heat up, uses cheap batteries and is so small you can forget its in your pocket.  I'm buying a few more.EDIT:  So I bought two more.  They were the 1-mode versions rather than the 3-mode that switch between high, low and strobe.  I like the single-mode better.

These artificial-fiber brushes aren't as supple as your better-quality art brushes that use natural animal fur.  However they are dirt cheap and as such, that makes them suited for a lot of jobs you wouldn't want to trash your fancy sable brushes on.  In my case I use them for applying synthetic grease to metal parts that need careful application.  They also do a good job as dust-removers and whisk brushes for use inside of complex mechanisms.If I was still building model airplanes that required a fine level of detail and control, I wouldn't want to use these brushes - but for general use they are an excellent value.

Works perfectly as the 4th level on my Voodoo Tactical Level III pack.  The MOLLE straps were a nice design innovation that my fingertips appreciated.  Like all 5.11 items its expensive for what you get but on the other hand it is undeniably a quality piece, and whoever decided to make it a full 3 1/2 inches deep sealed the deal for me when I was considering other alternatives.

This is the most tenacious lubricating goo I have ever had the pleasure to use.  I used this as a compound to quiet down some squealing disc brakes and it worked beautifully.  Holds up great so far under rain and high heat (aggressively applied aftermarket racing-type brakes).

Outstanding product.  I originally bought the Caldwell adapter which is also a fine product... but its solid metal and puts a lot of weight at the end of the stock which is the last place you want to add a metal weight.  This largely hollow plastic part is perfectly sturdy but is also very light weight.  Mako typically makes smartly designed, high quality stuff, and this is another example of that.

Can't imagine why I'd buy a genuine Canon when this thing exists. It recycles quick, is easy on batteries, does really well on TTL exposure with both my Canon 60D and Canon 600D, and even has manual controls. It's got a hotshoe mount on the side in case you want to mount it as a remote slave. It's got a DC power input, nice bright focus assist...Seriously I cannot find anything to fault this item on. Even the build quality feels about 90% as good as the Canon stuff.
Good quality pipe. Has held together well for well over six months. It's certainly not a top of the line model but it gets the job done and actually looks quite nice.
I can't complain about a 100% success rate burning these things. I was kind of leery about buying them but I can tell you that I will be buying more in the future.

On the HX20V you do not get the proper battery meter like you do with the genuine Sony batteries. I do not fault the batteries though, it's likely Sony just being finicky with their technology like they always are. Sony is NOT a company that embraces third party stuff.That said these do hold a charge and definitely operate the camera, though I'd say the battery life is slightly less than the stock battery. (Again it's hard to tell since the battery meter doesn't work properly). It could even just be my imagination. The HX20V is a battery-burning beast. It tears through the stock battery pretty fast too so in reality they're probably right at about the same as far as longevity. For the price I'll gladly put up with not having the battery meter work right (it still shows time remaining, just doesn't have the little indicator bars).

I run a production company and though we've tried to get away from DVDs so that we can deliver content in HD there are still folks who insist on DVD and I'll say that these Verbatim discs are hands-down the best price-to-quality ratio out there. Extremely few bad burns, I'd say we're rocking at least a 95% success rate with these (it would be higher but I'm also counting the customers trying to use burned discs on super old players or other similar issues).

This is the quietest little air pump I've ever come across. Unless you're standing within a foot or so of it you can't really hear it. The bubbles coming up in the tank are easily 5x louder than the actual noise that it makes. It has some nice soft little rubber feet on the bottom so I'd imagine that as long as you don't place it on a surface that reverberates you shouldn't really be able to hear it.

Tough little sucker. It's fallen off of my mirror a few times into my bathtub (after sitting for weeks without re-moistening the suction cup) and it continues to work great. It's also got great audio cues to let you know when it turns on/turns off or a setting is adjusted. Connects flawlessly to all of my devices. A++

Extremely simple. Just place it into the tank, squeeze it a couple of times to get the air bubbles out (otherwise it will want to float) then just put it in the corner and turn the air pump on. Totally cleared up my little 5 gallon tank in a matter of hours. For the cost, effectiveness, reliability and ease of use I will never use anything else again. It creates a few bubbles that rise to the top and create a very gentle little outward current that I think my Betta fish likes.Talking to some aquarium pros in my area I see that sponge filters, although commonly overlooked, provide great filtration, are super quiet, and maintain beneficial bacterial growth. I paired this with the JW Pet Company Air Pump 200 and it's completely silent unless you put your ear to the pump. Great combo and super cheap!

While I liked the first book it didn't have time to do much character development. This book made up for that. This one, while it had some interesting action, was mostly about character development and I felt like I really got to know the people onboard the ship much better. The author also introduced an interesting new character that was not in the first book. Overall while I really liked the first book this one got me totally hooked on the series. Eagerly anticipating #3, which will finish off the current story arc.It took a little Googling but I found it and I am now following the author's website at www.mmoreau.net for more info on when it is coming out.

I am a fan of the old Andre Norton books, the Solar Queen series in particular, and was very excited to see someone carrying on the tradition. You won't find a lot of subtext in this book, it's all about the main action, and that makes for a fun read. It's a fairly short book, but a good introduction to this strange universe in which "rocketships" are the main mode of interstellar transportation and there are "martians" and "rayguns" and all of that. I enjoyed it so I bought the second one as well.

It works, the battery holds charge for a couple of hours or so but the resolution is not that great. In fact my camera's built-in LCD is MUCH sharper than this Lilliput. If I were using it just as a bigger screen to find focus I would return it but I use it mostly as an LCD for a jib so using the camera's built-in screen is not an option. If you're just looking for a monitor for a jib this won't disappoint, just don't expect ultra-high resolution image.

We purchased this to go on top of my daughter's 4th birthday cake. She loves Doctor Who and that is what she requested, a Doctor Who cake. After we got all of the frosting off of it we played with it a little bit. It does what it says, you pull it back and it moves forward and spins. I'd say though that it makes a better shelf decoration than a toy. It looks nice but the construction if cheap plastic so I'm not sure how long the motorized insides would last if you played with it constantly.

Some reviews say it's not real leather. It is, you can smell it right away. It's nice and supple but quite sturdy. The color is just like in the photo and it looks like a really high quality item. The stitching is very nicely done and the snaps hold well but don't feel like you're going to have to tug them until they break to get them free.Some commented that it's a bit long for the 10-30 kit lens, which is true but actually not if you've got it still in the "on" position. Yes I know, most of the time that you will have your camera in this case it will be turned off but if you're shuffling through a crowd and want to keep the camera protected (but still be able to take pictures fairly easily) you might button it up and leave the lens in the on (and therefore more extended) position. Taking a photo with the case still on is as simple as undoing the two side snaps and flipping the front of it out of the way.Again, I can't emphasize enough how this looks and feels like an item that costs easily 4 times what it goes for.

::Skip to bottom of review for quick setup help::Let me first point out that I have tried several other modem/router combos and none of them worked. By that I mean they literally did not work no matter how much I tried to get them to work. No connection whatsoever. I am not computer illiterate either, quite the opposite, I ran a computer repair shop for years, have done tech work for major IT corporations and am knowledgeable in just about every platform, operating system and network interface on the planet but most of these modem/router combos are just plain garbage.This one DOES take forever to boot up, especially on the first boot, but after that it's all good. It didn't come with a manual (and at first I was too lazy to look one up) so I had no idea what the wifi login/pass was from the get-go so after hooking it up to my cable input and calling Cox to register the modem with them I hooked it up to my laptop via ethernet and went through the config page to set up everything to my preferences. I did have to power it down and back up a couple of times before it gave all of my devices an IP address but now all is well and it's quite fast. With my old modem I was getting a maximum of 19.1Mbps but with this new docsis 3.0 device I'm getting over 31Mbps and that's over wifi! I haven't even tested it via ethernet yet. Overall I'd say it's a great modem for a great price. Comes with 4 ethernet ports and the wifi is very dependable (although it's not the strongest signal I've seen on a router).QUICK SETUP HELP1. Remove your old modem and/or router2. Power down any computers you plan on using with the new one3. Hook the cable input to it and power it up4. Call up the cable company and give them the Serial # and MAC Address of the modem (on the bottom)5. Go ahead and power it down again. Make sure all of your ethernet cables are hooked up and restart it. Give it a few minutes until all of the status lights are blue (internet icon stays green though).6. Power up your computers/devices and they should all have connectivity. Use one of them to access the setup page, type 192.168.0.1 (as opposed to the standard 192.168.1.1 that most routers use) into your browser's address bar and hit enter. Enter "admin" as the login and "password" as the password. This gives you access to the config page. Go ahead and visit the wifi configuration page and chance the network name (SSID) to whatever you want it to be called and set up a passkey that you can remember.Hope this helps.

The instructions are kinda long and complicated but here's the short version:-urinate on the little pad at the end of the stick, compare the color it turns to the color on the back of the bottle they come in-Shows the presence of ketones which indicate that your low-carb diet is working and that your body is now using fat as a fuel source instead of carbs.

Everyone that has given this product a bad review has done so because they expected to put EOS lenses onto their Nikon 1 and have the camera interface with it and autofocus and all of that. I have news for them, those types of adapters are very expensive (several hundred dollars). This is just a plain old "dumb" adapter that physically mounts the lens to the camera.Back in the day folks were used to manually focusing a camera and manually setting exposure settings, I guess now everyone is so spoiled to fancy electronics that they expected miracles. Fotodiox makes great products and I had to review this to bring up the overall rating because the other reviews are total nonsense. They're rating the adapter badly because the camera itself doesn't like being fitted with non-Nikon 1 lenses.If you buy this adapter expect to have to turn the focus ring and focus the camera yourself and also know something about photography so that you can expose your pictures correctly.Please folks, don't give products bad reviews because you didn't know what you were buying. This product works EXACTLY as described and is well made.

Most folks like reflectors but all of that collimating just turns me off. My AstroMaster is always ready to go in a minute's notice and where I live (southern Louisiana) that's important. Our weather is cloudy for a large portion of the year so when the sky does clear I don't have time to play around with aligning mirrors.This scope is plenty powerful enough to check out the moon in great detail, Jupiter (you can see the cloud bands) and Saturn (rings are visible). It is also fine for the larger and brighter Messier objects like M31 (Andromeda Galaxy) and M42 (Orion Nebula). I do suggest eventually getting the Celestron lens addon kit for it though as that opens up so many more options and the lenses are just a better quality.Lastly I will comment on the tripod. I am giving this scope a 5 star rating DESPITE the tripod. It's not that it's flimsy, it's fairly sturdy, but the clutch system makes it really hard to get it set onto a moving object and then to re-position when it moves. Honestly, I usually just mount this scope on top of one of my sturdy video tripods and it works even better. There are threads on the bottom of the scope's dovetail mount that allow you to mount it to a standard tripod and that wins lots of brownie points with me.

I am a professional wedding videographer and this is always my go-to tripod. It's light enough to easily carry around but large and sturdy enough to get the job done. They're also priced affordably so I always have at least two of these.

IF you have a particular type of stone (like I do) then it really works. Using this stuff I've gone from 7-8 kidney stones (on my last CT scan) to zero on my latest one. I passed a few of them (while they were still very tiny) and the last one was 7mm but I managed to pass it after melting it with Stone Breaker.While it's not guaranteed to work for you give it a try. My doctor swore it would not work but after downing a couple of bottles of lemon juice and several doses of Stone Breaker all of my stones are gone, he didn't know what to say. I love proving doctors wrong :)

For the price these go for they're really, really worth the money. Macro lenses are really expensive and if you're like me and only very rarely do macro stuff for a hobby then get these, skip the fancy macro lens. While I wouldn't suggest them for someone who does macro work frequently for a living for hobbyists these more than get the job done. With all of the different sections that you can add or remove to increase or decrease the distance of your lens from the body of the camera you can get an incredible combination of options for macro work. Highly recommended.

I loved the way the book was set up, how Ben and Fallon meet on November 9, which is a particularly difficult day with bad memories for Fallon. From there, they have a pretty natural chemistry and easy comfort in each other's company as they spend the rest of the day together before Fallon moves away that night to the other side of the country. Fallon is an aspiring actress and Ben is a writer. That definitely puts the heavy expectation on Ben that he has a way with words, and he really does. Agreeing to meet up every year on November 9 for the next five years without contact in between, Ben and Fallon part with the expectation of resuming their building friendship or relationship so that Ben can write a story. Ben also encourages Fallon to spread her wings and to venture out of her comfort zone. He genuinely wants her to take risks and to explore.I really loved Ben right away. He sees Fallon the person, a girl with great qualities whom anyone would be lucky to know. Fallon is likable, too. She's been through some experiences that have taught her tough life lessons which chipped away at her self-confidence. Every year they meet up, Ben and Fallon pick up right where they left off from the previous November 9. I was really fascinated by this part, how for one day of the year, they could keep moving forward because they don't live near each other or email or call or text one another for the other 364 days of the year. I mean, most people have events and people in their lives around them that consume them, but in this book, they both look forward to the one day in November and the focus of the book is on those days. While it's hard to ignore their obvious magnetic dynamic, there's still so much in terms of the everyday details that they don't know about one another.So yes, there are some surprising twists to the story that build up the angst and drama. If you are wanting to feel blindsided or sucker punched, then this will do it for you. While most of the emphasis is on Fallon developing as a character, with Ben's support, Ben himself also has his own personal obstacles. The bomb that drops after the first one, is the one that could not have been easily predicted, despite the very subtle clues. I think some readers might feel like either one of the twists really diminishes the quality of Ben's character and what he represented in the first half of the book, because I briefly contemplated that myself, but in the end, I chose to accept it at face value rather than think about it in that way. I still loved Ben and I think for those particular plot twists, Colleen Hoover weaved them well in terms of how it was navigated in the aftermath. But no, I wasn't happy about them because they made me feel too much - anger, betrayal, disappointment, etc. but I think you should also trust Colleen in redeeming him, too.I would have loved a little bit more in the end, but otherwise I read the book in one sitting, had moments where I laughed out loud and also where my heart raged or hurt for the characters, so I definitely recommend this one.

Exactly as described, this book has an over the top alpha hero and a virgin heroine. Paine is a mechanic and Penelope has brought her car in for repairs. Although Paine doesn't think someone like Penelope would ever spare him a second glance or even give him a chance, he can't help but want her. When instincts take over and Paine decides he wants to claim Penelope for himself, all bets are off regarding Penelope's family issues because Paine will do what he needs to in order to make her belong to him. It was an okay read overall with some sexy parts.

4.5 stars. Semper Fi is Sebastian Hunter's POV and retelling of The Education of Caroline, which takes place ten years after The Education of Sebastian. Sebastian as a 17 year old was always very sweet, giving, loving and even a bit nave and immature. As a 27 year old, he's been hardened by the military and heartbreak.Sebastian hasn't had the easiest of childhoods and Caroline was the one bright spot of his upbringing and then the love of his life as a teenager. When he thought he and Caroline were over forever, Sebastian became very reckless, with no clear direction or goal in life. His decision to join the Marines wasn't his own, he was forced to do so by his father, a person he held in contempt.While Sebastian has a tendency to be rash and hot-tempered, he has never been confused about his true feelings and desires when it comes to Caroline, that is probably the only thing he can see clearly in his life. Caro's insecurities had a lot to do with being independent and confident, and now she's an accomplished and self-established journalist. Sebastian's insecurities come from not having any particular talent or craft that he can be proud of and his feelings of inadequacy for not having gone to college or being worthy of someone like Caroline.What I have always loved about Sebastian is his heart, it's very pure and unconditional. He doesn't see the rest of the world when Caroline is in his focus because he recognizes her heart and that's all he needs or wants. This book is definitely for Sebastian fans because there's not a lot of new information compared to The Education of Caroline besides a front seat to Sebastian's thoughts, although the ending gives a little extra into the future. However, the proceeds for this book do go towards military charities so it's still worthwhile.

4-4.5 stars. If you love second chance romances, this one will not disappoint. Ten years after Evie walked away from Adam without anything beyond a note and annulment papers, Adam sees her again at a coffee shop. Imagine his surprise that she's right there in front of his eyes after thinking about her for so long and even trying to search for her.I really loved both Adam and Evie. Meeting them 10 years ago tells the story of how they met and became a couple leading up to the actual marriage. As teenagers, they were perfect for each other, there was no doubt that they belonged together and what they gave up to be with one another. Adam had never had a girlfriend before and Evie didn't have a lot of time to devote to a boyfriend, but they made it work because they were fully committed so it didn't feel rash or like a stretch when Adam proposed.Adam was abruptly abandoned and never got closure from Evie's departure after he gave her his heart. As angry and upset as Adam is, there's still unfinished business between them and in order to move on, he needs answers. Evie is really relatable. She was put between a rock and a hard place and now she's being confronted to dish out an explanation that she's afraid to reveal because if she thought she lost her love once and it broke her, she could lose him forever this time and be completely devastated. Their situation is complicated because no one comes out a winner and even if there's a possibility of reconciliation, will they be able to forgive and forget the past? Yet when they were apart, Adam and Evie were not living their lives fully. Still, what good is love if there's no trust?I really enjoyed the tension, the feels and the dialogue, certain parts really hurt, too. So much pain created from so much love on both sides. My heart broke for both of them, Adam for being in the dark and Evie for having to make a tough decision. I was able to predict the reason behind Evie's leaving ahead of time and understood where she was coming from. The ending felt just a teensy bit rushed, but otherwise, this is very well-written and I definitely recommend it. I also hope it's not too soon to request a story about Max someday.

4-4.5 stars. A lot more information is revealed in this installment and adds more depth to the characters, particularly Frankie and her own personal situation. Derek's history hasn't been completely laid out, but it's obvious that he cannot deviate from his agenda although having Frankie in his life makes him want to. I really enjoy seeing Derek try to deny how he really feels for Frankie when it's obvious that she's making him break all of his rules without her even purposely try to. I admired Derek even more after the revelation about his sister came out and Derek didn't even bother to pick sides between her or Frankie. He's determined to keep them both in his lives. While things are still as steamy as ever between Frankie and Derek, they also build more emotionally, too. The cliffhanger on this one isn't as intense as the first two, but I still need to keep reading to find out how the rest of the story transpires. People's true colors are coming out and it's not pretty on everyone.

4-4.5 stars. #TeamSilence. After meeting Dylan at the very beginning in More Than This, he has always been the quiet one, so when it came time for his story to be shared, I was really curious as to what kind of thoughts were running through his head. Not to mention that he's been present in every book since senior prom of high school and very little is known about him. What's different about Dylan is that although he went to college with everyone else, he left college when he enlisted in the Marines.Dylan is home on medical leave and living with his dad and brother, who are former military, too, so they understand Dylan, but at the same time, it's a household where very few emotions are shared. Dylan is the sort of guy who doesn't have much to say and prefers peace and quiet. He likes to work on cars and is a handyman. His best buds are Jake, Cameron and Logan, as well as Dave, who serves in his unit with him overseas. Dylan is the closest to Jake among all the guys, which made me love Dylan even more because Jake is my #1 More Than guy. Dylan also happens to be a complete mastermind when it comes to Operation Mayhem.While I absolutely love Dylan and Jay's writing, the heroine was just okay to me. I really didn't see what Dylan saw in her, particularly at the very start when she's not presented in the best light. And this has nothing to do with the fact of whom the heroine is - I'm completely indifferent as to whether she wound up being whom a lot of fans expected her to be vs someone else  - she just didn't compare to Kayla or Lucy for me. Dylan fell for her pretty quickly, and again, I missed the boat on what drew him in to her because she was initially devoid of personality given that she was too busy drowning in her sorrows. She didn't strike me as Dylan's type, not that he's had so many girlfriends to know, but I do know that he's faithful and devoted so once he makes a commitment, Dylan doesn't back out, ever. He's similar to Jake and Cam in that way, he's 100% all in. The heroine grew on me a little bit as the story progressed, but I couldn't completely invest in her. Still, it was important to me to see Dylan be happy and she was his happy place.A happy Dylan is a talkative Dylan. It's very entertaining to get to know him. The main characters obviously go through their own struggles, mostly battling with her issues initially and then Dylan's later on. They are stronger together and pull each other out of the darkness and silence. I loved the letters that were written and the way Dylan handled the heroine with such care and affection, but he also has a very macho and sexy side (gotta love Lucy for her extra comments about Dylan). The rest of the More Than gang show up and they are as lovable and funny as usual when they are all together, especially when they come to the heroine's side while Dylan is deployed. Dylan's and the heroine's family are also very likable, too. I'm sad that the series is over, I've enjoyed the whole cast of characters and watching them all grow up to find their own love and happiness, and definitely wouldn't mind to see more of them in the future.

Before reading this book, I was not a big Kayla Moore fan but I was intrigued by Lachlan McGregor. After reading this book, Kayla and Lachlan became my favorite couple of this whole series. Kayla is like the 5th wheel of her group of friends - Steph, Linden, Nicola and Bram. She sees how in love her friends are and secretly hopes to find something like that on her own so Kayla is taking a step back from her usual hook-up approach and biding her time.Lachlan, Linden and Bram's cousin, is in San Francisco to lend Bram a hand to help increase investments in Bram's apartment building for lower income families while recovering from a minor injury. Lachlan is a professional rugby player in Scotland and has a very closed off personality. Even Bram and Linden do not know many personal details about him other than that he has some hidden demons and to avoid angering or upsetting him. Kayla is really captivated by Lachlan right from the beginning when she meets him. Kayla, who typically comes off as confident, speaks her mind and is a reputed man-eater, is trying her hardest to keep her cool around Lachlan and not scare him off.Getting to know Kayla's real personality revealed so much more about her. She sees herself as someone with a black heart, but based on how Kayla interacts with her mother, that's not true at all. While she may have deterred Lachlan initially with some of the things she says, Kayla really does make an earnest effort to curb her bluntness and to see Lachlan for who he really is. Kayla's personal struggles include being seen for her true self because up until now, she doesn't put much passion or effort into anything she does, including her job. But being around Lachlan gives her renewed purpose, partly because she's attracted to him and wants his attention, but also because she wants meaning in her life and to be proud of herself.Lachlan is a complex guy. He is moody, quiet, doesn't like being around people or talking about his past and has a tender heart when it comes to stray dogs. The development of Kayla and Lachlan's relationship was gradual and seeing Lachlan lower his walls showed how much of his past he keeps buried, along with pain. I really loved the dynamic between the two of them. Even though they seemed like opposites on the outside, there was so much they could understand about each other. The way Kayla immediately forms a bond with Lachlan's dogs was endearing, as well as Lachlan himself in terms of the endless love and compassion he has for the dogs.The biggest obstacle between them is the fact that Lachlan lives in Scotland and Kayla lives in San Francisco. What would they have to give up to be together? Is what they have worth that sacrifice? Not to mention Lachlan's deep issues that are already too much for him to handle, let alone someone else. My favorite parts of this book were how much Lachlan and Kayla had to stretch out of their comfort zones for one another and how they supported the other person when no one else would. To me, this is definitely the best book of the series.

4-4.5 stars. Derek and Frankie have nearly sealed the deal on the contract between their businesses, where Frankie will be representing Derek and now Derek is pushing forward on sealing the deal with Frankie in a different way. Wow, Derek can really charm and seduce. He thinks he can only offer Frankie one night but he's been paying attention to all the details about her, too.Derek is the sort of guy who is dominating and needs to be in control. He has to call all of the shots and make the decisions and he's rapidly losing focus over his goals because he's so busy thinking about Frankie. As for Frankie, she's a bit unnerved by how much Derek affects her but decides that maybe she should just go ahead and indulge herself, however temporary it may be. They are combustible together.I really want to know more about both of their histories, particularly Derek's. That ending was an unexpected twist, but at the same time, I loved it and can't wait to find out more.

4-4.5 stars. Great start of novella series! Frankie Jordan is competing for a contract to represent architect Derek Block in his new apartment buildings. While Derek comes off very rugged, sexy, impassive and intense, he's very interested in Frankie. I really liked the both of them. Frankie is very hard working, committed and independent. She gives her best at her job and wants to take over her father's company. She's not ready to dive into a relationship, but Derek isn't offering, so maybe something purely physical is enough for now. However, if they are coworkers, that's crossing a line that cannot be uncrossed.Derek is preoccupied with his job and he's got certain goals to accomplish that cannot be derailed from. While he cannot ignore his attraction to Frankie, he's hoping to keep it under wraps and simply offer her something temporary to satisfy both of their needs.There's more to the storyline than just instant lust and I found myself becoming very interested in how things would play out between Derek and Frankie. They both have a past that plagues them - Derek is trying to bring justice to his and Frankie is trying to forget hers. I definitely want to read what happens next as the chemistry between them continues to build.

3.5-4 stars. Nine years ago, Zach and Violet were best friends in college who shared some intimate moments along with each other's souls through music and poetry. Then Zach broke Violet's heart and walked away. Zach went on to become a musician and songwriter while Violet became a novelist and poet. Now they are both in the same place again at the same time and it's apparent that those old, buried feelings are quickly resurfacing. The problem is that Violet doesn't trust Zach and Zach will do anything to prove to her that he won't be so careless with her heart this time around.The setup for the story was brilliant, two artists away on a retreat at the same vacation home, trying to find their muses within only to realize that the other person is their true muse. Violet is struggling because if she doesn't meet her deadline, she will lose a lot of money, but the distraction of Zach in the same house is just too much. As for Zach, he's looking for ways to convince Violet that he's changed and for the better, that they deserve a chance to be together.It was interesting to see how different they were from the past, but also from each other in the present and how they had to work through accepting those changes. While I was engaged in the story, I had a little bit of difficulty getting into the story and fully advocating for both characters. They definitely work better together as a team and Zach had his work cut out for him in convincing Violet of the same. There was so much of the past to let go and to forgive in order to move on. Katy Regnery does a great job of covering all those areas even though I didn't love this book as much as some of her others.

Cameron and Lucy might have just tied with my favorite couple in this series, which is Jake and Mikayla. Knowing Cam and Lucy from the other books, it would seem like the buildup to their relationship was a seamless and easy transition, but actually it is far from that. Cam is the guy who pulled Lucy out of the dark and had infinite patience with her at age 15 while she healed and began to smile again. Maybe Lucy didn't pay much attention to him at first, but Cam showed up everyday to help in whatever way he could, empathizing with her and being an extra set of hands to support her in her daily struggles while she looked after her brothers. As if it wasn't already big of Cam to assist Lucy, he's also like a big brother figure to her siblings.Before this book, Lucy came off as fun loving and free-spirited, plus who doesn't love the drunk version of Lucy when her lips start talking and saying whatever is on her mind? In More Than Forever, Lucy struggles a lot with so many things, but Cam is always right next to her, no questions asked. In return, Lucy believes in Cam's talent and wants him to go after his dreams. If there was ever a more devoted boyfriend, it would be Cam Gordon.Oh, how I loved Cam's mom, Heather, and her boyfriend Mark. They are just plain awesome as parental figures and I loved the dynamic between Cam and Mark. Lucy's dad, Tom, is also fantastic, too, once he gets his act together. Even though there's a serious undertone in this book, there were plenty of laugh out loud moments, too, that are beyond entertaining. The scenes with all of the More Than gang never fails to disappoint. Definitely looking forward to Dylan's book next.

4.5 stars. Another great book by BN Toler! Connor is being released from jail after 8 years for history of manslaughter and Demi is picking him up to take him home. Demi is Blake's widow and Connor is Blake's cousin, except Blake is no longer in the picture. Even though the reader doesn't get to meet Blake, it's pretty obvious what a wonderful person Blake was and that he is not only a planner, but a perceptive judge of character. Because Blake vouches for Connor, Demi and the reader don't feel as judgmental of him despite his felon record. Once Connor steps into the book, it's becomes immediately apparent that Connor isn't a bad guy at all. I didn't just like Connor, I loved him.I really loved the dynamic between Demi and Connor. There's a bit of angst and sexual tension building up, along with the general white elephant in the room regarding Blake. The secondary characters are also well portrayed and I was equally invested in their stories, not just Demi and Connor. There's some unexpected surprises revealed along the way and I enjoyed unraveling these twists because it made the story unpredictable, but not in an unbelievable way. The passion, love and sacrifice, alongside with the determination for justice, really kept me on my toes and I would definitely like to see more of these characters in the future.

4.5 stars. Levi Beckford is Harley's best friend from Where We Belong. Laney Jacobs is Levi's true love from 8 years ago and now she's back in Missouri to win Levi's heart again. Laney and Levi went their separate ways because they had different paths to take. Levi never recovered because he had just professed something important to Laney while she dropped the bomb that she was moving.Laney always regretted not handling the situation differently and never strayed from loving him. Laney has a lot on her plate. She's reuniting with some old friends and her brother and she's got a life changing condition to deal with. Whether or not Levi accepts her back, Laney cannot live without knowing or regretting anymore. She makes every effort to show him how she really feels. Laney is a sweet girl with endless compassion. She thinks of others before her own self, but she's also determined and decides to start taking risks because tomorrow is not guaranteed.Levi is definitely resistant, and understandably so. But slowly, he begins to thaw and remember the Laney he fell in love with. I enjoyed seeing Levi transition from the guy who didn't become attached to anyone and simply survived to a guy who smiles and has purpose and something to look forward to everyday. When Laney tells Levi her secret, will Levi still be there to support and to accept her? Will Laney have finally gotten what she wanted after all this time only to lose it all in the end? Great story.

Grace and David knew each other as kids when they were neighbors. David rescued Grace when her house was on fire and Grace never forgot the boy who saved her, always dreaming of meeting up with him again someday. David often thought about Gracie, too, because she is the inspiration for him becoming a firefighter.Eighteen years later after the fire incident, David and Grace serendipitously cross paths and remember each other. David hasn't been looking for a serious relationship before but Grace makes him want to reconsider that. Grace is a little insecure about intimacy and has this way of rambling excessively when she's nervous. Regardless, they both have a natural and easy dynamic between each other because they already know the other person as they get reacquainted. David goes the extra mile to pull Grace out of her shell to let her be the confident and sexy woman he's attracted to.There's several references to 9/11, which is a thoughtful reminder to never forget and to honor all those who were lost at that time. When tragedy strikes again, David cannot be the knight in shining armor this time around. Does Grace have the strength to pick up the pieces for the both of them? What they go through is emotional and taxing. I really felt for Grace and David, because how does one navigate through something like that, knowing that things may not necessarily get better? Good story overall.

4.5 stars. Mia has decided to seek out Matt Quinn for his escort services. Quinn also happens to be her brother Harry's best friend. While he doesn't remember the specifics of meeting her years ago because he was drunk at the time, he left a memorable impression on Mia. She's moved back into town and is starting her new job and life and ready to take the plunge in physical intimacy.Mia used to be overweight and her dating experiences were extremely limited. Figuring that Quinn can be her first sexual partner to show her the ropes gives Mia the confidence to move forward. Not to mention that she has a crush on him, too. Initially, they only communicate via email or text message, but eventually progress to phone calls before their first face to face interaction.
