Mia comes off sassy to her brother and confident and fearless at work. But on the inside, she is insecure when it comes to anything intimate.I really loved Quinn. He's high in demand and he gives as good as he gets if not more, but he's become increasingly detached from his job. Forming a friendship with Mia prior to meeting her offers him something new, the opportunity to really get to know a client as a true friend with whom he can share his most honest thoughts with. What I adored about him was how much he enjoyed getting to know Mia as a person and he hadn't even seen her yet, but he wasn't ever focusing on her would-be appearance regardless.When they are together, Quinn and Mia fit with one another like 2 pieces of a puzzle. Now that they've met and Quinn has provided his services, do they continue to remain friends? What about when Quinn finds out who Mia's brother really is? Is Mia just a client whom he can let go or would Quinn consider changing his ways for her?

4.5 stars. Whoa, this book was angsty and made my chest hurt. I'm still trying to figure out my thoughts towards Emilia because she is the one who has all the hang ups and internal freak outs. Emilia lost both of her parents by the age of 12, they had the kind of love that made them whole, but destroyed them when one couldn't live without the other. Emilia decides that she could never allow herself to fall in love like that because it only devastates and ruins, where there's nothing left afterwards and having dealt with heavy loss firsthand, she cannot endure that again.Instead, Emilia focuses on school and her career. Then she meets Weston Carter and immediately, there's sparks flying between them even though the first encounter is casual at best. Emilia's MO tends to be to ignore her feelings or to force herself not to feel them when they become too much. Poor Emilia, little does she know that it just doesn't work that way, especially when it's the one great love of her life. Weston is especially dangerous for her because he's a musician (like her father) and he's a player. Poor Weston, he doesn't know that Emilia has all these issues and he doesn't care because he knows that she is the one for him.So the storyline isn't new, but the way it was written gave it a fresh vibe. I absolutely loved and adored Weston. He prioritized Emilia above everything and that was his downfall. There's no doubt that Emilia loved him back, so when she made certain choices out of sacrifice, I couldn't completely hate her, but I'm positive a lot of readers will and it doesn't stop from there. Don't get me wrong, I definitely hated her choices, she continued to let things spiral downward to the point of no return or irreparable damage. Yet, being in her head, I recognized her fears and how much they paralyzed her, even though they absolutely do not justify her actions. Emilia is a runner and until she can stop backing away from difficult situations and using deception in its place, she won't ever be happy. The people who love her wind up hurt repeatedly and no one escapes unscathed. After sinking down so low, will Emilia be able to climb back up? And will she finally fight for what she wants and eventually deserve?As for that emotional bomb of an ending, I'm really hoping the next book comes out sooner than later.

4.5 stars. Evelyn and Devon met in college. Although their first encounter was memorable, the second time they meet, Devon is dating Evelyn's best friend Olivia. From there, Evelyn stays on the sidelines while Olivia and Devon continue a relationship that results in marriage. But now Olivia is gone and it's just Devon and Evelyn again. Will they finally have their chance to be together?The blurb of this book drew me in because I didn't know how to feel about this plot, but I knew I wanted to find out more. I couldn't deny my curiosity, knowing there was more to the story. Devon and Evelyn are definitely attracted to each other, even when Olivia is around, but Evelyn buried it deep so not to interfere and remained the supportive best friend. I could feel the unresolved tension and angst between them and wondered how things would have played out if Olivia had not been in the picture. I also needed to know if Devon truly loved Evelyn or if she was a second choice to Olivia.Because this is Evelyn's story, I have to admit that I didn't care for Olivia. While Evelyn loved Olivia to the end of the earth and vice versa, I could not bring myself to tolerate Olivia even a little bit, dead or alive. Olivia was a barrier between Evelyn and Devon, before and after. Olivia isn't a villain, but I disliked her anyway.What I really loved about this story was Evelyn's journey. She gave up so much of herself for Olivia and to Devon after Olivia's passing. While she is generous with her time and love, Evelyn is very guarded with her heart and has a tendency to run away when things become uncomfortable or confrontational. She has endless compassion and understanding. What Evelyn doesn't have is a solid grasp of herself. She doesn't know who she is independently of her friends or what she truly wants in life. She's spent so many years devoted to the needs of others, and lost in her feelings, while watching Devon and Olivia live the life she wanted.Devon himself is a good guy. I really liked him a lot. He has the best intentions and his heart is in the right place. I wasn't sure he deserved Evelyn, though, unless he could prove that he saw her independently of Olivia and pursued her appropriately. The circumstances of their relationship was precarious because of the unique dynamics and the ball seemed to be in Evelyn's court so I wondered what was the sign she was looking for to move forward.Then something happens and it becomes crystal clear to me, like it does to Evelyn, as to what her path should be and who she should be with. I loved the ending for this because it was absolutely perfect for Evelyn, to be worthy and wanted first and foremost. Once Evelyn embraced herself, she could allow herself to let someone in and to return that affection. The underlying message of the story speaks volumes so don't hesitate to read this if you think you know how it's going to end based on the blurb, because you might be surprised.

I love books with socially awkward heroes or heroines and Lev was exactly that. Mina is living on the streets, desperate for her next meal when she meets Lev, who catches her stealing. Lev comes off as apathetic, precise, quiet and impassive. But from his first encounter with Mina, she strikes a deep chord somewhere within him and he offers to help her. I was a fan of both Lev and Mina immediately. Lev may not be good with feelings or social cues, but he can be intuitive and considerate with the people he cares about. While he may not offer up much in the way of conversation or affection, he does provide loyalty and protection, especially when it comes to Mina. He's very direct in his words and even though he thinks he is incapable of love, it's apparent in Mina's observations that Lev is far from cold-hearted.Mina herself is a fun character. She possesses a certain innocence about her, but she isn't entirely clueless. She's perceptive and compassionate. She appreciates any kind gesture towards her and she also understands the value of good friends and family. Although she is attracted to Lev, their relationship starts out as strictly friendship and it's very sweet and endearing in the way they interact with one another because they seem to understand one another in a way that others do not. Mina isn't looking for a relationship because she has to get her life back on track and Lev simply doesn't do relationships for obvious reasons. However, they are injected into each other's lives so everything becomes intertwined and that comfort they find in one another's presence continues to grow.The development of their relationship, along with Mina and the other characters that are part of Lev's life is at a natural pace and I enjoyed all the different dynamics. There were several times where I laughed out loud by something one of the characters would say, but there were other times when my heart squeezed, too. The cast of secondary characters is great, and I can tell that they have some interesting stories coming up ahead, which I look forward to. Mina came into the story with nothing to lose but now that she's a part of Lev's life, she has everything to lose if Lev doesn't want her to stay. For a guy who doesn't believe in or understand love, would Mina be the exception? I really loved that scene with Lev and the cue cards, definitely a unique one of its kind for something that often happens frequently in books. Fantastic story overall.

3.5-4 stars. Bryer Reid has a crush on her personal trainer, Nathan James. She hasn't had much luck with relationships and the last major one she had shattered her trust in men. Nathan is charming, seductive, serious and confident. He's also not someone who ties himself to women so even though he's very attracted to Bryer, he knows she's a commitment type of girl. But Bryer decides to kick it up a notch and take control of the situation by asking Nathan out and he agrees. From there, they start to spend time outside of the gym and really get to know each other.I liked Nathan and Bryer overall, they had great chemistry. It was interesting to see them both push themselves out of their comfort zones. Nathan wanted to romance Bryer rather than bed her and Bryer was not afraid to ask for what she wanted. There are other complicating matters, though, like Nathan's past that he has to reconcile and Bryer's past that she hasn't quite faced head-on. Also, a bit of suspense is thrown in, too, with surprises unraveling along the way.This is a good debut novel and storyline, but I had a hard time connecting with both Bryer and Nathan. However, I enjoyed seeing them develop as characters and am interested to see what happens next after that ending.

Marcus and Sophie move forward and both of them are baffled about the feelings that are involved. Marcus has never been in this situation before whereas Sophie is afraid this arrangement will be short-lived. Although she often opts for safe, Sophie is taking a risk with Marcus and it puts her on guard at all times. Marcus discovers that he likes the whole package of Sophie and not just the nighttime activities. I began to warm up to Marcus. While I understand where Sophie is coming from, I'm still trying to figure her out and why she is so hesitant and thinks so little of Marcus' intentions. He's never been a jerk or disrespectful towards her. Normally I would vouch for her to stay in her comfort zone, but since I'm becoming a Marcus fan, I would like to see Sophie throw caution to the wind. I'm interested to see how they continue to battle out their feelings for each other.

Sophie and Marcus are coworkers and Sophie is actually the one who initiates a hook-up with Marcus. Sophie is the supposed good girl persona while Marcus is the infamous playboy. While they seem like opposites on the outside, they are very compatible between the sheets and Marcus discovers that he enjoys Sophie's company. As for Sophie herself, she likes being with Marcus but she isn't ready to invest her heart into a relationship due to Marcus' reputation. I liked the dynamic between them because Sophie was the one who held all the cards and dictated how things would go and Marcus had no choice but to go along. However, I didn't feel like they were getting to know each other very well because they spent all their time sleeping together rather than having conversations about personal details so I didn't get to know them very well either. Even though Sophie is reluctant to open up, she's well aware of this game that she's playing and has to decide if she can trust Marcus with her heart. Will Marcus settle for being Sophie's fling or will he push her for more?

Bree Richards has been living in fear for the last decade. She doesn't have her full memory for the 5 days that she was abducted 10 years ago, but knows that danger still lurks out there. Michael Ryan, who participated in her capture, is being released from jail and Bree knows that Michael has the answers she is seeking so Bree decides to pursue him for the purposes of closure. Add in the FBI who are keeping tabs on Bree and a protective best friend who is searching for her and it becomes a suspenseful story filled with surprises while Bree travels with Michael because he might be the only one who can actually keep her safe.I really liked this storyline a lot. The characters were likable and the plot moved at a good pace. I couldn't predict what was going to happen next and Bree developed well as a character, balanced with revealing the real person inside of Michael. The flashbacks of Bree's memory were all pivotal and crucial in trying to piece together the puzzle as to who was after Bree. Michael surprised me in the best way and I loved that despite how bad his upbringing was, he wasn't a heartless person himself. The secondary characters, Jo and Agent Davis added a great dynamic to the complicated situation. However, this story could be additionally edited and/or formatted and some of the dialogue was a bit disjointed or immature, especially with regards to Bree. Otherwise, I definitely want to read the next book.

Makayla is one those adorable and awkward heroines who is impossible not to love because of the things she says and yet she's so caring and well-intentioned. She meets Max at an underground mixed-martial arts club because Max is one of the fighters. Even though everything about Max screams dominating, alpha and dangerous, there's a tender side of him that allows Makayla to set the pace when it comes to pursuing her.Both Max and Makayla have parts of the past that hold them back, but together, they are a fun and lovable couple. I enjoyed their banter and text message exchanges. This book is steamy, hilarious and entertaining overall.

4-4.5 stars. Both Tristan and Elizabeth are broken characters who are trying to move on with their lives. Well, Elizabeth is trying to move on for the sake of her daughter, but Tristan is at a stand still. Elizabeth meets Tristan by chance and their first encounter is awful, Tristan is not warm or receptive at all but Elizabeth sees a man who is hurting deeply. He continues to be cold and mean towards her afterwards. They are now neighbors, too, so it's difficult for them to completely avoid each other, not to mention the small town rumors buzzing around about Tristan and his unsavory character.This story was different in the sense that when Tristan and Elizabeth found each other, they weren't trying to develop a romantic relationship at all. They did, however, lean on one another to remember their previous relationships and to numb the pain. Elizabeth also sparked something in Tristan to pull himself out of his internal bubble. The relationship between Elizabeth's daughter, Emma, and Tristan is especially sweet and endearing.The emotions are heavy in this story and the dynamics between Elizabeth and Tristan continue to change and evolve. Can they have a future with each other if neither wants to let go of the past? And what happens when they discover that their paths are more linked than they realized? There's a little bit of a suspense element, too. Just when everything seems lost or out of grasp, can either of them find their way back to the light and into each other's arms and live in the present? I really liked the portrayal of both main characters and the balance in showcasing their grief and their struggles to believe in happiness again.

Absolutely love and adore Sebastian and Caroline. Their journey is full of obstacles and pain, but their love is so beautiful that it's impossible to not want to root for them to find a way to be together.

4.5 stars. The Education of Caroline takes place 10 years after The Education of Sebastian so Sebastian is no longer that seemingly young and innocent teenager he once was and his age isn't a barrier anymore. Where he used to be so thoughtful and caring and loving, he is now hardened and emotionally withdrawn. Sebastian and Caroline cross paths overseas while they are both on assignment, with Sebastian as a soldier and Caroline as a reporter. After a decade, neither of them have forgotten the other but so much has changed since then, they are different people now.I loved seeing Caroline being so independent and confident in herself now that she has made a living on her own and can stand on her own two feet. That's not to say that Caroline hasn't been lonely or struggled in her own ways, but she has accepted her life for what it is, both the mistakes and triumphs. Sebastian has risen through the military ranks and has also made a name for himself, now a multi-linguist and skilled soldier. Despite the divide in time and space, when they are together again, the strong connection between them hasn't dwindled. Sebastian is all man now and the growth in his character is obvious. Whereas Sebastian is impassive towards other people, Caroline is his weakness and while he was heartbroken for so long, he quickly realizes that he cannot survive without her and then glimpses of the old Sebastian, the sweet and tender and loving guy he once was, resurfaces.If things were difficult in the first book between them, they are not easier in the second book. The obstacles are different. They weren't worrying about their lives before, but now they do in a war zone. Sebastian has always had an unwavering faith in his love for Caroline, but now Caroline has to be the one to draw from her inner strength to help Sebastian pull through some dark times. I absolutely love both Sebastian and Caroline and needed to see them find their way back to each other and finally have the conclusion they deserved. Jane Harvey Berrick's writing is superb and even after I finished reading this, I still wanted more of them.

Sophie Tisdale is a college student who works in a coffee shop and fantasizes about a repeat customer named Luke. He is older, professional, super sexy and completely out of reach. They don't converse much other than for Sophie to take his order when he comes into the shop. But then they have an encounter in a different setting, at the gynecologist's office where Sophie is there for an examination and Luke is the examining doctor. Well, isn't that all kinds of awkward for Sophie!Sophie gives off a very young and innocent vibe, she is also funny and sweet, too. She is very serious about her college studies and has always put off having an intimate relationship because she doesn't want to repeat her mother's mistakes. Sophie can be mature in that respect, but given that Luke is older, Sophie does come off immature in comparison to him, but very age appropriate for herself. It was endearing on her, though, and Luke found himself drawn into that as well, no matter how hard he fought it.Luke is the sort of guy who likes to be in control and he's dominating. He's intelligent, confident and persistent. For someone who is so collected on the outside, Sophie gets under his skin. I really liked both Sophie and Luke. They had amazing chemistry and witty conversation. The way they navigated through their obstacles wasn't unlike what other couples deal with, although add in the age factor because they are at different stages in their lives, and Sophie is still trying to find her path towards the future while Luke wants to simply offer readily available solutions. Can they convince one another that there's more right than wrong between them? A cute and entertaining story overall.

4-4.5 stars. This is my favorite book in the series so far because of the Southern cowboy Cain. His voice is perfectly captured in his distinct thoughts and sayings, which is unlike any of the other characters so far. Cain has a big heart that is just waiting to love someone and he knew he was a goner from the first time he set eyes on Celia. From the previous books, it's obvious that Celia has walls up around her when it comes to anything romantic, but the reason why is unknown. The prologue pulls the reader in and sets the stage for discovering Celia's history.Celia is amazing at her job, she really cares about her patients and has infinite patience herself. She's very giving, compassionate and understanding. While she and Cain develop a friendship, Cain wants to push her for more because he can't deny his feelings but Celia keeps holding back with hesitation, explaining how unavailable she is. I thought Celia was emotionally unavailable, but it just so happens that there's so much more behind that statement. Celia was in love once many years ago and that love, while not the same anymore, is what she clings to and can't let go of.I admired Cain's tenacity in pushing through Celia's barriers but Celia is equally stubborn and won't relent, especially when she sees how much it hurts other people around her. I was actually really annoyed that her best friend Audrey was so unsupportive even though I knew why. Storms Over Secrets is angsty and charged with a vibe of longing and regret. I really empathized with Celia because she was stuck between a rock and a hard place and until she could find a way out, she couldn't be with Cain and he did what he needed to do in order to move on. There's a great message in this story about people who cannot be helped if they don't want to be helped to begin with. Seeking help is nerve wracking, letting other people in is scary, and baring one's vulnerabilities is frightening. Yet living on the side of the fear really isn't living at all and once that meaning is understood, a whole series of events begins to take place that sets things in motion in the right direction. I didn't expect Cain to be my favorite character so far but he is, especially with the way he is so devoted in his heart and how he will go to any length to help out the people he cares for the most. Great story.

Katie and Devin were best friends turned lovers growing up but then they had to go their separate ways. Katie has recently suffered a horrible ordeal and in the process of her recovery, is recommended to reach out to a soldier and the one she chooses is none other than Devin.I loved the correspondence communication between Katie and Devin. Because of their history, they didn't have to start with basic formalities and dove right into true and honest territory between them. The story alternates POVs between Katie and Devin. Katie has a lot of anger, frustration and grief that she is dealing with. She's overworking herself, extremely stubborn and she's numbing herself from any vulnerable emotions. Devin never forgot about Katie and when they reconnect, he sees this as an opportunity to prove to her that he still cares about her.Devin is overseas and gives a pretty good account of his life as a soldier. There's a lot of military descriptions (I had to look up some of the abbreviations or terms) and he has many fellow soldiers to keep track of in the book. I liked Devin a lot, he had a good heart and he was authentic in every way. He was also focused on his job and took his responsibilities very seriously.Katie had relatable qualities, but I couldn't quite relate to her fully. Still, I admired her for trying to overcome her issues so that she could move forward with her life. She really put in the effort to manage her roadblocks and to not mislead other people. I liked that after so many years, they could fall into such easy conversation again and that they still felt a strong connection with one another. While she wasn't sure about trusting Devin with her heart, she was open to resuming a friendship. If Devin wanted more and because tomorrow is never guaranteed, would Katie let him back in?I'm always in awe of the service and sacrifice provided by our military heroes, and Devin and his colleagues are no exception. If you like second chance romance with a military man and forgiveness being a big theme, then this book is for you.

4-4.5 stars. Such a fun read with quirky characters. Indy Savage is a Rock Chick, the type of girl who attends concerts, lives out loud and has fun. She's also been in love with Lee Nightingale since she was 5 years old, but after repeated rejections, she has moved on and avoids him. However, Indy lands herself in a dangerous situation and the only person who can both help her and protect her is Lee himself. Lee takes it upon himself to use this circumstance to his advantage so that he can prove to Indy that he wants her after all. Will Indy allow herself to fall for Lee again?The humor in this book is well-written. Indy tells the story like it is, infused with her sarcasm and observations that are beyond entertaining. Indy's life is in danger, there's multiple shenanigans involving gun fire, kidnappings, explosions and car chases. While Indy takes it all in stride, she's not the sort of girl who simply follows directions and sits quietly while waiting for the excitement to die down. She cares a lot about her friends and family and is both free-spirited and an independent thinker.Lee is a definite alpha and he's also a scary bad boy, all the more reason for Indy to be attracted to him. I really liked both Lee and Indy, they had definite chemistry and Lee had his reasons for pushing Indy away early on. The secondary characters are also a lot of fun to read about, too. I am curious to find out what happens to the others in the rest of this series. Great book!

I love a good forbidden romance, and Sins of Sevin seemed to promise that kind of storyline. But keep in mind that this is written by Penelope Ward and her stories are not predictable. Nope, not at all. This isn't a light-hearted read, there's a whole heck of a lot of stuff that happens and it's angsty, page-turning, heartbreaking and puts the characters and readers through an emotional meat grinder. The story goes even deeper than what the blurb describes and really pushes the limits of love in multiple ways - true love, platonic love, friendship love, sibling love, parent-child love, sacrificial love, substitute love, redemptive love and unconditional love.I grew quite attached to the main characters, Sevin and Evangeline, but they are very flawed characters. Sevin grew up in a conservatively religious household after his dad remarried to his step-mom and has the opportunity to get out when an offer to court Elle comes along his way. Sevin is at an age where he is beginning to understand that there are serious consequences to his actions and that while he is easily tempted by so-called forbidden things, he accepts that but wants to earn his place in life and fulfill a purpose.Elle and Evangeline are sisters and their upbringing is also rather traditional and conservative, too. Elle and Evangeline are very different from each other. Elle is sweet, optimistic and upbeat. She is also very simple in a lot of ways and her goals and desires in life are basic. Evangeline is more of the black sheep in her family, much like Sevin was. She is free-spirited, honest and has big dreams beyond the blueprint of the future that her parents expect of her. The chemistry between Evangeline and Sevin is undeniable, they have so much in common and it's obvious that they are the better match. Both Evangeline and Sevin acknowledge their imperfections and internally make promises to themselves to be better people, which is what guides a lot of their big decisions, and treads into the dangerous territory of being selfless vs selfish because of the potential aftermath.I didn't expect this book to be as emotionally consuming as it was, but it was. I'm not sure what to make of the turn of the events because it's a lot to process all in one book. I really loved the first half of the book, and then the second half veers into resolving the unresolved issues and it's messy, complicated and gutting. So many times I just felt clobbered by what happens and kept hoping that the characters would hurry up and find peace or closure - it's very well written and everything is addressed, no stones are left unturned. Although the plot and events are fictional, there's a true element of realness to the characters, their experiences and their feelings that make it all come to life with the highs and lows and everything else in between. I won't be forgetting this story any time soon.

Josephine Keller is pursuing her dreams to make it big in NYC, coming from a small town in Texas. She discovers quickly that life in the Big Apple is tough but she's determined to make it work. She winds up working for Julian Lefray, and her boss is flirty, sexy and fun. Unlike the last 2 books by RS Grey that were coworker romances, Julian actually isn't a jerk towards Josephine. They become fast friends and the novel is told in dual POV. Josephine refuses to give into the mutual attraction because she depends on her job to pay the bills and can't afford to lose it over a casual fling. I really liked both Julian and Josephine. They have a good sense of humor, an easy and natural chemistry and they respected one another. This is not a high drama or angsty romance, but there's plenty of entertaining events that made me chuckle. Another fun book by RS Grey!

In the follow up to Sweet Addiction, Reese and Dylan are getting ready for their wedding and with only days left to go, they are busy with preparations and finalizing the details for the future. There's plenty of Reese and Dylan love in this one, and it's fun to see how enamored they are with each other and some flashbacks in the past. Reese is still as sexy as ever but also very protective and dominating, too. Dylan is still hilarious and she and Juls and Joey are a happy trio of best friends. Brooke, Juls' sister, comes to work for Dylan and she isn't as obnoxious as she seemed in the last book so I'm looking forward to reading her story next.Sweet Possession is fairly light-hearted and low angst and fun. I enjoyed have an extended novel about all the events leading up the nuptials and revisiting this enjoyable cast of characters.

Liam Westbury is returning to Beaumont for his best friend's funeral and to face the love of his life, Josie Preston, that he left 10 years ago. Instead of becoming an NFL athlete, Liam is a famous musician and instead of marrying Josie, he's unattached and never let anyone take her place in his heart. Having read Finding My Way, I knew what Liam was thinking and I think this was helpful for me to understand him and where he was coming from when he went home. Otherwise, I think I might have had a harder time empathizing with him or wondering why he did what he did because some of his explanations weren't as detailed as I needed them to be.In Finding My Way, Josie comes off real sweet and loving, but I also thought she was a little vapid in some ways. Given that her future changed course when Liam walked out, Josie's had to grow up in many ways over the last decade so the Josie in Forever My Girl is more mature and not quite so oblivious. Their first encounter after so many years is definitely interesting and charged. I had to respect Liam for giving Josie space, but part of me wanted him to fight harder for her rather than waiting for her to come around. Sure, he let her down and thinks he deserves her hatred, but I expected him to try to redeem himself with everything he had in him instead of simply focusing on the singular connection that he has with Josie, which ties them together forever. She was great about putting the needs of others first and trying to comprehend what Liam went through.Even though things re-developed at an appropriate pace, I think I was still waiting for grander gestures or overtures so that I knew they could move forward past all the hurts and things wound up wrapping up more rapidly towards the end. Great second chance story overall.

Liam Westbury has his future all planned out already. The only problem is Liam is not sure that he wants to go along with that road map because it isn't what he planned, it's what others expect of him. Finding My Way is told entirely in his POV and gives insight to how Liam Westbury became Liam Page during the 10 year period after graduating high school. There's no doubt that he loves Josie Preston and wants a future with her, but Liam is struggling internally with measuring up to expectations that he can't see for himself and even Josie is expecting him to fulfill his potential. Although Liam is a star athlete with NFL potential, he's interested in pursuing music. Understanding his home life and how smothered he felt definitely made me empathize with him on the choices he made, including the multiple screw ups along the way. He needed to be in charge of his future and to make his own decisions, even if it cost him the person he loved the most because he couldn't be the person she deserved if he didn't like who he was or what he was doing with his life. Admittedly, Josie comes off as the sweet and supportive girlfriend, but also a bit oblivious and a little too idealistic with the image of her future with Liam. I felt like the story got a lot more interesting once Liam gets out to Los Angeles because he's left his bubble of security into a cutthroat environment where there's no trust, and it opens up his eyes but also pushes him to pursue his talent while living real life experiences along the way. Even though this is book 4 in the Beaumont series, I read it first because I wanted the background about Liam before diving into Forever My Girl when Liam returns to Beaumont to face everyone he left behind.

Piper and Tanner have always been attracted to each other but were friends/neighbors growing up. Brad is Piper's twin and Tanner's best friend and he's always had the stronger bond to the two of them. While Brad may not be ready to accept the idea of his sister and best friend being a couple, they sure are. Piper is a little insecure when it comes to Tanner. She's realistic, logical and goal oriented. Only Tanner seems to scatter her emotions. As for Tanner, he's persistent, determined and motivated. He's also sexy and charming.Before Tanner and Piper have a real chance to get started, they are already over due to deception. Now, 2 years later, they are going to be in each other's presence at Brad's wedding. Tanner wants Piper to forgive him and let him have a second chance. As much as Piper would like to concede, she can't compromise her morals or integrity for what Tanner did.What Tanner did isn't nearly as bad as some other types of deception. Not to mention that Brad isn't without his own faults. He came off self-centered and while I'm sure he wasn't clueless about Tanner and Piper's feelings, he didn't help them out when they were both miserable and missing each other either. And not just because he was doing Piper a favor in a big brotherly way, but more like he was unhappy and didn't mind dragging the others down around him to share in the misery.Although it was a good story, I expected a bit more in terms of Piper and Tanner's relationship, especially in terms of their maturity 2 years later. While Tanner had a lot of great qualities, I didn't really get to know him in terms of his quirks or personal details aside from him being Olympic quality in athleticism, his loyalty as a friend and his seductive charm. I also felt like I didn't get to know Piper outside of her insecurities tied to Tanner besides being a little bit frosty and a tomboy. Otherwise, the plot was decent and I am curious to see what happens with Brad.

The premise and storyline was good. Auden is asked to tutor and interpret for Aleksandr, a minor league hockey player who is fluent in Russian. They meet by chance before they are paired up for their jobs and the sparks already begin to fly. Auden has multiple insecurities so she doesn't let people in easily and assumes Aleksandr is a ladies' man. The reason behind Auden's cold exterior has a lot to do with abandonment type issues and the lack of nurturing and affection while growing up.I struggled to get into this story and following the characters as they developed was also hard because I couldn't tell if they were actually staying true to their character while progressing. I couldn't feel the chemistry between Auden and Aleksandr nor could I empathize with Auden's pain from childhood. I didn't find her very relatable. While I liked Aleksandr, so many things about him seemed at odds with who he appeared to be on the outside and lacked believability. He didn't really let the reader in too deep about him internally except for what little he shared with Auden. When he started expressing his true emotions, it felt out of place.The surprises that popped up in the story weren't predictable in a good way and kept me wondering what would happen next. Otherwise, it fell a little flat with the character dynamics.
For something quick and dirty that's a bit over the top, this fits the bill of an older alpha male claiming a younger innocent female with multiple sexcapades.

4.5 stars. Best Laid Plans has two very interesting characters, Lily and Marc, and "interesting" is describing them mildly. Marc is a mercenary and is absolutely ruthless but also precise when it comes to doing his job. He doesn't have the time or interest in any type of entanglement. He lives for himself and loves his solitude. Lily is a transporter and although she may seem like a gorgeous and unassuming girl on the outside, she's no damsel in distress. Lily can kick a$$ with the best of them and one of the best is Marc. Although they are barely acquaintances who hook up for one night due to a mutual attraction, everything changes the following day when they are supposed to part ways - and the change is far from romantic.Marc believes Lily double crossed him and goes after her, intercepting her long awaited plan in the process. From there, it's a lot of fighting and distrust and just about all the bad words known in vocabulary. They are at an impasse because neither will yield and they both want the same thing, the diamonds in their possession, because those diamonds are a bargaining chip to somewhere else for someone else. Located in an exotic place with very little around them while fighting for survival, they have no choice but to tentatively depend on the other person. It's a fragile bond at best and recipe for catastrophe at worst.I enjoyed their business-like interaction with each other. Lily and Marc are not soft people with emotional hearts who exchange poetry. Lily is not to be underestimated. Even though she's not a trained assassin, she can fight without ever surrendering and keeps Marc on his toes. Marc may be a killer who doesn't blink over death, but Lily gives him a run for his money. Together, even in mutual disgust, they manage to work as a team to reach their destination. This book definitely packs excitement as far as not knowing what's going to happen next since a lot of what they deal with along the way is improvised.Marc reminds me a tiny bit of Tal and Jameson in certain parts, but he is most definitely his own character. He's rough around the edges, impassive, instinctive and goal oriented. He's also scary and dangerous, where he will act first and think later. While he seems unshakable, he has begrudging admiration for Lily because she won't back down no matter how threatening he is, and she's also very resourceful. I really enjoyed their dynamic. The progression of their relationship where emotions begin to trickle in felt very naturally paced and organic. Throughout the whole story, one of the major themes is deviating from the plan and just when I think they are going to stick with the plan, the story veers off in another direction again. Very entertaining story for action and suspense fans who like hardcore main characters that fight for survival to the end. Can't wait to read more about these characters.

Both Brody Madden and Jordan Elliot have something to prove to the world. Brody wants to be more than just a football player, he wants to earn the respect and admiration of his peers. Growing up with parents who didn't value his true talents and sneered at his lack of academic ambition, Brody focuses his energy on being recruited into pro football. He has a lot of pressure on his shoulders with very little support because he doesn't trust many people with his secret, especially since it's at odds with his reputation at school.Jordan Elliot has a lot to lose and everything to gain with her international scholarship to play soccer in her senior year of college. That means no distractions and aside from studying to keep up her grades, she has to practice, practice, practice. There's no time to socialize, much less worry or care about other people and that includes Brody Madden. Her brother Nicky in Australia is counting on her to succeed and Jordan refuses to let him down.Everything changes, include the goals of the game, when Brody and Jordan meet. Although they are both stellar athletes who can relate to each other in more ways than one, trying to juggle a potential relationship amidst everything else proves to be quite a challenge. Jordan isn't one to mince words or be superficial so Brody's intentions send her mixed signals because she's not sure she can allow herself to get involved with someone, especially since she's not an American and plans to return to Australia. I admired her intensity and dedication to soccer, but she also has a good sense of humor and isn't selfish or pretentious. Brody surprised me with how much vulnerability he was willing to show Jordan because I thought he would play up the arrogant and confident jock more than anything. This story has some great themes about redemption, being true to one's self, pursuing happiness and looking internally for the strength to overcome big obstacles. Sometimes I got a little confused by how fast the timeline was moving forward and there were parts that didn't flow as smoothly as I would have expected, but good story otherwise.

Very nice little case for your Galaxy S6 - very slim and stylish and it comes in 12 colors!  You can choose any color that matches and they are very nice cases, well made and sturdy.  The inside case attached to the wallet is very durable and hard so that it will keep your phone well protected.  There is a hole in the back for the camera and the hard case has all the necessary cutouts for your jacks and ports so you can keep the case closed and plug in the power cord :)  So go and grab the color you want now, get a few because they are inexpensive and then mix and match with your outfit :)  This is great for taking one item in someplace because it has the wallet area on the left side and room for a few cards and a pocket for cash.  I love the wallet cases, I don't even want the old style cases anymore!  And check out the photo of the inside of the case - it is awesome!  It is a nice tan suede with the company URL and insignia :)  Great deal, great value, great case!  I received a complimentary product in exchange for an honest review.

Just the name of this was enough to tempt me to try it!  When you think of Cashmere what comes to mind?  Silky, smooth, beautiful and soft for me - which is everything you want in a hair treatment.  This one is a no-drip solution and there are no nasty residues left over and the Moroccan Argan Oil is simply amazing in so many products but especially for hair.  I love to use it right after my shower - my hair dries fast because it is short and it gets oily too - but I have noticed that this treatment done every night has cut down on split ends, oil and it has really made my hair look sleek and yet soft at the same time.  I no longer use conditioners, just this.  I just take a few drops on my fingers and run it through my hair and just let it sink in while it dries :)  Definitely the best hair treatment I have ever come across - I have always had to use conditioners and not having to use them is such a great thing!  This does way more than any conditioner I have tried - so give it a whirl :)  Your hair will definitely thank you!!!  I received a complimentary product in exchange for an honest review.

Have you heard of Matcha Green Tea?  It has been hailed as an amazing weight-loss ingredient and is actually quite tasty in smoothies, ice cream and lots of other foods.  It helps with memory and concentration as well - there are SO many benefits to using this and it comes as a powder that you just mix in - so no prep needed just add it to whatever you are making and let it flavor your food :)I am not normally a tea-drinker but every once in a while I will try something new, so when I saw this it looked pretty good and looked into it a little bit, and it is all organic and the powder is ground from fine Japanese green tea leaves.  Matcha Green Tea is also what they used to use in traditional Japanese ceremonies although there are 2 varieties - the Ceremonial and the Culinary Grades!  And I have always loved the tea they serve in Japanese restaurants so I gave it a whirl!  It was really easy to make - I just boiled some water and poured the powder into my cup and stirred :)  I would liken this tea to a bold roast coffee as it is quite strong.  But the flavor is intense and has just a tiny bit of sweetness to it.  It is extremely smooth going down.  It was amazingly good and comforting.  I have not yet tried but I think it would be a good flavor to add like to a chai smoothie maybe or something similar?  This tea also has a lot less caffeine in it than a cup of coffee and if you want to keep it all organic you could add some soy milk and possibly some agave syrup to sweeten it up without adding too many calories :)Now I have never been to Japan and never went to a tea ceremony - but I have seen it on tv that they use powder for their tea and not tea bags.  So I assume this is the closest you can get to original Japanese tea without ordering from overseas.  I definitely recommend this brand, I was pretty impressed with it and it is not overly expensive which is a definite plus!  I received a complimentary product in exchange for an honest review.

I got this fan just in time - the hottest day of the year so far here in Indiana and my A/C in the apartment wasn't working - it was HOT.  I have asthma and it was terrible so I decided to get this fan out of the box and get it working.  I expected the same amount of air as my other stand fans but this one is amazing!  The three small rotating fans put out at least double the air as normal stand fans and because there are three of them in a row it puts out air on 2 levels more as well - so you get it on your feet, body and head area all at once.  I absolutely am in love with it and we have like 5 fans in our apartment right now and my daughter never notices them but as soon as she saw this fan she immediately went over to it and watched as her dress fluttered in the breeze :)  I love that it comes with a remote control too - I work online from my desk so I keep the fan at a little bit of a distance from me and I am always getting hot and turning it on then get cold to turn it off.  But with this fan I can sit at my desk and keep working, click the button and change the speed, rotation and everything :)  I LOVE THIS FAN!!!!  It is truly high quality and well-constructed and it is very stylish.  I would definitely recommend this to anyone looking for a good tower fan!  I received a complimentary product in exchange for an honest review.

This is an awesome little steamer that you can use for anything you want!  It's not good for just veggies, you can cook a LOT of foods in it like fish or chicken and steaming keeps the nutrients in food better than other methods so it's also healthier.  The two features I like best are that the steamer opens just far enough to fit whatever size pan you are using and I really like the holder with the ring in the middle that allows you to grab it without getting burned.  And being stainless steel it will not rust and you will be able to have this for a long time.  You can throw it in the dishwasher when done and the sink sprayer works great for getting anything in the holes out :)  Wonderful product highly recommend trying it for your cooking needs!  I received a complimentary product in exchange for an honest review.

So far I really like this series even though I am not normally a fan of novels with cowboys and cowgirls. But this isn't the normal western novel, it's a story about 3 alienated sisters who come back to the family ranch after their father's death and find out that in order to inherit the land they must all live together. Kate is the one daughter who stayed with their father and worked the ranch and she loves it. So the thought of losing what she has worked SO hard for is devastating for her and she fights to ensure her sisters stay. The whole sibling rivalry theme runs strong through this novel as the sisters start to warm to each other and their new lifestyle. Each sister has a different personality: Kate is strong and has a will of iron and will not back down from any challenge including the one her father gave her; Jenny is also strong-willed but she is a city girl so living on a ranch is NOT the life she had planned for herself; and Jenny is the soft-spoken one who doesn't like fighting and doesn't make waves. Jenny is still a country girl at heart and in some ways I got the impression that she missed life on the ranch. She may not have planned this life but she isn't fighting against it as Jenny is. While Mandy and Jenny are struggling to adjust, Kate is struggling to find out whether her father was murdered or actually committed suicide. She has suspects but will she and her sisters be able to figure out the mystery before they become the next victim? Very well-written novel and the characters really come to life and are so completely different but somehow start to come together. I am working on reading Book 2 so I can't wait to find out what happens!  I received a complimentary ebook in exchange for an honest review :)

I have never been a big one for taking selfies until recently.  And I could not figure out how people take such masterful pictures of themselves while holding the phone! This was an awesome book about friendship, betrayal, loss and ultimately finding yourself and letting go.  Taylor starts climbing the stairs after she is involved in an accident and we are to believe they are the stairs to her final resting place.  But with each step she takes we see a flashback from her former life - most of them involving her best friend Sunny who is both friend and foe for Taylor.  Taylor expects the steps to lead somewhere, that there will be an ending - but what will she find at the end of the steps - or will there even BE an end?  I really loved the way the author kept making the characters more complex with each story.  I went from liking certain characters to disliking them and then some I liked again by the time it all unfolds.  Highly recommend this book, it is definitely a page-turner and really makes you think about your own life and how you look at the world.  I received a complimentary ebook to review.

I love stories about different places and times and this has everything; nobility, intrigue, romance, mansions and most importantly a strong heroine that won't bow down to what her father wants and rails against tradition to make her own way in the world.  Even though Rhona's father is set on her marrying a rich laird but she isn't having it!  Instead she opts to go against her father and enters into an engagement with the dashing agent Charles Blackwood.  What follows after she leaves her home is a harrowing journey with twists and turns, loyalties and the ultimate disloyalty ... being betrayed by your own family.  But WHO is betraying Rhona?  You will have to read the book to find out - is it just one person or many?  And is Charles Blackwood the good guy that she has come to trust or just another one out to get her?  Bringing a British agent into the Scottish landscape really adds a great point of interest to the story :)  I really loved the Victorian England setting paired with the Scottish lifestyle and some of the humor that is mixed in.  The ending of the book sets up the next in the series very well and I have got to read Book #1 and Book #3 now because they all have one thing in common - strong sensible heroines and that is one thing that I really love in books!  This is definitely not your ordinary novel but I definitely got hooked on it and had a hard time putting it down :)  I received a complimentary ebook in exchange for an honest review :)

This is the third different MeasuPro BP monitor I have been able to test and I like it just as well as the others.  MeasuPro has something for everyone and they all work great.  This one is a smaller upper arm monitor and the machine itself is also smaller and easy to read.  It gives you a really nice large LCD screen that clearly states SYS, DIA, and PUL so you can get the results you need instantly and easily.  It also has the capacity to store 2 people's BP results as the other monitors do, you can keep up to 120 total readings so you can have 60 per person if more than one person uses it on a regular basis.  I like the cuff on this monitor - it is the perfect size - not too long and not too short.  It is also small so it's easy to store and comes with a nice carrying bag for traveling :)I had perfect BP until I turned 37 and all of a sudden it went downhill.  Now I have to be on meds and having this BP monitor is something I need to make sure my BP stays within the correct rates and the meds are working properly.  I love that it has space for 2 people - my daughter is 8 and has Williams syndrome - she had heart surgery at 3 months old.  So I like to try to take her BP every so often to make sure it is good.  This allows me to keep hers as well as my own separate readings.  I will definitely be using these BP monitors for a LONG time - they are great and I love having them at my fingertips when needed :)  I received a complimentary product in exchange for an honest review.

I love to have pure water but unfortunately in the city you don't always get that - and even though a case of bottles is not super expensive it adds up!  Especially when you are living on a budget and you can get water from the tap for nothing.  I like this because you can keep it right next to the sink and use it to make your water whenever you need it - you don't HAVE to have the filter working 24/7 - which in turn saves costs on filters.  It can be turned on and off easily so you don't have to let it work all the time.  I honestly wish I would have had this at my old place because the water there tasted and smelled horrible even with a water softener.  It filters out all the nasties in your water and I must say the taste of this water is amazing even compared to bottled water.  It is really easy to install - you can have someone install it by cutting a hole in your countertop OR you can just hook it up under the sink and keep it under there for use when you need it which is how I have been using it - but very easy and unique product :)  I received a complimentary product in exchange for an honest review.

My daughter still has a thing for binkies - she has Williams syndrome and is 8 so I am really trying to wean her from them - but she literally gets anxiety attacks when she can't find them :(  So finding a substitute for the binkies that she can wear and chew on it a must for me lately.  These necklaces and bracelets are perfect - she got all different colors and types from hard to softer and she really loves them!  I am thrilled with them, they haven't completely gotten her to give up the binkies yet but they are working for her during the day and the nice part is she can use them at school and wherever else we go and no one looks at her strangely or complains.  They look like real pieces of jewelry so they are awesome for any kid, especially ones who are into dress up because they think they are so beautiful!  They come in all different colors - I received 3 sets to try, I had 2 necklaces, 3 bracelets and 3 regular chewie toys in the shape of regular toys :)  I definitely recommend these for babies but they can also be great for kids like my daughter who are still teething at an older age or have sensory issues!  Check out all 3 links to get all the sets!  They are all BPA free and made of food grade silicone but you don't have to worry about the orthodontic problems associated with binkies and these contain NO chemicals and they are large enough for mom to wear them so they don't get lost if your baby likes to be held a lot :) I received a complimentary product to test.

The title of this book just gives me chills - I don't know why - but it is clear from the title and cover image that when you open this book it will not be your ordinary Victorian journey.  And it isn't.  What we get is a fantastical journey into the world of steampunk which is a fairly recent genre involving bots and Victoriana and imagination.  This book is different from the beginning though because it is NOT set in Victorian England, but in France.  So that sets it apart and I love that you can read the book and actually hear the accents in your head as they are speaking.  We get a chance to meet Marguerite, a girl who seemingly has everything - she is wealthy, privileged, has her own "maid-bot", and has the absolute best of everything including clothing and education.  She is extremely smart but in the beginning we see her as this "model" of girls during that period - she conforms but wants to break free and be herself.  When I first started reading I saw her as a very shallow girl and then watched her grow into this strong and independent woman by the end of the book.  Fantastic characterization from the author as you really get to KNOW the characters and almost build a relationship with them.  Madame Pomphart is actually a hilarious character in my mind - and she reminds me a lot of the teachers in Jane Eyre.  She is mean and it is hard to figure out whether she dislikes the lifestyle Marguerite lives; Marguerite herself; or is coming from a place of jealousy.  Marguerite is fairly naive about the larger world and she decides to follow the man she believes to be the love of her life Claude into that world.  But what comes next throws Marguerite into a whole new landscape of reality, fear and ultimately becoming an adult.  The title comes into play when she leaves because she seems like the normal rich girl but underneath she is something different - and that something will allow her to face the realities of the big world she has never seen and overcome her flaws to become the lady inside.  After reading this I REALLY want an Outil maid-bot of my own :)  The whole book is filled with the backdrop of the steampunk theme - automation, bots, innovation and more.  I had to laugh at the "automated koi".  It is something that seems like a dream world, but in reality is it something we would really want?  And I guess that is part of the question that Marguerite must ask herself and find the answer to.  Very intriguing novel, and definitely a steampunk staple if you are into that genre!!!!  I received a free ebook in exchange for an honest review.

I love power :)  Who doesn't?  Especially when your phone or tablet is dying and you are freaking out because you have a call you can't miss or that game you might lose because you can't play.  For me it's my phone because it's my only phone and my daughters iPad because it keeps her busy and she goes nuts when it dies on her.  So when we are in the car or out somewhere that we can't to a plug and we need power this is great!  I have about 5 power banks that I always keep charged, and I really love this one compared to most of them because it's bigger but still very light and it gives one full charge quickly without taking forever.  Plus it's easy because it doesn't have a long cord and so you can keep both the cube and your phone in your pocket or purse together while they charge.  Plus this is a universal device, it will work with any device that has a USB cord so for the Apple iPad Minis or just the mini-USB cords.  It will give one FULL charge and then will just need to be charged back up when you get home - the greatest part of this one is that it comes with it's own dock :)  I leave mine on the chargers and grab an go :)  Can't beat them for mobile power whenever you need it and no matter where you are!  I received a complimentary product to test.

WOW is what I have to say about this book so far and now I cannot wait to read the second part ... the complete and utterly shocking twist of events at the end of chapter thirteen is just stunning and then you don't find out why it is happening!  The first thing I noticed about this book is the juxtaposition of light and dark.  The rooms are totally white, they must keep them completely perfect with nothing to clean with.  Then the red blood they must give each day set against this stark and cold background - it has to be a set up for the ending but I haven't figured it out yet.  They call the parents Mother and Father, and then the girls are called by their room numbers instead of their names.  All of the twins start to almost become the other twin and yet Claire is holding out she seems to recognize that something is up but with her headaches and fear it is hard to stay inside herself.  I found myself wondering about the half butterfly with metric shapes in between chapters - does it mean that they are trying to make 2 twins into 1 person?  It seems that way.  But it also shows the sterility of the whole book as well - everything MUST fit into these perfect little packages and yet they don't.  At least Claire doesn't.  Audrey seems like a very immature character compared to Claire in my opinion, but I loved the way the author brought Brayden into the picture and the way he metamorphosed - just like a butterfly.  Butterflies come out of a cocoon and then they live a short but beautiful life.  Is that what the twins are?  Butterflies who are destined to live short lives?  Will one but not the other survive?  What are they using the blood for and why does all the testing take such a toll on them?  I seriously cannot wait to find out - I read this all in less than an hour, I devoured the book!  It is a MUST-READ for anyone who likes suspense and paranormal and in the end what seems to be a dystopian universe.  I absolutely loved it :)  And the cliffhanger will have you literally holding your breath for about 2 minutes!  SUPERB!!!!

Helen loves her husband Tom but ever since she found out about needing a new heart she just has not been the same person.  Tired and lonely, she retreats into her own world which makes her husband upset and she expects him to be having an affair although surprisingly he is not.  Then a great doctor comes along - Dr Jack - and the find a donor for her and she embarks on an affair with Jack to find her own happiness.  Except for the fact that Tom still loves her and after she has the new heart he expects her to be just as she was before ... but she is not, she is changed and there is no going back.  And all the while she is falling in love with Jack and wants to leave Tom and build a new life but Marilyn, the mother of the young girl who died so that Helen could have her heart is following her around like a shadow watching Helen's every move.  She becomes one of the creepiest characters I have ever read in a book just because she keeps calling Helen by her daughters name and therefore begging the question if the reader believes that when an organ is transplanted does the donor received any of the former owners thoughts, ideas or wishes?  As Helen comes to resent her, Marilyn realizes that the heart went to someone who she believes is not worthy.  Losing Heart is truly a story of love, loss and the struggle for redemption and freedom.  I thoroughly enjoyed reading it, and it is an easy and quick read - I could not put it down and read it in one hour!  Helen is one of those heroines that you like but don't like, and you aren't sure whether you are rooting for Tom or Jack to win in the end.  The mother is really annoying and it's almost like she is inside Helen's head rather than a real person, like Helen is judging herself rather than being judged.  She knows what she is doing is wrong but she NEEDS it.  I was spellbound by this book, and it truly is a heartwarming and tragic story.  And the cover I think perfectly illustrates the theme of the book - the pomegranate once opened starts to lose the seeds just like once Helen's heart is opened she starts to lose herself.  But the question is can she FIND herself again?  I received a complimentary ebook to review.
Here is a quality product, worth every penny.  The construction is durable.  The ride is smooth and feels very close to the real thing.  Highly recommended product!

Messy Grace by Caleb Kaltenbach is an insider’s look at a pastor who has developed a deep and growing love for the LGBT community.  Pastor Kaltenbach has a unique perspective on this subject, as he grew up with parents who were gay.After revealing some of the details of his painful story, the author challenges the church to reach out to the LGBT community in practical ways.  What really stands out in this book is the balance between truth and grace.  Most churches and indeed, most Christians appear to land in one arena or the other.  Some professing Christians simply overlook the sin of homosexuality and give such people a pass.  Grace covers a multitude of sins.  Others, in an effort to be faithful to the Scriptures condemn the sin of homosexuality and alienate the LGBT community in the process.  The truth shall set you free.Kaltenbach argues for a radically different approach.  His aim is to see the church demonstrate grace to the LGBT community, but never at the expense of truth.  He challenges believers to love these people who struggle deeply with their sexual identity but without compromising biblical morality.I anticipate this book will stir up a hornet’s nest in the evangelical world.  It is a bold book.  It is a controversial book.  It will challenge conservative evangelicals.  Most important, it will reveal the heart of the Pharisee.May Christ-followers learn from Pastor Kaltenbach’s godly example.  More importantly, may they follow the example of Jesus by reaching out and befriending people in the LBGT community.  The recent Supreme Court decision, while disturbing and discouraging actually opened a huge door to Christians.  This door will enable followers of Jesus to demonstrate love to people who are created in the image of God; people created with dignity and a purpose.  Kaltenbach warns that such a move will prove costly.  Such a move will be messy.  But messy grace is the result of life-on-life relationships which are prompted by a desire to please our great God and sovereign king.  Messy grace is fueled by a deep desire to penetrate the nations with the gospel of Jesus Christ.I received this book free from the publisher.  I was not required to write a positive review.

Faith Alone by Thomas Schreiner is  much-needed treatment of the doctrine which was rediscovered during the days of the Protestant Reformation, namely, justification by faith alone.  The author makes it plain from the beginning that he does not intend to offer a comprehensive treatment of this doctrine.  Rather, he guides readers through a tour of the doctrine of justification.  The contours of this fascinating tour are informed by history, theology, and biblical/exegetical arguments.Dr. Schreiner is unique among theologians as he fairly represents opposing positions and graciously refutes them.  His stance toward Rome, in particular, is refreshing and sure to pose a challenge to Roman Catholic thought.Despite the gracious intent of the author, his arguments are robust and biblical.  His allegiance to the Sola Scriptura principle is evident throughout and his love for the doctrine of justification by faith alone is clear.I commend this work highly and expect it shall receive a wide reading.www.baldreformer.wordpress.com

The legacy of President Ronald Reagan is securely established in history. Liberals can scoff and moan but the fact remains; Ronald Wilson Reagan is one of the most influential Americans of all time. Indeed, Reagan is not only one of the loved and respected presidents in American history; he is also one of the most effective.Most books focus on the life of President Reagan and work hard to establish his presidential accomplishments. Craig Shirley's new masterpiece, Last Act: The Final Years and Emerging Legacy of Ronald Reagan takes a different approach. Shirley sets out to help readers see Reagan in a different light and in a different context. This book serves as a lens for Americans to view President Reagan in his post-presidential days, including the days which followed his diagnosis of Alzheimer’s disease.Last Act begins with President Reagan on his death bed. The author highlights Reagan’s life and legacy from different perspectives - including friends, family, and foes. One of the constant themes that weaves through the book is the deep and abiding love that America has for the 40th president of the United States.We would do well to listen to the words of Reagan's old arch nemesis, Senator Ted Kennedy who offered these fitting words, upon hearing of Reagan's death:He brought a special grace to the White House and the country in everything he did. We often disagreed on specific issues, but he had an undeniably unique capacity to inspire and move the Nation. On foreign policy, he will be honored as the President who won the cold war. It was more than the fact that he was a superb communicator. Some attributed at least part of his success to the fact that he was a superb communicator. Some attributed at least part of his success to the fact that he had been an actor. But his deepest convictions were matters of heart and mind and spirit, and on them, he was no actor at all.Last Act: The Final Years and Emerging Legacy of Ronald Reagan bears the marks of a book which is informed by thorough research and careful study. Craig Shirley should be commended for his clear writing and respect for the 40th president of the United States. Last Act is not only a tribute to one of the most beloved leaders in American history; it is a gift to the American people.The legacy of Ronald Wilson Reagan speaks for itself and will continue to reverberate throughout history. Antonin Scalia notes, “Ronald Reagan needs no one to sing his praises.” Justice Scalia may be on target. But the fact remains: History will not stand by in silence. The legacy of Ronald Reagan will endure for generations.I received this book free from the publisher.  I was not required to write a positive review.

He was a Augustinian monk, transformed by the sovereign grace of God. His newly regenerated heart beat with passion for Jesus. His mind was devoted to the sacred Scripture. This former Roman Catholic turned Protestant rebel was mightily used by God to influence a nation and eventually the whole world for the sake of Christ’s gospel.But one of the key themes in Luther’s life was the other love of his life, Katherina Von Bora. This fascinating love story emerges in Jody Hedlund’s new book, Luther and Katharina. This work of historical fiction captures the pathos of a woman who left the “safe” confines of the abbey. Safety was a relative term in the 16th century abbey, since the Roman Catholic church was plagued by corruption, heresy, abuse, and sexual sin.Luther and Katharina underscores the heavy works-based orientation among the faithful. At one point in the story, one of the former nuns asks with chagrin, “Do you ever wonder if we should have stayed?” “What if God is displeased with us? What if He’s punishing us for forsaking our vows?” She continues, “What if we’ve thrown away our best chance at salvation.” Such a sentiment not only characterized the church in the 16th century. It is still a part of the warp and woof of the Roman works-based system.Additionally, the book captures the tension between genders in a 16th century context. The author does a formidable job of fairly representing a male dominated culture, “without horns and without teeth,” as Luther might say.Hedlund is a colorful writer, with an ability to turn a phrase and guide the imagination of the reader in the right direction. She demonstrates a good working knowledge of Reformation culture, including the priesthood of believers, cardinal doctrines such as justification by faith, and the repudiation of celibacy.Luther and Katharina is a terrific historical read designed to awaken a thirst for authentic relationships which are grounded in gospel reality.Highly recommended!I received this book free from the publisher.  I was not required to write a positive review.

Some people love him; others hate him.  But one thing is certain about Bill O’Reilly.  The popular host of the O’Reilly Factor makes history interesting.  The “no-spin” Irish-American journalist began a series of killing books, with the publication of Killing Lincoln.  This effort was followed by Killing Kennedy, Killing Jesus, and Killing Patton.  O’Reilly’s latest offering, Killing Reagan has sparked a bit of controversy, since unlike the other characters, Reagan was not murdered.Readers will not be surprised that at the heart of this book is an insiders look at the assassination attempt of President Reagan.  The would be executioner, John Hinckley Jr. is rightly portrayed as a psycho-path drifter who will go to any length, including killing the President of the United States to impress the actress, Jodi Foster.But readers may be surprised at how O’Reilly portrays the President.  The author carefully paints a portrait of the 40th president and includes details that are making some readers uncomfortable and even upset.  Make no mistake: the king of no-spin in unwilling to leave any stone unturned in this book.Apart from some of the more controversial elements of the book, O’Reilly includes fascinating discussion about Reagan’s relationship with Nancy, staff members, Mikhail Gorbachev, and of course, the Iron Lady, Margaret Thatcher.This book will draw criticism from liberals.  But it will also invite the critical response of conservative who revere Ronald Reagan.  But it is clear that O’Reilly  writes as an unbiased journalist here.  He has no bone to pick. He has no axe to grind.  He merely desires a telling of the facts.  The end result is a fascinating read that ultimately honors the 40th President of the United States.  Killing Reagan is a memorial to one of America’s great leaders.  It is a vivid reminder of the importance of freedom.  This is the story of Ronald Wilson Reagan - patriot, promoter of liberty, and President of the United States of America.

Modern day readers in search of a thriller packed with action, intrigue, and espionage turn to authors like Daniel Silva, Vince Flynn, or Tom Clancy. Readers looking for historical drama may turn to Dan Brown or Bernard Cornwall. When I learned about the chance to read and review Mike Evans novel, The Columbus Code, I jumped at the opportunity. Initially, the book appeared promising and seemed to offer not only a good story but an inside look at the mysterious figure, Christopher Columbus. Unfortunately, the storyline in this book drags and the characters are not developed in a way the holds the attention of the reader. But the inability to hold the attention of the reader is not the greatest concern. The chief problem with The Columbus Code is the scanty discussion about the famous explorer. A small portion of the book is devoted to unwrapping the story of Columbus. Personally, I was disappointed with how The Columbus Code unfolded.I received this book free from the publisher.  I was not required to write a positive review.

They call him the "Wacko Bird."  Other words are often used to cruzdescribe the Senator from Texas: He's accused of being "extreme," "out of touch," "crazy," and  "arrogant."  The media has caricatured him as a right-wing lunatic.  The liberals in Congress have tried to discount him and marginalize him.After reading, A Time For Truth by Ted Cruz, I can say with confidence that the Senator is a man who means what he says and says what he means.  He is committed to conservative values and is willing to pay a personal price for standing up for those values.A Time For Truth is the story of an immigrant's son - a man who learned the value of hard work, honesty, and integrity at a young age.  It is the story of a Princeton graduate (cum laude) who walked away with an undergraduate degree in Public Policy.  Cruz went on to graduate magna cum laude from Harvard Law School.  The liberal law professor, Alan Dershowitz calls Cruz, "Off-the-charts brilliant."  Yet the Senator from Texas is portrayed as a "dummy" and an "extremist."A Time For Truth sets the record straight.  I have a sneaking suspicion that Senator Cruz will get the last laugh.  Time will tell if he has the right stuff to secure the Republican nomination for President of the United States.  But one thing is for certain: The Senator from Texas is unwilling to waver.  He is unwilling to back down.  He is unwilling to compromise his conservative principles.  The "wacko bird" is just getting started!

My introduction to Alex Kershaw took place several years ago as I spiespoured over his excellent book, The Longest Winter.  Kershaw is back again with another historical gem, Avenue of Spies.  The book chronicles the life and legacy of Sumner Jackson and his wife, Toquette.  These brave people joined the French in their pushback against the Third Reich during the heart of World War II.Kershaw is a master story teller who has a special gift for transporting readers into the heart of Paris, a city that was overtaken by Nazi thugs.  He carefully guides readers through the historical drama, noting the tragic turn of events for Mr. and Mrs. Jackson and their family.The author educates readers by helping them understand the worldview of Hitler's henchmen as well as those who fought against the Third Reich.  The attention to detail is breath-taking.  The scenes are memorable.  The heroic deeds of the Jackson's are sure to inspire readers.I heartily recommend Kershaw's excellent book, which is researched with precision and recounted in a thoughtful and memorable way.I received this book free from the publisher.  I was not required to write a positive review.

One thing that marked my childhood was hearing Billy Graham preach several times.  I saw him preach at the Kingdome in Seattle in 1976 to a capacity crowd, the largest crowd in the history of the infamous dome.  I saw him preach in Spokane as a teenager and saw him in his last Crusade in the Tacoma Dome in 1991.  I remember being impressed, even as a child with his boldness and courage in the pulpit - characteristics that never faded from the world-famous evangelist.Boldness and courage are two words that describe Dr. Graham's most recent offering, The Reason For My Hope.  After seventy years of ministry, the message remains the same.  The message is the simple gospel message that Christ came to die for sinners, securing forgiveness and eternal life for anyone who believes.Graham weaves personal stories and anecdotes throughout his gospel presentation.
