Color balance and exposure generally is good to great, and noise levels in the captured images are generally very low.The camera user interface remains largely unchanged from last year, except for the addition of Live Photos. This feature works by basically continuously capture a 12 fps video stream in the background when you turn on the camera. When you tap the shutter button to take a photo, the phone captures that image in time along with about 3 seconds of video before and after the shot. The result is a photo that when you press down using 3D Touch will come alive. Apple actually didn’t come up with this feature - HTC did it first back in early 2013 with the HTC One M7’s Zoe feature. It’s definitely very cool, but as always there are couple gotchas. First, the resulting “image” is basically a short video, and video clips take up a lot more space than a single photo. Apple was reluctant about how much additional space Live Photo would require. From my various Live Photo clips, it’s about 2 to 2.5 times a normal photo. That adds up quickly, especially if you have a 16GB phone. This was part of the reason why we went with the 64GB version. Second, it’s hard to make use of these proprietary short video clips, specifically in sharing. This was the main problem HTC ran into almost three years ago. Apple has a much, much bigger influence obviously, and I am cautiously optimistic that they will flex their muscles and get Live Photo support quickly with the major social media and other services. Time will tell, though.Still a bit sad that the 6S doesn’t have optical image stabilization like the 6S Plus. Electronic image stabilization is nice but I still prefer optical, especially for video.-Upgraded VideoFinally, 4K video! Okay, so it’s something that’s a bit of an overkill at the moment, since most people don’t have 4K TV sets yet. But it’s a nice feature to have and will futureproof the 6S as 4K TVs become more affordable and more common. Just be aware of the increased storage requirement for 4K video! I do like the improvement to the 1080p slow-motion video – now up to 120fps or twice as slow as before.-Faster CPU/GPUThe new A9 processor is very impressive, despite still being just a dual-core processor. Now clocked at up to ~1.8Ghz or so, which is a healthy 400Mhz jump from last year’s A8 at 1.4Ghz. The GPU performance is very impressive as well. I like Apple’s focus here – most apps are still single or double-threaded, and being among the fastest in performance-per-core is a good strategy vs piling on more cores every iteration. Fact of the matter is, a phone is severely limited by the compromise between battery life and heat dissipation. If I am going to do real work, I would prefer to use a powerful desktop or workstation.One added benefit with the improved A9 is the M9 coprocessor, which among other things allow for constant-on for Siri. This means you no longer have to be plugged in to trigger the “hey siri” voice command. Personally, I am not a big Siri user outside of messing around for fun. But if you rely on Siri heavily, this could be a big improvement.Also, finally Apple gave us 2GB of RAM! I believe this contributed equally if not more to the overall increased speed and smoothness in daily usage with the 6S. One GB RAM is just not enough anymore – hasn’t been for at least a year or two now.-Other Misc ImprovementsThere’s of course iOS 9, which adds a host of features and tweaks. Biggest thing for me personally was the claimed improvement in battery life. Other improvements include a faster Touch ID (I can definitely feel the difference, pretty much instantaneous log-in now) and tougher Gorilla glass and more robust aluminum chassis to prevent a repeat of “bend-gate” from last year. They all add up to a much more refined phone compared to the 6.Also, it appears Apple beefed up the seals in the 6s, and unofficial tests show that this phone will survive being dunked in water for a few minutes. Some are even saying up to 30 min or more. I personally haven’t tested it and will not be doing so for obvious reasons. But it’s good to know the added protection is there if I ever need it.POTENTIAL PROBLEMSWith a little bit over two weeks of daily usage, I haven’t encountered any major issues. There are two potential problems that I’d like to point out:1. Battery life – The 6S actually has a battery that’s about 100mah or ~5% smaller than last year’s 6. This is a bit disappointing for me. I understand the physical limitations with implementing 3D Touch, which required more space from other components. It’s just I am sure I am not alone when I say battery life is one of the few areas where we really need some improvement. Apple claims iOS 9 made up for the smaller battery, but just imagine if the 6S had a bigger battery, or even the same size as the 6. Regression is not good in this department, in my opinion.From my personal usage pattern, the 6S has more or less comparable battery life for light usage. But more intensive tasks like video, facebook, facetime, etc, I feel there’s a slightly decrease in overall battery life. Not enough to cause alarm, but just enough to take away from the otherwise refined experience.2. CPU Chip lottery – This is a fairly new development that came out over the past week. Basically, Apple had outsourced the production of the A9 chip to two companies, Samsung and Taiwan Semiconductor (TSMC). I won’t get into the technical details since that’s a whole other can of worm, but essentially the TSMC chip from informal testing has shown to give up to an extra two hours of battery life. That is not an insignificant difference. There are apps around that you can use to check your phone’s CPU. If your 6S has a N71MAP CPU, then it’s the better TSMC chip. If it’s N71AP, then it’s the inferior Samsung chip. Apple’s official statement as of today is that the difference is negligible. And maybe it is for some people. But as a tech enthusiast, it’s annoying and frustrating. Fortunately, we lucked out as both of our 6S’s are TSMC chips. If I got the Samsung chip, I actually would seriously consider asking for an exchange at the Apple Store.SUMMARYThe 6S is a very nice upgrade over last year’s 6. Refinement is the operative word here, which is what we expected from a S year model. If you have a 6 though, I am not sure if it’s worth the upgrade especially now with carriers doing away with subsidies. But if you’re coming from anything older, this is a great upgrade and should be good enough to last at least two years if not more.

1:20 Mins I’ve tried my share of phone mounts over the years – everything from simple air vent mounts to gooseneck and suction mounts. This Getron mount is definitely one of the best ones I’ve come across.DESIGN & OPERATIONThe mount came in two pieces. You have to completely loosen the knob on the tip of the neck near the ball joint socket before inserting the phone holder. I had it only somewhat loose at first and for the life of me could not push the holder into the socket – I almost broke the holder arms in the process. Fortunately, the thing was robust enough and survived without a scratch. The suction cup is sticky even without locking it down with the latch in the mount’s base. The phone holder has a nice little lower lip that you flip out to rest the phone on. You press a button in the lower right corner of the holder to open up the holder’s arms. The mechanism is actually nicely engineered and well built. I’ve included a short video to show how it works. Personally, I think this is one of the best holder mechanisms I’ve come across. As you can see in the video, it allows for practical one-handed operation, and it really grasps onto the phone once you’ve tightened it. And again, the releasing motion is just cool.The phone holder at its widest will accommodate a device that’s 3.5” wide. That should cover most if not all phablets and big phones, even in a bulky case.POTENTIAL PROBLEMSI was a bit tentative about the sticky suction cup. I love my car – and cars in general – and adhesives plus hours of basking and baking in the sun typically don’t equal good outcomes. Also, I hate residues left by adhesives, especially on my windshield or dashboard. After first testing on several different surfaces – table, kitchen countertop, fridge – and not finding any leftover residue after removal of the mount, I finally summoned up the courage to test it in my car. So far, there doesn’t appear to be any residue issues, so that’s very good. But I also realized that my dashboard’s texture was enough to create problem for the suction cup. This isn’t new – it’s the same with all suction based mounts I’ve tried in the past. A flat surface works best – just basic physics. On the windshield, this mount’s suction is very solid.SUMMARYThis is a solid suction mount with a great holder mechanism. It works best on a flat surface, as with all suction based mounts. I am not sure how long the suction cup will stay sticky – I will report back down the road. At least for now, the adhesive appears to be holding up after about a week of daily usage. And I didn’t see any residue left behind on the surface, which was a top priority for me.Full disclosure: I received a sample for testing. I am not affiliated with the seller in any way, and my review is a genuine and unbiased account of my personal experience with the product. Rest assured, I have absolutely no compunction about exposing products that suck. Just my way of paying it forward for all the other good reviews that have helped me so far :)

I’ve completely converted my entire house’s lighting to LED with the exception of a couple candelabra lamps. I decided to start on my conversion by testing out this Lohas candelabra LED bulb.DESIGNThis candelabra bulb is very solidly built, and it’s noticeably more efficient with its rated 680 lumens output at 7W power draw – about 97 lumens/watt, an excellent ratio. Most candelabra LED bulbs I’ve come across are around 300 lumens at 4.5W, or about 67 lumens/watt. The bulb has an impressive heatsink – supposedly made of aviation grade aluminum. It definitely feels robust and hefty to the touch. The LEDs are fully exposed by the clear tip. They are arranged to provide all around lighting coverage. Some people might not find this exposed LED arrangement attractive, but as an engineer and a tech geek, I love the look.The bulb from tip to the base is about 4.25” long. I got the daylight version with a color temperature of 6000-7000K. It is dimmable according to the manufacturer. The CRI or color rendering index is quoted to be greater than or equal to 80. The rated life of 30,000 hours is very impressive and higher than others, which typically are rated for 25,000 hours.LIGHTING AND ENERGY EFFICIENCY PERFORMANCEI’ve included two photos, one with this bulb and the other with a FEIT 300lm/4.5W/2700K soft white LED bulb in the same lamp. To better illustrate the difference in light output and color temperature, pay attention to the Altoids box I placed in the middle of the photo. Personally, I prefer higher color temperature as it makes me feel more awake and alert. At 6000-7000K, this bulb is at the high end in terms of color temp and I would typically use this for work or reading. The color of the light is definitely bright white and doesn’t have the dreaded blueish LED tint to it.Using a Killawatt, I was able to verify the bulb’s power draw (runtime/power draw):- At start up, power draw spiked at 7.7W for about 15 seconds then rolling down to 7.2W- 30 min/7.3W- 60 min/7.4W- 90 min/7.3W- 120min/7.4WThis is ever so slightly higher than the rated 7 W draw, but it’s certainly within reasonable range of deviation. Even at 7.4W, the bulb is still at about 91.89 lumens/W, which is still impressively efficient.The heatsink heats up quickly and can get uncomfortably hot to the touch. But that’s actually a good thing – it means it’s doing a good job removing excessive heat from the LEDs.If there’s any downside, it’s the lack of mentioning of operation in damp areas and/or enclosed light fixtures. Typically you’ll find this info on the box and the bulb, but I didn’t see it in either places with this bulb. Since heat is the main cause for shortened LED lifespan, I personally would err on the side of caution and avoid enclosed fixtures.SUMMARYThis is a very efficient LED candelabra bulb with good build quality. The only drawback is its price point. It’s not inexpensive – unfortunately that’s the case with most candelabra LED bulbs. Hopefully the price point will come down as technology improves and cost drops in the future.Full disclosure: I received a sample for testing. I am not affiliated with the seller in any way, and my review is a genuine and unbiased account of my personal experience with the product. Rest assured, I have absolutely no compunction about exposing products that suck. Just my way of paying it forward for all the other good reviews that have helped me so far :)UPDATE (10/10/2015): heard back from the manufacturer - they do not recommend using this bulb in damp areas or in fully enclosed fixtures. They promised to make that clear in their new bulbs/packaging.

This ipad 4 mini case by Oenbopo is decent cover, but there are some caveats due to the very inexpensive price point.DESIGN & OPERATIONThis case includes a semi-transparent plastic backing and the familiar cover that protects the ipad mini’s screen when closed and folds into two different positions as a stand. The ipad mini simply clips into the plastic backing – no magnetic connection as in the official Apple smart cover. The cutouts in the backing fit the ipad mini nicely. The entire backing does look and feel cheap, but at this price point that is within expectations.The cover feels pretty solidly constructed. It’s attached securely to the plastic backing, and I don’t feel like it will tear apart at the spine holding up it up by the cover with the ipad mini installed, which is a good sign. The cover does have magnets at the edge which comes into play when you fold the cover into its two standing positions. However, the magnets are pretty weak compared to the official Apple smart cover. It will pop open at the lightest touch. However, it does work fine as a stand with the ipad mini installed. Once you have it in position, the weight of the ipad mini helps to prevent the cover from popping open. Still, it’s somewhat annoying and takes away from the user experience.SUMMARYThis ipad mini case works generally fine, but the overall user experience lacks a bit due to the weak magnet in the cover and the somewhat unattractive plastic backing. But then again, the case is very inexpensive at only $5. It’s a great value, without a doubt. Just for me personally, I would prefer to pay a little bit more for a more refine experience after I’ve already shelled out for an ipad mini.Full disclosure: I received a sample for testing. I am not affiliated with the seller in any way, and my review is a genuine and unbiased account of my personal experience with the product. Rest assured, I have absolutely no compunction about exposing products that suck. Just my way of paying it forward for all the other good reviews that have helped me so far :)

This universal phone mount has some good ideas in its design, but the overall implementation needs some work. For starters, the mount literally broke apart the first time I tried to use it. The power plug had an extra rubber gear attachment that was way too big for the port. I felt like I was going to break something as I forced it in. When I tried to pull the mount out of the lighter socket, the tip broke off and was stuck solidly inside the socket (see attached photos). I had to use a set of small forceps to carefully extract the parts stuck – the fuse, the metal contact, the oversized rubber gear and the plastic tip. I then had to figure out how to put the pieces back together, which made me a little tentative about using the charger portion of the mount.DESIGN & OPERATIONThe mount is basically a two-port cigarette lighter attached to an adjustable smartphone frame with a gooseneck extension. The gooseneck is probably the best part of the mount – it’s very robust and strong, and did not budge one bit with a phone in the mount. It’s also easily adjustable, although you do have to put some force into it at first.Unfortunately the rest of the mount has some issues. First, the phone holder had issues grabbing onto phones with thicker cases. The problem here is the adjustable arm that moves up and down. The button and the arm itself protrudes too much out into the space for the phone. Even with a slim style case on my HTC One M7 and iPhone 6S, the holder had just enough clearance to hold onto the phone. With an otterbox case on, my phones were too thick for the mount.Second, as I mentioned before, the mount got stuck in my car’s lighter socket and literally disintegrated when I tried to remove it. Fortunately, no damage was done to my car’s socket and I was able to put the charger pieces back together. I left out the oversized rubber gear (see photo), and this made the mount usable. I understand the motivation behind the rubber gear – to add more support for the mount holding a phone. But it was way too big and not very well designed. The fact that the entire assembly failed spectacularly in my first attempt to use it didn’t help.SUMMARYThis mount is a good idea, but it needs to be better implemented. I actually found it useful after I removed the oversized rubber ring. It freed up my vents from my typical vent-based smartphone holder, and it also moved the phone further away from the windshield and the glare of the sun. The gooseneck is strong and robust, as is the hinge. But the holder mechanism needs to be refined to allow for thicker cases/devices, and the charge port plug needs to be designed (probably just remove the oversized rubber ring) to make sure it doesn’t get stuck or fall apart.Full disclosure: I received a sample for testing. I am not affiliated with the seller in any way, and my review is a genuine and unbiased account of my personal experience with the product. Rest assured, I have absolutely no compunction about exposing products that suck. Just my way of paying it forward for all the other good reviews that have helped me so far :)

When this light bulb was first introduced by Philips back in May, it quickly became somewhat viral due to the special introductory price of just $5 - for a two pack. This was unheard of for brand new LED bulbs without any utility subsidies. I bought two packs back in June when it became available at my local Home Depot, and I was so impressed that I ended up making it the primary bulb for my whole house.DESIGNThe bulb looks like a traditional lightbulb, with an almost perfectly circular plastic enclosure on top followed by about an inch of what feels like metal stem. It's rated to produce 800 lumens while drawing 8.5W with a color temperature of 2700K, which is closest to the good old incandescent soft white. The color rendering index (CRI), which is related to how accurate colors are rendered by the light emitted by the bulb, is 80 - this is about average. The bulb's main selling point is its low price point, and this is reflected in a couple areas. First, the rated life is 10,000 hours, or about 10 years at 3 hours per day. This is roughly half of what most other LED bulbs are rated for, which is around 20~22 years or 25000 hours. Second, the light bulb feels noticeably lighter than most other comparable 60W equivalent LED bulbs. This is due to the fact that there's no elaborate heatsink design. Instead, the only heatsink I can see is the inch of metal stem. I've attached a photo comparing this bulb with three other 60W equivalent LED bulbs. The weight is actually very comparable to the Philips SlimStyle, another Philips LED bulb with emphasis on affordability.The bulb is specifically labelled to be non-dimmable, suitable for damp locations but not suitable for use in fully enclosed luminaries.ACTUAL LIGHTING & ENERGY EFFICIENCY PERFORMANCEUsing a Killawatt to verify power draw, I installed the bulb in a standard floor lamp which places the bulb facing upward in an open enclosure situation. The bulb lighted instantly - some LEDs have a slight half second delay but not here. Power draw at the outlet fluctuated between 8.0 and 8.1W - a pleasant surprise as it's actually drawing less than the rated 8.5W. The power draw remained steady, sometimes dipping to 7.9W but mainly around 8W, at 30 min/60 min/90 min/120 min. At the rated 800 lumen output, this is essentially 100lumens/watt, which is very impressive and actually beats out all the other LEDs I have in my inventory, every one of which being at least twice as expensive if not more.Touching the lightbulb while it's on further supports its low power draw performance. After three hours of continuous operation, the plastic top part is barely warm to the touch. The white metal stem is hot, but I can actually keep my fingers on the stem for about 4 seconds before it's uncomfortable enough to force me to pull away. With other bulbs, I have to pull away almost immediately from the metal heatsink stem after 3 hours of runtime. This is really encouraging, as heat is the number one cause for failure in LED bulbs.The bulb is virtually silent. In certain fixtures, such as my bathroom and one older lamp, there is a very faint buzz if I press my ear next to it, literally about one or two inches away. This was a big improvement over my other affordable Philips LED bulb - the SlimStyle. Very nice.The color temperature is 2700K. This is a potential downside for me, since I personally prefer 3000K for daily lighting. This bulb definitely looks ever so slightly yellower compared to my 3000K bulbs. But at its price point, this is something I can overlook.The other potential shortcoming is that it's not rated for use in fully enclosed light fixtures. The main reason for this is most likely heat dissipation. Surprisingly, none of my other vastly more expensive 60W equivalent LED bulbs are rated for use in fully enclosed fixtures, including all the other bulbs shown in the attached photo. The only LED bulb in my inventory that's rated for fully enclosed fixtures is the FEIT 40W equivalent at 7.5W which I bought from my local Costco's through an utility subsidy. Therefore, I can't really hold it against this bulb - just be aware if you have fully enclosed fixtures, they might adversely affect this bulb's lifespan.Finally, this bulb is not rated for dimmers. However, I tested it at a friend's house with an actual dimmer, and it actually was able to dim down fairly smoothly, albeit with some flickering after about maybe 50% brightness. From other reports online, it seems like it's a hit or miss with dimmers with this bulb. Since it's not rated for dimmers, I consider this almost like a bonus feature if it works well enough for you.SUMMARYThe main selling point of this bulb is its very affordable price. The great 100lm/w efficiency is a very pleasant surprise. Combined with a virtually silent operation, this bulb has become my main bulb throughout my house. Of course, the shorter rated lifespan is somewhat of a concern. However, with its price point being so affordable, it's something that I can certainly live with. There's really no excuse to not try out LED lighting with the availability of this bulb.

First of all, I am a chocoholic and I am proud of it. This is my second bag in as many months, and I am about to order another bag. Yup I know, the subscription system for the first time actually makes sense to me with this :) My first bag arrived during July of this year. It was impeccably packed inside its own box, surrounded on all sides with thick thermal insulation and with a ice pack inside. I was a little worried about the chocolate melting in the powerful NC summer heat, but the entire bag arrived in pristine condition with no hint of melting whatsoever.I love the bite-size packaging. They're especially great for an on-the-go quick chocolate fix. My form of self-control is to hide the bag in the highest kitchen cabinet to prevent me going through half of the bag in one sitting. Initially, I didn't like the special dark flavor too much, but eventually I got used to it and even liked it. Even then, it's definitely my least favorite flavor. The other three - milk chocolate, milk chocolate with almonds and extra creamy milk chocolate with toffee & almonds - are deliciously addictive.If you have a chocoholic in your life, this would make a great gift for any occasion. Trust me, as a card-carrying chocoholic, I know! Just make sure they have a fast metabolism and/or good self control...

I got this as a replacement for my "daily driver" since my old New Balance 993 was falling apart. I admit this was a somewhat impulse buy - the price was great and I liked the class look of the blue/black color combo. I typically would go test them out in a local shoe store, but I chose to live dangerously and bought this blind. Very glad I did!First impression - the shoe is fairly light, just ever so slightly heavier than my Brook Ravenna 3s. The shoe box is average width, slightly looser than the Ravenna's but not so much that it's bothersome. The heel portion was a bit loose when new. The first week or so, I had the annoying sensation of wearing a pair of shoes that's slightly too large in the back around ankle/heel. Fortunately, after the second and the shoes more broken in, that uneasy sensation went away and now they fit my feet great. It's a neutral support shoe, which isn't ideal for me since I tend to over-pronate and prefer stability control shoes. So far I've used these as my general purpose, daily work/walk/gym shoes, and they work great in those arenas. I went for a couple of short distance (1 to 1.5 mile runs, about 10 miles total), and my main take-away is that the shoe lacks the cushioning and support found in my rotation of dedicated running shoes, which include Ravennas, 993s and Gt-2000s.Overall, I am very satisfied with my purchase. I love the shoe's sharp classic look and the price point was pretty reasonable. The level of shock absorption is good enough as my general purpose shoes. It is neutral and doesn't have stability control, but for daily walking and gym, I have no problem even though I usually go for stability control shoes.

I've always been a New Balance (specifically the 993) runner, and I only tried Brooks after the local runner shop's relentless recommendation. My first pair of Brooks was the Ravenna 3. And it was a revelation (see my earlier review of the 3 if you want details). I have weak ankle, somewhat weak arch and suffer from over-pronation. I run about 5K three times a week now - low-ish milesage runner. After getting the Ravenna 3, it quickly became my favorite pair in my rotation of the Asic GT-2000, New Balance 993 and the Ravenna 3. After about year and half and about 268 miles (according to my Nike+ tracking), my Ravenna 3 was starting to feel not as supportive. So the logical replacement is a new pair of Ravenna's. Enter my new pair of Ravenna 5.First impression - it continues the slightly skinny shoe box, which fits me perfectly as I have slightly skinny feet. That was one of the main reasons I loved the 3 so much, and I am very happy the 5 has the same fit. Cushion-wise, the 5 feels great. Reminds me of my first run with the 3, when I felt like I was running on small puffs of cloud. I know some runners prefer a harsher feel, but personally I and my knees appreciate the extra support. Stability seems good - I feel like there's good support for my over-pronation tendencies. Again, reminds me a lot of the Ravenna 3 when it was new. I was relieved to be honest, as I had read some not so positive things about the Ravenna 4, and I wasn't sure which lineage the 5 would follow. I've had the 5 since August, and so far I have about 30 miles on them. Definitely very satisfied.If there's a negative, it's the available colors. I got the "high risk red", which was really the only option as I thought the other color combos were all somewhat questionable - for my taste. But that's about it.

I was going on a cross country trip and while I usually don't have any issue falling asleep, I thought I'd try something new and see if help make the trip more pleasant. I got mine from Target. The ingredients are sodium (80mg), GABA, melatonin and 5-HTP (see attached photo). I took a bottle before take-off and promptly dozed off. I woke up about two hours later with a pulsating head-ache, which is really rare for me. Needless to say, I was pretty miserable for the rest of the flight. Fortunately, I was more or less back to 100% the next day after going to bed early. I did some research into the ingredients, and it appears 5-HTP's primary effect is it promotes serotonin production in the brain. Taking 5-HTP along with GABA (gamma aminobutyric acid) is an unconfirmed method for promoting sleep. I am guessing each person reacts to these "supplements" differently. From my adverse reaction, I definitely won't be trying this again (or any other similar supplements).  Also, it tasted a bit synthetic and left an unpleasant aftertaste.

I am an avid runner and I’ve gone through more than my share of smartphone armbands. One of the biggest issues I’ve encountered is a bad-fitting loose band, which is very annoying as I have to constantly interrupt my run to make adjustments. After running with this armband for the past two weeks (typically 5k every other day), I am glad to say it has great fit and hasn’t slid or moved out of place on me. The armband has two slots for looping the Velcro band through (photos attached). I have average sized arms, and it fits nice and snugly using just the outer slot. The inner slot creates a really small fit, and I think most people won’t need that unless you’re super skinny or maybe a kid. There’s also a slot for storing your key(s). It seems snug and tight enough, but since there’s no zipper, I personally wouldn’t trust it for my house or car keys.RUNNING NAKEDYou slide the phone in through a slit in the back. The fit is very tight – with my HTC One M7, which is virtually the same dimension and size as the iPhone 6/6S, I had to remove the phone’s case (even though it was a Seidio slim fit case) before I was able to get it inside the armband. At first I wasn’t sure about running with a naked phone, mainly due to the fact that I take really good care of my gadgets and I was a little wary about the protection or lack thereof. But after a few runs, I actually started to prefer running naked – naked phone, that is. The weight reduction from lack of case helps the band stays in place, which is my number one annoyance with armbands. The only other problem was that the headphone cutout is at the bottom, which makes sense since it’s designed for iPhones. My HTC has it at the top. Fortunately, it worked perfectly after I put in my phone the other way.SUMMARYThis is a good armband that has kept its good fit after couple weeks of running. The price point is pretty attractive too. I have three other armbands of various design, and this one’s definitely my go-to armband now.Full disclosure: I received a sample for testing. I am not affiliated with the seller in any way, and my review is a genuine and unbiased account of my personal experience with the product. Rest assured, I have absolutely no compunction about exposing products that suck. Just my way of paying it forward for all the other good reviews that have helped me so far :)

0:42 Mins This portable LED Lamp by Etekcity is a pretty interesting tool. When I first got it, I was expecting a basic lamp with some gimmicky extras. After using it over this past summer, I've been pleasantly surprised by how practical it and its additional features turned out to be.DESIGN AND OPERATIONThe lamp is made up of a mix of hard plastic shell with a metal band (most likely aluminum) in the middle. The plastic feels tough and not flimsy, which was better than I was expecting. There are two folding metal hangers, and the hinges are pretty tight and robust, and they feel like they won't snap off after a couple cycles. The top and bottom caps unscrew to reveal the AA (it takes 3) and 18650 lithium ion battery (it takes 2) compartments. Towards the lower part of the lamp you'll find a blue button for cycling through the different lighting modes and a rubber covered door housing a microUSB and standard USB for charging purposes.  To turn on the lamp, you pull the top until you reach the trigger point. You can adjust the light output by how much you extend the lamp. When it's in the off position, the lamp is about 3"x3"x5.1" (see attached photos). Fully extended, it stands about 7" tall.I thought the way you turn the lamp on was pretty cool. There's just enough resistance as you pull on the top to give a reassuring feeling - it definitely won't slide out on its own if the lamp is held upside down. Pulling up on this lamp made me feel like Dennis Nedry (aka Newman hehe) from Jurassic Park, you know that scene where he's stealing the dinosaur embryos from the cold storage tanks. I've attached a short video showing the mechanism in action, as well as the 4 different lighting modes (hi-white, low-white, red, flashing-red). There's also two magnets on the bottom of the lamp. It's a little weak, barely able to hold the lamp perpendicular on my fridge. I have to fidget with it to get it to stay, and any slight motion or vibration will cause the lamp to slide down. As you can see from the video, there's two other corners with rubber feet instead of magnets. I feel like with one or two additional magnets, this thing would attach solidly to metal surfaces.The lamp is able to draw power from three sources - the 3 AA's, the two lithium cells or via external power source through 5V USB. It also doubles as an emergency battery bank for mobile devices via the USB port, drawing from the two lithium cells (18650 cells are 2200mAH each, for a total of 4400mAH). You can recharge the lithium cells by plugging the lamp into a standard USB charger, but you have to remove the AA's before doing so. The battery bank function is a nice bonus - very practical for camping trips. I tested the lamp with my Eneloop AA's, and the combo worked perfectly.POTENTIAL ISSUESIn addition to the weak magnets on the bottom on the lamp, the only other issue I came across was the lithium battery compartment being a bit tight. I had to really use some force to remove the two 18650 cells.SUMMARYOverall, this is a very useful tool to have around. The build quality is surprisingly solid, and the additional battery bank feature is a nice bonus. I wish the manufacturer opted to put additional magnets on the bottom to make attaching the lamp to metal surfaces more reliable. Perhaps in a future revision.Full disclosure: I received a sample for testing. I am not affiliated with the seller in any way, and my review is a genuine and unbiased account of my personal experience with the product. Rest assured, I have absolutely no compunction about exposing products that suck. Just my way of paying it forward for all the other good reviews that have helped me so far :)

I’ve been using Meguiar’s quik detailer for a while now… since the early 2000’s now that I think about it. I started using it mainly to get rid of bird poop, which is acidic and will degrade and eat through the clear coat if left to bake in the sun. And without a good layer of clear coat, not only does your car look really unattractive, but the underlying paint surface is now exposed to the elements. I used to keep a bottle handy in the garage, but now that I am a proverbial poor grad student living in an apartment setting, I no longer have the luxury (and protection) that a garage offers. I threw a bottle in the trunk and it’s a perfect and quick way to wipe off bird poop, tree sap or any other crap that you’ll find on my car. It works especially well if your car has a decent coat of wax. I usually use one or two sprays followed by a few seconds to let the solution dissolve the contaminants. Then it's an easy wipe off.The bottle pictured in the product description has the old style spray nozzle, which is NOT able to be turned off completely. I learned this the hard way after most of my first bottle leaked out in the trunk. The most recent bottle I bought from Amazon contains a new spray nozzle that allows you to turn it 90 degrees to lock it. This is great as now I don’t have to worry about any accidental leaking.

I’ve always preferred slim, low-profile cases more than the bulky Otterboxes. I am pretty careful with my gadgets and I like to preserve as much of my phone’s sleek profile as possible. My significant other recently got a new rose gold iPhone 6S, and I was tasked with finding a suitable case and screen protector for her new baby. It’s only been a couple days, but so far this case by Easy-Tech has worked well. It does come with a “bonus” screen protector.DESIGN & OPERATIONThe case is a single piece of rubbery plastic that snaps onto her 6S, which has an identical physical layout as the old 6. The material feels slightly slippery according to my significant other. The fit is great, and all buttons (power, volume +/-) work properly. There’s good access to the silence toggle and the lightning connector port. Good cutouts for the speaker and the camera too. As you can see from my attached photos, the pink version that we got matches nicely with the rose gold 6S. There is an Easy-Tech logo in white near the bottom of the case, but it’s subtle and you can hardly see it from normal distance, which is nice.The case included a bonus screen protector. There’s a link in the package material to a how-to video on how to apply the screen protector if you’ve never done it before. This was actually my first time doing this, and I had to reapply several times before it was deemed okay by my SO. Part of the problem was me being a screen protector rookie. But the other part was from the fact that the screen protector does NOT cover the entire front of the phone. Instead, it’s literally just wide enough to cover the screen. I’ve attached a photo that hopefully illustrates this for you. According to the how-to video, this is due to the slight curvature towards the edges of the iPhone. I think it all boils down to cost, as it probably costs more to produce a screen protector that completely matches the slight curvature. It does cover the entire screen, so no issues there. We’ll see how she likes it. If not, the screen protector can be easily removed by gently pulling up at the corner. I had to do this a couple times in my do-over attempts, and I am glad to report it didn’t leave any weird residue on the screen.SUMMARYThis is a decent slim profile case for the iPhone 6 and 6S. It doesn’t offer as much protection as the beefier cases like Otterbox, but it’s a valid trade-off for the slim profile. I’ll update this as we put more mileage on the case. For now, the only con is I wish the screen protector had covered the entire front of the phone.Full disclosure: I received a sample for testing. I am not affiliated with the seller in any way, and my review is a genuine and unbiased account of my personal experience with the product. Rest assured, I have absolutely no compunction about exposing products that suck. Just my way of paying it forward for all the other good reviews that have helped me so far :)

I am typically very careful when it comes to using third party chargers for my gadgets, as there’s so much potential for serious problems. My recent encounter with a LG OEM charger (came with the phone) that failed spectacularly – loud popping sound complete with puff of smoke – further confirmed my philosophy that you can never be too careful when it comes to power supplies for your precious gadgets. I am glad to report that after a week as my primary charger, this 2 port 2.1A charger by Crabby Digital have performed without any problem, and I have no problem using it to charge my most prized toys.DESIGN & OPERATIONThe charger is a black square with a nice matte finish that doesn’t look or feel cheap. It’s about 1.9”x1.9”, slightly bigger and noticeably heavier than the iPad 2.1A single port charger. The heft is promising, as it tends to correlate with decent power supply components. The plug folds into the charger when not in use. The two output ports are each capable of up to 2.1A @ 5V. There is a thin blue LED strip between the output ports that light up when plugged in. I tend to avoid LED lights on power supplies if possible for two reasons: they can be annoyingly bright and also cause excessive standby or phantom power draw when nothing’s charging. I am glad to report that’s not the case here. The blue LED isn’t too bright (photo attached), and the charger draws negligible power when in standby, verified by my Killawatt which showed 0.0W with the charged plugged in and the blue LED on.I tested this by charging a retina iPad and a HTC One m8 simultaneously. Since it’s not a Qualcomm quick-charge charger, it only charged the HTC One at 1 A, which was expected. It charged the iPad at full speed at 2A with no problem. The power draw was verified using my Killawatt.SUMMARYThis is a nice 2-port 2.1A charger with a subdued blue LED that’s not aggressively bright. I especially like the fact that it draws negligible power during standby. This means I don’t have to feel guilty about leaving it plugged in when not in use – it’s not wasting power, raising my electric bill and causing unnecessary pollution.Full disclosure: I received a sample for testing. I am not affiliated with the seller in any way, and my review is a genuine and unbiased account of my personal experience with the product. Rest assured, I have absolutely no compunction about exposing products that suck. Just my way of paying it forward for all the other good reviews that have helped me so far :)

This is a decent jump rope that should be fun for both kids and adults. There are some issues related to the design and build quality that could use some improvement or refinement. Given the price point, it’s alright, but not great.DESIGN AND BUILD QUALITYThe entire jump rope is made of plastic material, from the handles to the rope itself. The handles are made of decently thick plastic outer shells held together by small screws. They do feel a bit cheap, like good quality Fisher Price toys almost. On one handle, there’s a small LCD counter that shows you how many reps. The battery compartment is on the back of this handle, secured by two small screws. To change the battery, you just need a small Philips screw driver (i.e. one that works on glasses or laptop hard drives) to remove the two screws holding the battery door. It comes preinstalled with a L1154 alkaline button battery (see photos). It’ll probably last years if not virtually forever, since the small display draws very little power and auto shuts off after a short period of inactivity. Still, it’s good to be able to easily change batteries.The rope itself is also plastic, and is decently thick and should stand up to normal use just fine. The rope length is just barely long enough for myself (I am 6-1).POTENTIAL ISSUESOverall the rope worked well, but I noticed that the counter wasn’t 100% accurate. It tended to add about 2 or 3 reps per 10 reps – so if I did 10 actual jumps, the counter typically would register 12 or 13. After playing with the handles, I realized the counter works when the handle core rotates past a physical counter, which has a slight resistance and clicks when you go past it. On paper the design sounds good. I am not sure what’s causing the extra counts. Since the count discrepancy gets worse when I go faster, my best guess is the counter is somehow “double clicking” randomly, adding extra reps to the overall count. Since the main draw of this jump rope is its built-in counter, this inaccuracy kind of defeats the purpose, even if it’s in the ballpark so to speak.I personally didn’t encounter much tangling with the plastic rope. They can get twisted and more tangly, but you can fix that by untwisting it using the handles.SUMMARYThis is an okay product given the price point. I can definitely see this as a cool toy to give to kids and adults alike. Personally, the counter inaccuracy is just enough to bug me, but it’s still in the ballpark and if that doesn’t bother you, then it’s not a bad purchase.Full disclosure: I received a promotional sample for testing. I am not affiliated with the seller in any way, and my review is a genuine and unbiased account of my personal experience with the product.

When I first heard about this, I thought it was a joke. Sure, spending my days frolicking and eating and headbutting as a goat is obviously entertaining, but probably only for a few days. Week at most.But then I didn't anticipate the power of licking as a goat. Total game changer. It absolutely adds at least another week - if not two - of blissful fun. No lie.In terms of control, it's easy and intuitive. You use both hands to control the goat's movement (direction/running/jumping/headbutting/licking) as well as the perspective via transparent virtual buttons. You will be running/jumping/headbutting/licking in no time.There are tons of no nonsense things on your goat to-do list. My favorite so far is the firework that leads to Michael Bay Kaboom. The physics is exquisitely modeled and as expected. The graphics is nicely rendered in full 3D. You can change your perspective with the right thumb - great for getting that money shot view. The physics is actually decent. Be wary though - this game is a nice workout for your phone's CPU and graphics processor. On a slower phone, such as my old LG Realm, the graphics got a little choppy when there's a lot going on. It's buttery smooth on faster devices like my HTC One.Overall, it's a funky little game that deserves a look. The price is somewhat steep, but Amazon has it for free over in the new Underground section. Download it now and see for yourself.

Nowadays portable batteries are more of a necessity than luxury, given how power hungry our various mobile devices are. I received a sample of the blue Lumsing 8000mAh powerbank for testing, and overall I found it to be a quality portable power source that's well built and aesthetically attractive. The only flaw is the lack of pass-through charging.DESIGN & OPERATIONSThe battery bank is indeed very thin - at about 0.3" thickness. The overall dimension is about the size of the iPhone 6, and slightly heavier, by about an ounce. The exterior is an attractive brushed aluminum casing that feels nice to the touch. Mine was the aqua blue version which looked nice. There are two USB ports - the full size USB is for charging your phone at up to 5V/2.1A, while the microUSB is the charge port for the battery bank (it takes up to 5V/1.5A). A charger is not included, but any standard phone USB wall charger should work fine. There's a power button next to a small flashlight. To charge, you press the power button once after you've connected the phone to the battery bank. To switch the flashlight on/off, you double click the power button. There are two small blue LEDs acting as charge indicator - two LED lit means >50%, one LED means <50%. Overall it's pretty user friendly and intuitive. I wish you didn't have to click the power button to begin charge, but it's a minor issue.A bigger issue is the lack of pass-through charging. If you hook up both a phone and a power supply to the battery bank simultaneously, only the battery bank will be charged but not the phone. This means at you can't just plug them in before bedtime and wake up to both the phone and battery bank being fully charged. Lumsing does not claim to have this capability, so it's not knock per se. But it's very useful feature that can potentially save a lot of time, and one that I've come to appreciate from my various trips using another battery bank that has this ability.Also, this battery only has one output port, so you can only charge one device at a time. Most banks now have two output ports. Although I think it's a valid trade-off for the thin form-factor.DURABILITY & CAPACITYThis is a 8000mAh bank. With overhead loss, you're looking at about 6500mah of usable capacity, which is expected. I was able to charge up my HTC One M7 about 3.5 times, which is about right given that the HTC has a 2300mah battery (it's probably closer to 2000mah now from normal degradation). I didn't notice any abnormal heat issues during charging and discharging, which bodes well for the powerbank's longevity. I will update this section in the future to see how this battery holds up longterm.Overall, if you're looking for a thin portable power source for your own personal use, this is a great choice. Just be aware of its limitations - namely no pass-through charging and only one output port.Full disclosure: I received a promotional sample for testing. I am not affiliated with the seller in any way, and my review is a genuine and unbiased account of my personal experience with the product.

This arrived in a very nice, premium packaging (see attached pictures), which my significant other appreciated very much. The vibrator itself is made of a soft feeling silicone material that's nice to the touch but firm enough to give an impression that it's solidly built. It takes two AAA batteries, which are not included. It works with either normal single use alkaline or nimh rechargeable batteries. Since AAAs hold less energy than normal AAs, I would definitely recommend some high quality rechargeable batteries, such as the Eneloops I tested with. Most rechargeable batteries are slightly wider girth wise and I am glad to report we had no problem inserting and removing the Eneloops.There are a plethora of modes, and you cycle through them by pressing the button at the end (see attached pic). There's low/medium/high constant vibration, followed by three different intermittent pulse modes and a combination mode. Overall, it's great product that's nicely made, and the great packaging was just icing on the cake.We received a sample for testing. We're not affiliated with the seller in any way, and this review is a genuine and unbiased account of our personal experience with the product.

Running with today's ever larger phones can be problematic. As someone who's pretty passionate about running, I've gone through my share of armbands and holders. The biggest problem for me is always keeping the bands from slipping couple miles into my run. This can be really annoying as I have to readjust the band periodically and takes away from the running experience.When I first saw this running fanny pack, I was definitely skeptical. I've never used a running fanny pack before. Or fanny pack in general. I was pleasantly surprised when I went for my first run with this holding my HTC One M7 (same size as an IPhone 6, see attached pic). The belt stayed in place and there was very little movement through my 5K jog. I was able to use my phone through the clear window. The zipper in the back completely sealed the compartment, which was great since it started drizzling half way through my run. If there was one negative, it was the fanny pack aspect. For one, you just can't look cool running with a fanny pack of any kind. Two, the lower position on my torso (compared to my typical armband) means added travel for my headphone wires, which increased random movement and chance of tangling. My solution was to lengthen the straps, which were very easy to adjust, and convert the fanny pack into a mini backpack that slings diagonally across my upper chest. At first, I tried with the phone on the front of my chest, but there was still too much movement during my run. But when I moved the phone to my back, it fit perfectly and there was very little movement even during full-on sprint. I love this configuration, and it's a much better option than my armbands which tend to slip after a while no matter how tight I make it.I also like the extra space inside the pack. I can easily fit driver's license and couple credit cards in there easy. And again it's securely sealed with the full length zipper (see attached pic). The material feels quite nice to the touch (another pleasant surprise) - has that underarmour nylon feel to it. This has become my primary running pack now, and it's worth a look if you're looking for a holder that's bigger than average. I will update my review if I run into any issues.Full disclosure: I received a promotional sample for testing. I am not affiliated with the seller in any way, and my review is a genuine and unbiased account of my personal experience with the product.

This is a nice looking basic belt that's surprisingly well built. It's thick and slightly wider (about 1.75", see attached picture) than the typical belt, so depending on your pants it might not fit all of them. I made the mistake of ordering one that's too large. I got the 38, for some reason thinking it was the length of the belt instead of my waist size. It still works, but for me personally a 36 would probably work perfectly. My waist size is typically 32 or so, so the advice from other reviewers about ordering at least one size up from your waist size sounds about right.Overall, I like this belt - looks good enough to be dressy and I feel very confident that it will take some beating too as a work belt. Just be mindful that it is a bit wider than the typical belt.I received a promotional sample for testing. I am not affiliated with the seller in any way, and my review is a genuine and unbiased account of my personal experience with the product.

To be honest, I had no idea beard oil was a thing. Granted, I haven't been keeping up with the latest trends in beard maintenance since I usually keep a clean shaven look, especially after reading about a recent study showing men's beards housed more bacteria than the typical toilet seat. I received this as a promotional sample, and I decided to test it out over the past two weeks. I have to say, I've been pleasantly surprised by its effect on my excuse for facial hair. I used the included dropper to put a few drops onto my palm and then rub it into my beard. I like the smell, but more importantly so does my significant other, who said it "smelled nice and minty and manly".The little pouch looks great and is a nice touch. I can definitely see this as a cool unique stocking stuffer or birthday gift. Definitely check it out if you (or someone you know) have a beard!As I stated earlier, I received a promotional sample for testing purposes. I am not affiliated with the seller in any way, and my review is a genuine and unbiased account of my personal experience with the product.

USB 3.1 type C is the latest revision in USB, and it's got a lot of things going for it - reversibility (no need to worry about which way to plug it in), robust power delivery (much higher wattage), smaller size and of course the high data transfer speed of USB 3.0. This adapter converts a standard USB device into one with a USB 3.1 type C connector. You simply plug the USB 3.0 end of the converter into the device's USB cable and voila, your device now has a 3.1 type C connector.USB 3.1 type C is still very new, but I was able to test this out on a new MacBook Air in my lab, which only has a single Type C port. I tested the following devices: Logitech wireless Marathon mouse (with nano receiver), generic USB 2.0 4-port hub, USB 3.0 4-port hub, Brother laser printer, a Sandisk 64GB USB 2.0 flash drive, and a Sandisk Extreme Pro USB 3.0 flash drive. They all worked perfectly, and the data transfer speed with the Sandisk flash drives were not affected in any way by the adapter.The adapter feels solidly built, and there was a reassuring click as I connected the cable. The size is small and the weight isn't excessive enough to make me worry about putting extra stress on the MacBook Air's port.Overall, this is a useful converter to have around, especially if you have the new MacBook Air with only one Type C port.This was a complimentary test unit - I have absolutely no affiliation with the company/seller. It had absolutely no influence on my review, where my goal is always to provide a fair, honest and unbiased take on my experience with the product in question.

When I first heard about this, I thought it was a joke. Sure, spending my days frolicking and eating and headbutting as a goat is obviously entertaining, but probably only for a few days. Week at most.But then I didn't anticipate the power of licking as a goat. Total game changer. It absolutely adds at least another week - if not two - of blissful fun. No lie.In terms of control, it's easy and intuitive. You use both hands to control the goat's movement (direction/running/jumping/headbutting/licking) as well as the perspective via transparent virtual buttons. You will be running/jumping/headbutting/licking in no time.There are tons of no nonsense things on your goat to-do list. My favorite so far is the firework that leads to Michael Bay Kaboom. The physics is exquisitely modeled and as expected. The graphics is nicely rendered in full 3D. You can change your perspective with the right thumb - great for getting that money shot view. The physics is actually decent. Be wary though - this game is a nice workout for your phone's CPU and graphics processor. On a slower phone, such as my old LG Realm, the graphics got a little choppy when there's a lot going on. It's buttery smooth on faster devices like my HTC One.Overall, it's a funky little game that deserves a look. I probably wouldn't have tried it at its normal asking price, but with Amazon Underground taking care of all the cost, there was no risk checking it out. Download it now and see for yourself.

I loved the original cut the rope, and I was quite disappointed when the sequel came out loaded down with tons of in app purchases. I know it's the latest trend of the "freemium" model, but I never liked the idea. When amazon came out with its underground program, I decided to give this game another shot. It's true - every single in app purchase is free, from the coin combo for getting power ups to the package for removing ads. It's certainly liberating!The big potential issue I saw was the extensive list of required permissions from the Amazon Underground app itself, which is needed to download and run Underground apps. You can see the list of permission on the Amazon Underground app page. To keep things in perspective, the list is pretty much the same as the one required for the Amazon app store app. So yes, you are probably being tracked on some way while using Underground apps, but probably not more than what was done in the past. And it's probably needed to compensate the developers under the "per minute played" model from Amazon. In any case, I was able to play the game in airplane mode, so that might be an option if you are concerned about privacy.

I've been looking for a car mount for a while that would fit my car properly. I initially looked at the Kenu Airframe for its elegant design. Unfortunately it didn't fit my car's vents, and so I decided to look for a more traditional suction cup based mount. I ended up giving this mount a try due to the gooseneck design, which I thought is a nice feature if it worked as designed. Also the holder bears a passing resemblance to the Kenu Airframe, which was my original target.DESIGNThe mount arrived in two pieces - the base with the gooseneck and the the spring loaded holder. It took me a few minutes to figure out that I had to first loosen the knob on the back of the holder before inserting the gooseneck mount. You can tighten the knob once you've adjusted the mount to your desired angle and position. The holder has a nice range and was able to securely hold an iphone 6, HTC One M7 & M8 and LG Realm with rooms to spare. The gooseneck is very stiff and somewhat hard to adjust. But I actually prefer that as it really doesn't budge even when holding up a big phone. The suction cup has a straight-forward clip that you push down to lock, and pull up to unlock from your car's dashboard or windshield. I've attached a picture of the mount next to a ruler to give you an accurate idea of its physical dimensions.RELIABILITYI've been using this mount for about two weeks now, and I've had absolutely no issues. I store it in my glove compartment when not in use to avoid baking it in the sun. I will update this section if I run into any unexpected problems.This was a complimentary test unit. It had absolutely no influence on my review, where my goal is always to provide a fair, honest and unbiased take on my experience with the product in question.

I bought this 3 pack of $15 gift cards during a promotion on Prime Day (bonus $10 coupon). The cards arrived quickly via 1-day shipping even though I picked the no rush option. I received an email confirmation from Amazon regarding the bonus coupon immediately after the cards were shipped out. The cards themselves were easy to use - just enter in the code printed on the back into your Amazon account and that's it.I am sure it's pretty standard nowadays, but still I think it's worth mentioning that these cards never expires and do not have hidden "service" fees that eat away at your balance after a certain period.

Tap Sports Football is a s a super simplified football game, to the point where it's too easy and boring. On top of that, there's a lot required permissions and even video ads, not to mention the substantial in-app purchases. I would not recommend it, even as today's free app of the day.GAMEPLAY & CONTROLAll you are allowed to do in the game is play offense. Kickoff is automated. Defense is automated (you select a general strategy). The automated results pop up immediately, without even an animation or anything. As for offense, all you do is choose a general strategy (running/passing/balanced) and then tap anywhere on screen for each play. At first, I thought where you tap would somehow dictate or control the play. Nope. You just tap and the play happens. It's really mindless and boring after about two minutes.You can upgrade with players and coaching staff. This is where the in-app purchases come in. You can blow up to $99 in real world money at a time. And the game promises the video ads will go away with any purchase. Just feels like rip-off overall.ADD-ONS & PERMISSIONSThe game has a lot of permissions:*access to internet*access to coarse location*access to SD card*access to wifi state*access to phone state*access to vibrate*access to receive_boot_completed*access to c2dm.permissions.receiveThis is in addition to the ads modules AppLovin and Google Mobile Ads, which I presume are for the video ads. There's also AD-X tracking for tracking in-game analytics. The presence of ads in a paid app is unacceptable. Coupled with the excessive and questionable list of required permissions, I would stay away even if this is actually a fun game - and it's not.

Lalaloopsy Diner is a cute time management game, a la Emily's diner games, except it's designed for a much younger crowd.GAMEPLAY & CONTROLThe premise is that you are in charge of your restaurant's kitchen, and your goal is to serve your customers as quickly and efficiently as possible to maximize your earnings and tips. You can buy upgrades like better cooking ware using your earnings to help improve your efficiency and speed. The game has three difficulty levels (user selectable under the option menu on the home screen), and it defaults to the medium level. It also uses the familiar 3-star system to gauge the player's performance for each level. Both of these should help improve the game's replay value, as it motivates players to try to complete all levels with 3 stars, and then perhaps bump up to a harder difficulty level.There's an intuitive tutorial before the first stage which was very helpful if you're new to this type of games. The controls consist of dragging and tapping the various ingredients, and it was smooth and precise.GRAPHICS & SOUNDThe game definitely looks very cute and geared toward the younger crowd. The graphics are well done and smoothly animated. The voice work and music reminds me of PBS kids shows, which is exactly what the developer was going for. You can turn off the music under the option menu if you prefer.ADD-ONS & PERMISSIONSThere's no extraneous add-ons or dangerous permissions here, and I didn't encounter any ads while testing. This is how a paid app, and especially one designed for young children, should behave. The required permissions are internet access and read/write access to the SD card. The former is used for the links to the developer's other apps, while the latter is used for the app's ability to move data onto the SD card if you have one.The only issue I encountered was that there didn't appear to be a way to exit or close the game properly. Back button wasn't it. I had to use the home button to get out of the app, at which point I noticed it was still running in the background. This has potential to negatively impact the phone or tablet's performance and/or battery life. A quick solution is to use the android multitasking button, and then swipe the app to shut it down. Hopefully the developer is reading and can address this issue with a future update.

Overall, this is a nice vibrator and worked as described, but there's some issues with battery removal/replacement especially if you use rechargeable batteries (see details below).GENERAL PERFORMANCEAccording to my significant other, this is a decent product with decently powerful motor inside. The pink panther spots, as corny as they sound, are a nice touch. The waterproof feature seems to be true, as the device has survived multiple washes. The vibration strength knob at the end is easy to adjust. However, if there's something to complain about, it's the location of this knob, as you might unintentionally adjust it during use.BATTERY COMPARTMENT ISSUESThe device takes two AA batteries. We first tested the device using high quality eneloop rechargeable batteries. The product works perfectly with rechargeable batteries, and I would imagine it's more economical and green to do so. However, we ran into problems trying to remove the batteries from the vibrator. Turns out, the inner plastic shell that holds the battery is quite a tight fit for the rechargeable batteries, which tend to be slightly thicker (bigger diameter) than regular alkaline batteries. Eventually, the plastic container fell out of the vibrator (see attached pic #1). It was then easy to push out the batteries using a pen. This wasn't too bad. The bigger issue was the copper strip (see attached pic #2), which popped out in the process and we weren't sure how it was oriented originally. It took a while to figure out that it's suppose to be in the position shown in the attached picture. We almost destroyed the copper strip before figuring it out. Fortunately, everything turn out okay. If you plan on using rechargeable batteries, I would suggest removing the end cap, gently popping out the plastic battery holder, replace with fresh batteries and then push the holder back into the vibrator, taking care to make sure the copper lead strip stays in the same position.After this ordeal, we tested it with regular alkaline AA batteries. The fit is slightly looser, and the batteries will slide out with some tapping without having to remove the battery holder.Hope this helps! We received this complimentary product in exchange for an honest and unbiased review.

Looking for Laika is an interesting take on the gear type game with a little bit of Flappy Bird sprinkled on top. It's definitely a bit more challenging than the average mobile game, which might turn off some players who're looking for a game with an easy learning curve. But if you have the patience, this game is actually quite entertaining once you get the hang of it.GAMEPLAY & CONTROLThe premise of the game is that the aliens abducted your beloved pet Laika, and you're an astronaut on a quest to track down and get him/her back. There are two modes of gameplay - story and arcade. In story mode, cute cutscenes tie together stages as you push forward in your quest to find Laika. In arcade mode, you simply run through stages without the backstory scenes. I've found arcade mode to be a nice practice mode, too. And you'll need some practice. This game is definitely challenging, almost frustratingly so when you first pick it up. To get past each stage, you need to pick up the key and then go into the "cloud" exit. There are power-ups and bonus items along the way, if you can pick them up. The Flappy Bird influence can be seen in the control - you simply tap when you want to jump. When you hit a "planet", it starts spinning and you have to time your jumps properly to move forward.Simple, right? Well, for my first few runs, I quickly discovered the planets spin quite fast when you first hop on. The timing you need is incredibly tight and frustratingly difficult. My eureka moment came when I started tapping randomly out of frustration - it turns out, you can bounce off planets without attaching by jumping right before you attach to them. Also, by doing so, you can also modify the spin rate and even direction of the planets! The timing and spinning become a lot more manageable and doable after I figured this out, and I started to finally have fun instead of trying to throw my phone on the ground in anger. Don't get me wrong, it's still very challenging, but at least it's not mission impossible now.GRAPHICS AND SOUNDThe game has a beautifully rendered look that's smoothly animated - definitely aesthetically pleasing. The music is pleasing, and you can turn it off if you prefer.ADD-ONS AND PERMISSIONSThe game has no extraneous ads or add-ons, and I didn't encounter any ads while playing. The only permission is internet access. Normally this is pretty innocuous, as it's used for links for social media or developer's other apps. However, I didn't see any such links in the actual game, so I am not quite sure why it's there. Maybe it was just leftover code. In any case, I was able to play the game in airplane mode without any problem, so if you want to be extra careful you can do that.Overall, Looking for Laika is an interesting game with a somewhat steep learning curve. But once you get it, it's actually quite entertaining. Just be prepared for some frustrating moments as you get your timing right.

I've always wanted a KillaWatt and after a lot research, I decided on this model. It's basically a derivative of the P4460 Pro model but with the "made for Dummies" marketing spin, and it includes the Pro's most important feature - battery backup. This means that when you unplug the KillaWatt, it retains the usage recorded (how many hours at what rate). This combined with the lower cost compared to the Pro made it a no brainer. I bought this in April '15, and since then I've realized that there's a couple points where this model actually wins over the Pro:1. the user interface is more logically organizedThe buttons are clearly labeled and you should have no problem using it without even glancing at the user's manual. There's a dedicated $ button for the cost, followed by buttons that toggle between Watt/VA, Volt/Amp and KWH/Hour. The yellow Pro button at the end allows you to see all the info plus detailed data about your CO2 emission (day/week/year/total) and cost (day/week/year/total).A couple useful pointers that may not be immediately apparent:-to clear the stored usage data, press and hold down the KWH/Hour key in standard mode.-to change the KWH cost to your local rate, go into Pro mode and press and hold the $ button until it flashes "rate". Update it to your local rate and press the Pro button to save-to change the pound of CO2 emission per KWH, go into Pro mode and press and hold the Watt/VA button until it flashes "rate". Update it to your local rate (you can get this info by contacting your local power company) and press the Pro button to save2. the user manualTrue to its nature as a "designed for dummies" product, this KillaWatt's user manual is well written and easy to follow!On the other hand, there's definitely some room left for improvements:1. Lack of backlight in the displayThe display doesn't have any backlight whatsoever. I get that it's probably good for not adding any extraneous power draw, but an option to light it for a second or two would be very useful since a lot of times, the unit would be in a tight spot behind appliances or furniture and it's almost impossible to read the screen without grabbing a flashlight.2. Front plug is extremely tightThe front plug where you plug your device in has an extremely tight fit. I have to really push and pull to plug and unplug devices. Here you definitely do NOT want to pull on the wire alone - it most likely will not unplug and you will damage your device and/or plug in the process. While I appreciate a tight fit for a solid connection, this is a bit overboard. I think a couple other reviewers reported similar experiences, so it's probably not an isolated incident. Just be extra careful when plugging and unplugging devices.The device is rated to take max voltage of 125V @ 15A, or a total of 1875 VA. Another reviewer mentioned that his KillaWatt failed after using it to monitor his electric vehicle. That's probably above the device's rated capacity, which is why it died so quickly. I think as long as you stay within the rated envelope, the device should work fine.I've certainly learned a lot about my various other gadgets and saved some power/reduced my carbon foot print in the process. For example, most of the new cell phone chargers actually don't draw any discernible power when the phone is unplugged. That was a relief as it's a lot easier to have the chargers constantly plugged in. My old microwave with a digital clock was drawing close to 3 watts just idling - I've since decided to only plug it in as needed. It's also fun to verify the performance of my new LED light bulbs - some actually perform better than their factor specs! My toshiba laptop has a nifty software monitoring tool that tells me how many watts it's drawing at any given time. And it turns out, the numbers match up with what I am seeing with the KillaWatt. Overall, I've enjoyed having this gadget and I highly recommend this model!

I purchased this for my first ever trip to Yellowstone earlier this summer. On paper, the hat's design sounds like a winner, with full coverage from the sun for the neck and most of the face. On top of that, I thought the ability to customize the coverage needed is a great idea. In practice, the hat didn't work very well. Although the hat itself fit well for my average sized noggin, the mask and back flaps were a bit loose even after my best attempt to get a tight fit. In addition to making me look like a sloppily dressed terrorist, the flaps and mask were flapping around wildly at the slightest hint of a breeze. Almost immediately after I started on my first Yellowstone hike, I found myself constantly adjusting and readjusting the flaps, which would ride up incessantly. I tried it with and without the mask on in an effort to reduce the flapping, but that didn't help any. I have to admit, it was a bit hilarious getting all the looks from the other patrons. I know I looked ridiculous, which was half the fun, but it was annoying that I wasn't getting the sun protection in return. A buddy had a similar hat, but his was much more robustly built with heaving flaps that actually laid down in the wind - and his didn't have the mask either. I ended up channeling my tourist mode and bought a safari hat from a crazy hat salesman just outside of Yellowstone.I've included a couple photos of the hat (I got the blue version). With the neck flaps and mask removed, the hat is an okay cap. It's just when the extra covers are attached, the material is too thin and light-weight, and flaps around wildly at the hint of the lightest breeze.

I bought this for my significant other because of her affiliation with UB and her affinity for all things pink. The water bottle arrived nicely packed - I was a little bit worried about dings to the bottle en route, thankfully it arrived in perfect shape. The pink hue actually looks better in person. It's a bit more matte than the product photo might suggest. The UB logo is a bit more subtle as well. Overall, the bottle looks very elegant with an industrial design flair. Most importantly, the SO loves it!

First and foremost, Piano Master is a game and not a teaching tool. It's just like Guitar Hero, in that you score by mashing the right keys in the correct sequence. Due to the nature of the piano, which actually have keys as opposed to guitars, I suppose there is some value of this as a guide for playing very simple versions of the included songs on the real piano if you really wanted to.As a game, this is actually surprisingly entertaining. I like how customizable it is - you can choose different difficulty levels, number of keys shown (for different screen sizes I guess), what in-game messages and notices you prefer to see, etc. I counted 44 songs, and it looks like the developer is still actively updating periodically with new songs. If that's not enough, you can purchase more song packs that cover various genre of music.The game is clean without any extraneous advertising codes, and I didn't encounter any ads while playing. It does include Google Analytics, which is used to anonymously track the app's usage and performance for further development. The only permissions requested are for internet access, which is most likely for the links that take you to the song packs on the app store.Overall, if you like piano and enjoy Guitar Hero, this could be worth a look.

Joinz is a mix between 2048 and Tetris. I think it has great promise, but ultimately falls short due to an unnecessarily difficult game design that pushes it from being challenging to frustrating.GAMEPLAY & CONTROLYou slide around blocks trying to match the three goal shapes given to you at the top of the screen. Each slide moves the block as far as it will go in the desired direction. If there's nothing between the block and the opposing wall, it won't stop in the middle or any where in between. Once you got the blocks aligned, you join them by swiping them together. They then disappear and you get more blocks to play with, Repeat until you run out of space to maneuver.The control works fine, but the game desperately needs an undo button. This is certainly a cerebral game and requires lots of planning, etc. One bad move and you can potentially ruin the entire board. Being able to undo, even if it's only one step back, would make this game so much more playable and enjoyable.GRAPHICS & SOUNDThe graphics and sound are nice. Very laid back and soothing. You can turn off the music and sound effect if you wish, which is always nice.ADDONS & PERMISSIONSThe game has Chartboost which is an advertising module. I didn't encounter any ads while playing, so it's most likely inactive. It does have flurry analytics for those who care. Permission wise it seems okay, asking to access the internet (probably for social/facebook) and external storage access.The game does stay as an active program for a while even when you exit out via the back button.
