This can potentially lead to unnecessary battery drain.SUMMARYIt's an interesting concept and certainly fun and challenging. The problem is, it might be too challenging. After all, a game is supposed to be fun and enjoyable. If you are a puzzle game guru and looking for a challenge, this is certainly worth a look. For others looking for a more casual experience, this might not be the best fit.

Earn to Die is the original game in a series of Mad Max type driving game. The premise is simple - the world has gone to crap, and you got to get the hell outta dodge and make your way towards the evacuation point (apparently Seattle) or you'll be zombie brunch.GAMEPLAY & CONTROLThere are three game modes (Story, Halloween and Championship). You start out in Story mode with a basic beater car with minimal gas and performance. You start making runs towards your next checkpoint. Along the way, you'll smash into obstacles and zombies. At first, you won't make it very far because your car sucks and you have hardly any gas. But no worries - you earn money each run for the distance traveled and number of zombies smashed. Then you head back to the garage and choose what upgrades you want to put on your car. Be wise in pimping out your ride. For me personally, I prefer to up the tires and gas tank, followed by engine and blades for cutting down zombies. I've realized it's always more effective to upgrade to the next car instead of pimping out your current car. But since they get exponentially more expensive, it's up to you to find the right balance between saving up for the next car or pimp out your current ride. Decision, decisions!Control is achieved via virtual buttons in the lower corners of the screen. Your right thumb controls the gas pedal and boost (if you have it), and your left thumb controls tilting back and forth (popping wheelies, etc). They work very well, and it took me about 5 runs before the control became second nature to me.GRAPHICS & SOUNDThe game looks very good, even though it's a somewhat dated game. Everything from your car to the stage and background looks great with smooth animation. There's ample carnage when you start causing some damage, and the eye candy is matched with appropriately satisfying explosions and other sound effects.ADDONS & PERMISSIONSThis game is completely clean - no extraneous add-ons or ads or even analytics! The only required permissions are for internet and network state, presumably for the links that take you to facebook/twitter and the developer's sequel to this game. This is how a paid app should be.SUMMARYEarn to Die is a fun game with an intuitive gameplay and great eye and ear candy. Warning - it's very addictive. The clean design without any extraneous add-ons or permissions is what all paid apps should be. I think it's worth the $1.19 price of admission (I believe Google Play has it for $1.49), and as today's free app of the day, you should definitely check it out yourself.

Floristry is a straight-forward adaptation of the -istry game format with a flowery flair, complete with soothing classical numbers serving as background music.GAMEPLAY & CONTROLThe goal is to clear the entire cube two small blocks at a time by matching cells with identical flowers. You can rotate the cube freely in 3D space by swiping in your desired direction. To select or deselect a block, simply tap it once. Tap another block with identical flower design on it and watch them beautifully disintegrate into nothingness. The tapping was surprisingly accurate on both small and large screen devices (HTC One M9, One M7, LG Realm) ranging from 4.5" to 5.0". The game almost always registered the right block. There's various modes of gameplay (puzzle, flower attack, stationary camera, one minute, five minutes, ten minutes) that presents different challenges and adds to the replay value. The only minor detail missing is that pressing back on the game's home screen doesn't seem to exit out of the game completely.GRAPHICS & SOUNDThe graphics is nicely done, with buttery smooth rotations and animations throughout. This was the case even on older devices like the LG Realm. The cube with all the flowers at first glance can be somewhat overwhelming, but it's not bad once you start playing. The background music is a nice collection of classical scores that you'll find familiar and pleasing. And you can turn the music and sound effects up or down as desired.ADD-ONS & PERMISSIONSThe game is very clean with no extraneous or unnecessary add-ons. There's the requisite Amazon licensing and login, as well as Amazon insights (analytics) and GameCircle (social gaming). There are no leftover modules for ads, and I did not encounter any ads during testing. The app only requires permission for internet access and network state - presumably for accessing services like GameCircle if you so choose. This is how a paid app should be.SUMMARYFloristry is a fun little matching game with nice graphics and music and accurate control. There's no extraneous add-ons or required permissions. All in all, if you like matching games and flowers, you should definitely give it a try. It's a certainly fairly priced at $0.99. As today's free app of the day, it's worth a quick download to see for yourself.

Matchblocks is an interesting game - at first glance, I thought it was going to be yet another Bejeweled type match game clone. I quickly realized it's actually a cool hybrid that crosses two classic games - Tetris and Simon Says (the color matching toy from the 80s). Sounds intriguing? Well read on folks - unless you're partially or completely color blind, that is...GAMEPLAY & CONTROLThe game's premise is simple - blocks of various lengths fall down like Tetris, and the game's over when you don't clear them off the screen fast enough. To do so, you have to click the colors at the bottom in the order they appear on the blocks. A white dot appears in the blocks whose color you've tapped. For example, in the accompanying title pic, you've already tapped blue and purple - you have to tap teal next to clear this block. You can start at either end of each block, i.e. with this example, you could also tap teal, purple and blue to clear it. If you tapped purple by accident, you can clear your selection by tapping purple again. The number of blocks on screen gradually ramp up as you clear levels and move up in difficulty. Basically, it's like the Simon color matching toy, but with multiple patterns presented to you simultaneously in block form a la Tetris. The tricky part is, your clicks register on ALL the blocks simultaneously. So one pattern might clear one or multiple blocks. When I first started playing I felt like I was randomly pressing different color combinations and hoping for the best. I found that you just have to pick the block that's got the easiest pattern and focus on clearing it. This gets challenging quickly as the game ramps up in difficulty and pace.You also get "obstacles" which are white circles with various number of dots in them. These number of dots indicates how many times you have to tap each obstacle to get rid of it. There are also bonuses and "bombs" that will clear all blocks off the screen immediately.There are four game modes - Classic, Arcade, Time and Zen. I am not quite sure about the difference between classic and arcade, except for the running bar at the top for arcade. In Time mode, there's a running clock represented by the green bar at the top. In Zen mode, you choose how many colors and the difficulty stays constant, so you can keep playing without too much stress.GRAPHICS & SOUNDThe graphics is decidedly retro. Even the menu and help sections have the 8-bit look to them, which was a nice touch. One complaint I have is the choice of colors. The lime green and pale yellow are too similar in my opinion, and I tested it on several devices with good quality screen (HTC One M9, LG G2, LG Volt). I can only imagine this issue being more pronounced on devices that have AMOLED screens, where the colors are inaccurate to start out with.The sound isn't too bad - elevator music with clean sound effects that provide good feedback on your inputs.ADD-ONS & PERMISSIONSThe game has a couple add-ons that might be somewhat worrisome - AdMob and Chartboost (ads), Amazon in-app billing, Flurry. I didn't encounter any ads while playing, so those ads modules are most likely inactive and leftover from the free version. I didn't encounter any in-app purchases either, except for the links to other games by the same developer. Flurry is mostly harmless as long as the developer only uses it for innocuous app analytics (performance, etc).The required permissions are internet access and read/write access to external storage. They are most likely used to link to the developer's other games as well as sharing scores via Amazon Game Circle - should be harmless.Pressing back will eventually close the game completely - I like that.SUMMARYThis is an interesting hybrid of two classic games. It's easy to pick up and play with virtually no learning curve, yet it can get challenging fairly quickly. The color choices could have been better to improve visibility. The developer hasn't updated the game in more than two years - most likely there won't be any more updates. As it stands, it's a fun game that's decently priced. As today's free app of the day, I think it's worth a try.

My significant other was complaining about how dark her apartment's front door is, and after extensive research I decided to give these solar LED lights from Mpow a try. Here's my take a few weeks after installation:BUILD QUALITYThe lights came in good quality packing complete with a quick user's guide, mounting screws and a pin for the on/off switch (a thin needle will do just fine if you lose the pin). The LED lights themselves are enclosed in a thick plastic housing and feel solidly built - I was expecting worse quality to be honest, so this was a pleasant surprise. The manufacturer quotes a IP64 weather proof rating. This means they certify the lights to be completely dust proof and immune to water splashing in any direction. We've a had a few thunderstorms and one torrential downpour since installation couple weeks ago. So far, the lights are working perfectly.INSTALLATIONI didn't use the included mounting screws. Instead, I used one of those 3M double sided stickers that's rated for holding up 3lbs to put it up near the front door. Single sticker does the job easily, as expected. Was a little tricky making sure the unit received enough sun exposure. You turn the unit on/off by inserting the included pin into the small pin hole to the right of the motion sensor. The light will flash once or twice when you turn it on. Push again to turn the unit off.LIGHTING AND MOTION SENSOR COVERAGEThe motion sensor works as advertised, triggering "high beam" when there's any movement within the 10 ft/120 degree area in front of the light. After 10 seconds of inactivity, the light falls back to "low beam". The sensitivity was great - if anything it's ever so slightly too sensitive, which isn't an issue for us. I charged up the lights for an entire day before installation. So far, the lights have stayed lit by bedtime. Since it's already light out by the time I get up, I haven't had a chance to verify if it's staying up the entire night. I'll update with an answer if and when I get up early enough one of these days!The light produced by one unit is good enough to illuminate the front door at high beam. However, the color of the light is a bit off from the pictures in the description. My girlfriend's initial reaction the first night she saw the lights in action was that they made her apartment look like a haunted house - eerie was the word that came to mind. This was because when on low beam, which is most of the time, these units produce light that's quite purplish - it's way over the blue-ish tint that I typically associate with the 6500K CFLs in our kitchen. On high beam, the light is a bit whiter, though definitely still more purple than blue. It was bad enough that the GF actually wanted them taken down. Caveat numero uno.The other caveat is somewhat related to the color of the light, and that is the inability to turn off the always-on low light mode. I like the always-on mode, since it adds to overall visibility and safety. But the color of the low beam is just purplish enough to make me wish there's a choice to turn off the low beam mode while leaving the high beam intact. So, the light would be off normally, but the motion sensor would trigger the high beam when there's activity. Alas, that's currently not an option. Caveat numero dos.SUMMARYThis is a well built Solar LED light that has good sensitivity in its motion sensor and good illumination with its high beam. It also has survived multiple thunderstorms unscathed, supporting its IP64 rating. Installation was painless. However, the color temperature of the produced light is definitely eerily purplish, especially with the always-on low beam. This combined with the lack of ability to turn off the always-on low beam mode may be annoying enough for some people. If these two points don't bother you, then I certainly recommend you take a close look at these.UPDATE 6/20/2015: I've had to get up earlier the past week and I noticed the light actually runs out of juice around 5 am. It's still dark enough that I don't think it's being turned off by the light sensor. The way that I have it positioned, it gets direct sunlight from noon to around 3:30pm or so, and this is during June. Will update during winter later this year.Also, last night I noticed the torrential downpour was triggering the motion sensor, causing the light to run at high beam almost continuously. I don't think this is a negative per se - just means the sensor is that sensitive. Of course, this probably means the light will be out of juice earlier in the night than usual.UPDATE 8/30/2015: with the days getting shorter, the number of hours of direct sunlight on the light has decreased accordingly. I've noticed that the light going dead shortly after midnight several times now, presumably due to insufficient charging. Lesson - definitely position these for the direct sunlight - indirect exposure is definitely not enough to keep it charged up.

At first glance, Amazing Breaker looks to yet another game where its best quality is the pretty eye candy. After playing through the first few levels, I found myself unable to put the phone down - the gameplay while basic and intutive is surprisingly addictive and fun!DESIGN & GAMEPLAYPremise of the game is simple - you're supplied with certain number of bombs for each level, and your goal is to destroy as much of the glassy object as possible using your ammo stash. To advance to the next level, you must destroy at least 90% of the object (you can see your progress in the counter in the lower right hand corner). As new bombs are introduced, there's a quick tutorial at the beginning of each level showing you how they work. Controlling the bombs is easy with good precision. Scoring is similar to games like Angry Birds - you earn points as well as stars (one to three) for each level. There are 6 stages with 20 levels each, for a total of 120 levels. I am guestimating the average gamer would take probably a few hours to complete the game. The replay value is very good since the star system serves as good motivation for going through completed levels in an attempt to get perfect 3-stars in all of them.The gameplay is surprisingly addictive and satisfying, especially when you get a good combo detonation that takes out a good chunk of your target. Great stress reliever!GRAPHICS & SOUNDThe game has some very nice eye candy - the targets look sharp, colorful and great. The various bombs look great too, and they are accompanied by very nice explosion animations and sound effects. The music is nice - I thought it was nice fit, not too frantic but not too slow either. Overall, the audio visual effects come together nicely for a very satisfying experience.ADD-ONS & PERMISSIONSThe included add-ons and required permissions are innocuous as far as I can tell. It includes Amazon licensing, Amazon Insights (analytics), Game Circle (online scoreboard) and no ads module whatsoever. The permissions are for internet and wifi access. These network accesses are most likely needed for the social networking (Facebook & Twitter included if you like sharing) as well as crash reports. The total installed size is about 52MB.SUMMARYAmazing Breaker is a fun way to kill a few minutes, especially if you need some stress relief. I encountered no ads and no crashes while playing through the game. I did encounter installation problem on both of my test devices (HTC One M9 and LG G4), but I think it might have been related to the Amazon Appstore. For $0.99, I think it's a great value. As today's free app of the day, it's definitely worth a look!

I've bought multiple packs of this for my extra sensitive nose over the past two years, and I can say with 100% confidence that it works just as well as its brand name counterpart Sudafed PE. Both have the same active ingredient, phenylephrine HCL, in the same concentration of 10 mg per tablet. The filler material does differ, but those are suppose to be inactive by design and should not affect the drug's efficacy. This is my first line of defense against running nose. Usually this combined with claritin or zyrtec does a pretty good job clearing up my sinus. There are occasions where my allergy or sinus is particularly bad and this doesn't do much. For those cases, I'll bring out my "big gun" or pseudoephedrine ("original" sudafed) before following up with this as maintenance.I've encountered no side effects whatsoever over the past two years on this, although this obviously will depend on each individual user since everyone's body chemistry is slightly different. The large 72-count box is now on my regular shopping list on Amazon. I would definitely recommend trying this out if you're looking for an inexpensive alternative to Sudafed PE.

I got this on sale with a coupon that Amazon periodically makes available. It works fine just like any other toothpaste that I've used in the past (Colgate and Arm & Hammer). The Crest's texture was noticeably different - it's a bit looser with what feels like small globules or particles in a somewhat thinner paste compared to what I've been used to. It's not a problem per se, just different. The only minor issue is the taste. It's minty, but tastes a bit too synthetic for me.Overall, no problem and the active ingredients are comparable to other similar toothpastes.

I purchased a pair of these to replace the wipers on my '96 Pontiac Firebird. GM had designed the '93 to '97 4th Gen F-body (Camaro and Firebird) with a wiper attachment hook that's reversed 180 degrees compare to most cars out there. This makes finding suitable wipers very, very difficult. According to Amazon, these wipers are one of the few that fits properly. When I installed them and they actually fit (you have to remove the preinstalled hook attachment and put in the included larger J hook first), I was about to break out my happy dance. But alas, it was not to be. The wipers ended up losing contact with the lower 30% of the windshield shortly after the wiping motion starts. I tried moving the hook position and adjusting the wiper blades to give it more curvature and tension, but it was not to be. For the area that does make contact, the wipers do a great job - I noticed no streaking and absolutely no noise. This would be a five star product if it actually fitted properly. I wish there's a way to contribute and correct Amazon's database for the fit with regards to '93 to '97 camaro and firebirds with these wipers.If you're looking for replacement wipers for a 4th gen F-body, I suggest looking at the Trico 24-9R. I bought a pair of those and they fit perfectly, wiping the entire windshield throughout the wiping motion.

As pointed out by some of the other reviewers, the Trico 24-9R wipers are the exact OEM replacement for the 4th gen F-body (Camaro and Firebird) from '93 to '97. In yet another brilliant design decisions by GM, the wiper hooks on the 4th gen F-body were a reverse J-hook. As a result, most wiper blades simply won't fit or will be turned 180 degrees. There are few that fits, such as the Rain-X weatherbeaters, but they end up missing parts of the windshield. I've literally tried just about every wiper available in my local Advanced Auto and Autozone, and the Trico 24-9Rs are the only ones that work perfectly.If you have a '93 to '97 Camaro or Firebird and need new wipers, this is it! Even better is that Trico sells wiper refills for $7 per pair. They fit perfectly and are a very cost effective - not to mention environmentally firendly - way to restore your wiper performance.

Have had several Yamaha receivers, and this one was a much-needed update from my RX-V663. Some of the latest (for this model) improvements are miles ahead of older (five years or more) models.The great things:1. Android/iOS apps are great. They offer superb functionality and control from anywhere in the home network. The UIs are similar so jumping from one device to another isn't a huge paradigm shift. The UIs also display album art and other controls depending upon the connected input device (USB, Pandora, AirPlay, etc).2. HDMI -CEC support is great. Even without programming other components into the remote (which is advisable, as menu, display, return buttons function on BD players), the remote can control other devices.3. Web control from any computer, Chromebook, or tablet in the house is just as handy. An undocumented setup URL to the receiver, exposing all the configuration options, is outstanding. No more searching the manual for the three-fingered salute method of getting to advanced settings.4. On-screen displays and information are great. You can enable or disable on-screen short messages. Missing, though is the display of input channels regardless to selected output DSP or processor. So to determine if a disc is giving me a 2.0 input, I have to enable the on-screen information. Previously (RX-V663) the front display indicated how many channels the receiver got from the HDMI or digital audio connection.5. Assignment of audio and video inputs. Ability to rename inputs (change "AV2" to "Xbox" or "HDMI2" to "Chromecast").6. Scene presets. Great to reprogram for a favorite, oft-used input like Chromecast, USB, Airplay. (See below regarding USB input.)7. HDMI pass-through. Don't worry if you don't know what this is. It allows a TV to show what's on a Blu-ray disc player without the amplifier being on; it will switch the input and "pass it on" while still in Standby mode.8. Multiple HDMI OUT. You can use #2 for a second monitor, or audio to a sound device, e.g. a sound bar. (HDMI OUT 1 has HDMI ARC, or Audio Return Channel, which carries Dolby Digital or DTS audio from the TV to the amplifier. HDMI ARC does NOT carry high def audio formats from the TV to the receiver! Many people make the assumption that they can plug their BD player in the TV and carry the Dolby TrueHD or DTS-HD back to the amp.)9. Multi-channel pre-outs (The RX-V675 does not feature these).10. Two LFE subwoofer outputs. For a medium- to full-size home theater, two subwoofers are recommended.Shortfalls:1. Airplay can barely get through a second song before disconnecting. Tested with iPod Touch and iPad under iOS 7.x, 8.x. Worthless.2. Pandora loses access to the service and give an "Access error" regularly. Tapping OK it recovers, but you shouldn't have to. (Comparison: my Samsung SmartTV plays Pandora for hours on end.) Under previous firmware, I had to turn off Network Standby (always on the network), cycle power, and connect again. I no longer have to completely shut it down, but disconnections are frequent. Since the last firmware update (1.60/2.13) songs will start to stutter, and the software on the receiver will just skip to the next song. This is even more of an annoyance.So far that's two Net functions that fail. I have a Netgear Nighthawk R6700 router, the receiver is connected by a b/g/n router acting as a wireless bridge, the receiver has a static IP address, and I've tried numerous DNS nameservers (Google public, my ISP, my domain host), no improvement.3. No video up-conversion from 480p or 1080i component video (RGB) in to HDMI out. My RX-V663 did this, so dropping it from a 700-series amp is a needless cost-cutting measure. I'd have to get the RX-A1030 or better to restore this upscaling. Is this critical? No, component video sources are getting antiquated, and this unit has oodles of HDMI IN connections. Still, it's an embarrassment that a RX-V775 must have a separate component video connection to the flat screen.4. On-screen display of the analog (component) video is "???" for 480p or 1080i. Oddly, it's happy with 480i. This is just stupid. I have to use the receiver because I have two devices with component video input.5. USB input cannot be selected with the input selection knob; it doesn't automagically switch to USB when you connect a compatible device. You HAVE to select the "USB" button on the remote. Silly, since you're likely to be plugging something in at the front of the receiver and need a way to switch to it. Workaround: reprogram a SCENE button for the USB if you use it regularly.6. The manual continues a tradition of not really explaining some of the options well. Eco modes? Tried it, disliked it, never looked at it again.7. Lack of wi-fi connectivity. (Later models have this built-in.) You either connect via CAT5 Ethernet, or buy a separate dongle. (Yamaha has an expensive one, but search for a "wi-fi to Ethernet adapter," you'll find lots in affordable price ranges, particularly small ones designed for gaming.)BOTTOM LINEFor a model that's a few years out of date (the RX-V777 is the current model as I write this), this should be a bargain where you find it (I presume you're reading this review while researching the model). Depending upon the deal, it may be a lot of receiver for the money, or a second-rate choice next to another purchase option. The network features can be very handy, but the only ones I've found 100% reliable were the web and mobile device controls, DLNA and local area network server are satisfactory in my limited use. As a basic central control for a hi-fi, the RX-V line are good value, and the RX-V675 and RX-V775 offer a lot of flexibility.

Badda-bing-bing-bang-bang ... Popcorn!  The last DVD release of this wasn't 16:9 enhanced, which means ... letter-boxed. Pffft.  Finally Cusack's mid-1990s hit is in true high def. I've always loved this film, the dialog is just snap, crackle, and pop full of witticisms, double entendres, quips, allusions. I found Grosse Pointe Blank better than the later, "spiritual sequel" War, Inc. The creators here just had the right elements, creativity, and inventiveness for this film. The new Blu-Ray transfer isn't stellar, but this is a 20 year old film, it's not going to look perfect. The audio is great, hearing the soundtrack clearly is important here. Worth getting if you love the film, or just want to reacquaint yourself."Thanks for the pen."

A great late 90s concert video, and a better bargain than the US$15.99 CD (which has fewer songs, albeit different cuts). You can do as I do, just put it in the DVD player and turn off the TV after starting main video. Some nice little extras too, including multiple angle options on some songs. The latter allows you to select one camera for the whole song (e.g. side to side pan, close on Sarah, wide static shot of stage); you can get motion sickness from the constantly-on-the-move camera, but just watching the singer instead of cutting is a nice change of pace.

Beautiful game, particularly casting to a Chromecast or Fire TV device. The game isn't very difficult, but beautiful and relaxing to play. Some may feel the game is short, but I think quality counts over quantity. I'll take a shorter, more thoughtful game like this to a 30-stage bonanza like Angry Birds or Plants vs. Zombies.

This is a review of the 2003 single-disc release ASIN:B00005JKFR, which includes extras apparently from the Laserdisc release. The "restoration comparison" compares a 1993 film transfer (warts 'n all) against a "1995 Laserdisc release." One of the interviewees on the 80-minute "Making the Earth Stand Still" documentary mentions "this Laserdisc release." The headline for my review is a result of reading reviews of the 2008 release (DVD and BD, timed for the remake release) that identify that "Making the Earth Stand Still" is missing, replaced by a shorter piece. The later 2-disc release may be missing the bazillion production photos in the stills gallery as well.So if you're getting the later BD release, compare the price with the 2008 remake 3-disc BD release that includes a BD of the original 1951 film (no extras), and get the cheaper of the two, and find a copy of this two-sided DVD release for the extras.

I love this film, and would like to see the longer version. For the price on Amazon, I sprung for "owning" the instant video version, and was disappointed to find that it's an SD master of a pan 'n scan earlier video release (like they did a cheap master of a VHS tape). So presentation here sucks mightily, but still it's a delight to be able to watch the film on demand without investing in a VHS player.

Good budget case for an iPad Mini. Not very fancy or highly finished, just very functional. I'm happy I have it so that I have a rugged case for tough circumstances that I don't want to  subject my Logitech Ultrathin Keyboard Folio case to.

Predator (Ultimate Hunter Edition) is anything but Ultimate. The 2-disc collector's edition DVD release looked okay, sounded fine, and had so many interesting remembrance interviews, production filming interviews, photos, outtakes, hilarious stories from cast and crew, you name it. The previous BD release left those out inexplicably -- probably so Fox could rerelease again and make more money. Talk about being greedy! So now they release a BD version of the collector's edition, called Ultimate Hunter Edition here, and ... oh no. They did something awful. The reviews on BD review sites are right, the digital noise reduction used on this remaster was turned up to 11, so to speak, resulting in a removal of benign film grain, and in some scenes even details that were captured on film. In some shots, you can't tell - the details are crisp, but in other shots there is such a blurring of the image and loss of details that it looks like one of those pics that people do artistic treatments on in Photoshop. Those pics don't look like the original, and in some shots Predator doesn't look like the film I saw in theaters all those years ago. It's overbaked. Whoever did this just wasn't paying attention to their work.It's known that the stock wasn't ideal for the filming conditions, they were filming in pretty difficult location circumstances, so there was visible grain, loss of focus,... it added to the film. This was a perfect production, but the combined talents of all parties involved made the film bigger and better than it looked. That's part of PREDATOR's charm. You can make a brilliant, original film on low budget and tech (e.g. PRIMER), while Michael Bay makes boring, predictable fluff with unlimited resources. Trying to change how the film looked on its original camera negative is just blundering revisionist history.It's a great disc to get for the extras, many of which are also in HD (nice, Fox). Nice menu design, etc.  But the remastering of the film is awful, Fox ought to be ashamed (particularly considering how great the latest ALIEN remaster is, crisp and clear and looking like it was filmed yesterday, but without any noticeable image "enhancement." I'm tempted to get the 2008 BD since reviewers claim it's not the best the technology offered in 2008, but at least the film wasn't overbaked. I got this for $4.99 at Best Buy during Christmas shopping, so I wouldn't consider it a waste of money. But if you're looking for the best value in a single disc for this film, wait for Fox to correct the transfer in a future release, or get the 2008 BD.For those will claim that my results are attributable to a badly adjusted TV, or Blu-Ray settings turned up high, no. My BD player has all enhancements and tweaks turned off so that only the plain disc content is sent to the TV. My Samsung ES6150 LED TV is also adjusted to accurate color representation, with all enhancement and "correction" options turned off for BD viewing.

** See my update below **Very nice case for the Mini. Thin, light, holds the tablet very securely. Seems very durable. Super stong magnet will hold it in the easel position for quite a while, even while tapping on the screen (a lot of case makers forget that these devices have TOUCH screens).The bad news, and no surprise here, is that the keyboard for a 7" table is going to be quite petite. Keys are as big as they could make them, but some design shortcuts to fit them all in this form factor are baffling. The super small backspace/delete button is hardly there.There are numerous function keys that work in iOS 8.1, but the nifty keys to change keyboard (8 supports third party keyboards; I'm a Swiftkey devotee) and make the onscreen keyboard appear or disappear are inconsistent.If you can get a good deal on this case, you oughtn't be disappointed. But don't expect this to make your Mini a laptop replacement. It's still a 7" tablet.August 2015 update: I'm on my second unit now. Why? The bracket which covers the power button is very weak due to the cut out power button. If you accidentally flex that corner to remove the iPad, or forget to insert the ipad in that corner FIRST and THEN snap it into the other bracket at the bottom (the "home button end"), you will break the bracket with the iPad's power button. The iPad can slide ever so slightly out of the brackets during use, it's easy to slide it back up, but when this one bracket is broken, the iPad slide more easily, and the power button is held down, prompting for the Shut down screen.Logitech should design this bracket better. Since only two of them hold the iPad Mini in place, they need to be sturdy and resilient to stress. An easily broken piece of plastic ruins this product. TAKING OFF TWO STARS.

Great shave cream. The fragrance was a bit weak for the first shaves (about an inch of the tube), but as I use it more, the scent has blossomed. It's a very nice, refreshing scent, nice contrast to Musgo Real Classic. The cream forms a rich, smooth lather, great for double-edged blade shaving. It's also a pretty good value, dollar for ounce. I recommend it without reservation.

Newly restored yet again from its late 1990s re-release, this Blu-Ray features a better image quality than audiences enjoyed from the original 35mm release. I believe all the extras from the 1999 DVD release are here ... EXCEPT the isolated music track. It was a joy to hear Sir George Martin's orchestral score in Dolby Digital 5.1 without dialog or sound FX tracks. This newer super-duper ultimate release is missing the music-only track, costing it a star. Oh sure, this is a superb way to enjoy the movie on an HDTV, but when studios leave off extras that they already have prepared and have released, you wonder just what they must think of us customers.

The newly released Blu-Ray & DVD release (2012) adds further image restoration and mastering to supersede this restored 1999 release. So why purchase this earlier disc? The isolated music track. Presented in Dolby Digital 5.1, Sir George Martin's superb orchestral soundtrack sits center stage where you can appreciate his flourishes and counterpoint to the visuals. It's a treat to simply screen the film without dialog or sound FX, instead enjoying the visuals with the music, only the music, playing.One star off for this early (?) DVD not being 16:9 enhanced, requiring you to zoom your HDTV in to be full-screen.

After splashing on some Lucky Tiger After Shave and Face Tonic, this simple but effective moisurizer seals in, well, moisture, so your face doesn't dry out. After washing, soaking in a a shave cream, scraping off a layer of skin, then splashing an astringent, the face easily dries out post-shave. A balm like this restores its natural ability to keep the moisture in and not turn to leather. If you don't use a combination after-shave balm (has both the astringent, disinfecting and soothing ingredients, and a moisturizer), then this is the ticket, particularly if you use Lucky Tiger Bay Rum After Shave (which I come to like as both after-shave and after-shower splash).See my "So you want to shave like a pro" guide for more suggestions and above-average products.
Works very well with my Nexus Qi Wireless Charger ("orb") (2012) and a Nexus 7 tablet. Solid charger, great price.

The original soft nibs are gentle and let you drag them easily about the screen. I found that in regular, and I do mean REGULAR use, genuine Wacom nibs last almost a year.If you prefer a firmer nib for  Bamboos,*  you want the ACK20601 (firm)  replacement nibs.* Old Solo (CS100K), Old Duo (CS110K), Pocket (CS200S) and Alpha (CS130K and CS130W)

This is a great set of high quality shaving products. Gentle face wash to prep, liquid shave cream to lubricate and keep the beard wet (works best with a badger shave brush), after shave tonic to soothe and disinfect the face, and moisturizer to protect and retain moisture. Has a great refreshing scent that harkens back to old times. Comes in a neat, reusable tin. Got this as a Christmas gift and immediately ran upstairs to get out of my bathrobe and try it out.  Gf approved of the results. ;)If, like me, you want to replenish these as they run out, here are the individual products:Lucky Tiger Face Wash, 8 OunceLucky Tiger Liquid Cream Shave, 5 OunceLucky Tiger After Shave and Face Tonic, 8 OunceLucky Tiger Premium Facial Moisturizer, 3.4 OunceI only wish they offered this fresh, citrus and clove fragrance as a cologne. Without my beloved Bay Rum, I've been left to wander the wilderness of contemporary men's fragrances, many of which appall me.UPDATE:Here's my shaving routine, derived from Charles Hix' LOOKING GOOD, barber instruction, and decades of experience.- Wash the face with a gentle cleanser (not bar soap, which can dry the skin) to wet and soften the beard, then rinse with lots of warm water.- Lather up with a good shaving cream (or shaving soap, if you must), using a pure badger brush and bowl. Cream is better because it will retain moisture better (keeping the beard wet), lubricate the blade as it passes, and even protect the skin a little. Some soaps are specially formulated to perform similarly. The real test is, does the blade slide easily across your face as whiskers are sliced off? Does your face feel any discomfort? Does your face dry after the blade has passed? Do you have to keep reapplying lather even before you've passed the blade on that area?- Rinse the blade of whiskers frequently in a sink with standing fresh water. (Don't leave the water running, it's wasteful.)- Done? Rinse the face with handfuls of warm water until all the cream and cut whiskers are gone. DON'T DRY OFF. Leave the water on to rehydrate your face. Be careful not to wash the small cut whiskers into your eyes.- Rinse the shaving stand of lather if necessary. Rinse the razor thoroughly, let it air dry with the blades up to dry first. Rinse the badger brush THOROUGHLY in warm water, until clean. Shake out the excess water (you could even gently towel it dry if you're traveling), let dry with the bristles down (you don't want water pooling at the handle). Set razor and brush aside to air dry.- Dry the excess water off your face. Apply an after shave tonic or lotion. The best products will not have much alcohol or any alcohol at all, as this stings and dries the face. Straight witch hazel is an economical alternative. An after shave tonic should not have much fragrance (fragrances are often based on alcohol), but based on something soothing like witch hazel or other light astringents. Other ingredients will vary. Some after shaves will have some additives to sooth and protect, others will be so light as to dry quickly. All should perform the same duty: soothe, disinfect, protect, and maybe have an appealing scent that doesn't linger.- Apply a moisturizer or after shave BALM. After shave balms may combine the soothing and disinfecting ingredients of an after shave TONIC with a moisturizer for a one-step solution. The primary use of a balm is to moisturize, or rather (since the water you rinsed with hydrated the skin) LOCK IN the moisture you've already applied. There should be no need to wipe or rinse off the after shave tonic; its ingredients will continue to sooth and heal your face. You needn't use a fancy, expensive moisturizer. Aveeno, Oil of Olay, and Neutragena make excellent products that won't cost you too much.- Work the moisturizer into your face to protect it from outside elements. Towel off excess oil if there is any (there oughtn't be, in my view).- Apply a modicum of fragrance (cologne or eau de toilette) sparingly to the warm zones of your neck where you HAVEN'T shaved (the alcohol will reverse all the good you've just effected with care and good products!). Listen up: less is more where great colognes are concerned. A cologne that dissipates and can't be detected an hour later is a rip-off. Ladies will appreciate your cologne if it's barely perceptible ... until they snuggle in close.Some confuse "after shave" with cologne or fragrance. Wrong. They have entirely different compositions and purposes. An "after shave" that is loaded with alcohol and fragrance is either mislabled, or a lousy product. That famous HOME ALONE poster image is a case of a little boy thinking that cologne is slapped on your freshly washed (and highly vulnerable) face. Resist the temptation for self-mutilation and stick to a proper after shave tonic or balm.See my "How to shave like a pro" guide for more great products.

(Disclosure: Lucky Tiger/Barbicide sent me a bottle to sample and review.)Caswell-Massey has discontinued my favorite fragrance, a refined and lasting Bay Rum cologne branded Michelsen's Bay Rum. This leaves a huge void in my medicine cabinet. Shame on you, Caswell-Massey, you've been culling my medicine cabinet staples for years....Enter Lucky Tiger.... Lucky Tiger is an American barbershop brand of men's grooming products, produced since 1935. They were hugely popular in the 1950s. Their packaging and "branding" is retro and attractive. I've used  the Lucky Tiger premium line of shaving gear, since receiving  their Lucky Tiger Grooming Gift Set for Christmas, and falling in love with the quality, fragrance, and value for money that each product offers. Their liquid shave cream and after shave tonic  are excellent products for the price. A morning shave with Lucky Tiger really starts the day out with some panache.This Bay Rum after shave splash is part of their "barbershop classics" line. As an after shave, it's great. It contains minimal alcohol, and some soothing ingredients that will ease your face after a wet blade shave and prior to adding a moisturizer. (By itself it will not protect and moisturize, which is important after a close, wet blade shave.) It's a nice alternative to their premium after shave tonic. The 8 oz. bottle should last you for months. The more I've used it, the more I've enjoyed splashing a little extra on after a shower. That's not typically a man thing (or wasn't until AXE invented the fashion of men's "body spray"), but let's get past that. It feels great, and your special lady will like it.Make no mistake, this is not cologne, and does not feature the pungent scent of West Indian bay leaf, lime, clove, and cinnamon  that I've come to love in a quality Bay Rum cologne. Lucky Tiger Bay Rum is agentle after shave tonic, and appropriately has only a very  faint trace of fragrance. This is surprising, because the fresh, citrus-y, clove-y fragrance of the premium Lucky Tiger products is quite nice; I'd be happy with a cologne with that scent. Lucky Tiger Bay Rum has a slightly more bracing feel on the face, more so than their premium after shave tonic due to a little more alcohol.I really like this Lucky Tiger product in its retro, barbershop  style (albeit plastic) bottle,... but my search for a refined Bay Rum cologne  continues. Until then, the Lucky Tiger line of shaving goods continues to make my morning routine a lot classier.See my "How to shave like a pro" guide for more great products.

It was tricky getting it placed just right because it covers the entire screen, but once I had it right, it's been on there permanently. The clear protector doesn't diminish the screen resolution or appearance. I've since bought these for my Nexus 4 and iPod touch. Great value for money.

The iPod Touch runs iOS just like an iPhone. Runs iOS apps just like an iPhone. Has a  great, 16:9 ratio retina display, just like an iPhone. Has a solid CPU like an iPhone (same chip as the 4S). But this device is super-slim and made of elegant materials. It ... just doesn't have a phone.But guess what? Google Hangouts lets you make free (US, some restrictions apply) telephone calls right from the iPod. And you can Facetime just like with an iPhone. So what's to miss? (I have an Android phone so I'm covered on the phone front.)This latest (2013) generation iPod has become my favorite tool for quick snapshots (due to the great camera) and keeping up with social network posts and updates from friends. Now running iOS 7.1 (March, 2014), iPod Touch is as good as having an iPhone for Facetime, iMessage, Facebook, Google+, Google Hangouts, iMusic, Google Play Music, Netflix, HBO Go, Pandora, and everything else. What's more, many of the apps which can "cast" to the Google Chromecast do so from the iPod as well as Android devices. With AppleTV Airplay or Chromecast, you have multiple choices for streaming entertainment.I  recommend this as an economical way for someone to "dip their toes in" to the waters of iOS 7. The crisp screen, great sound, HDMI out capability (with a Apple Lightning Digital AV Adapter), and snappy performance won't disappoint.

I've always loved this film. For Robby, for Leslie Nielsen, for Anne Francis (!), Walter Pigeon, that cool "space cruiser," the weird and imaginative "musical score" (experimental electronic music). ... There's so much to like here, including a rather thoughtful storyline based on Shakespeare's THE TEMPEST.The BD transfer is first rate, and includes many extras including "The Invisible Boy," a B-grade potboiler featuring Robby in another supporting role. The sound on this transfer is great too ... the thrumming notes of the score, and the sound effects, are full-bodied here (within the limitations of the 1950s recording technology).Great price on this disc too, considering all the extras you get on it.

What can I say that the product description doesn't? It works. I like it. It's portable. Great way to hear something (music, podcast, audio book, video) from any portable device. Comes with a nice cover, but it's a little tricky getting it in and out of it.Makes a lot of sound for a little box. A bit bass heavy though.

Okay. Sssshhhhh ... this is one of the secret ingredients I put into a home brew after shave lotion. Just a half a teaspoon or so per 8 oz of witch hazel and other secret ingredients. Don't tell anyone else, okay? Just get some and try it.

I've been using interdental brushes for years now, and get great reports from my dentist. These don't replace flossing, but are a great tool for cleaning some of the interdental spaces that flossing is supposed to clean.You can use these brushes to brush ACT fluoride rinse into the spaces, too -- a great way to ensure you get fluoride into the spaces that can be most vulnerable to cavities.

7:37 MinsI bought a new Bamboo Duo stylus as I'm really pleased with my plain Bamboo Solo Stylus (CS100K). The replaceable soft nibs (and, now, firm nibs for a little more money) are a plus, if you are hard on your stylii.I've had compliments and inquiries on my YouTube Android OS tutorials about the Bamboo Solo. The Duo stylus is about 1/2" longer than the Solo (the cap is longer), so a little more comfortable in the hand. Both stylii have some heft to them (made of brass, apparently), making them comfortable to use. The pocket clip can be removed from both of them making them more comfortable to pick up and hold. The Duo stylus is just as comfortable and nicely finished as the Solo. The pen cap snaps firmly into place over the pen, and the cap sits snug on the stylus end as well (no snap, just a strong fit from the rubber O-ring). (YES, the cap stays put. If you've read reviews that complain about the cap, watch my video all the way through.)Some complain about the nibs, but I'm happy with them. Kept clean, they slide smoothly across my Android and iOS device screens (some with screen protectors). The soft nib smushes pretty well, but the shape of the tip under the nib keeps it in contact with the screen. (Cheaper stylii have foam under the nib, so they can compress all the way to the metal sleeve on the barrel.) The tip actually extends out of the collar, so the nib should not compress all the way to the sleeve.It helps if your screen, and your nib, are clean.Now the bad news.Since purchasing it less than 9 months ago, the Solo received a hairline scratch while in a pocket, and the black finish started flaking off when I rubbed it with a fingernail. Disappointing from something you want to feel good in your hand, and only bought a few months eariler ... Wacom has replaced it under warranty, though! Worth considering when you're choosing between a cheap stylus and this stylus... who's got a warranty to back up their product quality?Now the really bad news.I've read some reviews from buyers who've determined that their Bamboos Duos are counterfeit, and many more reviews from unhappy customers with complaints that indicate their stylus is a counterfeit as well. (E.g. "Pen cap comes off easily," "rubber nib broke after a few days," "pen clip was bent right out of the box.") In my case,  Wacom replaced my counterfeit with a genuine product under RMA (after seeing pics of the counterfeit). Watch my video review for a comparison of the two. If you have questions about the quality of Bamboo stylus, contact Amazon, or Wacom directly via their Support page. Take good photos of your suspected counterfeit Bamboo stylus.In addition to the video review, I've added pics to the product gallery. Take a look at those for more detail views.* If this review has been helpful to you, please click YES so other unhappy buyers can be alerted to the problem. Thanks! *

Does just what you expect: it outputs a iPhone 5 or iPod Touch 5gen video and sound output to an HDMI input. On my HDTV, the image and sound is impeccable, and the lightning input port allows you to charge your iPod while projecting. On a 5V 1A USB port (not computer data grade, but charging grade), my iPod Touch actually charged up while my daughter played Little Inferno and displayed her gameplay on the TV for me to watch. Safari, Maps, Google Earth, everything else I ran displayed just fine on a HDTV.Bonus: HDMI carries sound, so the iPod's audio was passed through the TV via digital (optical) audio connection to my stereo. You gotta love HDMI's all-in-one connection protocol.I ordered from this ASIN and got a true, bona fide Apple product. Make sure the packaging and product that you receive feature valid Apple branding elements. Then connect it up, and have fun.

The marketing for this filter is over the top, but the filter in the box isn't all that much better than a micronAir, Purolator, Fram, or other more affordable brands. It's a good, well-made filter. It's doing the job well. It just doesn't seem appreciably better than any other filter I've bought (including Honda/Acura OEM filters, made by micronAir and sold for between ten and fifty, yes, fifty dollars more than those you find on Amazon).The car makers recommend you replace these filters every 10,000 miles, it keeps your interior air clean and smelling nice. Some dealers charge as much as $60 for a job that takes less than five minutes, no special tools, and can be performed by the owner. Like an engine air filter, the more dirt and detritus that gets lodged in the filter, the less effective it is. I replace mine roughly every year, 15000-18000 miles, after our annual apocalypse of pine pollen that turns everything lemon-green ... so who cares if it's super special and high tech, or just does a credible job of filtering out dirt and pollen? It's a "consumable" that I replace regularly to keep my vehicle up. Spending more money for something like this is not always a good investment ... unless the product is clearly and verifiably better.

This was my bible for Bond, even before Sean Connery fully hung up the holster. I hadn't even seen all the films, so the chapter on OHMSS was beguiling. What WAS that film without Connery? And how bad could it be if (sigh) Diana Rigg was in it, no longer in a leather cat suit a la THE AVENGERS.Updated later, this book is still a great relic of a time when the films weren't totally goofed up. Worth reading if you're a Bond man.

I'm hoping this has the proper fragrance, as my tried and true favorite, Caswell-Massy's Michelson Bay Rum, seems to have died the death of so many of Caswell-Massey's old prduct line.I can't be without Bay Rum. Mixed with witch hazel and some other secret ingredients, it makes a superb, and gentle aftershave lotion. I've only found one or two better. Lucky Tiger after shave is great. But Bay Rum has a distinctive, old fashioned aroma that calls to mind Key West, Hemingway, Cuba, mojitos, swimming in "Stingray City," warm nights dancing in a Puerto Rican discotheque, snapper and fried plaintains, and listening to a hundred coquis singing in the trees.It can also mean going to the Main St. barber shop and nervously getting into the steel and leather chair as all the older, grown men chuckle and rib you about "when you're grown," then go on talking sports or politics or that blonde sauntering by the window. That smell might remind you of grizzled, career barbers who could clipper cut your head with only one eye open, shave your neck, then smack a little this on your to make you feel not quite so young.If none of this means anything to you, might as well just get one of those awful CK fragrances. Many of the expensive, department store colognes smell like a stew of confused smells, anyway. Bay Rum comes from a presumably simpler, but no more innocent time. Things weren't better then, but the memories you have of them mean the world to you. Bay Rum might transport you back.Go ahead and get an old Pan paperback copy of LIVE AND LET DIE and transport yourself to another time, another place.

I've used amFilms before on my Nexus 7, and it's such a perfect fit on the tablet that I was a little concerned about this one. Not to worry, there's a little fudge space on the top and bottom, but after a few tries I had it positioned perfectly.[1] Including three in this pack lets you mess one up as a learning experience, and still have two as backup.Screen protectors aren't there to be pristine, they are there to take the scrapes, scratches and gouges that would otherwise fall upon your screen. After a while, they look beat up -- time to replace it! Offering a 3-pack is a great idea.Note about the fit. Though it's a good fit top to bottom (with cutouts for the front-facing camera and proximity/light sensor), the protector does NOT reach side to side. The Nexus 4 has an innovative "roll off" shape to the glass for usability, and the protector stops just short of the roll off point on the sides. Fault? No!. This prevents the protector from being caught and lifted by cases like the Poetic Palette SLIM Premium Hard Case (see my review) or the Poetic Slimbook Leather Case (yep, I reviewed that, too) that I use regularly. If you want a perfect fit, don't get these. If you want a protector that won't be mucked up by cases or bumpers, get this.The clear protector is hardly noticeable ... really. I hardly notice it.[1] My tips for positioning screen protectors.... Clean the screen with lens cleaner and then compressed air. Use a rolled up inverted roll of Scotch Magic Tape to position and lift off the cover (NOT your fingernails!). Use a fresh roll of tape to remove any motes of dust that get on the underside. Keep using the compressed air if you have to life and reposition. Use a firm, silicone kitchen bowl scraper or spatula to smooth bubbles out. When you've got it near perfect, YOU'RE DONE. Don't ruin a good job trying to get a perfect job, you'll be take the protector off in a year or so anyway.

This is a good value case when you need a bit more protection for your phone. The phone sits securely in a back shell fixed inside this "wallet" type cover, leaving the charge, audio, power, and volume keys accessible (thought the volume keys are a bit hard to get to). Superb fit, the case closes perfectly without any cards or cash in the pockets. The magnetic clasp is pretty firm, but easy to open one-handed (I wouldn't try this over cement, though).As a companion to the Poetic Palette SLIM Case for Google Nexus 4, I really like this. I use either depending upon my attire, where I'm going, how much protection I need for the phone. The phone charges on the LG Nexus 4 wireless charger from Google IF you position it just right, but I'd take it out to charge. I don't use this cover at home like the Palette SLIM case, just for out 'n about.Good product, good price.

Just a quick, placeholder review to tell you to GET THIS COVER. It's very easy to take off and put back on as needed, doesn't come off on its own, covers the fragile glass-like back, gives the side and back a good "grippiness" so it wont' slip and slide like a wet soap bar, and doesn't interfere with the LG Nexus Qi charger from Google.For the price, a great bargain. Good quality.Get this one.

Bullitt is known for its signature (and ground-breaking) car chase sequence. The realism, and use of sound and editing to put the audience right in this escalating duel of muscle cars are a revelation to those who haven't seen it in its entirety, and context in the film.But the entire film, one of several that McQueen developed as personal projects, was a revolutionary in the tired ranks of "cop dramas." The muted storytelling and subtle way in which plot points developed (more reminiscent of European New Wave productions than regular Hollywood output) require more of an audience than simply showing up. You have to listen to dialog, watch the characters, and realize what's going on through deduction. When you do, the car chase becomes nerve-gratingingly suspenseful from the outset. On a double-bill with Le Mans [Blu-ray] you can appreciate that McQueen had a distinctive tone and intelligence that he wanted his star vehicles to convey. It's a pity that he didn't develop more projects like these.The BD comes with several extras, including a superb full-length bio pic on McQueen, and an in-depth feature on movie editing (which includes details about the car chase and other scenes in Bullitt). A period studio featurette on the film, as well as feature commentary from director Peter Yates, round out list of extras.Other reviews complain about the picture quality. Not every BD is a remastered release of studio print material ... So long as it's not the DVD rendering simply reprinted at BD definition, what you get on BD should be fine -- at a certain price point. These "value" BDs don't disappoint me if the rendering and menus are done reasonably well. Compared with the outright terrible The Brothers Grimm [Blu-ray] release, in which colors and definition go haywire in a few spots, this BD of McQueen's signature late 60s production is fine. The colors are consistent and well balanced for the film stock and cinematography of that time.For the current sale price, this BD is a good value IMHO for the devoted fan, or for those who've yet to see this film in its full widescreen, full-range sound presentation (important when you hear that Mustang really rev up).

I won this product from a web site contest, and have been using it regularly for several months. It provides a smooth, reliable charge for my HTC Amaze 4G phone, generally providing about 2.5 full charges from 20% or so.I also found during travels that this battery doubles as a charger. Just plug in, then plug in the  USB/microUSB cord and connect your phone/device. The Amaze uses an OEM 5W-1000mA chargers and takes up to 900mA during a full charge from 10%. This ZaggSPARQ works great in this regard; I've seen it provide up to 600mA of charge, more than sufficient for the phone.  I found it invaluable during air travel, working in remote offices, etc. The Zagg battery generally charges up from 80% depletion (one light lit) in a few short hours. It does seem to charge up even with a phone connecting that's sucking 300mA-600mA from it; as the phone takes less current, the ZAGGsparq charges up faster. So for travel, this doubles as a power source, and an overnight charger for a mobile device.The case is so-so quality. Not very rugged, so I carry it with a microUSB cable in a Case Logic PHDC-1 Portable Hard Drive Case. It fits very nicely, leaving room for a cable or two, and the hard shell of the Case Logic protects the battery from damage.

I love the SwitchEasy products I've bought for my iPod Classic, iPod Nano (3rd gen), and now this. Check my other reviews for yourself. ;)  They give you such a great value for money: case, port plugs, screen protector... In this case, the "nude slim" case for the latest (2012) iPod Touch is superb, it just snaps on to the back, giving you a better grip, protects that neat metal finish, and doesn't interfere with anything. The plugs for the lightning port and earphone jack (two of each!) fit nicely.The screen protector is the weak item in this kit. I'm pretty advanced in applying these to devices, and usually get a zero bubble, zero dust application. But I couldn't do so with these. One was trashed, the other is on with a couple of pieces of dust. I think the problem is their adhesive is stronger than 3M Scotch magic tape, which is my preferred way to remove dust motes that get sucked under the protector. Using compressed air and a microfiber, no-lint wipe most assuredly cleaned the screen, but the SwitchEasy screen protector just wouldn't come clean. Repeated attempts to roll off the dust ended up deforming the first of the two included in this. So, one star penalty.If you get a Moshi or other brand screen film, then this kit is still a bargain. I'd give another five star review but for that one glitch.

Tarsem Singh knows how to give us a gorgeous film. And the set design, costume design (the last film work of visionary Eiko Ishioka), cinematography, all make this a visual feast for the eyes. The script, though very witty and smart, ends up with a rather predictable plot. What made me continue to watch was the production values and the cocktail party way in which the film plays with our expectations of the classic "Snow White and Seven Dwarves" tale, making fun of the original, with other retellings, and a film version. Fortunately, the film doesn't very often parody itself, so it remains true unto its own world. There are tons of puns and jokes and reverse twists that remind me of THE PRINCESS BRIDE, and I'm sure the filmmakers were well versed in the Rob Reiner classic.Entertaining to the very end, the credits begin with a Bollywood-style music video that would make me buy the BD ... if only they'd included the production number as a full-screen extra as many other films do. But no, the disc gives us other things we probably don't need.The BD is gorgeous, and the film lively and diverting (probably not for younger kids; Julia Roberts had her kids escorted from the set during shots so they weren't exposed to the dialog), I just wish we had that marvelous music video.

Don't ask me why, but my daughter (born 2002) LOVES these episodes. I do too ... if sci-fi is contemporary entertainment with all the volume knobs turned up (to 11), then The Jetsons is a priceless example. Basic 1950s family sitcom comedy, repurposed with futuristic hijinks and knowing winks to the "tomorrow" just beyond the space race that was in all the headlines. As conventional as these episodes are, they still come off as original and entertaining. Worth the price, though I try to boycott Warner Home Video for occasions when they've mislabeled disc contents.The discs have the usual menu structure and functions, but with an option on the Top Menu: "Play all." Handy. The menus are simple but well done. More DVD producers need to understand, "simple is better" in most cases.The book-like slip case has nice artwork inside. Pretty durable.Now, these discs look great. vibrant color, crisp lines. Where's the Blu-Ray disc set? My daughter's waiting....

1-BD "Future is Blu" edition-*- -*- -*- -*-Crisp, clear, good color, and a great lossless DTS-HD soundtrack that'll rattle your windows. As other reviewers have noted, this transfer seems to be mastered from a pristine print. This BD also includes the restored William Walton alternate score in a Dolby Digital 5.1 soundtrack, original English mono, and French DD 5.1. That's it. None of the documentaries or commentary, just the film. So hang on to your Collector's Edition DVD set.2-DVD collectors edition-*- -*- -*- -*-The prior single-disc release of BATTLE OF BRITAIN was nice to bring back the memories, but lacking in extras. This two-disc set is superb, has many extras, including a 1969 studio featurette that shows an old friend and former Confederate Air Force flier and his pals who did stunt flying in their own Messerschmitts they'd just bought in Europe. The cast is all-star, everyone at the top of the game, and though not a lot of the film required great range from more than a few, the entire cast's talent gives this film gravitas and immediacy that carries us through to the sudden, uplifting ending.The Battle of Britain is a historic and treasured memory to all Brits, so it's impossible to see this film without considering that enormous weight fell on the production staff to "get it right" in so many details. Scenes with Robert Shaw (even more imposing than he was in producer Harry Saltzman's Bond film FROM RUSSIA WITH LOVE, if you can believe it), Ian McShane, Michael Caine, Trevor Howard, Kenneth More, Susannah York, and so many more take us straight from epic, historical scenery to very personal stories. I don't know how else to put it, they JUST DON'T MAKE THEM LIKE THIS ANYMORE. Big budget, large cast, historical dramas like this are celebrated just for being completed ... THE BATTLE OF BRITAIN is an example of this type of film taken to the highest level, along with LAWRENCE OF ARABIA and others. Great script, too, which leaves a lot for you to follow and figure out. Stare into your popcorn for 10 seconds and you might miss some subtle dialog exchange.Laurence Olivier wanted his favorite composer Sir William Walton to score the film, and was put out when his shorter score was replaced with a longer, more rah-rah score by Ron Goodwin. Story has it that Olivier threatened to walk unless something of Walton's music was kept, so the dramatic "Battle in the Air" suite remains. This disc lets you watch the entire film with Walton's more reserved score in full stereo.In all, this is THE way to enjoy this film. You could spend a whole second evening going through the extras, and it's worth it. You'll appreciate just how difficult it was to make this film, and dedicated everyone was to overcome all difficulties.The package includes a special slipcover with commemorative image (see my pics in the picture gallery), and three-fold liner notes. Summed up, this "collector's edition" (a phrase that's lost its meaning mostly) has as much as you could possible want. Worth the expense.

These are "Race Tracker" headphones for use with a scanner in the loud environment around, ahem, a racetrack. (See my pic of the product packaging in the product gallery.) Essentially the same product as those red ones they sell with the NASCAR sticker on them.I've worn these as a corner worker (flag marshal) in several races with a Uniden BC72 scanner, and they work great. A nice feature is the mono/stereo switch on the cord, not the headset earcups where you can't find it while wearing it.Several reviewers have been baffled about the spring being in the rear, not the top like conventional "studio" or "music" headphones. This is to accommodate wearing the 'phones with a wide brimmed hat when you're exposed to the sun all day, like at a racetrack. The velcro strap goes UNDER the hatband. One reviewer even mentioned the "wires point upward." The spring goes in the back, folks, not on top! ... The rear spring is snug on purchase, it CAN be bent gently for a looser fit, though after a few days' wear they did this naturally. Okay, who wants to wait a few days, or weekends -- go ahead and gently bend them, but not too far. Worked for me.Noise suppression (for un-muffled, race-tuned engines, folks, not office conversation or kids' piano practice) is pretty good for an economical headset. I've worn these all day at Turns 11, 17, and 14 at VIRginia International Raceway, where you're as close to the cars at speed as you'll be anywhere (about 5' from racecars going by abut 45-75 MPH). My ears were still comfortable, my hearing just fine, after an 8 hour work day (13 hours at Turn 14).If you're looking for a cheaper alternative to Bose ACTIVE noise cancelling music headphones, KEEP LOOKING. These aren't the droids you're looking for! These are PASSIVE hearing protectors and mono/stereo headphones for listening to a radio scanner, or just protecting your hearing from the 90dB+ environment of a race track (or airfield, for that matter). The fact that they sound okay (and I emphasize, only okay, for the price) is because they are primarily for a high-decibel environment where you are blocking out aviation or racetrack noise and listening to a radio. If you want something to listen to music on a personal music player, you can get better over-the-ear or in-ear-monitor stereo headphones for the same price.

Many security apps for Android devices promise a lot, but Cerberus really delivers. When installed (either as Cerberus or as a "stealth" app which you can download from their site), it enables a number of remote surveillance features, e.g. tracking, sounding an alarm, creating a message on the screen, taking a picture (either camera), recording video, recording audio, etc. If you've rooted your device, you can hide Cerberus even better.For anti-theft, I think it's great. For tracking my daughter's tablet (she's only 10, so it's conceivable she'd misplace it), even better. And the one-time fee to cover up to five (5) devices is amazingly affordable.Try it out (trial period) and see if I'm not kidding.

8:10 MinsSecond of two reviews of Elago stands; check my review for the elago M2 Stand/Dock For iPhone. Both are well made, solid aluminum with an even powder coat of matte black. Both will suit smaller smartphones, but I've discovered that the P2 is better suited for larger smartphones as well as 7" and 10" tablets.Please watch the video for more. See my other Amazon review for the  elago M2 for further comparisons: http://www.amazon.com/review/R3M3BW3N3M7GSB/

As the title says this is s solid printer that packs a lot in a very small area. Photo printing is solid, though not on the level of a high end dedicated photo printer (I have a canon pro-10), but much more practical for printing 5 x 7 or 4x6 pics.  My only complaint is that the ink disappears super quickly.  After printing maybe 60 sheets of text and 4 8 x10 pics the black is 80% gone

Dual controls, one for left wheels and one for right makes it somewhat difficult to get used to the controls, and nearly impossible for my 4 year old to understand how to make it turn the way he wanted it too.  A forward back control, combined with a left right control would have been easier.Because you control the wheels on each side individually you can spin the car around within a very narrow area.Major cons are1.  the batteries drain fast.2. Range is only like 20 feet3. Doesn’t really propel itself on water (like a boat) does drive in deep puddles.

Pros:Top notch compressor that allows for two simultaneous hookups and more than enough compression to run them both.Compressor is quiet enough that it shouldn’t cause permanent hearing loss (watch out when letting the air out, it’s much louder)Compressor is just the right size for a “job site” compressor, allowing for near continuous use of air tools and it fits easily in the back of a truck.Built in cord control on the compressor.Perfectly adequate brad nailer with option for a push to fire modification (not included)Accurate depth on the brad nailer.Hook, on the nailer allows you to hang the nailer from a belt, a ladder or the wall when you need your hands free for setting up the next step of the project.I ran 4k nails through the gun to test it and it didn’t jam on me once.Cons: Make sure your wearing ear protection when you drain the air and moisture out of the bottom, it’s way louder than the compressor.Price: Let’s face it, there is a premium for the DeWalt name, there are certainly cheaper serviceable options out there.I’m nitpicking here but I wish the cord was a little longer.  I know you can get around this with a longer hose or an extension cord, but it would be nice to have a longer power cord built in.Overall: this is a great set and I would recommend it to anybody who will be using the tools a lot but doesn’t have a nailer already.As always, if you found this review useful please click to let others know.  And feel free to leave comments or questions, I track and respond.

First, pros and cons then my overall impression.Pros:1. Really light: easy to carry between floors.2. Great suction: no problem removing hair from a sink, or dog hair (short haired dog) from a carpet.3. Easy to push: no motor assistance but it glides well.4. Spinning carpet attachment for stairs: A great tool, hampered in this case by other features (see below)Cons:1. No way to deactivate the roller when cleaning a bare floor.  Which worries me in terms of scratching finished floors and also contributes to noise.2. Really loud… All vacuums are loud, this one is louder than most and probably passes the 80 dB threshold for permanent hearing loss (based on comparison with an air compressor I know is 70 dB).3. Only one extension for the wand means you have to hunch over when cleaning along the base of cabinets or other narrow areas.4. Vacuum has a tendency to tip when the wand is in use: Although there is plenty of stretch in the tubing the vacuum tends to shift and overbalance if you put even a moderate amount of tension on it. WARNING: vacuum form the bottom of stairs to the top (as supposed to top down) so that you don’t pull the vacuum down the stairs and hit yourself.Overall: The Eureka has great suction, and does an excellent job of vacuuming which, ultimately, is its purpose.  However, many of the negatives here make using the vacuum a chore (well more of a chore than just vacuuming), there are simply too many negatives here for me to recommend this vacuum.  This is however, the second Eureka I have had that does an excellent job cleaning so I would recommend looking at other vacuums in their line.As always, if you found this review useful, or didn’t, please vote and let others know.  Also feel free to leave comments and questions. I track and respond.

If like me, you had no idea a product like this existed, you probably have no idea what it does or how to use it.  The SpyderCHECKR is an additional tool for color management.  Until recently I thought of color management as a two-step process, 1. Calibrate the monitor, 2. Use appropriate color profiles with printer to ensure it matches the screen output.  I was however, ignoring the crucial 3rd step, camera calibration.  Enter the SpyderCHECKR 24.  All you do is take a picture of the color template, load the software and follow the instructions for calibrating.  Then you load the profile into lightroom (or another photo management app) and apply it.  The result is that your pictures will match the colors you saw when you took them, saving a lot of time you would have spent adjusting.What’s the catch?  Depends how much of a perfectionist you are.  To really get perfect results you need to create profiles for every lens/body combination.  In addition, you have to be very particular about the lighting setup used when you photograph the SpyderCHECKR calibration sheet.  You should try the recommend setup.  However, there are numerous users who recommend that you make a profile for each lighting setup you use, the same way you would with white balance.  I would try both and see what you prefer.Regardless, this is a tool that will simplify the color correction part of your workflow, and I highly recommend it to all photographers.

I will provide my thoughts starting with an overall impression followed by a pro-con format.At least as far as I can tell the Jam Storm is a premium version of the Jam classic speaker.  The biggest difference is the increased battery time (12 v 4) hours.  The other additional feature "Storm" is a bottom mounted transducer for bass.  Essentially the device sends vibrations through the bottom of the speaker and into the surface it sits on, turning the surface into a bass.  Unfortunately the results for this vary greatly depending on the surface, how well the speaker is sticking to it, and the listeners proximity to that surface. I got the best results with a decent sized wood table that had some flex in the top.Pros:1) Enough volume to fill a small-medium sized room without any distortion.2) When used for individual listening, provides a vastly superior bass experience to any small speaker I have tried.3) Decent battery life (and accurately listed I got ~12 hours in my test)4) Above average wireless range (still below advertised) (got ~20 ft outdoors without dropping the source, indoors it varied by obstruction but  ~20 ft despite being in different rooms etc.5) Audible indication of actions: I like this feature, but some people might find it annoying.6) Auto off: relatively fast auto off helps preserve battery life.Cons:1) At the top of the volume range there is a fair amount of distortion2) Storm bass does nothing if you are holding the speaker or it is on an object that will absorb the vibrations, like the ground.  Doesn't produce great bass on really rigid surfaces either.3) Bass is limited in affect area: Sound expands  as a cone, the cone from this transducer will be down and up from the source, so if you put it on a flat surface you have to be either above it or in close proximity to really get the effect of the Bass.  Even 4-5 ft away the storm feature doesn't seem to add much.4) Battery seems to drain fairly quickly in standby mode.
