I charged it fully then left if for a week and it was dead.5) The charge is not usb, which would be ideal for a portable speaker.6) The charger wall wart is huge and really limits the number of places it can be placed... moreover it will almost always cover more than one outlet on a strip.Conclusion: I feel that the Storm is a mixed bag, is it better than the JAM classic? Absolutely.  Is it good enough to warrant is premium price tag?  Maybe if you love bass, otherwise I would wait for it to drop before you purchase.If you found my review helpful (or not) please click to let others know, and feel free to comment, I track and respond.

3:51 MinsSince I got the UAG case as a reviewer sample I thought I would take the opportunity to compare it to my current case.  The bottom line is that I prefer the UAG, although it does have a couple issues.  Watch the video for the full rundown, and feel free to leave questions or feedback.

For the most part the at a glance books are the same formula.  A page of text on one side, a full page drawn graphic on the other side.  However, on many topics I find that they are too superficial lacking the depth to make them true study aids and instead acting as broad strokes overviews of any given topic.  That said, if you want to have an idea about a given system without the depth of Guyton & Hall, or you want more pictures to help you understand a subject, they are useful.I was however, surprised with the depth of "The Reproductive System at a Glance."  This book provides much more detail than many others in the series and will give its readers a sound foundation in reproductive physiology, anatomy, and pathology.  Although there were fewer illustrations than in some of the other "Glance" books I found them useful and felt they compliment, the text nicely.I won't say I loved this book but it would be a solid addition to your library and I do recommend it.

A serviceable whiteboard with just one problem, you can only mount the provided marker holder in the horizontal direction.  I hung the white board vertically and as such I had to trim the holder down to fit it on.

A good monitor, Not VESA compliant, but I popped the plastic back off and inserted a thin metal plate then closed it back up.  After drilling a couple holes I had no trouble mounting the monitor on a VESA mount,  I have been using it that way for 2 months with no problems.

I typically think of vacuums as follows:Uprights, are heavy and great for carpets, but annoying on stairs.Canisters are usually a little lighter, easier to use on stairs and better for bare floors.Cordless stick vacs are more like electric brooms, have relatively little suction and aren't meant for vacuuming a house.This Bissell while primarily an upright tries to combine the benefits of all three categories by offering a cordless option and allowing you to remove the "capsule" to carry it up stairs.Pros:1) Decent suction, pulled sand off of an office style carpet with no problem.2) Versatility, especially the ability to go cordless for 20-30 min, which is probably enough to vacuum a small apartment without ever having to worry about the cord.3) ability to change suction settings is ideal for drapes, or other delicate fabrics.Cons:1) Suction could be better.  Left enough dirt residue on a tiled bathroom floor that it still felt grimy and sweeping still collected a decent pile of dirt.2) Weight: the whole vacuum weighs 18.4 lbs.  Not abnormal for an upright, but the capsule weights 13.4 of those lbs making it awkward to carry up the stairs or use to vacuum on shelves or other off the floor vacuuming.3) Stair vacuuming: No spinning attachment for stairs means it doesn't do a great job vacuuming carpeted stairs.4) Difficult to push / Tilt Angle: I found that the vacuum was particularly difficult to push, the vacuum only tilts backward a little bit then the front lifts off the ground (which prevents the vacuum from working well), as a result I couldn't tilt the vacuum enough to get a strong push, and pushing, even across very short carpet was really difficult.5) No carpet height adjustment6) No motor assist.Conclusion:I'd rather have either a dedicated upright or a dedicated canister.  Pass on this one.If you found this review useful please remember to click so others will know.  Also feel free to comment, I track and respond.
Overall this is a fine addition to a toy kitchen.  However, it is a little harder to use than many of the Melissa & Doug toys.  Also unlike many of their toys this is all plastic rather than wood.

Feel free to skip to the end if you just want my overall impression.Pros:1. Great protection, I didn't intentionally drop my phone on this or anything, but it is rated against drops of 6' and vibration, and it is a substantial 2 part case with a lip that would protect the face, against face drops.2. Added weight from the "wallet" ensures that the case pretty much always lands on the back side further protecting your screen.Cons:1. It's too large: My determination of this is based primarily on the fact that I couldn't get it to stay in any dashboard mounts I tried.  The phone was too thick with this case on and would fall out.2.  Wallet is difficult to open: Practically stuck close and required a significant amount of effort to open.  And there is no easy way to get the leverage required to open the case.  Obviously this will reduce accidental opening, but a button release of some sort would have achieved that goal more efficiently.3. Only enough space for a couple of cards.  IMO you really need space for 3 cards + cash or 4 cards minimum.  Why? License, Credit Card, Insurance Card + either cash or debit card.  This case doesn't provide sufficient storage for what I consider to be the essentials.  But that's my opinion.  Maybe yours is different.Overall: There are cases that are smaller that provide close to or equivalent protection for your phone, there are probably better phone wallets out there.  I would pass on this one, but still if you need max protection and never use a dashboard mount you might like this.As always if you found this review helpful (or if you didn't) please click and let others know.  Also feel free to comment.  I track and respond.

I have owned the Bosch DLR130K Digital Distance Measurer Kit for about 6 months and I have compared it to the NWi LSC60 fairly extensively.Comparison: Based on accuracy, consistency, ease of use, additional features, and price***Feel free to skip to the conclusion***Accuracy and ConsistencyConsistency: 3 measurements at each of the above lengths.Accuracy: Tested inside at 5, 10, 20 and 30 feet.Results: At all distances both units were extremely accurate and consistent, yielding results within 1/16 of 1" of a tape measure measurement.  Additionally they yielded the same results on each of the 3 measurements.Ease of Use:1.  I found the Bosch more intuitive to use, especially in terms of turning the unit on and off.  I initially thought the NWi unit was defective as the power button failed to turn it on... However it turns out the power button turns the unit off and the Meas button turns the unit on.2. Lasers on both units are somewhat difficult to see outside on a bright day but I found the NWi clearer than the Bosch.3. The NWi has a backlight for the screen which helps when measuring in dim light.Additional Features:  Here is where the NWi really shinesFeatures both have:1. Automatically calculate area or volume.2. Display multiple units, ft in decimals, inches, ft + inches, meters.  You can change the units on the Bosch at any time, you can only change the units on the NWi between measurements.3. Memory, Bosch lets you save one measurement, the NWi shines here by letting you save 30.  Additionally if you change the units you are using the units of all saved measurements are saved as well.  So you can go back and look at them in meters or inches.  By contrast the Bosch converts all saved numbers to decimals.4. Min distance: bosch allows 2 inches, the NWi is 4. (rated distances)5. Max distance: Bosch 130 ft, NWi 195 ft (rated distances)Additional NWi features:1. The pythagorean functions (which allow for indirect measurement) are in my opinion the most valuable additional features (I explained each one below).1a. Use as an inclinometer by pressing the angle button 1 time.  Then simply place the inclinometer flat against the angle you want to measure.  (accurate and consistent but needs calibration, on mine 89.5= 90, 44.3= 45 and -1.2=0 respectively)(0.5 degrees at 90, 0 0.7 degrees on my unit).1b. if calibrated it can be used as rough level using that same feature.1c. Press the angle button twice and you can indirectly measure the length of a room by placing the unit in a bottom corner and aiming at the opposite top corner, then measure.  The LSC60 calculates the sides of a right triangle for you and you now know the length of the room.  Great if there is furniture in the way.  You can also use this to measure the height of a building.1d.  If there are no available bottom corners simply go to the third angle setting, then stand at any point in the middle of the room.  Measure the distance from any set surface to one ceiling corner, and then turn the device around and measure to the other corner... the result will be the length of the room.  Again great for real estate use.2. afformentioned backlight3.  The calculator is handy for calculating materials required for a job based off the volume or area in question.  HOWEVER, you cannot save previous calculations, you will have to right down all your results.  Also the calculator deals in unitless decimals (which makes sense since many calculations will change the starting unit.)4. 3 minuet auto shutoffPrice:  And here is where the Bosch really shines.At ~$89 for the Bosch vs. ~$148 for the NWi the Bosch is a better deal if all you want to do is to measure straight lines.  And you can get a backlit version that measures 165 ft Bosch GLM 50 Laser Distance Measurer with 165-Feet Range and Backlit Display for about $94.However to get the angle features you would need to upgrade to the Bosch GLM80 265ft Li-Ion Laser Distance Measurer which would cost 195.  (granted its measured max distance is 70 ft more).  For my money I would rather have the NWi.Conclusion: If you are a real estate agent or are thinking of buying a house, or you are remodeling, consider buying this measure.  Being able to get the distance witout moving all the furniture or taking multiple measurements, is a great feature to have that will save you and your clients time and aggrevation.  Additionally it's not something you cannot easily compensate for with your phone (like the calculator), it is a high end feature that accounts for the high end price.If however, you work in new construction, or mainly need straight lines, or just want to save some money, consider one of the cheaper Bosch units.As always if you found my review usefull (or not) please click the links below to let others know.  Also if you have any comments or questions, feel free to leave them.  I track and respond.

The dock uses DisplayLink and does so about as well as other docking stations I have used.  What really sets it apart is the design that lifts the laptop screen up so that it is at the same height as the other screens you are adding.

A good collection of test questions, but doesn't provide the breadth of something like USMLE World qbank, or the depth of books targeted to a specific subject.That said, the explanations for the answers are helpful and can teach you a lot.  Don't just read what you got wrong, read the explanations of what you got right as well.

For what it is, Medical Sciences at a Glance does an adequate job of touching on the very basics of medical sciences.  However it doesn't go in depth on any of them and in my opinion is too shallow.  Still it would make a good pre-med school primer, or a review of overall topics before a test,.  It will not however, replace your physiology or histology texts.
So far we have made about 15 recipes and enjoyed 14.  The serving sizes are right on and its fun to read about how they perfected the recipes.Recommended.

This charging station is fine, it works, it charges via usb.  However, there are a couple of things I do not like.Pros:1. can use all 4 ports simultaneously and get the full current flow through each port. (3x1 +2.1 =5.1)2. Great if you have a lot of 1A smartphones to charge.3. Silicone base keeps the charger off the counter for kitchen use.Cons:1. Port distribution... one 2.1A port and three 1 Amp ports. If you have a lot of devices that want more current, lets say a couple of tablets, or an S5 (uses a 2+A charger), you won't be able to charge at the same time.  Adding an additional 2.1A port would have the option to charge two tablets.  You just wouldn't also be able to provide full current to a charging phone alongside them (4.2 +1= 5.2>5.1).2. Size: the base takes up alot of space... more then is necessary.  It just seems kinda huge.3. Price: this is really the killer point: you can get similar products at half the price...Recommendation: look elsewhere.If you found this review useful please click to let others know... Thanks!

Although my new receiver has built in Bluetooth connectivity, my old receiver and speakers (which are now in the bedroom) do not.  This little guy works great for streaming from my phone to the speaker system.  As might be expected the range is rather limited 15' or so once you put a walls or floor between the source and the adapter.  But that maybe a specific artifact of my home and whatever is in the walls.
I don't know how much this putter would help an experienced golfer, but I have found consistent improvement in how I a lining up and taking my shots with this putter, so it gets 5 stars from me.

For actual writing these markers are fine.  However, the caps do not stay fixed onto the back of the marker when you remove them. As such they have a tendency to get lost.  Obviously once you loose the cap its not long before the marker runs out.I do like the narrow tips that allow for more precise writing, if they could fix the caps my rating would go up.Recommendation: PassIf you found this review helpful (or not) please vote below to let others know.Thanks.

I received both the Wilson Jones Heavy Weight Top-Loading Sheet Protectors, Clear, 100/Box (W21411) and the Wilson Jones Heavy Weight Top-Loading Sheet Protectors, Non-Glare, 100/Box (W21413) to review and naturally decided to compare the two, here are my thoughts. (SKIP TO THE VERDICT IF YOU DON'T WANT TO READ THE BREAKDOWN)The tests:1) I took one of each type of sheet protector and used them to hold a petition I was circulating, each petition was handled by a very large number of hands.  I then compared the two afterwards to check for the condition of the petition and the protectors.2) I examined the protectors containing the petition in various lighting conditions.3) I put paper towel inside and then spilled water on them in various quantities.4) I put paper in them and bent them to see how they protected the pages and retained their shape****I didn't try stuffing them, I meant to but kept forgetting, maybe I will update with their capacity in the future.The results.1) Both of the protectors held up well to heavy repetitive use.  The pages of the petition remained crisp and the protectors were still in great condition.  HOWEVER, the clear protectors had a large number of fingerprint smudges, these smudges were not present on the non-glare sheet protector. WINNER: non-glare2) In general the clear protectors provided a brighter more glossy finish much like a glossy photo, this looks great for short-term use in most interior lighting conditions (for long term use see fingerprints above).  The non-glare pages are more like a matte photo and there is a real difference in the amount of glare.  These are perfectly visible in just about every lighting condition.  I am not sure how to tell for certain but I believe these have been treated with an anti-glare resin and are true non-glare protectors.  WINNER: depends on the situation, but I prefer non-glare3) Both types of protectors performed well on this test.  Unless you spilled something such that it pooled right near the top-loading opening they completely protected the sheets.  If the protectors only had one sheet inside they even provided modest protection against spills from above (I used paper towel so I could see the wicking more easily).  However, the more sheets you add to the protector the less protection here.  WINNER: Tie4) Again, both protectors performed well.  They provided decent protection for folds and bends, stopping the paper from forming sharp creases.  However prolonged bending (like if you stuck it in a bag on an angle) did lead to kinks in the plastic sheets themselves.  There was no difference between the two types of sheets. WINNER: Tie5) PRICE: As of this writing the non-glare sheets are about $3.00 cheaper than the clear sheets, WINNER: (as of writing)--Non-GlareVerdict: For my money I would certainly rather have the non-glare protectors, I think they look great on presentations and they are more versatile.  Furthermore the non-glare protectors also resist fingerprints which means your reports stay nicer longer.  And they are cheaper, which makes it a bit of a no-brainer.NON-GLARE: 5 stars  CLEAR: 3 stars (-1 for glare/fingerprints, -1 for price)If you found this review helpful please click on the Yes button to let others know! Also feel free to ask questions in the comments, I track and respond.

I got this case because the magnet in my previous case made the S-pen act strangely at the peripherals of the screen.  It serves its purpose admirably.Pros:1) no magnets means flawless S-pen response2) elastic strap is easy to use and keeps everything closed well3) case acts successfully as a support should you use it in the folded/supported position.4) There is enough extra space in the cover that with some velcro tape you can stick in a small blue tooth keyboardCons:1) doesn't automatically turn off your tablet when you close it (but that is because there are no magnets)2) Doesn't provide much protection against drops or other damage, especially around the edges, so the note does get a little scratched up if your not careful.3) the 4 corners that hold the note in loosen with time, so one of the corners may pop off if is jostled allot.All in all I like the case and feel that it is serving my purposes of protecting the screen.  and for the most part protecting the rest of the tablet.  I wouldn't use this to protect it from little hands that might drop it or if you forget to turn it off all the time.If you found my review useful please click the yes button below and let others know!  Also feel free to ask me questions in the comments I follow them and respond.
As a board book this would have been perfect for the real babies but my toddler enjoys it and it is really well done.

We already owned one radio flyer trike so I knew they make good quality trikes.  However, this is a better product in my opinion.  My son loves to pretend he's a garbage man while standing on the back.  In fact he likes it enough to let me put his younger brother in the sitting part which means I can get us to the playground with the tricycle and no second stroller, a definite plus.Two precautions:1. From previous experience I will warn you that you should have some WD40 around if you own one of these.  Once they get any moisture in them they tend to squeak really really loudly.2. Make sure your child is wearing a helmet (always a good idea), the center of gravity on these is pretty high so they are prone to tipping if ridden aggressively.

This charger works exactly as described.  My only complaint is that it is a little too large to fit well into  a cupholder.  They should have added a more tapered bottom to accommodate smaller cup holders.Nice features:1. If for some reason you have a car that does not have a cigarette lighter this comes with clips that you could attach directly to electrical leads to power the inverter.  I doubt that this will be useful for most people, but if you need this it's there.2. Comes with a spare fuse so if you get a surge for some reason you can replace it easily.

It's hard to review baby toys I have trouble figuring out what will keep my kid's attention.  However this alligator does the trick and has become one of my son's favorite toys. It is will made and had moving parts that make some noise, and has different textures all of which seem to help keeping his attention.  It also seems well made.I recommend this.

As a lefty I have trouble using gel pens.  For some reason, possibly the angle I hold the pen, I always seem to be dealing with irregular flow and blank spots. With the hybrid pen I have not noticed any of the problems with flow rate but the writing is as smooth as a gel pen. Plus as I said in the title, the colors are great.

I have a stereotypical boy, who loves trucks and superheroes. But he also loves Disney classic movies so he loves princesses.  I knew he would love this and I was right, he is as excited about this as his Bob the Builder sticker/activity book.My complaint is that it could really be better made and better packaged. There is no good way to store the different components so some of them have gotten lost.  Additionally, because the crayons were individually taped in place and I managed to break 2 of them just taking them out of the packaging.I think this is a great idea, but the execution could have been better.  Still I recommend this for any child who loves Disney princesses, our classic Disney movies.

Getting channels with an indoor antenna in an apartment building in NYC is nearly impossible.  This is the third antenna I have tried to achieve that goal.Cons:1. I can't get all the channels, at the same time.  I cannot pick up NBC and CBS at the same time as ABC and Fox.  However this was true with the other antennas as well.2. No way to easily mount the antenna.Pros:1. Excellent reception on the channels I am receiving, much better than on the other antennas.2. So light you can actually tape it in place. (although its ugly)

Overall I think this is a great “toy” in fact it only has one real (if rather annoying negative).  However, with some prep the negative can be overcome.  I will go over the con and how to fix it first and then I will write about the set’s positives.Con:The set isn’t ready right out of the box.  You need to have specific “ingredients” on hand to complete any given project.  Below is a list of each project and the non-included ingredients.1. Pop for plants: Popcorn kernel, soil2. Growing garlic: 2 cloves of garlic, soil3. Funny Faces: soil, craft supplies (for decorating the pots), gress or chive seeds4. Pineapple Surprise: whole fresh pineapple5. Tri-“pod”: soil, 3 straws, packet pea seeds6. Cloud Garden: Bean seed packet, cotton balls7. Reach for the Sun: seeds for  quick growing plant (herbs, peas, sunflowers), dry erase marker, soil8. Colorful Carrot: Carrot with greenery, blue food dye.9. Roots never rest: Radishes, toothpicks10. Terrific Terrarium: Pebbles, soil, plant seeds (flowers), or sprouted seeds form other activities.Pros:1. This is a great way to teach a child about growing things, it is also a good intro to experimentation and science.2. Can be used as a method to teach a child about responsibility for another creature.3. All the pots are see through so you can see if roots are growing out against the edges etc.4. Comes with all of the hard ingredients you need such as pots and watering can etc.5. Pictures on the cards tell you what you will need, which is good for kids who cannot yet read or are learing to read.6. Pre planned activities provide parents with a good framework to get started.7. Activities are simple and straight forward enough that they work even for a black thumb like me.Conclusion:As I said at the beginning I really think this is a great toy.  However, there is no reason I can think of why at the least packets of dried seeds, food coloring and soil are not included.  It was very disappointing to open this and not be able to do anything right away.Hopefully with the list I provided you will be able to purchase the accompanying materials before you give this to your child and the two of you will be able to jump in immediately.  Once you do you will discover that the recipies and materials that are supplied make a great product.  I gave the set 4 stars because it is so good despite being incomplete.  If it were complete it would have gotten 5.

In the past I have criticized Green Toys for making toys that don’t do enough to inspire imaginative play.  The toys didn’t come with figurines, space to place figurines, or enough other interactive elements.  With some of their newest offerings they have taken a real step forward.Pros1. The ferry is the same environmentally friendly, thick plastic made in the US style of toy that I have come to expect from Green Toys.  From a production standpoint they put forward a very superior product.2. The toy floats well which is good for a bath toy.3. Interactive parts like a sliding ramp, and the two cars help inspire imaginative play.4. You can separate the bottom of the ferry from the top which facilitates easy drying.Cons1. The ramp that pulls out for loading cars is flimsier then I expect from Green Toys.2. When you separate the top from the bottom the  ramp always falls out.  This is the first toy from this company I have ever owned that has a build flaw.Wishes:1. Would have been great to see a pilot house or a wheel on the ferry2. I wish Green Toys would make a single sized figurine that was integrated across their product line and compatible with all new toys.  This would make for a more interactive environment between the various green toys.  In addition it would help contribute to brand image.Conclusion:Overall a fairly solid effort, the problem with the ramp is the only real reason I did not give it five stars (my son keeps taking the top off and then he can’t get the ramp back in himself).

In a lot of ways this is an excellent projector.  However, there are some areas in which it falls short.  To write the review I tested the projector inside against a screen with a projected size of around 80 inches.  Additionally, I compared it virtually side by side with a 55 inch LCD TV.  I tested using a 720p HD stream from my laptop, as well as a standard def stream.  I also tested the streams using a Galaxy Tab, and an iPAD, for wireless streaming.  I made a point by point pro con analysis so you can judge for yourself.Pros:1. Plenty of lumens so it is clear and bright even with large amounts of ambient light.  It was nearly identical to the LCD TV, and even with all the lights on I had no trouble differentiating colors and seeing white and blacks at 80 inches.  The picture was surprisingly crisp.2. Looks even better in a darkened room. (I anticipate the same will be true for outside, at night)3. Presentations work beautifully no matter the connection, HDMI, USB or WiFi.4. Over HDMI video streaming was seamless.5. Decent audio quality from the speakers.6. Basic setup was simple.7. Remote has a built in pointer.8. Small portable form factor, and carrying case mean you can easily tote this with you on vacation or to a meeting.9. You can play standard def wide screen content from most devices, iOS, Android, or Windows, which is nice.Cons:1. No included HDMI cable (more problematic because of 2)2. Over USB and wireless, HD video playback was choppy and would not have worked for watching a movie.3. USB was choppy even with SD playback.4. Only uses USB 2.0 which may contribute to the above issue.Conclusion:My dream of streaming video from my desktop home theater PC to the projector so I can watch movies outside is shot.  Equally gone are any thoughts of mounting and wirelessly streaming movies and TV to the projector.  However, this will still be useful for presentations and for the occasional outdoor movie when the weather gets better.  If you are looking for a good image and you don't mind being tethered by a cable this could be a great projector for you.

In the past I have criticized Green Toys for making toys that don’t do enough to inspire imaginative play.  The toys didn’t come with figurines, space to place figurines, or enough other interactive elements.  With some of their newest offerings they have taken a real step forward.Pros:1. The rocket is the same environmentally friendly, incredibly well constructed, made in the US style of toy that I have come to expect from Green Toys.  From a production standpoint they put forward a very superior product.2. The rocket comes with two figurines, and splits into two parts.  Moreover the doors on both the top and bottom rocket open to provide space for figurines.  This has led to many a space mission.3. The interior space is easily large enough for multiple figures, and bigger figures then the set comes with.  Our Duplo and imaginext figures have all been on missions.4. Did I mention it was durable, the spaceship has survived re-entry and numerous crash landings,  even the doors stay put.5. No small parts, great if your child has a younger sibling.Cons:1. Nitpicking, but I could have wished for some mobility in the astronauts.  Of course that would have increased the likelihood of breakage and small parts.ConclusionI have to say I am thoroughly impressed, a great interactive toy that shows you don’t need a lot of lights and noises to catch a child’s attention and imagination.

Pros:1. its easy to change up most of the pieces of the car so my 3.5 year old is able to do that by himself.2. ability to customize adds a nice twist to an otherwise basic product.3. All parts seem durable.Cons:1. switching from the small wheels to the big wheelbase is a little tricky (for a small child)2. The wheels freely come off of the rims and thus are easily lost.3. Only one set of large wheels, so you can either put them in the back or front, but you aren't making a monster truck with this.4. When the single set of large wheels are on the front of the car/truck contacts the ground... they are a little too big.Conclusion: These are an average toy, they aren't as customizable as legos, and they don't have the track options that hotwheels do.  In addition there are flaws with the system they have.  Furthermore unless you have more than the one set it won't maintain a child's interest much longer than any other car.  There are probably better options out there.

My three year old loves to put things together and play imaginary worlds.  However, he isn't quite ready for Lego.  The spinaroos provide an easy and fun alternative that he is getting a lot of play mileage out of.  I highly recommend this for anybody with kids in the 2-5 range.

Oral B makes several toothbrushes that have similar features the 4000, 5000 and 7000 all deliver 40k pulsations/min and 8800+ oscillations/min according to the specs.  The differences come down to other features and price.the 4000 $65,the 5000 is $110the 7000 is $160At each increase in price there are some additional features.  For example, the 4000 does not have a pressure sensor to prevent you from brushing to hard, nor does it have a timer that displays how long you have been brushing and the mode you are in. The 5000 also added a deep cleaning mode that has you brush for 3 min instead of two.  Personally I find the first two features facilitate better brushing habits and make the 5000 a better tooth brush than the 4000.The differences between the 7000 and the 5000 however are minimal.1. The 7000 is black2. The travel case is nicer3. A tongue brushing mode was added.That's it, oh and the tongue brushing mode is just the sensitive mode with a single 20 second timer according to the manual and my experience.For that they are charging an additional $50+.  I have not found that any of these changes improve my brushing or habits.  I see absolutely no reason to recommend this toothbrush as long as the 5000 is still available for sale at a cheaper price.I did not give the toothbrush 1 star because it does work well, and at an appropriate price it would be worth purchasing.

Comparative review: Haswell Acer Aspire S7, vs. Sony Vaio Pro 13Tech specs:Aspire S7: Core i7, 256gb solid state, 8gb ram, purchased clean (no bloatware) from Microsoft store for 1200 all in.Vaio Pro 13: Core i7, 128gb solid state, 8gb ram, received fee from Amazon vine (1500 on Amazon)I had the S7 for 30 days, I kept the Vaio because free was a better price.I have split this review based on various features so that you can directly compare, I will have some additional info at the end to wrap up.Design: In my opinion the S7 is the clear winner hereThe S7 (4/5)Pros:1) Round edges make it comfortable to put on your lap2) Cover tilts all the way back so that you can show it to somebody across from you, or more importantly adjust it to any viewing angle (and it also means you can hold it open for presentations.3) Not a lot of body flex which means you can click on the trackpad regardless of the surface you are using.4) Just looks nice.5) Stiff hinge allows  you to open it one handed and holds it in place really well (less typing shake)Cons:1) SD cards stick out of the slot a fair amount so you can't just leave them in there indefinitely. (mitigated by the larger HD space)Vaio (2/5)Pros:1) SD card fully inserts so it can be used as permanent file storage for music etc.2) Sturdy: I dropped it (not on purpose) and all it did was dent the corner slightly.3) USB charger on the power cord is a nice touch.4) Looks decentCons:1) Sharp edges dig into your lap (really hurt)2) Cover has limited movement, in fact I couldn't tilt it back far enough to type on my lap with an ideal viewing angle.3) Slight tilt to the screen and keyboard mean that there is a gap when you close it.4) Carbon fiber flexes a lot so sometimes you cannot use the mousepad because the keyboard has flexed.5) Cannot be opened one handed.Keyboard:S7 (1/5):Pros:1) Sufficient key travel (unlike on the earlier S7)Cons:1) Keyboard has some weird organization choices, like no Function keys, not sure why2) My spacebar only registered in the middle or left side, it missed most hits from the right side, this was a big problem.  While this does not appear to be an endemic problem it is also not isolated.  Had I  planned on keeping the computer I would have had them fix it.3) Backlight made it difficult to see the keys when the lights were on.4) No dedicated media controls5) One of the keys, either enter or shift was not full sized I cannot remember which.Vaio (3/5):Pros:1) Decent backlight2) Decent typing feel, full size keys.Cons:1) While decent to type on, it isn't a Lenovo quality keyboard... I wish it was.2) No dedicated PgUP, PgDn, home, end buttons.3) No media controlsGeneral use and other features:S7: (4/5)Vaio: (3/5)

Pros:1. Easy to set up: I used the setup wizard not the app, but I didn't have any issues getting the network set up or getting all my devices connected.2. Excellent wireless coverage: In my apartment the 2.4GHz range is crowded primarily by the signals of our multiple baby monitors.  Due to the interference wireless connectivity in most of the bedrooms was basically nonexistent.  With this router though we have gotten better connectivity on all our wireless devices.  The 5GHz band especially provides a strong signal to every area within our apartment.3. Cloud storage via USB: works well and fairly quickly useful for saving files to your home network from the road.  Enables you to stream your media in HD without a hitch which means I can watch movies on a laptop without having to worry about storing them.4. Capable of streaming HD video: As I mentioned above it has excellent range.  I have not tried streaming HD video to multiple devices simultaneously, but I can watch in HD in my bedroom via the wireless network.  Previously I was lucky if I could successfully stream in SD and consequently I used a powerline to connect via Ethernet.5. Optional guest network so that you can keep your guests out of  your cloud storage.Cons:1. Can't be used as a media bridge:  Odds are that currently none of the things you own have wireless AC, however many of them may connect via the Ethernet (xbox-360, blue ray player, TV, TIVO, AVR etc.)  One way to take advantage of wireless AC right now is to use a media bridge that uses wireless AC as a way of connecting all the aforementioned devices to the internet (you plug them into the bridge and the bridge connects to your wireless network.)  This won't work for that purpose, it can transmit wireless but it can't receive, a lot of the other AC routers have this capability.2. Setting it up so you can access your files via the internet is a pain: If you aren't computer savvy you won't be using this feature.3. The apps are basically worthless: the app for accessing your data, SharePort mobile, will allow you to access your data but I found it very tedious to set up, basically the same problem as above.  Additionally, if you have a lot of stuff on your drive (as I do) then it takes forever to loud a content list (this happens whenever you access the app).  Also it doesn't support .avi format (I haven't tested others yet), and the app doesn't run in the background so you cannot listen to music from your network while you browse the web.Conclusion:Overall for my purposes this is a great router, meaning I get more consistent faster connectivity.  However, I still think there is room for improvement given the price.

**First Impressions:**This thing is HUGE, easily bigger than a carryon bag, it looks like it ate 3 regular sized printers.  I had to clear everything off of my dresser so that I had a place to put it.  If you have a small apartment make sure you can actually dedicate the space.  (Also 13x19 paper looks like a gag gift the first time you see it.) If you do have the space though... the Pro-10 is worth it.I know the exact dimensions are already on the web site but keep in mind when choosing a location that (ideally) you want 10 inches behind the printer and 17 inches in front of the printer so that you can fully extend the trays (these can be over open air).Other initial notes:1. There is a handy slot underneath to keep the tray for printing on DVD-Rs.2. This thing ways almost 50 pounds and has to be attached to the computer via USB for setup, so if you plan to keep it somewhere far away from your computer bring it to the computer first and then move it to its final destination, you don't want to have to lug it back and forth any more than you have to.**Now on to the printing:**Many people have mentioned that this printer provides either near lab level prints or lab level prints.  I would argue that this printer, if used correctly is capable of producing prints that are better than you could get from most labs.Why?Complete control over all aspects of the print.What do I mean by "if used correctly?"Ultimately a great print will have both great print quality (something labs and this printer have in common) and will perfectly match your intentions for color, contrast, and brightness.  Even if you use a calibration tool (I use a Datacolor Spyder4Pro S4P100 Colorimeter for Display Calibration) keep everything in the same color space, and use proof previews in either Lightroom or Photoshop, you will often discover that what you see on the screen doesn't quite match what you get in prints.  If you are printing from a lab this usually means you are stuck with what the results (hey they're "pretty close" right?).If however, you to have a printer like this one, you can completely eliminate this problem.  As the title says, practice makes perfect.  Print the picture as a smaller analogue on a piece of 8.5x11 paper, adjust the printer settings to correct for any differences between the print and the screen and then try again.  When you feel you are getting perfect prints, save the settings as a preset (I use lightroom for this but the canon plugin allows for essentially the same thing) and use it as a starting point the next time.  Assuming you are using the same type of paper you should get near perfect results every time once this process is complete.Yah I know this seems like a waste of ink and paper, but most people aren't considering this printer because they want to print more 4x6s of their family.  They are looking to make high quality prints to either sell or frame and hang on their walls, and in either of those instances the Canon Pro-10 will allow you to get not just lab quality prints, but perfect prints.I highly recommend this printer.
By far the best camera I have used to date, a huge step up from my 40D.  Lighter, faster, better pictures.  Highly recommended.

Initial impression: Office 2013 provides incremental changes to office 2010.  Most are positive, at least one (that I have encountered so far) is negative, but few actually provide new functionality.Pros:1. Office 2013 feels a little like what office 2010 should have been.  With the getting started templates included in each module  it is easy to see some of the new features.  This would have been more useful when switching from the old toolbar and menu  office to the ribbon driven office.  Still better late than never.2. Mostly familiar if you are used to 20103. Old menu shortcuts (such as ALT, i, R to insert a row in excel) still work.4. Designed for use on a tablet, which is a huge advantage (if you have a Windows 8 tablet).5. Mostly better organized than 20106. Automatic integration of Skydrive (rather than requiring  you to download as an add on)Cons:1. Not enough is different to justify paying for an upgrade from 2010.2. Few novel features. Most of the differences are actually organizational rather than novel, making certain functions more  accessible, but not providing any new features.Pros and Cons by program:Word Pros:1. Integrated PDF editing (mostly for text documents): probably the best new feature.  Still rather than upgrade to office 13 for this you could buy Acrobat Writer which is much more robust.2. Ability to hide all info after a formatted heading makes long documents much easier to use and facilitates the creation of a table of contents.3. You can embed online videos (as supposed to downloading them first)4. Easier alignment of pictures in text.Word Cons: Haven't come across any changes that I didn't like yetExcel Pros:1. Suggested pivot tables (analyzes your data and suggests for you2. More accessible controls for formatting graphs3. Suggested graphs4. Smart filling of tables by analyzing what you have added and using that to create rules (eliminating the need for writing some macros).5. General better organization of ribbons and icons.Excel Cons:1. You can no longer use Ctrl + Click to deselect an individual cell. This is almost a deal breaker for me.  I frequently work with spreadsheets that have hundreds of lines.  If I want to select everything in a column but three rows I would highlight the whole column and then use Ctrl + click to deselect the cells I did not want included.  Now I have to go through and highlight what I want while skipping what I don't, and if I misclick my only option is to start again from scratch.  This honestly drives me nuts.  If I can't write or find a VBA workaround I may downgrade to 2010 because of this one "Improvement"Outlook Pros:1. Feels mostly the same to me,2. No problem syncing with g-mail3. Default now shoes 1 line preview of e-mails.Outlook Cons:1. Not Microsoft's fault but currently Cozi's toolbar doesn't support Office 2013PowerPoint Pros:1. You can now stream presentations onlinePowerPoint Cons: Nothing jumped out at meOneNote: Still Awesome, but the version for Windows 8 is just as good and is free from the App store.Conclusion:  Office 2013 is a pretty solid offering, but I definitely would not pay to upgrade from Office 2010. If you are purchasing to replace an early version of office I would say the following: If you use excel like I do, probably go to 2010 (unless Microsoft changes this). Otherwise get 2013, The overall improvements make it easier and more intuitive to use.

I got a set of OXO Grood Grip measuring cups when I first got married, and I honestly haven't had any complaints.  That said, these are undoubtedly better.Here is why:1. Easier to hang on a hook and keep together.2. Super easy to pour, even slowly. Pours out smoothly rather than running down the side (which was a problem with the originals).3. Despite the ease of pouring they don't spill easily (I was afraid they would)4. Handles are shorter and sturdier, my original handles were prone to bending.Nothing earth shattering but then the original was a pretty good design to begin with.

I have split my review into two parts; one for the 323AB Tripod, and the other for the BBH-200 Ball Head. First however, let me describe my previous kit as I will be using it for comparison and reference purposes.Tripod: Manfrotto 055XPROBHead: Markins "Emille" Q-Ball HeadCamera: Canon 40D with various lensesVANGUARD 323AB TRIPOD:I evaluated the tripod based on height, weight, build quality, and additional features.Weight: (4/10)The first thing you notice when you pick up the tripod is that it is heavy, nearly 8 lbs.  By comparison my Manfrotto is about 5 lbs (5.3 including the ball head).  I have hiked with the Manfrotto and you feel the weight, I wouldn't recommend taking the Vanguard if you are going to be doing a lot of hiking, or spending the whole day walking around.  Essentially, in my opinion the Vanguard is so heavy that it is primarily suitable for studio, or location work.Height: (7/10)I looked at size three ways, height when closed, height with the legs fully extended, and minimum usable height for (macro shooting).Closed:At over 31" with the ball head attached, the Vanguard is pretty long, you will almost definitely need to take off the ball head before you can store it in an overhead bin. (Not such a big deal if like me you don't tighten the hex nuts when you attache the ball head).Legs fully extended:In my opinion the tripod you buy, should be tall enough that you can use it with the center column down,  and short enough that with the legs fully extended the cameras viewfinder is at eye level or a couple of inches below eye level.  Fully extended the Vanguard is ~5'5" tall, which means that the viewfinder is about 5'8" off the ground (more if you use a camera with a battery pack).  Obviously you can use the tripod without fully extending the legs, but if you are using this primarily in the studio or on shoot locations you don't want to have to adjust the legs every time you set up on flat ground.  I would definitely look for a different model if you aren't at least 6', the Manfrotto I own is 2.5 inches shorter with the ball head attached, and it is also a little tall for me (I'm 5'8").Minimum Height:You can flip the center column of the tripod upside down, which means you can get pretty much as close to the ground as you can possibly focus.Build Quality & Additional features: (10/10)The tripod appears solid, mostly metal with plastic tabs for lowering the legs.  The tabs can be tightened or loosened by screws so you can adjust the tension.Features of note:1. An orange gasket helps to cushion the center column if you release it with your gear on and it drops quickly.2. Three different configurations for the feet (big rubber pads, rounded rubber or metal spikes) ensure grip on varied terrain, although I have never had any issue with my Manfrotto which only has the rounded rubber.3. There is a hook on the bottom of the center column which you can use to hang your camera bag or another weight to further stabilize the tripod, (or to hang the tripod in a closet for storage). A nice feature my other tripod doesn't have.4. A level on the top of the center column lets you know if the tripod base is level.5. An included tool contains everything you need to attach the quick release plate, adjust the tension on the legs or flip the thread on the center column to accommodate other attachments (really nice to have), and can be attached with a key-chain.6. The included bag is a nice touch and I wish my Manfrotto had come with one; I drilled holes in it to attach a carry strap instead.Conclusion: (21/30)Altogether I just felt the Vanguard is a little too big and heavy.  You want a tripod that you can and will use regularly and this one is just too over sized for regular use.  I would almost unilaterally recommend the 055XPROB over this tripod.  However, if you are well over 6' then this might be a better choice.  Remember before you buy a tripod to look at the maximum height and think about that as it compares to your height.

In a nutshell Quicken WillMaker Plus is a great easy way to make a basic will.  You can make multiple wills (one for you and your spouse for example).  Doing so is easy and straightforward, all that you have to do is answer the questions as they are asked, print get some witnesses and your good to go (pardon the pun).  Seriously though, the 2011 version was great I would recommend this product and assume the 2013 version will be just as good.

First: This book picks up exactly where Stargazer left off, so read the first books in the series first!Review:I enjoyed Evernight and Stargazer but Hourglass clearly surpassed the first two books.  The complexity of the main characters builds off of the previous stories, they face more difficult decisions and make interesting choices (I was surprised more than once).Additionally I really liked the emotional energy in this book, pushing on anger, happiness, terror, sadness, and a gamut of other emotions, that really kept me tuned into the book and turning pages.Ultimately I just thought the whole book was well crafted, from the main characters to the supporting characters to the plot elements and everything in between.I highly recommend this book and look forward to the next one.

My interest in diseases is one of the things that drew me to medical school.  I was therefore, prepared to really like this book.  However I found that the style, 0-2 page vignettes of cases seen by EIS officers, left me feeling underwhelmed. I think the book would have been more successful with a disease based focus.  As it stands it is just too fragmented.  I do not recommend this book.

Before reading I would just snap a photo now I consider the art behind my next picture.Whenever a group passes by and they ask me to take pictures I usually decline the request kindly.This helped a ton and gave me a lot of different outlook as a viewer of pictures and a lot of advice on what i should include in them.Can't wait for the next group ask me to take a picture.

This is an amazing charger! The 2.1 A is able to charge my phone extremely fast, which is why I love it so much! I travel a lot, so this is a pretty essential item for me! I can charge both my wife's and my own phone at the same time!

I like that you pick any color since it makes it easy to tell this from other chargers I have.The dual usb is great options since I usually have charge my phone and a guest.Overall, I was pleased with the service and it shipped faster then expected. I recommend this item.

If you can't afford real camera in every spot since they are pricey this is good replacement.Looks like real camera and the blinking motion give it realism.I highly recommend for putting in areas that are not likely to be broken into but you still want security presence.

Okay - so the first caveat is that you have to keep your house (or at least your floor) relatively clutter free when it runs.  My cat steals hair bands and leaves them around the house, and my daughter leaves her socks all over.  These two things are not conducive to an operating vac.I have a Mastiff (sheds constantly), a Maltese, a cat (also sheds constantly) and a long haired guinea pig (also sheds constantly).  My daughter, who wears black a lot, was complaining that she was always covered with pet hair and it was embarrassing. I bought this guy to try to get the pet hair under control between cleanings (about once a week).  It runs every day and has done wonders for the pet hair problem.One thing though - as many other people have mentioned, it takes several days of full charge/release to get it to it's full charge. When I first bought it, it would charge 5 or 6 times to do 600 or so square feet that includes my kitchen, living room, and dining room.  Now though, it can clean pretty much the whole thing on one charge.  It also has no problem with area rugs, and it vacuums UNDER furniture (like bookcases and end tables), which is awesome!The only gripe I have is that for some reason it keeps trying to get under my couch and gets stuck - only on one side though.  I have the magnetic band blocking doors so I may need to get another one, but overall this works great.
I use a lot of the NOW essential oils for making soaps, lotions and bath bombs.  I find the quality to be consistent and the price is very reasonable.

I usually wear the ASICS Women's Gel-Kayano 21 Lite-Show Running Shoe,Hot Pink/Lite/Safety Yellow,9 M US, but they are expensive.  Because I run about 30 miles/week, they need to be replaced OFTEN.  I read that these are a good training alternative to the Kayano though they are a bit heavier.  Some people even say the weight is a bonus when you switch back to the Kayano to race.  I'm training right now for a half marathon and the GT1000 have been working find.  Haven't switched back to my brand new Kayano's yet, but will do that about 3 weeks prior to race day.  For now, this is a good alternative to an expensive shoe.

In all fairness, the reason I don't like it is not the fault of the scale.  The scale is sleek, easy to use, and works great.  The problem - the glass top.  I loved it at first, and then I accidentally dropped the scale.  Of course, the glass plate shattered into a million pieces (after only 2 uses no less).  So I guess something this fragile is not for me.  If you plan to keep it on your counter and not move it around, it's probably a great product.  I don't have the counter space so I have to move it from counter to storage which, for a butter fingers like me, didn't work.

I purchased the whole series after reading the first book.

It's a utility cover.  Not sure what else to add.  I do like that it fits snug all the way to the ground so it stays in place even on the windiest days. We use it on a Honda Pioneer two seat ATVUpdate 9/22/15Well, I used to like it, but we got heavy winds that caused a little rip.  Well, seeing as this is not ripstop nylon, it just shredded.  There's really nothing left and it's only been a few months.  Not worth the cost.  Might work to keep dust off in a garage as long as it doesn't get snagged on anything.

I made the mistake of purchasing too light carpet for my house and of course, I don't want anyone actually walking on it.  I had carpet scraps left over from the install laid down but they kept bunching up and people were tripping over them.  I bought this to replace the carpet scraps.The good: Looks fabulous.  Despite the low price it has a very rich, formal look.  Lightweight so it's easy to move around.  WASHABLE!  Yes, this is the best part since I have pets with muddy feet and a mastiff who drools on everything.The bad: Lightweight (yes, it's bad too).  Because it's so lightweight, it doesn't stay put.  I'm not sure how to make it stay put on carpet.  Were it on hardwood, I would probably use carpet tape.Of course, the fact that it's so lightweight makes it easy to adjust so I just pull it back where it belongs a couple of times a day when I notice it is askew.  Overall though, I am happy with this purchase.
This was a stocking stuffer for my daughter.  It's cute and maintains time well.

I have been really looking forward to this series as it has been showing up in my FB feed for the last couple of months.  I really loved Ava. She is the daughter of "The General" (although I was unclear as to whether he was a were general or just a military general). I hate simpering female leads and while Ava had a few moments, they didn't detract from her strong, dominant personality.  She's not afraid to take the reins, and when she does, she succeeds at what she sets out to accomplish.  Damon is hot and strong.  He is definitely an Alpha male and shows some of the symptoms, telling *his* female what to do, but he seems to do it out of a concern for Ava's safety and not just because he can. After Ava is kidnapped by a rogue werewolf pack, Damon is sent by his leader to rescue her.  When he arrives, he finds out that the "evil" red pack has plans to use female werewolves as breeding stock to increase their pack size so they can run out the gray packs.  Damon is instantly drawn to Ava, and Ava to him, but Damon knows that he would lose his job and his pack if he mated with the general's daughter so he resists the attraction.  As he tries to keep Ava safe, they face other dangers that test them and Damon's strength to maintain his distance from Ava.I highly recommend this book.  I couldn't put it down!

I bought 2 of these almost 10 years ago for storing things under my bathroom sink.  In our bathroom I use it for contact lenses, bandages and medication.  In my daughter's bathroom she uses it for her headbands, hair ties and elastics, and contact lenses.  They are absolutely perfect for organizing little things that often get lost in the shuffle!As for the 1 star reviews - read the product description.  It's small!  But as I said, perfect for small items and after 10 years - it's still perfect!  It has held up wonderfully.

So - the good and the bad.The goodThis was cheap (as in inexpensive)It looks niceIt went together fairly easily - about 30 minutes by myself (I'm a medium build woman)The drawers are a nice sizeOnce you get them in, the drawers don't just fall out.All the pieces were nicely organized and easy to identify.I think that the 3 drawer pulls account for the majority of the price.  They are nice. (about $5 each at Lowes)I know a couple of people complained about the packaging and damage.  I found it to be very well packaged and cushioned.  It had dividers to keep things from scratching, foam on the ends to keep the edges from getting banged up, and everything was tightly wrapped to prevent movement.I also saw one review where the person complained that the back was cardboard and they threw it away with the packaging.  The instructions now have attached a very eye-catching warning NOT to throw away your packing materials until the whole chest is assembled :)The badThis was cheap (as in low quality - to be expected)I buy a lot of cheap furniture - usually on the drawers, the back side has a ledge so there are 4 ledges on which the bottom sits.  Not so here.  On the 4th edge (the back) you have to pound nails into the bottom to hold it in place.  So....this is pretty much for things like your unmentionables and other lightweight itemsThe plastic slides are horrid.  Difficult to pull out and push in.  I might try some silicone lubricant on them.Actually getting the drawers in is a nightmare.  It took me just as long to put in 3 drawers as it took me to put together 3 drawers.So - why 4 stars?  Well, it was cheap and it looks good.  Overall, I'm pretty pleased with the purchase.  It will do for a few years until it either falls apart or I decide I no longer like it.  The 4 stars is primarily because those plastic rails are awful.If you are looking for something that looks nice but is inexpensive, I would say you won't find much better.UPDATE - so I went to Lowe's and bought 3 drawer slides for a total of $12.  Even adding the additional $$ - I'd say this is a great deal.  It is still cheap, but it looks nice and I suspect it will last for about a year or so.  If it falls apart sooner than that, I'll update my post. I bought 12" drawer slides (but I think 14" would work as well and are easier to find) and just matched them up to the existing holes.  No problems.

I wanted so badly to like these books.  The reviews are so glowing that I kept telling myself that surely they must get better.  Three chapters into the third book I finally threw up my hands and gave up.  The characters have absolutely no depth, there is no plot, and nothing of note ever happens.  Frankly, I'd rather watch paint dry.  It is bound to be far more exciting than these books.  I'd say that if you are 12 or 13, these might be a good read, but the content is totally inappropriate so I'm not really sure who is enjoying these books so much.

I was immediately hooked.  While I was a bit confused in the beginning as to how the main character knew she needed to see a particular book and where it was, that was ultimately resolved, although later in the book than I had hoped.  Despite this, I was immediately drawn to both main characters and found myself turning pages quickly to see how the story ended.  My only real complaint would be the editing.  That's not against the author, but the editing looked like something I would see in a $2.99 self published book.  I expect quite a bit more from a $7.99 book released by a publisher.

LOVE LOVE LOVE!  I bought this for my friend's daughter who just started college.  As a culinary school graduate, I was pleased to see that it has information about basic cooking techniques and tools along with a myriad of recipes ranging from "dorm legal" items (only things that dorms allow including microwave, mini fridge, iron, scissors, etc.) to studio (hot plate, crock pot) meals, and finally through apartment cooking.  The recipes are tasty and healthy and provide a welcome change from standard dorm food.

The color is a bit darker than what is shown in the picture.  I may have missed it in the description, but this is microsuede.  However, I clean it with a damp microfiber cloth each week and it seems to be holding up much better than other items I have of the same material.  Absolutely LOVE the flip tray on the larger piece and it is very roomy inside.  We have 3 snuggies and 2 full size flannel blankets inside.  The little piece is light and honestly, I'm afraid to sit on it at 130 pounds but my 100 pound daughter sits on it regularly.  I think the little one should be relegated to a foot stool and not an extra seat.  Overall, it's a nice piece for the money.
Fun book about the importance of friends in the face of bullying.

The Introduction on the cover is what caught my attention.  If I had stopped reading there, I would have been far more fulfilled than I am after reading the whole story.  There was no point, the characters are poorly developed, and the plot nearly nonexistent.  If you like the "feel" of this book, I recommend Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children by Ransom Riggs.

I want to preface by saying I have a PhD in Computer Science and am a college professor in CS so I'm pretty savvy when it comes to technology. I originally loved this drive.  It's cute, compact and has a ton of storage.  Well, after using it for three months, it quit.  My computer recognizes it in devices and printers.  When I plug it in, the eject comes up and labels it as a Passport drive, but I cannot mount it.  It also does not show up in disk management.  I have Googled the problem and found that *numerous* other people have experienced the same problem but am unable to find a solution. WD tech support also has no answers.  Hopefully I can use Linux to grab my files.  I have a backup so it's no big loss file wise, but that's $100 down the drain.  I should have known better than to buy WD.  I've had problems with their drives before but apparently, I am a slow learner.

I wear a 38 D (very full cup) and bought this along with two Fiona bras.  While it does a *fantastic* job of keeping the girls in place during Fitness Boot Camp, it is *very* hard to get on and nearly impossible to get off.  Because it does not fully open (the cross straps in the back are permanent), and because there is very little flexibility in the fabric (which is a good thing), it is nearly impossible to get on.  I wear my Fionas almost every day and only wear this one when I haven't done laundry in a couple of days.  Too bad the design is so poor.  This really could be a fantastic bra.

I received an ARC copy in exchange for an honest reviewI have to admit that it took me a couple of chapters to really become engrossed in this book, but once I did, I could not put it down. The story is well written and between the suspense and the romantic tension between Rachel and Patrick, the story was incredible.Rachel James is a young mother with a terrible secret that may cost her custody of her child if it ever gets out.  She has recently moved in with an old friend after escaping a psychotic husband who was in custody for several crimes.  When she finds out he has been released because someone “lost” the evidence, she realizes that her ex-husband has a broad reach that will keep him out of custody and in pursuit of her and her child.  She flees for her life into the arms of Patrick who also has his own skeletons with which he is trying to deal.  Together, they fight for their lives and the lives of those they love while trying to ignore the feelings growing between them.Overall, I thoroughly enjoyed the book, but found the Angel Killer aspect to be superfluous and confusing.  The “’til death” quotes throughout the book, while suspenseful, but not well explained.  I felt that the book was suspenseful enough with Rachel’s predicament and did not feel that the Angel Killer added anything to the book.  Otherwise, I thought that the book was extremely well written and a wonderful read.

I have been trying to find a way to keep the sheets on my daughter's bed. She tosses and turns all night and ends up sleeping on the mattress.  She has a loft bed so it is difficult for me to keep up with it and she won't.  I installed these about a week ago and while the sheet is still on the mattress, two of the buttons are missing from the clips.  I'm sure they are in her room somewhere but putting them on is tough and sorting through her room to find them tougher.  While the sheets need to be changed every week anyway, I don't relish the idea of trying to find the pieces every week.  So 2 stars - at least the sheets will stay on her bed between washings, but the clips are not secure enough.

I like the XL over the regular as they seem to last significantly longer.  I haven't actually done any calculations or page counts, but I print pretty regularly and these last just over twice as long as the non-XL and quite a bit longer than the off brands.

Just over 6 months old and I swapped it out for my original battery and it is not recognized by my machine.  The laptop shows no battery.  Original battery that came with laptop 2 years ago is still working fine - no problems.

We always get so many comments and many small children refuse to come up the drive because of it.  Totally AWESOME.  (We take candy out to the little ones ;) )

So I am updating this review.  While it did in fact break, I sent Eco-Vessel an email based  on the response from Carol.  I received this email back from them:Hi,I'm sorry this happened and appreciate the chance to help. We recently discovered that there was a problem with the tool that attaches the plastic ring to the steel bottle. It was repaired but a small percentage of bottles were affected. Which bottle does your daughter have? If you can send a digital photo, for our records, please attach. Also, send your mailing address - thanks.Regards,CarolI will update again as soon as I have had time to give it a good go around to see how it holds up on the second try:)  Because I took photos for them, I'll see if I can attach these images here as well.This was a great water bottle....until it broke.  The ring around the top of the bottle broke - the grey threaded part (as other people have also indicated).  I went to the Eco-vessel website and while they have various replacement parts, this was not one of them.  It appears to be held on with a thick rubber band so it should be easily replaceable.  I don't, however, intend to pay $25 for a new bottle, only to have this occur again.  I will look for another water bottle instead.

I bought this book because it was in my list of "other people who bought this book" for Alexandra Ivy's Guardians of Eternity series.  I thought the description was intriguing and due to the numerous great reviews I bought it.  It was, in a word, horrible.  The comparisons that ran through my head as I trudged through this book were "soft porn" and "Magic Mike".  Oh, and remember when you were little and you would fan fold a piece of paper, hold it to your nose and do the "You must pay the rent" thing?  It was like that.  "I can't love you" "But I must love you" "But I can't love you" "But I must love you" "You can love her." "My hero".  The whole book was a conglomeration of cheesy writing, bad dialog, and little plot.  If you like cheesy porn (the kind where they stick a story line in there just so they can say it's a movie), then by all means, please indulge.  But if you like a little meat to your story, don't bother.  The first HALF of the book is about Jacob and Isabella not being able to love each other (oh but there's the demon she kills - that's the plot for the first half), then the second half is about the two of them being all dreamy eyed at one another (oh, but there is a necromancer that must be killed).  It's almost as if the plot is an afterthought.  I definitely won't be reading book 2.

There is only one book I have ever started and did not finish.  That was War and Peace, but that was only because I couldn't keep the characters straight.  I finished this book because I wanted it to be good.  I really did.  It wasn't.  First, there was so much going on in the book that wasn't critical to the story.  Why does it matter that her daughter got strep?  What did that add to the story?  Anything? Why do we care what she faxed to the kids every night?  What did that add?  As a matter of fact, other than it gave her a "reason" for her absolute stupidity, the kids did not serve any purpose.  What was going on with her husband - again, and we care why?  (Oh yeah, the hubby was support for her asinine choices.)  She also had three plot lines going on at once that she *tried* to intertwine but failed at miserably.  The ending was flat, and for lack of a better term "deus ex machina."  All of a sudden, everything resolves in about 3 pages.  And the resolution is ridiculous at best.  The story was poorly written, and poorly plotted. Honestly, toward the end, I read the first line of each paragraph and lost nothing.  I should have done that from the beginning.  This desperately needs to be tightened up.  It *might* make a decent short story, though I doubt it.

I saw this advertised on my Kindle and bought it because it was appropriate for young adults as I'm always looking for books for my daughter to read.  I love that it was set in the Chicago area.  I went to U of I and my brother went to Purdue so I immediately connected. I recognized the mindset having many friends from the Lake Forest and Winnetka areas.  The story itself was good.  I'll admit that I was more interested in Sydney's story and wanted it to work out for her in the end, but that could be because I'm an adult.  Grace's story may be more appealing to the younger set.  As with the other readers, I was a bit annoyed by the editing, but it wasn't so much as to throw the book down in disgust either.  Overall, I would recommend this to young women looking for some light summer reading.  Definitely worth the price.

Okay, I like romance, but generally more in the paranormal genre.  I like vampires, zombies, werewolves, etc. to grace the pages of my stories.  I picked this one up because, well...it was free.  I generally pick up those free Kindle offers when I see them, throw them in my TBR folder and never look at them again.  Well, I couldn't find a new vampire book to interest me so I pulled this one out of the folder and began to read.  Boy am I glad I did!  While the characters weren't my usual fare (no supernatural powers and the hero had a mustache!  Facial hair...ew),  this story kept me engaged to the end.  It was cute and quirky and I simply loved the characters. I'll admit that I read this book from start to end without stopping.  Every time I thought "Okay, right after this chapter I'll go do what I need to do", I found myself flipping to the next page to find out what happens to the characters. I will definitely watch for more books by this author!

I don't usually read anthologies as I find that I like some stories but not others and this one was no different.  I bought it because it came highly recommended from a friend on Facebook, and as with other anthologies, there were positive and negative aspects.  I really thought that all of the stories (save one) had value, and added well to this collection.First, the editing was inconsistent.  Some stories were great, others were so poorly edited it made me want to break out a red pen and start slashing.Overall, I really liked the stories.  They had something in there for everyone, from the overweight, to the stick, to the buxom.  I found I could relate to most of them.I think my favorite was "Found Rhythm" by LaTessa Montgomery.  The characters were so well developed that you couldn't help but be drawn into the story.  Isa was a strong woman despite her insecurities and I found myself rooting for her to get the guy.  I was engaged right to the last line and it left me feeling inspired.My least favorite by far was Eddie's Ring by A.T. Russell.  It was disjointed at best, confusing, and really made no sense.  The editing was atrocious to say the least and it left me with a bitter feeling at the end.  It really made no sense and at points was a little creepy (why would a married man want to sleep with his grown sister?)Don't let my comments about Eddie's Ring dissuade you from buying the book though.  There were other gems throughout.I really enjoyed "The Well-Rounded Woman" by Jude Johnson.  Ever the underdog, the main character finds her own talents and rises to overcome her difficulties she suffered growing up. I enjoyed this one because it demonstrated how one person can bring make things better for others."I've Never Been to Me" by Michelle Ann Horst reminded me of a friend I had growing up.  The main character had a lot of strength from the beginning.  That she used that strength to overcome her problems was uplifting and left me feeling happy at the end of the story."Bones" by Jennifer Welborn had a romantic undertone but in the end was about her own self discovery and acceptance.I found "Skin Deep" by Tina Carreiro to be a sweet story but with a few flaws.  Something that I found a little unbelievable though was how someone with so much talent could have so little self esteem.  The romantic interest was also a bit shallow and dysfunctional, moving from one dysfunctional relationship (his ex-wife had body image issues) to another dysfunctional relationship with a woman with body image issues.  Also, the ending was a little disturbing.  While it turned out well in the end, the means to get there were bothersome."A Lovely Mess" by Dawn Kirby was a bit of a mess, but overall, I found it to be a good story.  It is an accurate demonstration of how we can sometimes let how other people see us influence how we see ourselves.  In the end though, this story had a good ending and was fun to read.All in all I would recommend this book as it is a collection of inspiring stories from some great authors.

I have an HP DV6T Quad.  I bought this to replace part no. 608426-002, 120w 18.5v.  This part is 384023-001.  It is labeled HP so appears to be an OEM HP part.  The replacement is 120w 18.5v.  When I plug it into my computer, it does not register. Just to clarify, I bought this because my computer shows plugged in, not charging.  My laptop works on the battery, it works on the power cord, it just doesn't charge.  After trying several software fixes, I found a note that it may be due to a loose wire on the ac adapter/transformer.  Mine is a bit frayed and sad looking, so I thought I'd give this a try.  Thus, I *know* that there is a problem with this replacement part as my computer does not work when just plugged in with this item, nor does it show on the power symbol on the bottom.  It is *not* a problem with my computer - of that, I am certain.

Okay, I'm going to start off by saying that I really enjoy these books.  They are action packed, and I love the characters.  In each of the books so far, the characters have evolved and become something more as a result of their trials.So why only 4 stars?  Two reasons.  First - there is way too much sex.  I mean, seriously - ask yourself this...you are being faced down by one of the most lethal creatures in the universe.  Do you a) shiver in fear?  b) prepare for attack?  or c) quiver with sexual overload knowing that your recently discovered lover is on his way to help you?  If you guessed c, then you have obviously read the books.  Honestly, I think a little less sex and into you would be nice.The other issue I have is with language.  Ms. Ivy is a great writer, but she needs to move into the 21st century with her language, and needs to invest in a high quality thesaurus.  I'm not quite sure when the word "groused" started to bother me so much, but at some time around the middle of book 2, I started envisioning Alfred Hitchcock's The Birds (only with somewhat pudgy pigeons) every time someone "groused" about their circumstances.  Another complaint is the quirky language.  Yowza, holy guacamole, etc is fine if it's something specific to a character.  But to use that same quirky language for all of the characters in the book is a bit distracting.Overall though, I can forgive the excessive sex drive and the language for the story.  It's a good book once you can get past the quirkiness.
Great read. I'm usually more of a hard sci-fi fan but I found  this series very enjoyable and well written.

Well, it protected my phone from water, but the drawback is that there is no way to charge your phone.  So if you use it to take into a moist environment, then remove it to charge, then put it back on, it begins to stretch and no longer works.  The back doesn't seal after the second use so this is really just a 2 day option.

I bought this for my little two pound Maltese.  She has 2 full sets of teeth (her baby teeth and adult teeth).  She has always had a little tear staining, but when we took her to get her baby teeth removed, the tear stains became unbelievably dark.  We don't show her so it's not a huge deal, but it was somewhat unsightly.  After doing a lot of research, I found out that Angel Eyes works very well - but then after speaking to my vet about it, I found out that it is an antibiotic!  You are supposed to "sprinkle it on their food" - so no dosage control, nothing!  Well, first of all, I have more than one dog and I don't want to medicate all of them, second, my dog is 2 pounds!  What if she overdoses or something?  So, back to the search.  I found this that had very good reviews.  Well, I have used it for 3 days now.  I put it on a soft toothbrush like toothpaste and gently scrub around her eyes.  After 3 minutes, I rinse the toothbrush and use it to remove the "soap" (it's not really soap - much more gentle!) from around her eyes.
