I gently rub with a soft dry towel, and then let her face air dry.  After only 3 days, her tear stains are much lighter.  I don't know if it will make the tear stains disappear completely, but as I said, that's not a real concern, I just don't want them to be so dark - she looks like a little white raccoon!  So I really think that this is a good product.  Gentle, smells great, and definitely lightens tear stains.

Arrived with only the flashing LED's working. The other 80% were nonfunctioning. Also did not have mounting chain included. Very disappointing, this was for a Christmas gift and now I doubt I can get something else in time. I'll add to review later if I don't get a timely refund.

Okay - when I first started reading J.R. Ward's "The Black Dagger Brotherhood" Dark Lover (Black Dagger Brotherhood, Book 1) it was an addiction; so bad that I didn't touch FB until I had plowed through all of the books.This is turning out to be the same. Stephanie Rowe's "Order of the Blade" books are awesome!  The characters are extremely well developed.  The story line moves quickly (for the most part), and it's a great plot.  There are multiple stories going on but they interweave very nicely.  There are many excellent reviews here that give a very concise synopsis of the story so I won't bore you by repeating their efforts.So why do I give it four stars?  There are a couple of things.  First of all, while I love the romance, some of it gets rather redundant and annoying.  I found myself skipping pages to try and get through things that had already been said - over and over.  She's so strong but I shouldn't succumb to this, blah, blah, blah.  While I found it annoying, others may not feel the same as it *does* help to develop the characters and build depth.The other reason I gave it 4 stars is that I am a bit of a grammar Nazi.  There is nothing that irks me more than errors in books.  There were not many, but being OCD as I am, it made me clench my jaw and want to whip out my yellow highlighter each time I found one.  Now don't get me wrong, I'm not talking errors every other line, or even on every page.  Maybe about 25 or so throughout the entire book so really, not a lot, but as I said - I have a very OCD personality and it just detracted a bit.Overall though - I am sitting here thinking I MUST work, but would rather read.  I highly recommend this book/series.

I bought this because I have an older rabbit who pellets once in a while.  If you know anything about buns, they have very small, very lightweight, very dry, very round pellets that roll everywhere when swept.  However, if you run over them with your vacuum, as they get churned up, they start to make the vacuum smell, well, not pleasant.  I bought this so that I could "pre vacuum" my floor before running over it with my Dyson to pick up loose hair, dirt and what not.  Unfortunately, it doesn't pick up anything - at all!  With the floor sweeper on, it doesn't do anything.  If I put the crevice tool on, and put it over each individual item I want to pick up and hold it there for a minute - eventually it will pick it up.  Frankly, it would be faster for me to get down on my hands and knees and pick up everything by hand.  There is no suction at all.  The best that this can be used for is possibly a daily vacuum to pick up dust, but it doesn't work on dirt or pet hair at all.  You're much better off buying a cheap broom and sweeping the floor.  Definitely not worth $20.  I would recommend that you save a couple of dollars and buy a Libman Precision Angle Broom instead.

Well, this came on Wednesday.  It sat in our living room for a few days before we finally had a chance to put it together.  It took about 4 hours to put together.  I did it by myself (I am a 140 pound woman).  The instructions were very straight forward and easy to follow.  I had a few problems with some of the bolts not fitting properly, but I was able to work through the problem by using a ratchet rather than the included Allen wrench.  Once I got it put together, I used it for about 3 hours (I set up my computer across the arms so I can walk while I work) and I had no problems.  It's not super quiet - you can hear the belt running across the surface (not squeaking - just a sliding noise), and my footsteps (which tend to be heavy anyway) make it sound like a herd of elephants is walking through the room, but for the price, I am very pleased.

I bought this ball because I have a bad back and want to use it as a chair to help with spinal stability.  Therefore, achieving the 90 degree angle between my hips and legs is *very* important.  I bought the 75 cm ball because I am relatively tall.  I inflated it, using a level and a hashmark on the wall to ensure that it was inflated to the proper size.  At 65 cm., I was frightened to keep inflating for fear that I might over-inflate and injure myself.  I took it inside and when I sat on it (at 140 pounds) it barely makes a dimple.  Thus, I know I am at about max capacity.  The angle is a little shy of 90 degrees so I guess I'll keep the ball until I can find a better one.  Just note, if you are looking for a 75cm ball, this is not it (and just FYI - the box *does* say 75cm).
This second novel did not disappoint. Believable tech and character's I am anxious to move on to the next in the trilogy and really hoping to see another series.

Every year my daughter dyes her hair pink.  Unfortunately, most pinks don't have very good staying power, especially for my daughter who swims (about 4 hours/day - 6 days per week).  We have been using the Manic Panic Hot Hot Pink (not amplified)for a couple of years, and need to re-dye every couple of days to maintain the color.This year, we bought the Amplified.  Even with swimming, the color easily lasted 2 weeks!  This is much better than the original!

I bought this for my new Samsung Galaxy SIII (obviously).  My daughter had an Otterbox on her iPhone so I was somewhat prepared for the bulk.  I use a Vera Bradley Smartphone Wristlet as my purse and the bulk of the Otterbox makes it a rather tight fit, while the cell phone by itself fits easily.  However, I feel confident that the Otterbox will protect my phone from my random slinging and dropping (which is pretty standard for me).  Also, because I bought the Defender, I am hoping that if it gets splashed (not dunked) the Otterbox will provide some basic level or protection.  I like the fact that even the screen is encased in plastic, so I am relatively certain that my phone will be protected from all but the most extreme situations.The only thing I would like to point out - if you have never had an Otterbox, it takes the phone from a slim quarter inch to more than double that thickness.

For about a year now, I have been lamenting the loss of my 8 x 8 square Pyrex dish.  When I went to buy a new one, I noticed that they did something weird to the handles.  No longer were the handles small protrusions on the side of the dish, but instead - they were large *handles*.  In addition, the size of the interior of the dish seemed smaller, and the sides of the dish sloped in at a rather extreme angle compared to my last dish.  I also found, after research, that the new Pyrex dishes seem to have a bit of an issue with shattering whilst in the oven.  So, after much consideration and searching, I found this dish.  Mine was an Anchor Hocking (though I'm not sure if they leave the brand out because different brands are shipped) which is a very well known and respected company.  I am *very* happy with this purchase!

If any of you read Kim Harrison - you will know that Al always orders a latte with raspberry syrup and extra cinnamon.  I tried this drink at Starbucks and it was wonderful.  I have an espresso machine at home and thought I could save a lot of time and money making this drink on my own.  This syrup was perfect!  It tastes wonderful, both in my coffee and also on ice cream!

We received the case, did the water test, installed the phone.  While we told our daughter NOT TO TRUST THE CASE she "accidentally" dropped it in the swimming pool.  When we retrieved the phone seconds later - there were a few drops of water inside the case - sufficient enough to damage the phone!  Now, we need to buy a new iPhone (fortunately we have insurance but still a $169 outlay).THIS CASE IS NOT WATER PROOF DESPITE CLAIMS!!!! LifeProof DOES NOT GUARANTEE ANYTHING!!!  This should be a good indicator right there.This case is great if you want to protect it from accidental splashes, but NO MORE!!!!

I bought this (from Target) primarily because I have a 12 year old who likes to cook.  I like the fact that you can close the top and then lower the basket into the oil and I like that it has a cool outer casing.  Thus, my child is less likely to be injured when frying items.That being said, I noticed that everything we made, from french fries to fish to chicken, was mushy and oily despite the fact that I had the dial set to 375.  I used a candy thermometer to measure the temperature and new oil, with nothing in it, only registers at 320 degrees.  This is not hot enough to make crispy anything.After a lot of research about home fryers (and even commercial grade countertop fryers) I have found that this is true of most (if not all) fryers.  If anyone has information on one that reaches 375 degrees, please let me know!Back to the dutch oven on the stove.
This is *not* a NORPRO product.  It is a cheaply made substitute.  If you want NORPRO (which is a quality, well-made product), do NOT order this item.

I did a lot of research on this treadmill and thought I might buy it but wanted to do a bit more research.  I put it in my wishlist at 11:00 p.m. one day at $799, then went at 8:00 p.m. the next day to buy it and the price had jumped up $200.  It was a good deal at $799 but no so much at $1000.  Guess I'll just have to watch it and wait for the price to come down again as there seem to be a lot of people online who have purchased at the $799 price point.  It seems stupid to pay an extra $200 when you don't have to.  If it doesn't come down, I'll shop elsewhere.  I hear Walmart has good deals on treadmills....

Let me preface this by saying that I teach Computer Science at the University level, so I'm not an idiot.  I went to install the product on a Windows XP computer.  The installation seemed to proceed without any problems.  When I went to run the program, first - the shortcut that was automatically installed in my menu pointed to the wrong location - so I fixed that.  Then, when I went to run it, it gives me a black screen with an error that says "The primary display does not support 1024x768 resolution.  Proceed anyway"  Well, my resolution at 32 bit is 1280x1024, so I click ok - to proceed.  Still, black screen.  So I go to their website which gives some *extremely vague* instructions as to what *might* be wrong - most related to having the wrong DirectX installed. So I install the most current DirectX, same result.  Great.  I then call tech support - ummmmm, that would be ONE GUY!  Yes, that's right - there is one person to handle this so the person who answered the phone says "Can I give him a message?"  Well, yeah!  So I ask when I can get a call back.  The response?  2-6 hours!  Like I have 2-6 hours to sit by my phone/computer waiting for the ONE TECH GUY to call me back.I have one word for this 2 bit operation - WORTHLESS!  Definitely not worth the premium they are charging.  Maybe shareware for $10 but definitely NOT quality software.

We bought this along with the Great Northern Premium Quality Ice Cub Shaved Ice Machine Commercial Ice Shaver.  We shave the ice into a container, then my daughter uses her hands to scoop and shape the ice into the cone.  They are just the right size and everyone loves them.  My daughter is the favorite kid in the neighborhood, making snow cones for everyone!

Okay - so I knew when I bought this, I would have some issues.  I have a 2010 Ford Mustang convertible and a 2 pound Maltese.  I was worried carrying her in our laps for fear that a small front end fender bender would make the air bags inflate and kill our poor little pup.  So, I measured between the seats and knew it would be wide enough...but... I don't have the right type of console.  The back section of the console opens and the front part is a drink holder.  When I got the seat, I was right - it didn't work.  However, I was able to take the rear straps and attach them to the undersides of the front seats in the back, then, for the front (which was the real problem), I attached two additional straps with clips and attached those underneath the front seats in the front.  To access my console, I need to unclip the front clips, to tip the seat back.  It works great.  While it did take some jury-rigging to work, it keeps her secure between the seats, and all 4 of my seats are still open for passengers (which was the concern with over the seat options).  We use it with a harness since if she had just the collar and was thrown it would snap her little neck. Once we clip her in the harness, I am confident that she is comfortable and safe.  She was thrown from it once when we had to stop *very* quickly, and her harness kept her from being injured.  Thank goodness!  All in all, except for the fact that I had to jury-rig it to make it work, it is a *wonderful* seat!

So, we have a 2 pound Maltese.  She is scared to walk across the tile to the door, and even if she would scratch, we couldn't hear it.  We bought this about a month ago.  We started by taking her to the bells, and using her paw or her nose to get her to ring the bell.  Then we'd say "Outside".  After a while, we would just lead her to the bell (which is on the wall before the tile) and say "Ring the bell to go OUTSIDE".  We emphasized the word outside.  We would ring the bell, then tap the wall next to the bell until she nudged it with her nose.  Then we started asking "Do you need to go outside?"  And she would run to the bell and give it a nudge with her nose.  Now, about 50% of the time, when she wants to go outside, even just to play, she gives it a little nudge with her nose.  We can also get her to go outside by ringing the bell ourselves.  She's still learning, but she definitely associates the bell with going out.  You just need to be consistent and PATIENT!  It won't happen overnight.  Like I said, it's been a month for us, and we are still not all the way there, but we have high hopes.  It takes different time for different dogs, just don't give up!

Hey - I was looking for cookie scoops and saw this set.  It is a pretty reasonable price, but....if you are a PRIME member and get free shipping - you can get them cheaper if you order individually.Norpro Stainless Steel Scoop, 1 Tablespoon, 35mm is $15.99Norpro Stainless Steel Scoop, 50mm (3-Tablespoon) is $13.12Norpro 1-1/2-Tablespoon Scoop is $11.55For a grand total of $40.66 - total savings of $9.33.  Just sayin'.....

Wow!  Received this yesterday and just had the chance to set it up.  We used Home Sense Large Bowl Container - 48 Fl Oz to make our blocks.  They could have been about twice as tall but the width was perfect and they are only $2.50 for 3!  We had no difficulty setting it up.  Our first block cracked - as suggested by other reviewers.  We spent a minute wiping the cracked block on the plate to ensure it was cool - this solved the problem.  The next block went on without a hitch.  We turned it on and it made shaved ice.  My daughter screamed "THIS IS SNOW!"  It is feather light very thin AWESOME (I might add) SHAVED ICE.  This isn't like what you get from other snow cone machines - this is what you get from MUCH more expensive shaved ice machines.  It is extremely bulky. It's about 2 feet tall and about a foot by a little over a foot for the footprint  Even if this only lasts a season, it will be well worth it!

Okay - I'm going to start off with a 5 and I'll revise from there.  I'll tell you why I am giving this score when I have not even received the book. I am a well educated individual and teach at a college level.  My husband is a DVM.  I want you to understand where I'm coming from here - I'm not an uneducated lout.  So I saw this commercial on TV and thought hmmmmm....I have a daughter who struggles in math as well.  I thought this might help her (and I might find it useful too).  My husband was also intrigued.  I did some research on the web and found one of his teaching videos (It's about a half hour long if you are looking for it).  As I started watching, I thought...this guy is a quack.  My husband even said "How much did you pay for that book?"  I hadn't ordered yet...I was still trying to figure it out.  So as I continued to watch, things started to make sense.  He seems to use a combination of chunking and mnemonics to help you work with the numbers.  It's not going to make you a math whiz - you still need to know how to do the basics (add,subtract,divide, multiply), but...if you can do the basics, it seems that this will make you able to expand upon that knowledge.  I'll add more after I get the book and start learning....Okay - have had the book now for a little over a month.  The information contained within is very simple to follow.  At first, it seems as if it won't work, but with practice, it actually makes difficult math problems easy.  It's more for straight calculations (addition, subtraction, multiplication, division) rather than the higher level critical thinking involved in algebra or calculus, but it definitely makes those quicker as you don't have to take the time for the basic math.  The memorization skills taught are also very useful.  I have difficult putting names to faces, but now - it is much easier.  It's basic association and mnemonics, but the tips are very useful.  All in all, this is a very good book.

I work from home and sit on the couch pretty much 24/7.  While I'm not overweight, I am definitely a slug.  I bought this after getting a Kinect for Christmas and enjoying the games that came with the console.  I decided that I would use it regularly in an attempt to A) get in shape and B) lose some weight (could stand to lose about 10 pounds).  So far so good.  I drop my daughter at school in the morning and start with a 30 minute work out.  I usually do a couple of the warm up exercises, and then one or two of the routines depending on how I feel.  Sometimes I'll go for 30 minutes, sometimes an hour.  Then, throughout the day, at the top of every hour, I do one 5 minute modules, jumping around from exercise to exercise.  I particularly like the cardio boxing, but I've tried the Bollywood Dancing, the Hip Hop, African Rhythms, etc.  I also enjoy the Run the World modules.  This gets me up, gives me a break, and like I said - most only take about 5 minutes.  I'm hoping it's keeping my metabolism up.  At the end of the day, I sleep like a rock, which is great because I have been dependent upon sleeping pills for about 2 years now.  This is marvelous.  No weight loss yet (after 2 weeks) but I feel energized, and really less moody.  And it's soooo much easier than the gym.  (Like I'm going to pop over to the gym every hour for a 5 minute workout).  And since I am totally uncoordinated, I end up giggly half the time which I know releases endorphins which is a natural mood enhancer.  Okay - maybe it's not all Hoo-Ra and whatever, but it gets me off the couch, I feel pleasantly sore every day (not painfully), and even my family has noticed I'm less moody.  I'd say 5 stars for anyone who wants something just to get them started on a workout routine, but if you are already fit, and looking for something serious, maybe not for you.

White is a good historical fiction writer of sailing ship sea warfare, but he's not on a level with Patrick O'Brien or even C.S. Forester. He does however give a good depiction of the life of an early 19th century midshipman in the US Navy. The battle scenes are a bit contrived - even though based upon historical facts.This is the first book in a series and the first book by White I've read, so he may very well get better at his craft in later books. I will read other works by this author since I love sea stories of this period.

I've had several of this kind of tape dispenser over the years and like many others had developed a love-hate relationship with them. Either the spring holding the tape would bend beyond redemption or the tape would not cut. So, I would go out and either buy better tape or a new dispenser.Then I got smart and decided to actually read a few reviews before getting another tape dispenser. That's how I happened to come into possession  of this little gem. It works. Not only does it work, but it does a great job. There's an actual tape-holding spring (instead of a metal tab) that won't eventually bend out of shape and become useless. There's a deep tined set of sharp cutting teeth (they warn you about not cutting yourself in several places in the instructions) that easily cut through the tape at the end of applying a strip. You don't even have to apply much pressure to make that cut, which is probably the most pleasurable thing about using this device. Of course it's comfortable to handle and there's the usual tensioner knob to figure out. It also is well-constructed and looks like it will outlast me.

I've wired in many 3-way switches, so I'm far from a novice in how these things work and how they are supposed to be wired. When I tried this Lutron, things were different. One side of the traveler circuit worked and was able to turn the fixture on and off as well as adjust its brightness. The other traveler circuit didn't work at all. It would just leave the light on and you couldn't turn it off from the other 3-way switch - not how it's supposed to  be! I checked the electrical house wiring to make absolutely sure it was correct (and it was) and then I bench tested this Lutron unit. Sure enough, it was defective and one of the traveler legs wasn't working. What a PITA. I had to remove this defective hunk of junk and replace it with the original working (but not adjustable) 3-way.Fortunately I purchased through Amazon and was able to return it with no charge to me. I love Amazon!

The first question I asked myself after using this stuff is, "How the heck does it work?" But work it does and terrifically so. Just rub a nickel-sized blob of the UNO Pre-shave onto your beard and use your electric shaver to get an incredibly close smooth shave. There are a few other similar suspended - particle (either rice powder or other starches) products on the market, but all of them come with a stinky penalty they call scent. I can't stand the smell of any of these products, even if they do work. Shiseido UNO Pre-shave lotion works and it doesn't have any perfume to stink up an elevator.

I read the first edition of this book several years ago and decided that enough new stuff had been invented and discovered since then to justify getting Schewe's newest iteration. Am I glad I did!I own many LR and PS books on image editing. In fact I have a library full of them. And, I've been editing and creating fine art prints for many years.Jeff Schewe is one of the few authors out there who actually practices what he preaches. He says nothing in his books that he doesn't rigorously back up with multiple examples of techniques that you can try out yourself (if you don't believe). Almost everything in this book is oriented toward the practical, with some digressions into historical framework - which I'm sure he includes in order to provide a proper prospective.If you are serious about image editing and printing - both using Photoshop and Lightroom - then this is a must-read book.

I'm not impressed. I used it with an electric shaver and saw no difference between using no pre-shave lotion at all and this oily stuff.Eventually I discovered Shiseido Uno, which is so good I'll use it forever.

I have several different Lexar CF cards of lesser speed that I use regularly. This one is so much faster that all my others that I'm ready to buy another. I use it for still photography using RAW images that are 40-MB each, so there's no question that the card is given a workout every time I shoot or upload my images into a computer. Very fast! And Lexar quality.

I like this knife and Kershaw quality is evident in its construction, design and balance. It deploys quickly and locks in place equally well using either the thumb stud or the hilt protrusion. The knife is very lightweight for its size and comfortable in the hand. The addition of a protective hilt is a real plus.The only thing I have against the Piston Speedsafe is its size. This isn't a small pocket knife and this can lead to legal carrying problems in some locals. I also have a Kershaw 155BLKST, which is far smaller, and I find myself leaving the Piston at home and carrying that little gem almost all the time.

Quick and dirty way to sharpen. I don't really use this sharpener much on any of my better blades, preferring a Lansky system, but it does get the job done quickly. And, it weighs almost nothing so you can carry it anywhere.

I've always had difficulty sharpening knives. Either I was holding the blade at the wrong angle or doing something else incorrectly out of ignorance. I've tried those mini belt sander sharpeners, special electric disk sharpeners, V-sharpeners and a variety of wheels and flat sharpening stones. Never could get a great edge.This Lansky TB 2D2C system is perfect for me. It comes with a rough set of rods for initial sharpening, and a ceramic smooth set for maintaining the edge.You can choose either 20-deg or 25-deg (I use the 20-deg). Sharpening is as simple as cutting down vertically along the rods with an equal number of left and right strokes.I know it's a rather no-brainer way to sharpen a knife but hey, it really works.

This LensAlign specialty ruler is designed for fine tuning long lenses, 300mm and greater. It is best used with Tape's FocusTune software but you can do the fine tuning just with visible observations.Aligning really long lenses is far more difficult than for shorter focal length glass. The main problem is not the ruler itself, but rather the size of the centering and focusing targets that come standard with the LensAlign system. They're fine for up to about 300mm, but greater than that focal length causes you to be so far from the targets that both centering and focusing are difficult to achieve due to the very small size.The construction of the Long Ruler is top notch. Three sections snap together using magnetic connections to create the entire length of the ruler, which then fits perfectly into the LensAlign target hardware.Although not perfect, using the Long Ruler is still the best way to align a long lens, compared to all other methods available. That's why I'd still rate it with 5-stars.

Clearly not Clancy, but he tries to be. A very predictable tale filled with one-dimensional cliched characters and outright impossible satellite orbital technology. The author admits to his 'invention' when it comes to this satellite tech, but that doesn't make it right.

This is a very hard-to-put-down science fiction from a rather new author. It's full of all the accurate science technobable that you could ever hope for, but that also makes it a novel that's not for everyone. If you loved Author C. Clarke, then this book is a must-read. Andy Weir has created a environment of life threatening situations for his character - who is marooned on Mars - and only extraordinary problem-solving skills plus a little bit of luck allows him to survive.I can hardly wait for Weir's next literary endeavor. He can only get better.

This is really not a functioning headset. Yes, it comes with a tiny microphone that hangs down about a foot below your chin. However, this mic is so wimpy it hardly picks up your voice at all. I tested this by calling someone on both their cell phone and on their land-line. In both cases the receiver of my calls couldn't hear my voice unless I practically touched the mic to my lips - which caused the sound to be distorted.The headphones do work well and provide a beautiful sound, so if you're only interested in listening to music, it works very well. It's just not a realistic headset with mic plus headphones.

This Amped Wireless WiFi adapter worked well at first. The signal was 5 bars on both 2.4 and 5-GHz bands, compared to an older n receiver which was 4 bars on both. However, after a few hours use, the Amped adapter lost internet connectivity. I eventually traced the problem back to my DSL router, which had crashed. This scenario repeated itself several times over a 2-day period. Since this never occurred with my older slower adapter, I believe it is either the Amped hardware or software which is at fault.I tried to contact the company's tech support number, but was placed on hold for over a half hour. I eventually just hung up and returned the item.

Very easy initial setup, even if the instructions don't warn you that the device takes several minutes to complete the boot. I followed the steps for pairing it with my WiFi router signal, and it worked right away. Unfortunately the Almond 2015 is restricted to only working on 2.4-GHz, something that I didn't know about until after I got the unit. The WiFi signal really is nicely boosted (as measured with a smartphone app) and you can clearly see how it compares with the original router signal. The amplified WiFi signal is identified by having an 'Almond' (or lmond) appended to the original network name. The first few days I tested the Almond, I was able to pair it with both a LinkSys 1200A WiFi router and then a Netgear 779S AirCard.I then went to the Securifi site and registered the unit. Then things started to go south. The site kept on telling me to link my device with the Almond. The way this works is that they send a signal to the Almond and it then generates a code on its tiny screen that you're supposed to type in on the Securifi site. I tried this several times without success. On the second day, I couldn't get the Almond unit to connect to the Internet at all, no matter what WiFi adapter I tried - even disabling/enabling, etc. I called the company and they eventually did get back to me several hours later, but by then I became fed up enough to re-box and return the unit.Hugely in Securifi's favor is the fact that I was actually called back by a tech who apologized for my troubles. This communication in and of itself is enough for me to consider buying from them again at some future point. Also, if I had been more patient, I'm fairly sure that the tech that I spoke with would have eventually solved the problems I was encountering. On the other hand - and this is really a message to all tech companies - why the heck should I have to spend hours troubleshooting a brand new piece of technology when no one is paying me to do so?
Works exactly the way it's supposed to.

When they say extra-long, they mean it. In fact I found 7.3" a bit too long to handle on a smartphone or small tablet. However, when I used it on the touch screen of a laptop, it was almost the perfect length. The tip is smaller than most other styluses making it easier to press on tiny screen buttons and icons.

The belt itself is very strong and nicely finished. I am actually not using it as a belt but rather as a nearly perfect way to display a collection of belt buckles. The webbing allows for the correct placement of the buckle tines so that the buckles don't hang at an angle.I'm sure it makes a good belt too.
Every port and connector pin-out I can think of is shown.
I've only begun to explore all the uses of this incredible app and am already greatly impressed with what it can do. Unlike other such apps I've tried, this one allows you to calibrate.

Nearly useless as either a cell signal booster or a wi-fi booster. I tried this out with an AT&T goPhone (Air card) made by NetGear. It was a convenient way to keep the card charged and I was able to connect to my eithernet network, but that's about it. I returned the unit only after trying everything I could to get it to work properly.

I purchased the Autel MaxiScan after failing a routine inspection due to prior battery removal. I didn't realize that disconnecting the battery on a modern vehicle sometimes requires a few hundred miles of driving until the computer resets itself. My mechanic told me why the inspection failed and to bring it back after driving those few hundred miles. Why I got the MaxiScan  is so that I could keep checking the car's computer to see when it reset itself - which it eventually did. The second inspection passed and my mechanic was nice enough not to charge me for it.

Easy to install with plenty of spacers to tailor-fit it. The rim and tire are well-made. The reason for the 4-star instead of 5 rating is that this sort of solid tire is harder to push over bumps than an inflated type. But, then again, it should never go flat nor need air.

This is almost as much a history book as it is an historical novel, but overall Robbins succeeds in telling the tail of the fall of Berlin. The characters are all well-developed and humanly complex. The plot of course is predictable in that you know from the get-go how the story must end. However, with respect to the fictitious characters, he still retains a degree of uncertainty as you might expect.Robbins has written this book in the present tense, which takes some getting used to. His writing as usual is of very high quality and his characters - both historical and fictional) behave realistically.

These traps are much better made than traditional wood and wire mousetraps. I've been using them in a shed for about a year and see no signs of rust so far (traditional traps placed in the same location rusted very quickly). The placement of bate and the cocking of the traps is superior to what I've experienced with wooden trapsSo why no 4-stars? The bottom line for any mousetrap is will it catch mice. This one does do that job but not any better than those old wooden traps do. I think having a little cup for bait placement instead of wedging the bait under a clip (wooden traps) may be why I'm not seeing better results. With the cup, I often find the bait has been stolen whereas with the wedge method, it's somewhat harder to remove that bait without tripping the trap. I've started using sticky candy (Tootsie roll and Reese's Pieces) to make it more difficult for mice to remove the bait, and this has improved their performance.Overall, I'm satisfied with the MLG traps and prefer them to the old wooden standbys.

This case cover is well-made and fits the S5 like a glove. There is no blockage of the ports, camera, microphone, speaker when the case is open. The magnetic closure is just strong enough to keep the case closed in normal use, but it could open up if dropped. The protection is there, but the price of that is having to open the case for use. With the case opened, it is rather awkward to handle the camera - since just wrapping the door around to the back would then block it. This is a drawback of any such full closure protective case, but it is something that is worth it if you really want pocket and drop protection for the screen. The card slot is really not too useful since inserting anything but the thinnest card into it could interfere with the magnet holding the door closed.Overall, I'm satisfied with this smartphone case and have already ordered a similar one for my wife's iPhone.

Keep away from this product.We purchased one - based upon sterling (but in retrospect dubious) reviews and followed all the instructions about filling and boiling water through it twice before actual use. What occurred is that the unit gave off a strong plastic chemical smell. This awful smell persisted even after this initial 'break in period', and would not go away.That in itself should have been enough to return the boiler, but wait - there's more. The directions state that the user should expect rust spots to eventually appear on the inside of the stainless steel pot, even giving instructions as to how to clean these spots when they occur. We've owned a variety of different stainless steel kettles and pots and have only seen such rust spots appear on the very cheapest products.The Secura Electric Water Boiler is built like a house of cards. It's so flimsily constructed that I doubt it would even last several months. I'm guessing that the cheap construction and materials used is the reason for the low price compared to other such boilers.

I could not install this device on a Windows 7 64-bit desktop, no matter how hard I tried. All instructions were exactly followed - even making sure any existing adapter drivers were first uninstalled. The software that comes with this device didn't even install correctly (no tray icon and impossible to open configuration software). There was an ominous warning on an included card for potential installation problems, which turned out to be all too true. This was a total waste of time except that I was forced to learn a heck of a lot about how Windows Network and Sharing Center works.

This carburetor was almost an exact match for the original on my Echo SRM 260S. However, there are 2 major differences. The first is a negative in that the bracket for the throttle cable did not match the original. In fact, It was impossible to install the throttle cable since the new adjusting mechanism and bracket raised flange made the cable too short for it to be attached. The original was composed of a shorter deal consisting of two nuts and the original bracket had an open notch so that you just had to loosen the nuts and slide in the brass threaded end of the cable housing. The replacement carburetor had a closed threaded bracket so I had to drill out the threaded hole, cut off the extra raised flange and cut an opening on the side. Then I just used the original 2 nuts for the cable length (throttle) adjuster.The second difference between the old and this replacement carburetor is why I'm rating it with 5-stars in spite of my previous comments. The newer carburetor comes with a jet mixture adjustment whereas the original had none and was just factory set. This allows you to tune the mixture to achieve maximum power. I was able to just turn that mixing screw back and forth (with the trimmer running at full throttle) until I could get the rpm at its maximum. The increase in power on this trimmer was astonishing.

Is the MindShift Rotation 180 Pro the best day-hiker? No. Dedicated day packs made by several other well-respected manufacturers are both better balanced and more comfortable. Is the Mindshift Rotation 180 Pro the best photo pack out there?  Absolutely yes. Over the years I’ve accumulated several different day and photo packs and the Rotation 180 is in a class of its own.What makes this the very best photo day-hiking pack ever invented is its clever design. The pack is supported by an excellent suspension system consisting of a well-padded hip belt and comfortable curved shoulder straps. The shoulder, waist belt and sternum straps are all quickly and easily adjustable for the torso of most users. Unfortunately there's no dedicated torso adjustment mechanism (like on some Osprey and Lowe packs) for small, medium or large, but this is only a minor drawback. The back section is padded with foam and covered with a sweat-absorbing mesh. This isn't quite as comfortable as a full air-circulating mesh back, but it's adequate and does absorb sweat.There are additionally all kinds of patch pockets on the pack for small item storage as well as plenty of straps. All the zipper pulls are extra wide easy-to-use loops. The pack comes with a special rain cover that still allows the quick access rotation fanny pack to operate. It’s tucked away in its own small dedicated external patch compartment. Many of the straps that come with the pack have a unique spring loaded gated nylon hook which makes them very easy to attach and remove.Main (upper) compartment access is outstanding on this pack. You can get to the main upper compartment from the top or from the back (the padded back has a double zipper). This is important to me since the main compartment is where I store extra clothing, raingear, food, etc. – as well as extra lenses. This means that you have to remove the pack for upper compartment access, but that’s true for all conventional daypacks.Photo gear or day hiking gear for the main compartment?: This is up to the user. If you want to use it to haul around loads of extra lenses, flashes, etc., then get the Rotation 180 with the internal padded insert. Of course this then leaves you with little extra room for clothing, food, etc. I opted to not get that padded insert and saved several ounces of extra weight and gained a heck of a lot of extra room. I still pack some extra photo gear in the main compartment keeping things protected in either light-weight padded bags or with my extra clothing. I also purchased an optional top pocket for even more storage room, but I have not yet tried it out.Water hauling: The left side of the pack has a compartment that can hold up to a 3-liter bladder. There’s also a conventional pocket for a water bottle on the lower left. This means that your precious photo gear and clothing are kept separate from your water supply – an important consideration.EDIT: THE WATER BLADDER COMPARTMENT WILL FIT A 3-LITER BLADDER BUT IT'S FAR TOO TIGHT. ONCE THE FULL BLADDER IS INSERTED, IT BULGES INTO THE ROTATION (LOWER) SECTION SO MUCH THAT IT INTERFERES WITH THE FANNY PACK. tHE FANNY PACK CAN BE ROTATED OUT BUT ROTATING IT BACK IN WITH THAT WATER BLADDER BULGE MAKES IT VERY DIFFICULT TO FIT. MINDSHIFT NEEDS TO MAKE THAT WATER BLADDER COMPARTMENT MUCH LARGER AND/OR MADE OF A STRETCHY FABRIC. MY SOLUTION SO FAR IS TO USE A 2-LITER BLADDER (EXCELLENT ONE BY ULTIMATE DIRECTION) AND SUSPEND IT ABOVE THE ROTATION COMPARTMENT WHERE IT CAN'T BULGE IN AND INTERFER. ALTERNATIVELY, PLACING A 2-LITER BLADDER IN THE SIDE PATCH COMPARTMENT WOULD ALSO REDUCE INTERFERENCE WITH THE ROTATION COMPARTMENT.Tripod toting: A tripod can be securely mounted on the front or on the left side of the pack. I tried it out with a 2.5 lb. tripod strapped to the back for a combined pack weight of 20-lbs, and there was almost no back pull on the upper part of the shoulder straps. This is an indication of the good weight balance that the Rotation 180 provides.Protection for photo gear: I generally don’t like packs that have any photo gear on the bottom, since this is where you’re sure to thump down the pack when you eventually take it off. However in the case of the Rotation 180, there’s so much bottom padding on both the pack itself combined with the padded internal fanny pack compartment that this almost becomes a moot point. I still would be careful not to drop the pack on its bottom, just to be safe.Special access to a camera is accomplished by simply loosening the waist belt, lifting the magnetic hook and rotating the entire camera section around to your front. Then you unzip the camera section, remove the camera and shoot. There are plenty of videos of this procedure available, so I’ll just add that it actually works quite easily and rapidly. You can remove this entire camera section and use it as a separate fanny pack if you want. The camera section is big enough for me to have used it to carry a full-frame body with a 300mm lens attached. A typical deployment of the camera – from packed away to shooting – can be done in under 10-seconds, which is really what sets the Rotation 180 completely above any of the other competing photo day packs.Now what I like best about this pack: The Rotation 180 allows me to safely and comfortably carry my camera gear and not have to remove my pack every time I want to take a photo. This is a big deal, a very big deal. It encourages me to take more shots since I don’t have to take the pack off and did around for the camera. It also gives me the confidence of knowing that I can get to my camera in a few seconds if that special money shot opportunity suddenly materializes.Finally, a photo pack that's not a PITA!

This is another typical Lucas Davenport novel from John Sandford. Like all his other novels, you get the feeling that you're riding on a slightly out of control freight train. The plot is similar to many of his other Prey novels, so there's no big surprise there. If you're addicted to Sandford (I'll freely admit I'm one of the hooked ones) then you'll quickly recognize the story's progression, but I enjoyed it immensely nevertheless. Sanford writes beautifully and the array of characters he invents are colorful, heroic or evil as usual.How this guy keeps cranking out such high quality work is beyond me. I just hope he outlives me so I can keep reading him until the very end.

This is one of the few plastic pipe cutters that actually specify that it will cut both PVC and ABS.The tool is beautifully designed and manufactured and is extremely easy to use. I made cuts in both PVC and ABS 2" (2 3/8" O.D) drain pipe and was surprised at how fast and clean the tool operated. I had a special need to get absolutely square and smooth cuts and the Reed shears  were able to do a perfect job.This is a pricy tool, but in this case you get what you pay for.Note 1: The Company suggests that you slightly heat the pipe before cutting to prevent splitting. I did several cuts applying heat and several cuts without any heat in a warm basement. All cuts came out perfect - even from the ends of the pipe - with or without the extra heating.Note 2: The replacement blades for this tool cost about $57 - which is close to half the tool's selling price. This means that you need to be careful and not abuse the blade. Fortunately, the blade can be sharpened.Note 3: I called Reed Tools before I made this purchase and they were very responsive to my customer questions.

I have a bunch of this sort of pole tips from a variety of different manufacturers but these Black Diamond tips are the best. The secrete is the bottoms are covered in bumps which supply better grip than anything but a bare carbide tip. They will probably wear down eventually but I really don't hold this against them. I'll just replace them when that happens. I'd rather have that superior traction.Caution: these pole tips fit best on wider shaft ends. They were too wide for my wife's EMS poles.Hint #1: If the pole tips do not fit tightly enough, just coat the inside with some silicone adhesive or caulking. You can then still remove them but they won't easily fall off by accident.Hint #2: Get several pairs of these (or any) pole tips. I've found many of these things on trails indicating the ease with which they become detached from poles and are lost. I never hike without carrying a few replacements.
Well constructed and operates smoothly.

This kitchen faucet is very well made for the low price. I've installed other much more expensive brand name units that weren't as high a quality as this one.Unfortunately, KES doesn't include any installation instructions. This seems to be their practice since this is the second faucet I've purchased from them and both lacked directions.Fortunately, I already knew how to install these things but watch out if you've never done one before.I would have easily given this unit 5-stars if not for the lack of directions.

Very sturdy and comes with a substantial rubber gasket. I used this plate to cover old faucet holes that were 4" apart on a laundry sink. The fit was perfect and that rubber gasket sealed perfectly. It's also very pretty in chrome, if that matters to you.

I don't know whether or not I'll love it after a year (I've only had it a few months) but so far it works perfectly. Ironically, 10-minutes after I installed this battery backup/surge protector, we had a mini blackout. I have it connected to a large format printer that is particularly susceptible to voltage surge damage, so I'm very lucky.So far, I've seen it work through 2 blackouts, and it kept power supplied through the battery in both instances.
Don't let the low price fool you; this USB extension cable is very well-made.
Well-made and problem free.I use this with a computer system and attach a bunch of low power peripherals, then plug it into a surge protector.

I expected these things to be tacky just like all the other tack cloths I've used in the past. Not so - these things are only slightly tacky, which is enough to do the job without leaving a residue behind. I use these tack cloths for cleaning photos and boards for mounting, for which they are perfect.

No problems installing and cloning my Windows 7 system to this SSD. Very nice tweaking software from Samsung. I noticed an immediate speed increase over my older Samsung 256-GB SSD.My only complaint is that if I had waited just a few more months, I could have saved over $100 on the price.

The installation is the most difficult step. It took me several tries to make sure each memory module (I used 4) was seated correctly. Then they worked perfectly with no problems after a few months use. Crucial is a good company to deal with and I trust their products.

I've used this mini humidifier for several months and it does work. It sprays up a small fountain of mist that must be adding water vapor to the air. However, it actually does very little to increase the humidity. I have it in a 9.5' X 17' room with a humidistat, and it hardly registers any increase in humidity at all. Of course, this little vaporizer isn't really designed for such a large room volume. But, where are you going to use it otherwise? I imagine it would be fine if you used it in a closet, but that's just not realistic.You can't run this thing (it plugs into a USB port for power) for more than an 8-hour stretch, after which it just turns itself off. To turn it back on you have to unplug it from the USB port and then plug it in again for another 8-hours. I've kept it in an 8-oz container full of water that needs replenishing after about 24-hours or so because the wick is only a few inches long and needs to be at least partially submerged for the device to operate.The wicks that are sold for use with it don't dip very far into a water reservoir (bottle or cup) which is why it must be replenished so often. The Satechi humidifier does need periodic wick replacement, but a single wick did last for a few months of light (8-hours/day) usage.I suppose someone somewhere will have a viable use for this device, but I'm pretty sure at this point that I could have lived without it.
If you need a little something to just charge a USB device, then this is perfect.

I have used these particular Lace Locks  for several years on a variety of shoes and hiking boots and they are the only kind that actually work. I've tried all the other such devices available and only these little gems keep laces tight without slippage. I mean they won't slip even on hiking boots used rigorously through an entire day of climbing. They are also extremely easy to loosen or tighten for boot removal, yet incredibly stay put if you leave them alone. The way they operate is through a simple plastic cam gear that jams the laces against the sides when the slider is moved down. Slide the cam-gear up to loosen and down to cinch the laces in place. It's that simple.Some things to be aware of regarding the Sammons Preston Rolyan LaceLock: The diameter of the lace matters; too thin and there won't be enough surface area for that cam-gear to grab and hold on. Laces that are too thick will certainly hold better, but will be harder to insert into the mechanism. Fortunately most boot laces are just about the right thickness.A trick that I've learned to aid in installing the lace ends into the mechanism is to use a toothpick or a very thin screwdriver of similar small diameter. You can then push the lace ends through (one at a time) until they protrude enough to pull out with a pair of needle-nose pliers. Then, just follow the included directions for cutting to length and knotting.  Use some glue (or just melt if nylon laces) to prevent unraveling of the cut end tips.One last word on longevity, these things last and last. You'd imagine that since they're made of plastic that they'd eventually wear out, but I haven't been able to kill the original one I bought even after several years use.
Left earphone was DOA. The right one worked well, which is the only reason I'm giving it 2-stars instead of 1.

There was no difficulty installing this thing, just plug-and-play in Windows 7 at least. You can pop in a full-sized or a 2.5" drive - either spinner or SSD (I tried both successfully) and it connects to your system right away. Having a USB 3 dock like this is very convenient.So far, it's been functioning perfectly for several months of heavy use.

They do provide some extra warmth and don't take up too much room inside a regular glove or mitten. The best thing about using liners like this is that you can briefly remove your hands (with liners only on) from a mitten in below zero temperatures without instantly freezing.The liners themselves are well-made and look like they'll last. I take a large size glove, and the fit was good.
Tough enough to take a beating. They are large enough to fit into a standard size trash can, with room to spare.

Peter Bevelin masterfully shows us how to recognize the relevant clues in a sea of noise - all through the lense of Sherlock Holmes. Where do you need these skills? Everywhere, in business and in private life. What a great little booklet!

Breakdowns in communication affect your personal and professional lives. Communication professionals Ben E. Benjamin, Amy Yeager and Anita Simon identify six major behavioral patterns that undermine constructive conversations: "yes-buts, mind-reads, negative predictions, leading questions, complaints and attacks." Each chapter of their insightful manual contains valuable advice, as well as exercises to help you avoid falling into these patterns. getAbstract recommends the authors' methods to anyone seeking better communication skills in any setting and in any field, and to everyone in business - from the receptionist to the CEO.

Finding a glimmer of hope in the economic environment is a challenge these days - particularly in the aftermath of the recession. But business writer Rachel Botsman and entrepreneur Roo Rogers make you feel optimistic about the concept of "collaborative consumption" and its potential to alter the way people conduct business - and business relationships. The authors cite many user-friendly marketplaces where consumers share, rent, trade and barter while creating meaningful, human connections. Botsman and Rogers suggest that financial upheaval has paved a pathway to a kinder, more introspective era that will bring out the innate goodness and spirit of cooperation in individuals. Naive or brilliant, you decide. getAbstract recommends this book to marketers interested in how the marketplace is shifting and believes that anyone seeking some positive economic news will enjoy this informative, delightful and uplifting work.

Thousands of years ago, the Buddha established a framework to help people achieve happiness and avoid suffering. For Buddhists, work is an organic, important part of life and an expression of a person's highest values. Religious studies professor Franz Metcalf and business writer BJ Gallagher prove the modern relevance of Buddhist ideas, particularly in the workplace. Presented as question-and-answer discussions - as if students were quizzing a master teacher - this is a small book, but not a light read. It will give you plenty to think about, despite sometimes being a bit esoteric (consider the difficulty of condensing 2,500 years of thought into 176 pages). getAbstract finds that the readings have a cumulative, stress-relieving impact; they will give you a deeper understanding of Buddhist canons and their practical application in seeking balance.

When it comes to learning the skills you need to run a business, you are in good hands with the American Management Association (AMA). In this comprehensive manual for corporate managers, editor Edward T. Reilly, president and CEO of the AMA, expertly covers the topics you must know to be an effective leader and manager. This is solid and reliable - though basic - guidance for all businesspeople. getAbstract recommends Reilly's survey course to anyone, particularly newer managers, seeking up-to-date business management information.

Imagine a world where unknown companies can't track your every digital move, and where you don't have to click, agree and assume all the liability in every transaction. Technology writer Doc Searls envisions that world as the future "Intention Economy," a setting in which people access "Vendor Relationship Management" (VRM) tools that make vendor-customer interactions far more equitable than they are now. Searls intelligently analyzes the web today, the one-sidedness of vendor-customer relationships and the changes VRM can enable. Although tech-savvy readers will enjoy Searls's conversational style, getAbstract warns that nongeeks might find some of his concepts hard to grasp. Even so, Searls's vision is relevant to vendors as well as customers.

From the slums of Lima to rural Kenya to the streets of New Delhi, ordinary people are accomplishing extraordinary feats and changing other people's lives forever. These social entrepreneurs and the "changemakers" they enlist are the characters in this collection of case histories by former Ashoka vice president Beverly Schwartz. Ashoka, an organization that pioneered social entrepreneurship, has a support network of more than 3,000 fellows working around the world. Schwartz, a behavioral scientist, tells the stories of 18 fellows and outlines their approaches to social entrepreneurship. getAbstract finds her profiles truly inspiring portraits of people who tackled the most pervasive, seemingly insurmountable problems in the very places where they affect the world's most vulnerable, disadvantaged and disenfranchised peoples.

Gold has always had a special allure for consumers and investors alike, but speculating in gold can present enormous upsides with concomitantly disastrous downsides. Gold's precipitous climb as financial markets first roiled and then surged at the start of the 21st century raised alarms with investment strategist Yoni Jacobs. He offers a contrarian and sobering opinion based on his exhaustive research: The high-flying price of gold - that supposed safe haven beloved by spooked investors - will soon plummet to Earth. Jacobs pulls out all the stops - often repetitively so - to back up his claim, and his statistics and data are impressive, though pretty much all focused on his point of view. getAbstract, which never gives investment advice, recommends this thought-provoking look at gold to those worried that their investments could turn to dross.

For more than two decades, journalist Don Yaeger, a former Sports Illustrated editor, had a front-row seat for observing greatness at sports fields, boxing rings, basketball courts, Olympic swimming pools and racing tracks: wherever great athletes competed. Yaeger spent hundreds of hours discussing greatness with elite sports performers. In his solid exploration of how to achieve greatness, Yaeger draws on the inspirational lives and character traits of great athletes. This is great fun - if not exactly great literature - and filled with triumphant stories. getAbstract recommends Yaeger's insights to athletic adolescents and anyone who loves sports (particularly US sports, given the terminology) and who wants to learn about the personalities of champions.

Just when you want to be careful with money, along come confusing life choices: buying a car, renting a house, investing in the market, obtaining life insurance, and so on. Happily, MoneyWatch's Jack Otter provides superior advice. He lays out a series of either-or spending choices and explains the pluses and minuses of your options. getAbstract - which does not give financial advice, other than suggesting due diligence in light of your own situation - recommends Otter's savvy mini-essays on financial choices and his nicely illustrated pro-and-con presentation. If you seek clear-headed spending advice in a pretty package, you will appreciate his authoritative, easy-to-understand comparisons. On the other hand, if you find jazzy pages overflowing with big pictures laced with short doses of advice way too distracting, you may think this illustrated manual is a bit over-the-top visually. However, for the inexperienced young person or the financially daunted, the popular packaging may just open the door to sound fiscal counsel.

Making decisions is hard, and understanding new theoretical approaches to decision making can be even harder. Mathematics professor James Stein does a fine job of explaining these theoretical frameworks, converting abstract theory to applicable tools and illustrating his explanations with numerous examples. Stein offers many case studies, so readers can apply their understanding of the theoretical tools. But he doesn't always provide sufficient explanation of the factors involved or the reasoning behind how the decision makers in the scenarios weigh their choices. That aside, this is a useful introduction to a complex subject. getAbstract recommends Stein's methods to planners, managers, strategists and anyone who wants to make better decisions.

You can read this book two ways, depending on your perspective: If you are a marketer or businessperson selling goods or services, you can marvel at the skill and genuine cleverness with which media buyers and associated digerati companies have mined Internet connections to get beneath the skin of today's consumers. As a result, they are getting ever closer to the marketers' Holy Grail - the ability to target advertising to the right individuals and avoid waste. After all, people like receiving relevant ads, special offers and discounts, don't they? On the other hand - and this is the perspective of author Joseph Turow, professor of communications at the Annenberg School at the University of Pennsylvania - this style of marketing leads to discrimination: Marketers' favored consumers get better offers. Most people have little understanding of the law and find corporate privacy policies opaque. Turow explains (perhaps sometimes with too great a density of detail and jargon) that the public has had no choice in these developments. What if, he asks sagely, atomized advertising to individuals leads to a greater fragmentation of society and - as a side effect - undermines the economics of mainstream media, which are vehicles for bringing society together? getAbstract recommends his meaty exposition of one of the great dilemmas facing the information society.

Most people admire self-made men and women - the Bill Gateses and Anita Roddicks who establish successful companies and reap a multitude of rewards. However, the path to start-up success is fraught with roadblocks, detours, washouts and dead ends. Harvard Business School professor Noam Wasserman identifies the common "founder's dilemmas" and details their short- and long-term consequences. More specifically, he exposes the tacit tension that exists between creating wealth and maintaining control. This isn't a quick read; it's an in-depth, intelligent analysis based on 10 years of extensive research. At times, you may find yourself wishing for a bullet-point list. Yet getAbstract encourages would-be founders, entrepreneurs and venture capitalists to keep reading: You'll find Wasserman's insights and solutions well worth your time - and they may make the difference between your start-up's success or failure.

This exceptionally focused book concentrates on the value of generating win/loss reports to improve sales by making full use of the knowledge your salespeople learn in the course of their work. For some readers, the book's focus may seem a little insistent, since author and sales productivity expert Rick Marcet explains and argues for every step of the process. For others, his continued clarity, emphasis and focus will be reassuring. Either way, Marcet gives readers a professional tool for improving their sales results by collating better "business intelligence" from the front lines and learning from its lessons. getAbstract finds that this manual could make several kinds of readers feel like winners, including salespeople, sales managers, product line managers and anyone interested in applied knowledge management.

Facebook and other social media outlets have become ubiquitous tools for marketing. However, Ed Keller and Brad Fay, co-founders of the Keller Fay Group, a market research firm, challenge the effectiveness of these social modalities, arguing that face-to-face contact, word of mouth and other offline tools are more effective social marketing approaches for driving sales success. Citing their extensive research, the authors show that most brand conversations happen offline and that when firms shift their marketing focus to Facebook, sales generally fall. Keller and Fay seem to discount social media's positive attributes for most of the book, but they find a balance by the end, acknowledging that promoters should use offline social marketing in conjunction with today's powerful online tools. getAbstract recommends their study to marketing executives, social media experts and communications personnel. You don't need to close your firm's Facebook page - but you may want to rethink how you handle social marketing.

People don't usually associate creativity and innovation with government and bureaucracy, but William D. Eggers, executive director of Deloitte's Public Leadership Institute, and economist Shalabh Kumar Singh say a public agency can be as innovative as any private company. Innovation is a discipline, like budgeting or planning. If innovation is not a core value in your organization, you're missing the major ingredient you need to survive the shifting challenges of public administration. Referring to nimble private, public and nonprofit organizations, the authors explain innovation-building processes even big agencies can implement. Helpful infographics illustrate their concepts. getAbstract recommends this solid workbook to public agency leaders (especially new ones) and to other executives who want to harness the power of good ideas.

Most firms agree that their employees are their "most important asset," but few firms use their people strategically in today's "war for talent." When you "differentiate" your workforce, you develop your best employees to fulfill your company's strategic goals. Your job as a manager is to deploy talent as you would any other strategic resource - because that's what it is. So instead of using across-the-board spending to educate and develop all workers, you are more likely to realize your strategic goals if you allocate more resources to develop the people with the highest potential. Differentiating means identifying the right employees to "train harder and advance faster." Brian E. Becker and Mark A. Huselid (who co-wrote The HR Scorecard) and Richard W. Beatty (their co-author on The Workforce Scorecard) explain why a differentiated workforce strategy is crucial. Then they outline a step-by-step process for identifying which employees have strategic talent and for managing them to achieve your company's goals. getAbstract recommends their tactical approach to workforce management to business owners and human resources professionals who are eager to make strategic use of their troops.

Organizational psychologist Roger Schwarz understands people. He knows how they think, why they act as they do and how to encourage them to engage more productively as a group. He uses these insights to direct you through a series of meaningful, detailed steps you can utilize to run more effective and productive meetings. Schwarz illustrates these steps with numerous charts and highlights most lessons with a generous number of realistic dialogues. To help you become a better facilitator, he explains how to establish meeting ground rules and handle challenging participants. He also shares tips on how to set up the room, how to start and conclude each meeting, and how to engage participants in evaluating a meeting. Most important, he encourages you to look honestly at your thoughts and actions to improve your facilitation techniques. The book is sometimes repetitive and perhaps overly rich in psychological jargon, but getAbstract finds that it contains valuable wisdom that will help any facilitator become more effective.

The American workforce has changed dramatically since the 1960s. Today, only 17% of households consist of a father who works and a mother who stays home, challenging the underlying assumptions behind workplace success. How can companies attract and retain an ever-shrinking pool of skilled talent just as employees are redefining what it means to fit work into life and life into work? Deloitte executive Cathleen Benko and former executive Anne Weisberg say companies must abandon the traditional notion of a corporate ladder - on which you can only go up or step off - in favor of a new metaphor, the "corporate lattice," which views career paths across a grid - instead of a ladder - allowing for growth along varied paths. getAbstract recommends this book's solutions to senior managers and strategists charged with attracting, retaining and advancing a highly productive workforce, to those stuck on or off the corporate ladder, and to those who guide employees through career transitions and growth.

The heartbeat of Apple's success is deep reverence for design. The late CEO Steve Jobs had a vision for Apple that included using design to create "insanely great" products to wow customers and provide an exceptional user experience. That's why people wait in line for days to be the first to own the newest iPhone or iPad. It's also why the company is a runaway financial success. LUNAR president and designer John Edson examines the seven design precepts underlying Apple's success and explains how to apply them to your business. Edson regales readers with first-hand experiences and provides an inside look into Apple. If Apple were to design a book, it would look like this beautiful volume, with its clean white cover, glossy stock and elegant typeface. getAbstract believes designers and business managers should embrace and learn from Edson's report on Apple's successful devotion to design.

White-collar employees are working harder than ever. Many get to their offices early, leave late, work through lunch and stay at their desks over the weekends and on holidays. Yet these workers are often minimally productive. Robert C. Pozen, a former CEO who lectures on management issues at Harvard Business School, offers solutions for this dilemma in this sensible manual about time management, productivity and focus. His advice, which particularly applies to knowledge workers, is sound and generally useful. It seems like common sense, not new or flashy, but Pozen is good at helping you build confidence by establishing concrete processes. getAbstract recommends Pozen's helpful guide to professionals, managers, knowledge workers and all who want to boost their time management and productivity skills.

Organizations have different values and viewpoints. Some are "extractive," which means they drain the maximum financial value out of their coffers at all costs. Ownership strategy specialist Marjorie Kelly contends that the extractive nature of capitalism led to the 2008 recession because "financialized ownership" pushed the economic system beyond its tolerance. Some organizations, in contrast, are "generative" and base their structure on "sustainability, community and sufficiency." Kelly's impassioned arguments in favor of a generative, sustaining economy could strike some readers as pie in the sky, though she offers numerous real-life examples of global businesses pioneering fresh approaches to ownership. While never advocating any particular political point of view, getAbstract recommends her informed treatise to those pondering the economic future.

Management consultants Don Edward Beck and Christopher C. Cowan based this 1996 study on potentially game-changing work that professor Clare Graves completed 30 years earlier. The authors describe a series of spirals as the basic construct in the life cycle of a person, organization or nation. All the spirals or levels in this "spiral dynamic" system can be present simultaneously, and they are infinite - they place no limit on human or group development. Anyone who has worked with other people will find that spiral's levels look familiar and make sense. A less useful book might end by describing the levels and their values or "memes," but here, the authors supply dozens of examples and a detailed blueprint for putting knowledge of the levels into practice to help people and groups change. While smart and applicable, the book is difficult to parse: It is stylistically flawed, the editing is shaky and the structure is baffling. After reading the introduction and chapter 1, readers should skip to section 3 - a rich, interesting description of each level on the spiral. After this, getAbstract finds, reading chapters 2 to 8 - which cover the actual application of spiral dynamics - will be far more rewarding.

Many executives make decisions without consulting experts, weighing facts, considering options or engaging in thoughtful analysis. They trust their intuition and act accordingly. Such decisions often prove ruinous. Knowledge management experts Thomas H. Davenport and Brook Manville propose an alternative decision-making process - "organizational judgment" - that relies on the collective wisdom, expertise and reasoning of well-informed, collaborative groups. The authors cite case studies of varying strength (some really intriguing and useful; some perhaps not quite as piercing) to illustrate how organizational judgment proves far superior to the "golden guts" of prominent individuals who are subject to the same cognitive biases as everyone else. getAbstract recommends this perceptive analysis to all decision makers and organizational leaders.

Leaders of even successful companies unwittingly make bad decisions and costly mistakes. Consultant Neil Smith identifies "eight hidden barriers" that keep companies from reaching their full potential and explains how to shatter them. Recognizing barriers is the first step, but, to create lasting change, companies must reshape their corporate culture from the top down and employees must take ownership of their ideas. Smith identifies both obvious and subtle obstacles, though he can get bogged down in details. getAbstract recommends Smith's diagnosis to executives seeking to increase their companies' efficiency and profits.

Management experts Linda D. Sharkey, Nazneen Razi, Robert A. Cooke and Peter Barge acknowledge the common characteristics and competencies of good leaders but argue convincingly that global leaders need additional, unique skills. The authors have sufficient impressive knowledge of global business to write knowingly about global leadership based on their experience alone. Yet this work stands out because they add their analysis of past and new research, including surveys and interviews with some 150 global leaders, and they use that data to test their assumptions. This uncluttered, interesting read includes new, useful and, in one case, even surprising findings. Of course, the authors offer the inevitable global leadership basics, but they present these core concepts in a succinct, relevant way as they build toward a logical, evidence-based framework that features practical tools and guidelines for developing global leaders. getAbstract recommends this book to board members, executives, leadership development experts, HR officers, and actual and aspiring global leaders.

The world of intellectual property (IP) can be a scary place, where giant firms face off against their competitors, acquiring mammoth IP portfolios to intimidate others and discourage patent infringement lawsuits. Or it can be a place of shrewd investment and careful nurturing of assets. Harvard Law School professor John Palfrey examines the high-stakes IP world and suggests IP strategies to optimize organizational performance. getAbstract recommends Palfrey's worthwhile guidance to all managers seeking to understand their IP assets and to maximize their profitability.

In the late 1970s, China first began to open its economy and edge toward capitalism - a process that, perhaps, evolved into a conscious policy direction only when Deng Xiaoping declared in 1992, "To get rich is glorious." In this transition, China decided not to adopt the West's approach. Instead, it altered capitalism to fit Chinese culture, traditions and sensibilities. In the interim, China has experienced an "economic miracle," achieving an outstanding annual growth rate. Meanwhile, the United States faces economic challenges. Therefore, contends economist Ann Lee, the US should change how capitalism works within its borders. She says America could learn from China's policies, such as its inventive adaptation of capitalism and certain aspects of its governance. A former stock research analyst and now a New York University professor, Lee is a frequent US media commentator. She offers a pessimistic - though sometimes fond - view of the US and the West, and a positive - sometimes excessively so - view of China. (For instance, China does help African nations, as she says, but often in exchange for their natural resources.) Both points of view may seem contrarian to most Westerners, so Lee's treatise could well be instructive - and she may more candidly reflect beliefs held in China than most US coverage. While always politically neutral, getAbstract suggests her iconoclastic, controversial book to those who are interested in her take on how China's economy grew, how it works and whether it offers ideas that might benefit the West.

Self-made multibillionaire Eli Broad personifies the American Dream. Philanthropist, entrepreneur and founder of two Fortune 500 companies, Broad is the son of Jewish-Lithuanian immigrants who owned a Christmas theme store, though they did not celebrate Christmas and had no prior retail experience. In this autobiography, Broad attributes his accomplishments to his "unreasonableness," thoroughness and gutsy style. He explains how he made his fortune and offers tips on management and investing. Broad paints his personal story in bright primary colors with the simplest brush strokes, but he's glad to teach you how to get ahead in life and business. getAbstract recommends his saga to ambitious entrepreneurs, managers and investors.

Once upon a time, young manager Paul Smith worked diligently to prepare a slide presentation for the CEO of Procter & Gamble, A. G. Lafley. To Smith's dismay, Lafley sat with his back to the screen and didn't glance at the slides, choosing instead to focus solely on Smith. This taught Smith a valuable lesson: A fact-based pitch never works as well as a story. In this helpful manual, Smith offers more than 100 stories readers can use in a variety of business situations. He teaches the basics of storytelling, including examples and exercises.
