Smith's easy and absorbing manner draws you into each tale. getAbstract recommends that managers, salespeople and presenters read this charming compilation, from its useful instructions all the way to its happily ever after.

In 1945, engineer Percy Spencer was working with magnetrons, electronic devices that create microwave radio signals. As he stood next to a functioning magnetron, Spencer felt the chocolate bar in his pocket suddenly soften to a gooey consistency. He deduced that the microwaves emanating from the magnetron had melted his candy. This serendipitous insight led to the invention of the microwave oven. Entrepreneur Thor Muller and Lane Becker, both web experts and customer satisfaction consultants, explain why serendipity matters to your business and how you can spark happenstance in your organization. Their pleasant tone of voice and easy way with complex concepts make for a delightful read. Although waiting for serendipity to pass through your organization may prove as fruitless as anticipating a visit from Godot, you can foster a work environment that supports good fortune, allowing you to grasp hold of it - if it occurs. getAbstract recommends this original treatise to readers who want to turbocharge their organization's serendipity and reap the benefits of good fortune.

Most people can imagine their ideal day, but what would it take to make your perfect day - or parts of it - come to life? Jason W. Womack, an executive coach and workplace performance trainer, tells you how to change your habits and make your ideal day a reality. Womack identifies some commonsense ideas about how to "work smarter, think bigger and make more." While few of his ideas are revolutionary, they add up to a compelling prescription for breaking through barriers that hold you back. getAbstract recommends Womack's well-constructed collection of sound, practical, life-improving advice to anyone seeking increased efficiency and productivity.

People forget to mention the most important aspect of the book: It's fun to read! Yes, the tone can be harsh, even ruthless. Don't get offended by Taleb's tone. A fraud is a fraud and Taleb calls it that. Ruthlessness is just the expression of moral outrage. So, enjoy the read. It's fun. You will have a fabulous time.

Organizations with thriving corporate cultures - in which employees are engaged and energized - usually outperform their competitors. Executives and managers can reshape their corporate cultures to inspire their workers to be loyal, enthusiastic and dedicated. Global workplace experts Adrian Gostick and Chester Elton discuss how successful business leaders turbocharge their corporate cultures, thus increasing their bottom line and making their employees proud to be part of their companies. While some of their illustrative case histories strain a little to make the authors' point about corporate culture, most are credible and instructive. getAbstract recommends their insights to all managers eager to win employee commitment and enthusiasm.

Zoom co-author Vijay V. Vaitheeswaran blends the old and the new to produce something striking in his latest examination of innovation. Vaitheeswaran, The Economist's China business editor, mixes familiar points - the world is globalizing, innovation is essential - with surprising insights - innovation has innate dangers. The book's title refers to three key aspects of innovation: the need to innovate now, the speed of approaching singularity and the direction of innovation, and greed for what success looks like today, though the author actually warns against greediness. However, perhaps because portions of the text already appeared in The Economist as distinct articles, the various sections don't always fully integrate. That caveat aside, every reader is sure to find something new and useful. getAbstract recommends this smart, interesting exegesis to innovators, those managing innovators and anyone who wants to prepare for a changing world.

What do casting a hit musical and predicting the space shuttle Challenger disaster have in common? Both endeavors demonstrate the value of prediction markets - a way to aggregate knowledge, hunches and crowd wisdom - for reaching the best decision or the correct answer in a fashion that resembles a stock market. Organizations use prediction markets, or similar tools, to find a variety of solutions, from deciding on product launches to predicting the winner of presidential elections. Economist Donald N. Thompson explains how these powerful but little-known (and even less-understood) processes can help you improve your business. His text is not a how-to manual but rather a collection of anecdotes, each of which teaches a lesson on how, when or why to use a prediction market. getAbstract finds his treatise to be an easy and surprisingly entertaining read, but what will aggregated reader reviews predict? Only the crowd knows.

Risk intelligence expert Dylan Evans takes readers out of the clear but false light of certainty and into the challenging shadows of uncertainty. He defines "risk intelligence," discusses factors shaping your relationship to risk and knowledge, and walks you through the meaning of this information. The result is entertaining but it carries serious implications. If you work through the risk intelligence self-test Evans offers in the book and online to help you determine your "risk quotient," you may be humbled. getAbstract recommends Evans's instructive exploration to investors, strategists and anyone interested in being more self-aware or making better decisions.

Do you feel as if you see "Made in China" everywhere you look? Financial Times correspondent Richard McGregor explains why and more. He unveils the secrets of one of the most mysterious organizations in the world: the Chinese Communist Party. If you think a communist organization controlling a major global economy is counterintuitive, you're probably right. But McGregor explains how it all happened - and the roles that various entities such as business, the Chinese military, and the nation's regions and cities continue to play. Understanding how an anticapitalist, communist country became one of the world's economic powerhouses means dealing with a cast of thousands and a dizzying array of names and roles. And time is marching forward as China's new head of state, Xi Jinping, is now replacing Hu Jintao, the leader at the book's center. Still, getAbstract is confident readers will come away with a better understanding of what makes China tick. This is a must-read for executives interested in doing business with China and for anyone who wants to understand the system that governs its one billion people.

If you run through terms associated with the word "noble," you'll probably mention "noble leader," "noble physician" and "noble soldier." How about "noble salesperson?" Hardly. Yet, according to ace sales coach Lisa Earle McLeod, selling can qualify as a noble profession. People vitally depend on the products and services that someone sells them, such as medications that keep them well or vehicles that convey them to work. Having made her case with good stories (thanks for the one about us ) and easy approachability, if an inviting but leisurely pace, McLeod explains why salespeople who have a noble purpose outperform those who don't. She believes selling "is one of the highest callings you can have," and she shows the power of that belief for getting sales results. getAbstract recommends her heartening sales manual to everyone with anything to sell.

Tony Wagner, the Innovation Education Fellow at the Technology & Entrepreneurship Center at Harvard University, has created an impassioned guide to nurturing young innovators. He recounts the challenges creative students are facing as they struggle to change the world, and he describes the rigid educational systems they have to confront. Wagner punctuates chapter sections with Quick Response (QR) codes, which readers can scan with their smart devices to access extra materials, including interview videos that expand on key points. He offers readers take-away lessons on the importance of innovation and urges a renewed commitment to promoting innovation among young people. Parents and educators form the primary audience for Wagner's presentation, but getAbstract also recommends his insights to anyone interested in innovation, social policy and the shaping of a vibrant economy.

Philosopher Adam Smith himself was skeptical about the real-world results of his "invisible hand," but you'd never know it by the way modern-day free market fundamentalists try to push every regulation out of the way. As Cornell economist Robert H. Frank notes in his assault on the ideological force field that has blocked much US government action, naturalist Charles Darwin identified the problem: Evolutionary incentives benefit individuals, not groups. Frank uses that insight to argue that government must abridge some personal gains for the greater good. Frank is an economics professor, and his book sometimes falls into a challenging didacticism. But he writes with admirable clarity and verve, and - while his prediction that the world will one day recognize Darwin as the father of economics is perhaps a reach - he has done nothing less than provide a fresh intellectual foundation for progressivism. While always politically neutral, getAbstract recommends Frank's treatise to lawmakers, economists, historians and civic-minded professionals who are concerned with the large questions society must tackle.

Consider the iPhone. Did it succeed because it's a remarkable device, or because legions of Apple evangelists received and carried its message far and wide, making it a must-have? Both, says Michael Hyatt, chairman of Thomas Nelson Publishing. Success requires a great product, and great products demand a great platform. In this manual, consisting of snippets from his blog, Hyatt offers simple, effective ideas for boosting your online presence and developing a tribe of followers who will spread your message. Although some entries are too basic for an experienced business leader, getAbstract recommends this to-do list to any rookie businessperson, service provider, writer or speaker.

American poet Ralph Waldo Emerson once said, "The first wealth is health." This holds true for businesses as well as people. In this comprehensive report, McKinsey & Company consultants Scott Keller and Colin Price draw on their extensive research to explain how companies can achieve superior business performance in the long run while maintaining their organizational health. This clear set of instructions offers a new spin on maintaining commercial success in the medium to long term; however applying the book's program requires a dedicated time commitment. getAbstract recommends this impressive manual to leaders who want to achieve top performance, institute constructive transformational change, inspire their employees and invest in their organizations' long-term well-being.

"Performance analysis" (PA) allows companies to determine their needs and assess their accomplishments based on data, not guesses or hunches. Whether you're looking to improve your employees' skills, upgrade your company's support systems or forecast trends, accurate PA is the key to success. Business owners, human resources personnel and learning consultants must know how to execute PA. Clients who need PA usually want its findings quickly. Business moves so fast that any delay in PA risks making its information obsolete. But working quickly need not mean a drop in quality, argues education technologist Allison Rossett. With clear explanations, charts and testimony from "the trenches," she illuminates the path to accurate, applicable performance analysis. getAbstract believes her insights and advice are a valuable guide for chief learning officers, organizational development staffs, and HR officers or consultants who seek to lift their workforces or clients to the next level - and who prefer to look before they leap.

Many people wander through life with no direction or personal goals, even successful individuals with good jobs and hefty salaries. Modern-day Renaissance man Phil Cooke, a media consultant, offers some great ideas about how to discover your true purpose in life and to work toward it. Practical and inspirational, Cooke explains how to live a meaningful life and offers plenty of warmth and encouragement. getAbstract recommends his ideas to those who want to live life to the fullest, particularly those who share his heartfelt Christian perspective.

India has 1.1 billion people, about one of every six human beings on Earth. Until recently, most of these people were desperately poor. But while abject poverty remains an extremely daunting problem, many Indians are moving quickly into the middle class, a shift that offers a foundation for sustained growth and development. Editors Anuradha Dayal-Gulati and Dipak Jain - working with numerous informed contributors - provide an intriguing road map to the Indian marketplace, with insights about the prospects and challenges in several pivotal industrial sectors. This statistics-heavy compendium is thorough, though the style and quality of each chapter varies from one author's contribution to the next. Nevertheless, getAbstract recommends this fine book to anyone interested in India's industrial growth, opportunities, challenges and mysteries and to corporate executives with an interest in India as a market.

Knowledge management (KM) experts Dr. Carla O'Dell and Cindy Hubert present a framework for determining your organization's "critical knowledge," which includes what you know about your customers, your technology and technical capabilities, your manufacturing and distribution, your marketing strategies, your internal and fiscal policies, your corporate history and future plans, and more. They help you construct a strategic business case for KM, select the right KM programming and incorporate it into your employees' daily work, while demonstrating how to take advantage of emerging technologies and mobile devices to build networks and share knowledge. getAbstract recommends this useful guide to planning, launching, implementing and managing an effective KM program to managers, HR professionals and other executives looking for a road map to knowledge management.

Finance professor Andrew W. Lo and research specialist Jasmina Hasanhodzic present a history of finance and of the development of business and stock markets. Their informative research connects the commerce of ancient times to modern practices, theories and analytical methods. getAbstract recommends this sweeping and engaging history to professionals curious about how business evolved and to students majoring in economics, finance, history or related disciplines.

Managers who try to coach their employees often make wrongheaded assumptions about what their staffers think. They offer unhelpful advice about what staffers should do to improve their work, and this is exactly what coaching should not be. Human Resource Development Hall of Famer John H. Zenger and his colleague Kathleen Stinnett spell out everything for managers who haven't a clue about coaching or how to conduct coaching sessions. getAbstract recommends discovering whether you need this helpful manual in much the same way that the authors suggest using when you conduct coaching sessions: by asking questions. Do your employees need coaching? Do you feel ready to coach? What can you do to learn more about being a coach? Would reading thoughtful information about coaching help? If so, this is the book for you.

Judging from the hype, globalization is either the best thing that's ever happened to the world and its economy or the death knell for civilization as we know it. The truth lies somewhere in the middle, and that's where economist Pankaj Ghemawat wants to lead you in this smart, exhaustive study of the realities of the "semiglobalized" world. Given that there's no turning back, he posits that a more realistic approach to globalization will result in more fairness, greater productivity and increased affluence for developed and developing countries. His formula for making the planet a better place calls for free and open markets with judicious, appropriate regulation. Although the book doesn't dwell on concrete proposals, and it becomes increasingly theoretical in its last two sections, Ghemawat does a superlative job of debunking exaggerated fears about globalization and highlighting its realities. getAbstract recommends this intelligent look forward at the potential of "World 3.0."

The rules of business engagement have changed dramatically in recent years, and the traditional predictive model most business schools teach no longer suffices in the modern world. Babson College professors Danna Greenberg and Kate McKone-Sweet and researcher H. James Wilson present an anthology of academic papers that describe the college's experience teaching hands-on "entrepreneurial leadership." It also redefines the goal of business as reaching beyond profit to create social, environmental and economic value. This book of faculty papers from the Wellesley, Massachusetts, college offers an innovative, compelling model of leadership education, though like most anthologies it suffers from repetition and widely varying writing styles. Each chapter includes case studies and course descriptions from Babson, where students start and run businesses as part of their education. Although this collection may be a public relations bonanza for Babson, getAbstract recommends it because it shares enlightening insights about business education for professors, administrators, management students and today's leaders. If you've finished your formal training, you can apply its principles in your present leadership capacity.

Prolific management author Gary Hamel blends an almost nostalgic call for ethical action with tips for managing members of the Facebook generation. He cites case studies ranging from Apple to Morning Star to W. L. Gore & Associates. Though the book feels fragmented at times, it is an accessible, smooth read, and the title's imperative unifies its disparate, passionate pieces. getAbstract recommends this worthy treatise to Hamel fans, managers, innovators, those interested in corporate culture, and managers or workers struggling with change.

In this thought-provoking study of decision making, professor Frank Partnoy argues that people make the best personal and professional choices when they take their time. Too often, human beings act quickly when it isn't necessary. Partnoy helps you understand the mechanics of your thinking so that you can arrive at informed, unhurried decisions. For those who would relish a more leisurely pace, getAbstract recommends this cogent argument that time is on your side.

Social technology is changing the face of business as it changes the core element at the heart of business: relationships. Charlene Li, co-author of the best-selling Groundswell, moves you into tomorrow's world of business connections with tools, cases studies and practical experience. Some of her examples might seem a bit obvious, but her advice remains sound and grounded in the real world. getAbstract recommends Li's forward-looking approach to executives, PR leaders and managers of any-sized business seeking greater social technology involvement.

In Tom Hanks's 1992 hit baseball film A League of Their Own, an exasperated coach tells his all-female team, "There's no crying in baseball." Maybe not, but emotion plays a role in every other business. Emotional intelligence (EI) is the ability to understand your emotions and those of other people. EI derives from seeing and interpreting cues that indicate how you feel and how others feel. Such insights can be powerful tools for helping people reach their potential. This small volume by coaching experts Stephen Neale, Lisa Spencer-Arnell and Liz Wilson contains explanations, examples, case studies and worksheets to help you develop EI and use it in coaching. Though this primer can be repetitive and does cover some familiar ground, getAbstract believes that those new to coaching or to studying emotional intelligence will find it quite useful.

All relationships require trust, including professional situations where you sell to or advise other people. How do you define and cultivate trust? Consultants Charles H. Green and Andrea P. Howe start with an equation and use it as a template for practical, trust-building behavior in this worthy companion to the best-selling classic, The Trusted Advisor, which Green co-authored. Despite some confusing logic in the first section and a bit of repetition, this manual proves a thorough and thoughtful guide for building trust in a business setting. getAbstract recommends it to those seeking to establish and strengthen trust-based client relationships, and to readers of The Trusted Advisor looking to put that book's counsel into practice.

Sales and marketing guru John Westwood's comprehensive guidebook contains all the basics on exporting, including what types of firms should export and how they can do so successfully. Exporting offers numerous benefits to healthy businesses, including the opportunity to tap into the $68 trillion global economy. Selling your products in other countries can be bafflingly complex; Westwood himself experienced complications and yet remains a proponent. Though written somewhat like a textbook, his treatise provides a useful overview for managers who are considering expansion into foreign markets. getAbstract recommends it as a good starting tool for determining if exporting is right for your firm.

In this fascinating book, Kevin Kelly, a co-founder and executive editor of Wired magazine, draws on a broad range of disciplines to make synthesizing observations about the relationship of technology to life. Unlike many contemporary writers, Kelly uses the term "technology" broadly. He isn't just talking about the newest electronic gadgets; rather, he traces a history that reaches from chipped stone tools to the latest tech toys. Most readers will find some places where Kelly's argument goes too far or slides past an objection, but anyone who dips into his treatise will find it compellingly written and vastly intriguing. getAbstract recommends this thought-provoking work to futurists, planners, innovators, and those interested in human nature and history.

Digital analyst and sociologist Brian Solis steps from the virtual world into the real world to teach companies how best to exploit social media to engage consumers, build brand equity and compete. Solis backs up his comprehensive, detailed report with exhaustive research. He does occasionally fall prey to indecipherable phrasing such as, "Inward focus now must include outward contribution." Despite these minor problems, getAbstract recommends this definitive social media guide to executives who want to stake their firms' claim in the web's vast territory.

Why did the 2008 financial crisis occur? What steps must regulators and banks take to avoid similar disasters in the future? And how can individual investors protect themselves? Securities industry leader John G. Taft provides some thought-provoking answers to these questions and more. As the CEO of one of the US's largest full-service investment, advisory and wealth management firms and as a chairman of the Securities Industry and Financial Markets Association, Taft offers an insider view. His position lends authoritative heft to his admonition to Wall Street: Make stewardship of your clients' interests your primary mission. By extension, he exhorts everyone to take responsibility for safeguarding the Earth's future. Though Taft's treatise is, in some ways, a fiduciary reiteration of familiar, sound advice - be nice to everybody - getAbstract recommends his thoughtful, knowledgeable and impassioned appeal for professional and personal accountability. It's a call to arms no one can afford to ignore.

Just before the climax of "The Thin Man" Myrna Loy tells the waiter at her dinner party "Please serve the nuts." A pained look crosses her face and then she adds "To our guests." with his new Book Patrick Evans-Hylton add new dimensions to this simple suggestion.To really work a specialty cookbook like this-focusing on nuts-can't just list recipes and turn you loose in your kitchen. It has to draw you in and explain the specialty item and that Mr. Evans-Hylton does very well.He starts by explaining nuts and the different types and then how to roast them. considering how many recipes in other books call for roasted nuts I'm surprised it took someone so long to come up with a chapter on them. he is also the first person to tell me to soak chestnuts before roasting, Had I known that last year I might have spared myself and my wife  some very trying moments as unsoaked nuts started exploding!He then gets into recipes starting with small, simple snacks and building towards more complex recipes so this doesn't just tell you HOW to work with nuts, it teaches you as the book evolves leading you carefully into more complex works.In the end this is a wonderful niche cook book. I know this will be my 'go to' for nuts the way my bobby flay books are for meat.

I got these for my wife to try and her verdict was not a happy one. Capri cut they leave the bottom of her legs exposed and too cold, not good for this time of year, in the summer she would want more leg exposed.Her biggest complaint was the feel of them. She said for something that close fitting she would like it to have some cotton in it and these have no cotton at all giving them an uncomfortable...plastic feel.In the end she guessed they were ok for the gym but would probably keep them for things like an extra layer under clothes on cold winter days.

With the holiday season upon us this is a nice little thing to add to the total ambiance of your setting. It's a small cutting board with just that extra touch to say 'this is for something special' it can hold about 2 pieces of cheese to have the proper amount of space between them or a cheese and some fruit or maybe that special pate.Either way it's a nice centerpiece for a snack table or a good setting at something more formal.

In the late 20th century the people at TSR put out several supplements for games to deepen quality of play. Some were about particular races or classes or campaign ideas. A few were about world design , things like how to plan a world or how medieval castles worked which would add color and a sense of factual base to a game. Then we came to this: Arms and equipment.  I’d hoped it was about unusual stuff but it is not. It is for the person lacking any imagination or education. (How many of those are there in role playing?)There are a very few pages of things like clothes and gear like lanterns but far and away this is full of information for people who don’t know what chain mail is and who can’t tell the difference between a short sword and a two handed sword and page after page after page on pole arms so you can tell the difference between a glaive and a bardiche.  When D&D first came out there were articles on this in Dragon magazine, there were supplements with explanations of these and there were things called libraries with BOOKs to look them up. Now in the information age it is even easier to find out what the flock this stuff looks like.If you don’t have an imagination to tell you a short sword is, well, SHORT compared to a longsword then odds are you aren’t playing these games. If you don’t have the curiosity or intellectual ability to look this up you aren’t the person playing these games in the first place-go back to robbing freshmen of their milk money behind the gym and trying to impress the JV cheer leaders.While many of the TSR supplements are very good, this one is a complete and utter waste of time and money.

I liked the  first film, set in Edwardian England as Daniel Radcliff investigates an isolated mansion haunted by a vengeful spirit. Unfortunately the sequel set in World War Two was  not where near as good, loaded with historical errors with an ending that is beyond muddled.The film starts out in 1941 when children are evacuated from London in the blitz to an isolated mansion in the countryside, and pits a young teacher against the evil title character. From the very first frame, historical errors start popping up. It shows people sheltering from bombs in the London underground in 1941.  All well and good but all this was done in 1940 and people at the worst of it did not actually shelter on the tracks-as the trains kept running this would have been...bad.There are also referenced to LMF- lack of moral fiber, official cowardice. Great but this term was used in WW1, by the second war Shell shock/combat fatigue was recognized as the wound it was and treated. Such historical errors go on and just detract from the knowledgeable viewer's enjoyment.The biggest errors was the lack of the local village. In the first film the village full of paranoid locals is a key element balancing Radcliffe's sensible character. In this we only get occasional visits from the local doctor and that's it stripping away completely one of the key elements of the first film.Lastly the end of the film, the final conflict is so murky and dark I felt like I was watching an old radio show, yeah think about it.  In the first film dark shadows were highlighted by small islands of light, in this it is all dark. I guess that it is supposed to show that the teacher is struggling in the dark but the audience shouldn't. I honestly couldn't tell how she went from a hall way in the house to the bay. I hate to give spoilers but it was so badly done that I lost all interest.I thought about giving it a 3 star review , it started out with so much promise but the ending was so weak, so poor so badly flawed that it had to go down to 2 stars.

For those who don't know Vera Britain was an early feminist, a person who fought the needed battle for women's education in the early 20th century. Unfortunately her autobiography-upon which this is based- when compared to autobiographies of her contemporaries such as "Goodbye to All that" "There's a Devil in the Drum" or "Memoirs of an infantry officer" is slow, plodding and full of self righteous  and full of somewhat pedantic prose.I'd hoped that freed from her personal narrative the film would tell the story of this woman who having fought for the right to go to university became vastly disillusioned with the world seeing the best and brightest of her generation became chewed up by the horrors of the first world war.Unfortunately this was not to be. Most stories like this start out with people having happy lives that are slowly poisoned by the war, but in all honesty Vera of the film seems like what my dad would have called 'a right old misery.'  Even as a young woman she seems to be in a perpetual funk about this thing or that thing so as her world is torn apart by war, it just seems that she merely switches the target of her ire from one thing to another rather than discovering new levels of herself.The only time she actually seems happy are a few brief scenes of her engagement but overall she is portrayed as a completely unlikable and unsympathetic person who would make the likes of Sylvia Plathe say 'lighten up already!"As my wife said you wanted to feel something for her but she is so one dimensional, always upset about SOMETHING that you just don't care.

One of a series of supplements done for AD&D in the mid 1990's giving players a chance to explore other time periods rather than just classic high fantasy. This focused on ancient Greece with ideas to play it as the world of the great heroes, or the being of classical history. you can walk in the world of Lysander and Ajax, or Bellopheron and Perseus or even the world of Alexander the great.There are chapters telling what spells and classes can and can't work in a Greek campaign but more than anything there are details and pictures on everyday Greek life; clothes and furniture and jewels. this is how these things should be done. Too many just recounted history of the period but in  Age of Heroes we have a really good example of how to. how to set up an adventure in a classical world, and how to write this sort of supplement.You don't need this to play  a good game, but this will certainly help you setting up a different world than is normal.

I appreciate how difficult it is to make a tarot deck. you have to produce scores of pictures all of which follow the theme but you want to have your own impact indeed you have to work very hard to make a deck unusable. Unfortunately Donaldson and Pracownie have put that level of work in.I won't quibble over the artwork for its own sake. That is subjective. What I will take great exception though is how the pictures don't really match the themes. I mean that's the whole point of the ART on tarot decks. I mean you can just memorize what the 4 of cups or 3 of staves are by rote but the idea is that the art is supposed to convey some of that message within the picture and they just don't. I mean just to pick and choose 'temperance' shoes what looks like a goblin jumping at the viewer. Strength shows a dwarf sitting and thinking and  the hermit shows a dwarf standing with an ax in his hands-maybe these should have been reversed? the 'hermit' dwarf seems to more embody strength. The devil, a card meaning greed, shows the dragon Smaug burning a town, fair enough. the very next card, the tower, shows the same dragon, in almost the exact same position burning a valley. the images are almost identical. The magician card shows Gandalf-fair enough, entirely predictable. But so does the heriophant. again the wizard at a nightsky. uh, yeah. little enough to tell between them.The minor cards are even worse as traditionally they show the items names. I mean the 3 of swords is supposed to have a picture showing 3 swords. The 8 of coins shows 8 coins, and so forth, but these don't and the images again do not convey any sort of meaning. it just goes on and on and on. If you have a child who wants to play at reading cards without any real meaning or who wants to look at pictures of dwarves and such, groove, go for it. If you're looking for a usable deck, pass it by,pass it by.

At the end of the film Gettysburg, there were small vignettes about the facts of each of the principal characters lives after the movie. not enough to be distinct but enough to slake the idol curiosity of the casual student. For all intents and purposes Robertson has done the same here creating a book with 70 mini biographies of people he feels were important. Each is 4-5 pages long and just enough to answer the question 'I wonder what happened to...?"It's cute and for the passing student of the era, a nice little resource so long as the person you're asking after is one of those in question. A great many of the choices though seem to be less  people who shaped america than personal interests of the author. I think we ALL know what happened to Custer after the war (just a little off the top) and some, like George Pickett, who did darn little sort of makes you question his statement that these were people who shaped america during reconstruction. I could think of others who did not appear but so can pretty much anyone with a passing knowledge of the period.What we're left with is a very nice little reference book, like an osprey monograph it's not the last word on the subject but it can cover basic questions and maybe set you in the right direction if you're looking for something more.

I first encountered the stories of Dr Darwin decades ago in a paperback that had three of the short stories and I loved them but couldn't believe there were only three. Now, long years later I came upon this work, more stories, and all of them wonderful. My long wait has been rewarded!Living in the late 1700's the grandfather of Charles Darwin was himself a scientist and scholar and noted physician with an interest in mysteries and the unusual. Sheffield, a noted hard science fiction writer took this and molded it into almost Sherlock Holmes like adventures set in 1770's Britain. I don't give spoilers but an example is that he is lured up to Scotland with legends of a great beast that lives in a lake, but as he gets ready for the investigation, he discovers there's another reason the local Scots have gone to such extreme measures to get a famous doctor to the highlands.In another a man invites the doctor to examine his wife. the gentleman is sure his wife is going mad because at night she swears she sees people moving on the great fellside beside the house.  A brief examination convinces the Doctor that the lady is not only not mad but has very acute eyesight. so if she's not hallucinating then she really is seeing something and if so what? Faeries, demons, ghosts, or maybe something more mundane-smugglers or poachers. Still the good Doctor has to have a look.these are the themes followed wondrous possibilities with plausible resolutions. And just so much fun in the telling!

Bryant & May and the Burning Man is the latest police thriller from the pen of Christopher Fowler dealing with the slightly loopy members of the Peculiar Crime Unit.It’s fall and London is wracked by riots as people protest the inequality of the banks and lack of punishment for bankers who are financially irresponsible. The PCU members watxch with a sense of detachment until they are called in. A homeless man sleeping on the steps of a bank that was firebombed by the mobs needs to be identified and dealing with riots no other section has the manpower to spare but as things unfold they realize it was not a case of someone being in the wrong place at the wrong time, but someone targets for death, murder. When another man dies under equally weird circumstances it becomes clear someone is using the riots to cover their tracks as they commit murder, but who or even why, the victims seem unrelated, is the mystery.The real job of the PCU books is the way fowler and by extension his characters, look at the world. Although a serious mystery the detectives seem to have sprung from the same sensibilities as Douglas Adams. The book opens with a memo from the team leader to his crew informing them, among other things that builders have discovers a lock of support under the first floor interview room so please keep fat witnesses away from the middle of the floor. Detexctive May (good people skills) and (knowledgeable curmudgeon) Bryant drive their team leader to distraction with their ideas, theories and antics (“The last time I want on vacation you filled my office with Tibetan monks!) but they do get results.So if you’re looking for a good mystery with a slightly off kilter look at the world, then this is for you.

OMG! This is wonderful. The tin is filled with individually wrapped nuggets of Hershey's dark and milk chocolate around cores of caramel. Usually i find just straight Hershey bars a little waxy for my taste but here they have the balance just right resulting in a sinfully good candy.With the holidays coming up this is just the right thing either to take to parties, family gatherings or just to have around the house.

it's hard to say what I don't like about this because there's so little I like. My dad had a watch like this in the 70's and thought it would make a nice change from my usual leather strap watches. The problem is this watch doesn't know it it's supposed to be for adults or children. It is really large, the face is really big and very simplistic. you only need a face this simple if it is a small watch but the freaking thing has a large face and you don't need the numbers to be THAT big unless you're still using Sesame Street as a learning tool.The strap is very large, VERY large, like I put it on and it was not just sliding down my arm but out over my hand. I'm no pip squeak but this just seems too much, a massive band and childish face. it's like something for a near sighted Lou Farigno.Add to this the box was not clean. The cardboard box the presentation box was in had popped it's seams and the presentation case with in it was badly stained. I don't think that can be blamed on amazon shipping because the presentation box was inside the shipping box and THAT was inside the amazon wrapping. It sort of implies the people and or facility wasn't too clean or too careful or just didn't care, which sort of seems to be the entire motif for this product and they want $80+ for this? seriously?

The makers of blades have nearly put themselves out of business by driving up costs. Back in the late 80's I would use an electric shaver for my chin and upper lip and a blade for my neck and cheeks. A nice firm smooth shave. But as the price of razors went through the roof , I found myself more and more using just an electric razor for everything day to day.  I kept a real shaver with proper brush and all for special occasions but in general it was the electric shaver.Now this comes along. At less than $10 for 8 razors it is reasonably priced IF you can get 2-3 uses out of each shaver. At a single use it can be a little steep but if these last then you're looking at a reasonable price for the item, something badly missing of late, and might see a return to proper shaving.Yes this takes a little longer than the electric job but it does do a better job and if they've beaten the price issue, i'm sold.

I will say I did not buy this book, but seeing a copy in a store I did take a good hard look at it. I had heard about it but couldn't believe it was true.Uh silly me. The aptly named book is nothing but a collections of pictures taken of herself by one of the most vapid self centered women on the planet. Seriously page after page after page of pictures of her.I don't know who's more mentally deficient, the Kardashian for thinking there was a market for this or people who paid good money for this (if they didn't buy it as a gag gift) when there there are plenty of pics of her on line for free.So if you don't like this woman, and therefore have both good taste and a firm place among the majority in the country, or you are one of those strange, sad people who do like her, there is NO reason to spend money on this. Seriously do you really want to spend money to pour over pictures she took of herself? Page after page after page of them? why?

"So these differ from a candy bar how?" asked my wife looking at the box and her question is not out of place. Each tube holds 6 little nuggets of a candy bar type instead of a single solid bar. I think the difference is that that way it is easier to share and even if eating solo it takes longer to each the nuggets one by one so you'll find it more satisfying as a snack.flavor is a personal matter. My wife and I enjoyed the chocolate snacks. The other ones seems a little...lacking with a flavor best described as the sort of thing use in libraries to meant the spines of old books. That having been said, a box of 21 snacks for nearly $40 +S&H? Get real!  Considering what you can get at any supermarket, a bag of 'fun sized' candy for only $4-$5? seriously this is stupidly over priced. I suspect these will be given out to larger kids at Halloween.

The heater unit only stands about 2 feet tall. the pictures make it look much more imposing and potentially difficult to find a place for but it actually isn't that large. So it should fit nicely into a corner.The controls on the machine itself are very easy to work with you really don't need the instructions it's so easy to set up and all, but the remote control seems a little more limited. I think if I lost it or it never came with one, I wouldn't see it as much of a loss.I got this for free from the amazon vine program but late summer is hardly the time to test a room heater. I mean seriously? Is it hot? oh yeah. Was it the heater? No it's the flippin' sun! When it gets a little cooler I'll update this further but from what I've seen so far, I like it.

Earlier in the season I tried their seeds to shady areas and while I didn't have much  luck I think it was down more to me than the seeds. I gave half of THAT sack to my neighbor who'd had work done and it grew nice and thick. So then I was given a chance to try a sack for heat damaged areas i jumped. My back garden faces west which is great from fruits and vegetables  but murder on the grass, except under a shade tree. so here were have a chance to put down grass that will resist the scorching. The only issue for me right now is that I don't think it's the time of year to put in grass so this might have to wait until the spring for me to update, but having learned from my mistakes with the other seeds I'm looking forward to getting this right.

If you cook, you need tea towels. No just to clean dishes but to hold hot pots, wipe stuff down, clean your own hands one, they are the ubiquitous kitchen tool. In his book Kitchen Confidential Anthony Bourdain wrote that a supply of towels was part of his professional mis en place.In that light these are good, study, regularly adaptable ‘tools.’ I gave them only 4 stars because they are still just tea towels and I save 5 star for the stuff that blows me away, but these are, for what they are, very good.

Sure this has a pretty face and it hopefully keeps good time but this has some serious problems. My wife looked at it said it was pretty, probably too stylish for casual wear and then it went south.My wife is petit but this watch isn’t. The picture makes it look small but in fact the face is about the size of a half dollar which means this is very large on a woman’s wrist. Considering a woman’s watch goes for ‘delicate’ then the woman wearing this would have to have a pretty hefty arm to make it look delicate.The second serious problem is the clasp. With any buckle in existence since the 17th century the tongue has moved independent from the frame. That’s how a buckle works. In this case the tongue is fixed, ridged as a spike sitting down from the frame. It doesn’t move and the space between the tongue and the other side of the frame is too small for the strap to get in. We couldn’t get it on her arm.We spent about 20 minutes trying to figure it out. Instructions included told how to set the time and changer the battery but not how to put it on a wrist. With this we’ll have to either see if a jeweler could explain it to us, or just buy a new strap.Sure this looks pretty but it’s pretty hefty in size and impossible to put on as it is. Just look elsewhere for a watch. As it stands this has too many issues to work.

I absolutely love Jim Butcher's writing and the Harry Dresden stories about the only wizard in the Chicago Yellow pages. Although a wizard Harry has more in common with Sam Spade or Spenser than he does Gandalf and Dumbledore mixing magic, wise cracks and pop culture references.These short stories are just as good for their writing quality. But this is *massively* over priced. We've waited a year for the next Harry Dresden story which is usually several hundred pages long. Here we have the price we've come to expect and are willing to pay for because Butcher is just so damn good, but instead of hundreds of pages we get 130?  and these aren't new! They're short stories published elsewhere already. Seriously. That much money for so little?I understand the writing process can be hard. I even prefer him to take the time he needs to create a good story rather than just churn out any ol' thing for a buck. But to expect his fans to cough up the same amount of cash for a tiny work is a scam gentleman Jonnie Marcone would raise an eyebrow over.Seriously a full price for something so thin? Butcher has served up the equivalent of tofu bean curd pizza-it's just wrong man.

I remember when “The Devil went down to Georgia” was getting air play in the 70’s. It was an explosion of talent, two completely different violin solos by the same man within a single song. heck I bought this in vinyl and was swept away by all the other tunes.Now, years later, my nephew is learning the viol and while he enjoys it, he’s played for 4-5 years, he doesn’t like classical music. Hearing that there was no question what I would send him to show what else can be done when you rosin up your bow. Sure Alabama said you need a fiddle if you want to play in Texas, but Charlie is the past master.

I really like Ace Atkins. he did what I thought was impossible, he picked up a beloved character from a dead author and breathed life back into him. All too often such attempts are travesties of the original but through several books Ace has captured the essence of Spenser and allowed Boston’s best PI to live on beyond his creator. The style still holds here, but the story is a clunker.Spenser is hired to investigate a town where a local judge is coming down harshly on juvee’s and as he investigates it seems there are kickbacks, pay off and a hopelessly corrupt town. People who’ve tried to look into this are silenced, but of course Spenser is far too tough to be intimidated by redtape or thugs.On his own or in familiar settings Spenser is fine but the town becomes unbelievable. Every time he’s facing down corrupt cops/judges/clerks etc it is just too much, the sense the town couldn’t possible exist without this level of corruption without someone noticing. Usually Spenser deals with a person or company under the general radar but here it is the entire town and the fact he doesn’t makes calls to big city reporters he knows or senior state police or FBI contacts for at least information while he could just rolls through town, it’s as if the town doesn’t really exist in the real world but through a mystical portal and it’s just too much. Every time he hit the corruption in the city, the plot just dragged. Add on a sub story about a boy going through the system, which I started skipping  way through, and it is possibly the worst Spenser story since “The professional.”I think he, Ace, was trying for dystopian but the corruption is so endemic that you can’t believe it hasn’t come to the attention of other sources before Spenser hits the town.  that the point, you can’t believe it. It is so dark and evil that it badly interferes with the suspension of disbelief.Ace does good Spenser. He has a wonderful feel for the character and the style but here the story itself becomes too impossible and too clogged. I look forward to Ace’ next attempt but this one? pass it by.

OK I got this for things like cleaning the pavement under my roses and things like that. It seems nice enough but there is a real build quality issue.Out of the box it came together very easily and only took a few minutes. Fully assembled it didn’t have much mass so it was easy to manhandle. The power cord is a little limited but that’s easily fixed with an extension cord.Pressure level is good. I mean it could be better but that would be a professional level, gas driven engine. This is for the casual home owner taking care of little jobs around the garden and for that it works just fine.The problem is the wand. Mine has not started leaking but as several other testers have reported this problem it seems to be a serious problem of build consistency rather than a design flaw. This makes me wonder if I got lucky or if mine will go too. You shouldn’t be worrying about tools breaking down while ‘new.’ Considering the cost to replace the damaged unit, this is something they need to address before more people spend money on it.

Diane Davidson has been writing cozy mystery’s about a caterer for years. and now she has put together a cook book based on what her protagonist, Goldy, creates.The concept is pretty simple Caterers get invited to all sorts of places to provide food, like Victorian servants, if they do their job no one notices them but they see everything and when they keep getting involved in murders at events, well….Diane has done a good job making a cook book, not an anthem to her characters. With chapters arranged by the topic, not book, and the name of the book where the dish came from is supplied along with interesting commentary about the dishes’ inspiration and this is what really makes the book. any cook book will list ingredients and how to assemble them but a good cook book makes you want to do it, small little anecdotes about the meal makes it sound like something fun to try.The recipes themselves are not over the top. Each takes about a page total and while different do not seem to contain many hard to find ingredients, (I’m still looking for pickled walnuts for a Jennifer Patterson recipe from the 1990s!) so it’s not going to strain anyone with a decent pantry or local megamart to create these. A few pictures would have helped. Diane explains how these drive up the costs of cook books but still, she says presentation of food is important but the reader is left to wing it.I haven’t tried any of these yet but they look interesting and I’ll update this when I know how they work out. As an interesting aside I’m not sure I’d want the patronage of Diane or the business of Goldy. A great many of the restaurants Diane cites as sources she also says have closed and when Goldy goes somewhere, people actual die. I mean really ladies, I’ll read the books but keep my distance.

This is very much like the Norelco shaver I’ve been using for years so I was excited to give this a try. 360 rotating head, good. Nice little stand to charge it in, good. Easy to clean head, good. Actual job shaving-not so good.This is a design I’m comfortable with in my hand and I like the little stand it comes with. The charger cord fits in the base and it’s just a little frame so it doesn’t take up too much space but it looks so much more tidy than the shaver just sitting on the side. The head pops open easily for cleaning which is good. And the shaving head pivots all over the place for access. I was really excited about this.And then I used it. The multiple rolling heads works really well on the difficult parts of your face, the chin, under the nose, those areas where the rolling heads do their bit. The problem, ironically was having done a good job on the tough stuff, it fell down badly on the easy stuff, the long lines of the neck and jaw line. The 360 head was working so hard to rotate it really wasn’t handling the long flat plains. I was very tempted to put the damn thing down and get out just a regular razor to cut those as it would be less awkward, faster and safer as I was growing frustrated with the shaver.In the end I found this very frustrating. Remington in the past has made very good typewriters and rifles but lately they seem caught up in producing shavers with gimmicks and with this, the gimmicks are getting in the way of a good shave.

While many people read about the civil war for the battles or the legal changes wrought, or the changes to society (Sherman’s march or the siege of Petersburg by example causing a great deal of distress to local populations) another side of the war was race relations.  Not just the argument as to whether the war was about slavery itself but how blacks in federal uniform were treated when at the mercy of the Confederates.To address this Greg Urwin has amassed a collection of essays on the most infamous stories to try and get to the bottom of it. Even today 150+ years after the end of the war there are sides who argue did atrocities happen at all and this is reflected in the essays presented. The Federal investigation of Fort Pillow was led by a radical who painted as bleak a picture as possible and his poor research and political tact are held up by many southerners as proof the massacre never took place, but another writer  shows inconsistencies in the confederate reports prove there was violence, just not co-ordinated.Massacres of black soldiers at places like Poison spring, Marks Mills, Plymouth NC and “The Crater” are reviewed and repeatedly show that while there usually wasn’t a plan to murder blacks in uniform, there was also very little done to hold back individual soldiers from attacking blacks in uniform with people boasting to each other of the vast numbers they killed. While the boasts are clearly exaggerations they show that the men did not see such acts as murder or even wrong.One essay points a rather humorous picture of Prisoners taken at Ft Wagner, there were laws in place for the punishment of escaped slaves under arms but nothing about free born black men under arms. It became a political hot potato as the poor men languished in jail cells, no one wanting to take responsibility for either punishing them, which could lead to federal reprisals or even recognizing them as POW’s, but how do you hold them if they are not soldiers?In the end we are left with a view of the south horrified that ‘negroes’ were being used in war against them, and often incredulous that African-Americans were often competent, efficient, well-disciplined troops. and while politicians might splutter on about dire penalties to be visited on most generals did not have such orders, at the same time they did not do anything to restrain their men from exacting savage punishments on black troops. Nathan Bedford forest may not have ordered the massacre of black soldiers at fort Pillow, but he did damn little to stop it either and this is a pattern repeated time and again at other sites where confederates found themselves facing Federal troops who were men of color.Not all the essays are gems. One particular about the suffering of white officers who led black troops seems to break down to number crunching but overall these strive to present a very balance view of the evidence presented and the deeds done. The stories are well documented often citing witnesses of the events and current news paper accounts-allowing for the variance. although this came out in 2006, in the later haf of the 20-teens, as arguments are again raging over the confederate flag and is it a symbol of racism or ‘what my great great grand father fought for’ it is well to see that a great number of evil , racially motivated atrocities were committed under the ‘battle flag.’

With so much middle Earth art work out there this is nicely different as a wall hanging.  While most maps are copies of Tolkien’s own maps of middle earth or the Lonely Mountain this is a floor plan of Bilbo Baggins’ beloved Bag End. with it you can easily see where the dwarves came in and sat, the long wood paneled halls and easily imagine Bilbo and later Frodo living as THE Mr. Baggins of Bag End.For a child who loved the films or book it will be something special to put on the wall. Magical but at the same time, Home.  Which is ultimately what the books are about. having a home.My one problem, that stops this from becoming a 5 star review is it is the Bag end of the Film, not the book.  Yes it includes all sorts of things not mentioned in the film like cold storage and such but it has only one guest room and only two other vaguely named spare/empty rooms.One of the first things in the book “The Hobbit” is a description of Bag End with several guest rooms, the hobbit was fond of guests, and whole rooms full of clothes. None of which is shown here.So wonderful but the discerning reader will notice it doesn’t quite match up to the books and that does weaken it, from a literary link, to a movie prop.

I go camping a few times a year and the idea of something small and handy to light fires, meaning you can lighten your pack, seemed like a good idea.Ah, no. IF you’ve been chucked out of a helicopter in the Austrian Alps and it’s an emergency then this will serve but that’s about it.With a little work this does throw sparks but my striker was pretty dull, meaning I had to do work on it to make it functional. This is not listed a DIY.  The lanyard holding it together is sort of restricting since it limits how far apart you can move your hands and the amount of space of the striker it limited meaning this won’t last long.This comes with a little folded page of emergency survival skills like building a lean to and a snare for trapping, but no directions for the tool itself.  So you’re going to waste a little of the limited lifespan on this trying to work it out. Maybe that’s the Bear Grylls part of the item since this isn’t what HE uses. Just something he slapped his name on for a buck.In short IF you know what you’re doing this is ok for an emergency, but odds are if you know what you’re doing, you’ve got a better tool than this to start fires with.

In Kingsman we meet Eggy, a London street punk whose late father had been a secret agent. When he gets into trouble in steps Colin Firth, a member of the same organization who owes his life to Eggy’s dad and Colin seeks to repay that debt by saving eggy from his life by giving him the chance to join the same spy network, to become a Kingsman, just as they are heading into their most difficult case ever. So as Firth tries to find out what Tech billionaire Samuel L Jackson is up to, eggy is put into the training program to compete against other applicants for the top spot.You can see it coming. Naturally the student must rise to the role but you don’t mind it’s well done. The problem is that Kingsman is never sure if it wants to be a serious action film or a parody. It does both but if you were to  look at it a James Bond on crack/Arnold in a pinstripe suit/Harry Potter with a machine gun, you wouldn’t be too far off the mark.I enjoyed it because I stopped trying to figure it out and just went along for the ride, though Jackson’s character always talking with a lisp became beyond annoying. he’s such a great actor with such a wonderful voice and he hamstrung himself with a lisp that seemed to leave him in danger of spraying spit all over the set.In the end you just have to surrender to the mania. It’s the sort of movie to watch with a bag of chips and friends who are going to cheer the good guys and mock the bad guys. It is a lot of fun. Will you have a life changing experience with memorable quotes? No. it’s not that kind of movie, then again…

This is a universal story, thus its wide appeal to audiences and critics.  The mood is dark throughout the movie which increases the viewer's impatience/desire to understand the primary character's angst and disconnectedness with the world around him.  Multiple themes play into the progression of this cautionary tale which include: being labeled as worthless due to one's finances;  the barriers to those who are poor to succeed or break-free;  and the opportunist's who take advantage of those who have no voice to name a few.Hussein does have those who care about him but they have their own agendas as well and the more he sinks into despair the more he isolates.  When he decides that he will take a stand, he is humiliated and emasculated by the actions of others.  This drives a seemingly ordinary man to snap and do the unthinkable.It took me some time to really appreciate the insights this movie offers and it is well deserving of the acclaim it has been given.  The seemingly low budget feel is part of the movie's appeal and adds to its atmosphere. You won't be disappointed.

Sharon K. Souza is an author worth watching.  Her book was among some suggested on this website and I couldn't stop until I finished.  The characters are authentic and sound like people you've known and their actions are logical though not predictable.  Ms. Souza captures emotional trauma's aftermath with such clarity and vividness, she should be given her day in the spotlight.The premise of the story is taken from today's headlines.  It hits deep inside each person's psyche as something beyond a few moments of contemplation as the dilemma of such an awful situation to bear and yet the primary characters must live through the moments that follow one breath at a time.  Will faith be enough to sustain them?  How do you hear from God when you are angry at Him?  How do you think when your guilt overwhelms you completely?  How do you love when you feel so unlovable?  These are the questions addressed by most world religions for many eras past and are well managed by a talented author, who guides you through these landmines.Take the journey this book offers, it will challenge you and help you refocus on life's most important messages.  All aboard!

This is one of my favorite books when I want to find scriptures according to subject matter.  I always keep one in my car so I can use my time effectively when I am stuck in traffic, it is a great way to get your focus off your frustration on to what really matters.I also try keep one handy to give away, if I meet someone needing encouragement.  Many homeless people don't have a Bible, so this is lightweight for them to carry and I keep them enclose it in an individually sealed ziploc bag, so if they get rained on the book doesn't get damaged.  I can't tell you the appreciation I've been shown from those wanting one.  It is a great way to witness and lead people to Christ or repent and rededicate their life!

I thoroughly enjoy the layout of this book and the fact that it presents some of the Serrat's most known works (125 reproductions) and 48 of those are large sized and in full color!  Chances are if you like art enough to go to a museum on occasion and visit art shows/festivals, you are familiar with his work.His post- impressionistic style reminds me of  Manet and Monet but some of his pictures tend to be more bold and the colors more bright.  However, his work incorporates a variety of different scenes including crowds, seaside, water edges to nudes.  While you may not know them by name, this book includes: The Models, 1888, Barnes Foundation;  The Eiffel Tower 1889, California Palace of the Legion of Honor, San Francisco;  Gray weather, Grande Jatte, 1888, Philadelphia Museum of Art; A Sunday Afternoon on the Island of La Grande Jatte, 1884–85, Art Institute of Chicago (one of my favorites);  The Seine and la Grande Jatte - Springtime 1888, Royal Museums of Fine Arts of Belgium;  Fishing in The Seine, 1883, Musée d'art moderne de Troyes; and Bathers at Asnières, 1884, National Gallery, London.  While I did not name all of the pictures you can get an idea by using a search engine because the famous ones are all included.I am a big fan of Abrams Publishing's art books.  Their books at least in the 1980's were high quality (most of my art books are from that era and so I have more than one of them in my collection), the paper barely shows any signs of aging.  They have cloth hardcovers with lovely dust jackets that are very sturdy and they have traveled well among my moves.

Kathryn Ma delivers an insightful tale on the emotions stemming from being adopted.  While Chinese culture is a theme, since it is told from the viewpoint of a young Chinese girl adopted as a baby by a successful American born Chinese Woman, she still a struggles with the questions most adoptees have at some point addressed.  The voices in this story sounded very authentic to me.  While I was not adopted, I have had four very close friends, who were adopted and shared their anguish at still hearing a "voice" stating that they were "abandoned", "given away", or "unwanted"  despite a loving adoptive family.  While some cope better than others, the unanswered question of "why" plagues their relationships and other life choices.  While this was compelling in itself, there are also several secrets that enhance the story and work against a healthy family dynamic.  This coupled with excellent characterizations make for dynamic and twisting plots and subplots.On the surface, the author gives us a fairly common family type.  A successful, never married woman, Charlie, who desires a family.  She raises Ari within a small matriarchal system consisting of a long widowed mother and unmarried sister.  Charlie resists her more successful sister, Leslie, who is more a competitor than sister and their disapproving mother.  While Ari is the primary character, she is unknowingly influenced by the secrets each woman is keeping.  The saying, 'you are only as sick as your secrets' is quite applicable.  As an adult, Ari seeks to find answers and when she discovers Charlie's secret, she attempts to unearth the past but story unravels in unexpected ways, pushing her to greater despair.  As others share their secrets with the reader, we wonder if they can ever find peace with their past and common ground and trust with each other.Ari's characterization was well written and spot on for her age.  Meanwhile, the other main characters were just as believable as well as their reasons for keeping their secrets.  I thoroughly recommend this to readers of family drama.  While it had a dash of immigrant tale, with a splash of war and a healthy dose of teenage angst searching for identity.  It offers the reader a a present day story formed by adaptation to a difference in culture.  However, most importantly it is a story of family torn by secrets and failures.Great accomplishment for a debut novel, Ms. Ma will become a household name recognized for her insight and talent.

Long after I finished it, I have puzzled how to review these stories.  Nickolas Butler is an excellent storyteller.  His stories feature ordinary people facing life's limitations and in most stories they weigh in as the 99% up against the 1%.  We identify with their frustrations and applaud their actions (or some of them anyway)!  These stories unwind in such a manner that the reader has to read to the finish.Overall, I liked the stories, a couple in particular have continued to stir in my conscious mind though I've read at least 6 novels and a memoir since I finished this collection.  I don't generally read short stories, however, this collection was time well-spent.I will caution those contemplating the purchase, that some stories contain some brutal scenes and a few violent sexual encounters.  Additionally, some may find the presence of  graphic language and disturbing imagery as too dark, (however, this may not offend everyone but if you avoid this in your reading and viewing then you may want to pass); ironically, these are the same stories I tend to continue to ponder.  I would not recommend this for anyone under 17 except those emotionally mature for their age.  If his other collections are as graphic, then I may not read them.  I understand why he wrote certain stories in a gritty and brutal manner; I felt that the exacting detail given was unnecessary.  That said, I suspect I'm in the minority on this matter.

"To err is human; to forgive, divine." Alexander Pope in "Essay on Criticism".  This is the essence of the primary theme in Lori Nelson Spielman's book, "Sweet Forgiveness".  Spielman's writing is compelling with an intriguing storyline and fluid writing.  Her characters are drawn so that we are curious by to their lifestyle and we later see that even glamorous folks don't have an easy life and it isn't as glamorous as it would seem.I was uneasy about the resolution of the issue facing Hannah.  After I finished the book it took me several days ruminating over the plot and the reactions of the characters behaviors that seemed unrealistic to that which happens in real life.  How do I know this? I actually asked for forgiveness from people about 20 years ago and (continue to so quickly even today), for things not nearly as serious and most did not forgive.  I know others that have done similarly and my results aren't usual.  Of course, over time, some that are hurt do eventually forgive but this story's promise is "they all lived happily ever after".  A nice story for children and for a beach read, had the wounds in this story not been so injurious.Additionally, I was very frustrated and angry at how she handled the key issue facing Hannah, the protagonist.  She has been plagued by for many years.  I don't generally include spoiler's but I think the serious nature of the issue makes it warranted.  In a nutshell, while a young teenager, Hannah was awakened by an inappropriate touch.  The ensuing havoc devastates many lives.  When Hannah decides to confront the individual, just prior she concludes that maybe she misinterpreted what happened and she was wrong and at fault. HUH?  Yet, the statistics in the U.S. depending on the source says between 1 in 4 and 1 in 2, females are impacted by inappropriate sexual contact from touching all the way to rape before they reach 18 years old by someone they know!  The statistics for males are stated between 1 in 7 to 1 in 5.  This is an epidemic!  Talk to an addictions counselor and most of them will tell you nearly all of their clients experienced sex abuse as children.  Ms. Spielman has done a tremendous disservice to the anyone who has been harmed in such a manner.  It is quite common for those who were molested as children to dissociate or block these specific memories, to live in denial for years sometimes even decades because of this impact of betrayal, they emotionally can't handle the trauma and the lack of safety (and powerlessness) because they must remain living in the situation or lack protection/advocacy.  Nearly every sex abuser claims that their accuser is a liar.  Yes, a few will lie but that is the exception not the rule!  If you don't believe this, look at the most recent update on the Bill Cosby rape accusations, exceeding two dozen.I can recommend the writing and the concept of asking forgiveness is a worthy topic.  As a survivor, I Can Not recommend this story for its handling of a national tragedy that continues to be swept under the rug!  In fact, as I wrote this review I realize that I found this story offensive.If you happen to read Ladybug's review (which is great!), you will see that I left comments stating I intended to avoid this book.  Having read multiple stories since reading her comment, I had forgotten about her review and my intention.

These bars are great for the times you just can't grab a healthy bite to eat.  I find them very filling and unless I am extremely hungry, I tend to eat half or a 2/3 of the bar.  I am diabetic and I keep one handy in my purse as opposed from going through a drive through and eating unhealthy and nutrient deficient food with high carbs.I am not recommending this to others with health problems nor am I saying this is the healthiest you can find.I am saying this is tasty, filling and I don't feel guilty because I have either eaten a truly unhealthy snack or remain hungry which impacts my blood sugar.  Think Thin is my favorite Protein bar especially for the taste factor.I enjoy the Chocolate Fudge best but the Brownie Crunch is my second favorite.

I like these bags, they are made well enough that they would probably hold up if you were moving.  For everyday storage they work quite well.  My main concern is that they are bulky.  I have been using a well-known and advertised storage system that allows you to fit a lot of items in and then vacuum out the air that remains.  They are a much more compact means of storage overall and so I do still prefer this other brand.  However, with those, even the largest size won't hold a bulky comforter, while this most likely hold most (maybe not a California King).

Kimberly Belle, author of "The Last Breath" delivers a riveting story with dynamic characters and a twisting plot.  Her writing style is fluid and sprinkled at times with humor making it a delight to read.  This story captivated me as I kept turning pages instead of eating or sleeping.  This story is way more than a romance!  Belle's mystery writing is better than many I've read.The intriguing premise is who killed the beloved stepmother, Ella Mae?  Gia isn't satisfied with the answers she had been given and is determined that she will find the truth no matter what.  In the meantime, she tries to mend fences with her dying father after sixteen years of silence and he holds a grudge.  Can she reunite this broken family?  Will she find out the truth concerning Ella Mae's? This whodunit will keep you in its grasp until the very end.I could easily see this being made into a movie.  In a remote way the family dynamic, reminded me of "A Thousand Acres" although they are totally different stories lines and characters.  The sibling relationships as well as each individual fluctuated and evolved throughout the unraveling of the plot.  I highly recommend that you add this in your summer beach bag!Warning:A note to reader's - there are both sexually explicit and graphic rape scenes in the story; for those who find this frightening or prefer to avoid such scenes this isn't likely a story for you.  I considered these gratuitous in these details and had I known this prior to ordering, I would not have.  I consider this book Rated R, I think some readers would consider this porn.  For me this is a 3 or 4 star book, however, I know my tastes are more conservative than most.

Reading Eli Gottleib's "Best Boy: A Novel" was a rare treat.  I started it with the intent of only reading enough until my very tired, body and mind relaxed enough to fall asleep, 4 hours later I completed it.  His rich characterizations are intriguing and the plot flows in unexpected ways, resulting in a novel that demands to be finished post haste.We join Todd Aaron, a fifty year old man, who is highly functional man with autism.  Shortly, after a brief history of his childhood, we learn he was placed in a "home" for the developmentally disabled after he follows instructions literally, resulting in unintended injury.  Now living at Payton LivingCenter, he is skilled at completing menial tasks, demonstrates a strong vocabulary and has a grasp on variety of intellectual subjects via his research on the internet and reading the encyclopedia; however, he continues to fail to understand the nuances of language.  This leads to a great number of misunderstanding with quite serious consequences.  His greatest challenge is he doesn't know how to explain his lack of understanding and others around him fail to take note; they assume that because he is intelligent that understands their unspoken intentions.  His frustration yields greater anxiety and the facility doctor's response is to keep him heavily sedated creating even further mental inadequacy due to these drugs.Gottlieb's skilled in his ability to put you into Todd's shoes, sharing his confusion and fear.  Establishing greater empathy and compassion for his struggles.  Todd is very sensitive to the intentions of others, particularly when they are operating on behalf of their own agenda although he is clueless of true agenda.  Challenging us to realize that while not everyone relates to the world in the same manner but that doesn't mean that they don't have aptitudes, talents and are still worthy of love and respect.  Another compelling aspect woven into the storyline is the family dynamic, a loving mother, an anger father and a jealous brother, has had a tremendous impact on his perceptions of his present environment.  This in turn demands that the reader consider how we treat others that aren't like us.This story is highly recommended, though it could have been depressing, Gottlieb's delivery made it an unexpected delight that was both intriguing and hopeful!  This is certainly a story, you don't want to miss.

Based on the publisher's summary, I was excited to begin reading this story.  While the storyline itself was technically well executed, I found myself getting a bit bored by the middle of the story.
