Most of the characters were little more than one-dimensional with the exception of Mudas Summers, the protagonist.  I did enjoy the writing.  Ms. Richardson ability to use flashbacks and is adept at intertwining multiple plot lines is effective in fusing the story to a neat conclusion.I especially delighted in the opening sentence, "When a lie seeps into the very heartwood of a town, soaks the beams and the posts that hold it up from the earth, the rot sets to its work."  If the entire story had been so esthetically pleasing to read, it would have earned five stars from this reviewer.A primary part of the story is observing the transformation of Mudas from a teenager to an admirable, courageous adult in the span of a few weeks.  I wondered at the immense clarity with which she grasps the civil rights movement, that continues to grip the country in the summer of 1972 and seems to have had little impact in her small Southern town.  Her parents seem a bit disconnected with her daily life due to their own lifestyles and struggles, many are unknown to her (though these in fact propel the story).  For me, I felt her characterization to be a bit larger than life, however, I suspect other readers may view her differently.  For me only slightly detracted from this pleasurable read.If you enjoy coming of age stories mixed with suspense and mystery peppered into it, this is a worthy read.  The one sex scene was not graphic or overly descriptive.  It is recommended for those 12 and older.

I consider this one of the better selections from Film Movement.I found it very insightful.  Set in Czechoslovakia during the 1930's, the Czechs felt safe from German's aggression because a treaty with the Soviet Union and their own preparedness.  Famous and beautiful Hana stars in all the best movies but when the Germans march, her career disappears because she is Jewish.  Meanwhile, Emil, her husband vows to protect her from harm and compromises his ethics as a news reporter to do so.  Surprisingly, this turns out to be the best thing to happen in his career.  Frustrated at her loss of career and then at her husband's sudden rise in popularity with other women and the Germans, she feels betrayed.  Misunderstandings happen on both sides and their confusion fuels fires that no one can handle.Though one reviewer states these characters as stupid, hindsight is 20/20.  Yes, they make bad decisions, but they did so because they believed that hope was just around the corner.  When circumstances change one doesn't always make the best decisions or realize the immensity or consequences of their choice.  When there are many conflicting voices, who do you chose to believe?I liked the unique format of the movie.  It provides great insight into how people are selective in what they believe.

I watch many documentaries a year.  I viewed this approximately a year ago and its impact was so profound, I still think on it.  At the time of its filming, it focused on President, Mohamed Nasheed of the Maldives (which is composed of 100's of islands, many inhabited) efforts to reduce carbon emissions in large industrial nations because of its impact on climate which he believes is severely detrimental to his country.  These gorgeous islands are a popular tourist attraction among the rich and famous and particularly the Hollywood crowd.  Set in the Indian Ocean, they offer incredible beauty, friendly peoples and amazing resorts but unfortunately, some of the islands have already been abandoned by the people because their land has sunk and more islands are sinking quickly.Convinced that carbon emissions which causes global warming is the reason behind their disappearance, the former President went to the big carbon producing nations asking them to lower their emissions by changing how they operate the biggest offenders.  We watch as he is met with limited concern and lip service.  Eventually, he visits the United Nations and speaks to the entire body, and again meets with ambivalence and at times great indifference among his peers.One can only feel powerless, as he doggedly pursues his task to protect his beloved country, it will remind you of the Greek myth of Sisyphus.In the end, we are told a new President was elected and the viewer wonders why Mohamed Nasheed was not reelected.  I took a point off because this documentary stands on emotion but leaves some questions unanswered (I can't recall at this point).

Jennifer Steil has excellent writing skills as one would expect from a journalist.  She weaves many characters into the plot each with their own agenda's in the midst of a very volatile political environment.  It would seem that book is at least in some part based on the country of Yemen based on geography, political instability and her husband's prior posting as an Ambassador.  She manages to effectively use alternating person's narrate their perspectives and incorporates flashbacks to effectively development the storyline.  That said, there were drawbacks to the book as well.My biggest challenge was not relating or connecting to the primary characters.  Miranda is almost bigger than life in her mid-thirties, she would be considered by some a world traveler supporting herself teaching painting to others.  Her dance card of female lover's is nearly mind-boggling.  She is dynamic and the picture of selflessness.  Her political and social values and her dedication to them, particularly advocacy of women's rights is admirable.  She is a free spirit, who suddenly falls in love with a man, an ambassador no less under the most unlikely of circumstances.  She chooses to sacrifice much of what defines her to be a model of diplomacy as his wife.  This near 180, seemed implausible (yes, it could happen).  Her husband, Finn is also an exceptional accepting person, he is the epitome of the ideal ambassador.  Neither seemed to have any character flaws.  If you could call it a flaw, the Miranda is outspoken against injustice.  While I had trouble connecting to them because they were so perfect, I do believe a lot of reader's would enjoy these characters as they are.I also had some issues with the plot, however I will avoid ruining the story.  I found the reason for her kidnapping unrealistic.  I will agree with another reviewer that said she had some unanswered questions pertaining to technical matters involved in her kidnapping.  The author had several good options that she set up to explain the reason Miranda is kidnapped then reveals something unlikely.  Furthermore, Miranda's recovery is minimized.  As a severe trauma survivor and someone who knows quite a few others, I didn't find her recovery at all credible.  Again, many reader's might not be bothered or realize the lack of realism presented.This is Ms. Steil's first novel and as a debut it certainly has strong points, as mentioned earlier.  While there is a few intense violent scenes, they were minimally graphic.  Discussions of abuse suffered in this part of the world were realistic and disturbing but again the brutality wasn't over dramatized.  I would caution readers, who prefer to avoid reading books that are criticize or cynical of Christianity, some might find certain references quite offensive.  Likewise, there are a numerous mentions of female homosexuality acts; while not graphic they are an integral part of this storyline.In conclusion, Ms. Steil is a reasonably talented writer.  I enjoyed the insight she delivers on the life of diplomacy.  She demonstrates an ability to capture certain scenes and emotions quite effectively however, I didn't find this consistently throughout the story.  Her future works may overcome these gaps.

My two recently deceased, elderly Yorkies were quite picky, however this was one of three dog foods they would eat for most of their life (we didn't know about until 5 or 6 years ago).  My rescue dog that I have had for a month chose this over 7 different options given to him.  In the month that he has been here, he gained some weight initially (getting a little chubby, perhaps fear that he always get more?).  Feeling more at ease, he eats a consistent amount and has stabilized at the right weight for his size.  Though, he was abandoned, he found safety at a Humane Society (what a great group!).  They fed him Science Diet (he showed total disdain for it, when he realized we had better food).  In a month, the new growth of his fur is decidedly more soft.  When he first moved in, I wondered why it seemed so much courser than my other Yorkies.  I washed him once with no conditioner shortly after his arrival.  It wasn't until I contemplated his entire lifestyle that I realized it may be in part Fromm Gold!  He occasionally gets small bites of green pepper, carrots, apple and banana and daily Brewer's Yeast with Garlic and Vitamins (this too could be a contributing factor).One of the other great benefits is that the stool is firm (some Yorkies have sensitive tummies), thus I appreciate that Fromm provides readily digestible kibble due to quality ingredients.I wouldn't hesitate to recommend this to anyone seeking top of the line nutrition for Man's Best Friend!

Viet Thanh Nguyen has delivered an opus on the torn loyalties of sub-group within a generation of Vietnamese torn between two vastly worlds.  Having been exploited by other nations over several centuries and most recently, the French occupation of the past 100 years, many of Vietnamese people are weary of Western ways particularly the promises made, as well as, the lack of respect and appreciation for their culture.  Our narrator, a Captain in the Police Special Branch (similar to the CIA in U.S.) is an assistant to a General assigned to Saigon, however, his loyalty is to Communism.  In secret he aids those seeking to subvert those fighting the Communist take over (the U.S. military primarily).  It is through his eyes, the reader learns that no political system or philosophy is without its flaws and more importantly no system is completely equitable.  The value of human life becomes nearly meaningless then the agenda is in jeopardy.  As part of his cover, he is sent to the West to keep tabs on those planning to return to Vietnam in hopes of staging a coup and overthrowing the communist reign.  It is while he lives in the U.S. this second time (he had come temporarily as a college student several years prior to the conclusion of the war)  that he truly develops an affinity to the Western way of life and his Communistic loyalties are challenged and tested in the most heinous of ways.The book begins with the terror during the fall of Saigon in 1975, as we are riveted to our seats hoping that the despair and confusion don't take more lives, we experience a roller-coaster of emotion.  Initially, this portion is gripping and rated a 5 star for its account.  Thereafter, the key characters are followed as they seek to establish a new life in the U.S.  Few experience any opportunities beyond basic subsistence, their skills neither needed or desired in their new land.  The Captain is quite adaptable and begins to assimilate with minimal effort into American culture, while few of his compatriots are barely able function due to the trauma and ensuing depression they suffer.  It is at this stage of the novel where we get a very deep look into the Captain's psychological make-up, its inconsistencies: his development and poor treatment suffered at the hands of others for being a biracial and illegitimate; torn loyalties; motivations; and aspirations.  Just as we begin to think that the lure of the West has begun to take root, he returns to a very different Vietnam than he anticipated.  His ensuing experiences challenge his loyalty to extreme.One ponders throughout his account, who he would be had things been different for him as a child in that era?  Would he have been someone else completely?  In many ways this is a universal exploration of how early experiences mold us and our views not just politically but spiritually, philosophically and morally.  The use of the Vietnam conflict is an excellent platform from which to conduct such an analysis.I deducted one star because the last portion of the book became laborious to read.  It was both an anticlimax and to drawn out.  While I believe that the author did this to make his point more emphatic, the reader becomes somewhat frustrated for the delayed conclusion of the story.  The Captain's character was well developed and realistic.  He is neither all good or all evil.  However, I agree with some of the comments I've read, that the author seeks to impress readers with his: knowledge; command of language; and writing talent.  Yet, as a whole, it didn't interfere with my enjoyment of the plot.  If you are looking for a condensed history of end of the Vietnam War, this is a starting point.  I had wished there was more history incorporated but what was included was delivered adeptly.

For those of you who notice that they have a white coating on their tongue, bad breath or little white or red bumps that are sore on their tongue, these are often signs of an overgrowth of candida in the body.Candidais a type of yeast/fungus that exists in the body's blood stream.  Dictionary dot com, states "any of the yeastlike fungi constituting the genus Candida, members of which may cause athlete's foot, vaginitis, thrush, or other infections. Any of the yeastlike deuteromycete fungi of the genus Candida that are normally present on the skin and in the mucous membranes of the mouth, intestinal tract, and vagina. Certain species may become pathogenic, especially C. albicans, which causes thrush and other infections."  It is commonly termed Candida.Experts say that everyone has it, the concern is when it is beyond what is normal (check out one of the best books on the topic, "The Yeast Connection" by William Crook), which is when it becomes evident a host of different ways including the white stuff on the tongue, women frequently go to the gynecologist when it is severe in other places (and yes, men can have it too, they usually don't have symptoms).Probiotics in general will are a great means to address this because they encourage the growth of healthy bacteria that neutralizes the candida.  TheraBreathe is specifically designed to address candida that manifest in the mouth, which is serious issue since poor dental health can lead to other serious health problems.What causes the imbalance of candida?  Many things, some of the more serious factors are ingesting to much sugar, caffeine, processed foods with sugar or sugar substitutes like corn syrup, dextrose, rice syrup, maple syrup, oils that are reused such as those used for deep frying, potatoes,  products made with white (wheat flour), even to much fruit especially those with high sugar content such as grapes, watermelon, etc.  It is a given that if you eliminate or at least reduce the amount consumed of the above mentioned items, your Candida will be more quickly controlled.While I am a firm believer in probiotics, I have reservations about this TheraBreath product for several reasons.  First off, there is dextrose (a type of sugar).  It also includes sucralose (which is another name for Splenda), according to Prevention magazine, Dr. Mercola and other sources, Splenda is unsafe and can cause a host of health issues including:  Skin Rashes  Flushing  Episodes of Anxiety and Panic  Dizziness and Numbness  Diarrhea  Swelling  Muscle aches  Headaches  Cramping  Bladder issues  Stomach painGranted, you aren't consuming that much but why not just take a probiotic without sucralose and skip the side effects?Another drawback are other chemicals inside each lozenge include: Isomalt, Magnesium Stearate, Natural Flavors (which could be a host of really unappealing things, did you know that beaver anal secretions are often referred to as "Vanilla Flavor" or that red food products are made from beatle shells?  I typically avoid any product that has "natural flavors" as a catch all phrase, natural is a blanket marketing term used to 'conjure' a pristine farm with only organic substances being used, when it can mean the polar opposite.  Similar to the term "creamery" used to describe butter, real butter is made from cream, so it is redundant.  Another marketing tactic is using the term "Spring Water", the "spring" may not be flowing from a mountain stream but it meets minimal standards to be drunk, in fact, in Florida, it may actually be right from the tap!On the front of the package it states "8 Sugar Free, All Natural Citrus Flavored Lozenges", but as I've shown this is all quite vague, we really don't know what is in them.  Isomalt is used as a sugar substitute, derived from the sugar beet and has low calorie impact, however, it is partly absorbed by the body.  It can cause a side effect of stomach cramps (which I get) and a laxative.  According to Dr. Mercola, magnesium stearate is used in keeping machinery used in the manufacturing process from getting clogged.  It has been found at times to have toxic chemicals in it.  Furthermore, the June 12, 2012 article states that  " Magnesium stearate is not a source of magnesium and has no benefits, but may have a detrimental effect on your immune function as stearic acid has been linked to suppression of T cells. The filler also stimulates your gut to form a biofilm, which can prevent proper absorption of nutrients in your digestive tract".  The article further states other hazards including: "Another issue that has been raised in relation to magnesium stearate is the fact that the stearate is commonly sourced from hydrogenated oils such as cottonseed oil. This crop is oftentimes genetically engineered, but even when it's not, cottonseed oil tends to have very high levels of pesticide residues."  Thus, it may be counter productive to a healthy digestive system.  This is quite ironic since the use of probiotics enable the body to absorb healthy nutrients and improve digestive tract functionality (such as regulate or increase frequency of bowel movements preventing constipation while also preventing diarrhea), thus, it creates greater balance in elimination.In summary, while this product reduces candida in the mouth which is a good thing, unfortunately, there are many questionable ingredients that may create other health issues.  This alone is reason enough to seek another Probotic source, which doesn't incorporate sweetners or other unnecessary extras.  There are many excellent choices out there that offer a wide variety of different strains of probiotics (which can conquer candida quicker) and much more economically.  I think the price of $12.99 for 8 Lozenges, the current price on Amazon as of this writing on May 11, 2015 is absurd for the quantity of product.  Any decent probiotic will improve your oral health.Frankly, if I am feeling poorly, I increase my intake of probiotics because Candida often flourishes when the immune system is working against bacterial, fungal or viral infections.  I always double my regular dose when taking an antibotic as well.  Medication I use is sometimes constipating, so if that is an issue, I take more probiotics.  Try different options and see what your body responds to best.  I won't buy anything with less than a billion colonies per capsule.I am not a medical doctor, this is not to be considered as medical advice.  The information provided is research that I have located and applied to my own body.  Each person is unique and may have different results than I have experienced.  Consult a health advisor before you attempt to treat any medical condition!

He was interested and intrigued but he can't get it in his mouth.  My Yorkie is an inquisitive guy, who loves to have fun.  Unfortunately, though he is considered large for a Yorkie, (he is nearly 10 pounds), the "Small/Petite" Ultra Squeaker isn't small enough even though it is labeled "For Small Dogs Only".  It is 2" in diameter or 5.1 cm. just a tad to big for him to grip in his large mouth.CHUCKIT CHUCKIT lives up to its claim of a high bounce.  While it does squeak, it requires more pressure than many squeak toys, this level of force may be beyond some arthritic or elderly persons ability to produce.  Furthermore, when force is applied the air hole must be completely open or it won't make noise.I think this would be more appropriate for dogs weighing between 12-25 pounds with wide mouths would be able to get it to squeak.  It appears to be durable and not easily chewed to a destructive state within a few hours like some toys out there.  I would expect some dogs would highly enjoy this ball to pass away the hours.

Jennifer Allee delivers another thought provoking story with a unique plot.  Ms. Allee writes memorable, sympathetic characters, who face very believable life challenges.  Most reader's will deeply connect with their pain, reactions and perspectives.  She doesn't hold back but the journey is worth it!We meet Allie in her mid-twenties as she interacts with her beloved aunt and learn they are share a passion for trivia.  Soon Allie is traveling on the road to compete in a trivia contest with a large cash prize hoping the money will help someone in need.  Unfortunately, she never arrives at her destination, instead she ends up at Vinnie's Diner.  Vinnie is a rather unique story character, who encourages her to explore her emotions, as her past life is presented for review, when this assignment is finished, she must make the choice between life and death.  As the book description states along this journey, she literally faces her demons which is presented in vivid detail.Jennifer Allee has an extraordinary talent to address painful memories with Biblical truths.  "Vinnie's Diner" is thus written that most readers will find themselves identifying with at least some of the painful life experiences faced by Allie and others.  As scripture gives context to the pain, it is always gentle and respectful never preachy.  I believe many people will experience some level of healing as they consider God's view of the life's pain.  The book is solid in its doctrine as well.  I thoroughly enjoyed Ms. Allee's "Last Family Standing", however, I consider this to be a classic in Christian fiction!I highly recommend "Vinnie's Diner"!  In fact, it is not to be missed!  I am grateful, I got an opportunity to review it.

Looking for a great accent piece for your classic outfit?  This is it!  I love the design because while the marks at each hour and the outer edge have lots of bling, it isn't gaudy.  Meanwhile, the soft leather band and the hour and second hand match each other and compliment the rest of the watch exquisitely.For years, I observed that the "Classic look Never Goes Out of Style", while most fashions last a few months or maybe a year.  This is going to be a favorite keepsake whether you buy it for yourself or for someone special.  This is a classy statement piece that whispers to all who see it, "I have good taste."This is definitely a watch that you won't want to re-gift or leave in the corner of your jewelry box.

Paula McLain has written another smash hit!  "Circling the Sun" is an exquisite foray into historical fiction, engrossing the reader from the first sentence.  Between the covers is the life story of Beryl Markham, a woman of remarkable and numerous accomplishments in the early 20th Century, which include being a female landowner (rare) and horse trainer of champion racers in Kenya (also unique), and author.  She later becomes the first woman to fly cross the Atlantic from east to west, (Great Britain to N. America).  This is certain to be a book that makes the New York Times Bestseller List for 2015 and undoubtedly, a feature movie in the future.Initially, the story starts at Beryl's abandonment by her mother and elder brother to return their native England, leaving Beryl in the hands of her father, who starting with little manages to gain notoriety within white society of Kenya.  Beryl learns from a tender age, the theory and practical aspects of breeding and training racehorses and goes on to become famous in her own right.  The story of how she starts with little to achieve great respect and admiration is a very involved tale.  Soon she becomes friends with Karen Blixsen, a coffee plantation owner nearby and eventually Karen's lover, Denys Finch Hatton.  Their complicated triangle of friendship and love has far reaching implications, particularly for Beryl.  I promise I have not spoiled the story, that is why it is essential that you read it!McLain provides a thoroughly insightful look into the colony life and its struggles and secrets which are many.  She writes a smooth story in linear fashion that is strong and powerfully gripping.  If you like horses, this will be a close second to "Secretariat" as a  favorite.  Even if horses aren't particularly your bag, this story has such intriguing characters that your fascination with their behaviors will rush you to the finish line.  All though their are many characters within the story, the primary characters are all richly developed; additionally, McLain manages to make them so dynamic that you won't become confused.This book is a keeper, not only do I recommend that you read it, it is something you will want to buy so that you will have it to read again!

It might be YOU!I chose to read "Conversations with Saint Bernard" because I love dogs and just lost a very special dog very recently.  I was concerned that it might make me sad or I would find it to foolish.  It did neither, instead, I found it very accessible and uplifting.  Author, Jim Kraus writes a very engaging story of a lonely, elderly man needing deep emotional healing and restoration.  Through God's mysterious ways, he develops a different perspective on his life and his value to God as he interacts with Lewis, a Saint Bernard.Kraus writes a solid story with well developed characters and an interesting plot.  I was impressed with his ability to create suspense in a number of ways within this novel making it quite dynamic and fast paced.  I thoroughly enjoyed the characterization of the dog; Lewis' ability to draw others to him and address their hidden pain from the past is both intriguing and inspiring.  I enjoyed these interactions as a metaphor to the healing power of the Holy Spirit.  Likewise, we see people sharing their victories and failures with others as a demonstration of sharing one another's burdens as stated in Galatians 6:1,2 "Brethren, if a man be overtaken in a fault, ye which are spiritual, restore such an one in the spirit of meekness; considering thyself, lest thou also be tempted. Bear ye one another's burdens, and so fulfil the law of Christ." KJV  This is the essence of the novel.This book is a keeper.  I will reread this. I have already promised to share it with another, who needs encouragement. I heartily endorse it for younger people as well, if they are emotionally ready to deal with mature themes.

Martin Clark delivers a thorough legal thriller that doesn't get overly focused on the details of a typical lawsuit (I recently got scammed by an auto insurance co. after 5 year battle, which included severe, permanent injuries sustained in an auto accident).  This story is a realistic presentation of the people involved displaying flexible morality to score a win.  I have been stunned by the commonness that exists among lawyers and corporate big wigs, it would seem no one is above lying, falsifying evidence or manipulating facts.  Clark has obviously seen this consistent character trait in his courtroom.  The story flows somewhat rapidly and there is a lot of activity as we observe the situation through Lisa Stone's eyes, wife and partner with Joe Stone, at Stone and Stone, a small town law firm that gets caught in the middle of a firestorm over a patent issue.The story works because everyone lies.  Joe Stone is an easy going guy, well liked, considered as the ethical cornerstone of law in his region.  He displays immense patience with town lunatic, Lettie VanSandt, who files frivolous lawsuits like some people go grocery shopping.  When Lettie hits the big time, it is to late for her to receive her payday because she has died during a house fire.  This is when things go topsy-turvy for the Stones and their practice.  Add to this serious indiscretion by Lisa, her action may inadvertently cause their case to be lost, and in turn cause their whole world to be destroyed.  Additionally, when push comes to shove even Joe uses semantics to fudge the truth when talking to the big corporation.At one point, I wanted to give this a five for originality and the realism incorporated into the story.  However, Lisa's character is not the most likeable person.  She runs the gamut of emotions about her bad choice and at times is almost flippant about it's impact.  Her actions include getting her best friend to commit perjury on her behalf is extreme.  However, it is a side of human nature that many people in American society would probably chose.  What bothered me is that she has no consequences after the fact.  Similarly, Joe rationalizes his decision to fib because he rarely charged Lettie in her legal cases (most attorney's would rather have dental work than assist for free).  Additionally, everything got wrapped up in a tidy bow at the end, thus making a fairly realistic story end on an improbable note.This would make a good vacation read.  The story takes you by the hand and leads you through tedious lifestyles in a small town to encounters with a huge drug corporation, its bigger than life CEO (think Branson or Madoff) and its panoply of players with increasing intensity as the story unfolds.

Rahimeh Andalibian is a successful woman.  A practicing doctor of psychology and investor/businesswoman, who shares with readers the silent suffering that her family of origin had shrouded their most painful experiences.  When tragedy hits their family only days after the Iran Revolution began with the fall of the Shah in 1979,  major depression sweeps several family members as together they face tremendous terror, which grips each one.  Several go into denial of the facts thinking is best for the youngsters, but this choice is so blinding that impact leads each family member to disconnect from one another to seek a workable path as they struggle for survival.  The strong bonds of love is so damaged that it will be many years and many wrong choices before they slowly reconnect and rebuild; much credit goes to Rahimeh's deep devotion to them serving as the impetus to guide them to a path of true healing and recovery.It took several days of contemplation for me just to summarize only the highlights without exposing the details best told by author.  Although there are a few places in the story where the reader wonders if an event isn't out of sequential order; however, this is a minor defect that does not impact the deeper truths the author conveys.  Rahimeh does an excellent job creating vivid scenes, so that you too can smell the flowers as she walks past the garden and appreciate the grandeur of the Rose Hotel that her father built from the ground up as a very young man with only a dream and no funds of his own, to a elegant hotel visited by tourists to Mecca the world over.  They were admired in their community and quite wealthy.Ironically, her father tries to do a good deed from which springs a misunderstanding that gets lost among the revolution's chaos.  Ultimately, this misunderstanding spins out of control, the result being the family experiences several dire consequences leaving them emotionally wounded, penniless and fleeing their homeland.  They end up living in to a one room apartment in Great Britain and eventually relocate to Southern California to rebuild their lives and finances.  As the children attempt to assimilate into a culture wildly different than their homeland, things turn sour once again.  As Rahimeh struggles to find her own identity and heal her own pain, she realizes this will only happen if each individual family members address their pain and accepts the life paths that others have taken.Rahimeh has done an exceptional job introducing each family member honestly with their strengths and weaknesses (respectfully).  Her courage is admirable, yet she never boasts of her role in the healing that evolves.  The love this family exhibits is tangible.  The story has so many tragedies, it could be a Greek play.  There are frequent mentions of the beliefs and practices of Islam, which are integral to understanding the reasons out of which many of the situations arose.  It is shared in such a way that no one regardless of their faith or spiritual practices would find it as a tool for conversion or insulting to another faith.I recommend this story as an example of the resilience and strength this family found through their persecutions and losses.  There is not a wasted word.  As I read, my interest never flagged.

We have been a Greenies family for quite a few years.  It has been enjoyed by my Two Yorkies as a reward and me for improved dental hygiene and breath.  Since my receipt of this box, we have lost a beloved friend, Liza and added a new friend, a rescue pup, who is in large part Schnauzer.Both dogs enjoy this new version a great deal, they run to separate places to savor this special treat.My one concern is that despite it is grain free it has a modest level of protein (not recommended for dogs that have renal/kidney disease) at 23%.  For older dogs, kidney disease is a silent killer until it reaches advance stages, so please perform blood tests your dog and cats regularly when they become older.Since, I see no ingredient picture posted presently by the company nor reviewers, I will include the ingredients in order as they are listed.  They are: Dried chickpeas, gelatin (source unnamed), glycerin, powdered cellulose, dried potato, water, lecithin, potato protein, natural poultry flavor, minerals (dicalcium chelate, zinc amino acid, iron amino acid chelate, copper amino acid chelate, manganese chelate, potassium iodide ), choline chloride, dried apple pomace, fruit juice color, vitamins (di-alpha tocopherol acetate -source of vitamin E), vitamin B12 supplement, d-calcium pantothentate (vitamin B5), niacin supplement, vitamin A supplement, riboflavin supplement (vitamin B2), vitamin D3 supplement, biotin, pyridoxine hydrochoride (vitamB6, thiamin mononitrate (B1), folic acid, turmeric color.I am not a nutritionist but I have read labels for years and it appears to me these are fairly healthy ingredients (although I don't know what "natural poultry flavor" could possibly be and I wonder why they were intentionally non-specific).  Likewise, I have a big question over the source of gelatin which typically comes from bones of cows, with so many drugs and hormones injected into most of the beef in the U.S. (do you know our beef is banned throughout Europe because of the risk factors?) and a statistically significant number of cows are not even meeting the human health standards here in the U.S. are instead being used for cat and dog food, this does raise a red flag for me.  This is the primary reason I feed my dogs only organic dog foods and I only eat hormone free, grass fed beef.Now that I have reviewed these ingredients carefully,i will be more cautious and may stop feeding my pets these treats (although they enjoy them) because the packagings vague disclosure of ingredients, particularly since the gelatin is the second ingredient.

There are many adjectives words to describe "The Underwriting", a few must include: dynamic, suspenseful, engaging, driven and conniving.  Author, Michelle Miller has unveiled another aspect of the financial world, the creation and release of an IPO.  It is impressively told as compared to  the movie "Wall Street" portrayed insider trading.  The writing was so taut and realistic in it's presentation, that it is hard to believe this young artist has written such impeccable story worthy of national and international attention.The characters are plenty flawed, most are driven by either money or power and usually both.  Miraculously, the primary characters are so well written that one can't help at least slightly identifying or feeling a tad sorry for them, because each are blinded by their own ambition, the fear of failure and the lure of success.  As new critical characters enter the mix, they derail even the best laid plans.  Each character is necessary and has an intricately important role to play moving the plot further into chaos.  The gamesmanship is incredibly intriguing and leaves one wondering what could possibly go wrong next?  The ending was satisfying with a few characters seeing life with a different perspective.I highly recommend this book, it is probably one of the best suspense novels, I have read this past year maybe longer.  Yes, I am that impressed.  You will need to set time aside it is so engrossing, be prepared to loose track of time. I read it in 9 hours forgetting to eat, I was so captivated by this complex drama.  That this is a debut novel by the author is almost shocking because the story exceeds the quality of drama, complexity and characterizations published by many popular authors today.  Narrated by multiple persons, there was no confusion for the reader nor interruption to the flow of the story. There are no flaws, in fact, Miller does an exceptional job explaining the key aspects of an IPO in easy to understand terms, so don't let the topic frighten you away from enjoying this engrossing novel, that I believe will be a motion picture.  DO NOT MISS THIS BOOK!!

Colleen Oakley’s “Before I Go” captured my immediate interest and it never flagged as I rapidly read the pages to discover how Daisy’s deals with her impending death and her desire to protect her husband in the present and future.  Her reactions and plans are fraught with unexpected difficulties resulting in multiple miscommunications and misunderstandings.  The plot is well structured and delivers increasing anticipation for the reader.I liked the main characters, Daisy has nearly her completed her Masters in Psychology, who has “Lots of Cancer” and is always 5 steps ahead in her perception of everyone’s emotional state.  Quite simply she has control issues from which she is totally blind.  Jack is Daisy’s absent-minded husband, who adores her far beyond than anyone realizes.  Kayleigh (who is also 27, like Daisy) is her best friend since Elementary school, her life is directionless and her main entertainment is having flings with younger men, some who are recent high school graduates.  Her strengths are her loyalty, honesty and directness.  Although her role is small, it is important.  Each character is someone that is relatable; a person, you would want in your circle.  For some reason, I thought of Debra Winger's character in "Terms of Endearment" when reading certain passages.Though the topic is sad and the reader follows Daisy goes through the various stages of grieving; there is a sprinkling of humor at just the right times throughout the story to lower the tension and makes the reader connect to her even more.  One example is that she deals with her distress medical encounter by stating ‘If there was a Zagat’s guide for doctors, he would have no stars’.  Oakley’s has a gift in using humor to convey a perception of reality.My one issue is that there were frequent mentions of the sexual act (between Daisy and Jack, though they were not particularly graphic) which made this story more believable because our health does impact all facets of life.  However, I do object to Kayleigh’s behaviors because they are more descriptive and detailed which are borderline pornographic, though I suspect it won’t offend most people (most television is much more flagrant).I would recommend this story to anyone who likes realistic fiction.  My former Pastor’s wife set him up with his second wife, when she was dying.  Additionally, I lost three young friends (30 -52) in the mid 2000’s to cancer and I knew that each one was very concerned about how her husband would cope in the future without her.  This is a quick read that will be remembered long after you finish.

Laura Dave delivers an intriguing look at all facets of love.  Georgia Ford, the protagonist seeks refuge and direction from her family 5 days before her wedding day when fate reveals a colossal secret her fiancé has failed to share with her.  Upon her arrival home, she finds her world turned upside down with her parents and a brother’s marriage struggling through their own collision courses.  This further causes her to question marriage, love and trust.  In her angst, she tries to break the sale of the family vineyard believing that will solve some of the problems but things don’t always end up the way we expect.As each day passes, she learns more about love beyond the goose bumps stage.  As Dave guides through us through family turmoil, we survey constitutes real commitment to vows, honoring one another, real maturity, what is acceptable and when to forgive and when to let go.I seldom read Chick Lit but “Eight Hundred Grapes” provided some really powerful messages and offered insights that enhanced my appreciation for this genre.  As a bonus, the author spins a tale that is vivid and a plot with twists.  It ends with a possibility for a sequel, though it is a stand alone tale.Though it was a bit of a fairy tale, I was engaged with the characters frailties.  Regardless of the fact that these people were successful profession people with a very comfortable income and reputation, the reality is money doesn’t buy happiness.  One of the most valuable treasures in life is devotion to your partner by loving them enough to see the real individual and understanding their motivations.  This is a life truism.  So buy this and get uncorked!

It is bright and charming necklace.  Arrayed in Amethyst, Blue Topaz, Peridot, Garnet and the Yellow Stone might either be Yellow Topaz, Yellow Spinel, or Citrine.  The two ribbon strips along the center Amethyst are tiny little diamonds, they can only be observed within a 6 inch or closer look.  The stones are pretty and would brighten outfits that may have a matching shade to one of the colored stones.As you view the picture, it is exactly as presented.  That said, the chain is very light weight and links are extremely small.  The Lobster Claw clasp is very small and nearly impossible to hold open with modest length nails, when I finally got it to open (8th or 9th time), I could not get the amazingly small loop close to the clasp.  In fact, I never managed to get it to hook onto the clasp!  Even before attempting to put on the necklace, I thought I will have to wear pendant on a more larger more suitable chain, it doesn't look balanced compared to the chain in length or link.The bale on the pendant isn't very large, smaller than the center Amethyst.  You may need to take pendant along on a shopping trip to find an appropriate chain, however, I don't know a lot of stores that sell gold plated silver chains (perhaps online).  Gold is a better color choice for the chain, so find if you keep this chain someone to open and remove your necklace when you where it or wear it daily.I'm disappointed that the chain isn't more substantial, this is the second pendant/chain set I've gotten from the "Amazon Collection" and the other pendant was similar in size and the chain is the exact size, so the same disparities with the chain was an issue.  All in all, I like the pendant and will wear it possibly on a silver chain since I was robbed over all my gold chains and most of my silver.

BIC Flex 5 Disposable delivers a smooth shave with no nicks, stubble or stray uncut hair.  As a woman, I think some of us have hairy regions that are probably as challenging as many men's beards.  I really like this razor and I had previously been using a BIC Flex 3 which I reviewed quite some time ago.  I find if you keep the hair from getting stuck between the blades, the razors will last for months.Here is how I do that.  I run the wet razor in reverse on wet hand, at least half of the clogs are cleared.  Then, once dry I tap each of the sides of the razor against the sink basin multiple times removing more than half the remainder of hair, then I take tweezers and run it along the blades and crevices furthest from the handle then repeatedly tap again on the basin.  At this point, it is almost completely clean.I will be buying these again.  I recommend them to at least try them and observe how they compare to your present razor.

Christie Watson has delivered an emotional powerhouse about love, acceptance and misunderstanding in her story, "Where Women are Kings."  Watson effectively and efficiently tells a story about bonds of love that can't be broken despite the pain that intrusive behavior renders.  Though his birth mother, Deborah abused Elijah, it was not with the intent to harm him but to free him from the bondage of a wizard, she believes possesses him.  We soon realize that between her schizophrenia and the influence of greedy preacher that she saw no other choice but to try and remove the wizard herself through horrific means.  Elijah is prisoner to this belief as well and the fear of the wizard ultimately leads to traumatic results for him and others.This taut, fast paced story was so compelling that I completed it within 24 hours.  When the first bombshell is dropped, my shock was so great that I gasped aloud, "NO!"  and when the second bombshell occurred I was shocked, stunned and tearful.  Reading this tale is akin to listening to a dear friend sharing their own painful experience.  One can only feel this intensity when the presentation of each character is so well developed.  Leaving you to quickly empathize with each person's feelings and frustrations.  Particularly, when each one has compelling compassion for the downtrodden (Obi is a lawyer for immigrants soon to be deported and Nikki works at a dog rescue), their great love for each other and Elijah face numerous tests.  Unfortunately like all humans, they doesn't always express their love or at times, when they do, it isn't perceived as such by the other party in the manner intended.  This is so frustratingly painful because we feel the pain of the characters as they sometimes fail to connect.I didn't view this book as a treatise on race, it was far more a story of the varying beliefs of different cultures (Nigerian vs. British), mental illness, and adoption.  It provided a realistic look at the challenge of adopting an older child (Elijah is 7), that has an unknown history that hasn't been relayed to the adoptive parents.  It is also an insightful view of the challenge of loving someone, who has conflicted loyalties and misconceptions about the nature of his abuse (which is quite common among abused children).Watson's  haunting story that will be remembered long after you close the book.  I hope you choose to read this outstanding story.  It was a realistic account of adoption challenges and the roller-coaster ride of parenting.

Author Alan Cheuse proves that he is capable writing about tough subjects.  He incorporates a number of themes: Loss of Innocence; The Impact of Betrayal; The Allure of Money; and Money Can't Buy Happiness are intricately interwoven among the four members of the Bloch family, headed by a former Rabbi, Manny Bloch who becomes the uber businessman with great successes.  Cheuse also exerts mastery of symbolism as it relates to death and the circle of life.  This story is not only a story of the lack of fulfillment even those who are successful find but is a look into the minds of several people impacted by harsh experiences.The rabbi's tragic childhood and his rise to success and ultimately his fall are all narrated by his mother, Minnie Bloch as she relays his story to various friends and to his mistress and ultimately his daughter, who played a role in unmasking him to the world.  Her narration is clear and believable as a Jewish Grandmother.  Cheuse writing is strong through Minnie, whose observations are exacting and at times melodic though very serious as this she comments to Manny's mistress, a holocaust survivor "...not like the killer in Europe, those who gave you your numbers, they were like lovers and mothers to a dream of murder, nursing it at all cost..."  Her voice is strong and at times generous towards her only son, at one point stating that his deceased father, whom he hears speaking through birds at pivotal life points, encouraged him to make some of his life altering choices.Unfortunately, Minnie is very verbose and so overly descriptive that the reader wonders how long it will take to hear her story.  We also wonder why she doesn't share the details with only one person but that it takes years for her to tell based on the various settings and the decline of her health.  The mysteries unraveled very slowly and I at times became frustrated.  This book was originally published under a different name, "The Grandmothers' Club: A Novel" back in 1995, which apparently didn't win a lot of readers.  Likewise, I suspect that one reader/reviewer prior to today’s date either failed to completely read this book or heavily skimmed as the review is full of erroneous statements.  Midway, I was tempted stop but I felt obligated to finish out of respect to the author and readers alike.  This book needed to be on a diet, it could have lost 100 pages and still kept the authenticity and key points viable to a comprehensive story.I gave three stars because although the author is talented and incorporated multiple themes and symbols into the story, it was tiresome.  It appears from the foreword that Cheuse aspires to the literary success of people such as Chekhov, Joyce, Hemingway, Woolf, Malamud and Gabriel Garcia Marquez.  It is always wonderful to admire the most talented; however, I, myself do not see this story as accomplishing this goal.I would recommend this to those who like the use of symbolism and immigrant tales.  I wished I had enjoyed it more.Although billing is given to Tova Mirvis, she did not participate in the authorship of manuscript but only in the foreword.  This use of her name gives the book added allure which is in my opinion is a dishonest means to sell more books.

This product is a hit in my book as well as my very picky Yorkie.  I originally awarded 4 stars because of what I thought were great ingredients.I called the Boutique where I buy my dog food and asked why the owner didn't stock it.  She stated that Avocados are terrible for dogs and it may actually kill them if they eat to much!!  I said, "Are you serious?"  She told me to look it up, so I went to the ASPCA, and this is what I found "Avocado leaves, fruit, seeds and bark may contain a toxic principle known as persin. The Guatemalan variety, a common one found in stores, appears to be the most problematic. "  Since she only carries healthy and organic dog foods (which is one reason, I believe my Yorkies lived way past the typical life span).  My 14.5 y.o. is in kidney failure (FYI, never give a pet DRY Dog Food it further stains the kidneys, don't listen to the vet if they suggest it, especially if they sell it!).  Thus, I tossed the Avoderm bag out!While I won't list all the ingredients, I will say it is packed with some healthy stuff including key vitamins, minerals, amino acids and outstanding herbal extracts that improve digestion, absorption, skin, eyes, muscle and overall vitality.  Here is a list of the first 12 ingredients in the order shown on the Lamb bag: Lamb, Lamb Meal, Garbanzo Beans, Pea Flour, Tapioca, Chicken Fat (Preserved with Mixed Tocopherols), Avocado, Natural Flavor (since it isn't named, I am wondering what they are hiding), Alfalfa Meal, Flax Seed (Source of Omega 3), Dried Beet Pulp and Dried Chicory Root.  Other noteworthy ingredients incorporated into the blend: Kelp Meal, Avocado Oil, Yucca Schidigera Extract, Rosemary Extract, Sage Extract, Pineapple Stem and Papain.This confuses me, apparently they have some good ingredients but then they stick in avocados which are tasty but to be avoided!  Likewise,  I have reservations about the source of chicken fat especially since many chickens aren't given a healthy diet.  Also of concern is that Flax Oil can go rancid and I don't know if there is a way to prevent this from occurring.  Since not all ingredients are stated we have no idea if there is anything that is a stabilizer/preservative (or if that is a good idea in itself).I will state that typically, I avoid the purchase of products which list "Natural Flavors" because it is industry lingo intended to avoid disclosure.  This is mainly done to avoid consumer rejection.  For example, many people don't know that "Natural Vanilla Flavor" is actually Beaver anal secretions, which much less expensive than the use of real vanilla bean extract; unfortunately, none of the U.S. food agency's forbid this substitution and it has been going on for years.  Similar terminology or creative renaming is used to cover up the use of MSG in food and vitamins (for which it is often used in formulation process).  Until consumers demand better disclosure for the foods which they or their pets consume, this avoidance of full disclosure will not cease (if interested, see Dr. Mercola's website, it lists the data on MSG), Amazon will not allow the posting of the link.  These are not isolated cases.  Without having more information on the label, we can't really be sure what little precious is eating or what we are consuming.  We only know that the company is not fully disclosing all their ingredients, thus, I have lowered my rating by one star because I believe purchasers have the right to know what they are buying.In addition, my baby enjoyed the Turkey less than the Lamb.  So, I won't be buying that either.I can't recommend this because I don't want to ever even possibly endanger my dog.  I wouldn't have even gotten this had I a clue that it is on the avoid list.

The Marauders: A Novel is an intriguing story woven with a rich blend of interesting characters, multiple plots rife with drama, with a dollop of humor.  Tom Cooper's gift for descriptive prose is artful and his talent far exceeds what many respected writers aspire to produce.  I thoroughly enjoyed the rich scenery, regular injections of humor and particularly embraced the idiosyncratic characters as they doggedly fight to survive life in abject shrimping village after the BP Oil Spill.Our story introduces us into the lives of multiple characters but primarily, we follow: the Toup brothers, twin brothers who run a successful business, growing a unique variety of marijuana on a remote island within swamp land in the Gulf; Lindquist, a man who lusts for lost Pirate booty that may or may not be located on Toup land; Hanson and Cosgrove, two ne'er-do-well, stoners looking to make a quick buck; and Wes Trench, a young man, who loves his lifestyle and community but finds everything about the region constantly reminding him of his recently deceased Momma, who died in a hurricane.  Mix these character's together add a slick BP oil Executive in the pot and you have a rollicking ride of chaos, mayhem and gun battles and occasionally death but not all in the same chapter, at least not usually.If you are looking for a fast moving storyline, lyrically written with randomly humorous antidotes thrown at you, this book will satisfy.  While some reviewers compare Tom Cooper to Carl Hiaasen, I may actually prefer Cooper's style.  Though I know some reader's might find that statement inflammatory, I think Cooper demonstrates superior skill in his character development, and he delivers to the reader a deep understanding of each character's identity and a reason to rally's around those with whom they feel kinship.  This is not to disparage Carl Hiaasen's talent or gift for humorous writing.This book has earned a place on my permanent collection shelf and may be reread in the future, when a dose of fun is needed.  I hope that Hollywood makes this into a movie, I would buy a ticket!  Matthew McConaughey could play Lindquist.

Jonathan Holiff is the son of Saul Holiff, who managed Johnny Cash for almost 20 years bringing Johnny from near obscurity to fame and fortune that had alluded him prior to his management by Holiff.  Relying on film clips, photographs and reel to reel audio tapes of Saul's verbal diary, we are introduced to the thinking of Saul Holiff.  Jonathan tries to unveil and dissect the man that he knew as father in name only.  His father like Johnny Cash was a hard drinker and daily used pills as well.  Holiff's day in day out dealings with a drug and alcohol addled superstar left him totally drained and removed from his role as husband and father.  In the end, his desire for control was so powerful that he chose when to die, without even leaving a note.  Thus his widow, who plays an almost non-existent role in this documentary, Joshua, his brother, (not included in the video) and Jonathan must some how move past this tragedy.We are not informed why Joshua nor their mother do not participate in the film, perhaps, they own sorrow prevented them from doing so.  Jonathan presents to us primarily through the audio recordings made by his father, the summary of his father's life as it relates to Johnny and June Carter Cash (not much real detail, certainly not an expose of them that you haven't already been privy too through other sources); his frustrations when dealing with vendors who are angered by Johnny's last minute cancellations to music executives; and his anger due to his inability to properly parent.  Jonathan had a great deal of conflict with his father and was frequently told he was a disappointment but had no real understanding that this is typical in growing up in a home where substance abuse overshadows every aspect of life.As a study, of a substance abusing household this is as accurate as any example, those who are adult children of alcohols (or addicts) will tell you.  As many children in this environment tend to do, Jonathan left home as early as possible running from his home in Canada to Hollywood to become a manager of stars just like his dad.I liked that Jonathan doesn't play the victim in this movie.  Those survivor's of such homes must choose to walk in forgiveness and love or live their life tormented by the bitterness by all they missed because they didn't have a "normal" childhood.  Jonathan has obviously chosen to forgive as his understanding of his father increased.  It is an uncompromising look at the isolating pain, he experienced as he suffered ongoing rejection but never knew how to be acceptable.  This would puzzle any child.  However, that said, I felt he missed an opportunity to explore for the viewer how he overcame his pain of rejection or if he still struggles.  Further, I am so curious why the other family members only got a passing comment but never share the screen with him.I thought this documentary was going to be more focused on Johnny Cash instead of using his name to entice you to watch a true story about a son whose father just happens to work for Johnny Cash but is absent physically and emotionally from his childhood.  I thought it was a story about his father and Johnny's Cash's partnership "secrets to fame" or something more to do with their work relationship than the mere fact that Johnny's addictions were part of the reason for Saul's absences.  I felt this usage of Johnny Cash is plain misleading and intentional and thus I deducted a star for that.Furthermore, we only have a limited view of Jonathan's isolation, no one else is included in an interview format be it a relative, a girlfriend, neighbors, sibling or mother contribute their observations.  I am sure his mother had a great deal of her own pain having to parent two boys almost like a single mom at the hands of a verbally abusive husband (this is an assumption based on his treatment of Jonathan, little is mentioned about the parent's marital dynamics).  I do respect that this may have seemed to personal or invasive by his mother, it just wasn't touched on or it's lack of inclusion explained.It was a fair job as a documentary, its limited point of view kept it from being exceptional.  Other title options might have been more accurate, "A Look at Johnny Cash's manager, my Dad, Saul Holiff" or "A Look at Parental Substance Abuse impact on a Childhood".

I’ve been using a Bissell ProHeat Turbo Upright Deep Cleaner from over 20 years.  I don’t recall what motivated that first purchase but it lasted nearly 10 years and was great at keeping my whole house clean.*  Then, when I bought my house 20 years ago, I still needed a carpet cleaner for my Master Bedroom since it was Headquarters for my various menageries of cats and dogs particularly for sleeping and of course shedding.  However, I have enjoyed my Oreck Canister Vacuum for over 10 years (it is duct taped for continued functionality but it is a work horse).  So, I believe I can offer an unbiased comparison of Oreck Revitalize Carpet Cleaner and Bissell 8910W ProHeat Turbo Upright Deep Cleaner.Both are easy to assemble.  Oreck Cleaner is substantially lighter in weight and smaller in size than that of Bissell 8910W ProHeat Cleaner.  When the Oreck is in use it is a bit easier to maneuver however, both carpet cleaners require some strength in the upper arm and shoulder areas and I found this painful at times even with the Oreck due to some physical issues I suffer in this body region.  Both operate in similar manner, so I will focus only on the differences.One of the biggest drawbacks I found with the Oreck Cleaner is that it has two separate compartments for water, one to clean and the other is a receptacle for the dirty refuse.  They are so small, they hold very little water.  Their appearance is deceiving as they hold at most 4 cups each though it looks more like 8.  This led to many trips to the sink to empty and refill.  Whereas the Bissell 8910W ProHeat Cleaner has one large tank that holds about liter of hot water and it is comprised of a flexible, plastic, interior “bladder” which is filled with the clean tap water, while the exterior of bladder is the hard tank that fills with the dirty water that has been processed through the carpet.Due to the excessive visits to empty the dirty and refill the clean compartments of the Oreck, thus I had less time to clean the carpet.  Additionally, each time you remove the clean water container, a lot spills into the holding area.  Also, when the cleaner is stopped, water leaks out the bottom leaving a big “puddle” on the carpet or floor where it is setting.  I found this emptying/refilling tedious and required a lot of wasted effort I would not contend with when using the Bissell 8910W ProHeat (although, at times, it also puddles where it sets as well).  Upon cleaning carpet completion you must allow all water tanks to “air dry” because none are designed to wipe towel dry.Both Oreck and Bissell 8910W ProHeat do a fine job cleaning the carpet.  Using Oreck it may take longer to get the same area of carpet clean because of time utilized to empty/refill the water canisters.  When comparing price Oreck’s current price of $400. seems steep compared to Bissell’s $140., you get the same job for nearly 1/3 the money.  Thus, this extra $260 dollar difference is for the perceived value of Oreck’s durability and quality as well as the smaller size which will allow for easier storage (which is significant to many folks).*It’s replacement didn’t last two years, later I purchased the Bissell PowerSteamer PowerBrush Full Sized Carpet Cleaner and it didn’t last beyond 1.5 hours before the motor burned out (this was Brand New out of the box, not reconditioned).  So, I do not have any allegiance with Bissell.  Since this was a comparison between Oreck Revitalize Carpet Cleaner and Bissell 8910W ProHeat Turbo Upright Deep Cleaner, I didn’t want to focus on the bad experience I had with the Bissell PowerSteamer PowerBrush.

The title "Basic Law: A Mystery of the Cold War Europe" serves as a fine synopsis of this book.  Written by J. Sydney Jones, we travel back in time to 1994 before cell phones and computers would have quickly unraveled the mysteries that await us in this novel.  As a result of the lack of these impressive tools,  we instead rely on a burned out reporter, as we meander with through multiple countries multiple times, seeking multiple people of whom are made subject to multiple inquiries about multiple issues that reporter Sam Kramer has about his former lover, Renata Muller and her involvement with the current leader of a Neo-Nazi group.Renata is found dead a number of days later after her apparent suicide.  Those who know her can't fathom why this woman, who was so dynamic and full of life would be motivated to do something so drastic.  When Kramer discovers that he was named as her Memoir Executor, a document which he can't locate, his suspicions turn to murder.  The more he doggedly he digs, the more dangerous his life becomes.  Those closest to Renata begin to reinforce his perception that she was in fact murdered.  As in any good story, few key people are who they seem nor are those from the past as we remember them to be.  As the dots begin to connect, more questions arise and people closest to Renata face death attempts, too.  Little is what it seems until major piece of the puzzle is identified and the links between people and situations are much more obvious.Basic Law, "Grundesetz" refers to a code in current German law.  In the story, it is stated, "The law as written decrees membership in both right and left terrorist organizations to be illegal."  It is basis of the premise of Basic Law that Kramer manages to get confessions from some ugly characters that Renata had been investigating to revealing their activities past and present in Europe following World War II as it relates to Nazism .Yet, this as the underlying premise for the book didn't really wow this reader.  The book starts off powerfully with many curious matters to digest, but the main plot stumbles and falters as new, underdeveloped characters are utilized in moving the story forward.  As we learn the big reveal, it tends to drift as it concludes in wrapping up loose ends, while relevant motivations just seemed to pat.  As a reader, I was much more invested at the start of the story than I was past the middle, primarily because the characters never evolved beyond their introduction.  Jones is talented but I doubt I'll be reading more of his work.  I read a variety of genre's, so I may not serve as the best assessor of his Cold War story writing style, however, I offer a modest recommendation of this book on the basis that he capably delivered a strong action driven plot, despite my disappointment in its weak characterizations.

This story delivers a great plot and it keeps you guessing until the conclusion.Who is the man, that fathered her young, seemingly promiscuous daughter's baby?  Why can't this guileless young girl tell her mother the truth?  The viewer soon discovers that part of the difficulty is that the young lady is mentally challenged to some degree doesn't always seem to grasp questions.  Though she is sexually developed she has a limited understanding of her world.  Communication between her and her mother is limited but why is she so contrary?  She leads her mother in various misdirections that compound the frustration of both women further.Add to this that they live with very limited funds which is compounded by the fact that the grandfather has just recently died and the baby's father isn't contributing to his needs increases the need to locate the culprit.  The grandmother made a vow to the grandfather that the baby's father would be located, found accountable and give his name to the child so he may be christened before Christmas which is rapidly approaching.  Her anguish is compelling to the viewer and makes for great theater.  Things unfold or more to the point, unravel further and the situation worsens the more she seeks answers.  When unexpectedly she gets a gift from the most unlikely source.  Her shock at the truth in addition to the compassion of others in the midst of her pain makes this a memorable movie for the lucky viewer.Don't let the title or the cover make you quick to judge the gift that is awaiting your viewership.  It is a universal tale that crosses all cultures, races, and ethnicity.  It is timeless piece that keeps you guessing.

Buying store brands for multiple decades I found it frustrating to get locate the true color I desired.  I always had to go a lot lighter (blonde) to achieve a middle range color.  I didn't realize that Naturtint was able to deliver its color with such accuracy!  My first purchase, I went lighter based on experiences with other brands, so I wasn't expecting to become a platinum blonde.  Well, they let me return the remaining boxes and I selected Golden Blonde 7G after much agonizing over their awesome selection.  I am so pleased.  It looks exactly like the box shows!  My hair looks natural and it covers my white, gray and brown roots exceptionally well.  Plus, my hair feels soft and doesn't look dry, not even the ends!But my story gets better!  This is a safer alternative to the caustic, paraben laden products on the store shelves and it doesn't burn my scalp (I have sensitive skin).  It doesn't fade either.  I don't have to worry about color change after a few washes like I found with other brands.Yet, the best part is the cost!  If you like your color, you can buy it in bulk (6 pack) here on Amazon and spend the same or even less than what you would on the less effective, more toxic options in the store.  Can you beat that?  No, I didn't think so!I wish I had found this option years earlier!  I guess I'll be satisfied that I now know and I am enabled to pass this well kept secret to others.  Try it!  I found the company very cooperative when I didn't like my first shade selection.

Author, Sarah Rayner does a fine job encapsulating how stress and trauma may lead to despair and deep depression.  She engages the reader with a number of characters that face a variety of challenges including: loss of spouse; divorce; loss of parent; handicapped child; loss of business and financial viability; incest; chemical imbalances, etc.  She deftly incorporates signs and symptoms and numerous healing pathways in a readable almost pleasurable style.  Her storyline includes people of various ages, cultural and socioeconomic backgrounds.  The book roundly explores that depression can occur regardless of who you are or what you have achieved.The three primary characters meet at a renowned and respected, private mental hospital where each is in crisis.  As they realize that they must voice their situations at least in private therapy, they begin to see themselves and others as opportunities to learn and grow.  Group therapy provides an opportunity to learn which behaviors are detrimental and alternatively those which are healthy coping mechanisms.  Friendships of various types become a support system some are lacking and a honest sounding board in seeing how their thoughts and behaviors have kept them stuck or worsened their depressive state.The story explores the still taboo attitude toward mental illness and why these attitudes keep those in pain from seeking help.  Most people when they experience chest pain, go to the hospital.  Yet, most people who suffer depression won't even share it with a spouse or partner.  Ms. Rayner states that she has incorporated her own and others experiences to bring to light the nature of what depression is and is not, however it is not autobiographical.  I think she has done an outstanding job of explaining mental illness through characters, who were relatable.  The storyline was strong despite that she incorporates many great insights on the causes of depression and offers many strategies to combat symptoms and overcome situations that led to it.  For the most part, it was very realistic.  My one quibble is that most of the main characters transformed into a healthier self at an accelerated pace.  It is unusual for someone in long term clinical depression to make a such great leaps in a few weeks as some did.  Perhaps, she didn't want to add much on their recuperation process as it would lengthen the book and may distract from the key points.  I think that there would have been a way around that but perhaps it was an editor's call.  Thus, I deducted a star because this sends a message to the reader that healing can be easily attained, though this is true for only a small percentage.  Most people don't suddenly get depressed nor do they rapidly return to "normal".I recommend this book to anyone who has suffered from depression or currently stuck.  It is an encouraging read.  I think the quality of the information alone should make it required reading for those considering or working toward a mental health career!  It would also be meaningful to those who have known a friend or family member who struggles as well, so that they have greater understanding and offer healthy support.  Ms. Rayner is a talented author.  I intend to read her other novels.

For years, I have been enjoying Tomato & Roasted Red Pepper by Pacific and it is as good/better than Campbell's Tomato Soup in my opinion.  I particularly like that it is a much healthier choice as well.  Recently, I visited Trader Joe's and saw that they have an Organic version with healthy ingredients, too.  YES! (Imagine fist pump here).I made it shortly after my return home.  Though I had to shake (as instructed),  due to injuries, I am unable to do a sufficient job, once in the pan using either a fork or table spoon, I was able to break up the lumps and heat the soup (the lumps occur with Pacific's version as well).  It was simply delicious.  I had to have a second serving.  When I decided I wanted some for lunch the following day, I ended up making a second serving upon completion of the first.  Lesson learned, just make two servings because it is that good.Though I haven't had Pacific's for nearly a year.  I don't believe that Trader Joe's version is inferior in any way.  Presently, the price on Amazon is a bit hard to swallow but in my metro area, the price is more than a dollar less than Pacific's version per carton.  Prices tend to fluctuate on this website as different seller's compete on this site at various times.  My suggestion is to put it in your cart and wait until the price drops then place your order.The quality is there.  I recommend this to anyone.

I have been using Turmeric for years, then in April 2010 I was seriously injured in an auto accident and have been using Turmeric and other natural remedies to address nerve pain, inflammation and trauma.  Over this period of time, I have used several different Jarrow formulations which includes: Turmeric Concentrate Curcumin 95 and their newer formulation Curcumin Phytosome which is supposed to be more bio-available (my understanding is that the body is absorbs it more efficiently).  I have also used Terry Naturally's Curamin which has a combination of ingredients to enhance Turmeric's performance.  I've even tried NutriGold's  Turmeric Curcumin Gold which includes various components of Turmeric along with Black Pepper derivative (wonderful for pain relief).  I honestly think all of the above are excellent at what they do.  Being that each individual's body chemistry handles things a little different, one may find one product more effective than another.I found that NEW CHAPTER'S Turmeric Force has been quite effective as a daily supplement for me.  Every New Chapter product I have used I have found to out perform my previous brand as my favorite.  However, I would say this New Chapter's Turmeric Force 320 mg of Turmeric per capsule for my body was quite comparable to NutriGold's Curcumin Gold, which has 500 mg of Turmeric per capsule along with Black Pepper (which may be something my body really needs?).If one compares price points New Chapter's 120 capsules is currently offered on Amazon at $35.99 whereas NutriGold's $27.33 as of today's writing 1/25/2015.  Amazon's prices do fluctuate so if price is an important consideration, then New Chapter may not be your best option.  However, we all have different biochemistry, lifestyles and stressors that contribute to how we respond to any product.I really do like New Chapter Turmeric Force.  I believe in New Chapter's product line as being one of the most superior available to consumer's.  While they tend to be more expensive than competitors, they usually have ingredients not included by a competitor so you aren't necessarily comparing apples to oranges, in all other cases I am more than willing to pay extra.  I had an hour plus long conversation with their sales representative and their commitment to quality and the way they process their ingredients are calculated toward protecting the integrity of the ingredients.  You can't go wrong with New Chapter's Turmeric Force.I should mention that my first New Chapter's Zylamend Softgels for inflammation (which has numerous Anti-inflammatory herbs and spices as well Turmeric), which I have been using for at least 3.5 or 4 years.  It was the first anti-inflammatory that really made a difference for me (I've written a review on Amazon already).  Likewise, I wrote a review on New Chapter's Perfect Energy Multi-vitamin, which changed my life for the better!

There is a lot to like about the Freshware 7 in 1 chopper, so I start with what I didn't like first.I clean everything before first use.  So using soapy water and trying to be watchful, I unexpectedly managed to cut one of my fingers on one of the chopping blades, OUCH!  Please use extra caution when washing this unit (it is dishwasher safe).  Which brings me to the next issue, the little cleaning tool is inadequate.  I use an old tooth brush or vegetable scrubber (find one at a dollar store) to get the gunk out.  Clean and dry immediately after use for best cleaning results.This contains many different pieces to the unit so if you plan to use the container to refrigerate chopped items, you have to find a location for all the implements (so you may want to save the box, the entire unit is nearly 15").  I have a small kitchen, so its relatively large size is a bit of a storage conundrum for me, not a compliant, rather a matter to contemplate if kitchen storage space is an issue.I have issues with muscle strength and arthritis so regular chopping is a major struggle for me.  I was really looking forward to this enabling me to do more fresh food preparation.  Unfortunately, the 7-in-1 is a challenge for me assemble and take apart.  Furthermore, as a result of blade sharpness I use greater caution.A big consideration is how much will you use it?  If you do a lot of cooking or prepare large meals, this will be a great time saver, however, if you are just making a simple salad for one or two, it may not be a time saver.I noticed others saying that their slicers warped and I can see that occurring although I am not sure if you follow the guidelines (particularly about not forcing something too hard through a blade) that this will be an issue.
