They will make good liners under shorts to work out, or even under other clothing for "curve contol".  Not bad for about $14.  There are not terribly thin, but too thin to wear alone. I would like to see them available in more colors than just the Birch (light gray).

Temple Grandin faced many obstacles but she always found a way through them. I greatly admire her, and have read a couple of books that she wrote. This one was different because it was written ABOUT her and it goes back tothe very beginning--to her life as a baby and talks about what she was like and about her experiences as a young child, and all the way through her school experiences. BUt it is written as if in her voice. Also included are many terrific drawings and other visuals throughout the book. I highl recomend this book.

My sister just got a new Ipod, and I let her read and use this book.  She is a tech writer, so I wanted to get her opinion. So far so good, she said. She likes it alright, but needs more iTunes. i will add to my review once I get more information.

I bought these for my year-old grandson to use when he is eating at my house. He has another brand at home, also with the metal spoon/fork ends and built up plastic handles, but I think these OXO ones are superior. They have a nice weight and balance, and the handles are longer and the build up helps tiny hands grasp them, but the curved aspect also makes them quite ergonomic. The spoon and fork are not just stamped out of metal, but they have a nicely curved surface. I like how the fork is curved similarly to the spoon. I will say that they seem just a little bit large for a 12 month old, but he will definitely be able to use them for two years as he grows. I paid $5.99 and free shipping with Prime and got them in two days. Fair enough.

This is my first pair of foldable ballet flats, and I like them. I purchased the black ones at a great discount. I wear a size 7.5 Narrow, but the size 8M fits just fine. I wasn't sure I would like the little loafer-styling stitched on the front of the shoe, but it actually is cute and subtle. I think they look really classy and feminine on, and are easy to wear without socks. They do dig just a bit into the back of my heal, but I think the elastic is starting to loosen up some. I am an inveterate sandel wearer during summer, and these make a nice switch-up, but I don't think I would wear them all day because I have problem feet and need good support such as I get from my Birkenstocks or Alegria sandles. Easy to tuck into a purse or suitcase, so great for travel. They come folded in half and packaged in a nice looking box, so they look giftable, too.

0:52 MinsI gave this to my grandson for his first birthday, and he has shown a great interest in it, and is already mastering it, although he has had it only a few days. My son sent me a clip from his iphone of him doing the shapes, so I am attaching it. He has another shape sorter, but this one is better. It is very solidly built and has no sharp edges. Each piece has a rattle inside that makes a different sound from the others. Each shape is also a different color and is color-coded with the shape-hole. This is a toy that is fun, educational and will last. Recommend.

I was doing google searches on my old doctors who treated me in 70's, 80's and beyond, including Matthew Budd, and here, to my surprise I find that he has written a book about "Ways to Wellness", the same program I was in with him in the early 80's. I was a patient of three different primary care doctors at Harvard Community Health Plan, Cambridge Center, in the 80's, including, last but not least, Matthew Budd. With each new doctor, I had hoped that one would take me seriously and find an answer to my health problems and be able to treat my illnesses, but my hopes were dashed.Now, after decades of illness I have discovered that I have an inborn immunodeficiency that was causing me to repeatedly come down with infections, and I was also diagnosed with Systemic Lupus Erthymatosis a few years ago. Back then Dr. Budd, like many others, tried to convince me that my problems were really about stress, anger, or other emotional states, so that if I could just get a handle on these emotional problems I would become healthy. I followed all the steps in the workshop and did all the journaling and homework and I made a remarkable discovery. But not what Dr. Budd had in mind. Instead of finding that emotional states led me to physical illness, I found a strong correlation between getting physically overtired and getting sick. Actually with a little introspection, I should have realized this, but with the Ways to Wellness, I had veritable proof. I was never able to work more than half time, and I had to be very careful with my energy, or I would get sick. I had constant sinus infections, among other things. Dr. Budd was not at all supporting of my finding. Though it was very long ago, I will never forget his reaction. He did not believe me. I did the program, but it didn't work the way he wanted it to, so he just discounted my experience.No, it was not "what I said" that made me sick; it was my body and the crap shoot of genetics that I was dealt. Looking back on my life at 57 years old, I wonder how it would have been if "smart Harvard doctors" like Matthew Budd had believed me and tried to solve the physical problems I had, and had gotten me treatment for my immune deficiency and my lupus. It has long been the attitude of doctors, when they have difficult cases to blame the patient for their problems I hope that is beginning to change with the narrative medicine movement, for example. Just look at the title of this book "YOU are what YOU say"--points the blame right at YOU. I once asked Dr. Budd if I could read my patient records. He became very nervous and asked "why you you want to read them?" I don't know, it's about me, so I thought I should know what it said. Among the demeaning statements I read this one by Budd, "Difficult patient from Dr. Miller." It's been a long road to find doctors who were willing to solve the difficult problems instead of blaming me, but one thing I have learned from this as a medical consumer is: Check your records, for that is how you can find out how your doctor views you.Now I am reading books like Rita Charon's "Narrative Medicine: Honoring the Stories of Illness". I am reading a lot about the Medical Humanities programs that teach doctors to listen to their patients and understand their health issues. I am writing poetry about my experiences and getting it published so other people will understand. I am working on Disability Studies.I am sorry that this is not strictly a "book review", but I want to put my story out to you because if it helps someone get the help they need, it will be worthwhile. I get a lot of books to review, both on my own and from the vine, and always make it a point to READ them through, but in this case, I believe this is mostly, as a reviewer of another edition of this book said, "psycho babble". I do not recommend this book by Matthew Budd.

These pineapple chunks are quite tasty--sweet and flavorful in their own juice. I think it is a fair price, too. I like having a stock of these small cans because they are the right size for me to use by myself for two servings. The cans have pop-tops, so they are a good portable snack. Doubtless many people would find them to be the right size for a single serving, but for me, they are just a bit too big for that. I like to blend them with Greek yogurt, soy milk, chia seeds and ice for a super-nutrious smoothy pick me up.

I like these Herring Fillets a lot, and also the ones in mustard sauce. They are less salty and more tasty than kippered snacks. They are soft and easy to eat and the sauce is tasty. I think it would be nice if there was more fish in there and less sauce, but I end up eating all of the sauce, too. I disagree with the reviewer who said that one tin of these would serve three people. There are only six ounces in the tin and that's including the sauce, just enough for a single portion. I like to keep some in my car along with some Wasa and other healthy snacks because I hate fast food. Great source of tasty protein. But after I ordered the case for about $2 each, I found out that [big name] store carries them for $1.38 each. If they come down in price here, I will order more because I like the convenience of having them delivered to my door.

I got the bronze ones (from a different source, though, and it goes with a lot of different outfits, especially ones with a little metallic embroidery or metallic accents. One of the things that convinced me to purchase these shoes was the fact that the footed is made of latex (under the soft suede sole), which is in my opinion THE most comfortable substance. I have latex pillows and a latex mattress (very expensive) and they are way better than memory foam or any other material. Most of my shoes, especially my summer sandals are Birkenstocks, and these shoes are every bit as comfortable as any other them, including my soft foot bed Birks, and they are far more comfortable than Danksos, which, to me are actually hard.I have a narrow foot, and I wish this brand made at least a few of their shoe styles in narrow. When I saw these sandals with the two Velcro adjustable straps, I thought I'd chance it, and I am glad I did because they adjust to fit me very nicely.The material that the uppers are made from is definitely shiny and the square jewel-like adornment on the toe strap gives the sandal a unique pizzazz. The stitching around the outer part of the sole is a shiny gold color and it is visible when wearing it (it outlines your foot). Amazingly comfortable walking or just standing in them and a dress-up or down versatility make these Alegria sandals a good addition to my summer shoe wardrobe.

I was given this product in return for an honest review. It came at just the right time, as I was about to buy one! A friend has been doing fermenting and has posted many of his results on Facebook. I have been drooling over them, have downloaded a fermenting cookbook, and am raring to get started (as we say in Texas). I'm not walking well right now due to leg surgery, but as soon as I'm functional again I'll be using the heck out of this product. Do you know you can make your own yogurt, buttermilk, low-fat sour cream, fermented salsa, fermented cabbage (sauerkraut), fermented lettuce if you like milder sauerkraut, fermented carrots, and the list goes on. What's most important is that as these are high-acid foods you can use a boiling water bath to can them instead of having to use a pressure canner. I'll admit I haven't used this yet, but it's where I can see it every day when I sit down to eat and I'm looking forward with delight to the foods I can make in it.

I was given this product in return for an honest review. At this moment it is sitting on my printer stand, where I put it when it arrived. I am soon going to put it in my 72-hour emergency kit, because who knows what I or someone else may need to sew during an emergency? As other reviewers have already told exaclly what is in it, I am not going to repeat it. I will say, however, that it is small enough to be easily transportable, but thorough enough to cope with most emergencies. I am quite pleased with it and am likely to buy more for people I know will want to put it in their emergency kit. My stepdaughter will be particularly interested in it, as she and her husband like to camp out, and they have four small children. I remember that when she was a small child I never took her anywhere without a sewing kit, after the time she slid down a hill on a cardboard box, fell off the box, and ripped the entire back seam out of her shorts. Live and learn! I'd have been very happy to have this then; as it was, I was fortunate that another woman in the restroom had several safety pins she gave me!

I ordered these when I landed in the hospital with serious sepsis that began in my artificial knee. The surgeon had to remove the metal entirely and put in a "concrete" which amounted to plastic spacer impregnated with antibiotics. The pain referred all over the place, including my back, where it manifested as severe heat. A helpful CNA made me an ice pack, which was great until I moved and was instantly drenched with ice water. Then I remembered the disposable blue ice pack the hospital gave us one time when one of us sprained something or other. We had been using it ever since, but the problem was we had only one, and we needed more so I would have one to use when the other was refreezing. Rush to Amazon! Yep, they had it. Now I have it. Or rather, I have them. Problem solved. Now I'm waiting eight weeks instead of the usual two to be sure the sepsis doesn't return before I get my leg back. Oh well. I'd rather wait extra time than have an amputation.

I love this book and its instructions. It teaches you how to make meals for one or two in mason jars, and store them for reasonably short periods of time. If you have a microwave at work you can prepare your meal ahead of time and just grab it when you go out the door. Of course not all the meals will be okay in a microwave, but that's fine too. You can prepare ahead of time when you know everybody in the family will want to eat at a different time from everybody else, or when a major project such as moving gobbles up mealtime. This kind of advance plannig and preparation helps the entire family and whatever friends and relatives are helping with the project.

The title of this is confusing. I thought at first it meant making a ring of forged coins. But I read it anyway, and realized it meant forging a coin into a finger ring. It is interesting and I may use the idea in a novel, but I am never going to try it myself in real life.

I was given this in return for an honest review. Because I am on oxygen I cannot have candles in my bedroom. This "candle" is LED lights made to look like a candle. I am very pleased with it. Of course it won't work in case of power failure, but neither will the oxygen concentrator, so I can use a real candle in that situation.

This is not a novel. It is a collection of short stories, each one featuring a man who wants a baby and a woman who wants to give him a baby. Sometimes but not always the couple are married. It works very well.
If you are confined to bed because of illness or accident, you urgently need these to protect the sheet from the occasional accident resulting from your care-taker not reaching you in time.

These briefs are okay, but I got a size larger than I needed. I did that to be sure they would go over my ankle to hip leg immobilizer, but it turned out that my normal size fit just fine. I'm going to give the rest of these to charity. I don't need them but I'm sure someone will. I wish the seller had posted a correct size so that people wouldn't get the wrong size.

What can I say? My husband took my denture brush to clean inside the car windows with. He just thought it was a nice little brush, and he didn't think to ask me what it was for. When I sent him to get me a new denture brush, he went to three drugstores and couldn't find one. I wound up having to order it from Amazon, and I was very pleased with this one. Now that he knows what it is and what it's for, he will not take this on to clean the car with!
This is an important book for anyone who wants to survive the oncoming inflation/depression. My only caveat is that it doesn't go far enough into what is going on and what will happen all too soon.

Don't be intimidated by the sometimes long lists of ingredients. Most of them require only a few teaspoons and are things you probably already have in your spice cabinet. I shall be making some of things in this book. I should mention that I lived less than two miles from the best Mexican food restaurant in Utah, also recognized as one of the best in the United States, but you definitely pay for good Mexican food. I look forward to making my own authentic Mexican food, not more Tex-Nex,although as a transplanted Texan I still love Tex-Mex. If you like cooking, and you like Mexican food, this book definitely belongs in your cookbook collection.

I was given one of these in return for an honest review. This is a dashboard cam for individual usage. Although we usually think of dashboard cams only in relation to law enforcement, in at least one case a dashboard cam already has been used to halt a lawsuit brought by a scammer who deliberately swung his car into the path of another car, causing the other car to ram it. The sammer sued for a large sum of money, but the dashboard camera saved the day and caused the scammer to be sentenced to a large fine and payment of his intended victim's court costs. As soon as I read about that, I decided to get my husband a dashboard cam if I could afford one. (I don't drive anymore.) DBPower came to the rescue, and my husband now has a dashboard cam which will protect him from nuisance lawsuits and questions such as "Didn't you see that red light?" I strongly recommend this camera, which is easy to use and relatively inexpensive, to anyone who drives and doesn't like to be hassled.

I was provided a free copy of this book in return for an honest review--and what, you may ask, does a Utah Mormon do with a book about small distilleries in New York State? Well, I happen to be a writer, and I am already considering how to work some of this information into some of my novels. To sum up quickly, changes in the law allow New York residents to go commercial with spirits in much smaller quantities than was previously required, and to treat them as farm produce rather than as alcoholic beverages. The result has to be an extremely varied crop of beverages, many of which sounded interesting. The only thing that concerns me--and this is a concern with the liquor rather than with the book--is that absinthe is being produced. Absinthe is well known to seriously damage the brain when taken in even moderate amounts, and I would hate to see the Paris experience with absinthe repeated in New York. France long since outlawed absinthe entirely, and its major ingredient, wormwood, was declared unfit for human consumption. But the book itself is interesting, and if you use alcoholic beverages, and live in or intend to visit New York, you are likely to have a use for this information.

I was provided a free copy of this book in return for an honest review. Although it was written by a high school senior, I found it a well thought through and well written discussion of many music-makers and many who help music reach its consumers. There were very few errors in it and most of those were quite minor.  I recommend it to loves of music of all kinds, as it covers all kinds of music.

I was provided a free copy of this in return for an honest review, which is the only kind of review I ever write. I found it a delightfully written, delightfully illustrated, imaginative children's book. The words are too long for young children to read it themselves, but with a loving parent who can explain the longer words, it will be both interesting and informative read. I would have loved it as a child, and as a 72-year-old grandmother I love it now. I strongly recommend it for children, especially those who want to know WHY we should protect toads. Maybe parents should insert a little of their own knowledge here--toads eat harmful insects in the garden!

I ordered three of these, and I have been using them ever since they arrived. I am ill and confined to bed most of the time, so I am wearing them 24/7. They have already been washed several times, and there has been no fading. I do recommend washing them separately or with other dark blue items.

I received a complimentary sample of this product for my honest and unbiased feedback. That is the only kind of review I write. CLA is important for leveling your blood sugar and losing some of your fat deposits. Right now I am losing weight too fast, due to recent blood poisoning, but before I became ill CLA was important to me.  I used to have diabetes. Now I don't. My three-month blood tests have been normal for a long time.  Even my doctor says I no longer have diabetes. I do need to lose more weight, so I will continue taking CLA. I have found that Viva Labs products are good, dependable, and lower in cost than some other fairly good supplements. I recommend them.

This is a useful book, but I would add something to it. For heaven's sake get somebody to EDIT your book. I have read some of those 24-hour books and found the grammar, mechanics, and punctuation so bad that I could scarcely follow the information. Even this book could have stood some editing. Given that caveat, you CAN make money writing about what you know.

I found this book interesting but not compelling. It shows how to add new habits to habits you already have that are similar or related. It should work, but I have not yet had time to try its suggestions, as I read it only day before yesterday. I recommend it to anyone who needs to break bad habits or add more good habits, and who isn't in one or these situations?

I'm sure Brody Clayton is sick of my reviews. I'm sorry, and I know this book is interesting to others. My problem with this book is that I am a former CSI. I have seen too many murders and cleared too many cases. I'm now 72 and I've been away from murder for a long time. I downloaded several books about murder cases and found them depressing. I'm sure that people who haven't seen as many murders as I have would find this book fascinating. The first murder I saw, two days after I became a cop, was the stabbing death of a young mother. It did not become a cold case; her husband was found two blocks away sitting on the curb crying. Her baby was crying in the room where the mother lay, and everybody was afraid to go into the room to get him. I handed him across the floor to his grandmother. The young mother had bled dry; the knife, a short blade of a pocket knife, had hit her breastbone, corkscrewed, and gone straight into her heart. She bled dry. You cannot imagine how much blood was on the floor. That was my introduction to murder. This book brought those memories back. I'd rather not remember. That is my own reaction, not a comment on the book's quality.

This book was very interesting as it explored different stories form different Asian cultures. Whether or not they are true, the book was worth reading as a look into those cultures. I recommend it not only to readers who enjoy the paranormal, but also to those who are interested in the Orient.

My problem with this book is that I am a former CSI. I have seen too many murders and cleared too many cases. I'm now 72 and I've been away from murder for a long time. I downloaded several books about murder cases and found them depressing. I'm sure that people who haven't seen as many murders as I have would find this book fascinating. The first woman murderer I saw was a woman who had stabbed her own mother to death. I was sent to fingerprint her three days later. She was lying on the floor in her jail cell, still covered with the blood she had refused to let anyone wash off. She was completely catatonic, and easy to fingerprint, but the whole situation was horrible, and as I fingerprinted her I could not help but remember the gashed body of her mother, who had tried to fight back  Later my own youngest daughter was accused of a murder she did not commit. This book brought those memories back. I'd rather not remember. That is my own reaction, not a comment on the book's quality.
This book pleased me greatly. It is suspenseful and compassionate, and I want to read the other books in the series. I recommend it to anybody who likes romance, magic, and historical fiction.

I love cookbooks. I love salads. I like to make my own salad dressings. So what's not to like about this book? I recommend it to anybody who likes salad and likes DIY. It is terrific. I am presently laid up with a leg injury, but as soon as I can get around again I'll be trying some of these recipes. You should too. If you read the label on some of  your favorite salad dressings you''ll be horrified at what you've been putting into your body. This book will teach you to make salad dressings that are as healthful as they are delicious. So I also recommend t to anyone who likes to eat and cares about health.

I found this book riveting, for both its plot and its characters, as well as the way the backstory was presented. I intend to read all the other books by Sally Spencer. I hope to see many more Blackstone books.

The author studied many old cookbooks, most of which I have also read. I enjoyed her paraphrases and her method of combining different sources seamlessly. My only disappointment was that three days before downloading this book, I had decided to do the same thing she turned out to do! Now I have to find something else to do. If you are writing a historical novel of any kind set in the time period this book covers, I highly recommend it. I also recommend it to anybody interested in the history of cooking.

This book was provided free by the author in return for an honest review. I am sorry to say that I found the book unreadable. I closed it after the first five chapters, because to that point it had been almost all telling with very, very little showing and very little dialogue. The story might or might not have been good, but it was not accessible. If the author would take it down, rewrite with showing and dialogue and a minimum of telling, and send it to me for a new review, I will be happy to come back and change this review. But as it is, I cannot honestly recommend it to anyone. I'm sorry, because I know the author put in a lot of work, but it needs much more. If I were asked to book doctor it, I would not be able to charge less tan $5000, because in effect I would be rewriting it entirely. I do not want to do this job and I do not expect that any other honest writer will want to do it. The author needs to study writing much more before doing his own rewriting.

I received a complimentary sample of this product for my honest and unbiased feedback. Magnesium is essential to normal body functions. It should be taken in the proper ratio to calcium; use any nutrition site to find this proportion. Most people are unaware of this necessity and become severely low on magnesium. I am very aware of the problem, because I am bipolar and I know that I function better with magnesium. But even people with no mental problems whatever are likely to become depressed or unreasonably angry if their magnesium level is low, and few foods provide adequate magnesium. So I was delighted when Viva Labs asked me to evaluate this. I found that it provides adequate magnesium for my life, if taken in the proper dosage, and I used it until I ran out. I expect to purchase more soon. I highly recommend it to everybody who wants to keep their mind functioning properly. This is good stuff.

You may not be interested in this. I am. Even if you are not interested, I recommend you at least read up on the uses of garlic. You will find that some of these natural remedies attack viruses, which no pharmaceuticals do adequately except in very few cases, and in those cases they are hideously expensive. I know man who had AIDS who went to HIV negative and has stayed that way; his doctor says he will continue to do so as long as he stays on his meds--which cost him over $200 a day! And that is one of the very few viruses that can be treated pharmaceutically. I have used natural antibiotics for many years, and I intend to continue to do so. This does not mean I reject pharmaceuticals; I do not, especially since recent treatment saved my life. I was literally dying when I entered the hospital on a stretcher. But all the same, natural remedies can help with many conditions. My doctor and I have an agreement: if the stuff is known to be harmless I take it; otherwise, I ask her first. She rarely says no. Try this . . . oh, by the way, I started using natural remedies when I was eight years old, when my father came home to tell my mother that onions were known to help prevent colds and keep them lighter when people did catch them. From then on, we got onions at breakfast every morning. Try these ebooks. They may not save  your life, but they can make you a lot more comfortable.

I love gardening. But I have injured my leg and cannot get outdoors; and by the time I heal winter will be upon us, with heavy snow. The only way I will be able to garden is indoors. So I am looking forward to being able to plant in the kitchen, the laundry room, and the den. This box set of books will help me to do this, and also help me garden outdoors when good weather returns. I recommend this to anyone who wants or needs to garden indoors for any reason.

I was provided this flashlight free in return for an honest review, which is the only kind of review I ever give. I like this product. It is useful to me because I am presently ill and at times my husband has to get up at night to check on me. He can use this and avoid having his hands full of flashlight at night This is important because he and I are both old, and he needs both hands at time to balance. I can see that it would be useful to other people for camping, for working on car engines and oil changes, and for many other uses. It would be useful to a new mother going to check on her child without wanting to turn on the light and wake the baby. I consider this an excellent product and I highly recommend it to anybody who has any use for extra light at night or in dark situations.

I was offered this in return for an honest review. Every now and then, when offered something that I can't use, I will ask a friend to give me his or her take on it. This review was written by an eleven-year-old boy:Very convenient.Easy to set up.Easy to apply remotes to charger. Playstation didn't heat up once. Plug in more cables than just the charger.  Takes up less space. Motor runs very quietly.

I was given this sleep mask in return for an honest review. As that is the only kind of review I ever leave, I had no problem in complying.I found this sleep mask excellent. At the moment I am in a skilled nursing facility where I went after being released from the hospital. I will go home next week, but at present my sleep is frequently disturbed by people wanting to take my blood pressure, and do other things that require turning on the light. It is a scientific fact that people do not sleep well if even a small amount of light shines in their eyes. I ask everybody when they are through with whatever they are doing to turn off all the lights including the bathroom light, and to close the hall door. But they often forget, and the bathroom light is especially annoying because it reflects off a metal plate attached to the wall and shines straight into my eyes. But when this sleep mask arrived, it cut out all the light. I can almost sleep through a blood pressure test as long as I keep this mask on, and if I am wakened and do not have light in my eyes I can go right back to sleep. Another feature I like about this sleep mask is that it has two straps,not one, to keep it on. Some years ago I bought several sleep masks that has only one strap and I wound up having to hand-repair all the straps where they attached to the mask. I do not expect to have this problem with this sleep mask.I am very pleased with it and intend to buy more.

ROYAL CHILDREN OF ENGLISH HISTORY was written for children. It does introduce the reader to persons they might not have thought of or even known about, but it does not go into any depth about any of them.
I consider this book to be over-optimistic. I write ebooks and publish them, but I don't expect to be a millionaire any time soon.
I have an incurable itchy scalp. Scalplcin doesn't help long, but it helps when I can't sleep because of the itching. I recommend it to anyone with itchy scalp problems.

I was still using a scale for my food that only went u[p to one pound. When I was cooking, that often wasn't high enough. This scale is perfect. It does what I need it to do, and it is a convenient size. I expect to use it often. I was given this product in return for an honest review.

Very nice product. I'm giving them to my son and daughter-in-law, who will love them and wear them. The other reviews have said everything else I would say, and I am flat on back in a skilled nursing facility after leaving a hospital, so I'm not up to leaving a long review.

I was offered this book in return for an honest review. As I finished reading it, I was reminded of a dear friend who entered the Army as a buck private and retired as a two-star general with a degree in military history. His son is a Down's Syndrome victim. The general told us that he believed his son understands more than he does, in many ways, and he wished there were a way he could learn what his son knewThe general would have  understood this book and enjoyed it.If you have any interest in ESP, especially if you are an ESPer yourself, even if your abilities are slight, you will find this book fascinating and highly important. If you are interested in New Age thinking or in ancient people's thinking, the latter part of the book will rivet you to your chair.This is one of the most fascinating books I have ever read. I recommend it for every adult and for mature teenagers.

It is advertised as being for all women, but it is small and pink, with a "cute" picture on it. I wouldn't offer it to anyone over the age of twelve. It is, however, attractive for the age it seems to be intended for.  I was given it in return for an honest review. This is the most honest review I can give.

After three and a half weeks in bed doing nothing but read, I am finally able to stay up long enough to write some reviews. So don't think that my posting many reviews in a short period of time means that I didn't read the book.  I read every word of every one. This book was provided to me without charge in return for an honest review.Watch what you wish for. You might get it.The aliens were disembodied. They couldn't do much harm. Could they?If the phrase "monsters from the id" means anything to you,  you know the answer to that question. If you don't, see the seminal science fiction movie Forbidden Planet. It isn't very good. But all the science fiction movies and television shows stem from it in one way or the other. AFTER you have seen the movie, you may be ready to read this book. If you are at all interested in science fiction, or in the possibility of intelligent life on other planets (and if you aren't, you have a massive ego and delusions of grandeur) you should read this book.

After three and a half weeks in bed doing nothing but read, I am finally able to stay up long enough to write some reviews. So don't think that my posting many reviews in a short period of time means that I didn't read the book.  I read every word of every one. This book was provided to me without charge in return for an honest review.A friend of ours who was a very high-ranking officer in the US Army had son who had Down's syndrome. He told us once that he believed that his son was more intelligent than he was, and if he had a way to look inside his son's mind he would learn a lot. Trispero is the novel that if he were still alive I would give to him at once. It looks at Down's syndrome in a way no other author has ever done. if you read this book you will understand far more about why parents of such a child usually cherish the child. This book is from more than 200 years in the future, looking back at our time when people didn't know what they know now.I think this is a book for everyone, especially those who shy away from people with obvious mental defects.Oh, by the way. Our friend had a Ph.D. in military history and was well known for his tactics. Several weeks before his death, his son, frustrated by his mother's refusal to let him take a long walk in the neighborhood alone, lured his mother into the garden shed and then stepped out and locked the door. After his walk, he went and released his mother, who had steam coming out he ears. But I was mainly impressed that this young man, supposedly mentally retarded, took after his brilliant father in creating tactics that worked. Take this anecdote with you as you begin to read Trispero.

After three and a half weeks in bed doing nothing but read, I am finally able to stay up long enough to write some reviews. So don't think that my posting many reviews in a short period of time means that I didn't read the book.  I read every word of every one. I would have read a cereal box if nothing else had been available. This book was provided to me without charge in return for an honest review.This book is sui generis. It is often--what am I saying? It is ALWAYS difficult for the reader to figure out what is going on. No wonder, considering that it is also difficult for the characters to figure out what's going on.The only book with which I can honestly compare it is Hitchiker's Guide to the Galaxy, except the latter is better written than Genius de Milo. If you like science fiction combined with fantasy and Jungian  types, you are likely to love this book. Otherwise, I am afraid you will put it down before the end of the first chapter.My son and daughter-in-law will love it. So they will get it.

After three and a half weeks in bed doing nothing but read, I am finally able to stay up long enough to write some reviews. So don't think that my posting many reviews in a short period of time means that I didn't read the book.  I read every word of every one. I would have read a cereal box if nothing else had been available. This book was provided to me without charge in return for an honest review.Why do even the most skeptical of skeptics believe Devon Clarke's transformation into the guru Dadaram. His old friend Magnus Larsen doesn't believe it, but he can't seem to stay away from Dadaram, especially when Dadaram begins to pour money and gifts into the resumed friendship. Then Dadaram wants Magnus to kill him. When Magnus refuses, Dadaram sets a fire which kills one of his nicest and most reliable women disciples, as well as her sweet but retarded sister. Why? What's going on? Obviously answering those questions would create a trail of spoilers. But I can safely assure you that this novel, with its incredibly detailed and believable pictures of various Oriental cultures, is worth anybody's time to read it.

After three and a half weeks in bed doing nothing but read, I am finally able to stay up long enough to write some reviews. So don't think that my posting many reviews in a short period of time means that I didn't read the book.  I read every word of every one. I would have read a cereal box if nothing else had been available. This book was provided to me without charge in return for an honest review.This book is extremely interesting if you are prepared to believe that all scientists are wrong and so are most religious beliefs. Starting with "the big bang is a hoax" and proceeding to prove that important scientific discoveries cannot be made in a dishonest society: As our present society is dishonest, most of the scientific theories and proofs that have been presented in at least the last seventy years are incorrect, untrue,, and often contain lies about statistics and experiments.Everybody is out of step but me.I'm going to put this book on my shelves right beside the one in which Velikovsky proved that two planets in our solar system collided with each other within human history. On the other side will be Velikovsky's Mankind in Amnesia, which proves that the reason this event is remembered only in mythology is that all humans agreed not to remember what really happened because it was too frightening.If you still read Velikovsky anyway, as I obviously do, and enjoy watching The History Channel's shows about ancient aliens, as my husband does, although both of us realize that the stories told are idiotic, then you will enjoy this book. Otherwise, never mind reading it.

After three and a half weeks in bed doing nothing but read, I am finally able to stay up long enough to write some reviews. So don't think that my posting many reviews in a short period of time means that I didn't read the book.  I read every word of every one. I would have read a cereal box if nothing else had been available. This book was provided to me without charge in return for an honest review.I'm white. My best friend is black. Her husband is white. I found this book terrific in its explanation, on a child's level of understanding, of mixed-race families. I wish I had had it when my oldest daughter, seeing a black woman for the first time, shouted, "Mommy, why is that lady purple?" I told her the lady was not purple; she was brown; and it was because Heavenly Father doesn't want all the flowers in his garden to be the same color. As her grandmother had a magnificent iris garden, she understood that at once. But this book is ideal for answering questions like this. I don't know yet who I'm going to give this one to. I'll have to think about it, and maybe ask Shalana. What am I saying? I KNOW I'll ask Shalana.

0:51 Mins I am happy to present to you the easiest-to-use, easiest-to-clean chopper I've ever encountered.  The Black & Decker engineers hit a home run with this little baby.  Let me tell you why (then watch the video to see how easy and effective it is to operate).1)  Ease of use.  No weird twisty tops or latchy lids need to be engaged to get it to operate.  Simply put the blade shaft onto a spindle in the bowl, rest the motor on top, hold it in place, and chop away.  "Ergo" Chopper, indeed.2)  Everything (save the motor, of course) is dishwasher safe.  Makes for convenient clean up.  Wipe the motor down with a damp paper towel and you're done.3)  Safety.  I tried to get this thing to misfire and turn on when not closed.  With reasonable efforts (short of sticking a screwdriver into every hole), I couldn't.  It will be safe enough for responsible kids to use.4)  It's got good guts.  We've chopped any number of vegetables with this unit and it's always been up to the task.This product is very deserving of its 5-star rating.

There's a lot to like about this little powerhouse.  Since I received this product as a member of Amazon's Vine program, I felt compelled to put it through it's paces, so to speak.  Out of the box, I had the Bluetooth-compatible speaker paired with my phone and playing music in about 2 minutes.  It's very easy to set up and comes with clear instructions.Your first question probably is, "Does it actually float?"  Answer:  YES!  You just have to be absolutely certain you've got the rubber stoppers fully engaged in the back to keep water from damaging the access ports.  The instructions recommend you not submerge the speaker but you can be confident that a little washover and splashes won't cause any problems.I've been showering with this baby for a month without a hitch.  The easy-to-install rubber strap works well simply draped over my shower head.  It lasts about 2 weeks worth of on a single charge, which will vary totally based on your shower length experience...  ;-)  A helpful red light starts to notify you when the battery is getting low.  You'll have about 30 minutes of listening time before it completely konks out, during which time you may notice a slight decrease in volume but no degredation of sound quality.So, how is the sound?  Very CLEAR.  Crisp highs, and powerful mids.  While it makes a valiant effort, it doesn't have enough housing to make pool-shaking bass, so don't expect that it's like having a Bose Acoustawave equivalent in the bathtub with you.  There are a few separate EQ settings, all of which augment the mids (making the sound tinny, like an old AM radio), so my favorite EQ setting is "Flat".  The only reason this unit doesn't get a 5-star rating is because I believe at its current price point (over $100) I would expect more robust bass.  They've engineered this speaker so that your can turn it to max volume without notable distortion, which is nice.  In an outdoor setting, you'll be able to hear the music clearly at a radius of 20 feet or so, thus no need to worry about overpowering the neighborhood.Charging takes between 8 - 12 hours.  The unit comes supplied with a mini-USB cable that can be easily replaced if you lose it, so no worries.Weighing in at just a couple of pounds, the applications for this speaker are nearly endless.  Outdoors in any weather, on a boat, IN the pool, IN the shower, at the end of the picnic table, heavens, even in the car or carrying your NYNE around the house, you'll never have a reason for the tunes to stop.

Take your Hot Wheels tracks to new levels of awesome with this track starter.  This starter is am improvement over a another Hot Wheels track setHot Wheels Workshop Track Builder Starter Set for a couple of reasons:1)  It's got a much smaller footprint.  The 4-way starter requires a HUGE amount of floor space, while this one will get your cars zipping along in 2 directions without overtaking your entire living room.2)  It's got a built-in stunt.  The engineers timed this baby nicely:  A car gets released later flipped over (on the gray box) by the initial car that starts the sequence.  Your little stuntmen will think it's pretty cool.This set is not a simple set up, though.  The recommended age for this set starts at age 4.  If you can find a 4-year-old who can set up this set, sign them up for MENSA, STAT.  It took me about 20 minutes total from first opening the box to completion.All in all, this is an entertaining way to augment your Hot Wheels adventures.

I'll keep this testimonial short and to the point:  The print quality from these ink cartridges is fine, better (by a small margin) than the generic versions I'd been using for the last few years.  However, the blue cartridge ran dry within about 10 pages.  VERY disappointed, especially for the price.

Sporting high-quality graphics from the "real" Star Wars movies (Episodes IV - VI), this comforter has become our favorite movie-night sofa blanket.  The colors are vivid and well-defined.  The comforter is reversable with images of tie-fighters and other spacecraft on the back.  Best of all, Jar Jar Binks is nowhere to be found.  As with any printed graphic linen, it's not "fuzzy" in texture, but rather smooth.  It's comfortable, warm, and (since it's a comforter) provides more coverage area than your average blanket.This comforter will be a real treat for your little (or not so little) Jedi to stay cozy.

This is my third pair of Merrell shoes.  I've come to the conclusion that they may be my best fit for both comfort and toughness.  I'm a registered nurse and therefore on my feet A LOT.  I need shoes that don't make my feet scream at the end of the day.  Merrells are interesting in that they're not like walking on pillows.  In fact they're surprisingly firm.  Nonetheless, I don't suffer from foot fatigue at the day's end.  I can usually get about 6 months of use out of a pair of these shoes, which is double what I'll get out of a pair of Asics, Adidas, or New Balance.  They double as great hiking shoes, having taken them off-roading at some of our state parks.They do tend to run on the narrow side.  Consider ordering a half-size up if it's your first pair.  Highly recommended.

The best way I can think to describe SET DICE is to say it's a cross between Scrabble Classic Crossword New Game and Qwirkle Board Game, combining Scrabble's scoring grid and Qwirkle's rummy-like matching of shapes and colors.  It's fast and fun... if you can even get started.Once you understand the instructions, just about anyone over the age of six can enjoy this game.  The written instructions are a mind-boggling exercise in over-complication.  The concepts are, in fact, simple:  Create sets of three dice that meet certain criteria, i.e.: all different colors, numbers, etc..., then line them up like a crossword puzzle.  The instructions are about 10 panels explaining every possible iteration and variation (plus 2 full-on variations of the game for a nice variety).  The game rules are not difficult to explain (verbally) by someone who understands the game, thus you can play this with your friends without difficulty.  The initial start-up might be off-putting to some.  My kids were intuitively playing the game even before I'd finished trying to digest the instructions, which gives me hope for the future.Hang in there on your first read-through (or two) of the instructions and you'll be rewarded with a fun family-friendly game.

I'm a bit of a geography geek and was hoping this set would spark more curiosity in some kids I know, but there are so many problems with this set that it's being avoided by both the kids AND the adults.  Any way you slice it, this is a cheap (in every sense of the word) alternative to T.S. Shure Wooden Magnetic Map of the USA Puzzle.  If you want a more enjoyable experience (that will last longer, provide better play, lose less pieces, have a decent carrying case, etc...) save up a few more bucks and get the wooden version.  The shortcomings of this set make it worth avoiding at any cost.The carrying case is a flimsy plastic and paper combo.  It's not destined to last, even with "kid glove" treatment.  The backboard is a flimsy piece of what feels like posterboard that's got a magnetic coating.  The state pieces stick unevenly.  The pieces are very small and easy to lose, making a nightmare for people who like their puzzles/educational materials complete.  (The target audience for this playboard aren't inclined to keep things neat and orderly.)As a side note, the little pieces are a major choke/intestinal hazard for babies.T.S. Shure, it was a noble idea to make a cheaper alternative to your wooden set, but sadly I think you'll have to go back to the drawing board on this one.

After my expericne with the stellar T.S. Shure Alphabet Letters Wooden Magnets 26 Piece MagnaFun Set, my hopes for this T.S. Shure set were high.  Sadly, not only does it fail to meet expectations, it flat-out disappoints.As you can imagine with a puzze of the world, there are A LOT of pieces.  Any set with A LOT of pieces should demand a decent carrying case.  This set's case (if you can even call it that) is a paper envelope with a plastic window and paper handles.  A six-year-old boy I know nearly tore it in half just trying to open it up, and he wasn't even being rough.  Without the carrying case, you're going to have to deal with lots of loose pieces.  Lots.  Of.  Loose.  Pieces.Next, the background is like a lightly magnetized piece of cardboard to which you can sort-of stick the pieces.  The pieces are colorful but small, definitely a choking hazard for toddlers or younger.  If you've never considered this, magnates are a SERIOUS RISK and LIFE THREATENING if swallowed, potentially causing digestive tract perforations...  In other words, KEEP THIS AWAY FROM THE LITTLE ONES.Beyond that, I have a beef with the pieces themselves.  Now, with a puzzle this size, I don't expect to have a separate piece for Belgium or Burundi, but seriously, the designers didn't even seem to make a serious attempt at following country borders.  The groupings are somewhat bizarre sometimes with some countries getting cut in half and others bunched together.  Call me a geography geek if you will, but if you spend this much time designing an educational tool like this, having the pieces make geographic sense only... well, makes sense.Gobs of potential just didn't pan out here.  You can find better tools for teaching geography without all the risk and mess.

After my expericne with the stellar T.S. Shure Alphabet Letters Wooden Magnets 26 Piece MagnaFun Set, my hopes for this T.S. Shure set were high.  Sadly, it fails to meet expectations.A major disappointment came literally right out of the box.  As I picked up the plastic carrying case, 3 pieces fell immediately out of a large hole in the bottom.  It would have been almost all the pieces if I hadn't tipped the case flat on its back.  Not a good start.  What would have been a very convenient storage case has been rendered useless by cheap materials (until I get out a roll of 3M Utility Duct Tape 2929 Silver, 1-22/25 in x 50 yd 5.8 mils).The anatomy set is comprised of a magnetic body-shaped piece with a skeleton printed on it.  One can stick various body systems (circulatory, muscular, etc...) or clothes onto the base piece.  Play is very akin to old-fashioned paper dolls and can be adopted and mastered in a matter of seconds.  Though it is VERY basic in its instruction, kids can get a cursory introduction to different body systems and their anatomical layouts.  The mix-n-match possibilities are potentially the most fun part of the game (boy with skeletal head, muscular torso, exposed blood vessels in legs).  Without labeling, though, kids may not know what they're looking at.Please note there are pieces with genetalia printed for both genders, which weirded out my kintergardener and jr. higher (for different reasons).  While I understand that genitals are important parts of the anatomy, I think it's a safe bet to say that those will be the least played-with pieces and probably could have been better substituted with another body system (or more clothes, hair colors, skin types, etc...) that would garner more interest (rather than squirmy avoidance) from the kiddos.

This product is well constructed, can support up to 300 lbs (I'm just under that and it feels solid), and is comfortable to use when doing crunches.  I like the versatility of this unit in that you can flip it over and do steady dip exercises.  The crunch technique takes a little getting used to so one isn't straining their neck.  My wife and kids (all of smaller frame than me) had more difficulty perfecting the technique and I believe it's because they were having to reach for the arm support bar further, therefore were more likely to pick their heads up off the mesh support.It took me and the kids 20 minutes to assemble out of the box.  There is no way to conveniently break this unit down for storage between exercise sessions.  It's light and easy to move around, but a bit bulky if you're short on space.What I find inexplicable is the lack of printed exercise instructions included in the box.  No pictures or demonstrations except for the examples printed on the glossy box itself.  Instead, you're directed to a website for use instructions.  How many people are going to be doing crunches in their home office while they learn how to use this equipment, or worse yet, with an iPhone?  This seems like a major oversight of the manufacturer in order to cut costs.

There's a great deal to like about this product:  The ingredients list, for one, is spectacular.  I love the idea of combining both protein and greens (two things I can have trouble getting enough of in my diet) to jump-start my day.  The purity of this product appears to be up there with the best protein powders I've sampled.  The flavor is an appealingly mild vanilla that can be combined into smoothies without overpowering the mix.So, why just a 3-star rating, you ask?  Well, call me petty, immature, or weak, but this stuff LOOKS GROSS!  When stirred into water or milk, it's a grayish-greenish goo that resembles newborn diaper juice.  It doesn't smell bad, of course, but there is no way under Mother Earth's ionosphere that I'm getting my kids to drink it.  They gagged LOOKING at it.  I almost gagged but was able to chug-a-lug it eyes squished shut.  The texture isn't fantastic (thick, globular), but it's manageable, especially when used as an additive rather than a main course.  I could make some snide comment about anything that's this good for you is bound to be gross, right?  Well, I won't.To sum up, the ingredients are great, the flavor is nice, the texture is OK, the visuals are flat-out yucky.

I've got an iPhone 5c.  The spring-loaded adjustable caliper that holds the phone provides enough tension so the phone is always secure in the mount -- no worries about falling out.  There is stiff foam padding surrounding the contact surfaces so your phone won't get scratched.  The mount can be stretched wider to accomodate slightly larger phones as well.I would LOVE this product and give it 5 stars except that the piece that mounts to the vent is not nearly as grippy as the rest of the unit.  I find that I'm having to adjust the placement of the mount on my vent at least once on each commute.  It has yet to fully fall off the vent flap, but it's been darn close several times.  It's a minor annoyance, but one worth noting.This mount can provide you with an inexpensive, impermanent car mount for your cell phone.  Nothing fancy, just functional.

Easy to operate, fun to use.  The shell has adjustable straps that fit both a 5-year-old and a 12-year old.  Sprays are flung 20+ feet simply by pumping the handle similar to a pump action shot gun.  The shell holds about 2L of water, which will outlast most squirt guns.  It's easy to fill, too, so the kids won't have much difficulty doing it for themselves.  Surprisingly, I only noticed a few errant drips, not that you'll be using this thing indoors, but it's nice to know you won't be losing a great deal of water to leakage.Your little water ninja will soon be soaking all comers and having a great time.

For YEARS, I have struggled with fog on the inside of my car's windshield.  In Minnesota winters especially, it can take quite a while for warm air to start blowing to the point that one can see safely.  Countless times, I've found myself pulled over in my neighborhood waiting for my engine to warm and my windshield to defog.This little device (about the size of a portable pack of tissues) has made instantaneous improvement in my car cabin without the need for any sprays/chemicals.  It's as simple as you can imagine:  Wipe the inside of the windshield and internal fog goes away.  I've noticed that I will occasionally need to wipe the windshield a couple of times as the engine heats up to the point where the blowers can handle the job, but that sure beats sitting on the roadside for upwards of several minutes.The bottom line:  I feel safer already.

If you're looking for a well-equipped, consolidated emergency road kit for your vehicle, Bell has put together list of stuff for you.  As the three-star rating would indicate, it's OK; not terrible but also not great.  The supplies included are of very cheap quality (thus 104-pieces for the presented low, low price).  There's not much here that you'd buy individually, should you put this kit together yourself.  The tire inflator states it can fill 14" tires.  (That might work on a Mini-Cooper...)  The air pump did a servicible job on a bicyle tire but I can imagine it would take near forever (if ever) to fill a deflated car tire.  The blanket is exceptionally thin, as in just better than nothing...That's kind of how I feel about most of this kit.  It's better than nothing, but just.  You would do a great deal better by using the item list from the product description as a guide and going out to buy the items individually, thus creating your own kit.  At least that way, you'll be confident you're getting decent, functional products.

For full disclosure, I'm not a runner, but I'm on my feet all day and a good pair of shoes will determine how much I hate my life at the end of the day.  I've been wearing these shoes for around a month.  They have the most comfortable heel-strike of any shoe I can remember.  My heel feels totally cradled by this shoe.  The gel in the sole makes for an exceptionally comfortable walking experience without being "squishy".  I still feel well supported and stable.I'll probably be buying another pair of these shoes down the road.  Next time, though, I will order them a half-size smaller than my normal 13, as this pair seems to run just a wee bit on the large size.  (Maybe when I've got to break out my heavy winter socks, I'll feel a little more appropriately snug...  Could be a blessing in disguise!)I should also say, these shoes LOOK really cool.  I can hardly believe the number of compliments I've gotten.  I'm unused to the positive attention paid to my footwear.  For the price, these shoes are a really good value.

I love finding a bargain!This cable works every bit as well as the original Apple-brand cable both in data transfer and charging speeds.  It's a fraction of the cost.  Love it.  Thanks iXCC for producing an affordable alternative that's of good quality!

It's fun to find a true bargain.This battery charger works just as well as the original Canon charger we lost, but is a fraction of the cost.  Same battery charges just as well.  The battery slides in and out easily and is held securely in place while charging.  I don't think I could ask for more.  Thanks, STK, for providing a well-functioning and affordable alternative!

Well, now.  This is a surprise.Who would have thunk that this little dynamo would replace our Dyson ($300+) as the primary vacuum in the house?  No me, I assure you.  Stunningly, it has.  Is it BETTER than the Dyson?  Not on most measures, except possibly the most important ones:  User-friendliness and convenience.  Allow me to explain.First off, the design of this lightweight unit is so stunningly brilliant I can hardly believe I've never seen something like this before (though I'm willing to admit I may very well be a vacuuming idiot).  It's essentially a cordless hand-held vacuum (think "Dust Buster") that can be snapped into an upright attachment and used like a light-duty vacuum cleaner.  The spinning bristles draw their power from the hand-held core unit and they can be turned on and off with the flick of the thumb to make the unit safe for hardwood floors.  We've test-driven it on ours and the floors LOVE IT.  It glides around providing gentle suction (enough to pick up Cheerios, dust bunnies, hair, etc...).  When the spinner is turned back on, the unit does decent spot work on low pile carpets like berber or cut-berber.  (I don't have any plushes in the house, so am unable to give you a good report on that.  Sorry.)  It has a double-folding handle that makes it exceptionally maneuverable and it's light weight (approximately 8 pounds) means even the laziest of kids will have one less reason to complain.Speaking of vacuuming hair, this unit has the simplest, most-accessible way to remove and clean the spinning bristles.  There is simply one switch on the bottom that needs to be flipped and the spin brush comes right out for easy cleaning.  Additionally, the dirt catcher (while small) is clear (so you'll know when it's full) and very easy to empty.Make no mistake, this mighty mite will never replace a full-size vacuum.  The battery power is only good for about 20 minutes and the suction is nowhere near the rug-hickeys our Dyson applies.  When we need to do more than one room (or heaven forbid, the whole house), out comes the more muscular Dyson.  But if we've got a spot job (i.e.: we want to reach behind the toilet or do a quicker picker upper after a kid-related "activity") or want to do a quick run over the hardwood floors, the Bissell Bolt is getting the call.

Most expanding files I've worked with in the past have been of the paper/cardboard variety.  This plastic/mylar kit seems like a step in the right direction.  I was able to squeeze a bunch of papers in this thing quite nicely.  The 20+ dividers give you lots of flexibility in your organizational process and the whole structure is sturdy... with the exception of the lid.  This file system deserves a better lid.  It's wimpy and earns the loss of one star.

Have you got a curious little one eager to do "experiments" and "build stuff"?  This may be the perfect book for you.  Well designed and described projects will provide hours and hours of meaningful, productive, fun (and sneakily educational!) time together.Though the cover touts "Father-Daughter DIY Projects", adults and children of either gender will appreciate many of the fun activities included within.  Kids age 5 - 12 would seem to be this book's sweet spot, but there's some projects of more advanced difficulty that will appeal to those past the higher edges.  The projects are not so basic that you'll be able to complete everything with stuff lying around your home (unless you live in a General Store).  With varying difficultly, some tasks require no tools at all and at least one requires soldering.  With a little planning and the "ingredients list" included, you'll be primed and ready for some great fun.

This little chalkboard (the exact size of a standard piece of printer paper) has become a fun addition to our home, especially for our kids.  It's light (and therefore easy to hang), cute (the faux wood looks real enough), functional (with decent chalk will write easily and erase decently), and is fun (fill in your own fun idea here).  For the current price point, I can't imagine a better value.  My kids prefer this to the white/wipe boards we've had... AND no markers are required (a nice bonus for parents with mark-happy kiddos).I fully endorse this chalkboard, especially at its current price.

Tired of plain old butter and salt on your popcorn?  No, I'm not either.  Still, this variety pack of popcorn seasonings can really take your favorite movie time indulgence up a notch.  The flavors range from sweet (kettle corn) to savory (bacon cheddar) to spicy (cheesy jalapeno) and are all appealing in their own way.  Not quite sure why they included "butter" flavor... But butter lover, this is for you.There's something here to tempt many palates.  This variety pack will be huge hit with a group of friends -- everybody gets what they want.  The flavors are pretty true to life without any chemical aftertastes.  They're mild, too, meaning you'd really have to over dump the seasoning to ruin your popcorn.  The 0.9oz size initially seems really small, but we've been able to make it last.  The kids eat the nacho cheese flavor exclusively and we've seasoned at least 10 bowls with about half the container left.  The only flavor I had trouble with was the cheesy jalapeno.  For some odd reason it made me cough on two separate occasions.  Weird.  It's probably me.After our supply runs out, I'll definitely be buying either a bigger container of nacho cheese, or another variety pack just like this one.

I am not a poker player, nor do I watch it on ESPN.  (I don't know WHY it's on ESPN, but that's another essay for another day.)  My inexperienced state primed me for a fun maiden voyage into that 5-studded world.  Judging from other reviews, Mr. Whitehead's writing style seems a bit polarizing - you'll love him or leave him.  He meanders off topic into asides frequently and I can see how that would rub some the wrong way, but I found the diversions enjoyable for the most part.  I would have liked him to spend more time narrating his experiance at the World Series of Poker and a little less about his anhedonia.  Some might even argue this book isn't so much about poker as it is about the author simply experiencing something new.Mr. Whitehead is a talented writer.  His colorful prose and abstract way of expressing a thought can be both snarky and humorous even as he's describing his miserable state.  For a guy who supposedly suffers from anhedonia, he sure enjoys a bit of beef jerky.

These simply designed, appealing mugs are great for several celebratory occasions.  They work great for ice cream, soup, or a BIG OL' cup o' joe.  Consider your "normal" coffee cup is going to hold between 8 - 12 oz. of fluid.  Increase that by 50 - 120% and you'll get an idea of just how caffienated you can become!  (Just drink fast - the big mouth makes the liquids cool quickly.)They're both dishwasher and microwave safe, which is a HUGE usability bonus.  The colors are vivid and appealing.  Somehow, the cups aren't ridiculously heavy, just abit above average, making them easy to hold and enjoy.

When I received my first bottle of this product, I noticed that it was already expired.  (Heaven knows why I checked the expriation date... must be the nurse in me.)  I've never had that happen before with any vitamins/supplements.  So please be careful.  (Amazon replaced the bottle quickly, free of charge.)While I love the idea of having an all-in-one Essential Fatty Acid capsule (with the added benefits of CLA), I would recommend you consider buying these ingredients individually, if only for one primary reason:  One can have too much Omega-6 fatty acids.  A quick internet search will reveal the risks of too much Omega-6s, but we can summarize by saying that Omega-6s are pro-inflammation (while Omega-3s are anti-inflammatory).  Inflammatory diseases include heart disease, type 2 diabetes, inflammatory bowel illnesses, some autoimmune diseases, even some cancers.  A diet high in Omega-6s but low in Omega-3s will increase inflammation.  The Western diet is already high in Omega-6s (thus the prevelence of heart disease), so I have serious concerns about adding to it.The tabs have no fishy taste or aftertaste, which is a big bonus for any Omega-rich product.  I didn't know this product had Omega-6s in it, otherwise I would not have ordered it.  I can't bring myself to finish the bottle because of the concern stated above.Please do your research on Omega-6s and check the bottle's expiration date.  Take care.

Thinking it unwise to pound this many potato chips solo, I brought a few bags to work and asked for honest assessments.  The lowest rating I heard was an enthusiastic 7/10 stars with one key exception:  One guy rated them 1/10 stars, which I almost couldn't make out because of all the chips falling out of his mouth.  (He was insisting on further "research".)If you haven't had Kettle Brand chips before, they're cut thicker than typical potato chips, krinkle cut or otherwise.  They sit in that sweet spot where they feel substantial but are still easy to munch.  The sweet chili garlic spicing is perfectly named -- it's sweet without being sugary, got a little zippy spice (not as hot as Doritos chili chips), and just a hint of garlic.  If you like the idea of those tastes individually, just know the combination is fantastic.The only downside to these chips is how dangerous it is to open a bag if you're flying solo.  They have a way of disappearing quicker than expected.

I was so excited to get this product because I'm generally a fan of Irish Spring stuff anyway and how much more manly am I going to feel if I can scrub down with bits of lava in my soap?  That sounds like a recipe for awesome.Well...The first thing I noticed is that the typically appealing Irish Spring scent is missing, replaced with something faintly reminiscent of Elmer's glue.  Interestingly enough, it actually has the initial consistency of Elmer's as well, minus the stickyness.  It's gooey.  It's weird.  Can't imagine spending a day all gluey.  Thankfully (and much to its credit), it rinses away flawlessly.How about those lava flecks?  Well, they're in there.  That's about as much as you can say about them.  There's not enough abrasive material to feel as though you're getting any sort of exfoliation help, even when using bare hands, which you probably won't be.  Most body wash users utilize some sort of loofa, sponge, or washcloth, all of which will be more abrasive than itsy-bitsy pellets included here.  It's sort of pointless rather than cool.  That makes me sad.Two-stars for a body wash that cleans decently but smells funny and misses the expectations mark.

We've tried a wide variety of gummy multivitamins with the family and these are the best tasting gummies we've found, sugar-free or not.  The fruity flavors are very appealing, not "mediciny" tasting.  It's not a chore to get our kids to chomp these down.  (Having Mickey Mouse on the label doesn't hurt, either.)  The content is a nice, middle-of-the-road multivitamin that tastes good and is easy to chew and swallow.  Bet a number of adults might get a kick out of these as well!

The last decade has seen a significant number of books written with the goal of attempting to reconcile contemporary science and the Torah. This is far from a new phenomenon and it in fact goes back to medieval times. Perhaps its greatest proponent was Gersonides (1288-1344), also known as Ralbag (Rabbi Levi ben Gershon).In Gersonides: Judaism within the Limits of Reason (Littman 978-1906764784), author Seymour Feldman (former professor of philosophy at Rutgers University) has written an enticing overview of the life and thought of one of the greatest and most daring; if not most controversial medieval Jewish philosophers. Like his predecessor Maimonides, Gersonides attempted to reconcile the philosophy of Aristotle with traditional Jewish thought.In truth, I think it’s unfair to use the term controversial, as often is done when referring to the views of Gersonides, as the term carries with it negative connotations. While his philosophical views may be in the minority, and not universally accepted; as one of the greatest philosophers of his time, his views must be considered.But unlike Maimonides, Gersonides wrote very few letters and as such, details of his life are scant. Besides a very brief bibliographical overview, Feldman spends all his efforts understanding the man and his worldview.Feldman writes that unlike many modern scientists or philosophers who either scorn religion or compartmentalize it; Gersonides did not see any fundamental discrepancy between the pursuit of truth via reason, and its attainment through divine revelation. Understanding that there has to be but one divine truth, Gersonides felt it was an imperative that reason and divine revelation must be able to be harmonized.Reason was something Gersonides took quite seriously. In fact, he saw reason and logic as a divine gift. With that, he felt it was essential that God had to be, and must be understood within the limits of reason.Tertullian's notion that credo quia absurdum (I believe because it is absurd) would be an anathema to Gersonides. As a polymath in addition to being an accomplished astronomer, Feldman writes that the study of astronomy and other natural sciences according to Gersonides, were fundamental and prerequisite requirement for the ascent to metaphysics. The reason for this was that Gersonides felt that the whole of nature, even our own bodies, displays the handiwork of the Lord.In a dense 10 chapters, the book provides the reader with a detailed summary of Gersonides’ worldview in areas such as the Bible, creation, Divine knowledge and omnipotence, prophecy and more.Gersonides has a number of contentious opinions, and none of it greater than his approach to divine omniscience. Most Jewish philosophers felt that there was complete divine omniscience, of which human free will was simply a perplexing part of. Gersonides took the radical approach and felt that while God knows in advance what choices are available to a person; God in fact does not know what choice the individual will ultimately take.Gersonides methodology was in part to try to reconcile Aristotle with traditional Jewish philosophy. On this topic, Feldman spends a chapter and writes in detail how Gersonides was almost universally rejected for this approach as detailed in his magnum opus on philosophy Milhamot Ha-Shem (The War of the Lord). One of his opponents mocked it by calling it “Wars against the Lord”. Such mocking was grievous, given the six questions Gersonides was dealing with are fundamental to Judaism; and relevant to this very day.The book also discusses other non-traditional approaches Gersonides had, including minimizing the notion of miracles, and the approach that a person’s soul is not immortal, rather it’s their intellect that is.Gersonides didn’t create a formal system of thought, such as Maimonides did in Moreh Nevukhim (The Guide for the Perplexed). And like Maimonides, there are many ways to interpret Gersonides, to which Feldman provides a superb overview of all of Gersonides core ideas.Feldman shows how many of Gersonides’ doctrines were not traditional. Not being bothered by that, Gersonides never shied away from drawing the logical conclusion from what he considered to be the true philosophical premise.As interesting as he is provocative, Gersonides: Judaism within the Limits of Reason provides the reader with a comprehensive look at one of the most formidable Jewish philosophers.

It wasn’t that long ago that building a full network security test lab was a highly expensive endeavor.  In The Network Security Test Lab: A Step-by-Step Guide, author Michael Gregg has written a helpful hands-on guide to provide the reader with an economical method to do that. The book is a step-by-step guide on how to create a security network lab, and how to use some of the most popular security and hacking tools.The book is a straightforward guide that will help the reader in their quest to master the art of effective use of security and hacking tools. The reader that can put in the time and plow through the slightly over 400 pages will certainly come out with a strong understanding of how to run the most common set of popular security tools.The book is written for the reader on the budget. In the introduction, Gregg writes how one can easily find inexpensive networking equipment at budget prices on eBay. While brand new hardware devices can cost in the thousands; one can find Cisco Catalyst switches, and Nokia IP and Check Point firewalls for under $50. Combined with his emphasis on open source software and tools, this is a most practical reference for those looking to increase their security skills without breaking the bank.The book is meant for the reader with a strong technical background looking to gain experience with network security and related security tools. Other similar books will often waste paper and the reader’s time by devoting the first 50 to 100 pages with unwanted introductory text. This book hits the ground running and by page 100, the reader is already analyzing network packets with Wireshark.The following are the books 11 chapters, which cover the entire range of network security and tools:1. Building a Hardware and Software Test Platform2. Passive Information Gathering3. Analyzing Network Traffic4. Detecting Live Systems and Analyzing Results5. Enumerating Systems6. Automating Encryption and Tunneling Techniques7. Automated Attack and Penetration Tools8. Securing Wireless Systems9. An Introduction to Malware10. Detecting Intrusions and Analyzing Malware11. Forensic DetectionThe book provides a good balance of coverage between Windows and Linux, and details the use of the many tools for each operating system. Each chapter ends with a series of exercises which can be used to help the reader put the information covered into practice. Those looking to gain experience on a wide variety of tools will enjoy the book. It covers a wide-range of tools and utilities.Network Security Test Lab: is in the same genre as books such as Hacking Exposed 7: Network Security Secrets and Solutions. The difference is that Hacking Exposed focuses more on the tools, while this book shows the reader how to build a lab to mimic a real world environment.
