It comes with three different sized buds so you can get a great fit. there s a wing on the bud that holds it in place and blocks out extra sounds. The inline volume control is nice, but I think it is too far up. I would have liked it lower for easier access. I definitely recommend these for comfortable, high quality listening pleasure.

This took about 20 minutes to put together. You will need a Phillips head screwdriver and a drill. There are no holes in the bottom panel and you have to drill 4 Wood screws through it. It's is sturdy and even has adjustable feet. I put it by my front door. The top is great for displaying items. I'm not using the wine glass holders on the underside, instead I use the shelves for my bar set and other booze bottles.  Makes a great mini bar. Love it.

Great user friendly cuff to monitor blood pressure. It fits comfortably on the wrist. It starts working when your arm is in proper position. It inflates quietly and quickly. The results are quickly transferred to your phone for record keeping. Even without the wireless feature it's a great cuff.

This is a great kit for facial care.  I love the smell of the green tea. The wipes are great for cleaning in moisturizing your face.  I sometimes use the wipes to clean my face and do not use any cleanser or moisturizer. They work beautifully.  I have never had any problems with breakouts or oily or dry skin using this set.  Natural and healthy ingredients. It would make a great gift for someone you love.

Convenient single serving packages. It's spam. It's gross yet delicious. It's going to have high sodium levels, it's processed meat. It's addictive. I fry mine in coconut oil and season it with garlic and onion. Once fried, I toss it on a toasted gluten free English muffin with mustard and an over easy egg. Sometimes I use ketchup (see pic). To die for!

I was hoping for positive results like most people had from this supplement. I took it for 3 weeks. I noticed improvement as far as adrenal fatigue symptoms. I was thrilled at first but, this gave me large, painful breast lumps. This was only supplement I had been taking over the last month. No other prescriptions or supplements. I had to stop taking this. I'm guessing the lumps were from the soy lecithin, a phytoestrogen. I switched to a soy free brand from Gaia. Be careful if you choose to take this supplement.

So much better than my solo brand iPad mini cover. This folio is very sturdy and has a nice texture to grip. It has 5 different viewing angles. The iPad mini fits snugly inside. There is a great rubber like edging that comes over the top of the screen to prevent a break if it is dropped on the screen. Highly recommend paying extra for a better folio.

This slow cooker is so cute. It is perfect for 2-3 people. The crock is removable for easy clean up. The glass lid fits well and makes it easy to see what is inside. The only reason I took away one star was because this does;t have a timer. I know this is not a top of the line model, but the timer is so helpful, especially if this is cooking while you are away for an extended period of time. Still love this slow cooker.

I have other Ahava products that seem to moisturize better than this. It didn't seem to make my skin feel super hydrated. It went on smoothly.  Minimal scent. This doesn't have a lot of the unhealthy ingredients found in other lotions. For the price you can find better. This is a tiny sized bottle.

The nipples mimic breastfeeding so there isnt any problem returning back to breastfeeding. The bottles prevent excessive gas with the vented bottom. Easy to hold while feeding. Larger size for older babies.
The nipples mimic breastfeeding so there isnt any problem returning back to breastfeeding. The bottles prevent excessive gas. Easy to hold while feeding.
These are like the large tote, longer and shorter. These are not shopping bags. Too much of a hassle to return.

I'm a converted apple girl, so I wasn't sure how much I would like this laptop or going back to Windows OS. Well, I like this laptop, almost more than my MacBook Pro. This is so easy to use. I just plugged it in, turned it on and followed the set up prompts. It took me about ten minutes to get the laptop up and running. I was pleased with the quality of the display and the sound. The laptop itself feels solid/sturdy, yet it is lightweight. The keys have a very nice texture and feel to them. The pad controller takes some getting used to. Be sure not to rest your hand on it or the cursor will disappear. I haven't plugged any devices into the laptop yet and might not. The processing speed and e great. Very fast response. I don't have any real complaints as of now. Overall, easy to use, functional laptop.General highlights:Sharp lookingLightweight15.6 inch true color displayWirelessBacklit keyboard1 year warrantyRechargeable/replaceable batteryBluetooth1 ethernet port3 USB ports1 headphone jack1 HDMI port1 SD Micro portIntel i7 - 5500 processorWindows 8.1 (free upgrade to Windows 10)GeForce Video Card4 GB DDR38 GB Memory
This is sturdy without being heavy like stoneware. The color is vibrant. The best part is the minimal indentations around the bowl that make holding it easy and comfortable.

I was hoping this would be more of a guideline or instructional type book. It isn't. It is mostly the author telling her story of how she got into radio, got her dream job and then quit without a plan. Leaving corporate America is inspiring in itself. Even though it isn't really a guide book, it is worth a read if you are considering a career change or quitting your job.

Very convenient and absorbable method to get your omega fatty acids. It's is a large dose for the small amount of liquid. It tastes like a dreamsicle. I'm not a fan of dreamsicle so I didn't like the flavor. I didn't try it in anything yet. This might be good mixed into orange juice or oatmeal. I'm hoping they come out with other flavors. I'd be willing to try them.

This is 100% pure essential oil with no fillers or additives. It smells as good as my Young Living peppermint essential oil. I used it on the dog (and myself) to repel bugs. It works very well. Highly recommend.

I believe that this book represents the "coming of age", if you will, of this series. Ms Hunter can write, can write action, snarky humor and good plots. But Broken Soul starts to take the reader ever deeper into Jane's world and the hidden  history of the vampires.To quickly sum up, Jane is hired by MOC of New Orleans to review and tighten up the security of his new headquarters because the European Council is expected, but no actual date is set. As Jane, with her "Crew" go about looking into things, they discover that Leo has a very dark secret hidden away in the sub-basement of his new facility. It is a presence so monstrous and so dangerous that it threatens everyone and everything in Jane's life.Rather than try to summarize the entire book, let me instead tell you that what makes this volume stand out is the way Faith Hunter takes us into the back stories of several major characters, including Jane herself. There is also the undefined new status of Bruiser, with a potential for romance that Jane had never considered seriously.The book ends in a way that, while gratifying, leaves the reader yearning for the next volume moreso than any of the previous volumes. Must read for fans of the series and please don't try to start with this book; it will make little sense to you.

This book is actually two stories told side by side. It is a compelling account of human endurance and perseverance, during 1942, and again in 2012. It is an amazing tale of a plane lost over Greenland in 1942, the crash of a B-17 during the search for it and the search for and recovery of some would-be rescuers who were lost in the ice and snow as part of the ground search in the days following the original crash.Some of the members of the 2012 search team had been part of finding one of a squadron of P-38s lost over Greenland during the war. This is a story of courage, of faith and of honor. The stories told by those who survived and were rescued tell of extraordinary endurance and will, both on the part of the survivors and those looking for them, some of whom lost their lives during that search.The story of the searchers and their mission in 2012 shows just how far our technology has come, and how limited it still is in the face of the treacherous and unpredictable weather that makes up modern Greenland. Again, bravery and tenacity hold the modern day searchers to their task, despite the odds being against them.It's not a spoiler to say that they do eventually find the plane for which they were searching, but it recounts the ingenuity they needed to make their search and their high-tech tools work for them.This book is as compelling as any adventure novel and has the added touch of it being a true story and the superior writing skills of Mitchell Zuckoff.Very highly recommended.

I wrote about my attraction to this fascinating book in my review of the first volume. At the age of 12 or so I was fascinated, even obsessed with how this war had happened, especially since it effected my father so profoundly.I became fascinated with WWII and how it happened and how did this one diminutive man almost achieve world domination? I read so many books on WWII but never had the chance to read things from the German side. This book is the 2nd of two volumes of interviews with soldiers who were on the German front during D Day. The actual interviewer was the father of the man who edited these books.He did an excellent job. If you are a student of history, this is a must. They say the history books are written by the victors, but this book and its companion volume present a compelling view of what it was like to suddenly see this enormous armada coming onto the beach, to hear of the terror that offshore shelling by Allied battleships and cruisers unleashed for hours before and during the assault. Many of the interviewees are quite honest in how frightened and confused they were. In volume one, some even speak of what happened when they were captured and taken as prisoners. It turns out that many were sent to England and/or the United States, were treated very well, and some even stayed! In volume 2, the few who spoke of  being captured were not captured on D Day, but later in the war and say they were not treated very well. I have no reason to doubt them.No bones about it, as with the 1st volume this is not a book for the squeamish. There are very graphic descriptions of the damage done to humans and even animals as a result of the assault. There is also, from some, a begrudging admiration for the creativity and tenacity of the Allied forces. The interviews were conducted in 1954, and at that time, a small few of those interviewed still held that "only if" certain things had happened they would have repulsed the assault. I read this book and its companion volume very quickly. It is well organized and is not edited down to make it a "nice" read. This book is about the horror of combat, the confusion of war and the bravery of men on both sides The reader can almost hear the explosions, smell the cordite and sweat in the bunkers. Highest recommendation, but not for the squeamish.

What an absolutely fascinating book. I was born in 1950, and grew up in a world where people with German sounding names or who were of obvious Japanese descent were held in suspicion. I even remember when I was maybe seven, when a friend and I were playing with a toy metal tank. The turret came off and my friend's dad picked it up, saw that it was made from and inverted Maxwell House Coffee can and it said, "Made in Japan," and he threw it out! My friend's dad was a U.S. Marine who saw action at Guadalcanal during the war. We, my friend and I, had no idea what his dad was so upset about. I remember dating, later marrying a woman whose maiden name, which I won't disclose here, was discussed by my parents when I first met her. Her family had said they were Swiss, but my parents were sure they just didn't want it known that they were probably of German descent. Crazy!But it served to create in me a fascination with WWII and how it happened and how did this one diminutive man almost achieve world domination? I read so many books on WWII but never had the chance to read things from the German side. This book is the first of two volumes of interviews with soldiers who were on the German front during D Day. The actual interviewer was the father of the man who edited these books.He did an excellent job. If you are a student of history, this is a must. They say the history books are written by the victors, but this book and its companion volume present a compelling view of what it was like to suddenly see this enormous armada coming onto the beach, to hear of the terror that offshore shelling by Allied battleships and cruisers unleashed for hours before and during the assault. Many of the interviewees are quite honest in how frightened and confused they were. In volume one, some even speak of what happened when they were captured and taken as prisoners. It turns out that many were sent to England and/or the United States, were treated very well, and some even stayed!No bones about it, this is not a book for the squeamish. There are very graphic descriptions of the damage done to humans and even animals as a result of the assault. There is also, from some, a begrudging admiration for the creativity and tenacity of the Allied forces. I read this book and its companion volume very quickly. It is well organized and is not edited down to make it a "nice" read. This book is about the horror of combat, the confusion of war and the bravery of men on both sides The reader can almost hear the explosions, smell the cordite and sweat in the bunkers. Highest recommendation, but not for the squeamish.

This is a wonderful collection of four short works from the world of Jane Yellowrock. What makes it worth reading is the variety of points of view in the various tales. We have a story, "We Sa," which is told from Jane's Beast's point of view. She does this sort of thing in her novels, but this takes the reader way back in Jane's history and is a great addition to her back story. Then we have, "Haints," which is told from the point of view of  Jane's best friend, Molly Everhart Trueblood. It is a great way to see how Jane is seen by another person. The last two works are from Jane's perspective. One, "Signatures of the Dead was published previously in the anthology, "Strange Brew." Good story. Finally is a short work, "Cajun with Fangs," which takes place right after the end of "Raven Cursed," and is a sort of lead-in to "Death's Rival." As Ms Hunter says in her forward, "(It was) a blast." There is also a healthy chunk of the beginning of "Death's Rival" that serves to fatten the book, but fans of the series are going to read the novel in its entirety anyhow, so, the final bit is something of a waste, which is why I only gave it four stars. Recommended for obsessive fans of the series (like me).

I believe that this trilogy by Ransom Riggs will be considered a classic for the foreseeable future. This third book, which seems to be a finale, is, in my opinion, as close to perfect as a final book in a great trilogy can be. While I believe this is meant to be in the YA demographic, it is a story for all ages. I'm 65 and read it with the same excitement that held me when I was 8 or 9 and reading The Hardy Boys, and Tom Swift, Jr & Sr. Actually, I'd have to say I was enraptured because I have so much life experience now that to thrill me like this series has takes a lot. I'm almost immune to horror, and only a few sci fi writers really grab me anymore with their originality. There are few authors now from whom I can't wait their next publication.If you haven't read the first two books, you must do so in order to fully appreciate how masterful this finale is. It is unpredictable, filled with suspense, very honorable characters, duplicitous characters, very scary creatures and a conclusion I in no way saw coming. I had my ideas, but I was both flabbergasted and pleased with how this series concludes.Mr. Riggs has created such a unique collection of characters, that I believe he may be living in the wrong time. His trilogy brings to mind L. Frank Baum, Poe, Lovecraft, the Brothers Grimm, Hans Christian Anderson and many other authors of great and memorable fairy tales. Of course this series requires suspension of disbelief, but Riggs writes so well, the reader may pause to wonder if maybe this is all possible. The story spans several generations, includes alternate realities, time travel, magic and wonder. It is a story of growing young love, familial discord, misplaced trust and trustworthiness where one would least expect to find it.I am  not going to try to summarize this plot; I'm just not that good of a reviewer and can't imagine including spoilers if I tried. I will say Riggs will make you laugh, shake in your boots, feel the sort of hatred that Americans felt toward Nazis, and bespell you with the power of love and the power of growing into belief in oneself.I've already preordered the box set for both my children to read and share with their children. The story is unforgettable in the same way that Tolkien's best know works are. It really stays with you. I give this trilogy my highest recommendation and hope you will open  your heart to what is, in the end, a story of the power of love.

I just discovered Cathy Lemons recently, and I know this album dates back to 1998, but is is a great record, if a little uneven. This is real Texas style blues and every song is well done. One exception is "Goodmorning Little Schoolboy," which transliterated for Kathy to sing, just comes across as a bit lame. Ms Lemons' voice is clear and crisp. There are several guest artists on the album, none of whom I have actually heard on their own, so that's one limitation in my appreciation. Overall, the album is excellent. The question that hangs in the air is why have we not heard from her again until her very recent release, "Black Crow," which is an excellent album. If you like blues, women singing the blues and excellent musical back-up, this CD is worth picking up.

Every now and then, I pick up another CD by Gabrielle Roth & The Mirrors. I have always been thrilled with what I find and "Still Chillin'" is no exception. While she may vary tempos, styles, instruments and overall feel, the result is always rewarding. If you have never "Trance Danced," this is a great CD with which to start. The first track, "Descending", is very slow paced and allows you to just let the sounds penetrate you and to just move slowly in whatever way you feel moved to do so. The next track, "Shavasana," is longer, and of a similar tempo, but with chanting included. That's another freedom you have, you can make whatever sounds you wish, or just lose yourself in the vocal sounds that are recorded. The third track, "Stephanie's Song," is a bit more uptempo and creates a sort of sound cocoon around you as you listen and/or dance. Finally comes the title track, which is nearly 30 minutes long. If you just relax and listen and move, it will take you places inside yourself where you may  never have been before. This is "soul" music of the spiritual sort. Just listen and move or don't, but it will move you. Using headphones is very highly recommended, since they cut off exterior sounds which may distract you. You can also blindfold yourself, if you have an open safe space in which to move. No matter what, you can't go wrong with this CD. Highest recommendation!

I admit to being slow to warm to this series. There is no question that Ms Wilks is a masterful writer. I must admit that, at times, I have to go back and reread some of the previous pages to fully understanding what is going on at a given point in the book. I have no doubt, this is the best book of the series so far. The reader gets to know Cullen Seabourne and Cynna Weaver, usually more peripheral characters, both of whom have talents that are quite magical. Seaborne is not only a werewolf, but a powerful sorcerer as well. He and Cynna are at the beginning phase of acceptance that they are having a child.Cynna is a Finder, one of the most powerful ever known. She also works for the FBI. Lily Yu, the more senior of the FBI agents and the usual protagonist in the previous stories, is left behind by some interference in a ritual that will take her, Cynna, Seaborne, and several other characters to a magical realm, one that has only two phases, Night Season, which lasts half of the year and Day Season, which lasts the other half of the year.The mishap puts Lily Yu out of the picture, sends several characters to the wrong place and sends Weaver and Seaborne, along with a gnome, to the realm which is in Night Season, but not in the place they intended to be. The gnome has sought out Cynna because of her reputation as a Finder, and wants her to find a Sacred Medallion, which has been lost. Only the right person can wear it and thus rule the realm, anyone else will slowly go insane.The book's pace steadily quickens and intensifies until it reaches a denouement that I can't believe any reader sees coming. Highly recommended, but you must read the first three books in the series or you will be hopelessly lost in trying to grok this volume.

It's kind of hard to have a book as raw and frank about the horrors of war to be rated as, "I loved it." But this book by Wolfgang Faust deserves five stars. Why, because it is honest and it offers a perspective rarely seen, since, as it is said, "the history books are written by the victors." In this volume the reader is taken inside one of the last German tanks to make it through the Russian lines on the Eastern side of the Elbe, as it and a small cadre of other Germans, knowing they have lost the war they started, try to flee West, to cross the Elbe, where they will surrender to the Americans.Reader be warned, this is not a book for the young or squeamish. Faust tells things as he saw them and what he thought about them. He somehow maintains a sense of humanity and decency as his ramshackle cadre rush for their lives. He tries to save those civilians he can, but knows he must also be ruthless in his goal of making it through the Russian lines.There is brutality on a scale that exceeds any of the modern gore fest horror novels, in that what is described is real and the writing is so good, the reader feels the claustrophobia of being inside the Panther, the horrible smells, the sweat and fear that permeates the tiny crew compartment of this fighting machine.I recommend this book highly, because it may just introduce some to the true horror of war, no matter what side the writer is on.

As I read the other reviews I see that I belong to the side that felt the book fell short of what it could have been. I found it unnecessarily complex and confusing at times. The promise is there, and I will read the second book, but I am not expecting much at this point. I'll let you know.

I took a long time reading this excellent book by Frank MacEowen. I did so because I had been studying shamanism for a while and what is most predominant here in the U.S. is some form of "native American" shamanism. I studied that and found it beautiful but something about it did not feel right. My ethnicity is mostly Celtic and when I started to explore in that direction, I knew I had found my roots. I won't bore you with the rituals I did that made this evident to me, but I will tell  you that if you are looking for a spiritual path, then the work of Frank MacEowen is a very good place to start.This book is very thoughtful, very well tied together in the way it mixes myth, memory, tradition and ritual to bring about a sense of belonging in the world and a sense of the importance of developing oneself as a spiritual being. Highest recommendation. Take your time with it.

I couldn't agree more with the Amazon review submitted by Deborah Wiley. I had not read Wilks' work in a while and I was somewhat lost until I checked back on my highlights from the previous two novels in the series. I agree with Ms Wiley, by no means attempt to pick up on the series here. In some ways, this could be considered the third book in a trilogy that serves to open the series. There is no questioning Ms Wilks' skill at character development, plot and action writing. This is a great book, but I do think she could have smoothed out some of the rough edges as even those familiar with the series may find themselves a bit confused at times.Given that, this is still a superb read that holds so much promise for the continuation of the series.

As others have said, John Scalzi can't write a bad book or short story. This is a fast moving, thought provoking bit of speculative science fiction involving the unexpected behavior of the computer/robot on a Federation battleship. It opens up so much room for contemplating AI and what we just might get ourselves into without intending to do so. It also offers the hope that AI may well save us from ourselves. Great short read as only Scalzi can do it.

Read the summaries that are on the page for this book on Amazon. I can add little other than that, unlike some, who find some of the characters and situations improbable, I found this to be the best book of the three and an excellent wrap-up of the trilogy. Suspension of disbelief is required of readers in this genre and I did not find mine tested at all. The characters are wonderful, fascinating, confused, irritating, frightening and everything in between. I admit that the warrior for hope who lives within me was thrilled that Kress developed characters who saw that peace won out. She is one of our living Masters and this is another masterpiece to stand beside the "Beggars in Spain" trilogy.Excellent read, highest recommendation, so long as you read the first two books; if you don't, you'll be hopelessly lost as to the significance of the actions of various characters.

What can I say? If you have heard the Trance/Dance music of Gabrielle Roth and the Mirrors before then this album will come as no surprise. If this is your first exposure, then you are in for a treat. This is another gorgeous collection of musical pieces intended for listening while meditating or to be used as dance music. If you let go and just move however you feel, you can become entranced. As a shaman, I have danced for hours to her various albums and find that doing so moves/alters my ordinary conscious state to one of being open to unseen wonders in myself and the world around us. It is important to listen to her music with what I call "New Ears", wherein your body becomes the ears by which the music enters you and invites you to move and experience something you may have not thought possible, or even considered possible.If  you find you like this, I would recommend her album Totem as your next purchase.This music is not for everyone, but if you are looking for something of a new experience, facilitated by music, then Gabrielle Roth and the Mirrors will give you that experience. Very highly recommended.

It seems to me, that, as a rule, second books in a trilogy are a way of setting up what should  be a grand finale. This book is a bit more than that, in that it develops the characters and culture of the Worlders, who planet the Terrans have found by means of old, but far advanced scientific artifacts left behind by what would seem to be a now extinct race. The Terrans have returned and the intent is to take one of the moons that is, in fact, an artifact left behind by the ancient race. Perhaps it could be a weapon to help turn the tide of the ongoing war with the Fallers. Not everyone of the Terrans on the mission know that some of them are there for military reasons, while the others are just continuing their study of the geology, the flora and fauna, and the culture of the Worlders. The Worlders are, by current Terran standards, a very simple race, lacking in any real technology. They do share a collective mind, however, and things are declared real or unreal, by agreement of the collectives. Through  her work interacting with the Terrans, one Worlder, Enli, finds herself declared "unreal" by her villagers.She struggles with this as opposed to keeping her belief in the Terrans activities and seeing how real their technology is and suffers for siding with them. She wants her status returned to real and is torn by how to do it.Meanwhile, the Terrans have been exploring the Sacred Mountain, and Enli has seen what is inside. The source of the shared mind is, in fact, an artifact buried in the heart of the mountain, which the Terrans test by changing the settings and discovering that it can be a powerful weapon. One consequence, however, is the the Worlders lose their shared mind and are completely lost without it. Some go mad, some become aimless and Enli, because of her experience with the Terrans, keeps her own mind intact. Meanwhile, the Terrans now know that the "moon" artefact" is, indeed an incredibly powerful weapon, which they decide to steal.With great skill, Kress has created a world, a culture and a belief system that is genius. She easily demonstrates the manner in which the "sophisticated" Terrans can manipulate the, to them, the naive Worlders. Her characters are wonderful and the way she combines the well-meaning intent of the Terrans who are unaware of the military aspect of the mission and the ongoing story of war in space makes this a great read. It is far above what I usually expect from a second book in a trilogy.

I have read all of the Aneka Jansen series to date and have just loved it. I find Teasdale knows he's writing for adults and can be a bit heavy-handed when it comes to sex, but I found that was not the case in this first volume of the Ultrahumans series. I found this an exciting delight. Yes, it begins with an ugly duckling turned swan story, in an alternate, post-apocalyptic Earth. Some humans become Ultra human and have special powers depending upon their personalities. Some turn to crime; others register as crime fighters. Cygnus, our ugly duckling turned swan, seems to have unlimited powers and is only beginning to understand them. She joins forces with another Ultra, known as "Twilight," and they become an unstoppable team. There are two major crime syndicates in the city of New Millennium, MD. It is sort of the new New York. One uses Ultras and has a dark secret, the other is the more traditional mobster type and doesn't use Ultras, in fact, hates them and wants to destroy them. I can't say more other than the this book focuses most on Cygnus and her development and escapes from dilemmas and starts to familiarize the reader with this alternate reality and its occupants. The plot is good  and there is a nice cliffhanger ending setting up book 2 quite well.Unlike some reviewers, I find Teasdale to be fun, good enough to hold my interest tightly and full of enough  humor that the reader knows that they are on Teasdale's latest roller coaster ride, and I like his rides very much great summer reading or wait till there are at least three volumes, and set aside for a wintery weekend indoors. Recommended highly.

I love the work of Nancy Kress. She is, in my mind, a grand master of hard science blended with realistic speculation in the sci-fi genre. This first volume in the trilogy finds a very worn out and war-weary earth suddenly discovering a stargate through which they can reach out and colonize more planets than ever before. Earth is at war with the only other species, the Fallers, known to be capable of interplanetary travel. The Fallers are ruthless, never negotiate and take no prisoners. They are winning. When Earthers send their first probe through the gate, it sends back information suggesting a very earthlike planet with several moons.The first manned ship to travel to the new planet discovers a very unique civilization in which the residents are of one mind and when that mind is in full conformity, something is declared "real". If an individual does not fall into complete agreement, they are considered "unreal" until they rejoin the collective mind, they are again declared real.The earthlings,  with their separate minds, are considered unreal until a few show that they can be considered real.Of course, the mission has a hidden military agenda, which sends some of the crew into the depths of the most sacred mountain, where they have traced an unusual signal. It turns out this this non-native artifact is the source of the one mind of the inhabitants. It also possesses indicators that one of moons of the planet is actually a much larger version of the artifact and has the potential for use as a very powerful weapon in the war with the Fallers.Needless to say, the off-worlders are condemned ultimately as unreal and end up fleeing the planet to save themselves. Some choose to stay behind and continue the work they believed they were sent there to do, anthropology, botany and zoology.The use of the stargate system, also built by those who built the artifact on the planet  and the false moon, is complicated and I will not try to summarize it here. Let's just say that Nancy Kress works her special magic to get this trilogy off to a grand start.

Yep, just like it says, it is the best. As in my other reviews of Oz Naturals, when compared with much more expensive serums, this product comes out ahead. I have gotten so many compliments on how fresh and  young my facial skin looks (I'm 65) since I started using this product. It does what is meant to do and is very easy on the wallet as compared to much more expensive Hyaluronic Serums. You won't regret switching if you are not already using it.

Skin care with quality products is essential, not just to satisfy our youth obsessed culture (your reviewer is 65) but it is a vital part of self care no matter what your age. I found this product to be exactly as advertised. It moisturizes, gives skin a healthy glow and can be used pretty much anywhere on the body. I personally like Oz Naturals products because of quality and reasonable price.I admit I have tried some very expensive products of a similar intent and none could exceed this much less expensive product.One caveat I would offer is this stuff goes a LONG way. You don't need much and I recommend you start with very small dollops and seeing how far they go on your particular skin. This product is a great bargain, in my opinion.Very highly recommended.

I only give this four stars because the production is crap and has been cleaned up as much as possible. I admit I have loved John Mayall from this era since I first head the first blues breakers album featuring Eric Clapton, which I bought because I had to know what could draw him away from the Yardbirds, just as they were breaking big in the U.S.The appeal of this album is the presence of what would become the core of the REAL Fleetwood Mac. So many people would never guess to whom they were listening if they heard the early Fleetwood Mac because they were a serious blues band, witness "Fleetwood Mac in Chicago." All water under the bridge.This album shows a really great band going through the early staples of the Bluesbreakers setlist. What is frustrating is you can hear McVie, and then you can't. Mayall's voice is in and out. Even Fleetwood doesn't always come through. But the album is worth it for Green's playing. It is strange to hear him playing some of the songs associated with Clapton, but Green excels and Clapton's absence is not noticed at all.I have to say this album is for hard core fans of that early British Blues era of the sixties. It you are a Green or Mayall die hard,  then it is a must-have.

This will be a short review. This album has been in my current playlist since it was released. Why? Because I so love Anette Olzon's voice so much, I could listen to her sing the phone book. While differing in some degree to her work with previous goth/speed metal bands, this is classic Anette.She sings with sincerity and beauty and devotion. I can't pick a favorite track, because I just love the whole thing. This is a great album, in my estimation.It is not just for Anette's fans from previous days, this is an album for music lovers. Get it.

I have loved Sirenia from the first moment I heard them, which, to my chagrin was only about a year ago. Some may not like this album for various reasons. For me, it is among their best, if not their best. Their is the usual expected complexity of arrangements both instrumental and vocals as expected from groups in this genre.What makes it so good to me is that is is more of a group album than any of their previous efforts. What I mean is that there is no over-dependence on the lead female vocalist. She's there and has her spots, but for the most part, this is a gorgeous ensemble effort. You may not agree, but so be it. No matter what, if you are a Sirenia fan, this belongs in your collection. If this is your introduction to Sirenia, you'll be getting a great album, but realize that it is not typical of their previous work.Highest Recommendation

I just got this recording this morning. Rarely am I just blown away on a first listen. After the third listen, I knew this was the best work these two old veterans of the music wars have done in years. While it is a trend lately to do duet albums, either with one other artist and many are quite good (I'm thinking Emmy Lou Harris, Tony Bennett, etc.) this  is by far the best. If this album is not nominated in next year's parade of awards shows, something is REALLY wrong in the world, or, the boys put it so well in the second track on the record, "It All Going to Pot." Of course, given their reputations, this song is both socially accurate, but the double entendre is not lost on anyone who are fans of these two.The album begins with the title track and it is a magnificent tribute to their roots, to those who came before and inspired them. You can just hear the prestige and respect in which they hold all the "old timers" they mention in the song.The album offers a beautiful simplicity of instrumentation and arrangements. This is so very evident on "Unfair Weather Friend," a song that had to come from the mind of Willie.The homage to Johnny Cash, "Missing Old Johnny Cash," is truly that, a true honoring of the memory of the man who was a legend. It begins with Merle (my guess) sounding so much like Johnny, I thought it was really Johnny. They hint that while they tell amusing anecdotes of Johnny's life, they let on that there is much more to be told."Live This Long" is an admission that they would have lived a bit differently if they had known they were going to live as long as they have. How they sing so clearly with their tongues stuck that deep in their cheeks, I'll never know.The only solo effort on the album is Willie's "Somewhere Between" and is a classic Willie ballad about love between two people wherein something unknown comes between. It is a beautiful song.The album ends with a tribute to "The Only Man Wilder Than Me." They never reveal about whom they are singing which is a delightful way to end the album and leave the listeners with something to ponder, considering who is singing...This album is a must, in my book, no matter what genre. It's my current holder of the first spot on the second quarter's list of my nominations for Album of the Year.

My dermatologist told me that I needed to exfoliate at least two times a week. She recommended this product and I admit I love it. It is very easy to use, very gentle on my face, and after a couple of weeks I can see a real difference in my facial skin. People have even been commenting and asking what I am doing differently. I am happy to tell them about the Konjac Sponge. This is, in my opinion, a great product, available for a very reasonable price. Get one for yourself and you will see a difference. Note that it can take up to four weeks to completely exfoliate facial skin. The difference is wonderful and you can see and feel it for yourself. Highest Recommendation.

Full disclosure: I was sent this  item free from the manufacturer in exchange for an honest interview. I think this product is superb. The light is bright on low or  high setting. At this time of year in Vermont, we get a lot of sunshine, so the charge lasts well into the night. It is somewhat dull by sunrise. I do wonder how it will be in the Winter, when many days are cloudy and the sun does not shine for long. We shall see. However, for now my wife and I love it and use it to light up a part of the yard where, unfortunately we have found evidence of kids hanging out and leaving their refuse behind. This has stopped since the area is now well illuminated. We are very happy about this. This is an excellent product, very easy to install and use. It is a  sort of "set it and forget it" kind of thing.Why four stars and not five? I don't know if my product was missing a piece, but I have found no indications that it is. The problem is that once the stake is fixed in the ground, the light just sits loosely on the post, and even a strong wind can turn it. It could be easily stolen if someone checked it. There is just no way to secure it to  the post. Other than that, this is a GREAT product.

This review was solicited by the seller. I found this case to be quite a surprise.  It is rugged, durable and flexible on the inside. It can be used for cards from any non-video games that use cards. I also found it was snug enough to hold the playing pieces for games like Trivial Pursuit in addition to the cards. It zips up quite securely and even has a convenient carabiner to allow you to attach it to your belt or anything else, which is very convenient in my opinion.When I say it is rugged, I mean it. I decided since I had received it in exchange for an honest review that I would do some extra testing. I filled it with cards and board pieces and zipped it up and then tossed it around and opened it to find that very few of the cards and none of the pieces had left the compartment in which I had placed them. Did I say rugged? I also stood on it (I weigh 170 lbs.) and it showed no damage. I then stood on it again, in stilettos, and still it showed no damage! I think this is a great case at a great price. Highest recommendation.

I have a rather small office with hardwood floors. This item fits into the space perfectly and provides great protection and ease of movement of my chair. It's one of those little things that just make my office feel so much better to me, yet could easily be taken for granted.

For Gallagher fans, this is a must have CD. I don't care that it is spread over 2CDs and the price is a bit high. This is a very special event made available on CD. Why a special event? Because it demonstrates without doubt that RG was among the best, if not THE BEST blues/rock/folk guitarists ever. Hendrix, at the Isle of Wight declared him to be the best in the world. Clapton said that it was listening to RG that got him to go back to playing the blues. The Edge and Brian may have said that their respective bands would not have existed and sounded as they did had Rory not been so kind to them at various club gigs in London.This is special because it just another typical RG performance. His forte was playing live. This may be the best live recording of him playing live available on CD, with the exception, of course, of the six volume "Irish Tour '74" compilation. I would not want to have to choose between them for which one is the best. I must add that, in my opinion, THE BEST live recordings of Rory playing live are on Disc 3 of the 3 disc Rockpalast DVD, also available from Amazon.As I understand it, this was recorded during his American tour promoting his "Top Priority" album, which is, in itself, excellent. What you hear on this recording is Rory giving his all, thrilling the crowd with high energy. It could have been just another gig that many artists would have "mailed in." Rory covers some songs, such as "Keychain" from the "Top Priority" album, and, for me, he gives what was a relatively typical studio performance of one of his songs new meaning with his explosive live performance. What continues to amaze me, the more I hear of his live performances is how he manages to offer new arrangements and solos on some his old favorites, such as "Tattoo'd Lady" and "I Wonder Who?" and his classic favorite show ender, "Bullfrog Blues". He manages to keep his cover of Junior Well's "Messin' With The Kid," sounding bright and fresh.As usual he shows  his amazing versatility by doing both acoustic numbers and even covers, "Too Much Alcohol" with an amazing demonstration of his skill with slide playing on his ancient National Steel Guitar. I still mourn his early death and believe that if such circumstances had killed him today, there would be an uproar over poor care. So be it. At least with have great CDs like this one to keep us remembering just what a musician and musicologist he was. Be honest: have YOU ever heard of the Mississippi Sheiks before Rory sang about them? Get this album and be amazed by what RG could and did do on "just another night."
Another favorite author off my must buy list. I did not see Ménage coming with this author at all.  RETURNED
Awful! Lasted 3 weeks and I copy 50 pages a week. Today I am replacing this disappointing purchase with the more expensive one I usually buy.

4.5 stars as the beginning is a little off and doesn't really get going until the main characters are together.  Keep going; it's worth it.I can see where the similarities are made with this one to The Black Dagger Brotherhood as there is a group of royal vampires that have to fight other half-breeds who can’t play nice.  There are the Vampirian houses: Reihn, Cyphre, Korvinos Amaleh and Daemonov all represented by a glyph (tattoo) on their necks or face. Then there are the enemies, the Vampisapiens Houses: Remonai, Mazor, Lukjin, Federov and Zeigen.  There is a reference glossary in the back which you will need to fully understand the story.The best parts of this story and the major parts are when Vampirian King Xander and Elena are together.  Xander is alpha and sexy while Eleina is confused, but strong.  Xander has been waiting for his green-eyed mate for centuries but is falling in love with the blue eyed beauty he is bound to protect until her conversion.  His fellow warrior buddies love Eleina and tell him to forget about his mate, but he can only have children with his mate and his kingdom needs him to carry on the royal line.Eleina is human, but it sought after by the Vampisapiens.  The Fates have assigned Xander to protect from them since she has no family.There is descriptive sex, some profanity and some chapters devoted to the evil ones trying to kidnap Eleina, just like BDBH style, only I skip the ones in BDBH because they are so awful, but I read these.I will be getting the next book which is about Lucien and Samanda called My Dark Beauty, then later, My Dark Angel about Reichen and Angel.Would I/Did I buy it?  Yes 1.99Would I read it again? MaybeWould I recommend it to friends? Yes

This one was much better than book 2, in my opinion, with a better love story, no interrupted sex scenes, and a heroine who doesn’t do anything too stupid.  There are some “pushing it” plot points like Grace temporarily taking over Frog’s place in the band as a guitarist when she hasn’t played since high school, surviving a collision in a corvette and Kelli’s 10 year angry disappearance, but overall, it was a great love story.Grace became a model at 14 years of age to help her dad pay for her deceased mother’s medical bills.  She left the family to help pay for expenses including her siblings schooling, but they felt she had abandoned them, not knowing her sacrifice.  When Henry calls her to help out the band, she immediately says yes, having the need for family and escaping her hectic life as a model.Casey and Travis are asked to pick her up, and there is a misunderstanding about drugs that leads to Casey and Grace getting up in each other’s faces.  Both are very attracted to the other physically, but they both open their mouths and ruin it.  Grace is feisty and not intimidated by Casey’s looks and personality and he is thrown by how attracted to her he is, which is bad timing as he is trying to romance another girl named Morgan to get information on his parents deaths.  He is using Morgan, but she is persistent and tries to interfere with his growing desires for Grace.Grace’s boyfriend is history after cheating on her and she just wants to spend her weeks playing with her brother’s band and getting to spend time with her brother.  Henry warns her to stay away from Casey, but they end up having a secret affair, agreeing to “walk away” after Grace’s 8 weeks are up.  But then their lives start becoming endangered and Casey’s protective instincts start taking over.There is not much of the band in this one or any real storylines that include anyone other than Casey and Grace and the “bad guys”.  It is much more of a romance and has a lot more descriptive sex and dirty talk than the previous ones, which I liked.  While it is a very lengthy book, I read every page and enjoyed every minute of it.The next book looks like it will finally be about Mac and whoever she ends up choosing.  It used to always be Jake, but Luke and one other guy are now in the picture……I highly recommend this story for those who love a good romance and love story.  There were descriptive sex scenes and some profanity (f-word, gd, sh**t,).Would I/Did I buy it? Yes (2.99)Would I read it again?  YesWould I recommend it to friends? Yes

This one felt like we finally have come full circle.  Jenna and Leander are main characters in this one along with Jaqueline (Jack) and Hawk.  Seeing Jenna in dragon form was reminiscent of book one and Brazil brought a lot of the former main characters together to fight.Hawk and Jack’s love story is comical in that she thinks Hawk is a birthday present from her single best friend, and Jack spends a sex filled night with him; no strings attached.  He is actually on assignment to ruin Jack’s journalist reputation after she single-handedly got the prejudicial laws against the Shifters passed by the President and was nominated for the Pulitzer Price to boot.  When the Shifter colony decides to expose her to their way of life instead, and have her write a new story that takes back all the bigoted thoughts in the first one, they send Hawk to go fetch her.  He was already feeling a strange tug towards her during their one night stand, and feared he was losing himself by wanting to be with her.Jack thought she was being patriotic and protective when she wrote her scathing piece on the Shifters, but she soon learns she did not have the whole story.  Caesar was not the Shifter’s King nor was he acting with their consensus.  He was a loonie who represented the Shifters as accurately as Hitler represents humanity.  After experiencing time with Hawk in his colony she discovered that their ways and customs were different, but that in every way that counted, the Shifters and the humans were the same.  She also fell in love with Hawk.Caesar is still alive.  He is like Jason from those horror movies.  He just won’t die.  I skip his chapters because he is just evil, but he finds the Brazil colony and Jenna and Leander along with their 4month old twin daughters are there along with a prophecy of doom.  There are great secondary characters and characters from other books like Xander and his wife Morgan. Christian is not there.There is A LOT that happens in this book, but I really only read this series for the love stories.  That is why I read anything, so I tend to skim the political and evil parts.  The epilogue is a little foreboding and I am hoping for a miracle.  The battles are always built up more than they ever turn out to be, and I am hoping this is the case here too.Some good quotes:Those who can make you believe absurdities can make you commit atrocities – VoltaireFear becomes a part of you, like a tumor that can never be cut out – JackLove can be painful, sometimes cruel, but regret will devour you, bite by bite, until there’s nothing left at all. If love is a tyrant, regret is a soul-eating demon. - JennaJ.T. Geissinger always has a political message or idea she want to argue in her books, this book is not different.  While in E of D book 4 the message was of homosexual discrimination and cystic fibrosis awareness, this one consisted of: the different sexual standards Women are held to as opposed to men, USA’s unethical treatment of animals for consumption, mental illness, bigotry, rape, and that “’Hope’ is the single most powerful forced in the universe. More powerful, even, than ‘love’” (that one was an interesting argument).  She definitely uses her books to influence the readers to think and explore new ideas.Descriptive sex scenes and lots of profanity (f-word, Gd Jesus Christ a lot).Would I/Did I buy it? No, Prime MembershipWould I read/listen to it again?  Probably NotWould I recommend it to friends? Yes, fans of the series.

I would read Maggie Stiefvater's grocery list - I am sure it is brilliant.  This girl can really write, and I just sit amazed as I read captivating characters and descriptive inner dialogue.  It is amazing!Cole has come to LA because Isabel is there and he wants to take his musical life back.  He agrees to be on a reality show, which makes Isabel doubt she is the reason for his return to LA.  Their relationship is just as bumpy in LA as it was before, but they both have really interesting people in their lives which makes for some great reality TV and self-discoveries."Jeremy" The only problem with you on a reality show is that reality's never been your strong point.""Leon" - `My driver's eyelids were halfhearted tents pitched over his red eyes.  He was a dismal inhabitant of a suit unhappy to house him'."Sofia" `She was a year younger than me and lived in breathless fear of failure, time passing, and her mother falling out of love with her.  She also adored me for no reason I could discern. There were plenty of other people more worthy of her adulation'."Isabel's mother", `My mother had dressed herself in contempt. Not her best look, but better than tears'.While Cole is going through learning to live as Cole St. Claire again, Isabel is living with her mother, aunt and insecure cousin in The House of Divorce and Separation or The House of Dismay and Ruin."The truth was that fame was an inconsistent friend, never there when you needed it, ever-present when you needed some time away from it"."Ugly has hurt some things. It's just that pretty hurts more"."It pissed me off when people called common sense a magical power.  Because if it counted, I was the most magical creature I knew".I was a little disappointed with how little time Isabel and Cole spent together.  It is kind of hard to imagine them friends, let alone lovers, when they never say two words to each other.  What is it that keeps them together?  A shared secret?  Isabel had so many trust issues that the ending was a little too quick and out of character. Maggie Stiefvater's writing is like strong lyrics to an emotional song.  She gives all she has as she paints an emotional picture that relays all the information you could possibly want about the scene.  Her words make you feel the story with the intensity of being there - experiencing it as it unfolds.  She is truly talented at painting a story - not just telling it and the colors she uses are intense and perfect. Her writing is so poignant - poetic.This is classic Maggie Stiefvater writing that is exquisite and emotional.  You will not be disappointed with Sinner!Would I/Did I buy it? YesWould I read it again? YesWould I recommend it to friends? Yes

Finally, Geissinger has written a Night Prowler novel that did not aggravate me to tears with the tedious descriptions and she also used a normal amount of metaphors. While I really like the storyline of the Night Prowler Series, this author has been too descriptive and used so many metaphors and descriptive adjectives that would get in the way of the story being told.  Her writing is beautifully descriptive and tedious if that even makes sense.  But, this one was different.  I didn’t eve skim.So FINALLY Christian’s story!  I have been waiting since book 1 and have finally been rewarded.  He has fallen in love with a somewhat plain book store owner named September who is quite damaged herself.  She is all alone in the world since her father’s death of a heart attack three years ago.  She has been told of other world creatures by her mother, “Elsething” but thought they were fairy tales until Christian swoops into her life.  The have a VERY bumpy courtship and she does NOT handle any situation very well.  Basically she FREAKS out A LOT. (Personally, I was hoping for someone a little less dramatic for him, but she is likeable).  Christian is in Spain on a suicide mission for his brother and the Ikati – to root out Caesar and to kill him; even though Caesar is now, basically immortal.As always, the enemy was headed by a TOTAL CREEP, this one was named Caesar and let’s just say I skipped the chapters when this guy and Thirteen or Jahad, were narrating. Caesar is still wanting world dominion and is the truly damaged guy with his penchant for torturing beautiful girls and killing them.  Thirteen hunts the Ikati and Jahad is the religious nut that is an albino who was treated badly by Catholic school boys and whose own sexual desires are really disgusting.“Life is cruel in the same way people are. Casually. Randomly. Indifferently. Sometimes I wonder how anyone survives at all.Ultimately, we don’t.”I forgot, and got the audible, but wish I hadn’t as the narrator, Angela Dawe is awful and ruins the story even more with her awful intonations.  I ended up just reading it myself and enjoyed the story SO MUCH MORE.Descriptive sex scenes and language (f-word, Gd Jesus Christ a lot). Homosexual defense and history of descrimination,  Abuse, bestiality, sadismWould I/Did I buy it? Yes (1.99) plus audible for $1.99Would I read/listen to it again?  MaybeWould I recommend it to friends? Yes

The Distance Between Us is just as superbly written and a definite favorite in my house, so when On The Fence came out, I preordered it.  Skye from “Distance” makes a few cameo appearances in this one and it was great to see her again.  Kasie West’s books are YA with no profanity, some non-descriptive kissing but no sex.  The main characters are fantastic and the romance is so sweet.Charlie, a girl, is 16 and lives with her three older brothers and her policeman father.  Her mother died when she was 6 in a car accident.  The boy next door, Braden is like a brother and is best friends with Gage, the brother closest to Charlie in age and confidence.  Charlie is a TOMBOY who is excellent at soccer and football and whose brothers adore her and include her in everything.  When she gets one too many speeding tickets and frustrates her dad, he makes her get a job and a transformation happens in her life.  She starts meeting girl figures that make her question who she is.  Her boss is a motherly, new age type named Linda who can read her “auras” and understand what and how she is feeling.  She meets a make-up artist, Amber who uses her as a model and introduces her to feminine living and she meets Evan a boy who doesn’t know her as a tomboy and who seems to really like her – or at least the girlie girl she has become when working at Linda’s store.  But Charlie is also having nightmares and intimate talks with her brother’s best friend Braden at the fence most nights and is starting to feel confused and scared.Secrets have been kept from Charlie and in the midst of them unraveling, she is living in two realities: Charlie as the tomboy and Charlie as the pretty girl on the sidelines.  She wants to be accepted, but does she want to change completely?  Does she have to?  Can she embrace some of the changes and not others?  Who is she really and who does everyone want her to be and why can’t she remember anything about her mother?I love Kasie West’s writing style and her clean YA books.  All the girls (4 daughters) in my family fight for their turn with Kasie West books and reread them many times.  I will be reading more from her in the future.  If you haven’t read Pivot Point and Split Second, you need to.Would I/Did I buy it? Yes, totally worth it!Would I read it again?  YesWould I recommend it to friends? Yes

This is for the romance reader who likes a lot of sex; I mean A LOT of sex. I recently read another book that was similar to this one's style by Alexis Anne called The Storm Inside. It also had a sex scene every other page that gets a little tedious after a while.  I did enjoy the actual story to this one and was reminded of Consumed (Consumed Series Book 1) by Skyla Madi, only this book was A LOT better than that one. A LOT!!!!In the first chapter, Lexi is cheated on by her boyfriend and best friend, her twin brother dies, and the step brother, Ryder she has always had a crush on, rescues her from drowning, and then leaves.  3 years later, her step-father, David, asks Ryder to watch over her while he and her mother take a trip.  Those 6 days together finally bind them together and flesh out all the anger and abandoned feelings they have held.David, Ryder's dad, left his mother to marry Lexi's mother. His deep feelings of betrayal by his father and his mother's sadness and bitterness, turned him against his father for years and pushed Lexi and her twin brother out of his life.  After saving Lexi he became obsessed with trying to stay away from her, not wanting anything to do with his father, still and not wanting to hurt his mother.  But when Lexi comes to stay with him as he is training for his MMA fights, he can't keep his hands off her and she seems to want him too.There's jealousy, manipulations, people conspiring against them, but love is triumphant and it is great for the fictional romance reader.  I really liked it! (There was too much sex, though.  Yes, that can happen!)Lots (too much) of descriptive sex, oral sex and profanity (f-word)Would I/Did I buy it?  Yes (.99)Would I read it again? YesWould I recommend it to friends?

Okay, honestly, I enjoyed reading this story, but mostly because I liked this author’s writing style, not that she writes realistically instead of romantically.  For those of us who like a hero that never touches another woman after finding “the one”, this story is a disappointment.  Byron and London share a fantastic sexual encounter, but continues to have meaningless sex with other girls afterwards, making sure that London can hear.  London is obsessed about her overweight body and the reader constantly reads about her expansive behind and thighs, which is a mood killer during the sex scenes.  I am not kidding, the reader is CONSTANTLY reminded that she is not thin.  All other aspects of her personality are very strong, not embracing her body doesn’t make sense.  And finally, London’s best friend is the fantastic gay guy whose sexual conquests are almost on par with Byron’s.London doesn’t want to live at home for her sophomore year at UCLA and convinces manwhore Byron to give her a two month probation as his roommate.  He discovers she is unlike other girls he’s known and starts to fall for her.  London is convinced that Byron could never want her after being rejected by her last boyfriend, a guy who had a girlfriend and used her.  She talks like a guy, and refuses to throw the type of drama girls normally go through with guys.  Her best gay friend, Macon is her lifeline and he calls her “baby” and is ALWAYS there when she needs him.  He is also very wise about love.So the whole book is the miscommunication between Byron and London as they try to fight their feelings for each other while everyone around them knows they are perfect for each other and that they should just wake up.  The ending is quick and disappointing as none of London’s fears are put to rest, she just follows her heart.  Maybe there will be a book 2 that tells us if it works out.If you are looking for a romantic love story, this isn’t it.  It is also hard to read about Byron’s many sexual escapades while London is in the apartment having to listen to it all.  While realistic, most romance readers like to keep their fictional goggles on and never see the hero with anyone other than the heroine.  Actual manwhores are not swoon worthy and girls that pine after a guy who will do other girls are doormats.  It was an addictive read for .99, but it was not a satisfying love story, in that I would read it again.  If you like realism more than fiction, this will delight you.  If the other way around, it will leave you sad.Some hot descriptive sex, profanity (f-word)Would I/Did I buy it?  Yes (.99)Would I read it again? Probably notWould I recommend it to friends? Sure

With the Band is all about bass player Sam and his first love, Peyton.  All the books are written from the girl's point of view and none of them are even in the band (anymore) just dating the members.  I love band love stories, and this one was just as fun as those you see inDocumentary,  Foolish Games (Book 1) (Foolish Games Series)Series, Rock the Band Series and Lick (A Stage Dive Novel) Series by Kylie Scott.Romeo and Riley are still going strong in this book as are Justin and Allie from book 2 and make some cameo appearances, but Sam and Peyton are worth the time and their love story is a long time in coming.  Sam has a twin brother named Seth who Peyton was beguiled by in high school and was his girlfriend for a time as he was the lead singer in a garage band with his brother.  Because of his charismatic personality, Seth was always busy and Peyton spent a lot of time with Sam with whom she has a lot more in common.  When Seth's behavior and jealousy became too much for Peyton to handle, she unwisely turns to Sam for a night and is caught by Seth.  He ruins her reputation for her senior year and Sam and Peyton become strangers - until college.There was a lot that happened that night that is later explained in the story, but in the meantime, Peyton and Sam, who have avoided each other for the last three years, are now thrust together on a six week band tour as Romeo has hired her to do the publicity.  She has to travel with the band in a tour bus for six weeks with a guy who supposedly can't stand her.  But this is Peyton's dream, to become a music journalist, so she is going to get through it no matter how awful Sam wants to treat her.This was a sweet love story with a three year hurt that is finally explained and ironed out.  It was great to see all the band members again and to see Gabe not being such a jerk.  Surprisingly, Justin and Allie are still going strong and he remains faithful to her on the tour.There was descriptive kissing and sex, some profanity and reference to drug use.  In the Band was a YA story and Ink My Heart and With the Band are NA, which made them a lot more interesting for me to read.While there is nothing new in this story than what is normally out there with band books/tattoo stories, I do like these characters and anyone who read In the Band, will enjoy being with everyone again.  The ONE BIG CHANGE I would make is new covers for this series.  All of them are AWFUL.Would I/Did I buy it? No Prime Membership FreebieWould I read it again? MaybeWould I recommend it to friends

A big THANK YOU for giving us a taste of the story WE WANTED after reading Just One Day!So, this "story" is only 43 pages but, in my opinion, is what the second book should have been about in the first place.  Willem and Allyson have FINALLY found each other again and can explain to each other what happened and what they feel."He looks at her. She looks at him. "I told you I would remember," Allyson says.Before he'd kissed her that night in the art squat, she had told him that she'd remember everything about their day in Paris. That she would remember him.Willem had made no such promises. But he can taste, touch, hear, and smell every last detail of that day together. "I remember, too," he says.Lulu and Willy are finally together and it is beautiful.  I smiled through this novella thinking how much I loved seeing them "finding" each other again and how romantic it was.  It reminded me of how I felt reading the last chapters of Where She Went.  I have read that chapter over and over and I will read this novella again and again. It is just that sweet.This was beautifully written and well worth the .99 just to get an ending.  Honestly, Gayle Forman should have made this a trilogy because reading about "Lulu" and "Willy" NEVER gets boring.Boy, do I feel sorry for those who bought the book already and don't have a Kindle.  They will never get the love story we were all craving after reading Just One Day!  I guess she could always add an epilogue in the second printings of Just One Year.There was some non-descriptive sex scenesWould I/Did I buy it? YesWould I read it again? Yes, it made me smile!Would I recommend it to friends? Definitely

Okay, I will admit that book 2 was A LOT better than book 1, Cold Iron and I would recommend it even if you haven’t read Cold Iron.  There is a lot of review in this one and I don’t really think you need book1 to follow this story.  There was decidedly more romance (i.e.: sexy scenes) in this one and the action and plot was better.Helene has been secretly used as a pawn by one of the “magic people” (would be a spoiler to tell you who) and is missing hours of her days.  She tries to phone Beth about it to ask for help, but is unable to tell her anything but small talk.  She knows something is wrong and decides she has to go to Miach, the sorcerer who has tried to seduce her, in order to free herself from the compulsions she is feeling.  Miach is thrilled to have her back in his life (he made a bond with Beth that he would leave Helene alone) and since Helene came to him, he is able to help her.Miach’s life has become difficult with training the little druid, Beth, dodging death attempts by his vengeful son, Brian and dealing with the 2000 year old grudge he has with Finn and Finn’s son Garrett who seduced Miach’s “daughter” Nieve and got her pregnant two years ago.  When he needs Finn’s help to save Helene from a memory eating tattoo, he has to bargain with Nieve’s safety and finds that he is willing to sacrifice a lot for Helene.  Helene has found that she too has forgiven him for his part in kidnapping her and her best friend, Beth and trying to kill Beth to save his people.  She has decided to give in to him and have an affair with a dangerous, devious Fae.  She hopes her heart can take it.There is a lot more sex in this one, danger, torture and darkness.  We get to see Beth and Conn, but they are quite harmless and not very helpful, so it is anti-climactic to be with them again (somewhat like their own story in book 1).  Miach and Helene had some real sparks and a questionable love affair that is in NO WAY as certain as Conn and Beth’s turned out to be.  There is a definite inkling that Helene will be heartbroken, despite being warned.I found this story to be much more interesting than book one, but still a little dry.  Yes, I skimmed some paragraphs, but someone more history minded would probably enjoy it more.  While there were more sex scenes in this one, they were still not very emotionally felt and somewhat unsatisfying for all the talk that the Fae are such awesome lovers.There was some descriptive sex and another suggested ménage scene that seems to be a theme in this series.  While neither heroine has participated in these descriptive encounters, the desire to do so is getting more aggressive.  Wouldn’t be surprised if the next one has a ménage encounter based on the author’s interest in writing about it.  It is unlikely that I will purchase the next in the series.Did I buy it? Yes Deal of the Day 1.99Would I listen to it again? Probably NotWould I recommend it? Sure

My Cow-Eyed Beauty???There is NEVER a time when “Cow-eyed beauty” is a compliment.  Every time Conn would call Beth this, I would cringe.  So NOT romantic!  I got this book and its sequel as a deal of the day ($1.99) and hoped they would live up to their description.  They were billed “For fans of Jeaniene Frost and Kresley Cole”, of which I am one, but this is NOTHING like Cat and Bones or the Mortals After Dark so, don’t read this thinking that is in ANY WAY true.  Really not even close, but if you give it a try on its own, it wasn’t horrible.Beth was married to a ninny of a man who took her artifact finding abilities and bot only profited from them, but claimed them as his own.  He had a nasty best friend who was in league with him and together they set Beth up and even drugged her.  After the latest discovery, Conn the Betrayer was released from his “mound” and was “taken” with Beth.  Following her back to the states in pursuit of her and his famous one-of-a-kind sword, The Summoner.  Conn and Beth fall in love, discover there is more to her than she knew (which explains why she can find the fae) and lose the sword to Frank, her ex-husband.  The sword can be used to bring back the evil Fae and must be found before the gates are opened.While the story was pretty entertaining, it was predictable and dragged in some spots.  The worst part about this book were the extremely quick and unfulfilling sex scenes. The product description says, “this full-length novel is the first in D.L. McDermott’s fast-paced, sexy paranormal romance series”, but if you are reading this because you thought it was a paranormal ROMANCE, forget it.  The love scenes are maybe a paragraph and if you look away too quickly, you missed it.  I wasn’t even sure either of them was even satisfied as something else is quickly going on in the next paragraph.  All around, a real “quickie”.Most reviewers have mentioned they liked the second book better, so I will give it a try and hope that just knowing the characters will make it more interesting.Did I buy it? Yes Deal of the Day 1.99Would I listen to it again? NoWould I recommend it? Sure

I am a fan of the Moreno brothers Series and have enjoyed SOME of the 5th Street books, but this one was really disappointing.  I was expecting so much more and characters that I could really like, unfortunately, Bethany, the damsel in distress, was a complete liar the entire time and Damian was her fool.  There was way too much describing of emotions and not showing and repetitive revelations of “this is going too fast, or I have never felt this way so quickly and I will reveal everything when it’s over.”So there is this great family, just like in Reyes’s previous books, that includes four hunky males and one beautiful female.  The males are all gorgeous and self-confident: one is a musician, one is on a reality show, one is a cop (Damian) and one lives in in New York and seems to be moody. They all have “D” names: Delfina, Damian, Diego, Dominic, and Dimitri and are all very wealthy, of course.  Damian is a cop, but has family money and good investments and he meets Bethany through a friend, Jerry and quickly falls in love.  His detective’s intuition tells him that Bethany is keeping something from him and he suspects another man, but she continually makes him feel like he is being too jealous and possessive and he fights against his suspicions.Bethany is on the run from something that happened in California that the reader has no idea about until the very end.  She has a younger sister and brother that are still there and she sends them money from the multiple jobs she has.  A guy named Max has her running scared and it is her ties to him that she is trying to keep secret from Damian.  But her lies about Max are not her only ones.  She lies about who she is on the phone with, when her rehearsals are, when she is with Simon, a guy who likes her and what her situation is.  When he is rightly suspicious, she makes him think it is all in his mind and that he is having a jealous tantrum, making him apologize and question his correct suspicions.  She justifies this with knowing she will eventually tell him the truth after she has taken care of it because she does not want to get him involved.  I just don’t like the way she made him look like a fool and question his own correct assumptions.Of course, there was a misunderstanding, bad decisions and a happily ever after, but after an entire book of lies, flat characters and too much and too fast "I love you's",  it just didn’t do it for me.So while I really like this author normally, this book was just not up to the great romances the other series have.  The writing was more telling than showing and the heroine was stupid.  I did like Damian and his brothers and hope their stories will be better than this one was.There is descriptive sex including oral.Would I/Did I buy it? YesWould I read it again?  NoWould I recommend it to friends?  The author, Yes, not this book

I was just going to sample this story, but found I couldn’t put it down and ended up reading it in a couple of hours. It was really delightful and left me with a smile on my face.Biggest Flirts is very similar in flavor to Major Crush in its YA themes and romance revolving around drummers in the school band. In some ways this book also reminded me of Catching Jordan by Miranda Kenneally, as the two main characters are competing for Drum Captain and Tia, the heroine refuses to have a boyfriend, preferring to have one night stands regardless of the reputation that implies.  She has a hook-up buddies in the local pot-head Sawyer, but no ties to anyone boy.Tia has good friends, a busy dad, and three sisters that messed up royally when it came to men.  Two were left knocked-up and one left high school to follow her bum down south.  Being the only one left at home, Tia is convinced she is an irresponsible girl who should never be put in charge of anything, so when she wins Drum captain, she tries to convince others to challenge her and take it away.  Hot, new boy, Will Matthews takes Tia’s breath away one night after a party and the next morning takes her Captainship away in a fair duel.  Tia is relieved and bothered.  She has never felt about a boy the way she feels about Will and has to fight her feelings while shamelessly flirting with him in band.Typical high school drama incurs and is fun, sweet, silly and a little dramatic to watch unfold to its predictable and very likable end.  I loved Will’s character, identified with Tia’s and enjoyed all the secondary characters of best friends.  I really didn’t think I would like this book as much as I did after being disappointed by Such a Rush and The One that I want by Jennifer Echols.This story has a lot of different themes it tries to address: the abandonment issues created when a mother cheats and leaves, learning to trust, be true to yourself, not changing for another, jealousy and first love.I have previously enjoyed Echols “Romantic Comedies” such as Ex-Games and “The Boys next door” but I also love her more intense romance novels Forget You, Love Story and especially Going Too Far.  I enjoyed Echols writing and romantic stories whether they are for mature readers or as in the case of this story, suited for the younger YA reader.
