There is no doubt that Jennifer Echols is a fantastic writer and I have enjoyed reading all of her books.  If you liked Major Crush, you will like this book too.There is kissing, some alcohol and weed use, talk of sex and promiscuity and some profanity (f-word, sh**t, gd).Would I/Did I buy it? YesWould I read it again? YesWould I recommend it to friends? Yes

So, I know this story is narrated from the main character, Mia’s point of view, but it is called “King’s” and he is the only REAL interesting character.  Mia is a foul-mouth, edgy woman who is not at all likeable because she is angry 70% of the book, whereas King, the true “villain” in this story, is mysterious, dark and TOO PATIENT WITH MIA!  Seriously, the reader wants to strangler her and tell her to stop her theatrics and stupidity, but King keeps her alive while killing others less offensive.Did you notice the title is the possessive of King?  That is because he claims people for payment. “I am the man who can find anything. And you are my Seer of Light. Let’s hope you stay alive longer than the last one.” – King to Mia.Mia’s archeologist brother has been “kidnapped” in Mexico and after depleting all her options, Mia enlists the help of “King” in exchange for being “owned” by him.  Their first encounter is at his empty office where he mistakes her for his evening paid escort.  She quickly and abrasively clears that up for him and continues to be a twit for most of the book.  EVERYONE fears King, (but not Mia) and those that belong to him are protected and respected.  Mia now belongs to him (despite her claims) and has entered a world where dreams and reality are hard to distinguish from each other.King perceives that Mia holds the power of “Seeing” and she finds that she can indeed “see” colors left from murders and objects.  Refusing to embrace her powers hinders King’s ability to find her brother and King’s true motivation, the Artifact that Mia’s brother, Justin has discovered and disappeared over.  She meets a string of seedy men//people while traveling with King and continues to exasperate King by disobeying him and blocking his ability to find Justin/Artifact.King is alluring, complicated, mysterious and dark – perhaps evil – you just don’t know.  He is always right and it is frustrating to watch Mia complicated and interfere with his plans.  King is sexy, sensual and more than he appears:  “Spells are for children’s fairytales. I acquire power, or more accurately stated, I obtain ways to channel it and use it to my advantage.” – King.“Was it really possible for ordinary people to acquire extraordinary powers, as King said he had? Was there more to the world than what one simply saw on the surface?” – MiaAnd that is the question.  How does King mysteriously disappear or appear out of thin air?  How is he able to “read” Mia’s mind or torture her inside her head?  Why does he keep her alive when she is so much trouble?  Just how old is he really?Mia is attracted to him and when her “visions” come over her she can’t help throwing herself at him.  I am hoping for less sexual teasing and more MORE in the next book.“You’ll be fine, he (King) said in that deep, deep voice that sounded like it had been cut from a blanket woven from thick dark chocolate and sin.” - MiaThere is nudity, crass conversations and harsh profanity (mostly from Mia).  While not really liking her, it is REALLY WELL WRITTEN and I will read book 2 for more King.  Hopefully, he won’t disappoint.Would I/Did I buy it? Yes (.99)Would I read it again?  YesWould I recommend it to friends? Yes

"He walks away, leaving me alone with the echoes of his words. Nothing means anything. Things just happen. I’m falling down a philosophical rabbit hole, where there’s nothing but tiny tea cakes and mysterious vials that say “drink me, I promise I’m not poison”.  - MeganSo, this one was hilarious too, but to be honest, I found myself cringing a bit and not enjoying SOME parts of it.  I guess I just liked the first one better.  Megan is much “rougher” than her sister, but her problem around guys is fairly common in today’s world and many will identify with her defensiveness.  Megan is too honest, too defensive, too insincere and too scared and she doesn’t know why she behaves the way she does and says the mean things she says.I don’t know what I want, or why I want what I want. Or why I don’t want what I don’t want. But I do know I need to take another shower”. MeganMegan met Drew at her self-help group that she is accidentally apart of.  She went in thinking it was a weight watchers group, but stayed after liking the people there.  Drew makes her babble and say sexually forward statements.  She is abrasive and “complicated” (another word for the b-word) but doesn’t totally put him off.  In fact, he seems to like her and returns the next week for more.  Drew is a little bit odd himself, but she can’t figure out why HE is coming to the self-help group or why he is able to handle her “truthfulness”.  In fact, she can’t seem to offend him enough to make him stay away, and that has her running scared.“He measures out the coffee grounds and water like he’s a high school chemistry teacher making crystal meth” – MeganDrew is a dentist (only a mortician would be less romantic in my opinion) and I have to say, while many might find the part funny/romantic when she calls him over for an "emergency visit", it was my least favorite part and where the "cringing" was involved. Just, ICK! Okay, moving on.....Luca was Sexier, Drew was more Sensitive which explains why I liked book 1 better.This one is funny and at the same time, kind of sad because Megan is messed up and self-sabotaging.  Tina and Luca are in this one a little and offer some great support and Rory is adorable with her eccentricities.  Can’t wait for the third book, which I hope is hers.I have discovered that Mimi Strong books are best read out loud to friends.  They are hilarious and are easily enjoyed while sipping wine and hanging with girlfriends who laugh and identify with Mimi’s characters.  She tells it like it is actually happening and sometimes it is AWKWARD.  Sex is not always “wonderful” and conversations get stilted.  That is what makes these books so hilarious.  YOU CAN IDENTIFY.Download the sample pages, because if you do, you are going to need the whole book.  That is what happened to me after I read some of this one at the end of book 1.  It is the witty dialogue and the best friends that sell me on Mimi Strong books.There is some descriptive sex (more “adventurous than book 1, but still not “Peaches” level).Would I/Did I buy it? Yes (2.99)Would I read it again?  Yes, out loud to my friendsWould I recommend it to friends? Yes

Fiction Goggles are used to enjoy romances that have “beautiful people”, “simultaneous orgasms” and “no awkward moments”.  They are not perfect relationships, but the virgin can have sex over and over the first time, and the man-whore never looks at another woman after he meets “the One”.  Don’t get me wrong, I love those stories and regularly adjust my fictional goggles as I plunge into these unrealistic romances because that is why I read – for Fiction.  But Mimi Strong has introduced me to another type of heroine that makes me laugh and identify and I love it.I have discovered that Mimi Strong books are best read out loud to friends.  They are hilarious and are easily enjoyed while sipping wine and hanging with girlfriends who laugh and identify with Mimi’s characters.  She tells it like it is actually happening and sometimes it is AWKWARD.  Sex is not always “wonderful” and conversations get stilted.  That is what makes these books so hilarious.  YOU CAN IDENTIFY.Tina is swooning over the new guy on the block, Luca Lowell.  They are not in high school; Tina is 29 and has not fully recovered from her high school sweetheart dying ten years ago.  She normally dates skinny geeks, when she does date, so that she can feel in control, but when Luca’s heavy boots walk in her florist shop and she sees his big hands, she has changed her plans.“My eyes go first to the boots. They’re big.Next, my eyes climb up his jeans. And what a climb it is, over long legs and muscled thighs. My pulse quickens. He’s wearing a black shirt with a bike logo, stretched tight across huge muscles.He turns his body sideways to squeeze past the ferns.Damn it, he’s perfection” – TinaTina’s best friend since high school can’t tolerate sexual words. “Rory isn’t like anyone else I know. She gets grossed out by any mention of sex, in conversation, or in books or movies. A single word can send her screaming from the room”.  TinaDownload the sample pages, because if you do, you are going to need the whole book.  That is what happened to me.  It’s cute, quick and sweet, but it is the witty dialogue and the best friends that sell me on Mimi Strong books.There is some descriptive sex (milder than Peaches series).  I have already downloaded book 2 “Complicated Girl” and if possible, have laughed even more.Would I/Did I buy it? Yes (2.99)Would I read it again?  YesWould I recommend it to friends? Yes

I was a fan of book one, but this one didn’t do it for me.  The main character, Jessica who we loved to hate in book one, practically stalked her ex-boyfriend Taylor the ENTIRE book begging him to tell her why he broke up with her their senior year in high school.  He had left her the minute he found out he had a full scholarship to Ohio State and after hooking up with her best friend Mallory there for a month, proceeded to hook up with every blond bimbo the school had.  We know from Guys are Props that Jessica was damaged by this unexpected break-up and that she slept around to numb the pain, so when Taylor FINALLY explains why he dumped her, it was NOT GOOD ENOUGH.Jessica was so manipulative in book one and so clinging in this book, that I never really did like her.  She did love Taylor even before he became a hottie which makes me mad at the excuse he gave her for the break-up.  College is known for being the Place kids “find” themselves in and Taylor was hoping Jessica would find who she was.  Unfortunately he was unwilling to wait or love her enough to go through that with her.  They both slept with a lot of people creating emptiness and really bad memories.  It is honestly just really sad and STUPID.So no, I didn’t enjoy this story even with its HEA.  It was a lot of angst for no good reason and a lot of very conditional love and a lot of betrayal.  There was no cameos from any of the characters in the previous book or any information on how they are doing.I enjoyed Seymour’s style and would read another book by her. There was some f-word and some pretty descriptive sex and the VERY end.Would I/Did I buy it? Yes (.99)Would I read it again?  NoWould I recommend it to friends? No

I got this and the first one for free and admit, that might have a lot to do with my 3 stars ratings. Had they cost me $4.99, I would be a lot harsher.I actually liked this one better than the first one, whose heroine dated two men at the same time and REALLY bugged me.  This one also had Ex Sands narrate it, but either I am getting used to her being the voice of the Laurel Heights novels, or she has gotten less annoying.  She still talks in the back of her throat, which bugs me, but I guess I just didn’t find it as annoying.This is a totally separate and standalone story, which is good since you don’t have to read book one to know what is going on.  Freya, from book one, is mentioned, but even Anna, (who I would have liked to know whether she and Max got together or not), is not even mentioned.  Where Angela’s best friend was Freya in book one, in this book it appears to be Olivia, the lingerie owner.These stories are predictable and formulaic, but entertaining and the love scenes are pretty hot.  They come with side-stories and remind me of Susan Mallory’s Fools Gold Series and Elizabeth Phillips Football Series.Descriptive sexWould I/Did I buy it? Yes Audible $1.99Would I read/listen to it again? MaybeWould I recommend it to friends? Sure

This one hits the ground running and never lets up.  Cecile is a young farm girl who is planning to join her mother in the city to sing on all the great stages.  Her 17 birthday is the turning point to start her new life, only it isn’t the life she was expecting or dreamed of.  On her way home to her party, she is kidnapped by a fellow neighbor, Luc and sold to the mythical Trolls who live under Forsaken Mountain.Always believing that Trolls were not real, Cecile is quickly made aware of her dangerous position when she meets the evil and obese King of Trollus and he tells her of her immediate nuptials to his son, Tristen.  The Trolls come in a variety of shapes and tempers.  There are the usual hideous creatures, deformed, and some in-between.  Since the purebloods have mated with humans, there are also some really attractive trolls too, and luckily, Tristen is one of these.There was a curse put on the Trolls by a Witch that prevents them from leaving the mountain.  The Countess had a vision that would break the curse and it involved the royal line mating with a human with red hair.  The countess is part of an odd creature, she is conjoined to her sister, the queen, and sprouts from the queen’s back so that she is constantly demanding the queen turn around so that she can see what is going on.  It is kind of funny.Cecile has red hair and her singing voice is breathtaking.  I have to stop here and say, that although this book is call “Stolen Songbird” Cecile’s singing play NO ROLE in book 1; I am guessing it will be important soon, but it is not singled out in this book at all making the name seem pointless.  But I digress, Cecile is kidnapped, bonded to Tristen and imprisoned in the cave the Trolls and half breeds call home.  She begins to make friends and comes to realize that not all Trolls are not the evil creatures traditions have said they were.  She also finds that not everything is what it seems in Trollus and that there is a revolution underway to undermine the evil King and that her Tristen might be part of it.All the characters in the story have French names which leads one to believe this might be based on a French fairy tale that those more knowledgeable about French Culture could confirm.  I thought it was similar to Beauty and the Beast with the beautiful maiden being held by a Monstrous society, but it was also very unique.This is part of a trilogy, so there wasn’t a complete ending or all the questions answered.  While I enjoyed the story, I would have liked more interaction between Tristen and Cecile to believe their love story.  While their bonding let them feel each other’s emotions, the reader was not as influence and their sudden love for each other was too shallow compared to Tristen’s deep friendship with the female Troll, Anais.  One could feel Tristen’s need to protect Cecile, but love? Not as easy to see.No profanity, some (very little!) kissing, no sex (teased, but no)Would I/Did I buy it? YesWould I read it again? Only for review when book 2 comes outWould I recommend it to friends? Yes, gave it to my daughters

One sex scene – One!  And Beth acted like a biotch afterwards and ruined it.  If you read for romance, this is not the book for you.  There were 6 “major” kisses that all happened at inappropriate times (looking for a kidnapped boy, oh, let’s make-out) and again, Beth was a Biotch when she got her body back under control.  Yeah, Beth was not a likeable character at all.  The seals were all likeable, except Mac and the story would have been good, if not for the VERY SLOW PACE.I hated this author’s style of writing!  There was WAY TOO MUCH inner dialogue from Beth and Zane and it was repetitive thoughts.  There was too much description (she describes a kitchen at one point, as if we don’t know what a kitchen looks like!) of rooms and mannerisms.  It was detailed as if it was a script for a movie (have Zane place hand on lower back and puts foot on car), not a story.  And the conversations! Kill me now; they took forever to unfold and were headed to such obvious conclusions.  Zane would say something, then go silent.  Cosky would ask if Zane meant “this”, then go silent.  Zane would continue and say, “Yes”.  Rawls would ask what that could mean, then go silent.  Cosky would make a guess; reader would have already known this answer.  Zane would act surprised and agree, then go silent. Rawls would move the dialogue along with an obvious conclusion.  Cosky would ask a question the reader could already figure out.  Zane would start to answer it, then go silent.  They would all look at each other.  Rawls would answer the question.  Reader would throw kindle.The story doesn’t end.  After enduring a bad romance, sluggish conversation and men dying, the story doesn’t end.  There is no wrap up except for Beth’s immediate change of heart towards Zane which, after all her whining throughout the book, you want to tell Zane to run (too bad their “soulmates”).  Zane is stuck going through morning sickness with her since they share a bond.  How gross is that?I got this and book 2 Forged in Ash as Amazon’s deal of the day and got the audibles to go with them for .99.  I paid too much.  The narrator, Angela Dawe was irritating to listen to and made Beth worse than she probably was.Descriptive sex and lots of profanity (f-word, Sh**t, GD JC)UPDATE:  I did enjoy Book 2, Forged in Ash, so if you can struggle through this one, book 2 is better.Would I/Did I buy it? Yes Kindle book and Audible VersionWould I read it again? NoWould I recommend it to friends? No

I was disappointed in Suzanne Wright’s Carnal Sins (which I returned for a refund) and was hesitant to get Taste of Torment, so I used my Prime Membership to get it free this month. I am so glad I did. In this book, Sam and Jared remind me of Bones and Cat from Jeanniene Frost’s Night Huntress Series. They are inseparably in love and fight well together against their foes while desiring each other’s bodies and minds forever.This volume was full of action and new characters. The Hollow is once again under attack with investigators Collins and Eloise making trouble for Sam, having to deal with a lethal case of The Call, and fighting off a dangerous invasion.Collins was Antonio’s first Turning and he is an arrogant rule-follower. He is jealous that he is not the Heir and has come to the Hollow with trump up charges that Sam is an unfit Commander and that she has had complaints against her. Eloise is a former one-night-stand of Jared’s and is determined to get a negative reaction out of Sam to include in their report. Two previous friends of Sam’s Cristiano and his sister Ava have arrived asking for help finding their missing vampires. Cristiano seems to have a “thing” for Sam which bothers Jared to no end and makes his alpha rise. They agree to help, but three of their team contract a plague called The Call which is lethal to all vampires. They must search to find a cure that has never been discovered before. And finally, Jared’s coronation to become the Grand High Master and Sam’s secret life as a hybrid is exposed to enemies who want to take over control of the vampires.While all this action is going on, Sam and Jared still find time to make love and adore each other. They are a fun couple to watch and listen to as they share their deepest feelings of love and fears. If you haven’t started this series, I recommend it. I love the tone this author uses for her writing. It is upbeat, sarcastic, intelligent and just plain fun to read. Alpha vampires, homosexual vampires, sexist vampires and really powerful and awful vampires. There was never a dull moment and the heroine Sam could really kick some butt. Definitely recommend!Some editing issues such as using stood instead of standing and other proof reading mistakes. There is plenty of profanity, but much of it is British (plonker, bugger, f-word son of a .. gd ) and some great descriptive sex.I really wish Suzanne Wright would have this made into an audio version!Would I/Did I buy it? Free with Prime MembershipWould I read it again? YesWould I recommend it to friends? Yes

Another SAD story!  I was not really a fan of Ruin, but stated in my review of it that I wouldn't mind a book about Gabe.  While I might have got my wish on this one, it was not the story I expected or, really, wanted.  Ruin was sad, but Toxic was worse and I really don't like to read sad books.  I also got to thinking how similar Kiersten and Weston's personalities were to Nat and Alec from "Tear" and Gabe and Saylor were replicas of Alyssa and Demetri from "PULL" - another story where you had to suspend belief.  And that just really says it all about this story - you will enjoy it if you can SUSPEND BELIEF for the duration of it.Gabe turns out to be a famous person that NO ONE has recognized in the last four years even though he uses his real driver's license to drink. He is also the best friend of one of the most popular and rich guys at school, but that notoriety has also never exposed him. Gabe accidentally harmed the love of his life when he was 17 and now takes care of her in a home.  He uses girls to "forget", but is in a "dry spell" since vowing to Wes not to keep hurting himself.  Gabe is very angry and is a totally different character from Ruin.Enter Saylor, the new girl in his life that changes everything - only the reader never sees this love really blossom, he just one day is totally in love with her.  The reader has spent half the book agonizingly falling in love with Kimmie, Gabe's first love that is now a paraplegic, and then has to transfer feelings to Saylor, someone who accepts Gabe's undying love, care and preference for Kimmie.  What we do know about Saylor is that she is an ANGEL since most girls would never be able to handle the last fourth of the book as wonderful as she did.I did not like that sadness.  It overshadowed the love story and the love story was between Gabe and a dying girl, not Gabe and Saylor.  2 star reviewer mommyofone really got the problems with this story.  I would have given it 2 stars too, but for .99 I just found Toxic to be Okay; I didn't hate it, but I wouldn't read it again.There was no descriptive sex (one scene at the end).  There was very little profanity (sh**T, damn,).  This is a YA rated book.VERY SIMILAR to Jake Undone (A Gemini Novel) by Penelope Ward and Changing Course (Wrecked and Ruined) by Ali MartinezWould I/Did I buy it? Yes (.99)Would I read it again?  NoWould I recommend it to friends? Yes, fans of Rachel need the whole story

Yes, this "novella", "serial" or "really Short Story" is fascinating and addicting, but is it worth $12.95 by the end of it?  I Don't Think So.  Someone needs to take a stand and say, Yes, you can write, but can your write an affordable WHOLE story?First book $.99 at 143 pagesBook 2 $2.99 at 102 pagesBook 3 $2.99 at 91 pagesBook 4 $2.99 at 141 pagesBook 5 $2.99 at 150 pagesTotal $12. 95 for 600 pagesOnly 57 of the first 255 reviews paid for their copy of Book #2 (198 got it FREE!)Only 20 of the first 131 reviews paid for their copy of Book #3.  (110 got it FREE!)That's a whole lot of people who got these books for FREE and left 5 star reviews.

“Be yourself, because everyone else is taken.  Fat or thin, be your wild, wonderful, unique self.” – Dottie Simpkins, Owner of Charm Classes.Let me just say that I would have HATED this book’s cliffhanger ending if I didn’t already have book 2!  Some cliffhangers are worse than others, and the ones that leave in the MIDDLE of a story are the worst!  This is the WORST!  So, that said, this is one of the funniest, relatable love stories (?) I have ever read and while I was not enthused about it at first, I just couldn’t stop laughing to stop reading.Peaches Monroe is a plus figured girl who runs a book store and captured the eye of a visiting movie star, Dalton Deangelo when she literally fell into his arms.  She finds her life getting more complicated the longer she dates Dalton and continually reminds herself to Keep Her Eyes Open, knowing the relationship cannot amount to anything long term.  To add additional complications to her life, her old heartthrob, Adrian Storm has returned to his hometown of Beaverdale and Peaches cannot explain the fluttering she experiences in his presence, believing her high school crush on him to be over.  They both comment on the dangers of dating actors and that they (actors)  are the very best liars alive, since that is their job.I have never read a romance novel that was so embarrassingly honest.  The sex was not earthshattering, the romantic encounters did not go smoothly and everyone was not beautiful and sexy.  Peaches is hilariously sarcastic and witty and her best friend, Shayla is her true partner in crime.  They “get” each other perfectly.  Adrian is mysterious and sexy, Dalton is smooth and sneaky and Peaches’s mom and dad are awesome.  The story just embodies the small town relationships, gossip and togetherness through tough times attitudes.  I was repulsed, allured, entertained and mystified enough to just keep reading.  Then the cliff hanger made me shout and get angry.  Not Right!!There was descriptive sex and plenty of profanity.  The sex included oral and back door which I don’t like at all, but the sex was not romantic in the first place and took some adjustments to just read through, so I don’t know, I just skimmed over it, too.  There are all sorts of questions left at the end of this one, so I am off to go find out what happens in STARLIGHT and hope Peaches didn’t just get used.Would I/Did I buy it? Yes (.99)Would I read it again?  NoWould I recommend it to friends? Yes, with warnings about the sex and cliffhanger

I LOVED THIS BOOK.  I immediately gave it to my teenage daughters and my best friend who also totally loved it.  It has everything, action, YA romance, mystery, aliens, science, space camp, death, friendship, family and suspense.  This is one of the better YA books I have read in a long time.  HIGHLY RECOMMEDED.Maisie Danger Brown wins a cereal box contest to go to space camp for three weeks.  Wanting to be an astronaut since she was six, her only liability might be that she doesn’t have a right hand.  Her best friend Luther is a fellow science geek and homeschooler, who is loyal, witty and might have a thing for her.At space camp she is grouped with three other super-intelligent kids and they compete to win a visit to the “Beanstalk”, the world’s only space elevator docking on an asteroid 36,000 kilometers away.  Also, while at space camp, Maisie meets Jonathan Ingles Wilder, a cute rich boy who is not put off by her missing hand and whose wit and intellect coincide with her own.  Not sure why the cute boy is singling her out among the girls, Maisie is thrilled by the first chills of infatuation and first kisses.But space camp is much more dangerous and scary than the brochure described as aliens enter the stratosphere and a savoir of the earth is needed.  Friendships are tested, loyalties are questioned and danger is lethal Maisie and her team discover what the aliens can do and how they must stop them.I loved every exciting minute of this book, especially the writing style.  Shannon Hale outdid herself with the inner voices, the puns, the personalities of ALL the characters, and the intelligence of the story.  I loved the dialogue, the friendships, the mystery and the romance.  Don’t miss this one!No profanity or sex; some kissing and cuddling.Would I/Did I buy it? YesWould I read it again? YesWould I recommend it to friends? Yes

Honestly??? This one starts off with Alex and Olivia having descriptive sex with other people?  No, sorry, just no.  I don’t do stories where people supposedly in love and meant for each other have sex with other people.  That is the great thing about fiction; people in love remain faithful to each other – tempted, yes, but not able to follow through out of loyalty and love for their true love.  This is just disgusting and a HUGE betrayal.  I don’t care if they are separated, Olivia has sex with another seconds after seeing Alex again after weeks.  Who knows how long Alex waited before reuniting with some skank?  No Thanks.  Returned.  Will not continue with series.There was descriptive sex and some profanityWould I/Did I buy it?  Yes (.99)Would I read it again?  NoWould I recommend it to friends? No

This story takes place immediately following Book One My Wolf's Bane ending, with Autumn and Zack agreeing to date and Charles waiting for Zack to finish high school before taking him to the werewolf King.  While sad that Zack will be leaving, Autumn loves being his girlfriend, despite the insecurities Gina puts in her mind about what Gina and Zack did when they were together.  Two new characters show up, Renzo and his niece Alura who seem to be watching Zack and Autumn and being too inquisitive.  After fighting with Charles, Autumn and Zack feel they need to break up to keep each other safe and end up making themselves insecure about their relationship while playing their parts convincingly.  Zack gets together with Gena for a science project and Cameron, a nice boy from school puts the moves on the now free Autumn.  Both make each other too jealous and hurt while supposedly broken up. But it all ends with everyone getting what they deserve.Autumn's parents are gone most of this book which allows her to do pretty much anything she wants.  While this does give her the ability to spend the nights with Zack, they never do anything more than snuggle and kiss because sex between two different species will SUPPOSEDLY make them weak and vulnerable, which would give the enemy, Charles a chance to kill them.There is some action and some paranormal situations, but this is mostly an angsty love story (swoon) with a stalker, fights, mystery and is the second in a (trilogy-?).  Honestly if you loved Hayden in Something Witchy This Way Comes,  you will adore Zack.  I love conflicted, honorable guys and these two are great!  This book does not alternate POV's like SWTWC's did, but you still saw the struggles of all the characters and fell in love with them all.Veronica Blade is friends with two of my favorite authors; Katie McGarry (Pushing the Limits) and Susan Hatler (Shaken), who help critique her work and explains why I love her work so much.  All three are very talented authors whose stories I highly recommend!The My Wolf's Bane Series  doesn't have any profanity or sex; just lots of very romantic kissing! (Smile)Would I/Did I buy it?  Lender's LibraryWould I read it again?  Yes, For ReviewWould I recommend it to friends? Yes

If you love words, you have to read this book! Second books are traditionally the character development tomes that are not normally as exciting as book 1 or book 3, but are needed to round out the story.  Since Maggie Stiefvater excels at both character development and plot advancement because of her masterful use of words, book 2 is not just a filler but a brilliant work of art.In the first book we got the object of the mission (finding Glendower) and who was the leader (Gansey).  We also got the budding of an attraction between Adam and Blue, but the foreshadowing that Blue's real true love would be Gansey whom she saw herself lovingly kissing in a vision.  And let's remember, Blue's true love will die when she kisses him.  In The Dream Thieves we get a better perspective on some of the crew making up the expedition that Gansey is leading, specifically Ronan.  While, in my opinion, the story still centers around the group, we are given little tidbits of information about Ronan specifically that help us to understand his "viper in the grass" persona.  We are also introduced to a new bad guy (the previous one was killed off) named the Gray Man, who was just as fascinating as all of Maggie Stiefvater's other characters.  Here's what we learn:The Grey Man: has been hired by Professor Colin Greenmantle, for the last five years, to find the Greywaren which he believes is an instrument or relic that allows the owner to take objects out of dreams.  We learned that Ronan can do this and suspect that he is the Greywaren that the Grey Man is looking for.  While mysterious, he is as forthcoming as Noah was when he said, "I have been dead for seven years" and no one took him seriously.  The Gray Man is asked his job and he truthfully declares, "I am a hit man" and apparently the truth is stranger than fiction because no one is phased by his words. For a bad man, you really want to like the Gray Man and find him suspiciously charming.  It's like he half-heartedly struggles with deciding to be good himself, but never really puts any effort into it.Ronan:  Ronan can bring things back from his dreams and knows how his father made all his money beacause: "I am just like my father" page 37.  Ronan feels that "All of his secrets felt dangerously close to the surface".  We discover how important Ronan is to the search for Glendower as he discovers his abilities to bring things out of his dreams and what that means for Cabeswater. We really get to know and even like Ronan as we watch him make mistakes and learn to like himself.Adam: Made a deal to be the hands and feet of Cabeswater at the end of The Raven Boys.  Now he is feeling the effects of his sacrifice which has got him all out of balance and hallucinating.  He has to discover how to deal and communicate with Cabeswater and finds that his relationship with all the group has changed drastically, but not as much as he has himself has chaanged.The Beginning of Blue and Gansey's romance:  While Blue and Gansey did not change much in this story they are still struggling to find "that more" that each of them feels they are capable of, while at the same time discovering "more" in each other:"Gansey who prized honesty above nearly every other thing, knew it (a lie) when he heard it.  Blue Sargent cared whether or not he was interested in Orla. She cared a lot. As she whirled toward the truck with a dismissive shake of her head, he felt a dirty sort of thrill". page 195Blue crumpled the edge of the (Gansey's) sheet against her nose.  It smelled like mint and wheatgrass, which was to say, like Gansey."I have a crush on Richard Gansey".In a way, it was easier than pretending otherwise. She couldn't do anything about it, of course, but letting herself think it was like popping a blister.Of course, the opposite truth also seemed self-evident."I don't have a crush on Adam Parrish"Maggie has admitted to wanting to make her readers "feel" enough to cry and my instincts are that just like Noah and The Grey Man being very direct about who they are, Maggie is not fooling around when she says that Gansey will die (and from Blue's Kiss).  Every bone in my body wants to rebel against her taking the story in this direction and I grasp at the fraudulent belief that she will "bring him back" somehow for a happily ever after, but I don't believe it in my soul.  I believe I am on a journey that I have been told will end badly, but I have refused to take the warnings seriously and will have no excuse when the prophecy is fulfilled as defined. Blue and her mother experience the same fate: Missing loves.A lot more  profanity than the first book (because it is Ronan!)  (sh**t, gd, JC, MF, f-word), divination, psychics and overall creepy people that really make this story come alive. (smile).Would I/Did I buy it? Yes HardcoverWould I read it again? YesWould I recommend it to friends? YES!!!!!

So this is kind of hard to rate. I love Katie McCarthy's style of writing and enjoyed the story, but it was just a tad too similar to Give Me Love for me to give it many originality points.  Hey, I read a lot of popular authors that use specific formulas (Abbi Glines, Melissa Schroeder, M. Leighton, Michelle Valentine), but they are such great character writers, that readers tend to forgive the repetitive themes.  Katie McCarthy is just such a great character writer, and could easily expand her theme in the next book - which I am hoping is about the hottest guy in the book, Casey.This one is about another of Mac's brothers, Travis and Mac's new assistant, Quinn.  Quinn and Travis have a one night stand and later realize that they will be around each other a lot.  This is great for Travis who wanted more from Quinn, but Quinn has some self-esteem issues along with a psycho abusive step-dad hunting for her which makes her wary of making any long term attachments.  Travis is all alpha male, including being the silent, brooding, somewhat possessive boyfriend while Quinn is independent, wary and insecure because of growing up in an abusive household.  She is also loyal, self-sacrificing and in need of some devoted friends, which she gets with the Jamison crew. The story is mostly written from Quinn's pov, but  I love that we get Travis's POV at the end!Some issues: Too Similar to the First One, so if you liked Give Me Love, this one is VERY formulaic, but not as long and drawn out.  There is the immediate attraction or romance that has some roadblocks to get rolling, there is the dangerous, gun toting bad guy who just can't be caught and there is a girl who thinks she can and should handle it all by herself, despite knowing a crack negotiation/protection team.  There is also the continual interruptions that come just when the sexy parts are getting good - I mean over and over where you kind of just sit back and wait for the fore-play to get interrupted. And it does - continually.  REGARDLESS, I love Katie McCarthy's characters and writing style and will DEFINITELY be in line to buy GIVE ME GRACE when it comes out.I was thinking this series was more like Michelle Mankin's Black Cat Record Series Love Evolution (Black Cat Records series), which are also really good.  I highly recommend this story for those who love a good romance and love story.  There was sex scenes, but not very explicit. There was some profanity (f-word, gd, sh**t, etc).Would I/Did I buy it? Yes (2.99)Would I read it again?  ProbablyWould I recommend it to friends? Yes

This was a cute story that kind of reminded me of Don't Let Go by Michelle Lynn. Both stories had heroes that had secrets that harmed their relationships when finally divulged.  Of course it also very similar to First Daughter, only MUCH SEXIER!  The author's style also reminded me of Lauren Blakley'sCaught Up In Us .  It is a good story for .99.Carrie Wallington is the daughter of an OVERLY protective senator who uses a young marine to watch his daughter while she is in school in San Diego, despite assuring her she wasn't being guarded.  Finn Coram was the 23 year old assigned to her duty who falls in love with her, knowing he shouldn't.  He plays the part of a careless surfer dude who is also in the Marines, and knows that Carrie is going to find out he is working for her dad and will hate him.  I kept imagining Channing Tatum as Finn and fell in love with the story (smile).Some issues: somewhat repetitive inFinn's belief that Carrie would break up with him when she discovered his lies.  He bemoans it a lot and it gets kind of old.  Carrie gets attacked and blood is on her neck from the knife, but she is rescued, taken home, and ravished and the only blood mentioned is that from her virginity(?).  Her neck needed medical attention, but it was never mentioned.It is fun, cute and predictable and maybe dragged a little towards the end, but I have to say, the little teaser phone call Finn got at the end to make me want to read the next book, was too manipulative.  I didn't need a semi-cliff hanger to want to read more by this author and I thought the ending was a low blow.Descriptive sex, profanity (f-word, gd, sh**t)Would I/Did I buy it? Yes (.99)Would I read it again?  Probably NotWould I recommend it to friends? Sure

This was a good story that reminded me a little of Bad Rep by A. Meredith Walters, which I was not a fan of.  This one I liked.  Sadie is a girl who went wild sexually after a tragedy and gained a bad reputation, making her switch schools in her senior college year.  Starting over, she just wants to get through her classes with no more drama.  Her roommate, Jessa becomes her best friend and introduces her to the night life where she meets Brady, the lead singer for the band The Invisibles and a senior engineering major. Unlike her previous fraternity rich kid boyfriends, Brady is also not the typical rock star man-whore.  Against her own roadblocks, she allows Brady to enter her heart and learns to trust again.While Sadie shares all her past indiscretions and secrets with Brady, he is less forthcoming.  He is afraid she will leave him if he shares the drama in his own life and his lack of trust becomes a stumbling block for their relationship, especially because Kara, a family friend seems to know so much more than she does and is included when she is not.  Kara, who is in love with Brady despite his rebuffs, threatens Sadie verbally and keeps showing up in Brady's life.  Grant, Brady's childhood best friend, likes Sadie at first, but then meets her roommate Jessa who is dating Rob from the Invisibles and wants her.  His story is next due out in October 2013.Things I liked: Brady's desire to make Sadie realize she was the only girl for him.  When other girls looked at him lustfully or when Kara would not let go of her delusions of being with him, he ignored the lustful glares and stared only at Sadie, and he TOLD Kara that Sadie was his girlfriend and tried to get her to stop her stalking behavior.  He never gave Sadie reason to not trust in his love for her.  I love that he didn't tease her and try to make her jealous or lead anyone else on.Some issues: Brady doesn't ever use a condom?! Sadie admits to sleeping with half a town and if she is used to no condoms, she is a walking STD.  They never even discuss it or her being on the pill.  The sex scenes, while frequent were unsatisfying. It was descriptive up until the orgasm, then just flat.  Left one feeling really dissatisfied.Would I/Did I buy it? Yes (.99)Would I read it again?  MaybeWould I recommend it to friends? Yes

I couldn't help but compare this to The Sea of Tranquility: A Novel by Katja Millay when I was reading it.  They both have these beautiful pastel covers, they both have a heroine who is struggling with her identity after a tragedy and the heroine uses some self-destructive behavior and running to deal with emotions.  Finally they both have a really great guy who is suffering through his own issues that love them and help them recover.Aimee's best friend Jillian died in a car accident after a party they both went to.  "They were so close that it was an ongoing joke with my family that Aimee and Jillian were the opposite of Siamese twins - one head controlling two bodies."  Aimee spent her senior year in Portland with her grandparents because she wanted a fresh start, "a place where Jillian hadn't breathed the air".  She returns to Florida to go to college with her sister and meets Cole the very first day.  Not ready to date, Cole, a guy with a reputation as a man-whore pursues her knowing he has to settle for friendship and totally confused by his feelings for her. "You're not the only one who fell that day" - Cole.I read and like Autumn Doughton's  On the Edge of Glass, but I loved In This Moment.  It was a real story that took its time to reveal all the gritty details of death, friendship, love and devotion.  Doughton writes "bare bones" love scenes  in that she builds the heat and desire in the reader, then tells you when it's over.  She also uses alternating POV's so you feel the desire Cole has for Aimee and learn to trust that he doesn't want to hurt her with his bad boy ways.  The reader also is inside Aimee's head and see her confusion, guilt and desires."I never used to think about things like death and life and all the hundreds of thousands of seconds that get stuck in between.  Back then I didn't know the way that a person can crawl so far inside of you that your organs voluntarily shift to the side to make room for the shape of them."Another story this reminded me was After Math (Off the Subject #1) by Denise Grover Swank, so if you liked that or The Sea of Tranquility, you will love this story too.Would I/Did I buy it? YesWould I read it again?  YesWould I recommend it to friends? Yes

WARNING: This is Sad like  Chasing Nikki (Chase Walker #1) by Lacie Wetherford. Not my type of "Love Story" as I like to read for romance.  It is VERY WELL written, and if you can handle sad, you'll like it.Some Spoilers:So in this story, Eamon is the man-whore who doesn't want commitment/responsibility of any type.  He refuses the supervisor position at his work, he only does one night stands and  he is reckless with his own safety - taking stupid life-threatening dares for the adrenaline rush.  When he finds himself suddenly attracted to his life-long female best friend Rachel, where he just can't keep his hands off of her, he agrees to a weekend of sex with her to "get it out of his system".  Unfortunately for Rachel, she is and has been in love with Eamon for years and knows that a weekend of sex is going to kill her heart.  She hopes she is different from all his other girls, but finds she is not when he beds another red head after their perfect sex weekend.  What she doesn't know is that Eamon has to force himself to have sex with another girl because he can't get Rachel out of his mind and is afraid that he might be in love with her.Yes, I said force himself to have sex with another girl, actually TWO other girls.  He is really something. (Amazon prevents me from saying what!).  So while technically Eamon and Rachel agreed to only the weekend, he is not cheating on her, it still really FEELS like he is CHEATING on her and I hate that feeling in real life and when I am reading a LOVE story. Just saying.I really liked My Heart for Yours and Tobin and Delia play a very small role in this book.  This story takes place before Tobin sees Delia again since they have been broken up for eight months.  Tobin knows Delia is dating another guy, but also knows she is not in love with him.  Tobin is/was faithful to Delia for over eight months when he had no hope of getting her back, but his brother can't even go a week.  I forgot from My heart for Yours that Tobin's brother DIES!! This story is SAD! I really like Steph's writing, but this story is just depressing as far as love stories go.Editing is an issue in this one as there are plenty of missing words which makes the reader double take to get the sentence right.  There is descriptive sex and plenty of profanity similar to the first book.  While I really love this author's writing style , but I was disappointed by Eamon's hurtful actions and Rachel's too easy forgiveness and acceptance and, of course, the ending.Would I/Did I buy it? Yes (.99)Would I read it again?  NOWould I recommend it to friends? Yes, for writing and with warning that it is SAD.

A Big WARNING that this book ends with a MAJOR cliff-hanger, so if you hate that trend in indie books, be forewarned.  In many ways, the ending reminded me of the cliff hanger in the FABULOUS book by Claire Contreras called There is No Light in Darkness (Darkness #1) (Darkness Series).  Thankfully, that series was only two books long and hopefully, so will this one.This is a great story for only .99.  25 year old Inky or Anika is a great character who has been through abuse and survived - with baggage.  She has a great life-long friend in Aimes, a boyfriend/fiancé who she has been in love with for 3 years, but only been together with for 2 months and another roommate/friend, Lisa while working as an artist and a bar-tender.  The first half of the book is establishing her relationships and setting the suspicion that all is not as perfect as it seems.  Inky is happily engaged, she is expressing herself well in her paintings and singing and she feels truly happy.  Her best friend Aimes who is normally pretty slutty, is in serious love with a divorcee named Gus, but her other roommate Lisa has been acting bitchy towards her lately and Inky met a hot guy named Cole who helped her through a panic attack and sparks went off between them confusing her feelings towards Evan.SOME SPOILERS:Those of us who have been there, knew what the bitchy roommate/ working out of town at the same time roommate has "gone home" boyfriend really meant, but poor Inky didn't see it coming.  Her name Inky is from the large tattoo of an oak tree on her back that represents the bad things that have happened to her but have not knocked her down.  She puts a new leaf on the ground of the oak tree to show one more thing she has overcome.  Inky's mother was emotionally abusive and her mother's rich boyfriend "Papa Joe" was sexually abusive.  When he shows up again after 10 years, and tries to get at Inky, she starts to have panic attacks again.The second half of the book is Inky's SUPER FAST relationship with 35 year old Cole who is from high society and has an A&&hole father. It explores two bent, but not broken people who want someone to trust and love.  They are the answer to each other's prayer and "get" the darkness the other goes into and needs help coming out of.  I wish more of the story was devoted to them.  Their story was a little too neatly packaged and could have been livened up with an encounter with the ex's or even if "Papa Joe" had turned out to be Giuseppe Drago's son and the guy who bought her painting.  There wasn't enough action or drama in the second half before that agonizing cliff-hanger! I LOVED the beautiful cover of this book!  You definitely get a lot of story, emotional angst and great friendship along with some dirty betrayals, angry music and destructive memories.  I liked it enough to want to read the next in the series when it comes out. There is a lot of profanity and somewhat descriptive sex.Would I/Did I buy it? Yes (.99)Would I read it again?  MaybeWould I recommend it to friends? Yes, But it has a MAJOR cliff-hanger!

The first thing I noticed from page one was that there was too much "he said", "she said", not something more descriptive like,  "she whispered, embarrassed", or "he suggested, helpfully".  If you end your dialogues with "said" every time it becomes monotonous and misses out on the easy opportunity to flesh the characters out more.  Both Natalie Sharp and Alex Mercer appear to be robots at their first meeting with this stilted dialogue.The next thing was that the sexual attraction between these two was mysterious and emotionless.  "He smiled, and parts of my anatomy reacted to him. I growled inside at them to stop" or after refusing a drink in case it was drugged (3 pages in), and having just got his name, "An image flashed in my mind of him touching me with (his hand), stroking my breasts and pinching my nipples and I clenched between my legs". So, she wants the guy she thinks is wanker enough to drug her? And this "sexual attraction" is after she has tripped in front of him twice, once bloodying hands and knees and once knocking herself out and waking up in his house."New Zealand has one of those reputations for everyone knowing each other but that's not the case, except for when it is". ???It is in first person narrative which always seems to make the main character appear bitchy and the transitions stilted.  Then, at 10% when Natalie says she is not a whore and two minutes later is naked in Alex's truck "doing him", I lost interest in the story.  She met him the DAY BEFORE and he was in her restaurant with another woman.  She knows NOTHING about him but that his company is taking away her livelihood and  that he wants her and she beds him in his truck. Classy.While the story after that is fairly predictable and not much out of the ordinary really happens, it is the dialogue and the transitions that really began to frustrate me. I found it hard to care or even like these characters and wished the author had taken the time to flesh them out more.  I highly suggest getting the free pages first to see if the writing style is for you.Would I/Did I buy it? Yes (.99)Would I read it again?  NoWould I recommend it to friends? No

So I am really not a fan of first person narratives, they sound too much like a diary and it is really hard to like a person when you know their EVERY thought.  It is also way too descriptive: what she is wearing, what she is doing, what she is thinking, who she bumps into, what she is eating.... skim, skim skimming.  Really, that is just not interesting and needs to be edited.  I liked all the characters and that it took place mostly in London, but they all acted so immaturely and the "misunderstanding" was too stupid for words.Chloe was cheated on by her boyfriend Connor, so she moves to London for a job promotion and meets Jack, the bassist for the band SubZero and they fall for each other.  Conveniently, he lives across the hall from her and when her sister comes to visit she falls for Tyler, another band member.  All is well until Connor makes a surprise visit to get Chloe back and tells Jack that he is still in Chloe's life.  Jack breaks it off with Chloe without letting her explain. The rest of the stories goes on from there.  Jack is definitely NOT an alpha male who fights for what he wants, which was slightly pathetic.The dialogue was really agonizing at many times included juvenile conversations and ridiculous meetings.  I admit the story gets more interesting towards the end, but how about some words to  the song Jack writes for Chloe? While I won't be continuing with the series, I would suggest writing alternate POV's, refraining from the diary type entries and add some rock and roll drama.  These musicians act like kindergarteners, not heartthrobs. (also, what is up with Nick and Noelle being a couple out of the blue? That needs more explanation).This is for the younger YA even though the characters are older; nothing really fits a mature situation.  There is some kissing but no profanity and no descriptive sex.Would I/Did I buy it? Free DownloadWould I read it again?  NoWould I recommend it to friends? No

Have you ever wondered who the half naked models in sensual (sexual) positions are on the cover of books?  Welcome to the world that Rook enters when she meets a modern young Fabio named Ronin and becomes the next erotica model for the Tragic campaign. Now why this book does not have these two on its cover is BEYOND ME!Wow, this was really good!  If you are in for a love story that is slightly erotic, than this story about abused Rook and smokin' Ronin is for you.  I must say, though, that the product description is very misleading as we never see Rook "make it" in the modeling business in this book.  She is just a troubled girl that is helped by someone who used to be in her place and was helped in life.  The book is more about Ronin and Rook falling for each other and Rook figuring out who and if she can trust her new friends. Also, the PD suggest her past will come back and "get her", but again, not in this bookSo, the tone of this book reminds me a little of The Edge of Never by J. A. Redmerski.  Rook was in an abusive relationship that she fled but ended up in another state and in a homeless shelter.  After being fired from her job and being falsely accused of stealing, she "gets" an invitation to a photo shoot and ends up getting the job.  It is there that she meets the beautiful Ronin, who has the same unique color eyes that she has.  Too scared to enter another relationship, she is thrilled to get paid to model even if it is for erotica book covers or other "tasteful nudes" not porn (and I quote).Well, most of us might disagree with whether or not she might be doing porn, but the point is she is working and calling her own shots, and is not being controlled anymore; at least she doesn't think she is.  There is something about her new job that makes her feel dirty and all sorts of red flags about Ronin, but she is hoping that she is choosing right and is glad that SHE is doing the choosing.There was a lot of sensuality, descriptive sex and, let's face it, soft porn in this book, but the story was still sweet and was not filled with angst, cheating or drugs.  There are some questions that are not answered as this is the first book ( the second called, Manic is due out in August 2013), that will continue Rook and Ronin's relationship.  Just based on the business they are in, they have a long road to go, but I will be reading all about them as J. A. Huss is an excellent writer and made me really care about these two lovers.Would I/Did I buy it? Yes (.99)Would I read it again?  YesWould I recommend it to friends? Yes

This story is about Jonah who is a mafia type collector who worked for his Uncle Vinnie who is also a drug lord, and Olivia, who is a college student that runs into him accidentally when he is "collecting" from one of the professors.  She is immediately attracted to him, but he is brooding and makes a quick get-a-way.  Later that week, she and her roommates go to Club Risk and she sees him again.Olivia can't get Jonah out of her head even though he has tried to push her away saying that she was too good of a girl for a bad boy like him and that he would only hurt her.  He has secrets that he is unwilling to share and Olivia decides she can live with secrets if she can belong to Jonah.  They fall into bed together WAY TOO FAST especially for her being a virgin, but they are in lust, I mean love.While Jonah doesn't want Olivia to find out about his drug dealing job, She doesn't want him to find out her secrets either. But once she discovers his real job, she runs away from him and is in more danger than ever before.This story was really good but was missing the little something that made it sensational.  More intimate scenes would have help, more dangerous moments and maybe some jealousy would have given it the edge it needed.  Overall, it was a good mystery in regards to what Olivia had done that was so hard to confess, an alright romance in that it may have happened to fast and not enough emotional and physical description, but interesting characters. I will probably read the sequel which looks like it is going to be about Jonah's roommate, Denny and the girl he loves enough to leave alone.There are a lot of misspelled words and editing issues, but nothing too baffling, some not very descriptive sex and a lot of profanity (f-word, BS, sht, Hell,). Chapters designating WHO was talking would be helpful as well as additional space between scene/time changes.Would I/Did I buy it? Free downloadWould I read it again?  Probably notWould I recommend it to friends? Sure

This story was heavier than the first one as it dealt A LOT with grief and regret.  While it was well informed and sensitive, it was hard to find the love story between Demetri and Alyssa when Alyssa's previous boyfriend Brady was such a great guy.  Every time Alyssa went back in time to a memory with Brady, I fell more in love with him and swooned.  No, he was not perfect but neither is Demetri and sweet Alyssa deserves true love.  I could definitely see why it was so hard for her to move on.  Honestly, it was very depressing.The story starts off with the rock star, Demetri, getting a lowly job at the taffy shop which required masses amount of REALLY SUSPENDING BELIEF!  Demetri, crushed by a broken heart, drug addiction and reckless driving, is trying to turn his life around with the help of his therapist and closest friends.  He wants the consuming love his brother has with Natalee, but feels he has used up his one chance at true love when his girlfriend died in a car accident.  Natalee talks him into a common job working at the taffy shop because he has no inspiration to write songs.  While there, he meets the competition in the form of Alyssa, the beautiful, sarcastic girl who was not charmed by who he is and becomes his muse.Thus begins their love story: "What if you take the one part of me that's finally started to breathe without crying?" - Alyssa"No. I won't leave you alone. I won't abandon you. I'm sure as hell not going to listen to you, and you can damn well know that I'm going to fight for you". - DemetriBoth Alyssa and Demetri have suffered loss and, I am not going to lie, the grief sessions at Demetri's house made me tear up.  There were these flash backs of Alyssa and her boyfriend Brady that were so sweet, that the loss hurt that much more.  It was hard to read.  The whole book was emotionally draining and, while many will find this romantic, it is not my type of story.Was it as good as Tear?  Well, not really; it was definitely emotional, but not as romantic or filled with good drama, just sadness.  At least it didn't have a stupid love triangle, I really hate those.  You could really tell a female was writing Demetri's thoughts and it was a little lame sometimes because, as he confesses himself, he was really acting like a girl.Some confusion on story integrity: Demetri claims to be both nineteen and eighteen in the book which is it? Also, how hard all these kids fell in love at such a young age (15) - it is so Romeo and Juliet. And Alec and Nat's relationship sure got boring - where'd their spice go?  It's too early for the honeymoon to be over! And his reveal to Demetri that he might have got another girl in trouble was just wrong on so many levels.  Apparently book 3, Shatter, will be written from Alec's POV and will strain his relationship with Nat as AD2 becomes REALITY TV.Rachel Van Dyken is an entertaining writer who always keeps me turning the pages, and even though this one was too heavy for me, I will definitely be purchasing book 3! Her stories are definitely YA, not New Adult, but for .99, it is a STEAL.No Swearing or sex; but there was intense kissing, drug and alcohol use and sleepoversWould I/Did I buy it? Yes (.99)Would I read it again?  ProbablyWould I recommend it to friends? Yes

So in this book, Hope has the perfect boyfriend, Trent, but then meets Joey and is no longer in love with Trent.  The two times she sees Joey, he acts like a complete, wasted jerk.  Personally, I can't find a reason for her to be mooning over the Italian Jerk when her boyfriend is treating her so well.  Most girls marry men like their fathers if they have a good relationship with them, and Trent is just like Hope's father.  Hope and Trent have sex once in a year long relationship and the reader is expected to believe he doesn't try to get more?  Not likely. Hope was in love with Trent at one time, but now finds Trent BORING.My suggestion to Ashley Wilcox is to start this story with meeting Joey the second summer and gloss over the previous year that Hope is with Trent.  Do not make the reader fall in love with Mr. Perfect ("Trent has every quality that you dream your future husband will have - good looks, big heart, sensitive, hardworking and an overall great guy.  He's the perfect guy"), have sex with him and then bring in another guy. Hope has two sex scenes with Trent (one after Joey!) and only one with Joey. Oh, and make the love scene with Joey a lot hotter!This "love story" just leaves a bad taste in your mouth. I liked both guys (eventually), but not Hope. I personally, was hoping Trent would find a new girl and forget about Hope. Hope's reaction to finding out about Joey and making out with Trent felt like cheating.  She just was not a great heroine.Would I/Did I buy it? Yes (.99)Would I read it again? NoWould I recommend it to friends? No

Well, you know I bought this one just because of the COVER!!! Unfortunately, I hated the story! This book is for you if you like horrible people who have sex, I mean lustful f-ing, but they absolutely do not make love, like at all and SUPPOSEDLY fall in love. I know there are many out there that do (10 positive reviews already to prove it) but for those who like romance and decent people who do not play games with other's lives, cheat or use sex as a weapon, you will hate this story.By 17% through, I was not impressed and even slightly disgusted with the main character Aston. While I really like reading dual points of view, this one repeated the SAME events over again. The narration style made the characters seem less than charming; Aston was beautiful and knew it and Sloan was just a jerk: "Just looking at her through a window, like a pervert none-the-less, got me all hot and bothered. Man, I was going to have to start taking cold showers at work if this was how my *ick was going to spend its day" and "I don't know exactly what it was, but being in the close proximity and hearing her laugh, was making my *ick twitch." Classy. *ick is used 33 times. Also, Sloan is romancing Aston at the office, but still being a womanizer each night - douche.SOME SPOILERS***I am also not a huge fan of winking and these two did a lot of winking (35 times!). These two couldn't be more pretentious and conceited. I kept thinking I would grow to like them, but NO. I started skimming by 23%. Finally, at the Toby Keith's Bar, things started to get better (27%) and later with a hot night of sex. But then she succeeds in her mission of making her ex, Nole, regret her and leave his bride at the altar and all she can think about is sleeping with Sloan again and I am right back into hating this book. Oh, and Aston's best friend Shelby steals someone else's boyfriend, then later cheats on him with a waiter, then is with him again - quality girls. All this action happens within 5 weeks and let me just say, I hope there isn't a sequel, because you know these characters are not going to make it. END SPOILERS***(thoughts as I kept reading) Oh. My. God. These people all deserve each other!Keep in mind, the star system is not how well a book is written, it is whether or not you liked the book and reviews are subjective. This book wasn't for me, but that doesn't mean others won't like it. As for me, Aston, Sloan and Shelby are three people I hope I never meet.Some profanity YES!!!, descriptive sex and oral sex, self-sex, drinking.Would I/Did I buy it? Yes (2.99)Would I read it again? NOWould I recommend it to friends? No, my friends would cringe at people this horrible

"He practically had a `your mother did warn you' stamp on his forehead right next to the `yes, I do taste as good as I look' and it made her want to touch all the more."WOW,This is a REALLY long really GOOD book, so at the fantastic price of .99, it is a deal.  Airicka Phoenix is a very good writer if not too prolific!  This is definitely a teen novel that deals with highschoolers that are 17 but seemed younger, but then it also has some super ADULT situations that makes it very INTENSE.  There is a very big parental presence and some repetitive dialogue that may contribute to the length of the story, but overall, a very good romance with some absolute TERROR in it.There is a new bad boy in town, Spencer, with a schizophrenic hot/cold attitude toward the heroine Sophie. Sophie likes the most popular boy in school, Brian who is finally singer and invites her and her friends to the popular group's party that Friday night. Sophie has to sneak out of her house in order to go to the party and ends up being saved from three university guys by none other than Spencer. (She is continually walking into his "brick wall" chest and being saved by him).  While wildly attracted to Spencer's body, Sophie is confused by his meanness towards her.  Both throw insults and sarcasm at each other, but just when Sophie thinks he might be acting nicely towards her, he does something incredibly mean and keeps his distance from her.When Sophie later discovers that Spencer's old girlfriend hurt him BADLY and that is why he doesn't want her, she begins to understand his hot/cold attitude. As they start to get to know each other, Spencer's car is vandalized, they get hit with BB's and Sophie is left a bloody gift on her doorstep.  Somebody does not want them together and they have to hide out for awhile. Their romantic relationship is really sweet and fun to read!  Then there are chapters and chapters of Sophie being abused by the psycho that wants her and it is very disturbing to witness the sickness of this character. "You are much feistier than the others.  They were willing to do anything I said just so long as I swore not to hurt them." - psychoAll the characters are really great and definitely fleshed out, but it really was too long.  A good editor could really help tighten this book up (mostly by taking a lot of the conversations with her parents out as they are mostly repetitive). I really loved the plot and the characters, but to be honest, I skimmed A LOT and still found it a fantastic story.Some profanity (sht,damn,one f-word) very sensual make out scenes (hello!) sex but not even descriptive (talked about after the fact) and physical abuse from the psycho that wants her and kidnaps her and others. INTENSE ENDING!Would I/Did I buy it? Yes (.99)Would I read it again? Probably NotWould I recommend it to friends? Yes

If you were a fan of Veined (A Guardian of the Angels Novel) (download it while it is FREE!), then you will love Lethed just as much.  It is NOT the typical second book where nothing really happens - NO - it is full of action and love and kicking demon butt!  I love Anyta Sunday's characters - all of them - and her writing style.In Viened, Sylva became a Guardian because the Angels needed help to battle demons and keep the gates of Eirene safe.  She and Atticus were "lethed" - stripped of all their memories of each other but had the added "bonus" of being able to feel each other's wounds.  Sylva's family's memories had been "lethed" also so they had no memory of her.  It hurt that she wasn't missed and that she no longer had a family.  She felt ALoNE.  Marcus had left with his bonded Guardian Dimitri (gay relationship - not the only one, I might add) but she was going to get the chance to see him and go to a Vein Dance to watch two people get engaged.  Guess who one of them is.....There is a Moirae prophecy that says there's a way to relock Eirene and separate it from Ache forever  and that Sylva is the KEY to the prophecy, but only a few believe in its validity. Attic's mom, the Queen, still hates Sylva and is determined to keep them apart.  There is a lot more attention paid to the strained gay relationship between Dimitri and Marcus and adorable Jason (yes, I said adorable) is a major character who is trying to redeem his error of giving Silver to Furie.  Both Marcus and Jason are still half demon and have a hard time fighting the evil within.The great thing about Atticus and Sylva having their memories removed is that they get to fall in love all over again, I mean, once a couple falls in love, the story becomes a little stagnant, so if they get to start all over again, you start cheering for them to REMEMBER!!!!  I loved it.  This book also had a serious message about doing what was right over what is wanted. "We do what we have to" even when it involves a loved one dying or denying love because it is right.If you haven't read Veined in awhile, a review is needed.  While Anyta goes over some of what happened before, it is really skimmed and somewhat confusing at first.  There is some  profanity (s***, B*tch, f-word), really gross, descriptive, bloody fighting, drinking, some almost sex and some really good kisses (smile).  Book 3 called Phoenixed is not due out until 2014.  Someone tell Anyta to WRITE FASTER!Would I/Did I buy it? Yes (2.99)Would I read it again?  For ReviewWould I recommend it to friends? Yes

If you are like me, you see the word "Documentary" and think LONG and BORING, not romantic love story. While this book is long (Over 400 pages for only .99), it is definitely NOT boring! The great thing about reading a book this long is that you REALLY get to know the characters and come to care about them. And there are a lot of really great characters in this book from bad boy surfer twins, to Hawaiian Hotty to sexy, fun loving girls to slutty one night stands. If you enjoyed Foolish Games (Book 1) (Foolish Games Series), Tidal, Love Unscripted: The Love Series, Book 1 or  Incidental Happenstance then you will like this book too.This exciting story opens with a prequel where musician bad boy, Kai, and his (former) best friend, Jeremy are at the end of a knock down fight and Kai questions whether he has killed Jeremy who is NOT moving. What has got Kai so mad???? That is the plot of the story as everyone wants to know what happened that night as the fight took place in the ally.The first half (200 pages) is about college junior Dylan Carroll getting the coveted job of documenting bad boy singer Kia White for a couple weeks for Christmas break. This is Dylan's "big break" into the industry she loves and she has a natural talent at film making. Dylan, like all breathing girls, falls hard for the gorgeous Kai, but has to stay away from him in order to keep her job. This is WAY TOO HARD for her since Kai is continually flirting with her and staring at her. Both Kai and Dylan are damaged souls as Dylan's beloved brother, Mac, died 6 months ago and Kai has had a VERY rough life. Kai is constantly getting in fights and it is Dylan's job to help redefine his image by letting the fans get a look at the real Kai White."Cute or not, he seems like a disaster, and not the kind where you're both tolerable train wrecks and in the midst of the "baloney", it just sort of works out due to some sort of cosmic trickery" - Kate (Dylan's best friend) (Amazon wont let me use real quote)The second half of the book (another 200 pages) is about the super SECRET that Kai has and whether or not he will reveal it. Dylan is under orders from her boss, Nina, to wheedle out the secret and reveal it, but her deepening feelings for him only make her want to help him overcome his demons. Since Kai knows he can't be with Dylan and that he is "just a job" to her, he continually provokes her (and the reader) to jealousy. I know, Dylan's devotion to Kai gets a little much and you want to tell her to GET A BACK BONE! But just keep reading.To be honest, I would recommend this author take 80 pages off this work and give it a new title. No, I did not skim at all, and I loved ALL her secondary characters, but the book was long. As for new title suggestions that would help market this book better, how about: Record of Love, The Tattoo Song, Lyrics Are My Ink and lastly Team Dick (you have to read the story to get that one, LOL). I totally recommend this gem, especially at the low price of .99 - WHAT A STEAL! There is a sequel, but this does not end on a cliff hanger, thankfully!Profanity (btch, f-word, etc) descriptive sex, drinking and some drug reference.Would I/Did I buy it? Yes (.99)Would I read it again? YesWould I recommend it to friends? Yes

Michelle Mankin has a great idea of modern re-tellings of Shakespeare's comedies using a rock band and country singers.  I loved Love Evolution which was Twelfth Night and Love Revolution which is Much Ado About Nothing.  I am looking forward to Love Resolution due out in March (according to the author's comments at the end of this book) of 2013, but no hit is given about which Shakespeare comedy this one will be.I am a big fan of characters reappearing in subsequent books and was not disappointed to see Avery, Mason and the rest of Brutal Strength, especially JR, who was a main character in this book.  So if you know the Shakespeare story, then you know it is about two female relatives (sisters in this book) who fall in love.  One is prickly and is hard to love, the other is sweet and kind and the perfect woman.  I was surprised when Sara and Chris Alex (who we met in book 1) meet because their sexual banter seemed juvenile and I was surprised to find out they were 32 and 44 respectively.  I thought these two were the main characters and in their early twenties when I first started reading, but it is Sara's sister Sam who is in her twenties and falls for JR, the drummer of Brutal Strength.Of course there was the showdown and the feelings of betrayal, just like in Shakespeare's work, and a sweet/sad love song that Sara and Chris collaborated on called That Leads to Leavin' you.  I love that this author can write lyrics and it reminds me of Where She Went by Gayle Forman.  These re-tellings are really fun to read and, again, I have recommended it to my best friend.There was very descriptive kissing, some profanity (f-word) and some sex in this one.  I loved that it was romantic love making and not the dominate crap that is so popular today and in so many of the books I have read lately.  Both girls are CHERISHED by the guys that love them and not treated as ho's.  Brutal Strength's members seemed to be really decent guys as there were no groupies, casual sex, bad boy behavior or psycho paparazzi, just good clean Shakespeare comedy light-heartedness.Would I/Did I buy it? Yes (.99)Would I read it again?  PossiblyWould I recommend it to friends? Yes, especially Shakespeare fans.

This was a love story of two broken souls finding each other next door and fitting together to make something beautiful.  Ally had been through a traumatic family murder and Ian had lost his fiancé to cancer. Both just wanted to be left alone and sought isolation to grieve.  When Ally becomes too sick to stay home, Ian becomes her lifeline and her miracle worker and she unwittingly helps him to heal too."It sucks when someone you know turns into someone you knew, especially when it is yourself." - Ally"It is astounding how when you look at me I may seem Ok, like I have it all together, but if you see me when no one's around I'm thoroughly broken inside and struggling to put the pieces back together" - IanIan shows his inner beauty way before he ever falls in love with Ally or realizes she is beautiful to him.  He proves his loyalty, dependability and honesty way before he claims her beautiful body as his own.  I also like the alternating POVs so you know what each character is thinking.While I liked the love story, there were several parts that left a little to be desired and I did end up skimming some of the cheesing moments in the end.  The declaration of love was unnecessarily prolonged and misunderstandings took up the space. There was some editing issues such as missing "i" in the word "in" and some extra letters to some words. There was some descriptive sex towards the end.Would I/Did I buy it? Free downloadWould I read it again?  Well, NoWould I recommend it to friends? Yes

I got this because I liked the cover, was intrigued by the description and it was only .99.  I have to disagree with the other reviewers so far, as I found this story predictable, somewhat boring and the characters - flat.32 year old Theresa was married twice to two twits and was still making really bad choices.  While her second husband, Gary was stalking her to get her back, she goes on a blind date with Stuart, on her best friend, Jamie, recommendation.  She decides to sleep with this loser, but stalker Gary shows up and Stuart high tails it out of there, leaving Theresa to handle Gary on her own.  Convinced by her "sage" best friend to hire a body guard, she is yet again on the cusp of lust when she meets Nathaniel, the god-like body guard who just happens to "like" her back (because a two time divorcee with a bratty 9 year old is so attractive).  I found their romance to be dry, predictable and really boring.  With all the great reviews, I just kept expecting it to get better...something, but no.Theresa has an adopted daughter with her first husband, Glen.
