And what the heck is a "gram" or "milliliter" in the recipes section? :)This has all the bearings of a game which is pretty well made for a first-generation title, but may not stand the test of time as newer and more innovative games come out. Still, for someone looking for a "pure" exercise game, it's not a bad choice. The ability to see your own actual video image next to Mel B is not just cool--there's no better way to help you visualize and time the exercise, particular for aerobics exercises. And the scenery is definitely beautiful and head-and-shoulders improved over what you'd see on a Wii. That, plus the fact that this is the first attempt at any fitness game for the PS3, gets it a solid 4 stars from me.For "fun", I'll give it 2 stars, as at the end of the day it's still just a glorified exercise DVD, which I don't find particularly fun. Not that there's anything wrong with that, but I hope as game developers produce more fitness titles for the PS3, that they can introduce more "gaming" elements to make workouts a lot more immersive and fun.

I have dry eye and was going to give up driving. When driving when the sun is coming up I got blinded and could hardly see, having to put my visor down, but that still wasn't a perfect solution.I read the good reviews for these, after reading a lot of other reviews, but I decided to give these a try, they weren't terribly expensive, and I had a feeling they would be good.I don't wear eye glasses, so didn't have to worry about them not fitting underneath these. They are perfect for driving when the sun is rising, nice and clear and bright, no more pulling down the visor. I worried they would be too dark for driving, but they are perfect.

My old shredder was on it's last legs, so I ordered this as it had good reviews. My old shredder said it could shred twice as many pages as this, but I never put more than about half a dozen sheets in at a time. It was my second shredder. I normally do a big shred session every year, but decided it would be better to shred the papers more often, I think it's kinder on the machine, I don't like to overheat it.When I put the old one out with the garbage after it finally kicked the bucket, it had shreds of paper still in the blades I could not remove. I love this shredder, when it has finished shredding, I slide the button to reverse and all the sheds that didn't drop down the first time, quickly dropped down completely, leaving the the blades shred free. I really like that feature. It sits on top of a bucket type container, unlike the last one which slid out.At first I was a bit concerned that it wouldn't hold as much as the old one, but now I'm shredding more often, and keeping on top of it, it's not a problem. I would buy this shredder again.

It was so much easier. I stored them on the baking sheets for the next time.They are a nice size for my Hamilton Beach counter top oven.

This is my 4th  Bissell in about 12 years, the first two were really large and heavy, the third was smaller and lighter which was a great relief. Three days ago I was ready to clean the living-room carpet (as I do it twice a year) the water wasn't circulating, just like the others after I had them for a few years. The belt and motor worked OK and it was cleaned from the previous use, the water just leaked onto the carpet, which was annoying I was in the middle of spring cleaning. Maybe my Bissell's hadn't lasted long, because I hadn't vacuumed enough. After each use when I clean it, there's always some grit and dust which gets stuck into places impossible to get to, maybe the tubes got blocked. There doesn't seem to be a way to get to them, I gave up on it and looked online for a new one.I almost ordered a different brand that was really expensive, thinking it would last longer It had good reviews, but then I noticed the bad ones, so many reviewers ended up with the same problem. If I'd spent a lot of money and it wouldn't work, I'd be very upset. I decided that I may as well go with this cheap one, if it lasts two or three years I'll be happy, I ordered it Tuesday night.It's now Friday, it was delivered by Fed Ex at lunch time, I can't get over how fast it came with the free shipping, I'm not even a Prime member. I was expecting the large size I thought it said, but it's small and almost the same as old one it's replacing, which is great because it doesn't take up too much space.I vacuumed the living room carpet three times. There were some old tea stains I didn't think it would get rid of, but I'm happy to report the Bissell did it's job, the stains are gone, the fibers are soft and fluffy and the house smells lovely and fresh, it didn't take long for it to dry with the ceiling fan on high. The Bissell cleaning solution is very concentrated, you don't need much, it's amazing how black the water was. There was hardly any grit and dust when I cleaned it, vacuuming very well was worth it.This Bissell is very easy to use, a red button to turn it on, and next to it one which you press to move the handle down. there's another button you press to release the clean water with the cleaning solution onto the carpets. The handle must be down on the floor to release the tank to empty out the dirty water. Lift and snap up the two clips each side of the tank and lift it up, there's about an inch square opening for the water to be poured out through..I love Bissell's, and obviously I'm not the only one around here, I put the old one out by the curb next to the garbage last night with the instruction manual taped to it. The next morning just as the sun was rising, I looked outside and was amused to find it was gone, someone had taken it!

I was looking for something to help my bottlebrush tree, it began to look awful after a hurricane struck one of the branches off in 2004. Amazingly the gap eventually filled, but it just didn't look good, the branches were all over the place and it didn't look healthy or pretty. Last fall, I had the tree trimmed into a nice shape, but it still didn't look good.I saw this product on Amazon and thought I'd give it a try, I used about 4 lbs of it, the tree is quite old and tall, it probably could have done with more according to the instructions. I've also been watering occasionally, which is also recommended.It's now February and what a difference, it has greened out with new growth, and beautiful scarlet bottlebrushes are growing. The harsh outline from it being cut, has gone. It's looking so much better, I'm sure this stuff is helping it. I will keep using it.

I like lots of different types of music, and came across this recently on you tube and just couldn't stop playing. I decided to purchase it and add it to my collection of favorites music that I love to play, on my tablet. I noticed on you tube a Farenelli movie, which this is from, it was interesting to read the true story on Wikipedia.

I have been using this a few years now, I live in Florida and there is a lot of humidity. This stuff really does a good job, even in the winter when it's not so humid, it's surprising how quick the granules soak in the humidity and turn them to liquid. Last time I bought it, it was on sale really cheap, I bought a lot.Recently I was buying something else and needed to make up my purchase total to $35 for the free shipping. I saw this at  $3.98, you really can't get much cheaper than that.I use this in  4 containers which I originally bought (each containing 10.5 ounces of Damp Rid) The same individual containers now cost $6.54 at the time of this review. Four times $6.54= $26.16. A very good product for a great price.DampRid FG01K Refillable Moisture Absorber, Fragrance Free, 10.5-Ounce.

I bought this watch for my grandson (who will soon be celebrating his 10th birthday) and lives in the UK. I did some research before buying it, after reading mostly good reviews. On the British Amazon they have the exact same watch for 47 with mostly good reviews. I was taken aback by the price, I only paid $14.99.I looked up how much 47 British Pounds was in US dollars, after seeing it was over $70, I decided to buy it. I cannot say anything about how well it works, as it is a present, and I dont want to activate it. I was a little surprised when it arrived, it looked smaller than I expected, and the metal wasn't as shiny as in the picture, but for the price, that's OK, as long as it works is all that matters, it doesn't look bad. I'm glad I bought it.***UPDATE*** I recently found out that my grandson loves his new watch!
This is the perfect height for spaghetti, and is great for cereal, cookies, dried milk powder and a lot of other things, and it is air and water tight, and can can be used in the freezer too.

I purchased this foot for my New Home Combi DX 502, which I've had for several years, but it only had metal feet, I found it difficult to do some projects without a clear see through foot.Even though I've been sewing for many years, I didn't know much about different machines and their feet. I just found out mine has a 'Low Shank', and this foot would fit on, not only my old 'New Home' sewing machine, but also my new Brother electronic machine I recently purchased. I tried this foot on the New Home and the Brother machine, and I'm thrilled that it fits them both.I also bought a walking foot, now I'm excited to begin some new projects, which should be a lot easier with the new feet.

I bought this book after buying tiny dolls (like in this book) on Ebay. I've seen some of the little outfits from this book, or similar,for sale on Ebay too. If you are good at this crocheting very small items, this could be a money maker for you.Sadly, I'm more of a knitter, and new to crochet, I'm trying to learn, but finding it difficult on my own. I'm hoping that when I get better at it, I'll be able to make some of these adorable outfits, for my tiny dolls.

I bought this gas mask two years ago (May 2012) in the event of an impending catastrophic emergency. I paid $35.00, feeling a little foolish at the time, but I actually used it recently for something I hadn't planned on, and without the filter that came with it. I have really terrible allergies, especially to pollen and dust. I felt a bit silly, but tried it anyway; there was no one around to laugh at me!After I got it on, I had to adjust the straps slightly, as it was a little loose, it was easy to get it nice and snug on my face. It felt a bit strange at first, but got used to it after a while, it never steamed up as I feared it would.I'm happy to report, I never sneezed once, during or after vacuuming in the closet, unlike the times before, when I suffered miserably for days. Now I don't have to worry next time I have to be in a dusty atmosphere.

This is my first Lenox purchase, I knew when I ordered this set, it would be good quality, as I've seen other items on their site. They arrived very well packaged in a nice box, and as expected I loved them when I opened the box. They are excellent quality, a good size for a tree, and look exactly like in the picture. I cannot wait to hang them on the tree at Christmas.I saw the same sets on Ebay, most were more expensive, one a little less, but with the shipping, it would have been more expensive,  no tax or shipping here, this is the best price. You won't be disappointed.

I recently ordered these spoons to go with a beautiful modern espresso set. I wasn't quite sure about the shape, but when I saw the quality, I was glad I purchased them. They look great with my little espresso cups and saucers. I also bought a Cuisinox Stainless steel sugar bowl from Amazon which is quite small, and has a ladle shaped little spoon in it, these espresso spoons fit in it too.Stainless Steel 12.oz Sugar Bowl with Black Knob**UPDATE**I've found a new use for the spoons, they are small enough to scoop out small amounts from my spice and herb jars.

A couple of years ago I was happy to find good  rechargeable batteries after reading reviews on Amazon, they were quite expensive, so you can imagine how very happy I was to find these highly rated batteries by Amazon for a less expensive price. Great purchase.

This is my first ricer, I bought it because it wasn't too expensive and it was recommended by America's Test Kitchen. I'm used to lumpy potato and thought I'd spoil myself and buy this.I used it yesterday for the first time. I filled it up completely with potato, but it was hard to use. I took half out and it was much easier. I was amazed to see my plate pile up with potato that looked like grated cheese coming out! I'm going to love this thing. It was very easy to clean, I washed it by hand, then stood it up, just to make sure there was no water trapped inside, after reading a reviewer's comment about that happening. I wish I bought this thing a long time ago. I'm so happy I will no longer be eating lumpy mashed potato!

I came across this cake pan after purchasing the 'America's Test Kitchen Complete Cooking for Two' cook book. I needed a 6" cake pan and was happy to find one exactly the right size. I used it the other day for the first time. I greased the inside of the pan and put parchment paper on the bottom. After the cake was done I used a silicone knife to loosen the sides. It stuck to the sides a bit, but it cleaned up OK after a soak in warm soapy water. It served its purpose, I'm glad I bought it, can't wait to use it again.

I'm not experienced at making good coffee, but I wanted to be good at it, normally I use instant! After purchasing an espresso maker, along with an attractive set of espresso cups and saucers, I decided to buy this milk frother. It's beatiful, like in the picture, nice and shiny and looks fantastic with my new 'Cuisinox Stainless Steel Sugar Bowl' I received from Amazon yesterday.Stainless Steel 12.oz Sugar Bowl with Black KnobThe first time I used the frother, it was with low fat milk made from milk powder. It  was a total disaster, it didn't make any froth at all.I was determined to make it work (after all, the reviews said it did). I tried it again yesterday, but this time I used a really nice organic full fat milk. I heated a small cup of milk in the microwave, then poured it in the frother, I couldn't believe how frothy it went, and so quick. I ended up with a really delicious, thick dense creamy foam (which didn't go away) floating nicely on top of the coffee.**Update** I recently had success using a half a cup of evaporated milk, mixed with almost the same amount of water, it worked great, perfect for when you haven't got fresh milk.  This frother looks like it will last a long time, I can't wait to experiment using froth in desserts too.

I love the smell of coconuts, that's why I chose this. The sunblock I had been using smelled really awful. This is a pleasure to use, smells fantastic and is nice and creamy.  Instead of hating spreading the smelly sunblock on my body, now I cannot wait to put this on. Fantastic.

The shirt is very comfortable and fits perfectly.  Some have wrote about the fit not being right and I feel if the best fit is desired, then a tape measure will go far in helping with the correct size.  fox Head gear has a proper sizing chart available on their website where you can choose the best size for your dimensions. No two manufactures are alike when it comes to fit, so it should be expected that one brand offering a large should fit the same as another brand - that would be a perfect world.What I like most about the short other than style is the material. The material stays fresh smelling after 2.5 hours of riding. Compared to my other sports shirts not made of cotton, that's a great benefit.The shirt is not a tight fitting shirt like the roadies and does offer some breathing room.Message created on a smart phone. Please read through the replaced words - it's to difficult to go back and review my review.

Not every shoe fits everyone the same way, but these shoes fit me perfectly and they are so comfortable compared to any other and especially my last pair of Specialized shoes.Shoes arrived with two sets of lugs and a lug wrench.A performance review will be added at a later time. Today's date is 9-30-2014

I bought this for my son to cover his dorm bed and after testing for a few days, his comment was:  "I most certainly love it".That's welcoming news because I based the purchase off other reviews and this is a type of item which is probably best to buy at a local store.Most kids don't care about how such things look, but I did ask him and he said it just looks like a big piece of rectangular foam under his sheet. For the price and his approval, I am certainly happy with my decision and other reviewers comments.

So, how does this product compare against "Hammermill Inkjet Paper, 96 Brightness, 24lb, 8-1/2 x 11, White, 500 Sheets/Ream"?For the purposes of printing up office flyers and other everyday items you would like to present to others at the office - it's about the same.HP is a much whiter paper than the hammermill and colors appear to be brighter than hammermill which appears to print deeper colors. It's more noticeable as the paper drys.My printer is an edge to edge memjet and most of what I print is full color, so, if white borders and open white open areas are important to you, then HP is probably the best to go with. However, if printing full color, I would recommend Hammer Inkjet.Basically, the decision should come down to price - both brands use the same weight and one feels as flimsy as the other and unless you are holding both pieces side by side, I don't think any differences would be noticed.This is good proof paper prior to using a Heavy Flyer paper.

So, how does this product compare against "Hammermill Inkjet Paper, 96 Brightness, 24lb, 8-1/2 x 11, White, 500 Sheets/Ream"?For the purposes of printing up office flyers and other everyday items you would like to present to others at the office - it's about the same.HP is a much whiter paper than the hammermill and colors appear to be brighter than hammermill which appears to print deeper colors. 0:40 MinsI am using this to drill through glazed ceramic flower pots to allow water to pass through and I would like to include a few tips being that everyone else has already said how great these hole saws cut.Being a hole saw without a pilot drill, follow these tips for cutting on a slippery surface: 1) Begin drilling on an angle until the surface has been scratched enough to hold the hole saw in place. Don't try an force the drill straight down from the angled cut, but slowing bring it square with the surface.2) no special oils are required, simply use any vegetable oil by dipping the drill bit in the oil every few seconds or when the surface begins to appear dry. vegetable oil may also be applied to the groove if it is the preferred method. Be creative and keep the drill wet.Some have mentioned that the larger bit is difficult to use,, once again, hold the drill on an angle to scratch surface. Yes, the drill may jump a little, but eventually the groove will appear and you can slowly begin squaring off the drill. The groove will hold it in place as the drill is brought upright. - adjust RPM's to find the best speed.I will try and post a video for additional info.

Updated 11/9/20155 star for print speed while new - 1 star for output - two stars to get your attention before buying. 1) high speed printing 2) nice colors on proper paper.The problems: 1) first, my printer was replaced by memjet direct and the problems are the same. 2) Label Printing. C6010 is an edge to edge printer, however both machines printed crooked. Perfect on the top and off by 1/4 inch at bottom. It's not a true edge to edge. 3) Labels, you will never hit center on the labels because of crooked printing. See pic and look at top left label position compared to lower left position. 4) My machine has slowed to a crawl. Of course it's out of warranty.Best use: Proofing for print shops. It's too expensive to maintain for a poor output printer.I wouldn't recommend this machine to anyone. Epson business printers do a much better job for $150 or so. Of course print speed is sacrificed. If memjet would license it's technology to the big boys, printing would change forever - they created an amazing printhead, but they are not in the paper feeding business.Here's the scoop.The printer is amazing and it's fast. Be sure to use high quality inkjet paper for best brochure results..Okay,, now that you own the best printer on the market; where do you get it serviced? Well, I learned today that memjet does not offer any support or any type of warranty unless you purchase from a dealer who will service you. Which means, you are stuck with a very expensive printer if you should have a problem. Now, I've owned many business class printers including very high end lexmarks and epson commercial printers, along with a 42 inch wide canon and ever one of those companies offers support to their customers regardless of where you bought it from - they know by the serial number when it was purchased. So be careful,, enjoy this amazing printer, which in fact it is. The problem I am facing is that all my edge to edge print jobs are crooked whether it's printing from the manual tray or automatic tray.

Others have already written so much about this book and I am not about to compete. However, this is a good read for both salesman and business people alike - not everyone will take away the same understanding as I did, but that is what makes this book so amazing,, everyone will take away something different.

Perfect fitting sock and it is my sock of choice when running on the single track trails. As for me, I choose to use this sock all year round. The sock provides a proper amount of traction between your foot and the insole and it wicks away moisture better than any other running sock I own.I've used these socks for mountain biking a few times, then one day I came across another pair designed specifically for biking which I really enjoyed - therefore, I wouldn't recommend this sock as a multi purpose sock.Everyday I am amazed at how specific all activewear apparel has become and much more noticeable once the sport becomes a part of your lifestyle.

This paper is as good as Epson Brochure and Flyer Paper Matte Double-Sided (S042384) - but the price is very high for a "Single Sided" injet paper.It's my fault that I didn't read closely enough to learn that this is a Single Sided paper, but I won't kill the rating for that.. Just be careful, if you aren't familiar with how paper works (I don't), but from my understanding, a treatment is applied to either one side or both sides of the paper and you will notice a completely Dull print if you happen to print on the wrong side of the paper.

I'm new to mountain biking and I wanted a well made pedal and one which was easy to disconnect from my shoe. This is a low profile pedal and it holds me in perfectly on climbs, but most importantly, it will release with very little effort. That's especially good for a newbie during the confidence building period. The shoe does come with a multi directional release clip.

This is a german made product which is very well made.Not much to say other than the ratchet works perfectly and a good amount of torque can be applied before using the torque wrench.The ratchet is packed with my biking gear on every ride.

This product is very easy to install if you can fit under the kitchen sink. Watch the video posted by 3M and you should have no problem.About the product:Like any filter, it delivers fresh tasting water - but in some cases, your water will not taste fresh even with a million dollar filter. Why? Because this filter is behind the spout and not in front. If you have a bit of plumbing experience, remove your kitchen spout to inspect and you should find a lot of growth inside the spout - which your water will pass through before it begins to fill your glass.I recently replaced my kitchen faucet and after careful inspection of the old faucet spout, I discover that the bad flavor (which I thought was city water) was from the build up of minerals and possibly mold within the spout itself.The filter works great and I will now inspect the spout once a year and either clean the inside or replace it as necessary. Keep in mind, the hot water is not filter and there is a good chance that the spout will develop deposits in the future.

No complaints about this product. It's a two part cover which I feel will absorb more G's from a drop. It's much thinner than some of the big names and it does not overlap the screen - the screen can be accessed from any point. Some other's make it very difficult to use the entire iPhone screen.Screen cover is not included; then again, I've never used a screen protector.

The weather was cool enough to try out this amazing hat. The start temperature was about 37 degrees and 90 minutes later it was 33 degrees and the hat kept me warm for the entire night trail ride.The cap is a double layer with a very soft inside. It fits comfortably and kept both my head and ears warm.

Update: 1/6/2014After exchanging my initial purchase for a new light and battery; I am not achieving a 3 hour burn time on high. My battery will last for about 90 minutes, so I am looking into purchasing an additional battery pack or perhaps a second unit. It's an awful feeling losing light while on a night trail ride.The light is everything you can ask for at a low price. However, while trail riding at night, the connector pulled apart several times from vibration and the light turned off twice in 60 minutes from vibrations. If you are choosing this light for the purpose of trail riding at night and the trails are loaded with obstacles, then this might not be the best light for you.Negatives: 1) Ride time 90 minutes - battery lasted about 63 minutes. 2) Connector pulled apart on several occasions - use tape if you are buying this based on price 3) Light failed twice from hitting too many obstacles - failing on a trail ride at night is not acceptable and can be dangerous.On the bright side: 1) lights up everywhere you need to see. 2) light weight and simple to install. 3) charging indicator (Red - needs charging and Green - battery is ready) 4) Low price - but I would recommend purchasing two if you plan to trail ride for more than an hour. My guess is that I received someone else's defective item because the package appeared to have been previously opened and the contents appeared to have been used. I would like to hear back from others about battery time before I repurchase this item.

The light has many settings and it's very sensitive to touch - so it might turn on when you were not expecting it to.. I have a mountain bike with a larger seat post and it does not fit, so I've attached it to another area of my bike. I'm not too worried about where it is mounted because it will only be used for nighttime trail riding and never on the road.

Everything about this game speaks value and quality. The box is lined with felt, the wood is made of wood and the top slides in a groove. The dominos are excellent and have a good weight ( they don't feel cheap).There are no instructions for the game - but does anyone need Chickenfoot instructions??? Check out instructions on YouTube or Google ChickenFoot instructions. It's a fun and entertaining game to play for the entire family.

This Work-Stand is top notch. Sure, it's not bike shop quality or designed to be used 8 hours a day; but it's good enough for home use. Check out my posted pictures.I was as cautious as the others about purchasing a "No Name" work-stand; being that it was from Amazon, I had no concerns about returning an item if I found it to be junk - this is not the case. All parts are high quality and some parts are made of durable plastic and I don't expect any to break - however, you can easily replace some parts with after market products.The stand had no problem holding my bike in any position and I found it to be very stable in any position.A word of caution - the quick release located on the geared turning mechanism only requires about a quarter turn of the handle before it disengages and if you don't have a good grip on the bike at the same time as its released - serious injury could occur.

Updated Review: Although the Topeak pump is well built, it does require heavy pushing compared to a more expensive pump. I've since returned the Topeak and purchased a Specialized pump designed for Mountain Bike Tires and the difference in pumping action is night and day. My new pump feels effortless in comparison. In all fairness, the topeak pump which I received could have been defective - you can be the judge. Since receiving my Specialized pump, I have also found it to be much easier to use when securing over either of the two valve types, "Presta and Schrader"Topeak is a good brand, it just didn't work for me and I wish that it had - the price was right. The specialized pump is about $25.00 more and it was worth it to me, but it might not be worth it to others.Previous review: Maybe I'm doing something wrong, but the pump requires so much effort to put air through a Presta Valve. I also own a pump made by specialized and I don't use that much effort when pumping 100 pounds into a tire - problem is, I gave it to my son and purchased this pump to save money.Just spoiled I guess - but I will most likely return the pump and spend the big bucks on a new specialized pump.

This is an awesome book!  The characters were likeable and relatable, and I cared deeply about what they were going through.  I was touched by the sweetness of Sean and Natasha's relationship.  There was just the right amount of action, romance, and humor.  I furiously turned (well, swiped really, lol) the pages, with my heart pounding, dying to know how it all came out in the end!  I would LOVE to read future works by this author!**I received a complimentary copy from the author through LibraryThing in exchange for an honest review.**

This microwave didn't even last for 3 months!  It turns on and the turntable rotates, but it doesn't get hot.  The seller, Shop Chimney, went out of their way to refund my money when the manufacturer didn't even return my calls!  I really appreciate their great customer service and I would definitely do business with them again!!

I answered the author's query asking for people to read and provide an honest review in exchange for a complimentary copy of this book.  It sounded right up my alley as someone who loves alien invasion and YA novels.  But I found this story very hard to get into.  I kept picking it up and putting it down.  Now that I've finished it I think I would have enjoyed it so much more if I was an actual "Young Adult"!  There was a lot of romance in this book, which was sweet and would definitely be appreciated by a younger audience.  Personally, I would've preferred much more information about the aliens' invasion, and the timeline of the attacks.

This book, which takes place 300 years before Legacy Code, introduces us to Selene, her brother Eli, and their "Nan".  Selene and Eli are "Protecteds", which in essence means they will never get sick.  Selene considers herself and Eli to be more defective than protected.  We learn that the three of them have been living "off-grid" for the past 8 years, and they are very self-sufficient - canning lots of food so they won't be affected by food shortages.  Selene worries that they will be found, but we're not told much about how or why they became Protecteds, why Selene feels defective, or who may be looking for them.  This was an enjoyable quick read and I'm hoping the next installment will shine light on these questions.**I received a complimentary copy from the author in exchange for an honest review**

At first I didn't think I would enjoy this book, but I'm so glad I continued reading it!  The main characters were likeable and I found myself rooting for them!  I could totally see myself reacting the same way Era did to her difficult circumstances.  I would recommend this book to anyone who enjoys "Star Treky" sci-fi.**SPOILERS AHEAD** The ending was so sad!  First Dritan gets killed in a mining accident and then poor Era is murdered for committing treason.  The stage is set for a sequel and I'm looking forward to finding out what happens next!  I so hope that the colonists discover the secret about the defect.  Getting that information out meant so much to Era that she was willing to die over it.  It would be so very sad if she died in vain.

I  LOVED this book!  It was emotionally intense, suspenseful, and so very touching and beautiful at the end.  I cannot remember the last time a book brought me to tears.  I enjoyed the author's writing style and had to read many passages more than once because they were beautifully written.  For those who have not had the pleasure of reading this book yet:  Be prepared to feel a whole gamut of emotions and an OMG I NEVER SAW THAT COMING at the end!  I agree with the other reviewers who said they were surprised that this is the author's debut novel; it could certainly stand up to any established author's works.I received a complimentary copy from the author through LibraryThing in exchange for an honest review.
I received 2 deodorants packaged together and while they smell really nice, one of them doesn't wind up when I twist the bottom.  I'm very disappointed...

What a cool app!  It's really beautiful and mesmerizing.  You can sit back and enjoy the show or play a few games which involve tapping or swiping to set the fireworks off.  I'm so glad I discovered this!!

This book was not my cup of tea.  I stopped reading at about page 50.  I found it very slow-moving with too much emphasis on minute details that weren't necessary for plot or character building.  Yes, I wanted to know what was in that darn box,  but not badly enough for me to finish reading it.* I received a complimentary copy from the author through LibraryThing in exchange for an honest review.

I had previously reviewed the X-Mini ll XAM4-S Portable Capsule Speaker, and it sounded amazing to me, that is until I received this Alpatronix model.  This one blows the X-Mini out of the water!  The sound is crisp and clear & I love that there's no distortion when played very loud.  Pairing it to my Kindle Fire HDX via Bluetooth was a cinch, and I had never used Bluetooth before.  It's heavier than the X-Mini and feels more solid & of a much higher quality.  And I love that you can listen to it while it's charging.  This speaker comes with a 1 year warranty (you just have to register it on Alpatronix.com), but since I had purchased the X-Mini speakers from Amazon.com and not the manufacturer, they didn't come with a warranty at all.

Great for filling in a void with weight when you're a few grams short at weigh in.  I bring 3 things to weigh in: A drill to remove material if I'm over, this putty for if I'm under and graphite for one last lube, particularly if I had to do a lot of drilling.

I feel stupid for saying it, but I thought I was getting a steal but I wasn't:I was shopping for "bulk" tungsten because I've got 3 kids in cub scouts making pinewood derby cars for the next 5 years and $20 a pop for the pinewood derby package of tungsten adds up.  I could have done the math, but I didn't, trusting the weight listed: 2 lbs.  But that's shipping weight and it in fact only weights 8 oz. or so.  All of a sudden $50 to the door wasn't such a good deal (compared $60 or so for 9 oz in the pinewood kits).

These things used to cost $30 with the 30-pin devices.  Somehow they went up to $70 for the new iPhone 5 lightning connector.  And they're not meaningfully better than the only 30-pin ones.  We bought this Sony one for my son's iPod touch and it's fine, but I have a hard to justifying to myself why it costs more than twice as much as the 30-pin model sitting right next to it for my elder son's older iPod touch model.

As others have mentioned, they swapped out the launch pad in the picture with a lower end, but acceptable, launch pad.  But it really does come with most everything you need as a starter kit except the consumables.  Here's what you'll need to fly:GlueScissorsPencilA small sharp knife (like an exacto)A 9V batteryA pack of standard Estes motors (I suggest: A8-5, B6-6, C6-7)A pack of igniters (usually comes with the Estes motors)A pack wadding (special tissue-like paper that goes between the motor and the chute)My son and I were able to assemble everything in an hour or two (using gel crazy glue for fast drying).  It was really easy if you carefully read the directions.WARNING TO CALIFORNIANS:  Please, please, PLEASE be aware of the laws in CA for launching rockets.  You need explicit permission of your local fire marshal and the property owner as well as meeting a bunch of other laws.  In practice that means you'll probably need to find a rocket club with launching privileges to be able to launch legally.  Many launch illegally without a problem, but please note it is a $1000 fine for EACH launch if a cop decides to nail you.  There are horror stories of unaware parents getting multi-thousand dollar fines as a cop watched as they launched a handful of times without incident from the local park.  It's up to you if you want to take the risk, but I'd hate for people to be unaware of how pricey the risk they are taking could be.
Nothing incredible, but a good value.  Looks like they will stand the test of time.  They fit my relatively short / small 6 year old boy just fine.
Came with one angel with a broken wing due to bad packaging from the manufacturer.  I was able to glue it together and it looks fine, but frustrating nonetheless.

One bulb smoked the instant I put it in and turned in the light.  The other was just what I was looking for.  If there ends up being a lot of reviews saying this, stay away.  On the other hand, I could have just had rare a bad box.

I used this to make a nose cone for a model rocket.  I can confirm what other reviewers said about the packaging being a bit sub-optimal for preventing scratches.  It should have had some wrapping and then some filler in the shipping tube to both prevent it being scratched and from rattling around in the round shipping sleeve.  However, the scratches on mine were VERY minor.  In fact, most of what appeared to be scratches, was really just lint/dirt/dust that appeared magnified through the clear plastic.  A quick wash with water got rid of most of it.Others have mentioned material quality issues.  Mine had no voids or chips.  When I ground it down to the shape I wanted for the rocket, and then polished it to a smooth finish, it was obvious how consistent the material was.  No bubbles or voids at all.  (not to brag, but it looked awesome)Finally, the sticker.  Yeah, it's the type where the glue is stronger than the paper and getting it off without leaving a sticky mess would be a pain.  I didn't particularly care or try to get it off since I was grinding it down, but the Simple Green suggestion in another review seems worth a try for those who do care.

Looks from the reviews like for a while it was labeled as 3/16 not 3/32.  By the time I bought it, it was properly labeled, which was good because I was looking for the thinnest possible shock-cord with a polyester cover.  This is the smallest I could find and it's quality is pretty darned good.  Would love if I could find something even smaller, but as of now, this is the winner.

I was looking for a watch for my "tweener" son.  He doesn't want some pop-icon watch, which just about all the watches of the size that fit him are.  So we browsed Amazon for watches with 28mm-30mm cases.  Lots of women's watches (and looked it), but very few unisex or mens.That's why we were excited about this watch, which is listed as a 30mm diameter case.Except when it showed up in the mail, it was clearly too big, coming in at 35mm.  So it's going back.Otherwise a nice enough looking watch (hence the 3 stars, not 1).

I got two samples of this product, one black, one white, a few months ago and finally got around to testing them.  USB chargers are a difficult product category because the USB spec was never designed for the current/amps (and thus wattage) that today's products require.  In a desire to not damage computers, most high current/amp devices have special chargers that have the signal wires configured in a special way.  That way, when the device connects to their charger, they'll know they can draw all the current they want.  When they don't see the signal cables properly configured, they only draw what the USB spec allows, thus preventing them from damaging that charger (or computer).It's a fine solution to a tough problem, but unfortunately some of these signal wire configurations are directly contradictory to each other, (specifically Apple vs everyone else) leaving 3rd party chargers in a bind.  They can't support all devices easily, even though they all use the same plug.  The result is that lots of chargers don't charge lots of devices at full potential.To learn more about the particulars of this, see my previous review of the 10 watt PowerGen charger here:http://www.amazon.com/review/R1BSQFGYMS2DCH/ref=cm_cr_rdp_permThe PowerGen line has solved this problem by having each of their ports configured differently.  This was true on the older 10 watt and remains true for this newer edition.  The result is if you use the correct port, this device will work with more devices than any charger I know of.  If you've got just about any Apple device you're covered.  It'll cover almost all Android phones and many of the tablets, but some of the special tablets, it won't.As yet another bonus, this edition improves on the older 10 watt version with a more visible and appropriate labeling... "A" for Apple products and "NA" for non-Apple products.  On the previous 10 watt version it wasn't very obvious and was somewhat misleading being "2A" and "A".The other area where the new charger excels, and brings itself up with the best in the market, is the mechanical design of the product, particularly on the part that plugs into the 12V adapter in the car.  The older 10 watt product was a bit slippery and over time the vibration of being in a car would make it back out and lose its connection.  This one is a better design and I've left it in my truck for months now without issue.Back to device compatibility, based on my testing, their specs of what it'll work with are accurate.  It charged both my Android phones as "AC" devices and my iPod touch and classic.  It also does NOT work with my HP Touchpad, which is specifically mentioned in the specs.It would be nice if it would work with the oddballs in addition to the mainstream, but seeing how it does better than any other device I know, and I've tested 6 now, it gets strong marks from me here.(NOTE: the rest of the review was updated on 4/13/13, based on testing a new device from Anker that exposed some weaknesses in my test bench. As a result, I went back and re-tested this product):This product has yet another impressive feature.  All of the other products I have previously tested bridge the power between their ports, including the older 10 watt PowerGen unit.  However, this unit has independent power for both rails.  (for the techies out there: I tested this with resistive loads, and the voltage would only drop on the rails I heavily loaded and have no affect on the other rail's voltage or abilty to generate current.)This is good, because one device won't affect the other.  If you're charging your high-power phone and then you plug in your tablet, the phone's charging will be uninterrupted and not be slowed.  That's very nice and something the other products won't provide.In addition, there is some sort of load balancing going on between the ports.  I can push either port to 2.2 amps and stay well within the USB spec'ed voltage value (greater than 4.75 volts).  When I then tried drawing that much current from both ports, it went into it's auto-protection mode (that's a good thing, as it prevents the device from being damaged, as 4.4 amps/21 watts is beyond its capabilities) and the status LED started blinking to indicate this.I then tried multiple combinations to see how much I could draw without going into auto-protection and I found as long as I kept it below 3.2 amps combined (over 16 watts) it would keep running like a champ.  So, based on my latest testing this device can power just about any tablet in one port and just about any phone in the other, with one caveat:  They can't be both from the same OS.  You can have an Android phone and an iPad or you can have an iPhone and a Android tablet like the Samsung Galaxy, but you can't have an iPhone and and iPad because you can't configure both ports to support the same set of devices.Nevertheless, until somebody creates a dual port device where both ports are configurable for Apple or Android, this is the best car charger on the market right now and gets 5 stars.

A quick overview of this product before I get down into the details...This product, in unaltered form, suffers from a couple problems:1. Despite what the description says, it's designed for Apple products, not for other products like Android. I find the description quite deceptive because it will NOT deliver the current one expects for most Android devices (or the HP Touchpad as well).2. While it claims a 2.1A port and a 1A port, implicitly suggesting 3.1A total, it can not actually deliver 3.1A no matter what device you have (including Apple).  It delivers a total of 2.1A.However, by cracking open the case and shorting the data lines, something VERY easy to do with this device if you're at all competent with a soldering iron, you get an awesome unit for Android devices, and it's THE ONLY ONE (that I've found), that will charge an HP Touchpad at full capacity (more details below).Now to the details...A little background on USB charging for those who don't know:The USB power spec is for 0.5 Amps at 5 Volts... or 2.5 Watts. This was great up until the last couple years when devices have gotten really power hungry, particularly smartphones and tablets and to a lesser extent dedicated GPS's. Some of these devices use over 2 Amps, particularly the tablets like the iPad (or in my case the HP Touchpad).Manufacturers of these devices therefore had a dilemma. If they had their devices pull more than 0.5 Amps, they risked damaging the power source, which could be a computer, that was only prepared to source 0.5 Amps. Thus the manufacturers have used tricks to determine whether their device is connected to an unknown source, at which point they purposely only draw 0.5 Amps, or to the dedicated charger that was provided with the device, where they can draw all the power they need.There seem to be two common tricks used. The first is to short the two data-wires together in the charger. This is what most non-Apple devices do. Since a computer or older device wouldn't have done this, the device can assume it is safe to draw all the power it needs.Apple seems to have taken a different approach, one that I don't fully understand but know can be seen by the fact that the data lines are neither open nor shorted when the charger is plugged in, and is more sophisticated and probably superior, because I suspect it allows the device to know exactly how much power it can use.While Apple taking a better approach might be nice in concept, it's created chaos in the USB charger product category. What is the non-specific charger to do? They can't support both.This device chose to go the Apple route for both ports. While the PowerGen unit I purchased (see below for links to the others I've purchased) had the 1 Amp port setup for Android (data lines shorted) and the 2 Amp port for Apple, this device, like the others, has both setup for Apple. I don't own any high-power Apple devices, so I can't say for sure, but I suspect this unit performs well with Apple devices out of the box.But because I had bought 4 of these and they all had the same problem (except the PowerGen, which only had it on one port), I decided it was time to get down and dirty and see if I could open any of them up and modify them by shorting the data lines.  This was the ONLY ONE that was easy to open without damaging the casing.  Just unscrew the silver cap at the top and then pop off the silver plate on the bottom and it easily splits apart.  Then there are two sets of 4 pins, one on either side of the circuit board that runs up the middle that are somewhat obviously the pins to the USB port.  A solder blob on the middle two pins to short them together is all that is needed.  It took longer for the old soldering iron to warm up than to do both sides.  Reassembling took a bit of careful placement of the parts, but it wasn't too difficult and then all that's required is pushing back on the bottom plate and re-screwing in the cap.  The whole operation took 5 minutes.It bears repeating:  NONE of the others were easy to get apart.When I tested it afterwards, it performed beautifully with my android devices, just like I expected from my above explanations.  I got an additional bonus that I didn't expect with the HP Touchpad that requires some additional explanation.See, the HP Touchpad, while it's charger has the data lines shorted, also does something else.  It requires a specific voltage be on the data lines.  Thus it doesn't work with chargers that just have the data lines shorted, including the PowerGen mentioned in this review.There is a way to modify a charger further to get it to work with the HP Touchpad, by adding resistors to one's charger, but frankly, that was more work than I was willing to do.  However, whether it was luck or genius, the 1 Amp port on this device already has some resistive elements for the Apple charger setup, and when one shorts the data lines together, it gives the required voltage for the HP Touchpad to charge.  NICE FREE BONUS!Now, because this device can only source 2.1 Amps total, it'll be a little overpowered if you connect both the HP Touchpad (or an iPad for that matter) and a smartphone, but even when I did that, it continued to charge, just perhaps a bit more slowly than it would have if it could deliver all the current each desired.And it bears repeating that this is THE ONLY DEVICE I am aware of that can fully charge an HP Touchpad (after modification).Thus this device gets docked to 4 stars because it claims out of the box to support a number of Android devices that will not work as expected without modifying the device.  I suspect it will work well with Apple devices including the iPad (I don't own any).  It also gets dinged because of the deceptive amperage claims.Frankly, I am a bit uncomfortable giving 4 stars for something that requires modification to meet my needs, but because all the devices I tested have the same problem it made it easier to give it a 4 considering the ease of the modification and the nice bonus of the HP Touchpad charging.For those who don't have Apple devices, I ordered three additional devices:- "PowerGen Dual USB 2A Heavy Duty Ouput Car Charger" (http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00622AG6S/ref=oh_o06_s00_i00_details)- "Kensington K33497US PowerBolt Duo Car Charger" (http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B003PU01M4/ref=oh_o03_s00_i00_details)- XTG "Ultra Compact High Output Dual USB Car Charger" (http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00470C35E/ref=oh_o02_s00_i00_details)I have written a review on each of them with more details.I kept this one after the above modification and the PowerGen in unmodified form and returned the Kensington and the XTG.

This product suffers from the same problem many USB chargers do: It's designed for Apple products, not for other products like Android.  I find the description quite deceptive because it will NOT deliver the current one expects for most Android devices (or the HP Touchpad as well).A little background on USB charging for those who don't know:The USB power spec is for 0.5 Amps at 5 Volts... or 2.5 Watts. This was great up until the last couple years when devices have gotten really power hungry, particularly smartphones and tablets and to a lesser extent dedicated GPS's. Some of these devices use over 2 Amps, particularly the tablets like the iPad (or in my case the HP Touchpad).Manufacturers of these devices therefore had a dilemma. If they had their devices pull more than 0.5 Amps, they risked damaging the power source, which could be a computer, that was only prepared to source 0.5 Amps. Thus the manufacturers have used tricks to determine whether their device is connected to an unknown source, at which point they purposely only draw 0.5 Amps, or to the dedicated charger that was provided with the device, where they can draw all the power they need.There seem to be two common tricks used. The first is to short the two data-wires together in the charger. This is what most non-Apple devices do. Since a computer or older device wouldn't have done this, the device can assume it is safe to draw all the power it needs.Apple seems to have taken a different approach, one that I don't fully understand but know can be seen by the fact that the data lines are neither open nor shorted when the charger is plugged in, and is more sophisticated and probably superior, because I suspect it allows the device to know exactly how much power it can use.While Apple taking a better approach might be nice in concept, it's created chaos in the USB charger product category. What is the non-specific charger to do? They can't support both.This device chose to go the Apple route for both ports.  While the PowerGen unit I purchased (see below for links to the others I've purchasd) had the 1 Amp port setup for Android (data lines shorted) and the 2 Amp port for Apple, this device, like the others, has both setup for Apple. I don't own any high-power Apple devices, so I can't say for sure, but I suspect this unit performs well with Apple devices. Using electronic equipment I was able to draw 3 Amps when putting a fixed load on either of the USB charging ports. However, when I connect any of the 3 high-power devices I have (HP Touchpad (2 Amps), Motorola Triumph Android phone (0.85 Amps) and the LG Optimus Slider (0.7 Amps)), none of them drew all the current they could have, because they were expecting a shorted set of data-lines.To be fair, I tested the device using power resistors to see how much power it could source.  It performed beautifully.  It performed better than any of the 4 I purchased (see below) sourcing well over 3 Amps without significant voltage droop.  It could source it no matter which port it was from, whether it was all 3 Amps from one port or the other, or a combination that added up to 3 Amps (2 Amps from the top port and 1 Amp from the bottom as the labels claims).  From that standpoint, if you have Apple products, I think you will be quite satisfied with this charger and would likely be the best choice for you (either this or the more expensive Kensington who's specs are better than this one, but in practice the deliver about the same current).Thus this device gets 3 stars because it claims to support a number of Android devices that, while I don't have the specific ones mentioned, I firmly believe they will not work as expected.  While I suspect it will work well with Apple devices including the iPad (I don't own any) I ended up returning it because it doesn't meet my needs as a non-Apple user.For those who don't have Apple devices, I ordered three additional devices:- "Bracketron Universal Dual USB Car Adapter (UGC-298-BL)" (http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B0056VNVV8/ref=oh_o00_s00_i00_details)- "PowerGen Dual USB 2A Heavy Duty Ouput Car Charger" (http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00622AG6S/ref=oh_o06_s00_i00_details)- "Kensington K33497US PowerBolt Duo Car Charger" (http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B003PU01M4/ref=oh_o03_s00_i00_details)I have written a review on each of them with more details.I returned both this one and the Kensington and kept the PowerGen in unmodified form and the Bracketron after I broke it apart and shorted the data lines to have it work.Neither this product, nor the Kensington were easily to open without damaging them, so they got returned, even though they had better power output (potential, not in practice) than the two I kept.  Such a shame.

This product has two major issues:1. While it's description claims it has a 2 Amp port and a 1 Amp port, the reality is that it has bridged the two ports and it can only source 2 Amps total.  It is not capable of delivering 3 Amps combined like the description implicitly claims and could never simultaneously charge an iPad and a smart phone.  (UPDATE:  The technical details section now indicates more clearly the 2A total, which is appreciated.)2. The 2 Amp port appears to be using the Apple protocol for USB power, so that port will only provide 0.5 Amps to most other devices.The upside of this is the 1 Amp port somewhat over delivers, and can source 2 Amps if nothing else is connected and 1.5 Amps if the 2 Amp port is sourcing 0.5 Amps for a non-Apple device.  Thus this product can support one-high power non-Apple device (in the 1 Amp port) and one lower power device (in the 2 Amp port).Now some more background/details...First, a little background on USB charging for those who don't know:The USB power spec is for 0.5 Amps at 5 Volts... or 2.5 Watts. This was great up until the last couple years when devices have gotten really power hungry, particularly smartphones and tablets and to a lesser extent dedicated GPS's. Some of these devices use over 2 Amps, particularly the tablets like the iPad (or in my case the HP Touchpad).Manufacturers of these devices therefore had a dilemma. If they had their devices pull more than 0.5 Amps, they risked damaging the power source, which could be a computer, that was only prepared to source 0.5 Amps. Thus the manufacturers have used tricks to determine whether their device is connected to an unknown source, at which point they purposely only draw 0.5 Amps, or to the dedicated charger that was provided with the device, where they can draw all the power they need.There seem to be two common tricks used. The first is to short the two data-wires together in the charger. This is what most non-Apple devices do. Since a computer or older device wouldn't have done this, the device can assume it is safe to draw all the power it needs.Apple seems to have taken a different approach, one that I don't fully understand but know can be seen by the fact that the data lines are neither open nor shorted when the charger is plugged in, and is more sophisticated and probably superior, because I suspect it allows the device to know exactly how much power it can use.While Apple taking a better approach might be nice in concept, it's created chaos in the USB charger product category. What is the non-specific charger to do? They can't support both.This device chose to go the Apple route for the 2 Amp port. I don't own any high-power Apple devices, so I can't say for sure, but I suspect this unit performs well with Apple devices. Using electronic equipment I was able to draw 2 Amps when putting a fixed load on this USB charging port. However, when I connect any of the 3 high-power devices I have (HP Touchpad (2 Amps), Motorola Triumph Android phone (0.85 Amps) and the LG Optimus Slider (0.7 Amps)), none of them drew all the current they could have, because they were expecting a shorted set of data-lines.Luckily for my purposes, the 1 Amp port on this device uses the data-line shorting method.  As such, it was able to deliver all the power my Triumph and Optimus wanted.  However, for some reason, even when it was the only device connected, it would not fully charge the HP Touchpad at the 2 Amps it could have, because for one reason or another, the HP Touchpad rejected it as a high power charger.To be honest, this surprised me because it was able to source the 2 Amps the Touchpad claims it needs and the HP Touchpad charger has the data-lines shorted.  So I'm not sure why this didn't work.Thus this device gets 3 stars (UDPATE: 4 stars) because it can source the current it claims (minus the somewhat deceptive 2A + 1A notation (UPDATE: Which is now more clear in the technical details)), would likely support an iPad like it claims, but falls short in other regards noted elsewhere.For non-Apple users, or even more so mixed users (say an iPad and an Android phone?) this device is superior to the other device I purchased, the "Kensington K33497US PowerBolt Duo Car Charger" (http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B003PU01M4/ref=oh_o02_s00_i00_details) because on that device, NEITHER port works with non-Apple devices (although it performed better power-wise, see my review over there for details).I've ordered two additional devices:- "Ultra Compact High Output Dual USB Car Charger - 2.1A Output" (http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00470C35E/ref=oh_o01_s00_i00_details)- "Bracketron Universal Dual USB Car Adapter (UGC-298-BL)" (http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B0056VNVV8/ref=oh_o00_s00_i00_details)Hopefully one of the two of them will be able to deliver to their specs for my devices.UPDATE: I've increased my review to 4 stars for two reasons:1. The changed technical details text makes it more clear its total power capacity.2. Of the 4 models I purchased, it's one of the two I kept and it's the only one I kept in unmodified form.  That's got to count for something. :)

A quick summary of this product before I get into the details:Likely great for dedicated Apple device users that has all the power it claims (simultaneously 2.1 Amps on one port with 1 Amp on the other for a total of 3.1 Amps output combined, but under performs DRAMATICALLY for non-Apple devices due to protocol issues for USB chargers.  It gets 3-stars because all it claims to support is Apple devices.Now for more details...A little background on USB charging for those who don't know:The USB power spec is for 0.5 Amps at 5 Volts... or 2.5 Watts.  This was great up until the last couple years when devices have gotten really power hungry, particularly smartphones and tablets and to a lesser extent dedicated GPS's.  Some of these devices use over 2 Amps, particularly the tablets like the iPad (or in my case the HP Touchpad).Manufacturers of these devices therefore had a dilemma.  If they had their devices pull more than 0.5 Amps, they risked damaging the power source, which could be a computer, that was only prepared to source 0.5 Amps.  Thus the manufacturers have used tricks to determine whether their device is connected to an unknown source, at which point they purposely only draw 0.5 Amps, or to the dedicated charger that was provided with the device, where they can draw all the power they need.There seem to be two common tricks used.  The first is to short the two data-wires together in the charger.  This is what most non-Apple devices do.  Since a computer or older device wouldn't have done this, the device can assume it is safe to draw all the power it needs.Apple seems to have taken a different approach, one that I don't fully understand but know can be seen by the fact that the data lines are neither open nor shorted when the charger is plugged in, and is more sophisticated and probably superior, because I suspect it allows the device to know exactly how much power it can use.While Apple taking a better approach might be nice in concept, it's created chaos in the USB charger product category.  What is the non-specific charger to do?  They can't support both.Kensington chose to go the Apple route for the 2.1 Amp port.  I don't own any high-power Apple devices, so I can't say for sure, but I suspect this unit performs well with Apple devices.  Using electronic equipment I was able to draw 2.1 Amps when putting a fixed load on this USB charging port.  However, when I connect any of the 3 high-power devices I have (HP Touchpad (2 Amps), Motorola Triumph Android phone (0.85 Amps) and the LG Optimus Slider (0.7 Amps)), none of them drew all the current they could have, because they were expecting a shorted set of data-lines.The 1 Amp port on this device is a bit of a quandry however.  It didn't have the signature on the data lines of either the Apple protocol or the shorted lines.  It appeared to have them open... which was a surprise and I believe a mistake (although I can't be certain with Apple products).  The results for my 3 devices however were identical to that of the 2.1 Amp port.To highlight the positives, I can say this, I was able to draw all the power the product claims it can source using fixed loads.  As my above explanation makes clear, it is the DEVICE, not the charger, that chooses not to make full use of the available current (Amps).  So by using power resistors I could test the actual capacity of the device without dealing with the data-line issue.As such, I was able to draw both 2.1 Amps from one port and 1 Amp from the other, simultaneously.  I can not say the same for the other charger I have tried (and I have two in shipment to test).Thus this device gets 3 stars because it only claims to support Apple devices and without any to test I have to assume it would work great for them.  It also can deliver the current it claims.  It is likely a 5-star product for sole apple users.However, for non-Apple users, I STRONGLY encourage you to look elsewhere for your Car USB power needs.  The other device I've tried is the "PowerGen Dual USB 2A Heavy Duty Ouput Car Charger" (http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00622AG6S/ref=oh_o05_s00_i00_details).  It has other problems (the 2A port doesn't have the data lines shorted and it only sources a TOTAL of 2A, not 2A on one port and 1A on the other), but at least one port (the 1A, which can really do 2A by itself, see my review over there for more details on that) on that has the data lines shorted to get the full power with non-Apple devices.I've ordered two additional devices:- "Ultra Compact High Output Dual USB Car Charger - 2.1A Output" (http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00470C35E/ref=oh_o01_s00_i00_details)- "Bracketron Universal Dual USB Car Adapter (UGC-298-BL)" (http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B0056VNVV8/ref=oh_o00_s00_i00_details)Hopefully one of the two of them will be able to deliver to their specs for my devices.

From the pictures, I thought I would raise a dragon and then be able to fly it and use fire breath to destroy things. I thought it would have an adventure along with it, but I was wrong. There is no real story line, the graphics are not great (not awful, either), and there is nothing to "advance" to do. There are no prizes to earn, or upgrades to get. The mini-games (stressing "mini") are not a real challenge. In short, after 3 minutes, I was done.IF you want to pass the time for a few minutes, download this as a FAOTD, but you will likely find yourself removing it from your device about ten minutes later. I would not recommend buying this app.

I enjoy "exploration" games where you move around and find various objects leading you through a story, so this is a very welcome FAOTD. This one is also very well done, with great detail given to ancient Greece history and mythological stories.The music fits the game (unlike many apps with a steady "drone" of music. Overall, a very well done game. The challenges themselves are mostly in the easy-average range, but there are a few that are particularly challenging. The great news is that you have unlimited hints to get you through.There do not seem to be any egregious permissions, although Facebook programming is embedded, it is not required in order to play.The only reason I deducted a star was that the file size is significant. Although you can move the game to an SD card, those of use with Kindle Fires don't have that luxury, so it does mean I have to watch the number of apps on my device.Still, it is a great game to pass the time so I definitely recommend this game!

I really like Othello and this app takes those rules and adds a new dimension - a three sided board, then lets you play in a variety of ways. You can play against the computer or a person with you in the room (passing the device back and forth) and have up to 4 players in the game (mixing computer and live players). There is also a new strategy element by creating a super triangle, which is kind of a "power up" if you an get four of your pieces to make a triangle.You can set the difficulty level when playing against the computer. The hard level IS a challenge. In the easy level, the computer often takes the third or fourth best choice turn, leaving you with a lot of opportunities to beat it if you have  a decent strategy.there are menu buttons that take you to the Amazon app store and the dev's website, but the good news is that I did not find any strange permissions and it passed a Lookout scan with no virus warnings.Overall, a great game! I highly recommend this, even if you don't get it as a FAOTD if you love Othello.

This is a small play set, but it was perfect for stuffing in my daughter's Easter basket. The toys are cute and she loves playing Sophia. If you are looking for a large castle, though, this is not it. The set itself is less than 12 inches wide, including all the pieces. There are other mini sets like this that can be played with together, but they don't connect. This is really great for little girls who love Sophia.

First - 1 star for no strange permissions and another for no IAPThe game play itself is a fun word search-type puzzle. You search for words in the tiles on the board, then rearrange letters to form a quote. The easy level is very, very, easy, but there is an option for a harder difficultly level. That seemed to be an "average" difficulty for most word search puzzles. It is a fun game. However, I'm not sure about the "Presidents" aspect. I would have expected more than quotes from the presidents, especially since some quotes seemed rather generic. I think it would be a great game if categorized as a general word game. It is worth the price, even if you miss out on the FAOTD.

OK, first the prosThere are no invasive permissions - automatic + 2 stars to all developers for this very important feature in a paid appYep, only two stars on this review means....The cons-There are only 20 puzzles-They are all at an easy level-If you want more puzzles, you need to pay for additional Sudoku apps-You can't customize the puzzles-There is nothing "different" about this app from a paper and pencil Sudoku book or even a free online search of SudokuI got a former FAOTD called Sudoku 10,000 while that app is more than this one, it offers MANY more options and puzzles than this app does. If I had not downloaded that app, this one would still be two stars, but knowing what is possible in apps, I would definitely not buy this one. It is simply too simple.

I love this app! I was on vacation with my family at a zoo over 100 miles from home. My phone was stolen out of my purse and I didn't notice it for a few minutes. When I realized it was gone, I went to the zoo's main office and was allowed to go to the lookout website where I tracked my phone - on its way to a town another 150 miles away.After it stopped moving, I contacted the police and was able to give a location thanks to the Lookout app. The police were able to go to the house and retrieve the phone. Within 48 hours from the time it was taken, it was in police custody.I recommend this app to anyone with a cell phone.It is also great for scanning files for malware and has caught one app with spyware.

My 5 year old loves My Little Pony. I figured the box was cute and would encourage her to brush if I got it with a My Little Pony toothbrush. I was right, but amazed at how much she wants to brush.She actually reminds ME it is time to brush with Pinkie Pie. She has no trouble getting up in the morning, and making sure to brush every day. I love the fact she is motivated to brush!The only reason I removed 1 star is that the tube of toothpaste is not large. Granted, kids should not use much more than a pea sized amount, but, even with that amount, the tube is gone relatively quickly. If your child is a big fan of My Little Pony, I highly recommend this toothpaste to encourage brushing, but by the multi-pack.

This is a cute game similar to Temple Run in that you are going through various scenes, avoiding obstacles, and collecting power ups. The graphics are nicely done and the game play is challenging (I think it can be too challenging for me, but my teen loves it).It is fun to play for a while and the tutorial is useful, but not overdone.The great news is I didn't find any spyware or a lot of excessive permissions. It does connect to Amazon's Game Circle for score listing and that means it does connect to the internet and has permissions to do so.The theme involves the concept of needing to get clean water to third world countries. Some may find this aspect annoying, but the game play is still good.My biggest problem is the size of the file. It takes up A LOT of space on my Kindle Fire HD. I needed to delete two smaller apps on the device (saving to the cloud for later) in order to play this. When I (or my kids) decide to play one of the other games, this will likely be placed in the cloud to save space on the device.Overall, a worthwhile app, but a very large file with some rather overt PC messages.

First, as far as safety is concerned, the app downloaded and was scanned by Lookout and found not to contain any spyware. - 1 star!There were no in app purchases that I could find! - 1 more star!You may at this point notice a total of two stars in the review.... that is because the game play itself is definitely not one I plan to use again. The front page opens with a menu of topics - but the language is not standard US English and it appears to have several areas where the words were mistranslated. For example, when you select a topic, you can choose from Adjectives, Verbs, Animals, and Substantives. OK, in law, "substantives" is used to explain the topic of "nouns" but why are Animals not part of the noun category?  A bit confusing, but something I could get used to, I guess.Then there is the set of directions, a button labeled "How it's played." The game is summarized in two sentences and the word "then" is incorrectly used instead of "than." Admittedly, I don't really need much to know how to play, but it is still disconcerting that a game designed to help with vocabulary does not know correct grammar.Next, there are buttons on the main page that give you an option to send an email with directions in a language I don't recognize. Another button sends you to the Google Play web site to buy the game --- if you bought it here, why is this necessary? A third button takes you to the Facebook page for the developer, but I couldn't see it properly on my Kindle Fire HD. I'm not sure why. This seems to be a game that was almost a free giveaway then changed at the last minute to be a single purchase game.During the game, you have the ability to select any letter, consonant or vowel as one of your guesses. If you are correct, the letter appears in the grid above the hangman image. If you are incorrect, you see more of the skeleton. I played the game several times and won a few and lost a few. I was rather annoyed that, if you do not solve the puzzle, you are not told what the word was. I also didn't like the message -"Damn it, they hanged you!" I can just see my teens telling me this phrase is acceptable since it is used in the game "for all ages." The idea that the character is a skeleton and not an 8 bit man is a bit strange enough, but I would really prefer to see at least the ending comment edited. Finally, if you win, you are given a "Congratulation" instead of a "Congratulations."The minor qualms I have with the game play theme, though, are nothing to the concerns I have with the overall language issues of this app. As a result, I would not recommend a purchase of it.

I really like the feel of this game. The graphics are beautiful, as is the music. There are no intrusive permissions!If you remember the 80's there used to be "electronic pets" called Tamagotchi that you would hatch and care for on a daily basis. To me, this is the same concept, but with much more advanced feel. In addition to simply "caring for" your pet, you get to decide what it eats, and therefore, what type of creature it becomes (carnivore/herbivore). By choosing this, your creature then develops and, with each new development, can achieve different options.It is strangely meditative at times to watch the little "embryo?" float around. This is not a game, per se, but it is entertaining. If you see it on the FAOTD, it is definitely worth the download. If not, it is worth its price. :)

8 GB memory, 1 TB hard drive, NVIDIA sound card and WINDOWS 7 - very stable OS - and all for only 500!All great features....but then it arrives and it gets a little less spectacular. The power supply does not seem to be sufficient for this system. As a result, it may fail, causing many other issues. The good news is that customer support is awesome. The machine was able to be replaced and hopefully there will be no further issues. The system is a really good one that is definitely worth the price, however, if you buy this, you might want to consider changing the power supply. This will add to the final cost, but may save a lot of headaches.

I really enjoy playing Flow Free and appreciate that the graphics do not require a tablet. I can pass the time waiting to pick up kids in the school parking lot by playing this on my phone, or spend time getting through the levels on the tablet at home.You CAN get through all the levels without paying anything, but there are in-app purchases available to get extra hints, themed colors, and getting to the extra levels before working all the puzzles before them. I have played this game as a free game for a lot of time and still enjoy it -without any purchases.Be aware that if you give this (or any app, really) to a child to play with, you will want to set up parental controls either on the device or with the Amazon store to avoid making purchases without permission.

I really enjoy nonagrams and have several apps from different developers. This one has a nice selection of puzzles related to the sports topic and very few permissions. I would really prefer not to have any permissions to connect to the internet, but I can see how it could be helpful for some interested in the newsletter/online tips.The games themselves are very straightforward and the directions are easy to understand (although the video narrator is a bit monotone if you check it out here on Amazon).Some of the pictures require a bit of imagination to see what they are with only the blocks, but the design of the actual game portion is well done.If you enjoy nonagrams, this is a great app, especially if you get it for the FAOTD.

Very cute pets, combined with easy to understand directions make this a keeper for my youngest. While there are not a lot of mini games like some other apps, this does give younger children a fun set of activities to keep them busy.I really appreciate the fact the developer also does not bloat the app with ad and spyware. There are no in app purchases, either.Overall, very worth the purchase for my preschooler, but older children may get bored with it quickly.

This app is cute...for about the 5 minutes you get to play it before you need to buy more time. You can't earn the stars without popping al the frogs and that can't be done in the time given.
