His murderer himself was abused, horrifically, and wants justice to be served.  The thing is, Father James is an innocent man, and this murderer knows this.  But wouldn’t the murder of an innocent priest make more of a statement, a cautionary impact, than the murder of a man everyone knew was corrupt?  So, with just a few days of life left to live, Father James goes about his business.  He doesn’t want to burden the ones he loves most, and so for the most part he keeps his impending death a secret and just continues with his commission.  He continues to make himself an integral part of his small seaside community, extending his hand to those in need and waiting out the inevitability of his future as he contemplates the man at the end of the gun.‘Calvary’ cuts.  It beautifully rests in this place that feels so natural and honest and so human and so when we watch Father James mediate through his day, we feel a part of his life, a part of his soul, and we understand him.  We collect the information of his past and of his emotional frailties and we begin to understand the construction of his present self, which makes this man so relatable.  He isn’t just a figment, a fraction of a being, an ideal with no name; but Father James is a man, an honest man, a man trying to be what he promised himself he’d become because of the man he used to be and longs to forget.And this is where ‘Calvary’ becomes more than just another movie about the Catholic Church and their history with child abuse.Yes, child abuse is mentioned more than once, and the allegations that continue to swarm the church are used as ammo against an honest man and his vocation, but at the core of ‘Calvary’ lies something more; a feeling of universal failings and the encroaching corrosion of sin and guilt.  Father James, a man who was, for all intents and purposes, completely innocent of the crime he was being punished for, was not an innocent man, at least not in his own eyes, and being confronted with this act of essential martyrdom brought flooding back to him the unsettling realization that no matter how hard you may try and dress up your mistakes, hiding them behind a title and a robe, you can never fully escape your past mistakes.  Father James was a good man.  We watched him as he bonded with his daughter and reached out to those in the community in clear need and heard out the cries from those in clear pain and we saw the genuineness in his face as he took in their circumstance, but we also saw that the damage had been done.  He had been reminded.  He had been outed, so-to-speak, and because of that he would forever be doomed to his inevitable.‘Calvary’ has so many interesting things to say about faith, about our past mistakes and our own willingness of forgive or to persecute ourselves, regardless of where we are on our current path, and how much faith can or can’t fix those things for us.Just contemplate the decision Father James makes…about his own life.It haunts.

Sometimes it’s the simple things in life that make the most impact.  They hold us close, comfort our soul and whisper in our ears that they love us.  It’s often these simple things that we take for granted, always reaching for something that feels bigger, bolder and more obviously poignant, and yet it can be within these simple things that we find the biggest, boldest, most poignant impact.The same can be said for film.  Oftentimes films are convinced that beating us over the head with their views and ‘importance’ is the way to our hearts, or at least to our memories, but sometimes it is that film with a simple message told in a simple manner that contains the most heart and soul, and the one that reaches us deeper than we ever expected it to.‘We Are the Best!’ is that kind of film.I’ve said many times that children and stories about children fascinate me.  They reach to the core of me.  They find a soft corner of my heart and they blossom.  Now that my eldest daughter is getting older (my GOD, she’s inching closer and closer to those double digits), stories about adolescence are starting to work their way in there as well.  ‘We Are the Best!’ is one of those soft-hearted yet boldly idealistic portrayal of honest adolescence that makes me smile ear to ear and hope and pray that my children, but daughter’s especially, grow up into the young women THEY want to become.  All that prodding and pulling every direction, all that well intentioned guidance and advice and coddling is to be expected because we’re parents and we love them and we want the best for them, but at the end of the day, I want my girls to be THEM and only them and never what they think I or their mother or anyone else wants them to be.So, when anyone tells my daughter than “PUNK IS DEAD”, or anything to that nature, I hope she flips them the bird and PROVES THEM WRONG!‘We Are the Best!’ takes place in Stockholm and revolves around two young girls who are somewhat outcasts because of their lack of conformity to the stylings and likings of the in-crowd.  They don’t fit in much at home either, at odds with what their parents want from them and constantly feeling as if they’re taken for granted and not even heard.  And then, on a whim, they decide to form a band.  It’s really a complete whim, something that forms out of the burstings of their heartstrings; a desire repressed yet always lingering that consumes them at the same moment to where, despite ignored consequences, they just go for it.  It is then, through their rushed yet well intentioned music, that these girls (now ‘three’, thanks to the adoption of another outcast) find something special within themselves.I feel like the topic of misogyny comes up a lot when film is discussed.  I personally got engaged in the conversation this week.  It’s not really a reality you can ignore, especially when you glance over the array of male-centric films that are force fed to the populous on a daily basis.  The wonderful thing about a little film like ‘We Are the Best!’ is that is takes a genre and even a subject that could have, and most likely would have normally been centered around boys and makes it a matter of female empowerment.  What is even better is that this film doesn’t make this ABOUT girls as much as it makes it about growing up, regardless of sex.  In fact, the girls themselves stress at one point that they are NOT a girl band.  In this way, this film proves that you can make a film featuring strong female characters that aren’t there because the story RELIES on it.  For me, we need more films that integrate male and female roles in this way, because there are so many stories that don’t demand a specific sex in the lead.  Let’s give more of these roles to women!And what astonishing child performances from the three talented young ladies!  Mira Barkhammar anchors this film with such beautifully composed honesty.  You can sense the inner struggle she faces to be herself, to be who she feels is swelling in her heart that is looking for any way to escape, and it reads so effortlessly on her face.  For me though, her two co-stars really steal the show.  Liv LeMoyne handles Hedvig’s flowering beautifully, with such attention to the smallest detail, and Mira Grosin (who I demand become a HUGE star) is so organic here, so natural in all of her detailings of Klara.  She gets everything right, from the attitude to the immaturity to the honest childlike emotions.  She lights up every scene and, for me, possessed the strongest character development.Such a beautiful performance.Lukas Moodysson deserves major credit for making this story as fluid and as universally compelling as he did.  It would have been easy to make this a gender thing, to pander to the obvious and beat things over the head, and yet there are so many moments when we forget we’re talking about three girls in a boys world; we’re just watching three kids finding themselves in their world, because this world does belong to all of us.

It took me a while to get into Pedro Almodovar’s films.  They have a very distinct tonal quality to them.  That whole ‘glorified Telenovela’ thing can be, for the lack of a better word, awkward to watch.  Sometimes these tones can make his films feel like a really glossy Soap Opera, and I’ve never been one to embrace that form of storytelling.  But, his status and reputation within the cinematic community always had me sure that I should attempt to get more acquainted with his work, to try a little harder.It’s funny how when you start to explore something you aren’t initially comfortable with, you start to discover nuances and details and tidbits of merit that help grow your appreciation for it, despite your initial reservations.  I’ve noticed this in myself many times when it comes to film.  When I first started exploring film as more than just a medium of immediate entertainment, I was urged to explore foreign cinema, which to me only existed (at that point) in laughable Kung-Fu movies and ‘Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon’.  The idea of subtitles just didn’t appeal to me at all and so I had no real interest in digging in, and yet I did and I found this whole new world.  My preconceived notions that lead to initial observations were soon dismissed for a real appreciation.  For instance, I initially considered Asian cinema loud, obnoxious and overtly theatrical (granted, some of it is), but the more I saw, the more I found such rich texture and such variations of tone I took for granted initially.So, the same can be said for Almodovar.So far, I’d only seen six of his films, ‘All About My Mother’ being my seventh.  Like I said, he can be a bit much to take at first, but as these six films rest in my mind they help build a real tapestry of appreciation for his gifts as a filmmaker and the sheer originality and unwavering vision within his work.  Almodovar loves color, flamboyancy, drama and women, and he uses them all in such distinct and vibrant ways.  While I don’t always react to his films with unabashed delight, I do get a little giddy now when I watch one of his films, for I know what to expect and I know what to look for.I really liked ‘All About My Mother’.  This is one of those film that I have felt, for a long time, that I needed to watch, mainly because so many tout it as one of Almodovar’s finest films, lauding it in a year that is lauded as one of the greatest cinematic years (the greatest, by many) since 1939; 1999.  The fact that I had sought out some of his more obscure titles and yet hadn’t found the time to see this one was a shame on my part, but I’ve finally rectified that.  Anchored by a truly inspired ensemble, Almodovar’s black comedy of sorts covers so many characters and so many sub-plots and so many hidden agendas that keeping up can be exhausting, but the finished product is so splendidly delivered that I can’t help but smile when thinking about it.  Whether we’re lamenting alongside Manuela as she grieves the loss of her son, or we’re secretly judging Huma and her oddly distracting relationship with the troubled Nina, or we’re rooting for Rosa and her desperate situation or trying to figure Agrado out, we are constantly IN this movie, which is something so refreshing.I can’t say that I loved this movie, but I will say that it never let me stop watching; and I didn’t want to.Some of Almodovar’s flagrant touches don’t come off as smooth as in other films, and I have to say that I’ve always somewhat preferred him when he reigns it in, just a little, but his attention to character detail is just unreal.  He creates such lived in worlds for his actresses, all of them so full and ripe regardless of their actual place within the plot.  Even Agrado, who is far from a main character, has her moment and her completeness which all makes her feel so whole and real.  You understand these women because Almodovar understands these women, and that love for his characters (even the troubled, hurtful ones) shows up so well in these films.  In fact, his finest films, that I’ve seen, are the ones where he allows women to take center stage.  Throw a man in, and things start to get murky.Roth is outstanding; such a powerfully layered performance, and Marisa Paredes and Penelope Cruz are also just wonderful.There is a lot going on here, and it doesn’t always mesh as cleanly as I would have liked it too (just edit a little bit), but overall, ‘All About My Mother’ is a beautiful dissection of these women, what makes them tick, what makes them whole and what unites them.

My wife baffles me.  She hates animals.  She has banned them from our home.  She makes us all strip at the door if we’ve been in the home of anyone who owns animals.  She shuts down any conversation about owning them.  When we are at a friend’s home and they own pets she avoids them like the plague, talks about how awful they are and begs our friends to get rid of them.  I know, this should make her a terrible person, right?  But, she’s also quite fascinated by them, and from a distance she adores them.  It’s strange, but she makes our kids watch nature shows every Saturday morning and drags the whole family to those awful IMAX movies that play in our local museum that are basically the most boring depictions of wildlife put to film, with someone like Morgan Freeman explaining every single detail to us; ad-nauseam.  She pleads with us to go to the cinema anytime Disney decides they want to create a fake family of animals to ‘document’ for our enjoyment.  She did it with that ‘Chimpanzee’ movie and I wanted to kill her (my god, that movie was awful) and she did it again with ‘Bears’.Well, she almost did it.In fact, the film came out and I refused to suffer in the theater for this movie and so we waited until it was released on DVD.  She kept prodding me every week, “has it come out yet?” and I prayed we’d never find it, and then we did find it and I wound up sleeping through the whole thing.  I needed a nap.  I was exhausted.  The next morning my kids wanted to watch it again, and I was kind of shocked because they usually complain about these kinds of movies despite my wife’s constant insistence that they are wonderful films, and so my interest was slightly piqued to the point where I decided to laze it on the couch with the kids and watch the movie I’d snored through the night before.This is in no way shape or form a benchmark for documentary filmmaking, but it is in no way shape or form as pointless, silly and pandering as that awful ‘Chimpanzee’.The thing I hated so much about ‘Chimpanzee’ is that it felt like it tried way too hard to make this ‘documentary’ a movie.  It gave awful names to these apes and gave them backstories that felt forced and it fed in conflict that felt anticlimactic and overly dramatized and it focused on inane things, trying to give it meaning beyond the obvious and by the end of the movie it felt so pointless that it might as well have just been scrapped altogether for an animated film about chimpanzees, since that’s really what they wanted to do.  My fear for ‘Bears’ was that it was going to suffer from the same construction issues, but it doesn’t, at least not wholly.‘Bears’, narrated by one of my favorite underappreciated actors, John C. Reilly, tells the story of a mother bear and her two cubs and their journey from hibernation caves to life giving streams of the open valleys.  From first step to last, the journey is dangerous, exciting and rewarding, and the way in which directors Alastair Fothergill and Keith Scholey capture this journey (the cinematography is stunning) is a very solid and touching experience.  There are some moments that feel overwrought, and this is Disney, and so the film does suffer from a saccharine glaze at points, but for a family wanting to educate their children while entertaining them, this is actually really well done.  The weight of the average journey taken on by these majestic creatures is captured in a way that will educate, captivate and touch your whole family.

I just got these bags in yesterday from Amazon and promptly used them as I was cleaning up and throwing away a lot of stuff.  What I first noticed that while there is odor protection in these bags, the fragrance is not near as over-powering as the ones that I used last - the GLAD bags.  While I got used to the fragrance in the GLAD bags, I like the lighter fragrance with this bags from Hefty.  They seem strong as I stuffed these pretty full and they did not tear apart.  I also put in some liquid food stuffs and did not notice a leak (which unfortunately this is a problem with the GLAD bag (I always have to double bag with those if there is a lot of liquid).  These bags expand which helps with stuffing more garbage in but what I also like is that the draw string at the top expands so that the top actually will grip (hug) the garbage can so that it stays put (which is also a nice feature).  While I thought the GLAD bag was an improvement in garbage bags, I like this one better and think this is the one I will continue to use.

I have not had a George Foreman gill for a long time.  I got one when they first can out which as been quite a few years now.  It was small and tended to dry out the food.  My have things changed!  This is a lovely grill that is absolutely huge and what a joy that you can use it out on the patio or in the kitchen.  It has a removable stand (thus you can set it up to grill outside or take the stand off and use it on the kitchen counter.  This is a great solution for me as I am just not comfortable using my Weber grill because of having to get the charcoal just right.  I use a chimney and that certainly helps and honestly, I am a bit afraid of propane.  So, this is just a nice solution.  The one thing is that you need an outdoor electrical outlet as the grill is electric and while I suppose you could use a heavy duty extension cord, it is best to plug it in directly.  This grill as I said is huge and is big enough to serve 12 or more people depending on the size of your burgers, chicken, steak, etc.  It has a slanting surface which helps to drain the grease away which is the other reason I really like this grill is because it is more healthy cooking than some other methods.  I am glad that I tried this grill as I was not sold on the older versions but this is a really nice one.  I doubt that anyone looking for a nice grill (and does not want to mess with the clean up of a charcoal grill (or if you are like me and afraid of a propane grill), will be disappointed!  Highly recommended!

I finally got around to making some Stonewall Kitchens popovers from their mix.  They came out great!  This pan is perfect for really high, light, and airy popovers.  The well is the right size and the nonstick surface is great.  Even though I buttered the pan and the rims per the recipe I doubt that even if you did not do such a good job at buttering the pan that you would have any trouble with sticking as the nonstick coating just naturally prevents it.  This pan is well constructed and I put it I. The dishwasher without any problems.  I would not use any other pan for popovers.

This is a popular toy with my adopted grandkids.  The fact that it is Disney's Frozen characters makes it popular right off the bat.  It is an interactive toy with a brief musical interlude about building the snowman which even I find quite cute and intriguing.  This reminds me of toys that I played with (albeit updated version) but the bicycle, the dolls, all can be used for imaginative play.  I recommend this for children old enough not to put the smaller pieces in their mouth (I would say that this is the only draw back to the toy and thus why it has 4 stars vs. 5).Update - the kids have been playing with this toy for a bit now and unfortunately I am having to resend my initial review.  The durability of this toy is very poor, especially for the bicycle.  First of all, the bike's front wheel does not roll well and the dolls' feet do not stay on the pedals.  The main problem though is that the bike broke at several places within the structure and has since been abandoned.  The kids do like the dolls as they have jointed legs and arms and so they can play with them like they are marionettes.  This toy is a good idea and the girls still like the Frozen theme of the toy but over the long haul, this toy did not hold up well.

First of all, I want to say I am writing this based on the taste of the bar.  It has that salty sweet thing going on that many people enjoy (me included).  It has a chocolaty (cocoa) drizzle on it which adds to the depth of taste.  I could really taste the nuts and it was crunchy and chewy at the same time.  It is supposed to have a hint of orange but I did not take that.  I can tell it is a health bar (if you know what I mean) as many of these bars that that "taste", (you know this is supposed to be good for you and not a candy).  I think a lot of people are going to love this thing.  Easy to carry (like a candy bar) but again, supposed to be good for you.Now, here is the problem for me, generally I am not allergic to nuts (except cashews) but I had not been munching on this thing for long before my mouth started itching.  Thank goodness I only ate a bit or two as I was busy doing other things and was just taking my time with it.  I wound up taking some Benadryl to stop the process.  Again, I am not usually allergic to stuff but I was to this.  The other bar i had difficulty with was a Kind Bar (it took me eating several of those bars before I had difficulty with it - same symptoms).  So, whether this bar is processes in a factory with other tree nuts like cashews (I did not find that the outside wrapper said this but I could have missed it) I am not sure but for those with potential allergies, I would say be careful.  This was really a surprise to me (although as i said I had trouble with the Kind bar).

First of all Mead has been putting out quality products for years and this item is no exception.  The cover is simple and looks just like the picture which shows the item.  Also, as the description says, it has a plastic cover which not only protects the planner but it also can be used to hold loose items that you might need (which I find this a really good feature as I often has loose notes from my students about scheduling, etc., and I do not want to loose them but I often misplace them.  Having a specific place to keep them makes keeping up with them easier.  Most planners tend to go a calendar year but this one is an academic year starting in August.  This is also great for me as I teach and like to have the same planner for the school year without having to get another one in January when the new year starts.  This is great because I need notes and phone numbers, etc., for the entire school year and I do not have to worry about transferring the old info into a new planner in the middle of a year.  I also like this because (again as the description says and is a great feature) is that the month is spread over two pages and there is plenty of room to write appointments and there is a lot of room for notes.  If you are a teacher, this is a nice tool and it is big enough to keep a lot of information but it is not too big that you cannot put it in a backpack, large purse or briefcase/satchel. I have had a lot of planners but none of them have been ideal but I think this one is going to be and I think this would be a good tool for any educator!

I received these from Amazon yesterday and used them for house cleaning today.  I like them.  I often use Bounty paper towels and put soap on them to clean the kitchen counters, stove, etc.  These already have Dawn impregnated into the towels.  Once you put water on the towel, they soap up (in fact, they are really soapy.  You can rinse the towel and use it to remove the soapy film or use another regular paper towel (so I am not sure if I am saving  anything by using twice the paper towel for the cleaning but they sure do clean and cut the grease (which is why Dawn is a good product).  The towels are strong and convenient.  The reason for 4 starts vs. 5 is because of the above comment with using extra paper towels but also I accidentally pulled off a paper towel from the Dawn ones vs. a regular one to dry my hands and of course I got my hands soapy again.  So, you really need to make sure you keep these towels off the counter where they will be used for regular paper towels.  I will be keeping the under the sink and use them like any other cleaning product.

This is an excellent resource for any teacher - experienced or otherwise.  You know you have an excellent text when you spent all of your lunch with a colleague talking about various aspects of the text (which I have did today)!  Stephen Brookfield captures much the emotion, angst, and joys of teaching.  One of the points that comes through is that you cannot please everyone and you cannot know everything there is to know about teaching.  I like the fact that "muddling through" can be a positive.  The chapter on understanding students" resistance to learning is priceless as well as there are a lot of strategies talked about to build a working relationship with students for better learning. There is a nice section about teaching online (which is sorely needed).  As he says, online learning is going too be important to all faculty where you are teaching face-to-face and have a online supplement or actually teach a whole course online. He touches on some very sensitive topics as well including racism.  Much of what he talks about I have read about in other articles and resources.  I think the whole idea of micro-inequities is certainly a pertinent topic in today's diverse classroom.  This book is written so that anyone can understand it.  It is what I think is profound yet simple to understand.  In my own practice I have been discouraged at times because some of my students really do not like my teaching style, activities, and sometimes they just do not like me.  This book addresses this topic and helps one understand that this situation is going to be inevitable but there are things that one can do to improve some of it.  Sometimes the fact that you are doing your job (and doing it well) does not jive with some students.  Education equals change for the student and change can be threatening!  I highly recommend this book for any person that teaches at any level (K-12 or higher education).

This did not work out too well.  I thought it might be a good thing so that drinks could not spill but my adopted grandkid (the younger one - age 3) just cannot get the hang of pushing the button and drinking at the same time.  She just does not have the dexterity or the strength.  Mom says that if the button was a bit lower on the bottle that it would have worked better.  It's pretty in pink and I like the no BPA aspect but it just did not work out like I thought it would.

Barbie was a big hit with my adopted grandkids.  They love her but it remains how long she will stay intact (they tend to amputate her legs and give her a "bath" quite often!  The glitter does stay on the hair but it also stayed on the carpet.  Kids had a difficult time opening the vials of glitter without the lids popping off rather forcefully with glitter going all over the carpet.  While vinegar, a scrub, and a vacuum took care of it.  So, bottom line, while mom is not as happy with Barbie as the kids, it is a big hit.  They love putting the glitter in the hair of the doll!

My dog eats these but not with the relish that she eats the Wellness Rewards Beef jerky bites.  She sniffs at these and slowly takes one and eats it while the Rewards, she just gobbles.  I don't like the smell of these treats at all.  They has a slightly sweet, strongly smokey, and slightly fishy smell.  The size of the bites are nice and one or two treats go a long way.  I like that they are soft (my dog is not real fond of hard treats like Milkbone biscuits), because she enjoys the texture and softness of these treats.  These are made in the USA which is really good.  I trust this product in terms of being good for dogs.  While these are OK, I will probably stay with buying the Wellness Rewards jerky because of my dog's preference.

I wanted to like this product as I am always looking for sweeteners to use in cooking as well as in tea, etc.  However, I just do not like the taste of this product.  I like the thickness (reminds me of agave syrup in that respect) but the taste is just "strange."  It has an oddly metallic after taste.  It is really hard to describe and while the description of this article says it tastes of caramel or a caramel candy corn, I would say that it takes slightly burnt (yet, that is not exactly correct either).  It is sweet, better on food than by itself, but this would not be a product I would use.  I tend to use maple syrup a lot.  I like maple syrup mixed in mascarpone cheese to top grilled figs.  I also use agave syrup (very nice in homemade Bar-B-Que sauce) as it has a really neutral sweetness but this product just has too much after taste for me.

This is a fun product and I can't wait to use it on my table (it is a table runner) this Halloween.  Made to look like lace with spiders and spider webs, black in color, it should go well with other spooky Halloween decorations.  Light weight but seems sturdy.  While I have to be honest and say that I have ordered other DII products and was somewhat disappointed, this table runner is much better than I expected and I am thoroughly pleased with it.

Made in the USA (never good to give dogs food from places like China if one cares for safety), these are natural and grain free treats.  My dog loves these as she gobbled them up with out much hesitation as soon as I offered it.  She is usually more found of a chicken product but she loves these.  What I like is that instead of a strip of jerky (which is sometimes too big of a treat for my dog since I have to watch her weight), these are tiny pieces.  They make a good "reward" treat just like the package says.  Ingredients are few - Beef, Dried Chicory root, dried cultured whey, salt, lecithin, and mixed tocopherols to preserve freshness (no wheat, corn, artificial colors, flavors, or preservatives)!

I love this old fashioned candy as I have been eating it for years.  I like that I could order a fairly large quantity of it from Amazon and save a bit of money from buying it at the store.  Also, the fact that Amazon has it and will deliver it because I cannot always find this product at the store (my best bet is to go to WalMart of Walgreens) but they usually have only 2 or 3 bags if they have any.  The one thing I did not like too well was that some of the bags had a few candies that were stuck together.  I'm not sure why this happens but it was only a few.  I love the sweet/hot taste of these and when I run out, I will order again.  It is so convenient and like I said, I actually saved money - about $.25 per bag or so!  What is not to like with that.

I have eaten other Fiber One products and liked them.  Generally I love anything "cheesecake" and especially strawberry but this was not my favorite product.  First of all, it is really a pretty tiny square; not that would make a difference as long as it tastes good.  This brings me to my second point, it has sort of an artificial taste.  When looking at the ingredients, I would not have expected it as I did not see a lot of artificial anything in the list.  My third issue is that after eating the bar, I had a weird after taste and it was not pleasant.  It is hard to describe but sort of a mineral (maybe slightly metallic) taste.  I did feel full after eating it though (which is probably because of the fiber - which it has quite a few grams).  So, if you can get past the taste, I think these might help one to feel full and eat less.  I just did not like them and will no buy them.  Glad I had a chance to taste them through the Vine Program.

My doctorate is in educational leadership (although my specialization is in curriculum development and instruction), so anything on educational leadership is going to peak my interest.  Jossey Bass publishing does put out some of the best materials on education, so I had a feeling this book would be valuable. As Thomas said in his review (Dean and professor at the University of North Texas), the strength of the book lies in its "thoroughness" and "documentation" of the recommendations for building academic leadership capacity.  While one tends to think of those in administration as being the leadership, the book indicates and talks a bit about how anyone can be a leader.  I think that is the value of this book is that the situation can dictate who will be a leader. The book talks about much of what I learned about in graduate school including change theory, reflection, systems approach,inclusion, and skills development.  There is also a nice resource guide in the appendix as well as several diagrams and charts that help to summarize key points.  I think this is an excellent resource for anyone in academia as all of us (at some point in time) are in leadership positions in some aspect of our careers.  Highly recommended.

The first thing that struck me was the author.  When I ordered this book I had no idea that the author was "Erin" on the old TV show "The Waltons."  This was one of my mother's favorite shows especially the early shows where multi-generations were living together.  I think the author thus has had a lot of experiences from the show related to exploration of family situations from a multi-generation perspective which is indeed what the theme of this story is all about.  The book explores both the good and the not so good situations that affect the members of a family in the South (Virginia) to be specific (not unlike the part of the country that was key to the Waltons' TV show).  The second thing that struck me was how much reading is involved in this book.  This is a fairly lengthy tome and while the book is very interesting, it does take quite a bit of time to get through it.  I think overall that the quality of the writing and the story line is very good and certainly a book that I would recommend if you are attracted to novels that chronicle the life of a family and an interest in the Southern way of life.

This is a Christian based mystery so it does not have any adult language but the situations in the story do push the boundaries of what one would think of in a Christian novel (thus the 4 star rating).  With that being said, this story caught my attention pretty much from the start by taking off with a bang which includes a murder which is integral to the rest of the story.  There are lots of twists and turns including a romantic situation which keeps the reader interested.  The basic theme of the novel is how one's past "sins" catch up with one in the end especially when they are compounded by lies and regret.  Because this is a Christian based novel, there is the component of how one's past behaviors impacts one's relationship with God and how God gives second chances including forgiveness.

I liked this book but it did have it points where I needed the Kleenex box (thus the 4 stars vs. 5).  Almost all dog stories do that to me though.  This is a Christian book without violence or language or sexual situations.  This does not mean that there are not life situations that are discussed but nothing objectionable.  The synopsis on the back of the book gives the premise of the story but the book is much more in-depth than what the synopsis says.  Overall this is an uplifting book with funny moments and poignant moments.  I first started reading this author when the first book came out called "The Dog that Talked to God." followed by "The Cat that Talked to God."  All stories are worthwhile reading!

I have been looking for a caulking product that is easy to use and this it is; however, for those of you who are as "novice" as I am at doing home DIY projects, overall, this is not as easy as just pressing on the caulk.  The real work of this project is taking off the old caulk.  This takes some muscle, patience, and time.  You also need to plan on going to Home Depot or Lowe's and get a caulk removing tool and some acetone or other product to help you get all the old caulk off and the area to be re-caulked nice and clear and dry in order to put this new caulk on.  So, while this is a good product, it is only part of the project equation.

While this is a nice soap (glycerine soap is very nice in terms of lather) and this one has nice emollients for the skin, the smell of the roses is just too overpowering for me.  I have a small bathroom and when I put the soap out in the soap dish, after just about 2-3 hours, the smell was just too strong.  It filled the whole bathroom with the rose smell.  It was so concentrated that it made me a bit nauseous.  I not only was smelling it in the bathroom but in the hallway coming from the bathroom.  I finally had to put it in a storage bag.

I never watched this show on its first run but I am certainly enjoying it as a streaming video.  I like the fact that the commercials have been eliminated.  The sound and the clarity of the video is excellent on my iPad and I can watch one episode or as many as I want.  I have read the reviews of some others that have reviewed this second season and I tend to agree.  It is too bad that a writing strike or some such thing limited the number of episodes during the second season and while I have liked some episodes better than others, what I am surprised about is that there is some pretty profound philosophy that comes out from some of the characters in some of the episodes.  On the other hand, I find some episodes a bit ridiculous and far-fetched like the Holideck (not sure I spelled this right) detective episodes. You have to take the good with the bad but overall its a bit of fun.

I love this mystery series and have read every book.  This one is all about the folks that make chocolate candy, their family and marital problems, and how Sophie saves the day after a murder is committed.  I did find this one a bit draggy and slow in spots.  It had a bit more of a convoluted plot that some of the other books.  However, all the quirky characters are back including Natasha, Wolf, Mars, and a mention of some of the others that have been featured in other stories but serve to comfort the reader in making Old Town a place you always like to visit.  There are some quirky New characters and a bit of romance for Sophie (on and off).  Altogether a fun read and can't wait til I get to come to Old Town again!

This was a smaller item than I thought.  The block is made from nice wood but it is compact.  The red color is striking and it matches well with my red toaster.  The knives are very sharp and hopefully they will stay that way since they are surgical steel.  They are suppose to resist rust and tarnish which I would think would be the case (although over the long haul is the test) since again, they are made from surgical steel.  The blades are very shiny.  I like that they are light weight, feel fairly good in relationship to holding them in my hand and this is in part to the ergonomic design.  I was a bit worried about the plastic handles but I have been using these knives for a while now (using them everyday, putting them in the dishwasher, cutting up frozen chicken, etc.) and these knives are holding up well.  No cracks in the handles (which was my main worry) and they are staying sharp.  In fact, these are better than my Ginzu knives that I bought.  I still miss having a nice serrated knife in this set but I could not be more please and they are holding up with a lot of use.  So, I changed my 4 stars to 5!

The author makes it clear that the language in the story is correct just very British English.  I liked the story.  The characters were a bit quirky.  I have to say that while I am a dog lover, the frequent dog comments and references was a bit too much and became a bit annoying.  The story rolls out a bit slow but overall the pace was OK.  Penny, the main character and her dog move to the country and discover a murder, thus the beginning of the journey to finding the killer.

My old toothbrush bit the dust and I saw the reviews for this one on Amazon and thought I would give it a try before I bought another Rotodent.  At first I did not like the sound emitted by this toothbrush and I did not like the feel of it.  With continued use I got use to it and thought that it was doing a good job as my teeth looked clean and even a bit whiter after using it.  I liked the 30 second intervals and time system and the fact that it quit after two minutes which is as long as I would use it anyway.  I had been using this tooth brush at least 3 months or more and I started having a toothache.  This is significant as I have not had a cavity or a toothache for years (not since I started using the Rotodent back around 2004 of 2005).  I started using the Rotodent because of cavity issues.  I went to the dentist and indeed I had a cavity.  Even though I thought this brush was working, it just was not getting in-between my teeth and under the gum line like the Rotodent.  My dentist reluctantly agreed because he was hesitant to have me purchase a Rotodent because the product has changed since another company (not the original owners of the company) took over.  The Rotodent is not quite as smooth operating, you get less brush heads (2 instead of 4), and you no longer get a stand to hold your Rotodent for charging.  Also, the company will not stand by its warranty unless you buy the Rotodent from your dentist or from the online company listed on the Rotodent website (my dentist no longer sells them because of the warranty issue and the changes in the product).  I decided to take a chance and bought the Rotodent classic (the latest version of the product has terrible reviews) from dentist.com and I am OK with the product even though the company has changed.  I have been using the Rotodent now for about 3 weeks and I can already tell the difference in how my teeth feel.  I tried this Health HP product but the toothbrush head just is not fixed so that it goes in-between teeth and under the gum line like the Rotodent.  For me, that is what I need to prevent cavities.  It is too bad since I sort of liked this product but the proof of product effectiveness is the absence of cavities and I do not have that with this product.

I have had this computer about 2 months now and I am still having a difficult time getting use to it.  I think I am fairly good at using a computer as I got my doctorate online and I work with a computer all the time in teaching.  However, I am having trouble finding files, getting the resolution and the size of the screens right.  One minute it is the right size for reading and the next it is too small (and I have no idea what I did to cause it).  I am finding it a bit easier to do the touch screen than using the keyboard (which is a bit of surprise).  It is probably the new Windows 8.1 system that is throwing me off but I also find the sound in this HP not nearly as good as my old HP Pavilion (and it is 8 years old and thus was the reason for buying a new computer).  The keyboard and the built-in mouse area feels a lot different to me.  My other computer the keys are smooth and the mouse control area is smooth under my fingers and the new computer, it is more of a texture feeling (this is kind of hard to describe) but I am just not as happy with the whole system and the "feel" of the computer.  I find the screen a bit more glaring and thus I had to buy one of those screen filters to put over the screen to decrease the glare (I did not have to do that with my old computer).  I am sure that eventually I will get the hang of it but I find that I am going back to use my old computer once I got a lot of the information off of it and cleaned it up to make it faster and run better.  I can't say if it is just me but I am not as impressed with this HP computer as I have been with those in the past and this is my 3rd or 4th one.

This is one of the nicest tools in my kitchen.  I was really surprised about how nice this grater is when I opened the Amazon box.  It is a lot larger than I thought.  I have a rasp that I use for zesting limes and lemons and garlic, but it is quite small with little surface area compared to this tool.  This rasp grater has a nice weight to it and I really like the plastic cover that comes with it.  It just feels comfortable in my hand when in use.  I really think that if you are looking for a durable, useful rasp/grater, this is a great choice!Update - this is really the best tool I own in terms of using to grate zest and best of all garlic.  I have used a garlic press for years but find it hard to compress now that I have a bit or arthritis in my hands and the garlic is hard to get through the holes in the press in any major proportion to use in a recipe.  This tool grates it wonderfully.  I am just thrilled with this item and would not be without it.

This is a hard core Christian themed novel.  The main character is subject to a life review and has to deal with the traumatic and "ugly" things in her life.  It is about choices that one makes and the choices that others' make that can impact the lives of not only ourselves but those around us.  As I always say in recent years, Christian books take liberty with subject matter.  This book would not be for everyone.  Not only does it have a very hard core Christian theme but it deals with sexual situations, incest, rape, abortion, and bigotry within the Church.  It has a supernatural overlay dealing with angels and demons.  So, again, this is not a book for all on many different levels.  Those sensitive to subjects as mentioned prior and would be offended or disturbed by reading this type of material, this book is not for you.  For those of you who are not into hard core Christain doctrine, this is also not the book for you.

While one can never tell for sure about the success of a product like this until one has used it for a while, I do have to say that I think my toenails are better even after just a couple of days or so of application.  I like that there is no odor to the product, I cannot feel anything when it goes on.  My skin around my nail is slightly less red.  Most products that go on topical have a hard time penetrating the nail and therefore do not work very well, but I really think this product is worth a try.  I will write more later after I use this for a while but this product has a good beginning as I am definitely happier with a natural product vs. a systemic anti-fungal that might have a lot of side-effects.Update - I have been using this a while and unfortunately, it is not taking care of the problem.  The package says that you might need to use more than one bottle but I am not going to spend my money.  As a nurse I have read that topical treatments just will not work.  You need a systemic medicine or they are now talking about laser working.  You need to see a podiatrist and follow his/her recommendations.  While I really had hopes that this product would be a topical that would work, it does not.  I think I might even lose the nail so my recommendation is to save your money.

I like the regular Starburst as they have nice fruit flavors and they have a slight "milky" taste and feel.  While the flavors are OK in the minis, I am just not a fan of the texture of these.  They do not seem to have the same mouth watering production in the mouth and they definitely do not have that slightly milky feel and taste.  They seem to be a bit more of a artificial taste and waxy texture in the mouth.  I was excited about having smaller portions but this is definitely not a replacement for the original, larger size candies.

I have been looking forward to another installment of this series.  This is actually one of my favorites from this author as well as the Corduroy Mansions series.  While the synopsis on the back of the book taunts this story as a mystery with a bit of paranormal overtones (and it is) but what I find most interesting is the discussion of philosophical topics.  This look is loaded with "food for thought" brought about through Isabel and her husband Jamie (which is really who I think the story is ultimately about - these two characters).  There is discussion about death, life after death, politics, spirituality, sex, and of course ultimately relationships and happiness (which is indicated by the title).  These books are ones to be savored.  It is not your typical cozy mystery where you can read straight through.  This book is one that takes a few days to ponder and as I said savor.  McCall Smith is a master at getting the most content into a book of anyone I have ever read!

Pie on a stick is an interesting idea that I think I will try for our next potluck at work.  I am particularly interested in doing t huh e pumpkin one for this fall.  This book has both sweet and savory pie ideas which makes it have something for everyone's taste.  This makes a nice edition to the cookbook collection.

While the Pennyfoot series grew on me, I have to Sat that I liked this series right off the bat.  The main character, Elizabeth is strong nd competent yet the other characters are delightfully quirky.  This first book in the series, while I guesses the culprit right from the start, the story was fun getting to the big reveal.  The Americans coming to the Manor House leaves the door wide open for a raft of stories.  I look forward to reading the next books in the series.

I just received these and I am going to try and see if they produce herbs and veggies.  They are guaranteed to grow but I have to say I have my doubts. When I took one of the pods out, it fell apart.  The top paper cover that sealed the pod just fell off as it was so dry that it was not sticking as a seal.  I lost some of the seeds out.  The instructions are under the seal and I find them a bit hard to read.  While I think this is an interesting idea, I am skeptical about how they will eventually work out.  Stay tuned for updates.

I loved this show when it was on prime time.  The re-runs are just as funny and what I really like when they are streamed on Kindle through Prime is that there are no commercials!  The streaming quality is excellent, I can view one episode or several.  I actually view these on my iPad through the Amazon APP so that the screen is bigger.  This first season is such a great introduction to the series which I had forgotten about because of all the episodes that the show had.  It is also one of my favorites because Eddie, the dog, is front and center!  I find myself laughing all the way through!

This was a good mystery cause I did not figure out who did it before the reveal.  The food truck aspect is a new one as I have not read any murder mysteries with this topic before.  What I did not like was the liberal amount of adult language, thus the 4 stars vs. 5.

This is an excellent book.  As one can surmise from the title, it is very Christian based. so if you are not interested in the Christian faith and the church in a global sense, this is not the book for you.  I found this book fascinating.  As the title indicates, the author found herself "called" by God to explore how Christianity is lived in other countries.  This is the everyday worship of God and the how the Christian faith plays out in 5 different countries including Wales (in the UK), Brazil, China, Tanzania. and Honduras.  This is a very intimate and personal view from Ms. Hudson's viewpoint.  As the author says, this book is about expanding one's horizons related to our spirituality and our faith.  The author felt compelled to do this journey.  I think we all have journeys but I am glad that this author wrote this book so that the reader can share in her's.

This book is very reminiscent of Tuedays with Morrie by Mitch Albom.  This is a story about a Harvard-educated young man who by the age of 32 is struggling with life's most difficult questions.  He finds answers from an 86-year old Nun.  This is a very Christian and Catholic based book,. so if you have an aversion to either, this is not the book for you.  The author is at the beginning of his life and the Nun, she is at the end (thus the 5 year time limit on this relationship).  There is a lot of truth, wisdom, and contemplation in this story.  It is wonderful that the author chose to share so that all of those who choose to read this book can share in this contemplative process.  I think we all come to asking these questions at some time during our lives, some earlier and some later.  I find this book filled with wisdom and certainly a lot of food for thought.  highly recommended.

It would surely be a tough task to abridge Thoreau’s “Walden” enough to fit into a 32-page picture book. (Heck, it took Henry seven years, seven complete drafts, and lots of thought to create the original and longer version.) You would also have to make sure that your selections did justice to the main intent and message of the classic. And additionally, you would have to gauge that the quotes were simple enough for a young audience to understand and to enjoy, too. Whew! But you know what? Steve Lowe chose wisely. This storyline makes sense. Appearing here is Thoreau’s reason for going to live at Walden Pond, as well as his reason for leaving it after two years, two months, and two days. We share a few of his experiences and nature observations along the way.  And Robert Sabuda in turn provides good visualizations to match the words. It’s a short but somehow complete presentation.The four-star ranking comes as a result of the introduction written by long-time Thoreau Lyceum director Anne McGrath. For years, Anne did much good work in promoting Henry to visitors to Concord. Her passion for all things Henry knew no bounds. I’m sorry I never had a chance to meet her. Unfortunately, I’m disappointed in her biographical summary here. The gist of it is okay; but a lot of the details are not quite correct. To elementary and middle grade students who are inspired to learn more facts about the rest of Thoreau’s life, I recommend that they look elsewhere. But enjoy Lowe and Sabula’s book as a step into one part of his history.Three more Walden-related Thoreau picture books have been published since this book was released. Henry David's House also uses quotes from the book “Walden.” They’re longer than the ones here, and they tell only the story of how Henry built his pond-side house and how he lived in it. It doesn’t get into his reason for going to the pond in the first place, and it doesn’t mention the fact that he left after two years. Readers may get the idea that he stayed there for the rest of his life.The Trouble with Henry: A Tale of Walden Pond is a fictional story based loosely on Thoreau’s reputation among his Concord neighbors. Here, people think he’s odd and crazy until he shows them the great things he finds in nature and at Walden Pond. Too bad these final scenes didn’t happen in real life! It’s a fun story, though. The book concludes with a decent summary bio that could lead readers to learn more on their own.If You Spent a Day with Thoreau at Walden Pond (Christy Ottaviano Books) synthesizes Thoreau’s approach to nature, to Walden Pond, and to life, in a what-if style format. It fantasizes that a young person has met Henry at Walden and is learning from him. It’s a terrific way to put readers right into what they’re seeing on the colorful pages.  The book concludes with a selection of Thoreau quotes. And Wendell Minor’s illustrations throughout the text are soft and enticing.So. Young folks (and anyone who reads these books to or with them) now have a number of options to choose from.  All while they’re still too young to read and understand the original “Walden” for themselves.Corinne H. SmithAuthor of "Henry David Thoreau for Kids: His Life and Ideas, with 21 Activities" and Westward I Go Free: Tracing Thoreau's Last Journey

Portland, Oregon, has city code ordinances against graffiti vandalism. This doesn’t stop some young people and amateur artists from arming themselves with cans of spray paint and filling what they see as blank canvases all around them. One teenager named Kelly has taken the art to a whole new level – literally – as she combines her love of mountain climbing with her slightly illegal love of tagging. Lawyer Cal Claxton doesn’t know it yet, but the artwork he suddenly spots halfway up the side of his downtown office building (Caffeine Central) was created by Kelly.The trouble is, when you’re out and about during the darkest hours of the city, you may see things you’d be better off not seeing. Kelly is perched high above a street one night when she witnesses a deadly shooting that takes place below her. She scrambles out of the killer’s sight, she thinks, and is injured in the process. Now she has to make sure that no one discovers that she is “K209.” In spite of the danger, though, she’s curious enough to start figuring out on her own the identity of the killer she thinks of as “Macho Dude.” What is really happening in Portland?Cal also has connections to this murder. The victim was Claudia Borrego, the fiancé of Cal’s office landlord and friend, Hernando Mendoza. Nando asks Cal for support and for help in learning about the reasons and the responsible parties behind Claudia’s death. Cal is eager to lend an investigative hand, while he tries at the same time not to interfere with the efforts of the local police force. By now he already has “history” with some of its members. He too begins to track down the primary players in this tragic tri-fold drama.The chapters of this book alternate between the first-person narrative of main character Cal and the third-person story of young artist Kelly. As you may expect, the separate paths of the lawyer-investigator and the teenage painter begin to narrow as both of them start following similar leads. This is a great tension-building technique chosen by the author. And by the halfway point of the book, we don’t want to leave either character. We keep reading and turning pages, hoping against hope that the two will soon come together and team up against the evil parties. We also want Cal to be able to help Kelly out of whatever trouble she may find herself in (or vice versa), because this incident is obviously bigger than just the untimely death of one woman and two men. The trail unfortunately seems to stop at a city gun shop. And too many guns are involved. Still, we expect justice to be served to the killer(s) in the end.If you’re a mystery lover, you MUST read this book.  And be sure to read the first two episodes in the series, too:  Matters of Doubt and Dead Float. I guarantee that once you reach the midway point of any one of these books, you won’t want to stop. Please keep writing, Warren! You weave compelling stories.[I was given a free copy of this hardback in order to write a review.]

It's May 1848, and once again, there's trouble going on in Plumford, Massachusetts. This time the problems surround those residents who have chosen to become part of the Underground Railroad. Ezra Tripp, one of the "conductors," is killed in the line of duty, and his "shipment" -- the young woman he was transporting -- is now missing. Leave it to Henry David Thoreau to find Tripp's body and to start piecing together what's going on.This book is the third episode of the trilogy, following Thoreau at Devil's Perch and Thoreau on Wolf Hill. And although it can stand on its own merit, you should read the others first to get a firm grasp of background. In any event, you'll soon see that the narrative is told in first-person tag-team style through chapter-length journal entries written in the alternating points of view of Dr. Adam Walker and his non-blood cousin and now-girlfriend, artist Julia Pelletier. (Ironically, the story is NOT told through Henry's writings, even though he would become famous for his journal ruminations after he was gone.)Emotions are running high in the New England anti-slavery movement these days. Thoreau's mother, aunts, and sisters participate in rallies and sign written proclamations.  And Henry has been known to help a former slave or two reach a railroad station in order to continue the journey north. The roads seem to be filled today with any number of dubious travelers: especially those men who may be wearing disguises and may be bounty hunters, looking for runaways. They make decent suspects in Tripp's murder. As does Julia's French husband, once a slave trader himself, who shows up from Europe unexpectedly. Julia made such a mistake marrying this guy! She would like nothing better than to see him jailed or otherwise out of the picture. If she can pin a murder on him at the same time, so much the better. In the meantime, she does some investigating on her own and finds important evidence in the case, so to speak. Unfortunately, other "conductor" murders seem to create an even more disturbing pattern.Adding to the mystery is the fact that Tripp was killed at the edge of Phantom Bog. Did the slave or even the murderer fall and drown underneath its sphagnum mat? When Henry, Adam, and a group of men from town tiptoe across the moss and do some probing, they find only bodies of decaying animals. But they also see a wispy visage of a young woman, rising from the mist. What really happened here? And can Adam, Julia, or Henry located the missing runaway before the bounty hunters do?If you're a savvy mystery reader, you may discover the one perfect clue that points directly to the identity of the murderer. Other readers will no doubt skim right past it. And that's okay. Either way, the story makes for good reading.  And rest assured: justice will be served in the end.There are hints at the beginning and the end of this story that something romantic was going on between Henry and Lidian, wife of Ralph Waldo Emerson. Some Thoreau fans (including this reader) will grouse and grimace at this implication. But if you've read Amy Belding Brown's novel Mr. Emerson's Wife and agree with the same conclusion, you may feel the repeating of the supposition is warranted here.I have met and corresponded with the authors, Ben and Beth Oak, and they are a delightful couple. I know they work hard to maintain historical accuracy. They are also devoted Thoreauvians who portray the man as close to historical record as they can. Alas! This third book appears to be the last in the series. For the same reason that Henry Thoreau left his Walden Pond house after two years -- "Perhaps it seemed to me that I had several more lives to live, and could not spare any more time for that one" -- the Oaks have decided to listen to the voices of the many other projects that beckon them.  They leave us to consider on our own the future of Adam and Julia and the rest of the people of Plumford. We can predict where the couple is headed. And we definitely know that Henry Thoreau will soon be sitting down to polish his writing of a book called "Walden.""Thoreau in Phantom Bog" is recommended as solid historical fiction, as an intriguing murder mystery, and as good entertainment for a few days' worth of reading. I recommend reading the other two episodes first.[I was given a free advance reading copy of this book by the authors, with no expectation of a written review of any kind: positive, neutral, or negative.]

For the longest time, the standard reference for Henry David Thoreau's correspondence has been Harding and Bode's 1958 The correspondence of Henry David Thoreau. It's more than 650 pages long, and it goes well beyond the scope of any previous volumes that contained random letters.  I have to admit that I once spent some time and money standing by a library copy machine to create the copy I now keep in a purple three-ring binder in my office.But now, voila! As part of the long-range Princeton project for Thoreau writings, this first volume of Correspondence was released in 2013. The project is known for its meticulous detail, its deliberate publication pace ... and its hefty purchase prices. The plan was to go back to the original manuscripts and to fully update the 20-volume set of writings from 1906.  The team has finished "Walden," "A Week," and the other "books," as well as about half of the journal. Finally, here's the first Correspondence volume.  The first!  Two more will follow! Because as the decades have passed, many more letters have come to light, and much more context has been deciphered. It will take three books to cover it all. Amazing.Major kudos in this effort go to Correspondence editor Robert N. Hudspeth. I admire Bob's diligence in locating all of the references for each and every letter. I've even offered some tidbits to him that may appear in several entries in the third volume.But even if I didn't have any knowledge of the people and the work behind the scenes, I would value this publication. I'm happy to still use the two-volume Dover reprint of Thoreau's journals, unabridged yet condensed in format from the 14 volumes of the 1906 edition. And I'll recommend them every time to individual users and to public and school libraries.  These folks don't "need" and usually can't afford the Princeton editions of the journals. But Correspondence is a different matter. This new publication doesn't mark a mere update. It's a major overhaul and monster addition. The three volumes will eventually become the standard reference for Thoreau's letters. In the meantime, we have to satisfy ourselves by pairing this first one with Harding-Bode for semi-complete coverage.I've already consulted this volume to confirm the text of several letters as part of my own research.  But on some long weekend in the future, I plan to sit down and read this book from cover to cover.  I know I'll learn a lot about Thoreau, his friends, and the mid-19th century by doing this.And I won't recycle the pages of my Harding-Bode notebook just yet. I won't drop them in the bin until I have the second and third Correspondence volumes both lodged firmly in my grasp. I know the rest of the process will take a while. But for this unique set, it will certainly be worth the wait.Corinne H. SmithAuthor of Westward I Go Free: Tracing Thoreau's Last Journey and Henry David Thoreau for Kids: His Life and Ideas, with 21 Activities

Self-improvement books abound. Yes, other titles can help you devise a strategy for dealing with clutter and for tidying up your home. Other books can motivate you to get your life back on its intended and most purposeful track, one way or another.  Many also employ visualization techniques in order to reach your goals. What's the big deal about having one more book addressing these subjects? Well, this one is different.  John Benz's approach is a deeper and more comprehensive one.  It turns out that a lot of our problems, negative attitudes, and most frustrating issues can be linked to two things that make up a large part of our lives: residual "stuff," and residual personal relationships.  Here we learn how to dispatch and remedy our associations with both.The first half takes on the task of "clearing your possessions."  This act goes beyond just cleaning up a room or sorting through the litter on a cluttered table. Which items make you feel powerful?  Which ones make you think only of stressful times or annoying people?  Scrutinize each and every item, make your decisions, and get rid of the ones with the negative vibes.  They've been bogging you down without you even realizing it.The second half is all about "clearing your residual relationships." Think of personal encounters from your past that ended badly. Benz explains how you can resolve them by confronting the individual, apologizing, and forgiving.  You can visualize a new ending to every story, make it happen, and clear the way to a brighter future.Of course, I've oversimplified his process here, for the sake of providing basic information.  Benz goes into much more detail in his text. He has devised specific steps for the actions he recommends. He gives real-life examples. He explains why it's important to follow the method.  He shares client successes (with names and facts altered, for confidentiality). His plan may take a lot more thought and more time to apply than any others.  But he assures us that the results can be more fruitful and lasting.I've read my share of de-cluttering books and can attest that Benz's approach is fresh, different, and interesting.  Some may think it's far too complex.  But anyone can be motivated by anything at any time.  For many people, this approach will be the perfect one to help them take charge and to improve their lives.  At the very least, it'll give readers ideas. Benz advises that all of the steps must be taken in order for the plan to work.  And admittedly, a lot of people will want to shortchange the system.  He cautions us not to pick and choose what we want from his recommendations.  But of course, people will. I myself have decided to do a streamlined version of the possessions-clearing portion.  I honestly don't think I have any residual relationship problems to resolve.  (Maybe Benz would convince me otherwise, in person.)The book is well written.  At 304 pages, it's too long for anyone who is looking for a quick fix. You have to really want to change your habits to stick with Benz all the way through to the end. Naturally, there are some ways the information could have been presented that would have made the process a bit more user-friendly.  The pages outlining the steps could have been typed in form style, like typical full-page worksheets.  They could have all been reprinted in the back of the book, for easy access and for copying to use in each instance.  Benz could even have made them available on his web site, with password protection for purchasers of the book.John Benz is more than a therapist. He's a cheerleader, eager to champion your good efforts.  But he's also a tough taskmaster.  If you choose not to follow each step and to go the distance, he will be quick to explain why you'll soon return to your old habits. Overall, this is a good and thoughtful book.  It does have the power to change lives. In order to do so, however, the reader has to devote his/her full attention, commitment, and participation.[I was given a free paperback copy by the author in exchange for a fair-minded review.]

I've been reviewing books here since 1999.  At one time, I was ranked as a Top 500 reviewer.  I've fallen back, in recent years.  But my name is still on mailing lists for folks who are frantic to get reviewers for their books. And now I get besieged by companies selling various "products," who seem desperate to get as many good online words associated with their items as possible, in attempts to attract customers.  I ignore most of their requests.  I said yes to Clear-Ad because I knew I could use the brochure holder after I wrote this review.As another reviewer has suggested: This brochure holder is a little thinner than its competitors.  It's fine.  It works well on an undisturbed desk or counter.  What does it need to do, anyway?  Stand straight and tall without wobbling.  Hold what is put into it. Not collect a lot of dust and dander.  For this last requirement, two slots at the bottom of this holder appear to have this job.  I assume they're there so that dust doesn't accumulate and so the holder never requires much rinsing out.  Please note that this holder also slants back at a bit of an angle, so that brochures more directly meet the standing customers' eyes.  As a result, it's not a candidate for wall installation, so there's no need for holes on the back. And it's a little wider than a standard brochure or rack card is. So if your publicity people decide not to go with that standard width (or don't know what it is), the printed promotion may still fit in here nicely.I recommend this product, especially if you're just going to keep it on your counter or desk and not move it around constantly.  If you want take it along to trade shows as part of a display on your vendor table, you should pack material around it in your traveling cases so that the back doesn't break.  If you do lots of these kinds of mobile presentations, then maybe a more solid and durable holder is the right product for you.  Otherwise, this one is just fine.  Thanks, Clear-Ad![I was given a free brochure holder by Clear-Ad in exchange for a fair-minded review.]

Ian Marshall has found another way to bring mountains and literature together. In Story Line: Exploring the Literature of the Appalachian Trail, he paired sections of the Appalachian Trail with pieces of literature that were representative of each region.Here, he uses Abraham Maslow's psychological "Hierarchy of Needs" as a foundation for mountain and personal exploration. We go along with Marshall as he hikes with the spirit of fulfilling basic human needs, even while he relates the experience to appropriate literary references. Got it?  Whew!  It makes sense when you read it.  And aside from the psychology and the literature: "It is the purpose of this book to remind us why we need the earth, why we need to make contact with earth, why we experience renewal there." (p. 4) These are worthy goals.The five chapters take us to five different mountains or regions in North America, as we also scale the sides of Maslow's pyramid.  The accompanying literature selections are: Henry David Thoreau's "Walden;" Homer's "The Odyssey;" Pattiann Rogers's poems; John Muir's essays; and Walt Whitman's "Song of Myself."But the narrative isn't filled with serious stuff all the time. This is not an overly scholarly tome.  It's fun and compelling.  It contains many thought-provoking moments, posing questions about life and nature and priorities and such. Along the way, Marshall isn't afraid to put his own story into the mix, or to bring one of his children along on his hikes.  He reveals what's happening in his own life: both the good and the not-so. He gets downright poetic himself, especially in the Whitman section. "Song of Myself" is conveniently divided into 52 cantos.  So Marshall takes the text with him up the nearest mountain to his home in central Pennsylvania, once a week, for a year.  The object is to see how Whitman's classic relates to the mountain, to Marshall, and to the population at large.  What a great idea!  Some readers may be prompted to do the same after experiencing this project vicariously on the page.When you read "Peak Experiences," you may want to have two other books at your side.  I recommend borrowing a library copy of Pattiann Rogers' Song of the World Becoming: Poems, New and Collected, 1981-2001, which is what I did to get the most from the third chapter.  I wasn't familiar with her poetry; and the additional collection contains every poem referenced by Marshall.  This way, you can read each one in its entirety and separately, away from Marshall's comments and explanations.  You may also want to have a copy of Whitman's Leaves of Grass: The Original 1855 Edition handy so that you have the full text of the poem, "Song of Myself." You can follow Marshall's 52-week journey with Walt, and maybe find your own mountain to celebrate it with.I recommend this book to lovers of nature writing; to those who like hiking stories; and to fans of Thoreau, Muir, Whitman, Rogers, Homer, and/or Maslow.  You're sure to find some new ideas, insights, and perspectives here.

You have to appreciate the thought that went into the design of this clear glass teapot.  The pink butterfly knob on the lid is said to represent change for the better.  The dots on the handle and the sides are like drops of tea; and the intermingling lines on the sides represent waves.  This is creative but serious stuff. And what the folks at Tea Beyond want you to do most with this teapot is to use it in combination with their blooming teas. (Tea Beyond Tea Combo FLS-TCBO-FJEC001 Fab Flowering tea plus assorted whole leaf tea)I conducted the blooming tea experiment in my workplace to share with others.  The flowery directions (such as they are) didn't specify whether or not the glass infuser needed to be in the pot during the "blooming."  But it looked absent in the photos, so we went without it.  This was the right thing to do. Otherwise, there's no room for the flower to grow correctly.Each bloom begins about the size of a large marble.  After you pour hot water (acquired from another source, please, as this container is not stove-top safe) into the clear glass teapot, the mass begins to bloom and expand.  The tea that results is very light in taste and in color.  It's not overpowering, but not it's very memorable, either. My co-workers felt the same way.I think the pot and the blooms would make a unique centerpiece, or a host beverage for an intimate gathering of no more than three people.  The pot is rather small; but it does keep the tea warm for longer than you may expect.  You can keep adding hot water regularly, too.You'll also have to be respectful of the delicate nature of this glassware.  It could easily be broken. My everyday teapot is a heavy one, made of dark brown ceramic.  I chose it deliberately so that it would be durable for daily use, and so I wouldn't have to be diligent about washing it thoroughly between brews. (!)  It's perfect for me.  This clear glass teapot is too dainty.  I'm sure someone else out there will find it a perfect match, though.The blooming teas and the teapot didn't wow me.  I'm glad I had the chance to try them.  But I'll probably return to my usual patterns after these teas are gone.[I was given this package for free, in exchange for a fair review.]

This nicely-wrapped box consists of 10 items: two resealable packets each of three loose premium teas (Jasmine Green, Earl Grey Black, and Caramel Black); and four of Tea Beyond's tea blooms, especially for use with its clear glass teapot. (Tea Beyond PINK Glass Teapot Butterfly 710ml 24 Oz Non Drip with Infuser)The loose teas each have a nice consistency, and they brew well in any standard teapot.  I am a lover of Jasmine Green ... so I wouldn't have minded if all six packets had been of it.  This blend has a terrific aroma and flavor.  I'm enjoying it while it lasts.  The Earl Grey is okay.  I'm not much of a fan of the Caramel Black, however.  It had a dusty taste, I thought.  This is probably a matter of personal preference and not an indication of its quality.  For reference: When I'm left to my own devices on a typical day, I throw three bags into the pot: one of store-brand green tea, one of brand-name black tea, and one of Celestial Seasonings' Nutcracker Suite.  The last one is my second favorite to Jasmine Green.  I drink this or some combination of it, all day long.  The mix evens out the bite of black.The blooming teas were an interesting experiment that I conducted in my workplace to share with others.  Each bloom begins about the size of a large marble.  After you pour hot water into the clear glass teapot, the mass begins to bloom and expand.  The tea that results is very light in taste and color.  It's not overpowering, but it's not very memorable, either. I think the pot and the blooms would make a unique centerpiece, or a host beverage for an intimate gathering of no more than three people.  The pot is rather small.Overall, the teas are good.  The Jasmine Green is spectacular.  The rest are up for grabs, depending upon your own appreciation.  They didn't wow me.  I'm glad to have had the chance to try them.
