But I'll probably return to my usual sipping patterns after these teas are gone.[I was given this group of 10 items for free, in exchange for a fair review.]

These days, aspiring and veteran authors can find and attend writers' conferences in just about every nook and cranny of the planet.  Decades ago, this wasn't the case.  And one of the most notable series was the Fiction International gatherings sponsored by St. Lawrence University and held at Saranac Lake in the Adirondacks.  From 1975-1979, this beautiful setting served as the backdrop for some thoughtful conversations about the act and art of writing, among folks who knew what they were talking about.  (And went on to know even MORE about writing, as the years have passed.)  Here, via printed transcripts and archival photos, we can transcend both time and place and put ourselves right back into those audiences, with a volume that is singular in both content and physical format.We can eavesdrop on individual interviews with Margaret Atwood, Joyce Carol Oates, Ann Beattie, Annie Dillard, Gail Godwin, Jayne Anne Phillips, and Russell Banks.  We can replay discussions that involved some of those writers, as well as John Hawkes, William Kittredge, Robie Macauley, Carolyn Forche, Rosellen Brown, E. L. Doctorow, Charles Simmons, Maxine Groffsky, Nancy Nicholas, Daniel Halpern, G. E. Murray, and Annabel Levitt, and additionally Joe David Bellamy, who hosted the conferences and who edited this volume.  You'll hear a variety of voices from a variety of writers and writing-related professionals.  You can fill in the blanks of the successes have that since followed some of these folks.  In the later years, a continuing topic centers on the ideas raised by John Gardner in On Moral Fiction. in 1978.  You'll also get a glimpse into some writing processes, and what the publishing world looked like back then.  Before the Internet.  Before Amazon.  Before self-publishing could be masterfully achieved with a few clicks on a few keys and with electronic delivery.This hardback book is simply a joy to hold and to behold.  It was produced to look like an old-fashioned binding, with cloth-looking boards and a leather-like spine.  It's delightfully smooth to the touch.  It's heavier than it looks too, at 3 lbs.  The front cover has a round die-cut that allows an archival b&w scene to show through from the flyleaves.  And the reader's fingers will find it as well.The back cover summary ambitiously predicts: "Open the covers of this book to become part of a special exchange that will forever change the way you live your writing life."  I don't believe these pages will result in life-changing experiences for each writer.  For some, it may.  For anyone who aspires to be a writer, any book on writing or any conference can become a jump-starter.  It all begins with an eagerness to listen to the mentors.  Some good ones are found in these pages.  This book deserves a wider readership than perhaps it has yet gotten to date.

Daphne Michaels is a psychotherapist who conducts her own motivational programs in Tacoma, Washington.  This book is the first installment of a five-part series on these Gifts, "the principles that guide the Daphne Michaels Institute."  It can therefore be seen as a promotional piece for her seminars.  Which is fine.Each chapter here outlines one of the nine Gifts:  Awareness, Potential, Stillness, Disharmony, Harmony, Ease, Clarity, Freedom, and Engagement.  Most of them have additional sub-qualities associated with them, too.  Michaels defines what she means by these concepts and how important each presence is in our lives.  She's really just reminding us of what our instincts and inner voices should already be telling us -- although the Gift of Disharmony may sound a little counter intuitive and startling at first.  She concludes with a four-sentence paragraph, saying that if we deliberately acknowledge and live with these concepts, we will be able to "live the life of our dreams."  This advice is kind of like what we hear when the Beatles sing "All You Need is Love."  (Though love is NOT one of the Gifts outlined here, nor is it a sub-quality of any of those identified.)  These nine Gifts are all we need, Michaels implies.I like how she makes her points, then continues to reference and to link them from one section to another.  The writing is well thought out and polished.  The trouble is that the audience is given no takeaway, nothing to think about or to do in response.  At least a chapter-end series of questions or suggested activities would have made her philosophies more relevant to the average reader.  The book ends up being a theoretical lecture, and not an interactive or empowering experience.  And just like those old Lennon and McCartney lyrics, the message sounds wonderful at first.  You're eager to sing along.  It's only when you think about it later that you question the practicality of it all.  You ask yourself how you're going to implement the advice.  And the songsters can't help you.  They've already moved on to the next town.Michaels probably wants to use this book as a teaser, a customer attractor for her seminars.  And she doesn't want to give away all of her material for under $15.  Fine.  But if she markets this title to a wider population who will never venture to Washington state for a personal encounter, then she needs to give those readers an extra nudge to get started on their course of self-improvement.  Questions, considerations, exercises, some tangible somethings. Maybe a link to special offerings on her website.  Otherwise, it's all in the clouds.Ms. Michaels likes to use metaphors; so here's one to describe this book.  It's a recipe for living more fully and authentically.  The author gives us a list of nine ingredients.  And that's it.  We don't know whether to mix them together in equal amounts, bake them, broil them, or toss them into the air to see where they land.  Maybe it's enough to merely gather them together on a table and stare at them until something magical happens.At any given time, any individual can be motivated by any book, any person, or any experience.  The Ripple Effect can show up at any time.  The bottom line is that this general conceptual approach may be all that's needed to gently prod some people into living a fuller life -- or even to seek out the programs at the Daphne Michaels Institute.  I suspect that the larger majority, however, like me, will want and expect more concrete examples and more definitive ways to put these theories into practice.  Without them, we can just breeze through the chapters, put the book down when we reach the end, and then say, "Okay, I understand the importance of these Gifts.  Now what do I do?"[I was given a free copy of this book in return for an honest review.]

William Trogdon made his now-famous cross-country back-roads drive in 1978.  His subsequent book Blue Highways: A Journey into America was released in December 1982, more than 30 years ago, under the name William Least Heat Moon.  How did he transform himself from traveler and interviewer-photographer to author?  How did his experiences finally reach the printed page?  These are the subjects of this memoir.  And they form an interesting story:  one "more of labor than luck, more of fight than fate, but it also wasn't without those other two elements." (p. 133)We have the advantage of knowing how this tale ends. We know the book will come out and that it will become a bestseller.  But the process of getting there -- yikes!  It's enough to drive a sane person to craziness.  And that's one of the points.  This business of writing and publishing may be one of the most frustrating endeavors ever devised by mankind.  (Witness "Eleven Thoughts on Rejection Dejection," p. 77.)Heat-Moon walks us through the process:  through various drafts and readers and submissions and rejections ... until the magic day arrives at last, when someone says Yes.  But more writing and negotiation must take place first.  Many months pass, and at last he is PUBLISHED.  Along with the release date comes the emotional tumult realized in seeing the tangible manifestation of one's work.  It's a satisfying feeling.  For a short time.  Then as other authors do, he finds he has to move on to the next project.He concludes with more specific advice for writers, outlining the kinds of references and resources we should have at our fingertips.  Some are classics, and some may be new to most writer-readers.  This book is therefore recommended to both Blue Highways fans and to writers of all kinds.This book happened to come my way just as I was under deadline to produce a finished manuscript myself.  Instead of working on my own chapters, I chose to take a few days off to read William's book.  I'm glad that I did.  His words reassured me that I should be able to survive and succeed.  If he did it, I can too.  Thanks!I owned a copy of Blue Highways back in the day.  It has since found another home.  (The bulky silhouette of PrairyErth: A Deep Map, however, is quite noticeable on the shelf.)  I may need to get another copy and travel down those roads again.  I'm quite certain that the original book (along with others, like On the Road with Charles Kuralt) pointed me toward the possibilities.  It helped to prod me to get out and explore the countryside past the interstates in the 1990s, 2000s, and today.  Double thanks!~ Corinne H. Smith, author of Westward I Go Free: Tracing Thoreau's Last Journey

What a terrific idea!  Compile a volume of 44 of Garrison Keillor's best stories and poems.  His admirers can then sit down with him and hear them again in person, this time with additional words of explanation.  A few b&w photos are even sprinkled in for good measure; and at least one of them will generate a giggle or three.If you listen to "A Prairie Home Companion" (APHC) on NPR on Saturday nights ... if you've attended a live broadcast ... if you've seen his one-man shows in person ... if you've read at least one of his Lake Wobegon books -- then some of this material will sound familiar.  Nevertheless, It's all good, as the saying goes.  Each story comes with introductory remarks from the author himself that give insights into the background, the characters, or even into the writing process.  The selections venture well beyond the region of Lake Wobegon and Minnesota.  As with most of his tales, the audience can never really be sure where the memoir ends and the fabrication begins.  That's part of the fun.  His people seem to get themselves into quirky situations that are all too plausible in real life.  And yes, a shortened version of the pontoon boat story appears early on in the text.Here we hear his voice rise off the printed page, in the style to which we've become accustomed.  Mr. Keillor is one of the most creative and prolific writers of all time -- a true lover of language and a master of description -- and we are fortunate enough to share the planet with him.  When we consider his career, we have to wonder how the man has time to do it all.  He is constantly penning poems and stories for books, columns, live appearances, the weekly radio show, and more.  Yet he made the effort to create a unique and substantial book in this one, and not simply a literary greatest hits volume of pieces that could be found elsewhere or that everybody already knows.  You may even shake your head or laugh out loud as you follow along.  Don't rush!  Take your time and savor the moments.  Please also note that the nuances of some selections may come with an R rating.  (Including a poem that no publisher wanted to touch, until now.)I'm especially glad to come upon the inclusion of Mr. Keillor's New York Times review of the first volume of Mark Twain's autobiography.  It's a classic on its own.  He's honest about a book that he could easily have given a mere and courteous nod to.  Instead, he points out its many inconsistencies and failings.  It was the bravest stand he could take.I became one of his fans and admirers after picking up Leaving Home: A Collection of Lake Wobegon Stories in the late 1980s.  When I turned a page and saw the line, "Corinne doesn't believe in God, but there is some evidence to show that God believes in her," I had to say out loud, "Whoa!  How does he know me so well?"  Anyway:  Yes, I've read several of his books; and I have witnessed his performances and the APHC broadcasts in person many times over the past ten years.  When I learned that this new reader was in the works, I knew I wanted to get a copy as soon as it was released."The Keillor Reader" will not merely appease APHC and GK fans (although it will do this job thoroughly and sincerely).  It should also be welcomed by fellow and aspiring writers:  both for the back stories that Mr. Keillor provides, and for the example he sets in his own writing style.  (If you REALLY want to know the secret of how "the news from Lake Wobegon" gets done, turn immediately to page 35.)  And if you like what you find here, you'll be happy to know that you can always hear more.  Just tune your radio to the proper station each Saturday night, or go back and read one of his previous books.  There are many to choose from.

The famous Gutenberg Bible.  We all know that it was the first major book to be published on a printing press with movable type, instead of being handwritten by humans.  But what's the story behind the basic facts?  This is what Alix Christie explores here in her first novel.The tale is told through the eyes of Peter Schoeffer, a young but experienced scribe who is apprenticed to help Johann Gensfleisch, the man known as Gutenberg.  Peter's adopted father Johann Fust is the merchant who is backing Gutenberg's project.  We hear the details here in retrospect, when Peter describes to someone else just how the Bible came to fruition, as he looks back about twenty years after its publication.  Enough time has passed and enough people are gone that he feels safe enough to reveal the whole story.This is the 15th century, a time that would later be referred to as the Early Renaissance.  The town of Mainz is Germanic, but there is no Germany.  This region is instead part of the Holy Roman Empire, a church-dominated society with a complex hierarchy of archbishops and cardinals and elders and such, all operating beneath the auspices of the pope in Rome.  And there are decrees and bans and indulgences and seemingly, a lot of tension all around.  Add to this mix a man like Gutenberg, who creates this new and exciting and revolutionary process that has to be employed in near secrecy, else the church officials or the powerful guilds discover it and take it away from him.  And then they may see fit to remove him and his associates from that society as well.  It's a near miracle that he finds any success at all.  And IS it truly success?Once Peter designs and carves the type, and once the decision is made for the first major print job to be a Bible -- a rather long and ambitious text, don't you think? -- the stress increases exponentially on the small handful of Gutenberg's men.  Peter is caught in the middle between his two mentors, the visionary and the funder.  At the same time, he's working daily with Latin verses that seem to grow more sacred and more personal with the turning of each beautiful page.  It takes two years for the shop to produce the book.  TWO YEARS!  And even as they set type and roll out paper or vellum and pull the presses, the workers are always looking over their shoulders, always wondering when the project will be interrupted or ended by lack of funds, by technical problems, by church interference ... or even by Gutenberg's unintentional self-sabotage.  And even though this narrative advances nicely for us readers too, it sometimes seems to take just as long for us to read about it as it took them to print the actual books.I chose to read this novel out of book-lover curiosity, even though I'm more comfortable with American settings and with events of the last two centuries.  This historical period is thus not one that I know well or really, at all.  At times I felt as if it confounded me, and that I surely didn't understand the nuances of all of the politics and the pervasiveness of the Catholic church and the craftsman guilds.  I glossed over a few of the more confrontational scenes: not because I wasn't interested in them, but because I couldn't quite get the sense of their importance and what the relationships were of the authorities involved.  Maybe an opening chart of Empire hierarchy or an introductory note of historical background would have helped me.  Still, Christie's work here is quite good, and it represents a tremendous achievement for a first-time novelist who herself also has a background in the printing process.I am VERY glad that I read this book.  Its story will stay with me for a good long time.  I recommend it to members of a general literate audience -- especially to those who love books and the printed page -- knowing full well that its subject matter and time period won't appeal to everyone.  (In fact, I know EXACTLY which friend I will be passing my copy to.)  This is a perfect book for church- or religion-based book clubs.  Read "Gutenberg's Apprentice," and you will look at books and typefaces and the whole process of publication more intently from that moment on.  Once again, an instance of historical fiction gives us a terrific way to learn real history.

In other books about writing, I ran into enough quotes from the creative wisdom of prolific American author John O'Hara (1905-1970) that I finally decided to seek out the source.  If others thought this man's insights were worthwhile, then maybe I should read them in their original context.  They were right.  These pieces are worth reading and underlining.  Some are even laugh-out-loud funny.This book offers an interesting mix of stuff.  41 separate selections consist of O'Hara's lectures, speeches, forewords, published and non-published essays, and interviews.  They span the decades from the 1930s through the 1960s.  Writing or a specific aspect of the craft is the main topic of each.  Its act and art transcend time.  A full section addresses the work of F. Scott Fitzgerald.  ("[He] was a RIGHT writer, and it's going to be a damned shame if the generation after mine ... and the one after that don't get to know him.")  O'Hara's asides offer some of his funniest moments, too.  I wish we could know what reactions he got from his initial audiences.You may get bored if you first study the table of contents too closely.  You may think that you won't want to read each selection.  I recommend that you instead launch into the pages and proceed from front to back without worry.  That's the only way you'll come upon the gems that speak most to you.  It's all common sense material here, but someone had to actually say it or write it down.  Examples of his simplicity:"You do not think of becoming a writer; you KNOW that you are a writer, with even fewer doubts, I suspect, than the doubts that bother a young man who suspects that he should study for the priesthood." (p. 32)"The most truly satisfactory reward a writer ever gets is the moment he holds that book in his hand and says, This is my baby." (p. 68)"Old authors never die, they only talk for pay." (p. 71)No, this book isn't a narrative like Stephen King's On Writing: A Memoir of the Craft or Anne Lamott's Bird by Bird: Some Instructions on Writing and Life.  But in their own way, O'Hara's collected lectures and essays aptly convey his approach to the craft and the profession.  This volume deserves to share the writer's reference shelf with King, Lamott, and the rest.  Sometimes you need to plop down beside a crusty, experienced curmudgeon and just listen.  And on some days, it's easier and more inspirational to READ about writing than it is to actually sit down and WRITE.  I'll bet John O'Hara would have an opinion about that, too.

... with the help of terrific insights, like the ones Michael Sims offers us here.  There's nothing like a new Thoreau biography to re-introduce our favorite author-naturalist to another population.  And veteran Thoreauvians are entertained as well, because it gives them new material to chew on and to debate.Yes, quite a few Thoreau biographies already exist.  In the beginning they were written by Henry's friends, as a way of honoring and remembering him.  Then a few fans at the turn of the last century (and on both sides of the Atlantic) took on the task of adding to and refining the information, because they could still ask crucial questions of those few remaining people of Concord who had once known Henry.  During the WWII years, the literary scholars joined the crowd; and they set the standard for many decades.  Today we hear a diversity of voices, from a variety of sources -- many of them, from those folks who encountered Thoreau in high school or in college in the 1960s-1970s-1980s.  Like Michael Sims.  (Like me.)We all have our own personal versions of Henry.  For Sims, he's forever young and vital.  The focus here is on the first 30 years of Henry's life:  up until the time that he leaves Walden Pond in 1847.  He paints the picture of a highly sensitive man who is curious about the behaviors of both Nature and mankind.  Someone who wants to be at least a little successful at being a writer, but who encounters difficulties in getting published.  Included are naturally the usual stories and the near-myths of Henry's life -- abruptly resigning after teaching only two weeks at a public school; becoming devastated by his brother John's death; accidentally setting the woods on fire; moving to Walden Pond; spending a night in jail for non-payment of the poll tax, etc. etc. etc.  To those who know or who have read a lot about Thoreau, many stories will be familiar.  Some won't.  All of them are told in a fresh, new style.  Sims also adds more context than is found in some previous biographies, and he includes intricate details that have not previously surfaced.  He also adds more references to Nathaniel Hawthorne and Edgar Allan Poe than most people do.  The result?  More voices telling the story, and some new connections made.  Nice!Sims also writes with a Thoreauvian flourish, casually weaving in some of Henry's own turns of phrase.  His narrative will have the most savvy readers nodding and smiling and thinking, Ahhh, I know why he said it this way.  These pages will also set a few devoted fans and accomplished scholars who are approaching any "new" facts to scratching their heads, saying "Wait -- what?  No!  Really?  Are you sure about this?"  (He had me scrambling to my stash of reference books on more than one occasion.)  The answer is, Yes.  And he's got all of the documentation to back up his facts.  He did original research.  This book isn't a mere rehash of the old stuff.Sure, Sims may have overlooked or omitted a few aspects or incidents that will surprise readers.  For example:  he glosses over the fact that Thoreau taught himself surveying and took on jobs marking many local property lines around Concord, beyond his initial scrutiny of Walden Pond's depth and borders.  The author may not have had a chance to read Patrick Chura's Thoreau the Land Surveyor before finishing this manuscript.  (This ground-breaking book isn't included in the bibliography.)  And of course, this narrative doesn't touch much on the last 14 years of Henry's life.  Only one final chapter serves to summarize "the rest of the story."This book is highly recommended:  not only for Thoreauvians, but also for the general public and certainly for libraries of all kinds, including public and college libraries.  (Don't dare weed out Harding and Richardson!  Just put Sims next to those guys.)  Thanks to writers like Michael Sims, we're learning even more about our old friend Henry Thoreau.  Someday we may know it ALL.Corinne H. Smith, author of Westward I Go Free: Tracing Thoreau's Last Journey

What is "home"?  How and why are animals drawn toward it?  That's the topic of Bernd Heinrich's new book.  Thanks to the title and to the dust jacket illustration, we initially think here of the act of migration, and especially of the most noticeable ones:  of large groups of birds flying overhead in the spring and the fall.  But Heinrich gives us additional examples of homing in species of insects, amphibians, reptiles, and mammals; from his own observations and from the research of others.  The animals may be led by instinct, sight, or a combination of reading the landscape and responding to magnetic earth forces.  The choice depends on species, location, and opportunity.  It's interesting stuff.  The topic of homing is a much richer one than it may appear at first thought.Then:  What comes after the creature finds its best territory?  Home building and home maintenance, of course.  And we learn more fascinating details about the kind of structures that animals create, if they feel the need to build them.  Now Heinrich turns his sights toward humans.  (And we knew that he would get to this eventually, after we read the Preface.)  We follow him to Maine, to his own most familiar places.  Here he gives us further fodder for consideration, especially in debating why humans developed into home-builders at all.  I wish he had reached this connection a bit sooner, though.  And he doesn't quite resolve the personal conflict that he references in the Preface.  Still, I do appreciate his final, environmentally savvy, conclusion.Animal lovers should be forewarned or reminded that Bernd Heinrich IS a scientist.  He "collects" animals for study, hunts for deer, and has no qualms about sacrificing bumble bees to orb spider webs.  If you can't bear even the mere idea of treating animals in such a manner, then you'll have to skim over a few passages.  But the book is well worth your efforts.  And I hope you're familiar with the metric system, too, because all of his measurements run to centimeters and meters and such.As always, Heinrich's drawings are wonderful additions to his text.  And he leaves us with a terrific bibliography that could lead us in reading directions for the rest of our lives"The Homing Instinct" is recommended for those who crave more information about animals -- and especially about birds, insects, and humans.  The book release is well timed for Spring, the period of migration and home-building.  I found myself remembering reading Edwin Way Teale's North With the Spring: A Naturalist's Record of a 17,000-Mile Journey With the North American Spring at this time of year:  a classic and similar book, and yet quite different.  Since Heinrich has already given us Summer World: A Season of Bounty and Winter World: The Ingenuity of Animal Survival, perhaps this new book is his way of offering us both Spring and Fall at once.  We'll see.  The bottom line is that our world is full of amazing sights and behaviors.  We can all be inspired by people like Berrnd Heinrich, who seek out and find this kind of amazement in even the smallest things ... and then are nice enough share it with the rest of us.

Those of us who grew up in Lancaster County, Pennsylvania, in the 1960s and 1970s don’t have to ask who Bill Saylor is.  To us, he’ll always be the weatherman for WGAL-TV, Channel 8:  the one who wore the blue Atlantic uniform when he stood in front of a simple U.S. map and told us what kind of weather we could expect the next day.  Bill has finally taken the time to write a memoir that includes some of the details of his broadcasting career as well as highlights from some of his other endeavors.Bill grew up in the wake of the Depression in Reading, Pennsylvania.  He talks about his childhood, a few of his family members, and some of his school memories, especially with playing baseball and football.  Then he served for two years in the U.S. Navy and got to see a bit of the world beyond Reading and Philadelphia.  A few post-military jobs got him into radio and television broadcasting … which landed him in Lancaster.  And he’s been here ever since.  He talks about those relatively early days of TV and of the later attempts to bring unions into the station.  He showcases his celebrity interactions, along with b&w two-shots of his interviews with the most famous.  He also reveals some of the issues surrounding his recent campaigns for local office, as a floating Democrat in a sea of Republicans.  If I had lived in the area at the time, I would have voted for him.  Alas, no.His narrative makes for easy and interesting reading.  But I have to admit, there are a few oddities and quirks in his telling.  Bill rarely makes references to dates or years, so it’s only by happenstance that we can figure out that he started working at WGAL in 1961.  And even then, you have to almost be an insider yourself to understand the connection, because he NEVER mentions the station’s call letters or its channel number.  He doesn’t tell any stories about being the Atlantic weatherman.  He doesn’t talk about the majority of the reporters or the on-air people that he worked with at Channel 8, and he doesn’t drop any local names that we would recognize or remember.  He doesn’t call his closest family members by name, either.  Perhaps he was wary of recrimination or backlash.  Perhaps he figured his audience would know what or who he was talking about.  I guess some will.  And as is the case with many self-published books, these pages could have benefited from the services of a casual proofreader or a freelance editor.  Occasional lapses in punctuation or spelling slipped through a few cracks here.I had the terrific opportunity to meet Bill Saylor at one of his local book signings.  Now that I’ve read his book, I’m REALLY glad that I had a chance to chat with him for about 30 minutes.  He told me in person the kinds of stories and details that I had hoped were in the book.  Now I know that they aren’t.  If you get the chance, go see Bill.  You too may be impressed with what a nice guy he is, as well as startled by how tall he stands (6’3”).This book is recommended for anyone who wants to know “the rest of the story” …  although we have to understand that this isn’t ALL of it.  Not by a long shot.

Life is nice for Betsy Devonshire, owner of the yarn shop called Crewel World in Excelsior, Minnesota.  Her live-in boyfriend, Connor Sullivan, is simply the grandest gentleman who ever stepped out of Ireland.  Her business is doing well, especially in the capable hands of store manager Godwin DuLac.  And Betsy is taking good care of herself by eating sensibly and by participating in regular water aerobics classes.  It’s when the venue for these classes is temporarily relocated that her routine changes and a murder takes place.  How can she NOT get involved in solving it?The lifeless body of Theodora “Teddi” Wahlberger is found in the pool of the senior citizen residence called Watered Silk, a facility Betsy has just gotten to know by teaching a punch-needle class to some women there and by using that same heated therapy pool.  But why was such a young woman killed?  And why was her body put there, of all places?  When the guard on duty is fired for negligence in the line of duty, his aunt asks Betsy to find Teddi’s actual murderer.  Betsy does her best to trace Teddi’s life and friends -- especially since the woman was pregnant and had associated with at least three different men in recent months.  Her investigation steps up a notch when another woman is killed at Watered Silk, probably because she knew too much.  Now Betsy has two murders to solve.  Naturally, she lets local police officer Mike Malloy in on her findings.  We have no doubt that the killer will discovered in due course.  In this case, it’s good that Betsy has friends to help her with stake-outs!Avid fans of Monica Ferris’ series will gobble this one up.  Newbies can be attracted to this title but will ALWAYS be encouraged to go back to the beginning to catch up. Incredibly, this is our 17th encounter with Betsy, Crewel World, and the people and pets of Excelsior.  It’s difficult to believe that Betsy was once brand-new to the town, to running a stitchery store, and to puzzling out murder mysteries, and not all that long ago, either.  Here’s hoping for more shared adventures!

No doubt about it:  Henry David Thoreau's most famous book can be a tough nut to crack.  How can contemporary readers understand its lengthy passages?  And why should anyone page through the ruminations of a guy who lived next to a pond for two years, back in the 1840s?  What could his words possibly mean for us today?These are the topics that Dr. Payne has generally taken on here.  Whew!  At only 89 pages of text, this slim book serves as a teaser, a prod, or a nudge to the potential WALDEN reader.  First of all, Payne provides biography and context.  He drops Thoreau and the book in the Concord of the mid-19th century and describes the times, the people, and the surroundings.  Then he aligns some of his chapters here with selected ones from WALDEN, covering a few of its main themes.  He includes some small b&w illustrations, which are usually present-day photographs taken around Concord and Walden Pond.  These images may mean more to people if/when they've seen the sites in person.  Or they could assure long-distance readers that these places do still exist, even if they don't quite mirror the landscape that Thoreau saw and wrote about, himself.I'm not sure Payne definitively answers the Why.  His approach instead is to rustle up the evidence and to let the audience members themselves realize how much Thoreau's thoughts, words, and actions are still relevant to our own lives.To be fair:  I met Dr. Payne at the conference that he hosts, the John Burroughs Nature Writing Conference & Seminar series at SUNY Oneonta, in 2012.  I consider us to be professional acquaintances.  He did not ask me to read and review his book.Readers should note that early editions of this print-on-demand book contained a number of typographical errors.  I have been assured by the publisher that these have been corrected.  This book could now act as a prompt or a supplemental study guide for those opening WALDEN for the first time.  It's not as detailed as the analysis you can find in Leslie Perrin Wilson's CliffsNotes Thoreau, Emerson, and Transcendentalism, but Dr. Payne's book is certainly a resource that a frantic undergraduate under studying deadline could be grateful for.By Corinne H. Smith, author of Westward I Go Free: Tracing Thoreau's Last Journey

And who wouldn't be?  The part-time public library director in Battle Lake, Minnesota, has discovered at least one dead body per month since she arrived in town last Spring.  Her most recent interactions with bad guys and investigations have left her so scared that she's taken to sleeping UNDER her bed.  How can she get herself out of this funk and back to a reasonable life -- the one that includes being nestled in the arms of her charming boyfriend, Johnny Leeson?Well, being mugged by a couple of druggies from Chicago doesn't help matters at all.  Seems there's a new gang in town.  Literally.  And before you know it, not only has Mira had contact with these thugs, but she's also spied a body in the lake that may have ties to the newcomers.  Mira's got to figure out what's going on.  But at the same time, she needs to run the library, write a newspaper article about a local history museum, and put in some PI-in-training hours to find a missing person.  AND make time for Johnny.  AND deal with Mrs. Berns, her ever-exasperating library staffer and co-conspirator in crime-related shenanigans.  Really, it's a wonder the woman even has a chance to breathe.  We have to turn the pages quickly just to keep up with her.Once again, author Jess Lourey has crafted an intricate and satisfying series of plot lines that have no choice but to converge.  Mira James is one of the most likable people in contemporary mysteries.  And she has to get everything done in order to understand the situation herself, and to reveal it to everyone else.  This time, readers will probably put two and two together on at least one front, before Mira does.  It still makes for intriguing and fun reading.  And even at the end, we're left with questions.  Will Mira get her PI license?  Will Mrs. Berns continue to be her sidekick?  Will love prevail with Johnny Leeson?  I have to admit that I'm already a little sad that we may share only three more escapades with these people.To be fair:  I've been a fan of this series since the beginning.  I met and chatted with author Jess Lourey at a book signing for November Hunt in 2011.  I've interacted with her on Facebook.  I've found her to be an approachable author who doesn't hesitate to help and to motivate other writers.  I probably won't read the non-mystery books that she has planned -- she's got lots! -- but I will devour the rest of this series."January Thaw" is highly recommended for any mystery lover.  You don't need to have read the previous Murder-by-Month episodes before this one; but as is often the case, your reading experience will be greatly enhanced if you do.  Begin at the beginning with May Day.  By the time you read all nine, Jess's "February Fever" will be further along in the printing pipeline, and you won't have to wait too long to catch up with Mira James again.

For Lynn Darling, this is the perfect time to figure out her place in Life.  Her daughter Zoe is away at a college in Maine.  Lynn now has a chance to contemplate her roles as a mother, a widow, a woman, and a writer.  She chooses to buy a small house in South Woodstock, Vermont, in the heavily-forested Green Mountains.  The trouble is, she has a habit of getting lost.  She's directionally-challenged and can't even read a simple map.  She goes out for a walk and can't find her way home.  This memoir is thus a book-long metaphor on getting lost and then becoming found -- both in the woods as well as in Life.What works here?  Well, Darling is an accomplished wordsmith, first of all.  She's good at descriptions and she comes up with unique observations.  Secondly, I give her kudos for embarking on this self-imposed exile -- which is even interrupted by a diagnosis of breast cancer and a series of subsequent treatments for it.  I feel very strongly that individuals need to be spend time alone and know themselves before they can successfully manage getting caught up in relationships with others.  It seems as if Lynn is finally getting the chance to do this here.  She's long overdue for it.What doesn't work?  Well, Darling takes the concept of being lost to a point of obsession.  You have to wonder if maybe the law of attraction is at work here, and that the more she focuses on being lost, the more lost she becomes.  She does a great deal of research on folks throughout history who have gotten famously lost and how they coped with their situations.  She knows she needs help, and she gets some decent advice from a variety of wilderness-oriented teachers.  She even takes a stab at learning how to use a compass and a topographic map.  But she seems to take on her overall task as more of a required assignment than as an intrinsic desire.  Is her Vermont house a sanctuary or a prison?  The fact that she names it Castle Dismal (after Nathaniel Hawthorne's assessment of his childhood home), is a more revealing act than she may care to admit.  And she will probably never get over the stranger-in-a-strange-land syndrome of being a big-city girl plopped down in a rural and mountainous New England town.In the end:  Has Darling changed?  Is she better off when she leaves the woods four years later than when she first got there?  Only she can truly decide.  The bottom line for me is that I didn't always see her as a likable person in this book.Still, I recommend "Out of the Woods" to women who are going through the kinds of cancer treatments that Darling did.  Her experience may help others who are coping with similar struggles and tangled emotions.  This aspect of the book is not the one being most promoted, but it may prove to be the most useful one for readers.

Canadians Robert and Signe McMichael didn't begin their adult lives as deliberate collectors of art.  And in the early 1950s, when they first bought a large piece of farmland in Kleinburg, north of Toronto, they did so because the land spoke to them with the kind of beautiful voice that they felt represented all of Canada.  It was not because they quickly envisioned it as a place to create and open a unique public museum.  At least, this wasn't their initial intent.  The idea came to them over time."When we searched out a site in the unspoiled countryside, built a shelter of natural materials and filled it with art drawn from nature we felt we had somehow created a symbolic microcosm of our nation," describes Robert McMichael. (p. 30)  And that was the beginning of something special taking place at the building they called Tapawingo, "a place of joy."This is Robert McMichael's autobiography, but it's actually a history of the McMichael Canadian Art Collection, too.  It also serves as an interesting study in fine art collecting, and specifically of the works and nuances of the members of the Group of Seven (Franklin Carmichael, Lawren Harris, A.Y. Jackson, Frank Johnston, Arthur Lismer, J. E. H. MacDonald, and Fred Varley; and A. J. Casson, Emily Carr, who number among later additions).  Initially it's the artwork of Tom Thomson (pre-Group) that the McMichaels are most attracted to.  And so they start to collect Thomson paintings as pieces become available.  Along the way, they also collect key connections with friends and relatives of the Group of Seven -- most of the artists themselves, being already gone.  And these encounters lead to the purchase of more pieces and more encounters and more connections, and so on and so on.  It's The Ripple Effect, in startling Technicolor.  As the couple adds to the collection, the house grows organically to display all of it at once.  Eventually Inuit art of First Nations people fits nicely into the mix, too.  The collection can thus be said to represent the creative historic work of residents of the entire country.Since Robert is telling the story, he's not exactly unbiased.  You have to remind yourself that the narrative is told from his own perspective, even though he obviously tries to be both neutral and polite in some cases.  Humble, as well.  This tiptoeing is especially noticeable when he's dealing with the legal hoop-jumping and paperwork regarding transference of the ownership of the museum to the province of Ontario in November 1965, as well as in various administrative actions that happened in the years afterward.  You just know there are more details to these stories than he's revealing.  And he chooses in the end to keep the reputation of the museum clean, within the covers of this book.  A wise decision.One frustration is that Robert talks about the various Group of Seven paintings as if we know them simply by title and can accurately envision them.  Alas, there are no reproductions of artwork in this book, other than the small graphics that head each chapter.  Sure, it's nice to see the b&w portraits of the McMichaels and their friends and associates in the photo section.  And yes, putting images of art into a publication can be problematic; and b&w reproductions could never do full justice to the original vibrancy that Group paintings are known for.  But still.  To get the full experience of this history, the reader should have access to a nearby reference book that showcases pieces by the Group of Seven.  Or, he or she should be standing physically in the museum itself, and be able to gaze upon the real-life paintings.  Just as Robert McMichaels may have, as he assembled this manuscript."One Man's Obsession" should be mandatory reading for lovers of Canadian art, philanthropists, and anyone intimately familiar with the legacies of Tom Thomson and the Group of Seven.  It offers an interesting story that a lot of people will overlook because they've not heard of the McMichael Canadian Art Collection and haven't been to Kleinburg.  To this audience, it's an intriguing introduction to something brand-new.  If you HAVE visited this place, then you should pick up this book and read how it all got started.  You'll be prompted to return to the museum for a second, more knowing, look.  At least.

New Hampshire-ite Ben Kilham has spent many years studying black bears, raising cubs, reintroducing them into the wild, and coming to conclusions about their behaviors and habits.  Because the females in bear society control the organization of the territories, we most often get to follow Squirty, the dominant female in Ben's local beardom.  Through her actions and Ben's narrative, we learn about food supply size and distribution, communication modes and patterns, ways of treating both family members and strangers, and the simple system of rules and punishments that guide the acts of cooperation and altruism.  With bears, you ask?  Yes, with bears.  And it all makes sense.  Even when Ben discovers the special organ that bears have in their skulls in order to discern the edibility or the trustworthiness of something or someone new, it makes sense.  It turns out that bears lead relatively quiet but fairly interesting lives.  And they certainly don't aim specifically to attack humans, as some fearful people have been led to believe. ("The solution to the nuisance bear problem is not so much about managing bears; it's about managing people" ... and "controlling smell." pp. 164-165)He gives us enough to go on -- because you just know that he's got tons more data and documentation and illustrative stories -- and then he proceeds to the topic of how we can learn from the examples presented by these creatures.  He anticipates the silent "So what?" that his readers may ask, and he answers the query quite admirably.A basic but key connection is how we humans acquire bits and pieces of information, over and over, every minute of every day.  "Somewhere in our past we began relying on the writings of others and lost the ability to use the high-quality information our brains were designed to process," Ben says, on p. 138.  If we could take the time to observe and to process the details ourselves, like bears do, we'd be in much better shape.  That the concept of war is alien to the bear world is the single most important lesson we can learn from them, and from many other animals as well, I believe.  Bravo to Ben Kilham for bringing this issue to the printed page.  And for his work with New England black bears, Chinese giant pandas, Russian browns and polars, and other four-footed kids around the globe."Out on a Limb" is a book that should first be read by anyone who lives in a natural habitat where bears reside.  Next, it should be read by every animal control officer, every wildlife manager, every animal lover, every public-serving naturalist, every environmentalist, every peace activist, and even every legislator -- all of these, regardless of location, and perhaps not in this order.  I haven't felt this strongly about a nature-oriented book since I mailed paperback copies of David Brower's Let the Mountains Talk, Let the Rivers Run: A Call to Save the Earth to all of my then-legislators.We also need to make space in our canon to welcome the wisdom of independent researchers like Ben.  These are folks who approach their favorite topics out of interest and fascination and love; and not out of academic requirement, perceived financial gain, or celebrity accolade.  Even so:  Here's hoping Ben Kilham gets much praise, many donations for continued research, and a big stand of mountain blueberries for Squirty and her relatives to share.  Because we have every confidence that they WILL share.

... so now is the perfect time to revisit the formal investigation of the assassination of President John F. Kennedy.  Howard P. Willens was part of the 23-man legal team that assisted the 8-member Warren Commission in its mission to puzzle out The Truth back in 1963-1964.  Willens is the sole surviving member of the overall supervisory staff, so it makes sense that he should be the one to confirm these details.As soon as those gun shots were fired at the presidential motorcade, the facts of the tragedy became tainted with rumors and speculations.  The Warren Commission had to launch its investigation amidst all of the inconsistencies that were being fed to it at every turn:  from the hospitals, the CIA, J. Edgar Hoover's FBI, and from the Secret Service and its Treasury Department overseers.  It had to work with and maintain good relationships with each one of those entities, as well as with security and political authorities in the city of Dallas, the state of Texas, the U.S. State Department, the U.S. Justice Department, the Immigration and Naturalization Service, the IRS, and even some contacts in Mexico, Cuba, and the Soviet Union and their embassies.  It had to research the lives of both Lee Harvey Oswald and Jack Ruby.  It gathered testimonies from 552 individuals.  It dealt with the ever-present media and a confused and worried American public.  And all of the Commissioners and lawyers assisting them had to work closely together, get along, and agree on their findings.  The task became the largest criminal investigation ever conducted in the United States, and one of the most politically sensitive.  And it took place in a pre-computer and pre-Internet world, when surveillance cameras were not mounted upon every city lamp post, and as Cold-War anxieties simmered at the surface.Willens' re-telling of the procedure at times reads like a detective novel.  In this, it also reminds me of Woodward & Bernstein's All the President's Men, back in the day.  Both are full of many details, names, dates, and who-knew-what-whens.  (You may want to create your own list of the major players in the game, in order to keep them straight.  I did.)  This book follows all of the threads of the Commission's daunting investigation.  Obviously the emphasis is on the undertakings of the staff members, who were the real worker bees for the project.  It's fascinating to watch them tunnel their way to real results.  I understand now that the Warren Commission did the best job it could, within some limitations and certainly under pressure-cooker conditions.The JFK assassination will always be debated.  It will always be controversial. It will always serve as a case study for political science students to consider the interactions of crime, authority, procedure, and law.  Willens may hope that this is the final word on the subject, but it cannot be.  The Warren Commission report served just as a beginning point for discussion.  While tons of other JFK-related books and media continue to surface -- especially in this anniversary year -- this book is among the most important one.  Read it:  for background, if for nothing else.  Read others, if you wish.  And then read Stephen King's 11/22/63: A Novel to see how one fictional character tried his best to stop the whole ordeal from happening.

"If not for books and animals, I'd die from boredom." (p. 76)  Looking back, Helen Peppe dares to share with us her memories:  not only as the youngest of nine kids, but also as an animal lover living on a working farm where creatures are offed, eaten, or sold on a regular basis.  It doesn't take long for us to get sucked into her world of childhood misery.  We all have had some of these feelings, or at least we imagined that we did.  Helen's are magnified by a factor of nine (or really, more than eleven, if you count her parents and the ever-present household hanger-on).  No wonder she continually begs for time to move faster so that she can become an adult and can lead her life the way she really wants to.This is not your Tourist's Maine.  This is not the place of picturesque rocky beaches or thick green pine forests.  This is the hardscrabble interior, living past where the paved road ends, visiting the City-of-the-Library and the City-over-the-Bridge only for grocery shopping and occasional visits to the doctor.  And Helen portrays it authentically, as she does with her family members.  In her words, her siblings include: the blustery-and-favored brother, the holier-than-thou brother, the brother-I-barely-knew, the tough-yet-admirable sister, the hair-twirling-pretty sister, the sad-tittering sister, the sister-of-poor-choices, and the sister-who-holds-grudges-longer-than-God.  This is Helen's story, after all.  She doesn't have to name names.With the wisdom of hindsight, the author can be downright practical and humorous in considering the highlights of her past.  Perhaps she looks back now to puzzle out how she became the woman she is today.  Here the younger Helen compensates with her difficult or eccentric circumstances by losing herself in Stephen King novels, loving the animals she can, becoming a vegetarian, and dreaming of a different grown-up life.  We turn pages and keep up with her, also anticipating that day.When I first read the summary and decided to read and review this book, I warned myself that animal deaths would be probably be part of the narrative.  I was right.  I steeled myself, but I wasn't quite prepared to be hit with so many.  Helen Peppe is a compelling writer, however; and the fact that I didn't skip a word says a lot about her craft and talent.  Fellow animal lovers need not dismiss this book, but they may anticipate a possible need to pass over some passages.  (I considered giving it 4 stars instead, because of the horror.  But Helen's excellent writing overshadows the bad stuff.  It also helps to know that today she's a photographer of horses.)We read memoirs in order to find out what other folks were doing while we were simultaneously growing up elsewhere, involved with our own daily dramas.  This tale ends with another beginning, as Helen and her boyfriend Eric head toward high school graduation.  She leaves us wanting more, to keep hearing the news from Maine.  "Pigs Can't Swim" will appeal to and will entertain a wide variety of readers, as well it should.  As for the title itself -- Ah, but it turns out that they CAN.

It's August 1846, and there's trouble in the town of Plumford, Massachusetts.  A dead man has been found at the bottom of a cliff along the Assabet River.  Who is he, and how did he die?  The fact that the man is an African American adds an extra challenge to the direction that any further decision or investigation will take.  But Dr. Adam Walker and Henry David Thoreau will not be deterred in any event, and neither will the doctor's cousin, Julia Bell, who is an independent and headstrong woman with an interest in the case.  All three do their best to puzzle out the mystery.  Some other nasty business takes place, unfortunately, before the unapologetic perpetrator can be identified and dealt with.The narrative is told in first-person tag-team style, with chapters as journal entries written in the alternating points of view of Adam and Julia.  (Ironically, not from Henry's, even though he would become famous for his journal ruminations.)  It's a good example of historical fiction, with characters accurately operating under 19th-century attitudes toward minorities and toward women.  (Enough to goad at least one female reader into yelling advice to Julia at key moments in the plot.  Alas, the young woman wasn't able to hear it, in the dimension where she lives.)Plumford is a fictional town, located just west or southwest of Concord.  At the time of this story, Henry Thoreau is still living at nearby Walden Pond; and he hasn't yet published even his first book.  Though he expresses his investigative opinions to Adam, it's really the doctor who seems to do the majority of the detecting in this book.  Perhaps we get this impression because we're reading Adam's journal entries all along, and we get to follow his lines of thinking and his resulting actions.  And Adam and Julia may be cousins, but the two of them obviously have inclinations to become more than friends and goofing-around relatives.  Will circumstances ever allow them to be together?I've met the authors, Ben and Beth Oak, and they are a delightful couple.  I know that they work hard to maintain historical accuracy, especially when it comes to the medical practices that Adam Walker must employ.  They are also devoted Thoreauvians who portray the man as close as they can to historical record."Thoreau at Devil's Perch" is recommended as historical fiction, as a murder mystery, and as good entertainment.  Watch for more in the series![I was given a free pre-pub copy of this book in exchange for an honest review.]By Corinne H. Smith, author of Westward I Go Free: Tracing Thoreau's Last Journey

Right on the heels of Mrs. Lincoln's Dressmaker, Ms. Chiaverini offers us another insightful Civil War-era book in "The Spymistress."  This one too is based on fact and on a real-life and little-known person of the day.Elizabeth "Lizzie" Van Lew is her own kind of independent woman:  a spinster of middle age who manages her extended family property, complete with slaves, on Church Hill in Richmond, Virginia.  When her beloved home state secedes from the United States, Lizzie's allegiance remains with old Virginia and with the country headed by Abraham Lincoln -- and decidedly NOT with the new Confederacy.  She's far from the only Northern sympathizer around, for there are a few other "Unionists" hidden and scattered across the city.  Lizzie vows to do whatever she can to help the cause from her impromptu post in what becomes the Southern capital.  She begins by taking food and medical supplies to the Northern prisoners, now kept in former tobacco warehouses and in ever-worsening conditions.  Eventually her self-assigned duties lead her to become even more of a spy behind enemy lines.  She's eventually recognized for her good work by authorities in the Union army and is given additional tasks to accomplish.  All while maintaining the artificial faade of being a loyal Confederate.This book is not only the tale of one fascinating woman.  It's also the story of her hometown of Richmond, and its own transformation and tragic heritage during the war years.  Readers will have the advantage of knowing (at least, in general) what will happen to both as the war progresses.  The characters on the pages don't have this benefit.  And so we are led on, always wondering if / when the Confederates will finally figure out what Lizzie and her compatriots are up to.  We Northern readers silently applaud their diligence."The Spymistress" is recommended for readers interested in American history, the South, or in real-life escapades of decisive women.  For quick or casual readers, however, the book may seem to contain too much history, too many explanations.  Kudos to Jennifer Chiaverini for following these historical paths and for diverting us away from the quilts for a while -- although ALL of her books make for good reading.  Additional nods to the author for tackling the traditionally male-oriented topic of Civil War prisons, and in offering it up to a female audience.  The narrative calls to mind the vivid scenes in Mackinlay Kantor's Andersonville.  And anyone who has read that classic will gasp at the name and its baggage, whenever it is mentioned here.  Surely these situations could never have been that bad.  Could they?

I've read a fair number of financial advice books, and specifically every one that was written by CBNC's Saturday night maven, Suze Orman.  But in such a critical arena, we can always use a second opinion.  That's why I opted to read and review "Give Yourself a RAISE."  I have to say that I was pleasantly surprised by the helpfulness found here.  Gordon Bennett Bleil is no Suze Orman, and that's OK.  We don't need another Suze.  I think Bleil has done a terrific job at explaining issues and details and offering remedies for resolution of money quandaries.His best audience will be individuals who are in debt and have thus far been unable to manage it.  But in order to use this book most effectively, you have to WANT to make a change.  There are a variety of spreadsheets to fill out, in order to understand where your money comes from and where it goes.  A LOT of spreadsheets.  In the book and on the author's web site.  (Suze generally has only one.)  But they sure outline your situation in black and white, and are crucial for unveiling the truth.  And you don't have to use all of them for Bliel's approach to be enlightening.The strong points of Bleil's techniques are in analyzing one's financial situation and in managing debt, especially credit card debt.  Other good sections are the ones that focus on setting goals and analyzing the personal reasons for overspending.  We can all use a push to get moving.  Especially regarding our dealings with money.I see one notable difference between Gordon Bennett Bleil and Suze Orman.  Bleil treats a credit card as a funding source, and not as a pure expense.  It's an interesting and critical nuance.  It gives you a different perspective on how a credit card should be viewed and (if necessary) used.Please note that the First Edition of this book was published in 2010, and the Second Edition came out in 2013.  The First credited the author as Gordon Bennett, and the Second lists him as Gordon Bennett Bleil.  Reviews and product specifics of both editions appear to have been unfortunately combined into this one merged entry.  The ISBNs that I see on the screen don't match the ones on the title page verso in the paperback copy of the Second Edition in my hand.  The bottom line is that if you are truly interested in learning how to better manage your financial life, make sure that you are indeed getting the Second Edition of this book.I'll still watch "The Suze Orman Show" on a regular basis.  I will also recommend "Give Yourself a RAISE" to those people who are frustrated enough with the state of their personal finances that they want to commit to making a change.  Just like facing other challenges in life, the first step here is in admitting that you have a problem.  After that, the paperwork and explanations will help you on your way to attaining a more sustainable financial situation.[I received a complimentary copy of this book in exchange for an honest review.]

It takes only several dozen pages to catch up with 30-something PI Kinsey Milhone, whom we last hung out with nearly two years ago in V is for Vengeance.  Veteran storyteller Sue Grafton is aware of our possible forgetfulness and eases us back into Kinsey's Santa Teresa life by giving us subtle clues without making us feel like dolts:  checking in at her studio apartment and with her generous landlord Henry Pitts and his hypochondriac brother William; driving around so that we can pass Rosie's Tavern and visit Kinsey's office and get to the beach, which she jogs along every morning; even looking in her closet and seeing the all-purpose black dress.  Ah, yes.  We remember this place and these people.  In the meantime, a new set of mysteries has already surfaced.Two deaths have come into Kinsey's life.  One is the murder of Pete Wolinsky, a PI who had his own shabby little practice in Santa Teresa.  He was neither a friend nor a real competitor for Kinsey's business; but their paths crossed enough that she can feel some sorrow for his loss.  Given the kinds of people he associated with and the site of his murder, we shouldn't be surprised that he got caught up in something bad.  Author Grafton craftily uses back story and change of point-of-view in four separate chapters to help us learn the details of his demise.The other body belongs to a homeless man who died in his sleeping bag on the beach.  The only information left with his body was Kinsey's business name and phone number.  Who was he?  Why did he carry her number around with him?  And why doesn't Kinsey recognize him when she's called to the morgue?  Kinsey at least helps out the coroner in learning the identity of the man, which leads her to interview three of his homeless friends.  Without really meaning to do so, our favorite PI gets even more caught up in what was the life of this man named Terrence.  Almost before she can turn around, she's up to her shaggy brunette hairline in legalities.  And her name is at the top of the paperwork.  Will this scenario indeed turn out to be her highest-paid case to date -- and one that she wasn't even hired to investigate?And of course, all this action takes place during the autumn of 1988:  well before the days of computerized everything and ubiquitous handheld devices and the ability to look up answers via the Internet.  Kinsey and the authorities she deals with are relegated to searching for answers the old-fashioned way: by telephone, travel, personal interview, and looking through primary source documents and reference books.  It's actually a breath of fresh air to go back in time with her.  It wasn't so long ago, really, but it represents a step back from how such an investigation would be conducted today.Once again, stories that at first seem to be separate, eventually converge.  Once again we are able to fill in some of the blanks in Kinsey's personal history -- whether she's willing to learn them or not.  Once again, some surprises from the past pop up.  And once again, some brand new entities enter the picture.  (Can you say "cat"???) And we willingly tag along for the ride, page after page.  I won't reveal any more salient details.We avid mystery readers demand regular product and consistent quality from our favorite serialists.  Sue Grafton continues to deliver on both counts.  "W is for Wasted" is a worthwhile and gratifying read, whether it takes you a full day and night, or the savory course of a week to finish.  Fans will not be disappointed.

Wyoming resident Jenna Elliot happens to be driving home on a dark night when she stops to pick up a hitch-hiking Washington politician who's in trouble.  She helps him escape the bad guys without hesitation.  After all, he's Ken Marsden, the President of the United States.  But who is after him?  Which one of his advisers can he still trust?  And once he figures out what's going on and the proper individuals have been identified and subdued, will Ken remember the woman who helped him at his most critical time of need, out in the American West?What follows is a variety of chase scenes, both throughout the Wyoming landscape and within the District of Columbia.  Some are physical pursuits, while others are psychological and emotional.  Frustration builds for both Jenna and Ken, as they both seem individually unable to prove the facts of the situation.  What can you do when forces beyond your control thwart your efforts at every turn?  Can the real truth ever be unveiled?Norma Pyper Mitchell's first novel has the strengths of an intriguing plot with interesting characters.  Readers will also have to figure out who's leading the attack against the President and therefore by association, against Jenna.  The manuscript itself could have used one more round of proofreading, especially when it comes to dealing with instances of punctuation surrounding dialogue.  A few segues of character point of view could have been tightened as well.  Overall, however, this is a good first novel.I recommend "25 am" to most mystery readers, as well as to people who enjoy political thrillers, or even episodes of political nonfiction, like All the President's Men.  When read at a time when the White House appears on the TV news every night, the mere sight of the building makes the action in this book seem even more plausible.  It makes you wonder -- like the movies The American President and Dave and others do -- if fiction does indeed mirror fact.  How true could this story be?[I was given a free copy of this book in exchange for an honest review.]

In this fictitious account, Red Hawk remembers being at the site of the fighting at Little Bighorn, Montana, as a 15-year-old Lakota warrior in 1876.  Here he outlines what he saw and what happened that day.  His story is based on actual native recollections.This is a well-known but somewhat complex event to convey within the limitations of a children's book.  Paul Goble meets the challenge by depicting the bands of soldiers and Indians in a special way, in his ledger-book style.  Aptly, these illustrations look very much like the kind of Native American pictographs you might find on the smooth rock walls of a western canyon.  Paired with native narration, the presentation is complete.  The confrontation itself is confusing and messy without being bloody, with soldiers and Natives sometimes heaped in piles of humanity.  But through it all, we can always pick out General Custer in his fringed buckskins and lighter-colored hair (which is seen here as being short, because Goble explains that he had just had it cut.).  A good map of the river valley and battle positions is included.I've read a fair amount about Custer.  I also once happened upon a reenactment weekend at Fort Lincoln in Bismarck, North Dakota; and there I walked past General Custer in his buckskins, sitting astride his horse.  I could think of nothing to say to the man.  I've stood on that grassy Montana hillside among the markers of the downed soldiers.  What a brief two-dimensional approach cannot ever convey is the eerie feeling you still get in that place, and what it sounds like when the western wind blows hauntingly across the blades of grass.  That landscape doesn't show up at all in this book.  It just can't.This release is said to be a "revised and updated" edition of the 1969 book, Red Hawk's Account of Custer's Last Battle : The Battle of Little Bighorn.  Author-illustrator Paul Goble is pleased to explain that he finally got the picture book layout that he wanted for this story when it first came out more than 40 years ago.  Instead of the original 64 pages, this one has 44, with fewer all-text double-page spreads and less white space around the illustrations.  The pictures have been digitized and are more vibrant than the old ones were, especially in the hues of blue in the soldiers' uniforms.  Tribal historian Joe Medicine Crow added a new foreword.  Goble revised his author's note accordingly.  The volume looks more like a contemporary children's book.What's bothersome to me is that the updates are almost entirely devoted to layout.  In a quick scan of the text, I noticed only one minor change, and that was a difference in a tribal name.  Although Goble includes in his new author's note a paragraph about the American Indian Movement and what was happening to Native Americans in the 1960s and 1970s, that's where he ends the information update.  The bibliographies on the final page are exactly the same as those found as the 1969 book, with one exception:  a book about the Cheyenne that was re-released in 2008 by Wisdom Tales, the publisher of this book.  The rest are almost exclusively from the 1930s to 1960s, with the majority having been published in the 1950s.  How disappointing!  Over the past 40 years, a tremendous number of relevant books have been published about Custer, Sitting Bull, Crazy Horse, Little Bighorn, and Native American tribes and culture.  At the very least, Dee Brown's Bury My Heart at Wounded Knee: An Indian History of the American West should have been added to the list.  It came out shortly after the first edition of this book.  Directing children (and adults) to books that their school and public libraries no longer carry is a major oversight for a brand-new publication.I also recommend adding a glossary (defining the tribal distinctions of Lakota, Oglala, Hunkpapa, etc., and the tradition of counting coup, which Goble had in his former note but omitted from his new introduction) as well as a summary paragraph stating how many men on each side were killed, what the long-term consequences and historical significance of the battle were, and so on.  A "Rest of the story" explanation.Without more acknowledgement of new information and resources, "Custer's Last Battle" represents just a freshening-up and re-polishing.  To me, it offers more questions than answers.[I was given a free copy of this book in exchange for an honest review.]

Widow and former librarian Mary Fisher has opened a new bookstore at Ivy Bay on idyllic Cape Cod, where she used to spend summers when she was young.  During a book-signing event for a well-known mystery author, Mary spies a familiar face in the crowd.  It's Claire Wilkes, her former best friend.  The two women had parted ways -- badly  -- decades earlier, after Mary met and married John Fisher.  When Mary tries to reconnect with Claire this time, the woman evades her efforts.  Confronted later, she gets downright rude.In the meantime, Mary learns that the plot line of Addison Hartley's new book mirrors the Mary-Claire-John triangle from the past.  Did Claire somehow divulge the details to Addison?  Who else on the Cape knew or still knows about them?  And what about the mysterious checkbook of John's that Mary found hidden in an old school yearbook?  Could it be that Claire and John really DID have some sort of relationship behind Mary's back?"Rewriting History" is a satisfying read: a benign mystery without a murder that still carries puzzling elements.  Since it is part of a Guideposts series, you know that religion will enter the picture.  Its appearances are not overwhelming; and those readers who would rather not get involved with it won't have to skip many lines to keep up.Still, a few aspects of the story are terribly unrealistic.  First of all:  the publishers have the chutzpah to let a character open a new bookstore, in this day of e-readers and diminishing print sales, and when real independents are closing by the dozens.  Is this wishful thinking, or clinging to either the past or to a presumed ideal paradise?  The Cape is known for being a book-friendly place, but even shops there must be feeling the pinch. And this new store sells 200 copies of a bestseller at one author event.  Really?  A small store like Mary's wouldn't even carry 200 copies of one book.  They'd be lucky to have 30-50 in anticipation of the book-signing.  And later, when Mary finally breaks through Claire's defenses, the other woman casually agrees with the reconciliation.  It's too easy an acquiescence, I believe.  In fact, since this is Christian fiction, I'm surprised that Mary doesn't share her faith with Claire in order to resolve their differences.Anyway:  Suspend your disbelief, and enjoy a decent story.  If the rest of the series is as good as this installment, you'll have even more pleasures to follow.

OK, I'll admit that I've been remiss.  I still haven't gotten around to reading Jack Kerouac's On the Road: The Original Scroll. My neglect hasn't stopped me from enjoying other vicarious and even quirky road trips through the printed page.  In fact, I'm attracted to them.  So it shouldn't surprise anyone that I recently picked up this copy of The Potomac Circle while I was traveling through northern Michigan, the author's home region.  I found it in a Mackinaw City gift shop, read the back cover summary, and promptly carried the book to the checkout counter.  Then I made my way through it as I followed my own path home.  It proved to be as good a traveling companion as a chewy slab of Mackinac fudge.Here, 40-something George Mills is in search of some mid-life clarity.  He recently lost his job in Virginia, and then lost his marriage too when his wife Maggie divorced him soon afterward.  Cut free of such ties, he's not sure what his next step should be.  So he loads up his Jeep and takes to the road heading west, as all great adventurers do.  By the time we catch up to him, he's already gotten as far as Idaho.  We follow along as he meets a few intriguing people, including possible love interests.  Or not.  Then California calls, and off we go, passing through Nevada, of course.  Will George find solace or any answers at the edge of the Pacific shoreline?  We'll have to wait and see.Invariably, as George turns around and heads back east, his thoughts swirl around his problems in Virginia.  His only true and trustworthy confidant has been his 22-year-old daughter Jenny, whom he continues to reach by phone.  It seems only appropriate, then, that he invites her to fly out and ride back home in the Jeep with him.  With her by his side, George experiences even more realizations.  What road will he choose in the end?The climax comes, not just with George's return home, but with the high school class reunion that he attends right afterward.  It's been 30 years since he's seen some of his old friends.  Naturally, Maggie is there too.  Have George and Maggie now come full circle as well?"The Potomac Circle" offers a decent storyline, and also a chance for readers to think about their own pasts, choices and life-changing decisions.  Because it was either self-published or released through a tiny press, a few noticeable mistakes escaped the proofreader's eye. Nevertheless, it's too bad this effort hasn't attracted a wider audience.  I recommend it for any reader (esp. 40-ish or older) who longs to take to the highway and get that motor running.

Most authors want to be paid well for their efforts, and many also hope that their words will ultimately make a mark on the world.  Here veteran (but fading) fiction writer Conner Joyce has a chance to fulfill these dreams through a Faustian-like arrangement with a man of mystery, means, and presumed power.  And yet fairly quickly, Conner's life and work don't take quite the turns he expected they would.  In fact, his decision merely increases the complications.  Is there a logical and decent way out of this mess?His confidant in this dilemma is the narrator of the story, Adam Langer.  Adam is another author who is struggling with his own daily challenges.  He can barely find remedies for his own problems -- regarding career, residency, and family matters -- let alone help Conner figure out a way to resolve his more dangerous ones.  But he's intrigued enough to listen whenever and wherever Conner needs a sounding board.  From New York to Chicago, from Bloomington IN to Delaware Water Gap PA, we follow along as the two writers puzzle out their situations and do what they think is best.  It's all about choices and results.The framework of the overall plot is as layered as a set of Russian nesting dolls.  Revealing too much of it would spoil the delight of discovery for the reader.  Suffice it to say that it makes for compelling reading, especially for fellow writers who understand that the current state of the publishing industry could easily lead to this sort of happenstance.  Has it in fact done so already?The fuzzy lines of authority add another dimension to interpretation.  The narrator of the story shares his name with the real-life author of this book.  You have to wonder:  Where does fiction end and real life begin?  Ah, you see, that query merely adds to the fun.Highly recommended for readers who enjoy most genres (mainstream, literary, mystery, suspense, thriller), and especially for those who write or who aspire to write.  They will be the most receptive and nodding-along audience.  (Though they may envy how quickly Conner can churn out an original manuscript on a Smith-Corona manual typewriter...)
