As an aspiring and sometimes published author, I like to get inspiration and validation from reading books about writing.  Here's a terrific one.  And don't let the title put a false limitation onto you.  It's got great writing advice for EVERYONE, and not just those folks who believe they have time management challenges. (Then again: who DOESN'T have a problem with time management?)Aine Greaney's main focus is on making the most of our days and using every opportunity for writing, editing, revising, and being creative.  She finds minutes to fill at every edge.  She's high on journaling, finding a good writers group, and attending occasional workshops, conferences, and retreats.  She offers exercises to help with planning and implementation.  Additional sidebars offer concrete advice on technique: on employing various points of view; developing memorable characters; fleshing out settings; working with scenes, mastering authentic dialogue.  Granted, these familiar topics are covered in other writing books.  The difference here is that Greaney puts herself into the narrative.  She's practical and down to earth.  She talks with us as if we're in a face-to-face conversation.  She supplies examples from her own writing life.  She's not pontificating from an academic tower.  Hers is not a household name, and she is not taking advantage of any best-selling fame to issue declarations.  No.  She's One of Us.  And if she can succeed and meet her own writing goals, then we realize that we can follow her lead.If her voice isn't enough to get you going, then the 20 additional author interviews at the end may give you more motivation.  These people reveal their own habits and writing processes, as they work around and through their Real Lives.  Surely a few of their situations will resonate with you.I have already recommended "Writer with a Day Job" to several friends and acquaintances in person, and I'm already following Aine Greaney on FB.  If you're serious about getting the most from your writing life, you need to add this book to your home reference shelf, too.

Ever since Henry Thoreau spent two years living in a small house at the edge of Walden Pond in Concord MA, people have been finding remote places to hole up in and to experience Nature.  And then they write about it, too.  This book, first published in 1977 and then in paperback in 1982, falls into this category.  Except that the author doesn't take credit for it.  Readers will have to figure out who actually wrote it.  (The assignment shouldn't take long.)As a busy college professor, Edward Lueders spent time in his northern Wisconsin cabin only during summer breaks.  Imagine his surprise, then, when he ventured into the forest in June 1970, only to find that his retreat had been used by a nameless stranger and that a sheaf of papers waited for him on the living room table.  Someone had broken into the place and had lived here over the winter months, and that same someone had left all of his writings for Lueders, as partial payment for the opportunity.  Do I hear the suspension of disbelief ratcheting into place?The bulk of the book is the text of these left-behind papers, introduced and "edited" by Lueders.  While the Clam Lake area of the 1970s didn't resemble Walden Pond in the 1840s -- the house sat in the middle of Chequamegon National Forest but was equipped with running water and electricity and therefore had heat, radio, and TV -- the site did allow for the resident to ruminate, especially during the cold and snowy days of the Wisconsin winter.  His thoughts and observations appear here as brief entries, reminiscent of the style used by Walter Collins O'Kane in The Cabin and Beyond the Cabin Door.  Some report on the weather, animal tracks, and what's going on outside the warmth found within the cabin walls.  Most however are more cerebral, and many address the literary device of the metaphor:  what it is, what it isn't, what it should be, how and when it should be used, etc.A nice enough and interesting read for an afternoon or two.  The hook about the mysterious author is a way for Lueders to distance himself from the opinions, but I'm not sure the supposed disguise was necessary.  "The Clam Lake Papers" is recommended for avid cabin-book readers, as well as for residents of the Upper Midwest.  Oh, and if you're interested in the crafting, development, and employment of metaphors (and how they are the essence of human life), this one's got your name written all over it.

Cindy Ross was a young adult when she tackled the Appalachian Trail and hiked the 2000+-miles from Georgia to Maine.  It took her a few separate stints over two years, and two different hiking partners went with her.  Here she describes portions of her experience for us.  Her highs and lows are nearly as dramatic as the mountains she traverses:  with utter euphoria in successes, and sobbing sessions at setbacks.  Nevertheless, this is an endeavor that will change her life path forever.This book is not a step-by-step AT guide.  (Other volumes and maps serve that purpose.)  Ross's approach is more emotional.  Instead, it's about the spirit and personal accomplishment of the act, and not necessarily about the miles themselves.  The text also appears in a flourished italic font in order to resemble a handwritten journal.  Ross's own line drawings go along perfectly with her words.This was evidently Ms. Ross's first foray into the field.  More miles and more adventures lay ahead for her.  She has since published a variety of trail-related books, including her memoirs of hiking the Pacific Crest Trail, Journey on the Crest: Walking 2600 Miles from Mexico to Canada and the Continental Divide Trail in Scraping Heaven : A Family's Journey Along the Continental Divide.  She still lives as a writer and artist in the mountains of Pennsylvania.AT through-hiker stories abound, and I've read several.  My favorite is Leslie Mass's In Beauty May She Walk; Hiking the Appalachian Trail at 60.  It obviously offers a different perspective than "A Woman's Journey" does.  Readers looking to be inspired by empowered women could turn to that book, too.There's nothing wrong with vicariously thru-hiking by turning the pages of the memoirs of others who have really done it.  Keep 'em coming, and we'll keep absorbing them.

I bought a copy of this book because David Petersen quoted it profusely in Writing Naturally: A Down-To-Earth Guide to Nature Writing.  As a result of reading that text, I wanted to read this one.  What fun!  It sure doesn't take long, though.  Of its 99 pages, only 78 actually have words on them.  And many of those sheets are not crammed full from top to bottom margin.Guthrie warns us on the opening page:  "Here I put down, as concisely as I can manage, what I have learned through effort, trial and error, association, rejection, and acceptance."  He's definitely concise, I can attest to that part.  And sometimes his succinctness can be downright amusing.  He comes off as a curmudgeon about the profession, too.  I like his style.  The way he presents himself here makes me want to finally read The Big Sky and his other western novels.I read a lot of books about writing.  (Yes, I admit that it's sometimes easier to READ about writing than it is to sit down and WRITE.)  As Guthrie suggests, beginning writers need a copy of Strunk & White's The Elements of Style (4th Edition) (which this book resembles, in a way).  He also recommends John Gardner's The Art of Fiction: Notes on Craft for Young Writers, which I own but have yet to read.  Then Guthrie zips through it all:  viewpoint, characters, plots, dialogue, plausibility, figures of speech, and so on and so on.  Forty of the shortest chapters you'll ever read -- and yet, all of them worthwhile.  His practical advice is aimed at writers who are in the middle of the muddle and who either need reminders about such things, or a kick in the pants.  True beginners won't know enough to understand the whys and wherefores.  And they may not know who A. B. Guthrie, Jr. was.Guthrie's guide is not a necessary purchase.  But when so many used copies are offered at bargain prices, it becomes an easy addition to make to any personal library.  If you're someone who loves to read about writing and who gets inspiration by doing so, then this book is one to get, read, and keep on a nearby shelf for a random quick fix.  Guaranteed you will smile and nod at least a few times when you do.

Lately I've been reading a lot about nature writing:  what it is, and how to do it.  This title keeps popping up in bibliographies and reference lists.  I thought it might be dry or potentially unhelpful, since it appeared at first to be merely a slim transcript of four academic presentations.  But no!  I can attest that it's instead a fascinating behind-the-scenes look at the craft and the profession, courtesy of a handful of key contemporary writers of natural history.These four dialogues were held at the University of Utah in February 1988.  The talks were moderated but left unstructured.  Each evening featured a pairing of two writers:  Barry Lopez and Edward O. Wilson; Robert Finch and Terry Tempest Williams; Gary Paul Nabhan and Ann Zwinger; and Paul Brooks and Edward Lueders (who moderated all of the sessions).  The subjects of their talks overlap, but never cover completely identical ground.  General topics include:  the roles of natural history writing in our culture; the importance of storytelling; the different approaches taken by scientists and by creative writers; the commitment to a strong sense of place; and the technique of taking field notes and expanding upon them at home.  Each discussion contains a number of gems worthy of highlighting or underlining.The conversations are interesting, as is the participants' booklist at the end.  It could serve as a checklist for your own shelf inventory or for planning future reading choices.  Each participant has written and published more work since this paperback was released in 1989.  It's just a starter list, then.Of the eight, only Paul Brooks (1909-1998) is no longer with us.  Some of the others are "getting up there," you may say.  I've been fortunate enough to hear Robert Finch and E. O. Wilson speak in person.  But if you don't have those kinds of first-hand opportunities, this book will help to provide personal insights.While books like John Murray's Writing About Nature: A Creative Guide and David Peterson's Writing Naturally: A Down-To-Earth Guide to Nature Writing give you advice about craft, this book delves into the why and how of nature writing.  Mostly, the why.It's obviously dated.  So, it sure would be wonderful if someone got a grant and gathered new sets of nature writers to discuss the genre.  Maybe every couple of years, even.To readers who are merely curious about these people and their writings, I give this book four stars.  But to those who are fans or are practitioners who write about nature too, I recommend this book as required reading.  Get a pen ready to take notes.

An outside consultant flies to an Asian country in order to explain to an organization how to improve itself.  (Basically, it's either shape up or ship out.)  For possibly one of the few times in his career, he meets with some success.  And as success can breed success, we witness this weary milktoast of a man suddenly rising to the occasion.  He transforms himself into a Super Consultant:  a cocksure firebrand who doesn't need notes or previous thought in order to deliver his spot-on advice and recommendations to whoever needs to hear it.  Soon he's in demand and off again:  to Denver, to New York, and then to parts of remotest Africa.  And he's being courted by other companies to work for them.But just as quickly as roller coasters climb, they soon crest that top ridge and begin to fall.  And that's what happens to Our Hero as well.  Or does it???I admire some aspects of this book.  The compelling plot and its unique resolution deserve 4.5 stars for craftsmanship.  But occasional grammatical and/or spelling errors knock the finished product down a few pegs for me.  (I'm demanding in that way.)  And the fact that the storyline is very psychological grew to be mind-numbing for me as well.  Nearly all of the characters, including Our Hero, remain nameless in the text. Surely some literary critic could claim that this technique serves to focus on the internal processes rather than on external identities.  Or some such analysis.  For me, it grew a tad bothersome.  And although the story was quite plausible, the main character became likable for me only toward the very end of the book.  The VERY end of the book.Still, "The Traveller" is recommended reading for anyone who is a long-distance business traveler, for they will certainly find themselves on some of these pages.  It is especially appropriate for everyone who hates -- truly HATES -- their bosses.  And if you dare to read this book, you may have to turn right around and read it a second time; for after reaching the climax (!), you may want another go-round to take advantage of knowing NOW what you did not know THEN.For me, once was enough; but it did make for interesting reading.  Thank you, Mr. Addison.[I received a complementary paperback copy of this book in exchange for an honest review.]

I must begin this review by saying that I've admired John Hanson Mitchell's work for years.  This isn't the first of his books that I've read and reviewed.  I've seen John at readings and conferences, and we've had a few quick chats in person and in letters.Here he's brought us back to a territory called "Scratch Flat."  We first encountered this place in several of his previous books:  Ceremonial Time: Fifteen thousand Years on One Square Mile and Living at the end of Time; and as a tangential reference in two more, Trespassing: An Inquiry Into the Private Ownership of Land and Walking Towards Walden: A Pilgrimage in Search of Place.  This time the focus is obviously on the plant and animal life that Mitchell has witnessed -- and often, whose presence he has even initiated -- over the decades of his residency.  His main topic is his garden; but as usual, he doesn't mind at all about digressing into adjacencies.  He wanders at will.The exact location of these two acres is described only in general terms.  Perhaps Mitchell truly wants to keep the site a secret.  Perhaps he uses this technique to better connect with readers who may be looking for qualities of their own properties in these pages.  After all, too many of us have witnessed the carving out of highways or the dropping of suburban developments on fallow fields:  both too-new scars on previously open and presumed worthless landscape.  We long to create sanctuaries from the storm, for the benefit of those other wild ones who need consistent habitats.  Mitchell has done this.  So even though I know the name of his town, I'll go along with its anonymity here.  Let's just say, it could be anywhere."I have always favored gardens that are rough around the edges," Mitchell says. (p. 54) In and around his planned-out plots, he has let Nature take her course.  He's quick to admit that he's rescued or even stolen plants from other properties in the region, and has found worthy sites to relocate them.  He talks about how this place has evolved in his lifetime, and what he's planted and why.  We also follow him as he prepares the scene for an upcoming late-summer wedding.  Will the grounds be ceremony-worthy by then?But this isn't a gardening book, per se.  (You'll enjoy the reading more if you can at least distinguish a dandelion from a delphinium, however.)  This is instead a natural history book at its core.  And Mitchell explores the full range of other creatures who share this site with him:  mammals, amphibians, fungi, fairies, and insects, tons of insects.  "The children of the compound" often accompany him, as do a few domesticated animals.  Surprisingly enough, this long-time MassAudubon editor puts off a study of birds until one of the later chapters in the book.  Mitchell's insightful and thoughtful prose flows across the pages, especially when he bows toward environmentalism.  Suzan Osborn's vibrant impressionistic watercolors lend just the right amount of perspective and chapter-leading glimpses at a place that's still kept "rough around the edges."  Countryman Press also did a terrific job with the high quality of the physical book itself.John Hanson Mitchell is among my favorites, and I enjoyed this newest vicarious visit with him.  "An Eden of Sorts" is recommended for lovers of natural history; for those who have read Mitchell's previous books, even though those titles are not exactly prerequisites for this one.  Avid gardeners may find a kindred spirit here as well, especially if they like to continually "improve" their spots.  (Fans of Sara Stein's Noah's Garden: Restoring the Ecology of Our Own Backyards may especially like it.)  Non-gardeners will at least be inspired to go out and attempt to inventory the various species they can find in their own backyards.  You have to care about a place in order to want to save it.

I must begin this review by saying that I admire David Petersen's work.  His 2005 release, On the Wild Edge: In Search of a Natural Life, sits on a nearby shelf:  the one that's reserved for secondary and contemporary nature writers.  (The top shelf is crammed full of the best of Abbey, Burroughs, Dillard, LeBastille, Leopold, Muir, Olson, Teale, Thoreau, and others.)  So in my recent search for books about the CRAFT of nature writing, I was pleased to see that a familiar author had penned one.  Then I had to read it.Petersen has a unique informal style in addressing his readers.  His narratives read like in-person monologues and conversations, complete with opinions loudly voiced.  Readers can choose to ride along for the fun, learn a bit, laugh on occasion, and let some prickly remarks slide by.  Or they can become incensed at the author's presumed authority and rail against him.  The decision is free to make.  I take the former stance.The "basics" of this book are great, even as a refresher course.  Petersen covers a good deal of territory:  how to write essays, articles, journals, and books; attending to grammar, style, transitions, publishing, and the personal writing process.  His is an easy and thoughtful read, worthy of underlining or highlighting terrific salient points and relevant quotes.  And his concluding page is a sure-fire motivator.  Every nature writer should read it.  Every WRITER should read it.  It's guaranteed to get you putting pen to paper or placing finger on keyboard.  But don't jump ahead.  Read the rest of the pages first.I've got only two bones to pick with this book.  The first one comes with the chapter about writers' workshops and conferences.  Petersen freely admits that he never attended any as a student, and that he taught at only one, in 1998.  (This book grew from his instruction there.)  So it's difficult to take without question what he says about workshops.  I suspect that many folks who are apt to pick up this book will have already gone to at least one writing seminar or session before reaching this chapter.  They can surely use their own judgment and experiences as their guides in this case.The other caution comes as a caveat emptor.  This book was released in 2001.  Petersen worked on it in the late 1990s and early 2000s.  Considering the length of the publishing process, this text is now well on its way to being a decade and a half old.  So while the basics still apply to the art of writing in general, there are indeed certain spots where Petersen's advice now fails.  The chapter on research desperately needs an update about the current state of library and online resources.  And the Internet and the preference toward digitalization have both since changed the ability to publish as well:  with the explosion of online outlets (blogs, etc.), e-books, and even the method of checking web sites for submission details.  We may not need to rely on the newest print edition of "The Writer's Market" anymore.  We certainly don't need a whole chapter about that.  There are other ways to submit and to get our pieces out there.Today may be a good day to assemble a second edition of this one, David.  You'd have few competitors.

What a great story!  It's about a quirky and challenging self-imposed project that involves travel and adventure.  And it happens to be true, which makes it even more delightful.His first homemade boat sank when he was six years old.  That's when John Pollack vowed to himself that he would build a boat that had no chance of sinking -- one made entirely of corks from wine bottles.  So he and his family members began to save them, one at a time.Fast forward a few decades, and John is at loose ends in Washington, D.C.  He just finished up a great speechwriting stint for President Clinton.  But when the Bush administration steps in, John's ready to get out of the political scene.  Why not revisit his lifelong goal of building a cork boat?  And the action really picks up from this point on.  Soon John is dealing with a perfectionist partner and a multitude of corks, rubber bands, assembly line volunteers, and tow truck drivers.  Two-thirds of the book deals with the process.  The final third of the book details the Cork Boat's unbelievable inaugural voyage down Portugal's Douro River.The narrative is well paced, and John is obviously a good writer.  This is the kind of book where the intrigue of the idea alone can compel you to start reading; but the action and language serve to sustain your interest.  Gradually you have no choice but to sit back and cheer on the guy and his team.  The hardback edition is even a joy to hold, with its palm-sized pages, depictive dust jacket, and handy-dandy maps on the flyleaves at both ends of the block.  Even your hands won't want you to put it down."Cork Boat" is highly recommended reading for anyone who enjoys a good tale, especially one with a travel element.  No nautical experience is required.

Here's an interesting assignment:  Frame a story around the songs found on a classic record album.  That's what Chad Gayle has done with "Let It Be: A Novel."The action does not take place at the time of the release of the final Beatles album and famous group break-up, however (1970).  Instead, it's nine full years later:  musically, unfortunately, in the midst of the disco era.  The setting is Amarillo, Texas, where members of one small family are doing their best to survive.  Michelle and Bill Jansen are divorcing.  Their children Pam and Joseph have moved with Michelle into a new-to-them city.  Each individual has his/her own struggles to deal with and to resolve.  For 10-year-old Joseph, it's finding his niche in the hierarchy established by the other local kids.  For teenager Pam, it's discovering what she can get away with.  For Bill, it's a douse of denial and settling scores.  For Michelle, it's getting used to a new job and the possibility of dating and falling in love again.  Let It Be is the album she puts on the turntable whenever she wants to feel good about herself and her stressful situation.  The melodies take her back to a better and less complicated time.So yes, it's a simple story, and one that could be considered to be a universal one.  What makes this telling unique is its connection with the music.  I borrowed a copy of the "Let It Be" CD after I finished reading the book.  (Something I recommend that all future readers do.)  While I applaud Chad Gayle for the idea and the approach, I believe he didn't go far enough.  Of the 12 songs on the album, only 8 are used as chapter titles in the book.  I was disappointed that four songs were left out.  I think if you intend to use this premise as your framework, you should go for the whole enchilada.  And I think the omitted ones could have been worked fairly into the plot line.For a first novel, this work is innovative.  The more I think about it, the more I like the idea of the book, even though I don't especially like most of the characters.  Without the album connection, this novel would have been merely a coming-of-age story for young Joseph.  If all 12 songs had been used, it could have been a masterpiece.  Gayle's approach does give us an added dimension and the interaction of both the visual act of reading and the aural act of listening. Overall though, I think this is a slightly above average book that could have been a bit better.Recommended for readers of either gender who may be intrigued by the story-song framework.  Beatles fans may be especially curious.  Just be sure you have your old CD or vinyl album handy.[This review is based on reading a promotional copy donated in exchange for a fair review.]

I was overjoyed to come across this book on a mystery swap table a few weeks ago.  Bill Tapply remains one of my favorite writers.  I read all three of his Stoney Calhoun books, as well as the three mysteries he wrote in tag-team style with fellow New Englander Philip Craig.  (I've read some of his nonfiction outdoors books, too, and even had a chance to chat with him in person to thank him.)  I thought it might be time to go back and finally read the whole Brady Coyne series.  This is the 10th episode in the full run of 24, and I have to admit that for Bill Tapply, it's merely average writing.  Then again, he produced it during only the first decade of his long writing career.  I don't believe he had hit his stride yet with this one.Attorney Brady Coyne is invited to a client's home on Cape Cod for the weekend.  Who could resist such an offer, especially when the fish are biting?  But in the middle of the night, Brady is assaulted and the client is robbed, beaten, and left for dead.  No one has asked the Boston lawyer to play detective, but this situation has quickly gotten personal.  Can he figure out who orchestrated the theft?  Can he locate the seven gold Mayan jaguars with the emerald eyes?  Can life ever be normal again for his client?  And -- as usual -- can Brady get the girl in the end?A lot of puzzling goes into unraveling the truth here, and a fair amount of additional violence has to take place before Brady understands what happened and who was responsible.  Some answers come from a different place, and others were just hiding in plain sight.  Brady is one of the good guys, though, so we are fairly assured that he'll be successful in his quest.Readers should be cautioned about a printing error in an early edition of "The Spotted Cats."  The hardback copy that I read is missing about two pages of text at the beginning of Chapter Four.  It's not that any pages were torn out, or that the pages were left blank.  Someone wasn't paying attention during the initial publishing process.  A sentence is left dangling, and the next paragraph doesn't continue the action where it left off.  It jumps ahead.  Luckily, I found another copy from another printing at our local library, and I was able to see and read the missing portion of the initial police officer interrogation scene.  You can figure out what happens without it, but of course it's nice to have access to the full story."The Spotted Cats" is recommended for Tappy, Craig, and Brady Coyne fans.  Newbies to the series can start with this one if they wish.  Just be aware that while this one is good, there are other Tapply mysteries waiting out there that are even more compelling.

Business executive and widow Linda Crill tried for a year and a half to "get on with her life" after her husband Bill died.  Nothing really worked.  She was as miserable as ever.  Then a flippant remark about learning to ride a motorcycle developed into a commitment to join three other riders on a 10-day bike tour of the Pacific coast.  Linda had to quickly learn how to manage the machine, take a class, pass the driver's test, practice riding a borrowed cycle, buy leathers, and make arrangements for the flight from Virginia to Vancouver, the starting point.  Her trip from the board room to VROOM! was not without its glitches, but she succeeded.  We join her journey here.We follow Linda through all of those tasks she must master before she hits the road with Ron, Alberto, and Eva.  Then we go along for the ride as the quartet rides hundreds of miles a day, passing through the spectacular scenery of Washington, Oregon, and California.  Driving a motorcycle is different from driving a car or a bicycle.  At first there's so much to remember that Linda spends more effort paying attention to the bike and to the road than in appreciating the places she's traveling through.  Sure, on this trip she learns much about motorcycles and the culture surrounding them.  But she also gains quite a lot of knowledge about herself.  Here she's asked to be a follower or a team member, dropping out of her typical business role as leader or analyzer.  She can't help but continually scrutinize situations, however.  Now she has the time to be introspective, with opportunities to analyze herself and her own behavior, under circumstances that she never expected to be in.  These realizations are worthwhile for both Linda and for us (though they sometimes last longer than we may need).  It turns out that the term "blind curves" makes for a nifty metaphor."Blind Curves" is recommended for female readers of all ages, and could be especially helpful for those who are facing challenges of their own.  Linda's lesson is that we sometimes need to be jolted out of our comfort zones in order to understand ourselves better and to regain control of our lives.  She leads by example.  And it's a guarantee that we'll all look differently at motorcycle riders from this time on.[A review copy of this book was sent to me by The Cadence Group, in exchange for an honest review.]

I've driven around Minnesota fairly frequently over the course of the past decade, especially for someone who is based on the East Coast.  So I was pleased to have the opportunity to get an advance copy of this new road atlas from National Geographic.  I had a 2006 edition of DeLorme's Minnesota Atlas and Gazetteer sitting on the passenger seat of my car during my previous trips to the Gopher State.  I thought that it might be time to get an updated reference.Some introductory matter begins the book.  A four-page spread of "Places of Interest" outlines 36 worthwhile sites to visit throughout the state, with one-paragraph descriptions for each one, and photographs of 20 of them.  I've been to only six of the sites, and the write-ups for these six are fairly accurate.  But the entries are not in any regional or even alphabetical order.  They include the names of the towns where the sites are located; but since the names are embedded within the text, they're not found quickly or easily.  The biggest oversight is that there are no page numbers and map coordinates to go along with the descriptions.  If a place is indeed of interest to the user, she'll have to read the paragraph, find the name of the town, turn to the back of the book for the index, find the town name with its page number and map coordinates, and then turn to the proper page and look for the town and site.  <sigh>  I'm very surprised that the National Geographic editors didn't think of the users in this respect.  AAA guides do it.  So do the DeLorme books.  And the charts that follow the "Places of Interest" here -- for campgrounds, state parks, trails, golf, and recreational lakes -- DO include page numbers and map references.  Although smartphone QR codes are also printed on the "Places of Interest" pages, they lead people to the state tourism web site, Explore Minnesota.  This direction probably won't help them find any of the individual sites any easier, either.Then again, most users may not read or even look at the first few pages.  After all, this is an atlas, and people will buy it for the detailed maps that National Geographic is known for.  Here the book is very much like the DeLorme books.  Can maps really differ all that much?  Well, sure they can, especially with varying type styles and colors.  And don't forget scale.  NG offers a closer look with the 1:175,000 perspective than DeLorme does at 1:190,000.  This book thus has more maps and pages.I decided to evaluate these new maps by looking for the sites that I've visited.  Most were fine and appeared just as I expected.  But although NG outlines the territory of the Lower Sioux Indian Community along the Minnesota River, it does not pinpoint the site of the nearby Lower Sioux Agency History Center, which is affiliated with the Minnesota Historical Society.  (Though it does mark the casino down the road from it.)  Other MHS sites are noted with squares and names.  Why not this one?  My Delorme book marks it.And a glance at the city of Red Wing, along the Mississippi River, shows the location of "Barns Bluff Park."  Really?  "Barns"?  Barn Bluff is a singular geologic formation that NG map makers should be familiar with.  It's in every print gazetteer, and it's easily found online.  And it's Barn, without an s.  Always has been, always will be.  Hmmm.  If some of my favorite places are missing or mislabeled here, what else could be wrong?While it's nice to now have a newer Minnesota road atlas to take with me on my next trip west, I have to admit that I'm not throwing away my older DeLorme edition.  I'll take both along from now on.  Your results may vary.~~ Corinne H. Smith, author of Westward I Go Free: Tracing Thoreau's Last Journey, which details Henry David Thoreau's 1861 trip to Minnesota

When we go hiking at an outdoor recreation area, we rarely notice the condition of the trail itself.  That is, unless a recent storm has blown down a sizable tree, right onto the path.  (And even then, we'd only have to problem-solve if we had to climb over it or walk around it.)  This is as it should be.  This means that the park's maintenance crew did a good job.  Who are these "traildogs," and what do they really do?  Christine Byl draws back the curtain on the world of these underappreciated workers, as she and her colleagues tramp through some of our most beautiful and wild western places.She frames her memoir with six tools of her trade:  axe, rock bar, chainsaw, boat, skid steer, and shovel.  Don't worry if a few of them are unfamiliar.  She'll explain.  Along the way we hear her own story, beginning as a seasonal laborer at Glacier National Park in Montana.  These are days of learning how to fell trees, build bridges, and even pay attention to angles of walkway ascent and descent.  Naturally, there are interactions with wildlife of both varieties:  animals and tourists.  We tag along with Christine and her husband Gabe as they move to Alaska, where they first work for the Forest Service in Cordova before landing jobs at Denali National Park and Preserve.  Are you kidding me?  Living and working within sight of the tallest mountain in North America?  Is this the pinnacle of park service maintenance work as well?  Read more to find out.Some may wonder, Why read (or write) a book about people digging post holes and tearing down trees?  Well, Christine's account is not just about the down-and-dirty daily tasks (many of which require heavy lifting), but also about the people who choose to do them.  You'll meet some real characters here.  An outsider might have glamorized this work, might have romanticized it, given the stereotypical idea readers may have about working close to protected nature.  Admittedly, the book's subject matter alone may deserve only a four-star rating.  It's Christine's terrific and engaging writing style that brings the narrative up a notch.  She's a pro who can craft elegant turns of phrase even while describing the grimiest of situations.Sure, there are underlying themes here that readers can dwell on, if they wish.  Gender roles, and the whole woman-in-a-man's-job routine.  National parks vs. other wild areas. Montana & the Lower Forty-Eight vs. Alaska.  Even, Man vs. Nature.  Christine offers her succinct opinions in these areas and then moves on.  This isn't an outwardly feminist, environmentalist, or political book.  And that's good.  She's given us just enough insight into a complex workplace and has brought into view the invisible lives of the traildogs.  It's obvious that for Christine and Gabe, this once seasonal and temporary employment has become not only a passion, but also a year-round livelihood.  I can't wait to find out what comes next for these two."Dirt Work" is recommended reading for anyone who loves the outdoors.  It certainly will provide food for thought, the next time you're out hiking.  You may even find then that you've brought Christine and her traildogs with you.  The book would also be a great selection for book discussion groups, especially those with a nature focus, for it should appeal to a wide audience of readers.  I took my time with this one in order to savor every page.  I didn't want my time with the traildogs to end.

Twenty-something Nathan Lochmueller is a professional bird watcher in rural Indiana.  His job may sound idyllic, but it can be a tough one, especially since he's working in an area where most wildlife stalkers carry guns instead of binoculars.  Nathan is also young enough to be still living the carefree, college boy kind of life.  Girls, booze, whatever.  Without fully realizing it, Nathan is searching for his role and his place in the grand scheme of Life.  So are his friends.  And although Nathan is an Indiana native, it sometimes seems as though he's living as a stranger in a strange land.Since the main character tells his own story here, the plot lines wrinkle forward and back in his memories and conversations.  His recount resembles other coming-of-age stories.  Some incidents are mildly amusing, others are downright dangerous.  In a way, the book somehow reminded me of Richard Brautigan's Trout Fishing in America from 1967.  When I grabbed my old copy and paged through it, though, I decided that No, it wasn't much like that book after all.  Not off the wall enough.  I ended up mostly feeling sorry for Nathan.  Is the place changing, or is he?  It's depressing to think that the people in such rural spots are the way they're depicted in these pages.  Yet the portrayal is all too realistic."Snapper" is a decent enough tale to visit for a while.  What it might mean in the long run is up for grabs.  Did I like it, or Nathan?  Not a lot.  I don't agree with the publisher's back cover blurb that it reflects "a great, hilarious new voice in fiction."  Maybe it's a guy thing.  Or a younger generation thing.  Author Brian Kimberling does offer a fresh view that we could expand upon to consider the choices we make, especially in the places where we decide to live.  That's the sense that I gained from it.

This picture book is a wonderful international embodiment of "the ripple effect:" What you do affects me; what I do affects you.  It offers a universal lesson to not take casual encounters for granted."Because Amelia smiled, coming down the street, Mrs. Higgins smiled, too."  The story begins simply enough.  Then the next action causes another one to happen.  And so on, and so on, passing from one individual to the next, and influencing average people at various locations around the world.  Adult readers will probably predict where the storyline will lead; but to the young, the ending may come as a complete surprise and revelation.  To think how far each one of us can reach!  And to indeed be part of a global, connected community!There's a lot to see in the illustrations, and children should enjoy pointing out the items and activities they recognize.  As mentioned, the text holds a valuable message for readers of all ages.  Author/illustrator David Ezra Stein even foreshadows it in his opening dedication:  "To you:  Pass it on!"  I cannot think of anyone who would not benefit from sitting down for a few minutes with this book.  Its premise and ramifications will stay with you for a good long while, too.

During a fifteen-year time span, I lived in or near Altoona, Pennsylvania.  I always heard that the Germans had intended to destroy Horseshoe Curve during World War II, but no one I ever talked to could provide any details of the story.  That's why I was intrigued by the title of this book.  But as a previous reviewer has already noted, the book addresses the POTENTIAL sabotage of the Curve and the THEORETICAL subversion in Altoona; and it provides more back story and diversions than one might imagine possible in one volume.  Still, if you're intrigued by the subject matter, you may find this to be a worthwhile read.The narrative is divided into three parts.  The first one describes the German sabotage mission that landed four men on the coast of Long Island and four others on the coast of northern Florida in June 1942.  The Germans were assigned eleven targets to dismantle in order to cripple the United States:  key factories, transportation centers, and public works facilities that were located in the Northeast, Midwest, or Mid-South.  Included on the list was the Horseshoe Curve, which led the main railroad line west of Altoona and through the Allegheny Mountains toward Pittsburgh.  But the eight saboteurs never had a chance to implement their plans.  Almost immediately, they were caught and their mission was thwarted, thanks to one turncoat in the group.  Within two months of their shoreline arrivals, six of the eight men were executed, and the other two (one of them, the informant) were imprisoned.  McIlnay supplies many details of their trials and even the minute-by-minute blows of their executions.  If you ever wanted to know anything about this tale, you will probably find it here.The second part of the book deals with "subversion."  At the same time that the Germans were planning their mischief, J. Edgar Hoover was assembling a massive list of "alien enemies" who lived in the United States and who represented potential danger to the country's safety.  We forget, if we ever knew, that some German-Americans and Italian-Americans were sent to internment camps in the 1940s, just like the Japanese-Americans were.  On July 1, 1942, 225 potential alien enemies were arrested in Altoona ... and then just as quickly, they were released.  Author McIlnay does his best to track down the real meat of this story, but he ends up merely teasing us.  He finds some people whose relatives had been involved in the arrest, but he chooses not to identify them or even to tell generically of their experiences.  Instead, he devotes his pages to J. Edgar Hoover and the larger reach of his initiative.  The local element is noticeably absent here, except in the reproductions of the newspaper headlines of the day.The third part of the book is a history of the Pennsylvania Railroad itself, and how the Horseshoe Curve came to be designed and built.  Actually, McIlnay first steps back to the days of Pennsylvania's canal system of the 1820s, which eventually lead to the beginning of the railroads in the Keystone State.  (But not before he gives us a history of railroading in general, especially in England.)  Clearly the hero is John Edgar Thomson, who was president of the Pennsylvania Railroad for 22 years.  He was also the chief engineer who defined the route and supervised construction of the Horseshoe Curve.  Rail fans may particularly want to absorb the details supplied in this section, which go well beyond just the creation of the Curve.  But since this history laid the foundation for the possible German sabotage, as well as the arrest of subversives in the state's largest railroad city, we are caused to travel backward as we turn the pages of this book.  Another author might have reversed the order of the tales.Author McIlnay is admittedly at his best at the end of the journey, when he himself makes a pilgrimage to Horseshoe Curve to see what he can see.  The mystique of this feat of engineering comes when you stand in the middle of it, and when trains are clattering all around you, on their way up or down the mountain.  (Don't follow the author's rambling directions on how to reach the Curve, however.  I-99 is a north-south route that he insists on describing in east-west terms.  If you're interested in railroads and the Curve, you should first visit the Railroaders Memorial Museum in downtown Altoona.  It's a great place to start your tour, and maps to the Curve are available there.  You'll also get a discount on admission.)I understand all too well the desire to share everything one knows about a topic.  I hesitate to chastise another author for something I tend to do myself.  McIlnay goes above and beyond in the habit, however.  This book is at times a tangential and therefore tedious read.  I am glad I made it through it, because I wanted to know these stories.  Other readers may not be as forgiving, and may abandon the venture after the opening section.

On April 16, 2004, Professor Abner Fraume is strangled to death by Professor Emil Kravitz in Bath, England.  Why?  Because Fraume owns a set of rare 15th-century typesetting artifacts that Kravitz desperately wants.  Unfortunately for the murderer, the items are no longer in Fraume's house.  The researcher had anticipated his rival's intentions and had mailed the package elsewhere.  Then he also sent three separate letters to his sister Edythe containing cryptic clues revealing the package's location.  At the scene of the crime, Kravitz sees one of the letters and reads its clue.  He thus knows where his search must lead next:  to Edythe Bender's Olde Victorian Bookstore in Annapolis, Maryland.But alas!  Before Edythe can fully deal with her brother's death and with the artifact clues, she herself succumbs to cancer.  Enter Dan and Rivka Sherman, acquaintances of Edythe.  The bookstore owner knew her time was limited, and she convinced the Shermans to buy the business before she died.  The couple is brand new to this type of enterprise.  Added to the sudden stress of managing a store is the Shermans' necessary entanglement in the artifact search.  They quickly learn the basic details of the murder in England and its American ties.  The mystery writing critique group that they host at the store has attracted a number of new members.  Four of them are male.  One is probably Emil Kravitz, traveling under an assumed name.  But which one is he?  Can Dan and Rivka uncover his identity, solve the clues, and/or find the artifacts before he does?  How much should the two get involved in an investigation that really shouldn't concern them?Readers are served a rather complex plot here.  They are given the chance to know some of the back story and to witness certain developments as they happen, but not all.  This enticement keeps the pages turning.  We can only hope that Rivka and the artifacts will be saved, and that Kravitz will receive the punishment that he deserves.Still, some niggling discrepancies in the narrative prevent this novel from being a flawless offering.  The bookstore seems to operate more like a library, with the clerk filing the volumes by Dewey numbers instead of by genre and surname.  No one notices if anyone is speaking strangely, or with a possible disguised accent, when at least one of the men must be a British investigator who is tailing the Chicago-born Kravitz.  As a reader, I found myself questioning circumstances more often than I usually do.Overall, "Death Goes Postal" is a decent read with somewhat compelling main characters that may appeal to an audience of both genders.  I won't keep track as new installments are added to the series, however.  I may have had a different response to this book if I hadn't just read Wendy Welch's The Little Bookstore of Big Stone Gap: A Memoir of Friendship, Community, and the Uncommon Pleasure of a Good Book right before it.  Her memoir depicts the everyday dealings of the used bookstore that she and her husband started in the mountains of Virginia.  If you want to know what it's REALLY like in the independent book business, that's the volume you should pick up.  Cozy mystery series based on bookstores include Carolyn Hart's Death on Demand series, Lorna Barrett's Booktown Mysteries, and Allison Kingsley's Raven's Nest Bookstore Mysteries.  Dan and Rivka's first adventure, though unique and challenging, is relatively average by comparison.

I must admit up front that in 1972, I was 15 years old and liked the Kansas City Chiefs. I hated the Miami Dolphins. I have since grown to appreciate several AFC teams: but alas, never the Dolphins. I like reading good football stories, though, and that's why I chose to read "Perfection," which was released in time to celebrate the 40th anniversary of the Dolphins' 17-0 perfect season. After reading this "warts and all" chronicle of the team, even Dolfans may have to admit that while Perfection lay in the final record, it was not always found in the team's front office, locker room, or off-the-field behaviors.The 17 chapters follow the framework set by the 17 games. The authors provide the facts of each contest, along with profiles of players and other personnel as they take the stage. It's as if a ribbon is being woven, with the trajectories of single strands coming together to form that singular roster and its common goal: to win the Super Bowl, after having lost it the previous year.We especially learn more about Coach Don Shula and about Bob Griese himself and the intricacies of being a quarterback. When Griese gets injured in Game 5 against San Diego, veteran QB Earl Morrall steps in and leads the team well over the following weeks. Griese appears for a few series in Game 14, the last regular season game; then comes back for good in the second half of Game 16, the AFC Championship Game against the Steelers. The Black and Gold was fresh off its "immaculate" win against the hated Raiders. But Miami prevailed. "It wasn't their time yet," says Griese. "It was ours."Yes, this is a feel-good, hooray-for-the-underdog, sports story. It's difficult not to smile at the end. The narrative additionally reveals the machinations of the league back then, in its early days. The varying techniques about dealing with trades, the draft, and other practices, are ones that may not be tolerated today. Griese and Hyde are also quite frank about the costs of the game to the health of the team members. They outline those instances where guys played with severe injuries, and used drugs to be able to do so. Forty years later, these choices have manifested themselves in the aging bodies of the former players. The text reinforces the lengths that an athlete will go to be able to play the game and to make the money: which back then, wasn't really much money at all. The fact that this imbedded message comes from Bob Griese, one of the well-known good guys, makes it all the more impactful. And you really have to wonder just how often Bob has watched all of those 40-year-old films."Perfection" is not the first recollection of this season. It''s not even the first book by journalist Dave Hyde on the subject. Ten years ago, he did a 30th anniversary book with Don Shula, Still Perfect! The Untold Story of the 1972 Miami Dolphins. Recently Mike Freeman has also chimed in with Undefeated: Inside the 1972 Miami Dolphins' Perfect Season. I have not yet read either book, and so cannot offer advice about them.Football fans are really outsiders looking in, hoping to find heroes. They might find a few here. And this is not a tale just for Miami fans. You'll like this book if you enjoy learning about planning offensive and defensive game strategies. You'll like it if you yearn to recognize names from the past, like Jim Kiick, Larry Csonka, Paul Warfield, and Larry Little (just to mention a few). "Perfection" is recommended reading for any student or fan of the game. What I'd LOVE to read (and may even be interested enough to write someday) would be a companion and comparison account of the near-perfect 2007 New England Patriots to the 1972 Miami Dolphins. I wonder if Bill Belichick would ever allow that to happen?

I had read and enjoyed Adriana Trigiani's Big Stone Gap novels (Big Stone Gap, Big Cherry Holler, Milk Glass Moon, and Home to Big Stone Gap) when they were first released a while ago.  So I wasn't entirely unfamiliar with this little mountainous corner of southwestern Virginia before I picked up this book.  It's almost ironic that Wendy Welch and her husband Jack Beck choose this very town as the site that could fulfill their long-time dream:  to own a used bookstore.  Had either one of them ever run a small retail business?  No.  Did they know anyone in Big Stone Gap beforehand?  No.  Did they have sizable capital to invest in a new venture?  No.  Were the local and national economies robust enough to encourage such an endeavor, right out of the chute?  Not really.  But these challenges didn't stop Wendy and Jack from launching themselves into the fray.  They were lovers of books, after all.  And they wanted to share that passion and ignite it in others.Wendy relates the sketchy beginnings of Tales of the Lonesome Pine Used Books, as well as the fish-out-of-water encounters with local residents.  In this respect, the narrative resembles the stories of most small but gradually vibrant businesses.  Readers can approach this tale in several ways.  They can appreciate it as a good-things-eventually-happen-to-good-people story.  They can smile and laugh at the questions and antics of the quirky customers the store owners get to meet.  They can savor it as a darned good story that happens to be based on books and literature.  Or they can understand it as either a cautionary tale or one of ultimate inspiration.  The first page reads:  "If you have ever walked away from doing something 'important' to do something better, this book is dedicated to you.  It's also dedicated to everyone who loves books."  A wide audience.Each chapter starts with an appropriate quote; and none of them are the tired and overly used ones that we run across often enough.  (Some, I had to write out and save for my own collection.)  They mirror the chapter themes.  Late in the book, Wendy reveals her top reading recommendations, along with a follow-up list of "Classics that shouldn't be."  Whether you agree or disagree with her assignments, this section provides much food for thought.  If someone asked *you* for advice on a few good books that everyone should read, what would you come up with?"The Little Bookstore of Big Stone Gap" is a must for book lovers, wherever they may be.  Adriana Trigiani fans should enjoy it, too, if they are willing to dabble with nonfiction.  And if this story resounds with folks who decide to make the trip over the Blue Ridge Mountains to see the shop in person, so much the better.  Let's keep the independents alive!

Quirky Minnesotan Mira James finds herself with several weeks of seasonal unemployment, so she bites the bullet and decides to go back home to celebrate the holidays with her mother.  But all too soon a disturbing trend emerges.  A serial killer who strikes only in December has made his/her way north into Minnesota.  In the past two years, young brunette women have been offed in Chicago and in Wisconsin.  The Candy Cane Killer leaves signature treats, but has yet to be caught.  Naturally, Mira -- a brunette herself -- gets in the way of the investigation.  Or does she help to SOLVE the mystery?  With this gal, it can sometimes be difficult to tell.At the same time, Mira is finally taking steps to become a licensed private investigator.  (Why shouldn't she?  She's been stumbling across dead bodies on a regular basis, ever since she moved to Battle Lake eight months ago.)  Her trusty and eccentric sidekick, Mrs. Berns, even shows up in Paynesville to lend a hand, both to protect Mira's mother and to track down the perpetrator.  What the two don't quite realize is the seriousness of this particular endeavor.  They're dealing with someone who is struggling with such intense personal demons, that he/she is taking advice from a brown-haired doll.  We readers are privy to information hidden from the view of our dynamic duo, so we can understand some of the disturbing thought behind the acts.  But that doesn't mean that this is an easy mystery for US to solve, either.  Even when we know that Mira is about to meet the killer in a final face-to-face showdown, we still can't be sure who that person will turn out to be.As usual, author Jess Lourey has given us a terrific read.  The Murder-By-Month Mysteries feature a very likable main character in Mira James.  The antics and banter between Mira and Mrs. Berns rivals that of Lucy and Ethel, or of any other good comedy team.  In fact, at their essence, these stories are comedies with some killing tossed in (unfortunately, for the victims) for good measure.Yes, "December Dread" is about solving a mystery and catching a killer.  But it's also about being with friends and family, coming to terms with your past, and having the courage to go home again.  Readers who are drawn into the series for the first time here, through this seasonal offering, should go back and start the whole shebang with May Day.  They won't be disappointed.

Renowned German author Gunther Grass doesn't usually keep a journal.  But after the Berlin Wall fell in November 1989, Grass felt compelled to jot down daily developments during what would prove to be an historic time.  This volume covers the period from January 1, 1990 to February 1, 1991.  Here is a first-hand account of what was happening in the new Germany and in the burgeoning European Union, as reported by one of the most politically and environmentally conscious writers of our day.But these pages offer much more.  We also get insights into the life of the writer himself.  We witness his creative process at work.  Even while he monitors the continual updates on the reunification front, Grass considers the nuances of fictional characters, settings, and plot lines.  This year sees him begin to sketch out the elements of two books to be published later: Call of the Toad (Unkenrufe) and Too Far Afield (Ein weites Feld).At the same time, Grass holds a schedule of nearly nonstop public readings and lectures.  He simultaneously travels among his homes in Portugal, Paris, Germany, and Denmark, and spends a great deal of time cooking, gardening, and entertaining.  It would be challenging to keep up with his hectic lifestyle, even without such important changes happening in his native region.A few of Grass's exquisite line drawings are included.  He describes making his own ink out of squid and walnut shells, too.  Ever recurring in the text and the illustrations is the motif of the toad.  A real one shows up on the final page.Readers don't have to have a firm grasp of German politics -- past or present -- in order to understand some of the ramifications of the events.  But I have to be honest:  it sure does help.  Otherwise, appendices in the back of the book offer more details about the people, places, historical events, and political parties that are referenced throughout the text.  Grass's concerns about environmental issues are prescient, given what we know now.  And as his journal ends just as the first Gulf war is beginning, we are left to consider what subsequent international confrontations have happened since Grass penned these words.Read these journal entries, and you're apt to wish there were more volumes of them available.  The passages may entice you to read Grass's other writings, especially the two books mentioned earlier.  "From Germany to Germany" is recommended reading for German students, for fellow writers, and for anyone interested in this historic era in German history.

When you survive one of the worst natural disasters in history, your view of what's important in life HAS to change.Here interior decorator Nate Berkus shares his thoughts "about the relationship between people and their things."  He begins with his own memoir, and his new-found joy at 13 years of age, when he was given the chance to design and decorate his own basement bedroom.  We follow along as he gets older and first works in an auction house, then launches his own business endeavor.  We meet his partner Fernando Bengoechea.  The couple was together only a year before they were caught in the tsunami of 2004 in Sri Lanka.  Only Nate survived the awful ordeal.  His honesty in recalling the experience is both painful and poignant.Nate shows us around their Chicago apartment and describes the objects that mattered to them.  Then it's on to the stories of other people, their stuff, and where they live and work:  Brian Sawyer, Barri Leiner Grant, Kelly Framel, Steve Berg, Chris Gardner, Dr. Ruth Westheimer, Barbara Hill, Dolores Robinson, Corin Nelson, Fabiola Beracasa, Sandy Foster, and Brooke & Michael Hainey.  These friends and/or clients have both inspiring lives and homes.  Nate helps to uncover the bits of their pasts in the present.  The most treasured items often include flea market and eBay finds, as well as natural objects like branches and stones.  This residential excursion concludes by circling back to Nate again:  newly partnered with Carlos Huber and living in a new apartment in New York.  It's the perfect end for the tour.As should be expected, this book is heavy on illustrations, including many double-page spreads.  The advance uncorrected proof included only b&w photographs.  I assume that most if not all of these photos will appear in color in the final publication, which will make for a beautiful book.  It's a tad disconcerting to the reader when objects described in the text are not pictured, or are shown on adjacent pages.  Otherwise, this book delivers as advertised.I have to admit that I've seen Nate Berkus on TV only once:  when he appeared as a guest judge in an episode of HGTV's "Design Star."  You don't have to know who he is to enjoy hearing his story, visiting interesting spaces, and being moved to look at your own home in a different way.

Here poet/author Donald Hall once again shares his memories about his grandparents' farm in rural New Hampshire.  In this slim holiday offering, 12-year-old Donnie takes the train from his home in New Haven, Connecticut, north through Boston and through Concord, New Hampshire, and finally arrives at the tiny depot in West Andover.  He's in for a treat:  a chance to spend five days at Christmas with his grandparents.  He had previously visited them only in the summertime, and he always wondered what the farm would be like in winter.  Now he will get to find out, firsthand.This is the simpler time of traveling by horse-drawn carriages, cutting your own wood, milking the cows by hand, filling the dinner table with food raised only on the farm, and going to bed with a hot water bottle tucked between the sheets.  Donnie helps his grandparents with the chores and is amazed at the differences between summer and winter.  He's also dealing with his youthful yearnings to be in two places at once:  in Connecticut with his parents, and especially with his ailing mother; or with his grandparents, here in his favorite, special place.  Yes, the grown-ups talk about FDR and the war in Europe, as everyone dives into the Christmas feast.  But that seems like a world away.Hall's easy style of narration is a joy to read.  An added bonus is the addition of Mary Azarian's line drawings, which add just the right touch of old-fashioned whimsy to the story.  This is a quiet and reflective book that's perfect for the season and for readers of all ages.  It feeds the human need to go back home again.  Only in the concluding Acknowledgements pages do we learn the reality behind the tale.Those who wish to hear more about Donald Hall's grandparents; farm -- which now happily, he calls his own -- can find lengthier memoirs in Eagle Pond, Here at Eagle Pond, Seasons at Eagle Pond, and String Too Short to Be Saved.  Hall has also based some of his children's books at Eagle Pond:  Lucy's Christmas, Lucy's Summer, The Farm Summer 1942, and Old Home Day.  Both young and old should enjoy these visits.

... at a time when other girls wanted to MARRY the Beatles.  For Ann and Nancy Wilson, making music was almost always an important part of their lives.  The challenge, then, lay in figuring out how they could make successful careers out of doing it.  But if their ancestor Hannah Dustin could wield a tomahawk and kill her captors to gain her freedom in colonial Massachusetts, then surely the Wilson sisters could don guitars, approach microphones, and slay audiences in the twentieth century.  Eventually, of course, they would.Here they share their story in their own voices:  a duet on the printed page, toggling back and forth between the two women.  It's as if we are sitting across the table from them in a coffee shop, just listening to the two of them recount their experiences and memories.  Other voices of friends and fellow musicians chime in when necessary.  (After all:  the sisters are "merely" the front-women for a full-fledged rock band.)  But this one belongs to the Wilsons.This book is everything fans of rock music and of Heart could ask for.  We learn of their beginnings and growing up in a mobile military family, and then settling down in Bellevue, Washington.  The sisters played at any venue that would have them in the early 1970s; and at one point they were known as "Little Led Zeppelin" because they played so many Zep covers.  We follow them to Vancouver, British Columbia, and tag along as the band called Heart begins to gain real popularity and initially, in Canada.  After that, the path becomes a whirlwind course of music, touring, fame, and fortune, that spans the course of four decades.Naturally, we are treated to some juicy tales from that insider world of sex, drugs and rock-n-roll.  We meet the real-life men and witness the incidents that inspired the lyrics to "Magic Man" and "Barracuda."  The surrealism of the performers' rising position shows up in their inevitable interactions with other celebrities:  the members of Led Zeppelin themselves, Elton John and Bernie Taupin, the Van Halen brothers, Mick Jagger.  Then there are all sorts of other "Devil's bargains" that arise, even beyond the easy availability of drugs and alcohol.  The women learn firsthand about ethics and legalities of binding contracts in the recording industry.  They are almost constantly confronted by the blatant sexism of the chauvinistic business they happen to be in, having to endure insults about appearances even while fending off unwanted advances.  Even so, through the 1970s, 1980s, 1990s, and 2000s, we can see their personal and professional lives change course with the inevitable progress of maturity.It's always a gift to be able to see behind the curtain:  to find out what went on in our favorite performers' lives while we were living out our own dramas, out in the audience.  Now in their 60s (!), Ann and Nancy Wilson share their memories with a clear retrospective view.  Not only are these women still performing, but they are still kicking and dreaming and above all, still keeping the love alive.  It's easy to turn these pages to the strains of "Dog and Butterfly," "These Dreams," and other Heart songs ringing in your head, supplying a background to the narrative."Kicking and Dreaming" is highly recommended reading for rock music fans of any kind, whether or not they have ever followed Heart.  This book is sure to create new "Heart Mongers" as a result.  These talented sisters deserve them.

What a coup for the museum on Wyoming's Wind River Reservation!  An exhibit featuring items from Buffalo Bill's Wild West Show is scheduled to include historic regalia belonging to Black Heart, an Arapaho chief who actually accompanied Buffalo Bill on his European tour of 1889-1890.  The hand-decorated adornments had been out of native hands for more than a century.  But excitement soon turns to outrage when the cartons containing Black Heart's pieces turn up empty.  How could this theft happen?  Who was involved?  What are those two noticeable white men doing on the rez, driving around in a dark sedan?  And, as usual:  Can Father John O'Malley and Arapaho lawyer Vicky Holden figure out what's going on in time, so that the artifacts will not be lost to the native people forever?Margaret Coel keeps the story moving as we toggle between the action taking place today and those activities in the summer of 1890, when the Wild West Show was performing in Berlin.  One of the sticking points in the memories of the Arapaho descendents is how Black Heart's valuables were lost in that city, back then.  Thanks to the author's deft design, we are privy to both sides of the debate.  We can only hope that the two strands will merge and culminate in the successful return of the regalia to Riverton.  Though the instance here is indeed a fictional one, surely following this narrative will cause readers to reflect upon the challenge and the rights of Native Americans to recover their own relics.  There's nothing more satisfying than learning about history and culture through the quiet ease of the pages of a novel.Never far from the main plot here is the on-going relationship between Father John and Vicky.  Can they ever be more than friends?  And what will it mean now that Vicky's former boyfriend and law partner, Adam Lone Eagle, has returned to the area?  As usual, Coel has given us another fresh and interesting episode in this mystery series:  almost unbelievably, Number 16!  Avid readers should be pleased.  Newbies to the series could begin here without confusion, but will shortly insist upon devouring all of the other installments.  They won't be disappointed.

Kate Garrett works as a police detective in a city in southwestern Ontario.  She's in the midst of a drug-related homicide investigation when she gets the worst news possible:  her father Joe has been hit by a car and killed.  A retired police officer himself, Joe had since turned to running his own private investigation service.  Was it his most recent case that put him in harm's way?  Or was this merely a tragic accident?While Kate and Joe's business partner Jake Carmedy grieve separately for their loss, they both begin to puzzle out what Joe had been working on.  A tension from the past prevents them from working together, at first.  But as additional deaths take place, both find too many threads that lead to the offices of Touchstone Insurance.  With the backup of friends and professional colleagues in the local police department, Kate and Jake are able to collar the ultimate perpetrator in the end.  Whether they will be able to work well as a team from this point on, is anyone's guess.  The dynamic between the two could develop, change, and go in any number of different directions, as the pair takes on new cases.A special nuance to this story is that it takes place over the course of ten days in November 2018.  Kate and her fellow officers therefore use better computer technology than we have now (in 2012) to gather and process information.  Security measures in both private and public buildings have been stepped up a notch as well.  Otherwise, this book that is set in the future -- for now -- is not overly "futuristic."  After all:  any such mystery and police procedural boils down to uncovering the vagaries of human behavior.  That idea transcends time."Deadly Legacy" sets a good scene for further episodes in the series.  Kate Garrett is a likable character who deserves to have more adventures.  As mentioned above, her budding business relationship with Jake Carmedy is one that has potential.  The author chooses not to name their city in this book.  I believe it would help firm up the readers' imaginations if she did, and if we were told a bit more about the place.  What with the various investigations and the wakes and funerals of all of the deceased, several more minor characters show up here than are probably necessary.  Readers may have a tough time deciphering and remembering which ones are more important than others.Overall, this book is an intriguing first episode that should have readers wishing and hoping for a quick sequel.  We want to tag along with Kate and Jake on at least another outing.[This review was based on seeing a paperback copy, compliments of the author, in exchange for a fair assessment of the work.]

In considering this book, let me first explain what it is NOT.  When a volume has the phrase "Nature Writing" in its title, it often turns out to be a mere anthology of such pieces by a variety of authors.  The editors may preface the pages with a brief history behind the writers and the selections, but that explanation has to be necessarily cut short.  (See examples in This Incomparable Lande: A Book of American Nature Writing, The Oxford Book of Nature Writing, and Norton Book of Nature Writing.)  These compilations are fine, if that happens to be what you're looking for.  Each one is unique, too.A Natural History of Nature Writing is not an anthology or a compilation.  It's a narrative that provides a natural history of the genre as it has progressed here in the United States.  Author Frank Stewart (Univ. of Hawaii) covers the impacts of Gilbert White's 18th-century walks through his native Selborne, England; and then turns to the best-known Americans in the field:  Henry David Thoreau, John Burroughs, John Muir, Aldo Leopold, Rachel Carson, and Edward Abbey.  Stewart analyzes their lives and writings in chronological order, including the overlaps in their lifetimes and the influences each had on one another.  A few additional folks surface as well, like Walt Whitman, Mary Austin (a southwestern author who was new to me), and Bill McKibben.  Some works are quoted for illustration, but no complete pieces appear here.Nearly one full chapter is devoted to the "nature faker" controversy that took place at the turn of the last century.  Pitting "a popular nature writer named William J. Long" against John Burroughs, this debate bounced around enough in the public media that President Teddy Roosevelt eventually got involved.  Stewart provides a good analysis of the dispute and concludes that both sides "may have realized that the natural world is more complex than they had been willing to conceive."  This story is key to any discussion about the scope and accuracy of nature writing today; and it is sometimes difficult to find the details of this controversy.  (Of the anthologies previously noted, only the introduction in This Incomparable Lande: A Book of American Nature Writing gives it a brief mention; and none of the three includes any works by Long.  A quiet lesson in omission, perhaps?)Henry David Thoreau permeates every chapter here.  Stewart is obviously a fan, and he claims (probably correctly) that Henry "is the touchstone throughout."  The concept of nature writing in America begins and ends with the man.  Stewart also shows no fear.  He opens the book by tackling the most intricate and most debated passage in Thoreau's WALDEN:  the parable of the hound, the bay horse, and the turtledove.  What a way to start!  If any faint-hearted readers are put off by this intense dissection of just one literary line, they should skip ahead to Chapter Two, where the chronological treatment begins with Gilbert White, and then leads into the others.Stewart concludes the book by getting personal:  by exploring the wilderness found in his Hawaii homeland, and by considering statements made by environmentalist Bill McKibben in The End of Nature.  Stewart is more optimistic than McKibben is, about the fate of nature and by extension, nature writing.  The text thus ends on a positive note.Although this book was first released in 1995, it's still a worthy read and reference for anyone who is interested in nature writing and in the major American authors we associate with it.  A real gift is the 12-page appendix of "Bibliography and Further Readings," which we can use as a home library checklist or as a program for future finds and purchases.  This book is highly recommended for the nature/environment crowd.

Douglas Wood has his own Walden-like retreat.  It's a cabin on an island in Rainy Lake, at the edge of the Minnesota-Ontario border, "Deep in the heart of the North Woods."  This remote site offers not only personal sanctuary, but also a variety of natural scenery to explore, both on land and by water.  It seems like a perfect, idyllic place.In this collection of short essays, Wood invites us to visit the area for a while.  We walk alongside him, and we help to paddle his canoe.  We listen as he shares interesting past encounters with the land or with its inhabitants.  Fairly soon we realize that the man's got a subtle sense of humor.  The sign on his outhouse even reads "The Church of Peace."  He also has an easy-going, casual style of storytelling.  His quick monologues cover such topics as fishing, boating, camping, splitting wood, and even feeding cat food to a wild fox.  He pokes fun at himself, thinking of tours he once conducted as a paid wilderness guide, when he would point out to unsuspecting tourists features like the "Glacial Eroticas."  These are fun stories to hear.He can also be uniquely spiritual on occasion.  Some of his experiences lead him to call upon the wisdom of the Native Americans or the Zen Buddhists.  And above all else, Douglas Wood is an optimistic man.  It's refreshing to meet one.Author Wood provides for us a delightful read on these pages.  He warns us in the preface that "Rusticating on an island roost can sometimes lead to Serious Thoughts.  And sometimes not."  We find both here in "Fawn Island," the book.  It's an exploration of both place and self.

This novel takes place in the fictitious Cape Cod town of Oyster Creek, Massachusetts.  For artistic and romantic types who visit or relocate from the mainland, this close but remote setting can be magical:  full of brilliant light that inspires heightened creativity.  And yet the Cape holds the traditions of its own residents as well:  of the sailors and fishermen who make their livings based on the vagaries of the bay and the sea.  Many of these natives can trace their roots back across the Atlantic to the country of Portugal, where even earlier seafarers once had the courage to set out on that long watery journey to the New World.Oyster Creek harbors a small population of both "washashores" and Portagee.  What happens when the two mix?  Well, we find out when washashore artist Sabine Gray entices Franco Neves, the assistant harbormaster, into having an extramarital affair.  Sabine becomes pregnant.  When little Vita is born, Sabine raises her daughter on her own, in their small cottage.  Naturally everyone in town knows that Franco is the father:  including Danielle, his wife.  Attempts at somehow reconciling the two families are clumsy at best.  And yet, Life goes on.When Vita is three years old, her mother is brutally murdered in their home by a local man.  Sabine's will dictates that her friend LaRee Farnham gets custody of Vita.  LaRee is a divorced nurse with no children of her own.  Suddenly she's thrown into the role of mother to a girl who is already a victim on two fronts.  LaRee raises her as best as she can think to, alternately sheltering Vita but allowing her as much freedom as seems appropriate.
