Their relationship with Franco and Danielle is also a tenuous one."The Harbormaster's Daughter" checks in on these individuals over the course of more than a dozen years, until Vita is close to finishing high school.  It can thus be seen as a coming-of-age novel.  But the story offers quite more than that.  It's about realizing the complexities of life:  How to find your place in your own skin and in your own community, where everyone already knows too much about you.  How to live in the present, when all of the reminders of the past still loom large on the landscape and in the minds of others.  How to refuse to allow your tragedies to define you.  What it means to Belong.  And these are challenges that can face us all, no matter what age we might be.This book is a great summer / beach read that should appeal to both adult and young adult women.  It will be easy for readers to cheer on Vita and LaRee -- and in a way, to root for Franco and his wife Danielle too, and for all of the other quirky people in this far-flung place.  Those who are addicted to Cape Cod novels will not be disappointed in the role of the setting here.  And if this is your first encounter with the author, you might want to pick up the first book she placed in this town, The House on Oyster Creek: A Novel.

Knowing that this book was published by the Teachers & Writers Collaborative of New York City is helpful information to have.  Potential readers will then understand that this book is missing a key word from its title:  TEACHING.  Otherwise, individuals may think that, like other published books of "nature writing," this will turn out to be a compilation of nature-related prose and poetry by famous-name authors.  Well, it IS a compilation volume.  But it's a guide to TEACHING nature writing.  And as such, it's a nice manual to add to any teacher's arsensal.Poet Gary Snyder begins here by addressing the concepts of language and writing.  Then twenty-eight writers/instructors offer their experiences and advice in inspiring people to write about nature.  The exercises are intended for a variety of audiences, from kindergarten age to adults; and many can be tailored for just about any type of group.  Some of the assignments focus on penning short essays, while others involve journaling with both text and drawings.  Many of the lessons aim at the creation of poetry.  Most of the contributors include work samples from some of their past students.  An added perk is the recurring theme of how to encourage people to write about nature while living in an urban environment.  Each teacher provides information about resources that were consulted and found to be useful.  But truly invaluable is the comprehensive bibliography that appears at the end of the book."The Alphabet of the Trees" contains a lot of ideas for anyone who is considering teaching nature writing, especially for the first time.  Who knew that there were more approaches to the task than just asking folks to go outside, look around, and then put pen to paper?  Tangentially, this volume could also be used by adult and young adult writers who find themselves in need of some inspirational prompts to jump-start their minds and set their fingers to flying on the keyboards.

At first, it may have seemed like just a crazy dream:  to somehow create a brand-new professional sports league from scratch, from absolutely nothing.  But that's exactly what fitness expert Jake "Body by Jake" Steinfeld, lacrosse player Dave Morrow, and television exec Tim Robertson did.  Their work toward a common goal -- establishing Major League Lacrosse -- is outlined here.  The casual narration is supplied by Jake, with occasional interjections by Dave.  Their voices are set in two different fonts, so that readers can tell them apart on the page.For those who aren't familiar with the game, lacrosse can be described as a blend of the key elements of hockey, soccer, basketball, and football.  It's the oldest American sport.  Native Americans were seen playing it when European missionaries first arrived in North America in the seventeenth century.  Four hundred years later, lacrosse was mostly relegated to being merely a high school or college sport:  one that had a small but devoted following, mostly in the northeastern part of the country.Through a series of interesting events and circumstances, Jake and Dave and Tim met one another and began pursuing the professionalization of outdoor lacrosse.  Even with Jake's EXTENSIVE Hollywood and Wall Street connections, these guys had myriad challenges to face:  whether it was finding investors, sponsors, or even enough light bulbs to broadcast a game on TV.  Jake's sharing of the fine details has necessarily been condensed and watered down to fit into this one slim and very readable volume.  To his credit, he doesn't drag any famous names through the dirt, even when some deals don't work out.  But since Jake is an extrovert in the extreme, and Dave is a talented athlete but an introvert at heart, you just have to feel a bit sorry for Dave whenever Jake pushes him at every turn.  It's all for the best, though.  Everything works out in the end.The book covers the background of the MLL organization from 1998 to 2001, as well as the first full playing season (2001) and the challenge of putting forth a second (2002).  MLL is now in its twelfth year and can be considered an athletic success.  A section of color photos is included.This tale is also a subtle lesson in motivation.  Jake has been reined in a bit, on this count.  But he occasionally launches into vibrant pep talks for the readers.  "[L]ife is all about facing obstacles and finding a way under, over, around, or straight through them." (p. xvi)  "When you're passionate about something, great things happen -- maybe not overnight, but they do happen.  And they happen in a bigger, better way than you could have imagined."  (p. 66)  The MLL is proof of that statement.Fans of lacrosse will no doubt be eager to pick up this book.  But most sports fans of any ilk will probably find the book a good read.  It's fascinating to think of all of the work that has to happen for a professional sport to exist.  If this tale motivates you to follow your own passion, well then, that's probably also worth the price of admission.

Have you ever driven along an interstate highway and wondered about the farms and the fields that were once cut up to accommodate our need for traveling convenience?  Have you thought of the people who might still live there?  Or:  Have glimpses of a handsome house, a bucolic barn, or a serviceable silo sped past your gaze at 55, 65, or 75 miles per hour?  If you answered with quick yeses; or if those thoughts have never crossed your mind at all, you would do well to read Mike Perry's newest book.  It provides more than a few of those off-the-shoulder stories.Mike lives down the road from octogenarian Tom Hartwig, in an area near Eau Claire, Wisconsin.  Back in 1967, the construction of I-94 intruded on and dissected the farm that Tom had already lived on, all of his life.  At least 23,200 cars speed behind his silo each and every day.  The continual whine of engines and tires touching asphalt now provides a constant backdrop for any conversation held in the Hartwig kitchen.  But that's where the real action lies for this memoir:  for that's where Tom is likely to tell the tales of his past, to any eager audience that happens to be seated around the old dinner table.  We are lucky that Mike has written some of them down and has shared them with us here.Lest you think this might be a Tuesdays with Morrie kind of offering, the author is quick to claim:  "He is not my mentor, I am not his acolyte."  Funny:  the rest of the book only serves to disprove that statement.  Tom is not only a long-time farmer, but he's also a masterful Mister Fix-it when it comes to any type of metalcraft or machinery.  He's exactly the man you want to know and learn from if you are a young farmer yourself -- which author Perry insists that he is not, despite the fact that he lives on nearby acreage.  Mike calls upon Tom for routine advice, for the "accumulated wisdom of the elders" ... and often gets more than he asks for.  In a good way, of course.Through this dual biography, we learn more about both Tom and Mike.  Often, it means old versus young, and old times versus contemporary ones.  The past, present, and future intersect here, and are augmented by a strong sense of place.  Like the rest of humankind, both Tom and Mike have dimensions to them that can be surprising or conflicting.  Tom see-saws on politics, for example.  Mike shows that he is a sensitive man who is moved to deep emotion (even to tears) at chance moments spent with his wife and two daughters.  He can even get misty at the thought of the many boots that have worn down a floor board in an old farmhouse.  And yet, he can take down a buck with a single arrow shot, and can gut and dress his victim in less time than it takes to finish the chapter that describes the hunt.  Go figure.  And while Tom has the legacy of the interstate to live with, Mike is fighting the battle of Starkey Road.  Common threads run amok.Mike Perry has a vivid writing style.  He makes unique observations and uses interesting turns of phrase.  For example:  On a road tunneled by fully-branched trees, "In autumn, at peak color, it is like motoring directly into the September page of a bank calendar."  The narrative itself is framed by italicized passages.  Without supplied explanation, the reader gradually discerns that these particular interviews were conducted as photographers were posing Tom on his property, for the purposes of illustrating this book.  We get to see a few of those views as they introduce each chapter.This is the first Michael Perry book I've ever chanced to read, and I'm eager to go back and read the rest.  "Visiting Tom" is recommended for anyone interested in farming, in Middle America, in the rural way of life, or in gleaning the "wisdom of the elders."  And make sure you wave, during your next trip to Madison.[This review was based on seeing an uncorrected proof of the book.]

Henry David Thoreau (1817-1862) may be the most quoted and least read American author.  Every year, "new" volumes of Thoreau sayings are compiled and released.  Some take the form of coffee table books, fleshed out with illustrations of natural scenes that coordinate with the classic word pictures.  Others let the original texts merely speak for themselves.  Many of the latter follow a specific theme.Nowadays the quintessential and most complete book in this genre is The Quotable Thoreau.  But this nifty paperback from 1991 is one of the better subject-oriented compilations.  I picked up a copy at a used bookstore because of an upcoming project where I needed to find just these types of Thoreau quotes:  examples of his writings that have to do with the concepts of preservation, wildness, and the environment.  I could have done the research and looked them up myself, but who has the time?  Especially when someone else has already done it?Tim Homan put together a nice variety of material here.  Some of it is commonplace and fairly familiar.  "In Wildness is the preservation of the World."  "We need the tonic of wildness."  Some, not so much, but still gem-like.  "Nature doth thus kindly heal every wound."  "The globe is the richer for the variety of inhabitants."  And so on.  Good stuff.  With source citations.  And if you don't know much about Mr. Thoreau, this book marks a decent place to start.  It's a testament to the volume's worthiness that new copies can still be purchased here.  Another one of my favorites among the quote books is H. D. Thoreau, a Writer's Journal, which assembles Thoreau's observations about writing and the writing process.

Mike Link and Kate Crowley believe that endings can often mark beginnings.  So when Mike anticipated retiring from the Audubon Center of the North Woods in Sandstone MN (where he served as director from 1971-2009), both he and wife Kate began thinking about their next project.  With their love of nature in general and of Lake Superior more specifically, the idea grew to take some time to walk around its perimeter.  They already knew much about Superior.  They had visited various shoreline sites in the years beforehand, and had even been married on a boat on the lake in 1986.  After much planning and the gaining of contacts, sponsorships, and a terrific support assistant named Amanda, Mike and Kate began their official journey on April 29, 2010, in Duluth MN.  It took them nearly five months and 1,555 miles to make it back to that city, after their diligent counterclockwise circumambulation of this incredible inland sea.What kinds of pre-trip concerns did they need to consider?  Well, their own physical conditions, first of all.  Both were in their early 60s; and Mike had recently experienced a few medical setbacks.  But they kept track of their health and also benefited from the advice of a few doctors and hospitals along the way.  Weather could also be a factor, as could encounters with wild animals, domesticated dogs, or even with singled-minded property owners.  But it turns out that the biggest danger on this hike lay in slippery rocks, which could cause sudden falls and random injuries on any human body.  And Superior is edged by millions of such potential obstacles.If this pilgrimage had been undertaken merely for personal enrichment, it would still have made for a terrific tale.  But Mike and Kate enhanced its value by collecting data on the lake and its flora and fauna, at three-mile increments.  GPS coordinates and photographs helped to pinpoint locations.  They asked people they met to complete paper surveys about impressions and changes throughout the years.  The resulting details mark the first such comprehensive scrutiny of Superior, whose beaches run through two countries, three states, one province, and many individual public and private parks and reservations.  Some data is shared here; the rest is left to the project web site and to educational institutions in the region.  The additional intent was to bring awareness of lake issues into the public eye, and to reinforce the need to take care of this natural resource.Sure, Mike and Kate saw wonderful water views, beautiful birds, and even interesting lichens during the trek that led them from the appearance of spring wildflowers to the falling leaves of autumn.  But it was the people they met along the way who were the true gems of the journey.  Year-round residents, landowners, and long-time tourists.  Native Americans and First Nation peoples.  Superior means something to each one of them; and Mike and Kate were lucky enough to hear many of their stories.  The number of family members and friends (new and old) who joined the couple enroute to celebrate their last day of walking was a testimony, not only to the intrigue of the trip itself, but also to the strong pull of Superior.  At its core, this is a love story:  one that connects thousands of humans with a place that they honor and care deeply about.With its narrative told in tag-team style, "Going Full Circle" is a welcome read for anyone who has traveled throughout the Great Lakes region.  You're sure to find intersections of your own experiences with those of the authors.  And you're apt to learn of new places that you might just want to visit now, yourself.  Yes, there is a road-based Lake Superior Circle Tour that anyone can navigate via bicycle or by motorized vehicle.  But much more can be witnessed and learned by going on foot and by talking to the people encountered along the trail.  Thankfully, we can all make the trip this way vicariously through Mike and Kate.What's next for this well-traveled and water-based couple?  "Full Length Mississippi:" a tracing of the great river from its source to its outlet, by bike and boat.  Stay tuned.

Wow. This is an amazing novel for a first-time author. It is epic. It is addicting. This is a book for all time, for any reader teen and up. I am a grandma and I was spellbound. I could not put this down and kept reading into the night, as addicted to the book as its hero Ryan Mitchell is addicted to time travel. He spends four centuries reliving the same year, trying to get his life back on track, trying desperately to find the right combination of events or the right moment to start over and to find the love of his life who got lost when he chose time-jumping due to its addictive qualities. This is a coming of age novel that gets stuck in the same year, and yet the hero has a revelation unlike any other. This is a philosophical novel, and is more about the cognitive dissonance people experience in realizing they have made horrific mistakes  that cost more than they wanted to pay. As Ryan jumps, and plays various roles such as crime-fighter, or even criminal, we learn more facets of his personality, and it all hangs together at the end with a surprising solution. I am amazed. I am amused. I am addicted.  I am enlightened. I am waiting for this author's next work.  Brilliant. (except for a few copy editing errors..)

This is the perfect floral tape for the brooch bridal bouquet I am working on! For that, the green floral tape would just not look right. This tape sticks well, and stretches right while covering wire stems. I really like this tape. It is hard to find in this color locally so I got it on Amazon. It is good quality. I used to work with  a florist so I am no stranger to this sort of tape and can  tell you it's good stuff.

This is interesting stuff! Plus, you get TEN yards. I am using this in a brooch bridal bouquet and found that it's pretty versatile. You can glue it to a surface, you can glue a strip of it to itself to make a double-faced strand and then use it as loops in a flower arrangement. That's how I am using it.  But you can tie it in a bow around mason jars or candles or for napkin rings or use it with wrapping paper. This is a reasonably-priced craft item that provides a little bling for little money. I love it.

These faceted bead wires are a decent price considering that if you made them yourself, you'd be twisting wires and if you're a klutz like me, probably cutting your hands in the process.. These beads are exactly as they say..aurora borealis faceted beads. They are plastic. They will look fine in a bridal bouquet for added bling as they they are not meant to be the focal point of a bouquet. They are an accent and as such work just fine for their intended purpose. I gave this four stars because the beads were square and I didn't expect that. I suppose it doesn't really matter, but I hoped for round.

I am making a brooch bouquet for my friend's wedding and these are the perfect thing to add for a three-dimensional touch. They are exactly as described. While it is true that the rhinestones are flat-backed and shiny only one side, this is not a problem. The little wires can be twisted so only the shiny part shows in the arrangement.  The silver wire on these is sturdy yet flexible. Each  little  branch or spray has about five rhinestones on it. the bunch you see pictured on Amazon is of the entire package of the sprays, not just one. All in all, I am pleased with these. I just added to this review pictures of the brooch bouquet in which I used these sprays. Everyone loved the brooch bouquet, and the sparkly sprays added dimension to it.

This story has enough twists and turns to satisfy anyone. It is a stand-alone book, but I think you would enjoy it more reading the first in the Gold Rush Romance series because many of the characters are first introduced there. However, this particular book is Lily's story--and is a tale of human trafficking told against the historical backdrop of the California Gold Rush. Lily is from China where an evil aunt sold her to a ship captain who abused her and sold her when the ship docked in San Francisco. But Sarah, an independent young woman who runs a restaurant and who also has a habit of taking in stray people who need help comes  to her rescue, winning Lily's freedom in a poker game. What happens after that is a jaw-dropping story you won't want to put down. I am new to reading Mona Ingram but I am certain I will be looking up her other works as well if these are a sample of what she writes. Ingram surely knows how to tell a story and how to surprise the reader. This is not some bland romance book. It's gutsy and real and just like its heroines,

OK. I admit it. It doesn't take much to make me smile. I love this balancing eagle that I got for my grandson. (I loved it so much I got one for me, too) It really does balance and it fascinates the little folks. I like to put it on the top corner of my book case, but it does come with a little stand so you could put it on your desk. This one is nicely painted. Even the bottom is painted. I have had it for months and no signs of wear. It seems durable and ...well balanced!

I wish I had gotten these years ago!  For years, I have struggled with trying to get ice cubes removed from the tray without wrecking my fingers or dropping the tray on the floor. Heck, I'm a relic. I remember those aluminum trays with the lever-release that sometimes worked and sometimes didn't. But the trays that come with the fridges these days--well those are horrid. But THESE, these lovely, smooth, blue trays are heavenly. The ice cubes practically slide out on their own. No need to struggle! Just effortless, blissful ice cubes easily stored in a bin in my freezer. They work perfectly. They are EASY RELEASE just like the name says. So happy to find this wasn't just some advertising ploy. I highly recommend these ice cube trays!.

This is a compelling, courageous story beautifully written. Misty Griffin and her sister, Samantha, were victims of the most hideous abuse for all of their childhood. Then, as young women, they were turned over to a strict Amish community where they saw more abuse unchecked. Most people have the idea that the Amish are a simple people, with beautiful ideals. Yet this grim, inside view reveals a culture where incest, child abuse, and attempted murder are covered up by church rules. In this world, women have few rights, and men, sometimes evil men, make and enforce all of the rules. The author  left the Amish in order to reveal abuse and try to help some of the victims. She wrote this to show the world that the abuse is real, but also to bring hope. This book is hard to read because the abuse is described so clearly from the first person perspective. Misty Griffin poured her heart and soul into this and revealed her innermost thoughts growing up in a world of hurt. Yet this book is laced with hope and the idea that no matter who we are, we are people with rights and that nobody has the power to steal the essence of who we are. The only way to stop bullying of any kind is to stand up to it. The personal story of Misty Griffin reveals that in her own life, she managed to transcend the horrible childhood, to embrace it as part of herself, but to also move beyond it to achieve her dream of going to college and starting a foundation to help other abuse victims. While this book is an eye-opener, and not the usual view of the Amish culture you find in movies and novels, this is a true story. It is a lyrical and beautiful book. I am amazed. It is breathtaking. I used to belong to a church that had cult-like aspects and it was difficult to leave it. I totally respect this author for her accurate and intimate look at the cognitive dissonance that occurs when you leave a group like the Amish. This book deserves a lot of attention for its message and also for its incredible style. I hope to see more from this author. .

Having just completed reading this book and also comparing Bible commentaries on 1 &2 Thessalonians, I can't help feeling that Beth Moore is not at her best with this study. It almost seems as if she is distracted. There are too many anecdotes about her, her family, her troubled kids, her failed adoption. The more I read about Beth Moore, the more I feel that her ministry, although it may do  much good and bring Christ to some, is a little bit too  much about her. The study has some scriptures that are misapplied. She uses some of the scripture to talk about doing good, which is fine in of itself, but the verses she chose weren't about that. This means that would-be consumers of her works need to be on guard against false teachings and to be discerning in their studies. Unfortunately, there are a lot of women who follow Beth Moore with almost  cult-like enthusiasm. It may seem petty to some that I am "picking on" a woman of God, but anyone who sets themselves up as a teacher, who makes millions of dollars off of the Word of God, must be held to a high standard. Anyone who makes claims that God speaks to them or  who claims to commission women to be a light in the world, (something that is God's place to do, and he has so commissioned all of Christians to be...it's not Moore's place to do it) must then be open to the criteria set forth in scripture, namely, if their words do not come true, they are false teachers. Additionally, if they add to or take away from scripture, then they are false teachers. Proceed with caution studying Beth Moore's works if you are a person who wants to live by the Word. Personally, I feel that the Bible is the book I want to study, but anyone who chooses Moore as a guide to the good book should be really careful to do it critically and to not accept her word as THE word.  There is much good in her writings, but they ramble a bit too much and rely on her own ideas too much for me to accept her as a true teacher of the Bible.

We love these fragrance-free baby wipes. Our grandson has sensitive skin and these never give him a rash. They come in a nice huge box and we never run out because we get them from Amazon on the subscription basis. It is convenient. The wipes work great, and baby  has a clean bottom. The wipes are tough, but gentle.

Why not five stars? The most demanding application for this is for expresso and we don't use it on that fine grind. We use it on the coarsest grind. For this use, the grinder is perfect, but we can't address whether it works well for those who need the finer grind for french presses or expresso makers. We use fairly dry beans in it and brush it regularly, have had no jam ups from using the oilier beans you might use for expresso. So, although I am giving this four stars, it's noit because of any kind of lack in the product as far as we are concerned. It is easy to use, and grinds the beans the way we want. What's not to like? We wish it actually had a coarser grind, though.

Nemo's reef is a soothing, addictive game. It is a scam. It is KNOWN that the game will not load on Kindle Fire after level 30 or so. So, while it has a relaxing musical theme, it's really playing your wallet's death dirge unless you keep yourself from buying any pearls.  There are quests to complete. The graphics are lovely.  You build a coral reef with various plants, harvest sand dollars or algae, and buy more plants. Rare fish come along and you have to figure out to keep them. I am at level 31 and the game has started crashing or I get messages saying that the server is not available or that the game has stopped. I am playing on a Kindle Fire and I am finding out that others have the same issues at higher levels. Also, it should be noted that you must spend some money playing this game at some point because you need pearls to complete some of the quests. True, you can grow pearls from your rare fish, but this takes days and some quests have a time limit. I would give this game five stars if it didn't keep crashing. I admit it. I love the game, but the annoying stop messages are getting to me. My grandson has a version of this game on my Kindle in the section just for him called Kindle Freetime. Because the kid side of the Kindle has parental controls and the kids can't go online, this game is a little different than the public one which gets updates periodically. The version my grandson plays has the rare fish producing pearls left and right to the point where he has 8,000 of them. Of course, in the kid version, you don't need to spend them as much. He is at level 34 and his game never crashes and never gets the messages that the game has stopped. Even when I cannot get in, he can. So...hmmm....what's up with that? I wish that Amazon would hold Disney accountable to make a product that works on Kindle. Or, they should not sell it. Yet, like hapless fish, I am already hooked.<<  Now I am at level 32 and the game will not load. I contacted Disney and got this email:" Hi there,We have found that Kindles have troubles loading reefs once they pass about level 30. Kindles are primarily reading devices, and can have troubles loading some games, especially when the profiles get larger.The best way to fix this is to try force quitting any other apps you have running in the background. This may give Nemo's Reef enough resources to load your reef, but I can't guarantee anything. Connecting to a strong wireless network will help, too.If you're unable to load Nemo's Reef at all you may have to start over. If you've purchased any Pearls we'd be happy to readd them to your new account. Simply take a screenshot of each purchase receipt and reply with all of them and your new reef name.I hope you're able to swim around your reef again soon!>>I have no other aps running in the background. I have a wonderfully strong wireless network. And I'm not about to "start over playing the game."  Also, how on God's green earth do you take a screen shot of purchaces on a Kindle???Folks, this is a scam game that will rip you off. Don't start playing it. And, if you have, don't buy pearls. ALso, email Amazon and Disney and let's hold them accountable for this ap they offer that is KNOWN to NOT WORK ON KINDLE FIRE.>>>UPDATE:Glitches in the game seem to be fixed---but they did it by taking away new stuff, weekend quests, and it makes you seriously plod through collecting endlessly in order to advance. No expansions. No new fish. New plants few and far between.....but I'm addicted and do like this game so I play it anyway. I heard they plan to create a Dory's reef once the movie comes out. But to tell you the truth, I love this Nemo's reef and hate to feel that it's a forgotten product with Disney. At least I don't crash out of the game all of the time and I seem to be able to sign on..

This is a well-written, endearing story. This is a coming-of-age story told from the male perspective. Josh grows up before our eyes, enduring hard times on the farm. It's a page-turner. I had only read a few Janet Oke stories before and found them simplistic and predictable as well as preachy. But this book? Wow! It is deep, the characters are well developed and the Christian values expressed in it are second-nature to the characters and not at all out of place.  I was surprised pleasantly to find that even when I got to the end, I wished for more. People who like "clean" stories and historical fiction will enjoy this book.

I love the green quart jars with the wide mouth. I have the plastic lids so I use these to store things in the kitchen such as jelly beans, goldfish crackers, and trail mix. They look good on the shelf or the counter. I only wish they had come in blue. The blue pints are fabulous in color and I would dearly love them in a larger size. So happy they made both green pints and green quarts. These are perfect for canning, of course, but so fun for other things. I found that Ball makes a fruit-infuser lid in green that fits these jars perfectly so they would make a great summer drink jar. I also found a plastic straw and lid combo made by Ball that fits the regular-mouth size jars. These are good for a no-spill drink. So glad that Mason jars are trendy enough that accessories and colors are available! Fun times. Not sure why some folks said their jars smelled like chemicals. The ones bought in blue and the green were all smell-free. I should think that running them through the dishwasher would eliminate any problems, The color in the glass is not painted on. The color is due to adding certain minerals to the liquid glass before it is molded or pressed. There is no way the glassware could smell bad unless something had spilled upon it.

This is a sort of Cinderella story, Amish style.  It even has a fancy blue dress. No pumpkins, however. I found the characters  a little simplistic and undeveloped and the story itself a little unbelievable, even for isolated Amish. But hey, this is a fairy tale adaptation, right? So I was willing to let some things slide. This is short, so to be fair, there probably wasn't much space to do more with the story. I suppose my main beef is that in Amish fiction, I want reality. I found it a little far-fetched that someone would be able to hide in a barn loft for years without Amish neighbors noticing something. Well, that IS how the story progresses...a neighbor DOES find out that our heroine has been treated like a slave for years. Prince charming is a handsome Amishman who rescues the damsel in distress. Justice is done when her step-family realizes she has been nothing but good to them and they feel shame. There's even a happy ending. Roll the credits. Cue the white doves. Whatever. I don't know if I wanted more or if I was relieved when the story ended. Something is missing. But what's there was good enough to give it four stars. I will have to read more from this author to see if this is a typical story for her or if the limitations were from the boundaries of doing a Cinderella story--which, by the way, is rather overdone in any genre.

This is a fairly funny book. The author is one of those people who probably had to coordinate crutches and slings into his back-to-school wardrobe. I decided to read this book mainly because I am one of those people who broke her toe answering the telephone and who once got her hair caught in a mail slot. I survived to adulthood, too. I'm a Grandma now. So it was with some degree of fellow-feeling that I truly enjoyed this book. Matthew Weinrich not only is able to laugh at his many mishaps, he is able to cheerfully show us that despite nearly biting off his tongue and despite messing up his marriage proposal, there is a lot to be learned--and tons of reasons for constant hope.  I wanted to love this book. However, it is too short. It took less than an hour to read. On the other hand, if its target audience is middle school and high schoolers who were bullied or who felt social anxiety and needed some cheering up and cheering on, then it's the perfect length. I can't tell the target audience for this book. Is it young people or adults? Or both?  I found it jarring to read incidents that were not in chronological order. We jumped around the author's life from school days to adulthood, rather willy nilly, I felt. Thus, this book is best read as a devotional for the clumsy. It is best read one chapter at a time, and not in one sitting, methinks.  Matthew Weinrich does know how to tell a good story. He knows how to find the kernel of truth in all of these clumsy moments and shows us what he learned. The underlying message is that human beings can make it, even if events are so out of control we really should carry a parachute and a life raft with us at all times.  The author seems to be a kindred spirit not just to the clumsy, but to all those of us who need inspiration on a dark day, a reminder that the human spirit can transcend emergency room trips, bungled proposals, and broken bones. I recommend this book for that reason.

I love these green bands and lids. The green bands have a tiny rim of silver. They must have used silver lids then colored them. They are absolutely lovely. The lids work just like regular Ball lids, but they are bright green. These will look good on gifts. I plan to use a bunch of these this summer for sweet relish that will be given as gifts. The lids are BPA free, another plus. All of Ball's lids are BPA free, so if you've seen on the web that they aren't--well, you've been misinformed. I have been canning for 30 years and didn't really think they could come up with much that would surprise me in the way of canning supplies! Yet the new blue and now the green jars and coordinating lids add a bit of color to an  old, familiar task. These are, indeed, very, very green!

When the grandson simply says, "Play Jesus!"  I know he is wanting me to play this  particular song, "Jesus Loves Me." It is a nicely done  version, with children singing. This is a relaxing, well-known song  easy for children to understand and to sing along. My grandson is  just over two years old and really loves this song and the other songs from the album we purchased. Had I realized how much he would love it, I would have simply bought the entire album at the outset. I highly recommend this song, for its harmony, for its message, for the joy it brings the little ones to sing along.

This shade is awesome. It is beautiful. It insulates the window against cold or heat. It is cordless. It works smoothly. However, it didn't fit my 27-inch window. It was about a quarter inch too big to install via inside mount on my window. I am so disappointed because this was a good price for a high-quality window shade. It was not wide enough for an outside mount or I would have kept it and installed it. The installation instructions are pretty simple and  includes illustrations for clarity. All in all, if you have a window that is sightly larger than 27 inches, this shade is the one you should get. From what I understand, if you're getting these shades for a 27-inch window, it is too large, and the shades should be 3/8 to 1/2-inch smaller. I should have realized that if the shade is 27-inches, then it would be too large for a 27-inch window. Hindsight. I just learned this now.  However, this is not the fault of the manufacturer nor does it reflect on the quality of the shade. It seems to be a good shade, but since I couldn't install it and try it out for a period of time, I hesitate to give it the five stars it likely deserves.

I bought this book as a gift for a nursing home resident who said he wanted books  about the Civil War. I included this in a gift bag. I found it at Amazon in the used books and didn't pay much, so I'm glad I got it cheap. The photos are nicely chosen, but I found the editorial part of the book rather dry, repetitive, and tedious. However, there is nothing like seeing actual period photos, and for that, I gave it four stars. The recipient of the gift loved it and was thrilled. This book seems aimed at people who need an overview of Brady's photos taken during the Civil War. It's not scholarly, but I think you would already need to be interested in the Civil War and know a little about it in order to enjoy this book. In short, it doesn't break any new ground, but it's pretty good, too.

I am a grandma. I don't really  need one of these devices. I don't even own an i-phone. But I have a college-age daughter who does, and when I was asked to test this device and to post an honest review, I decided, "What the heck?"  Thus this little green speaker arrived at my house and my daughter was delighted with its tiny size, and its collapsible, compact cuteness.  We connected it to her i-phone and played music for the entire family. My husband, who is a musician in several historical string bands, was amazed that his band's  songs played so well on this speaker. "There is NO distortion," he exclaimed. If there was, it was so slight we couldn't tell.  Indeed, the packaging proclaims the distortion to be less than 1.0 percent. I think this is telling the truth.  This device has a lithium battery that takes two hours to charge, and will play for about ten hours before needing recharging. The packaging says it has a playback time of up to 12 hours. My daughter said it was ten hours for her, so this falls into the acceptable range for the product's claims. It comes with a protective cloth bag to keep it in when not in use, and protect it when you take it along. I am a relic of the days when "boom box" meant a huge, clunky box-shaped thing you had to have muscles to carry around. This little thing,  with dimensions of 2.3 by 1.8 inches, is so small it looks like a cat toy.I love that it comes in colors. Adults might not want neon green, but that's the color my daughter chose. It's bright. It is easily seen. But good looks aren't all that critical. She likes it because she is a cheerleader coach and she can put the team's music on her phone and use this speaker for practices. Yes, the team could hear it just fine in the gym. This was pretty surprising. We didn't expect it to be that good! For my daughter, it means not lugging around a lot of equipment. She is delighted as can be. Also, the price is pretty good for a young person to afford to give it as a gift to a friend. This would make a wonderful stocking-stuffer or small gift for people on your list who have MP3 devices or i-phones. Even this grandma might get one--I'm not that old-fashioned, after all.  Disclaimer: I was given one of these devices in exchange for an honest review. If I did not like this device, I would have given it a low rating. I'm like that.

This towel bar is getting lots of compliments from guests at my house. We just remodeled a bathroom and I used brushed nickel finish faucet, towel bar, paper holder and shower head. The finish is lovely and resembles pewter and the ceramic adornments give this modern towel bar a Victorian look. It holds the towels just fine and is very sturdy. The  Victorian faucet I chose had ceramic handles for the hot and cold, which is why I chose this towel bar. It matches perfectly. I am delighted with the looks and function of this towel bar and would highly recommend it for its beauty and ease of installation.  It's a classic.

I got this cup for my husband who wanted a travel mug to take to work. This one is leak proof. The lid comes apart so it can be cleaned easily. He says it keeps coffee hotter than his thermos does, for longer! It holds two full cups of coffee.  The handle grip is comfortable without getting in the way of car cup holders. The bottom width of this cup is just under 2.5 inches,  about  2 and 3/8 inches. It should fit in standard car cup holders.  We looked at other travel mugs that were more expensive and touted as the best, only to learn that the lids needed periodic replacement because they could not be cleaned properly. This one has a lid that comes off and can be taken apart so all parts of it can be cleaned. It is also dishwasher safe. My husband is delighted with this mug and only wishes I had gotten him one much sooner. The Thermos people knew what they were doing when they made this one! P.S. My husband told me that yesterday, much to his chagrin, he accidentally put this cup in his bag upside down. He was so happy that it did not leak--not even a drip--that he asked me to add it to this review.

This sweater is a trendy, pullover that looks so much better on than it does in the picture. My daughter wanted it and I got it for her as a gift thinking, "Well okay if she wants it, but it looks kind of ...large." It's not shapeless when worn, and the black and white looks good with jeans or a black pair of pants. Billed as a loose pullover, she expected it to be an oversize, loose fit. That is what she wanted, but it fits much tighter than she wanted. Otherwise, it is an okay sweater, with the hem in front shorter than the one in back. This is not designer clothing, and it's not an expensive sweater, and she's keeping it, but we think the description could have included some dimensions in the size offered so there would not be this confusion about "loose" fit. We don't know how it washes because she hasn't washed it yet.

This puzzle is shiny and fun! My two-year old grandson loves it. It has latches and locks with brass chains, hooks, and even a window latch. He sat down right away and tried all the little doors and latches and was able to do them.  The pictures are bright, and the little doors have numbers and inside, animals in the corresponding number amount. We joke that this will teach the little kids to be burglars because the latches and such are real ones! But it does provide hours of fun for little people who need to keep their fingers busy. Our grandson did get a little bored with it after he solved it and what we did was put it away for awhile. He was thrilled to see it again and enjoy it like it was new. We do this with all of his puzzles and it extends their play life.

This magical book will thrill the millions of people worldwide in 176 countries who tuned into the Cornell University's Heron Cam in 2012. With a  web camera perched high on a dead tree on Sapsucker Pond, viewers were treated to the heron's eye view of courtship, mating, egg laying, hatching, and raising chicks. The author was one of the people who tuned into the camera and chat room online at Cornell's website--and I for one, am glad she did. What resulted from her hours spent online watching this heron drama unfold is a beautifully told tale that teaches children about the life cycle and habitat of herons. But it is more than that. For the people like me who also watched those herons, this book is a handcrafted, loving souvenir of that magical season when we were glued to the screen, watching the five eggs to see if all would hatch. We watched as the Dad heron sat on the eggs during a freak April blizzard.  Our hearts nearly stopped when we saw a great horned owl get chased off by the mom heron. All of us cheered and cried when the last heron, Fiver, finally fledged. All of this is captured, too. The beautiful water colors that accompany this tale are right from the screen shots that those who tuned in saw. This book could have been done with those photographs but it would not have been half so lovely. The watercolors lend a personal viewpoint to the book, and they are lovingly done with spectacular results. I am impressed by them and by the information in the book. This is a book that adults will not be bored reading to their kids and grandkids. I plan to order an extra copy for me. Even if you were not part of the chat group that got hooked on watching the herons, you can share that experience of wonder through this book.My two-year-old grandson is a bit young for this book but even he enjoyed the pictures and hugged it to himself, saying "Heron birds!!!" (he is a grandson of two birders, haha)  The goal of the author is to encourage young people to get out in nature and explore for themselves. With a book like this as a jumping off place, how could they fail to want to see birds in real life?  I was there in that chat room, and along with many who bonded over the birds, am part of a group on facebook. None of us remembers  the author there, but while we were chatting away, she must have been frantically sketching at home, with little time to join our chatting. The spirit that imbues this book will bring you joy, knowledge, and a little bit of the experience we all shared watching Fiver grow up.  Thank you, Thank you, Anita Schmidt-Kyanka for this gorgeous labor of love.  Some parents may hesitate to buy this book because it may seem a steep price for a paperback. But the original artwork and the jam-packed pages of information are truly worth the cost. This is well written and well done.

I really love these pink sterling silver CZ earrings. They actually perfectly match a pink  CZ necklace I bought in 2005. I had matching earrings then but lost them. I have hunted all this time for just the right match in sterling silver and took a chance on these. They are exactly the color I needed. This alone would have been amazing enough. However, these earrings come prettily packed in a little gift box inside an organdy bag. If you were giving these as a little gift, it would look much more expensive than the price you paid.

I sent this as a get-well gift after a friend came home from the hospital. His doctor told him to eat healthy things for his heart. He and his wife wrote me to say that the fruit was really delicious and they truly enjoyed it. They said it was packed nicely. So I'm giving this five stars because when I spoke to my friend on the phone I could tell in his voice that he was pleased with this and he repeated what was said in the card they mailed me.UPDATE: December 2014. I ordered one of these for myself! My friends were correct on all counts. The fruit is wonderful! The packaging is perfect. The little wicker plate comes inside a fruit-decorated cardboard box that is attractive.The fruit not only was delicious, it was prettily displayed. This does make a great gift. Glad I checked!

This faucet caught my eye with its good looks. I really like the shape of the faucet and the fact that it has porcelain handles. I just had a bathroom remodeled. The contractor likes this faucet, too. He says it was easy to install and easy to adjust. What I love about it is that the faucet is up and over the sink. There is ample room to wash your hands without bumping into the sink. When I can, I will post a picture of it. You'll see why I think it's beautiful. But more than that, it's practical. The Brushed finish is easy to clean and doesn't gather fingerprints. The handles feel good and work great. The drain works easily and simply. The instructions that came with it were clear. However, the plumber didn't need them. He said this faucet was simple to install. He liked it because it is sturdy. It's a heavy faucet. I like it because it is beautiful. I bought this faucet a year ago and have used it for a year and it still looks great and works perfectly.

This is a wonderful, large-print word find book. I got it for a gift for a nursing home resident who loves these kinds of puzzles. I was so happy to find it in a large-print version. The type font is clear and the puzzles are challenging without being simplistic. In short, this book is for adults who love word puzzles. While it helps the eyesight, it won't insult one's intelligence. Good job. Love this.

It's a Catch-22 situation. I am giving these things five stars because we needed replacements and lo, there they are, for sale. They fit the cups we bought them for--and they suit their purpose perfectly. However, we have to lodge our complaint that these cups should need replacements in the first place. These valves collect dirt, and sometimes black mold if you don't wash them separately from the cup, and even if you put them in the dishwasher on sterilization mode. I have used little bottle brushes, pipe cleaners, and sprayed them with vinegar or hydrogen peroxide in order to clean them. I finally tossed them and bought these new ones. I called the company to tell them that their valves get moldy over time and they sent me two new ones for free. I guess the message is---replace when necessary. It's cheaper than buying new cups.

I really love this clock. it is heavy, and won't get knocked off a table or mantle easily. It tells time accurately. The one thing I dislike about it is that the alarm hand is so large, it is easily mistaken for the second hand. We got the clock because we needed one in the living room, so we aren't going to be using the alarm. If I could, I would rip that stupid arm right off. However, restraining my self from clock disfiguration, I decided to live with this flaw instead of returning the clock. This clock has a traditional look to it, which is why I picked it. It looks good on our mantel, and it is easily read from across the room. Another plus is that this is battery operated, and you can tell time during a power outage, assuming you have a flashlight. We felt this was a decent clock for the price, having looked at many.

We've had this lunch kit for a while and I have to say it still looks like new. Jeremiah took it to his play group over the summer and it survived. We've also used it for packing snacks, to keep them cold during warm weather. So this got practically daily use in the hot weather. It is easy to clean. I just dunked the whole thing in warm, soapy water and hung it up to dry. Came out sparkling. The Thomas image has stayed bright and nothing on this has cracked or disappointed my little Thomas fan. We really love this lunch kit. In fact, Grandpa coveted it because he is a grown-up Thomas fan.

I love this magazine because there are so many recipes even I, with multiple food allergies, can be inspired. Each issue has seasonal recipes and ideas. The pictures are stunning. Just looking at it on Kindle makes your mouth water. That's another thing I like about the Kindle format: you can enlarge the pictures. Another plus is that if you want to keep the issues, you aren't stacking them up in a corner to collect dust. You can keep it on Kindle or the Cloud and always have recipe magazines to flip through for inspiration. The recipes are neither trendy nor traditional, but a really great blend of the two...and there is not a single issue in which I have not found at least a couple of recipes I consider keepers.

This was a Kindle freebie, one I deleted after owning it a whole ten minutes. I should have checked the reviews for this one. First, if you are in the US, this won't help much. It should be more clearly labeled that it is mainly for folks in the UK. Second, there is hardly any information in it. It is just 64 pages. As such, it seems to be a teaser of some kind for other books. In short, it's a free infomercial, and after reading this simplistic little tome, I have to say, no. Or maybe that should be a NO. There was nothing in it for me of any help whatsoever. Now, I am person who has had a few kitchen table businesses of my own. There was the few years I put myself through college by selling stained glass windows I crafted and sold at flea markets. There were the home made earrings I sold for a few seasons for extra money. I do home canning in a big way and have considered selling my jams and jellies. Hence, I got this book thinking it would push me from thinking about it to doing it. Nope. Not helpful. Delete. Delete....

This was a Kindle freebie for me and I skimmed through it, then immediately deleted it. Although it could be a good primer for someone trying to figure out if they want to try food drying or canning, it really is not useful to an experienced canner or to a person who has already experimented with food drying. Without recipes, this is just advice. It is not a how-to. It's half a how-to without the recipes. I rated it OK because I do believe that any publication that promotes home food preservation in a sensible and safe way deserves at least that. I have been canning for nearly 30 years and this book is not as useful to me as a book that contains new ideas and recipes. If you are a novice canner and interested in food drying as well, you should get yourself the Ball Blue Book and start from there. If you want recipes, skip this book.

This game entertains everyone in the family from the two year old to the grandma. Everyone loves it. It is challenging at the higher levels. The only problem we had is that it stopped responding and we had to delete it and download it again a couple of times. Otherwise, we love it.  Addendum: I have since discovered that when this game stops responding, it will work again and keep all of your levels if you simply re-boot the Kindle. Wish I had known this sooner. I hope they can fix this glitch.

I like this game for my two-year old grandson. He loves it, of course. It makes cute popping sounds and some of the balloons have animal features, which seem to delight him. I would have rated this five stars, but it really does nothing more than allow the player to pop the balloons. Period. That's it. Even my grandson seemed to want more. However, he does enjoy playing this for brief periods, and when he asks for it, I let him give it a go. It's kind of fun, a little addicting, and those adults who can't resist bubble wrap might even find they secretly like this giggly version with sound effects!

It's hard to beat a Peterson's guide. I particularly  appreciate this one because there are not a lot of publications about moths out there. This one comes complete with wonderful photographs, and all the information you need to identify moths. It's confusing at times, because so many moths look alike, but with this guide, I was able to sort out several species I was unable to without it. Like the bird books, this guide has information about range, but also includes information about host plants, or what kind of environment in which the particular moth could be found. Mothing is not the most popular hobby, but serious moth-ers put out lights and sheets and then photograph their moths to create their "collection" rather than kill the creatures they want to identify. This information is also covered in the guide, which was, frankly, a revelation to me. I love this guide because it opens up a whole world of moths I never really thought about until a facebook friend began posting beautiful moth pictures. I'm hooked now. This guide is just the beginning, I'm sure.

I bought this mower new from WalMart. It was a bit over $300 and has the American made engine.I have used this mower this Summer with no problems.It has the easy-starting motor. It almost always starts on first pull, very rarely have I had to pull it over twice.The drive speed is adjustable, sort of. There is not much you can do by way of adjusting the speed. This is fine as it works well and I regulate speed by how hard I squeeze the speed control lever.An added bonus with this model is the attachment on top of the deck where you can hook up a garden hose and wash the deck. Simply attach the hose, turn on the water and start the engine.I haven't used the bagger or discharge chute as I use the mower to mulch when I mow. It does a good job.This mower has enough power and hasn't bogged down in moderately tall grass.Assembly was very simple. This mower weighs less than a Craftsman self-propelled that I used.The only caveat and it is minor.....why is it that Briggs & Stratton doesn't provide the oil capacity in the owner's manual? They have the graph for oil recommendation by temperature and how to change the oil but there is no mention of the oil capacity for the engine. Seems like an important omission or oversight to me.I did find the oil capacity (18 oz) online at a Briggs & Stratton website after some searching.Overall I am very happy with this mower and would not hesitate to buy another one.

I bought this gelpad to replace a cheap foam one that fell apart.I currently use a Fellowes paper shredder so being familiar with the brand helped in choosing this wrist pad.This mouse pad is exactly what is pictured in the listing.It looks to be very durable and it is no-slip.I really like it. The mouse area is the right size for what I need. Not too small but not so large to make the unit bulky.Most of all it is comfortable for my wrist.I recommend this gel wrist pad.

I bought this cable on Amazon mostly because it was much cheaper here than other online sites that I found.I am very happy with the cable, it works on my new computer and appears to be a quality item.It was an excellent buy and I would look here first if I needed another one.

I bought the lifetime license from an Amazon Marketplace seller. Downloaded and installed the program and registered it.The price for a lifetime license was cheap and I was surprised that it was still available.This program runs well on Windows 8.1. It updates regularly and the scan is fast.Malwarebytes Anti-Malware has a reputation for being effective against malware and I like the real-time monitor.It's compatible with Kaspersky Internet Security and I would definitely recommend this program.

I bought this camera as a close-out at a local chain store. I got a decent soft case and USB transfer cord in a bundle.The things that I like the most about this camera are the quality of the photos and ease of use.The camera itself is very easy to shoot photos with and uploading photos with Canon software is easy on Windows 7.I use this camera quite a bit for posting sale items online. It's a real asset! I always get at least one clear photo out of each batch.Close-ups look great also.This model has been one of the better digital cameras that I have owned and I definitely recommend it!

I bought one of these locks in red from a local store.It came with the combination on a paper on the back of the lock.The big problem is that the combination works sometimes and sometimes it doesn't. I expected a lot better from Master Lock. This is going back where I bought it!

I bought this job-site radio hoping it would be small enough to fit in my locker at work. The older Milwaukee job-site radio(Rockford-Fosgate powered) that I have is bigger and heavier.Well this radio doesn't fit in my locker without marring it up. So much for that idea!What I have found while using this radio at work has been positive in many respects.First the size. This radio is compact compared to my older one(Milwaukee 49-24-0200). It's also surprisingly light in weight.  So toting it in and out of work is easier.The sound quality. This radio is rated roughly 5 watts lower than the other Milwaukee that I own.That's not a negative as the sound clarity with this radio is better in my opinion.I use job-site radios with an mp3 player as an auxiliary device. This radio works well for that. And it is loud enough to hear on the factory floor that I work on.A bonus is the compartment on top of the radio for storing and plugging in an auxiliary device. It's convenient and it is sealed. Nice touch!There is already an auxiliary line to plug in the mp3 player and a phone or mp3 charger plugin.EQ and display..The EQ is pretty basic. You can adjust the level for Treble and Bass. Nothing fancy but it works.The display is powered by two AA batteries and it is a bright red that is easy to see. The batteries also power the memory for preset stations.I can't address the battery power for this radio as I only use it by plugging it in to an outlet. I don't need batteries or a charger.It seems durable and there are plenty of handles on the top, bottom, and sides.I paid $10 more for this new radio at a local store than I did for the older, used Rockford-Fosgate model. From looking around at prices these radios seem to be cheaper, particularly if you don't need a battery charger or extra on-board outlets.This Milwaukee radio has met my expectations for performance and I would buy one again if this radio got stolen.

This watch winder is just what I was looking for in this price range ($39.99). I wasn't willing to spend a lot of money on a winder.I like the spring-loaded watch holder. It makes this winder adjustable and my Invicta automatic watch fits.This winder has to lay flat (the strap should be on top) and the watch holder has to be far enough in to click into place.The indicator light and motion have worked well for me.It's worth the convenience of not having to wind an automatic watch that is too nice to wear to work.

This antivirus always has fared well in the detection and real-world tests that I watch. Most notably av-comparatives.Kaspersky doesn't slow down either start up or browsing. The updater is dependable and the program is configurable for those users like me that prefer to tweak some settings.I just set it up and run a manual scan periodically.For the price I can't see trying another antivirus program again in the future. This is the program that I keep coming back to after finding others disappointing.

This is a very nice screen protector! It comes with the prep kit and clear instructions.Installing the Tech Armor screen protector was very easy. The only part that was a bit tricky was lining up the protector with the screen.The box contained alocohol wipes for cleaning the screen (after removing the old protector).Then there is a microfiber cloth and dust removal tabs.You peel off the coating and that side goes down. If you have the protector lined up it almost adheres itself! There is a bubble removal tool included if you need it.I am impressed with the ease of installation and the fact that this screen protector has no bubbles under it.Another thing I like is the clarity. This protector is very clear!Add the warranty on top of that and this screen protector is a no-brainer!I definitely recommend the Tech Armor Premium Ballistic Glass Screen Protector.

This is the first Spigen product I have bought.It fits my Samsung Galaxy S5 very well and it was simple to install.The back is clear and it does come with peel-off plastic on both sides of the back.With as thick and rubbery as the cover feels you would expect to have issues with the buttons on each side. This case doesn't interfere with either button or the charging port. Very well designed in my opinion! And I like the texture of the case for grip.The phone is recessed enough on the front to protect it from dropping on it's face. Feels very secure and durable!I have dropped my phone, it bounced on a corner and did no damage!I would definitely recommend this case!

Eleuthero is an adaptogenic herb. One of the claimed benefits is that it helps deal with stress mentally and physically.From my experience it does help on both counts and with no side effects. I notice that working long hours and stress aren't as draining as they were prior to my taking Eleuthero. I only take one 500mg cap daily.After trying a number of adaptogenic herbs I found that there is no universal, magic herb. Some herbs that get excellent reviews on various sites didn't work for me. This is one that has been beneficial for me personally.I have a lot of confidence in the NOW Foods brand for quality and price.

I downloaded this song because of Eric Clapton's involvement in it.Tracy Chapman's trademark voice on this song was a given. I heard it enough to know the vocals were great.Eric Clapton's collaboration on this tune is an improvement over the original in my opinion. The guitar work is excellent and this duo sounds excellent together!

I started taking this to aid in recovering from my workouts.I don't feel as sore after my workouts now. I take the recommended three caps before bed with water.NOW Foods is a brand I trust and ZMA does what it advertises for me.

I bought a Saddlemen Profiler seat to replace the uncomfortable stock seat on my 2012 VStar 950.This seat fit well and switching seats was very easy. The instructions were clear and helpful.The Profiler is much more comfortable. It's not broke in yet, but I can already notice the improvement. The old seat was uncomfortable and hourly stops were necessary.The appearance of this seat is better than the original with the separate pillion in my opinion. Just looks nicer.I bought it on sale and that makes it even better!I have owned Saddlemen motorcycle seats in the past and they always were quality seats, this one looks to be exactly what I expected.

I bought this motorcycle jacket to replace an old fringed leather motorcycle jacket.I wanted a jacket with plenty of secure pockets with snaps or zippers. This jacket has plenty of pockets inside and out!Other features I like about this particular jacket:Leather laces for adjustment on lower sides.Convenient zippered vents on chest and two on the back for air flow.All pockets are either zipped or snapped with a button.Quality leather. It should last for years with regular conditioning.It's warm and it fits well. I ordered one size larger than I normally do and that worked for sizing.The zippers are YKK. These zippers are heavy duty!I really like what I got for the price with this jacket!In addition to this jacket, I recently bought an armored textile fabric motorcycle jacket made by XElement. I'm happy with that also so I like the brand and the price range for their jackets.

This windshield replaces an older National Cycle model that was 3 inches shorter. The additional 3 inches in height are an improvement.I installed the Street Shield EX on a 2012 VStar 950.It does fit but.... The instructions are next to worthless! Hence the 1 star deduction on an otherwise excellent product.This shield differs from the Deflector screen in that besides being taller, the Street Shield EX has 4 mounting points instead of 2.The handlebar mounts are the same. What is different is that hose clamps are used to mount the bottom of the screen to the top of the forks. Makes for a stable windshield.This screen is also easy to detach quickly.I normally avoid any tinted screens or shields. Surprisingly, I like the tinting a lot! It does not effect visibility much at all.Installation would have been much easier and less time-consuming with better instructions.I found that I needed to tweak or adjust the windshield a few times to get it where it should be. That is an easy task with an open-end wrench and the Allen wrench that was provided.Overall I would buy it again. Just beware that if you don't have experience installing these types of screens the instructions will be of little help.

I bought this jacket directly from LeatherUp's website.I wasn't sure about the arms fitting, they are angled. They do fit well even for my long arms. The arms have zippers on the end as well as a velcro cuff.After reading a number of suggestions on ordering one size larger I did just that that. Rather than order a Large as I normally do, I ordered an XL and it fits perfectly! Another tip on sizing...do a Google search for "XElement jacket sizing" and you should find a helpful link to a usbikerrescue site that has a size chart by chest size.I really can't find a personal complaint with this jacket.There is a lot to like and these are just a few:Zippered vents on arms, back, and chest for air flow on hot days.All pockets have either zippers or snaps, that's inside and the two outside pockets. There is also a handy cell-phone pocket on the inside. No shortage of pockets for storage!Zip-out liner.It has velcro loop adjustments for fit on each lower side.This jacket looks like it will be durable and it looks well-made.What this jacket isn't is a cold-weather motorcycle jacket. If it's Spring and the 50s you will feel the chill. It's made for warm to hot weather.The zippers are not the YKK heavy duty metal zippers. They work well enough but I thought I would mention that because XElement does use that brand of zipper on a lot of their motorcycle jackets.This is also a textile material as opposed to mesh. I prefer this to the mesh jacket I wore previously.

I bought this product from Swanson's as they always have a good quality product at a competitive price.For me a half cap works better than the full 100mg. The full cap would work well as a sleep aid. Half a cap takes off any edge for me. I take this with GABA and feel it works very well for mood support.The only change for me regarding this product is that I will order the 50mg in the future.

I have been taking this product for 4 months and I have noticed it has been beneficial for me.There have been no side-effects and I only take one of the 500 mgs capsules daily.The key to GABA from what I have read, is taking it with B6 so that it crosses the blood-brain barrier. The accuracy of that I don't know as I have always bought GABA products that include B6.Does it work? Everyone is different, but for me personally, I have felt more calm even on very stressful days. Another positive effect I notice is that I have pumped up some from my Bowflex workouts. That's something I didn't notice before taking GABA.What I appreciate the most is that GABA is natural. NOW Foods has always been trustworthy and priced competitively in my experience. That's why I ordered more of this product and plan on continuing to take it daily.

This Wahl trimmer set replaces a Norelco rechargeable trimmer set.All of the attachments are included and they even have a small bottle of oil.The larger trimmer has more power than I expected.The nose and ear hair trimmer does a very good job! A lot better than any other trimmer that I have owned.I like that the small trimmer is separate rather than being another attachment. It seems that the Norelco attachment used more energy so having a separate trimmer makes sense to me.Another thing I like about these Wahl trimmers is the ergonomics- not heavy, the switch is on the side and it just feels comfortable in my hand when I trim my mustache. The design is well done.I recommend this Wahl trimmer and the price is very reasonable.

I bought the silver GoGear Ariaz as an upgrade in MP3 players. I use this player mostly at work. It is plugged into a Milwaukee jobsite radio via the auxiliary jack. What triggered me changing was the short battery life and long charge time of my used Sony Walkman.I like this player better than any other mp3 player that I have used.Some of the features that impress me are:* The battery. I use the Ariaz up to 32 hours playtime and still have juice left. It charges a lot faster than I expected. A matter of a few hours at most when it drops to 1/4 charge.* Sound Quality. I prefer the sound clarity of the GoGear to others I've used. There are a lot of EQ settings to use and there is a custom EQ I can tweak. Full Sound is a nice sound also.* Ease of Use. This player is easy to use with a little practice. It did take me a while to find my playlists. Once you figure out how to get to the Folders it's a breeze to use those. The buttons are laid out nice and convenient.* Computer Compatibility. I use Windows 7 to load music or edit files. I have loaded songs, deleted songs, edited info on music files, and created playlists by hooking this player up though a USB port. Very simple. Drag and Drop comes in handy. The Walkman may be easier for creating playlists, deleting songs etc.. as it can do that on the player. I still prefer the Ariaz because of it's versatility when using Windows Media Player.* The Screen. Another nice feature is the screen. Aside from it's size, the Ariaz screen also shows the information about the song that I like to have displayed- Artist(or contributing artists), album cover, album name, and genre.I have found that mp3 players are not an end-all for every song or genre. Most songs sound great through the Milwaukee radio without the punch or bass EQ activated while others sound better with punch activated. I think this player sounds better for the choices in music that I listen to at work. Everything from classic country(Haggard,Cash) to blues(Bonamassa,Clapton) and hard rock.I don't normally change the EQ from custom and it seems to sound good.I really enjoy this player and if I ever lost it I would definitely buy another of this model. The battery life and charge time alone have been a big improvement for me.

I bought this hard shell case for a Philips GoGear mp3 player.While this case is a little wide for my mp3 player I found it works good when I put the player in sideways under the elastic strap.The net storage side works great for the mp3 jack.I also used this case for my Samsung Galaxy S5 cell phone and it fit perfectly.I like the hard shell protection and I would definitely buy it again.

This song was a pleasant surprise! I have liked Mick Taylor's guitar style dating back to his time with The Rolling Stones. He has a blues style that I like almost as much as his solo on the extended version of "Can't You Hear Me Knocking". Carla Olson's vocals really work well on the tune.This is an excellent blues song and a dynamic collaboration.I'm glad I found it and enjoy listening to it. Nice price also.

I bought this electric knife sharpener for my longer blade jack knives.I like that it has angle adjustments that are simple to change.I haven't tried the first stage(coarse) stone but the other two stage stones work well.The longer blades that I sharpened were surprisingly sharp. I was impressed.The only down side is that this sharpener doesn't work well for the small blades, like the shorter jack knife blades.Overall I would buy this electric sharpener again and I would recommend it.

I bought the New Jerusalem Bible after reading the reviews.One thing I was unsure of was buying a Bible that was "gender inclusive."To date, I haven't found that to be an issue for me. I rarely see it in the text.I have had the original Jerusalem Bible(1966) for quite a few years and I really like that version.In comparing the two, the new version is not as thick and the text looks to be the same size.This is a revised Jerusalem Bible and in comparing various passages of Scripture this Bible fares well.A few examples that I look at:+ I Samuel 6:19 renders the number of those struck as 70. Some Bibles have 50,000 or 50,070.+ Revelation 22:19 has "tree of life" where some have "book of life."+ Matthew 6:13 has "and do not put us to the test" rather than "lead us not into temptation."+ I Timothy 5:17 has "double reward" rather than "double pay."+ I John 5:7 doesn't include the "Erasmus Addition."- Another verse that has different renderings is Mark 10:25. Some use "large rope" where this version uses the common "camel."Those are some of my personal observations of verses that are commonly translated differently.In the Preface the editor states that when a choice had to made, "fidelity to the text" was preferred over "literary quality."For modern English versions of Scripture this one reads as well as any of the others that I have used.I personally prefer a good "study" Bible. This book fits that bill superbly!Like the original, this newer version is loaded with footnotes that are keyed to the chapter. That is especially helpful when there is a difference between source texts. I like to know the differences whether they are used or not.The paragraphs have captions which is also helpful. Particularly for navigating.There are Scriptural cross-references in the outer margins.There are lengthy, educational Introductions at the beginning of each section."Yahweh" is used in the Old Testament.I Like The New Jerusalem Bible a lot. Slightly better than the original.There does not appear to be any doctrinal bias.This has become my daily reader and a favorite.

I bought a used Sony Walkman to play at work through a stereo.I wanted something a little bigger in size than the Sansa Clip +.The pros on this MP3 player are:+ Easy to transfer music files from desktop to player. I use Windows Media Player.+ The eq options are versatile. You have enough choices to form the sound to a degree.+ There is plenty of room for storage. I have over 725 songs loaded currently and still have a lot of room!+ Sound quality is very good.+ There are capabilities for both bookmarking and playlists. And using that feature is incredibly simple!+ Shuffle works well.The only real negative for me has been battery life and charging.Playtime is nowhere near the advertised length. I get 20 hours on a full charge. Getting a full charge takes much more time than expected. Plugging into the wall takes over 12 hours(closer to 18) when the battery is below 50%.I suspect a weak, old battery. Like most mp3 players that are portable, this Walkman has an internal battery which is not removable.That's the only gripe I have and that may be an inherited problem from buying a used device.For sound quality and features I like this player.
