This 1964 movie, directed by Russ Meyer, would get a PG rating today, since there's no nudity or profanity.  Filmed in Berlin, this black-and-white film is set in 18th century London.  Fanny Hill is played by Letícia Román.  She is very pretty, but doesn't measure up to the super-stacked women who usually appear in Russ Meyer movies.  Young, nave, and penniless, Fanny fortunately finds work as a chambermaid in a bordello, run by the madam Mrs. Brown (Miriam Hopkins).  Of course, Fanny doesn't realize that the place is a bordello.  Later in the movie, she meets Charles (Ulli Lommel), who is also a virgin.  The two fall in love and, after a series of mishaps, end up getting married at the end of the movie.  Russ Meyer is out of his element in this costume comedy, which includes slapstick humor, silly music, and overacting.

This 1970 movie was co-written, produced, and directed by the legendary Russ Meyer. Harry (Charles Napier) is a small town sheriff. He lives with his girlfriend Cherry (Linda Ashton), who works as a nurse. Harry's associate Enrique (Bert Santos) is sleeping with his girlfriend Raquel (Larissa Ely), who works as a prostitute. Harry and Enrique are in the employ of the old, corrupt Mr. Franklin (Frank Bolger). They illegally divert marijuana over the border, and split the profits. Mr. Franklin informs Harry that another associate named Apache (John Milo) has gone into business for himself, and must be killed. Apache avoids the ambush Harry and Enrique had set up for him. Later, Apache steals Harry's jeep, then runs over and kills Enrique. When Raquel arrives at the hospital where Mr. Franklin is staying to sexually service him, she finds that he has been killed by Apache. Raquel stays in the hospital, recovering from the shock of finding Mr. Franklin dead. Her nurse Cherry takes care of her, which includes having sex with her. Harry: "I don't like women messing around with women. It's un-American." Uschi Digard, as a supporting character named Soul, runs around naked in various settings, without advancing the plot. Looking at Uschi when she was in her prime is worth the price of the movie.  As for the movie's characters, the narrator accurately states that they're "superficial in their makeup, but so necessary to our way of life."

This 1970 movie was co-written, produced, and directed by the legendary Russ Meyer.  Harry (Charles Napier) is a small town sheriff.  He lives with his girlfriend Cherry (Linda Ashton), who works as a nurse.  Harry's associate Enrique (Bert Santos) is sleeping with his girlfriend Raquel (Larissa Ely), who works as a prostitute.  Harry and Enrique are in the employ of the old, corrupt Mr. Franklin (Frank Bolger).  They illegally divert marijuana over the border, and split the profits.  Mr. Franklin informs Harry that another associate named Apache (John Milo) has gone into business for himself, and must be killed.  Apache avoids the ambush Harry and Enrique had set up for him.  Later, Apache steals Harry's jeep, then runs over and kills Enrique.  When Raquel arrives at the hospital where Mr. Franklin is staying to sexually service him, she finds that he has been killed by Apache.  Raquel stays in the hospital, recovering from the shock of finding Mr. Franklin dead.  Her nurse Cherry takes care of her, which includes having sex with her.  Harry: "I don't like women messing around with women. It's un-American." Uschi Digard, as a supporting character named Soul, runs around naked in various settings, without advancing the plot.  Looking at Uschi when she was in her prime is worth the price of the video.  As it states on the cover, the video is of mint quality, made from the original negative.  The movie's vibrant colors attest to that fact.  As for the movie's characters, the narrator accurately states that they're "superficial in their makeup, but so necessary to our way of life."

Dan Curtis' production of "Frankenstein" was an episode on "The Wide World Of Mystery" TV anthology series, and originally aired on January 16, 1973.  In 1985, Elvira hosted a direct-to-video series called "Thriller Video."  In addition to episodes of the 1980 "Hammer House Of Horror" TV series from England, it also featured Dan Curtis' productions of "Frankenstein," "Dracula," "The Strange Case Of Dr. Jekyll And Mr. Hyde," "The Picture Of Dorian Gray," and "Turn Of The Screw."  This 130-minute production is a low budget, faithful adaptation of the classic Frankenstein story.  Robert Foxworth stars as Dr. Victor Frankenstein, Susan Strasberg plays his love interest Elizabeth Lavenza, and Bo Svenson plays his creation, referred to in the credits as the Giant.  In fact, the good doctor initially calls his creation a giant baby, who has to be taught to walk and talk.  When he first comes to life, Bo looks like a dazed stoner dude who was in a bad car accident, with his face all scarred up.  In addition to looking human, he speaks quite well, which sets him apart from previous Frankenstein creations.In one scene, Bo wants a young boy to keep quiet, so he puts his giant hand over the boy's mouth.  Sadly, the young boy dies as a result.  Later, Bo asks Dr. Frankenstein to create a woman for him.  During the creation process, Dr. Frankenstein gives her too much electricity, intentionally killing her.  Bo swears revenge, and does end up killing Elizabeth.  Near the end, while Dr. Frankenstein is trying to shoot and kill his creation, he falls and impales himself on a metal rod.  As Dr. Frankenstein lies dying, Bo cradles him in his arms.  Crying, Bo expresses remorse for accidentally killing the young boy, and for murdering Elizabeth.  A couple of men keep shooting Bo until he dies, still holding the lifeless Dr. Frankenstein in his arms.  This production of "Frankenstein" was well-intentioned but overly long, and boring in spots.  Its bleak tone did not fit all that well with Elvira's humorous remarks and outgoing personality.

In 1980, the anthology series "Hammer House Of Horror" was broadcast in England. The "Visitor From The Grave" episode originally aired on November 22, 1980.  In 1985, Elvira hosted a direct-to-video series called "Thriller Video," which features episodes of that series.  In this episode, Penny (Kathryn Leigh Scott) is the wealthy, live-in girlfriend of Harry Wells (Simon MacCorkindale).  She is mentally unbalanced, and had been institutionalized.  While Harry is away, Charlie (Stanley Lebor) breaks into their house.  He starts attacking Penny, and she shoots him with a shotgun.  When Harry arrives home and discovers what happened, he doesn't suggest calling the police.  Harry has Penny burn the bed clothes and clean the blood stains from the floor, while he buries Charlie's body in the nearby woods.  Then Harry drives Charlie's car into the lake.  Later, Penny thinks she sees Charlie at a party, and then driving around town.  Penny goes to a fortune teller named Margaret (Mia Nadasi) to help her stop having visions of the dead man.  Margaret can't help her, but suggests contacting Swami Gupta Krishna (Gareth Thomas).  To entice the Swami to come from India to England, Penny gives him $150,000, which the Swami needs to set up shop in England.  Later, Swami Gupta, Margaret the fortune teller, and Penny hold a séance to contact Charlie, while Harry looks on in disbelief.  Charlie's disembodied head appears, declaring that he wants revenge.  Penny admits that she killed Charlie, then runs out of the room.SPOLIER ALERT: A combination of taking too many pills, and having a guilty conscience, causes Penny to take the shotgun and shoot herself.  As Penny's dead body is taken to the hospital, Swami Gupta, Margaret the fortune teller, and happy Harry celebrate with champagne.  It was all a scam they planned to swindle Penny out of $150,000.  No sooner do they take a sip, then the ghost of Penny appears before them, declaring that she wants revenge.  The pile of money on the table catches fire, and burns up.  As Elvira said after the episode ended, she should have waited until they put the money in their pockets, then set it on fire.  In my opinion, this is one of the best episodes in the "Hammer House Of Horror" series.

In 1980, the anthology series "Hammer House Of Horror" was broadcast in England. "The House That Bled To Death" episode originally aired on October 11, 1980.  In 1985, Elvira hosted a direct-to-video series called "Thriller Video," which features episodes of that series.  In this episode, William Peters (Nicholas Ball), his common-law wife Emma (Rachel Davies), and their daughter Sophia (Emma Ridley), move into an old house that needs a lot of fixing up.  Years before in that same house, a husband poisoned his wife.  He hacked up her dead body with a curved sword, and then buried her under the floorboards.  Almost immediately after they move in, bad things start to happen to the young couple and their daughter.  Their pet cat is found dead, its throat cut by sharp glass on a broken window.  They find a severed hand in the refrigerator.  At Sophia's birthday party, someone gives her a curved sword for a birthday gift.  Later, a water pipe near the ceiling breaks, spewing blood all over the children eating birthday cake and ice cream.SPOILER ALERT: It turns out that Andrew James Powers (Milton Johns), the real estate agent that sold the couple the house, along with William and Emma, caused all of the supposedly paranormal activity that occurred in the house.  A.J. Powers wrote a book called "The House That Bled To Death," and it became a bestseller.  William and Emma get a million dollars for the movie rights, and move to a mansion in California.  Unfortunately for them, their daughter Sophia spoils their happy ending, which I won't spoil by saying how.  Personally, I found this to be one of the weaker episodes in the "Hammer House Of Horror" series.

In 1980, the anthology series "Hammer House Of Horror" was broadcast in England.  The "Guardian Of The Abyss" episode originally aired on November 15, 1980.  In 1985, Elvira hosted a direct-to-video series called "Thriller Video," which features episodes of that series.  In this episode, a woman buys a small, antique mirror at an auction.  Her friend Michael Roberts (Ray Lonnen) decides to get it appraised before she sells it.  As he's driving along, he encounters Allison Lussan (Rosalyn Landor), who has just escaped from the Corinson occult society.  They're a cult of devil worshippers who wanted to sacrifice her, as part of a ceremony to summon Corinson, a demonic figure who guards the gates of Hell.  It turns out that the antique mirror is really a scrying glass, which is needed for the summoning ceremony.  Michael takes Allison home, and gets intimately involved with her, which turns out to be a big mistake.  Charles Randolph (John Carson), the cult leader, uses hypnotism, and a form of voodoo, to get Allison back to the cult.  Michael finds out where the cult's headquarters are located, and drives like a maniac to get there.  When he arrives there, the cult members take him instead of Allison, to become the human sacrifice in the summoning ceremony.SPOILER ALERT: The summoning ceremony works, and Michael becomes possessed by the evil spirit of Corinson.  Allison happily stands by his side, as his devilish bride.  As Elvira mentions after the episode is over, what happened to the happy ending?  In this story, evil triumphs over good.  Unpleasant dreams!

I only bought this movie because the late, great Ed Wood appears in it.  There's lots of nudity and simulated sex in this softcore movie.  George Stone (Victor Rich) is a middle-aged business executive who goes to swinging parties.  His wife Martha (Karen Johnson) wants George to take her to one of those orgies/parties.  To give you an idea of how good their acting is, this is the only movie that Victor Rich and Karen Johnson ever appeared in.  About half an hour into the film, at the party, an obviously drunk Ed Wood appears in a bedroom with a parrot.  Ed starts taking off his clothes, and starts putting on pantyhose, then a bra.  The movie keeps cutting back and forth between Ed and the party, so the viewer won't have to take in that sight all at once.  At one point, a woman walks in, looks astonished, then walks out.  Later, a man walks in, and poor Ed looks ashamed to be wearing a bra and pantyhose.  The man tells him that it's all right, he looks nice, and to keep putting on women's clothing.  "I'm game for anything, after all that booze," Ed blurts out.  Whatever they paid Ed to appear in this movie wasn't enough.  Looking drunk, disoriented, disheveled, pale and bloated, Ed the transvestite was a very sorry sight to see.  As for Mr. and Mrs. Stone, they learned the error of their ways.  At the end of the movie, they decide to stop going to swinging parties, and start a family.  Thankfully, there was no sequel to "The Sensuous Wife" called "The Sensuous Mother."

This album was released in December of 1967.  It's an album of cover versions, without any original instrumentals written by Bob Bogle, Nokie Edwards, or Don Wilson.  It starts out with the Ventures version of "What Now My Love," which is similar to the version done by Herb Alpert and the Tijuana Brass.  "To Sir, With Love" and "Sunny," with an organ backing the guitars and drums, are among the better instrumentals.  My favorite songs on the album are the rocking "Music To Watch Girls By," and the funky (by Ventures standards) "Uptight (Everything's Alright)."  "Windy," a big hit for the Association, is another highlight of this album.  The last song is the Ventures version of the Beatles classic "Yesterday."  It's given a tasteful arrangement that features acoustic guitars, piano, harpsichord, and drums.  It's a good album, but not among the Ventures very best.

This album was released in February of 1966.  It starts out with the song "Action," which was a big hit for Freddy "Boom Boom" Cannon a year earlier.  In keeping with the album's theme, it also includes the instrumentals "Stop Action," "Action Plus," and "Little Bit Of Action."  Their rocking version of the standard "A Taste Of Honey" is similar to the version done by Herb Alpert and the Tijuana Brass.  "Nutty," also known as "Nut Rocker," is my favorite instrumental in this album.  My least favorite instrumental, "No Matter What Shape (Your Stomach's In)," was originally done by the obscure instrumental group the T-Bones.  It was also used in a commercial for Alka-Seltzer, which may explain why I'm not crazy about that song.  This very good but somewhat uneven album peaked at #33 in Billboard's album chart.

This album was released in January of 1963.  The album starts out strongly, with a great version of the classic instrumental "Telstar."  "Apache" is one of the best instrumentals the Ventures ever recorded, and would be right at home on any of their many greatest hits collections.  Part of the album has a Latin flavor to it, with the songs "The Lonely Bull," "Mexico," and "Calcutta."  In addition to "Telstar," the instrumentals "Green Onions," "Red River Rock," and "Last Night" feature an organ.  Obviously, the instrumental "Let There Be Drums" features the late, great drummer Mel Taylor at his best.  The eclectic nature of the songs covered, plus the addition of an organ to supplement the guitars and drums, makes this a very versatile Ventures album.  In fact, this was the Ventures highest charting album, peaking at #8 on Billboard's album chart.  Over fifty years later, the timeless songs still sound great.

The album "Twist With The Ventures" was released in 1961, the same year that Chubby Checker had a #1 hit with "The Twist," and a #8 hit with "Let's Twist Again."  The Ventures' versions of both of those songs appear on this album.  The album starts out strong with the rocking song "Driving Guitars (Ventures Twist)," which was written by Bob Bogle, Nokie Edwards, and Don Wilson.  It's one of the best original songs they ever wrote, and rightfully appears on the 29-song "Walk Don't Run: The Best Of The Ventures" collection.  In keeping with the twist theme, this album also includes the rocking tunes "Guitar Twist," "Opus Twist," and the classic "Bumble Bee Twist."  Starting out with a rocking drum solo, "Moon Dawg" would be right at home on a surf instrumental album.  "Movin' And Groovin'," written by Duane Eddy and Lee Hazlewood, is another highlight in a solid album that doesn't have a weak tune.  I would never classify the eclectic Ventures as a dance band, even though their next album, released in May of 1962, was "The Ventures' Twist Party, Vol. 2."  On the other hand, both albums are guaranteed to get partygoers dancing!

Elvis Presley was inducted into the Army and, on September 22, 1958, sailed to Germany. Comprised of previous recordings, "For LP Fans Only" was released on February 6, 1959, while Elvis was still serving in the Army.  It included four classic songs that Elvis recorded at Sun Studios in 1954: "That's All Right," "Mystery Train," "I'm Left, You're Right, She's Gone," and "You're A Heartbreaker."  The song "I Don't Care If The Sun Don't Shine," also recorded at Sun Studios, is included as a bonus track.  The remaining songs, recorded in 1956, include "Playing For Keeps" (#21 in 1957), "Poor Boy" (#24 in 1957), "Lawdy, Miss Clawdy," "My Baby Left Me," "I Was The One," and "Shake, Rattle And Roll."  The song "Let Me," taken from the 1956 "Love Me Tender" EP (Extended Play), is included as a bonus track.  Even though the songs were assembled from various recording sessions over a two-year period, thus combining early Elvis with Elvis in his prime, the resulting album works very well as a whole.  With Private Presley overseas, "For LP Fans Only" managed to reach #19 on Billboard's album chart.  Over 50 years later, the songs still sound great.

Dave Myers and the Surftones released the album "Hangin' Twenty!" on Del-Fi Records in 1963.  All twelve of the songs from that album are included in this collection, plus two bonus tracks from the 1963 "KFWB's Battle of the Surfing Bands!" album; "Driftin'" and "White Water."  Dave Myers was a multi-instrumentalist who played electric guitar, steel guitar, tenor saxophone, trumpet, and bongos.  Their best known song is the classic "Moment Of Truth," which appears on Rhino's "Cowabunga! The Surf Box Set."  Another great instrumental is "Suferama," with the saxophone playing the lead melody.  The surf standard "Church Key" begins with a saxophone solo, before launching into the familiar melody.  "Smokey Stomper" is a rocked-up version of "On Top Of Old Smokey" that's guaranteed to get your toes tapping.  "Aquavelva" sounds otherworldly, with an icy reverb lead guitar.  That song would be right at home on "The Ventures In Space" album.  "Surf Breaker" rocks along like a giant wave crashing on shore, while "Surfer's Theme" slows the pace down.  Though not very well known, Dave Myers and the Surftones were one of the better sixties surf instrumental groups.  It's too bad they didn't last long enough to release a second album of surf instrumentals.

From 1959 to 1965, Chubby Checker had 22 top 40 songs.  Keep in mind that "The Twist" peaked at #1 in 1960, was released again a year later, and went all the way to #1 in 1961.  This 32-song collection starts out with the classic hit "Let's Twist Again" (#8 in 1961).  Chubby Checker recorded a novelty song in which he imitated Fats Domino, the Coasters, Elvis Presley, and the Chipmunks, singing portions of the song "Mary Had A Little Lamb." The single was called "The Class," and it peaked at #38 in 1959.  That song is included in this collection.  Also included are the top 10 songs "Pony Time" (#1 in 1961), "The Fly" (#7 in 1961), and "Popeye The Hitchhiker" (#10 in 1962).  In keeping with the twist theme, this collection also includes the songs "Twist And Shout," "Mister Twister," "Dear Lady Twist," and "Love Is Like A Twist."  In addition, this collection has seventeen songs that were previously unreleased on CD before, including "Quarter To Three," "Bristol Stomp," and "Hello Baby Goodbye" (with Dee Dee Sharp).  Detailed liner notes would have been a welcome addition.  Considering how long it took for a legitimate collection of Chubby Checker's original hits to be released on CD, I'm not going to complain about that.  Chubby Checker's remaining top 40 hits not included in this collection, including the original version of "The Twist," are included in Volume 1.

From 1959 to 1965, Chubby Checker had 22 top 40 songs.  Keep in mind that "The Twist" peaked at #1 in 1960, was released again a year later, and went all the way to #1 in 1961.  This 31-song collection starts out with "The Twist," and also includes the top 10 songs "Slow Twistin'" (#3 in 1962), and "Limbo Rock" (#2 in 1962).  In keeping with the twist theme, this collection also includes the songs "Twist It Up" (#25 in 1963), "Twistin'," "Twistin' USA," "Twistin' Around The World," "Twist Along," "Don't Knock The Twist," "The Lose Your Inhibitions Twist," and "Teach Me To Twist" (with Bobby Rydell).  This collection also includes the rare version of "Let's Twist Again" sung in German!  That's one of the sixteen songs that were previously unreleased on CD, according to the back of the cover page.  Detailed liner notes would have been a welcome addition.  Considering how long it took for a legitimate collection of Chubby Checker's original hits to be released on CD, I'm not going to complain about that.  Chubby Checker's remaining top 40 hits not included in this collection, including the original version of "Let's Twist Again," are included in Volume 2.

This is the only time that the Ventures, the ultimate instrumental group, recorded an album with a singer.  Bobby Vee is a very good, accomplished vocalist.  On this 1963 album, Bobby Vee and the Ventures sound like they had been recording and touring together for years.  Their collaboration truly brought out the best in each other.  I'd like to give a brief description of each song in this excellent album."Goodnight Irene" - It's a rocking version of the old standard, with a great Bobby Vee vocal."Walk Right Back" - This was a hit song for the Everly Brothers.  The only thing missing with Bobby Vee's vocal is another singer to harmonize with."Linda Lu" - This is a rocking tune with a strong Bobby Vee vocal."Caravan" - This is a classic Ventures instrumental; the guitar playing and drum solo are incredible!"What Else Is New" - This is a pleasant pop song, written by Bobby Vee, with a pleasant Bobby Vee vocal."Candy Man" - This was a hit song for Roy Orbison.  Bobby Vee does a rocking vocal that would do Roy proud."This Is Where Friendship Ends" - This song was written by Tom Leslie and Bobby Vee.  Some of the melody is reminiscent of "My Bonnie Lies Over The Ocean."  The Ventures rock out in support of Bobby Vee's vocals."Honeycomb" - This was a hit song for Jimmie Rodgers, which Bobby Vee handles well."Pretty Girls Everywhere" - This rocking song, with a strong lead vocal by Bobby Vee, sounds like it came from an Elvis Presley movie."Wild Night" - This is a rocking Ventures instrumental, written by Bob Bogle, Nokie Edwards, and Don Wilson."I'm Gonna Sit Right Down And Write Myself A Letter" - It's a rocking version of another old standard, with another great Bobby Vee vocal."If I'm Right On Wrong" - The Ventures rock out on this song, with Bobby Vee doing a Buddy Holly style vocal.  It closes out the album on a strong note.

This 12-song album starts out with the instrumental "The Brass Are Comin'," which uncharacteristically features a banjo.  "Good Morning Mr. Sunshine," and "Robbers And Cops," have memorable melodies.  The haunting ballad "I'll Be Back" is very moving, and a highlight of the album.  "Moon River" starts out with an arrangement that sounds like Nelson Riddle on a Frank Sinatra album, then segues into a classic Tijuana Brass arrangement.  The best song on the album is "The Maltese Melody."  It's a catchy, up-tempo tune, and was included in the 1987 collection, "Herb Alpert and the Tijuana Brass Classics, Volume 1."  The familiar song "Sunny" starts slowly, with a brief Herb Alpert vocal, then segues into a fast instrumental for the rest of the song.  "I'm An Old Cowhand" is almost done as a novelty song, with the brass sounding at times like the moo of a cow!  The love song "You Are My Life," which closes out the album, features a vocal by Herb Alpert, backed by more strings than brass.  Overall, this is a pleasant album, but not among Herb Alpert's best.  The album peaked at #30 in Billboard's album chart, and marked the end of an era.  After "The Brass Are Comin'" was released, Herb Alpert disbanded the Tijuana Brass.  The 1971 album "Summertime" was credited to Herb Alpert only.

Dion DiMucci's first recordings were as the lead singer of the doo-wop group the Belmonts, whose members included Angelo D'Aleo, Fred Milano, and Carlo Mastrangelo.  All the big hits Dion and the Belmonts had are included; "I Wonder Why" (#22 in 1958), "No One Knows" (#19 in 1958), "A Teenager In Love" (#5 in 1959), and "Where Or When" (#3 in 1960).  By 1960, Dion went solo, and the hits kept coming with "Lonely Teenager" (#12 in 1960), "Runaround Sue" (#1 in 1961), "The Wanderer" (#2 in 1961), "Lovers Who Wander" (#3 in 1962), "Little Diane" (#8 in 1962), "Love Came To Me" (#10 in 1962), "Ruby Baby" (#2 in 1963), "Donna The Prima Donna" (#6 in 1963), and "Drip Drop" (#6 in 1963).  Like his contemporary Bobby Darin, Dion went from recording doo-wop and pop songs to recording folk songs.  Dion's last big hit was "Abraham, Martin and John" (#4 in 1968).  It's great to have one collection that includes all of Dion's hit songs from 1958 to 1968, which includes his work on both Laurie Records and Columbia Records.  It's also a treat that the last song on this collection, "Heart Of Saturday Night," was taken from Dion's 1978 album "Return Of The Wanderer."  After listening to this collection, it's no wonder that Dion DiMucci was elected to the Rock And Roll Hall of Fame in 1989.

Ace Records began in England around 1978.  They quickly established a reputation for remastering songs from the original tapes, to get the best possible sound on CD.  In addition, every CD they released includes exhaustive, informative liner notes.  The "Dion Hits: 18 Original Hit Recordings By Dion & The Belmonts 1958-1963" collection definitely adheres to that tradition.  Dion DiMucci's first recordings were as the lead singer of the doo-wop group the Belmonts, whose members included Angelo D'Aleo, Fred Milano, and Carlo Mastrangelo.  All the big hits Dion and the Belmonts originally had on Laurie Records are included; "I Wonder Why" (#22 in 1958), "No One Knows" (#19 in 1958), "A Teenager In Love" (#5 in 1959), and "Where Or When" (#3 in 1960).  By 1960, Dion went solo, but remained on Laurie Records.  The hits kept coming with "Lonely Teenager" (#12 in 1960), "Runaround Sue" (#1 in 1961), "The Wanderer" (#2 in 1961), "Lovers Who Wander" (#3 in 1962), "Little Diane" (#8 in 1962), and "Love Came To Me" (#10 in 1962).  The hit songs, along with essential album tracks like "When You Wish Upon A Star" and "Born To Cry," have aged very well.  They never sounded better than they do on this collection.  After listening to this collection, it's no wonder that Dion DiMucci was elected to the Rock And Roll Hall of Fame in 1989.

Gary Puckett possesses one of the greatest singing voices I've ever heard. Gary Puckett and the Union Gap achieved commercial and critical success with their first three albums, all of which were released in 1968. Their fourth album, released in 1969, only reached #50 in Billboard's album chart, despite featuring the hit song "This Girl Is A Woman Now" (#9 in 1969). In 1971, the Union Gap split up, and Gary Puckett released his first solo album. The power ballad "Gentle Woman," written by Gary Puckett and Michael Rhodes, starts the album out on a strong note. If it had been included on an earlier Gary Puckett and the Union Gap album, it could have been a big hit. The best songs on this album are Gary's cover versions of "I Just Don't Know What To Do With Myself" (written by Hal David and Burt Bacharach), "Keep The Customer Satisfied" (written by Paul Simon), and "Delta Lady" (written by Leon Russell). Inexplicably, despite distinctive vocals and strong arrangements, the album was a commercial failure. Gary Puckett was never able to duplicate the success he had with the Union Gap, and I still can't understand why.

Gary Puckett possesses one of the greatest singing voices I've ever heard. Gary Puckett and the Union Gap achieved commercial and critical success with their first three albums, all of which were released in 1968. In addition to producing those three albums, Jerry Fuller wrote several of their hit songs. For various reasons, Jerry Fuller and Gary Puckett parted ways after 1968. "The New Gary Puckett & The Union Gap Album" was released in 1969, and produced by Dick Glasser. It featured the hit songs "This Girl Is A Woman Now" (#9 in 1969), and "Don't Give In To Him" (#15 in 1969). Another outstanding song is "My Son," written by the Union Gap's bassist Kerry Chater and keyboardist Gary Withem. It begins with a proud papa welcoming his son into the world, and ends with his son's tragic loss, having been killed in action in Viet Nam. Even with two hit songs, the album only reached #50 in Billboard's album chart. The band's 1970 single "Let's Give Adam And Eve Another Chance" stalled at #41 in the charts. In 1971, the Union Gap split up, and Gary Puckett continued with a solo career. Unfortunately, Gary Puckett never had another hit song. The four albums he recorded with the Union Gap have aged well, and are excellent examples of what I describe as pop perfection.

Gary Puckett possesses one of the greatest singing voices I've ever heard. Gary's vocals and song selection make him a cross between Tom Jones and Roy Orbison. Gary Puckett and the Union Gap achieved commercial and critical success with their first two albums, both of which were released in 1968. Incredibly, their third album, entitled "Incredible," was released in late 1968. It peaked at #20 in Billboard's album chart. The album was produced by Jerry Fuller, and featured the #2 hit "Lady Willpower" (written by Jerry Fuller), the #7 hit "Over You" (written by Jerry Fuller), and the song "Give In" (written by Jerry Fuller). Prophetically, the last song on the album, written by Jerry Fuller, was entitled "I've Done All I Can." Gary Puckett and the Union Gap wanted to write and produce their own songs. After this album was released, Jerry Fuller never worked with Gary Puckett again.

Gary Puckett possesses one of the greatest singing voices I've ever heard. CBS producer Jerry Fuller signed Gary Puckett and the Union Gap to a recording contract in 1967. The band included bassist Kerry Chater, keyboardist Gary Withem, saxophonist Dwight Bement, and drummer Paul Wheatbread. Their first single, "Woman, Woman," reached #4 in 1967. It was featured on their 1968 debut album, which was produced by Jerry Fuller. The album also included the song "Paindrops," written by Jerry Fuller. Gary Puckett's distinctive voice dominated the album, which included cover versions of "By The Time I Get To Phoenix" (written by Jimmy Webb), "You Better Sit Down Kids" (written by Sonny Bono), "Kentucky Woman" (written by Neil Diamond), and "To Love Somebody" (written by Barry Gibb and Robin Gibb). With all of the great albums released in the sixties, Gary Puckett and the Union Gap's debut album should not be overlooked.

Gary Puckett possesses one of the greatest singing voices I've ever heard. Gary's vocals and song selection make him a cross between Tom Jones and Roy Orbison. Gary Puckett and the Union Gap achieved commercial and critical success with the release of their debut album in early 1968. Later that same year, they released their second album. The album peaked at #21 in Billboard's album chart. Despite its somewhat controversial nature, a memorable melody and great vocal propelled the single "Young Girl" all the way to #2 in the charts. In addition to producing their first two albums, Jerry Fuller wrote the song "Young Girl." The album also included three songs written by Jerry Fuller and Gary Puckett; "I'm Losing You," "The Pleasure Of You," and "Say You Don't Need Me." The two best and boldest choices for cover songs are their versions of "Lady Madonna" (written by John Lennon and Paul McCartney), and "The Mighty Quinn" (written by Bob Dylan). There was no sophomore slump for Gary Puckett and the Union Gap on this album, even though it was released quickly, to capitalize on the success of the hit single "Young Girl."

Gary Puckett possesses one of the greatest singing voices I've ever heard. Gary Puckett and the Union Gap achieved commercial and critical success with their first three albums, all of which were released in 1968.  Their fourth album, released in 1969, only reached #50 in Billboard's album chart, despite featuring the hit song "This Girl Is A Woman Now" (#9 in 1969).  In 1971, the Union Gap split up, and Gary Puckett released his first solo album.  The power ballad "Gentle Woman," written by Gary Puckett and Michael Rhodes, starts the album out on a strong note.  If it had been included on an earlier Gary Puckett and the Union Gap album, it could have been a big hit.  The best songs on this album are Gary's cover versions of "I Just Don't Know What To Do With Myself" (written by Hal David and Burt Bacharach), "Keep The Customer Satisfied" (written by Paul Simon), and "Delta Lady" (written by Leon Russell).  Inexplicably, despite distinctive vocals and strong arrangements, the album was a commercial failure.  Gary Puckett was never able to duplicate the success he had with the Union Gap, and I still can't understand why.
